Title: Federal Judge Orders Hillary Clinton to Answer Written Questions About Email Server Use

Article:

A federal judge has ruled that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton must answer written questions from the conservative legal group Judicial Watch regarding her use of a private email server while in office. The ruling comes as part of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit that Judicial Watch is pursuing against the State Department.

Judge Emmet Sullivan wrote that Judicial Watch has failed to demonstrate that it cannot obtain the discovery it seeks through other means, such as interrogatories. He gave the group until October 14 to provide Clinton with the questions, and she has 30 days to answer them.

Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton stated, "We will move quickly to get these answers. The decision is a reminder that Hillary Clinton is not above the law."

Last month, after completing his investigation of Clinton's private server, FBI Director James Comey recommended no charges against Clinton for mishandling classified information, despite reprimanding her for being "extremely careless" in using a private server.

Judicial Watch, which has pursued Clinton and her husband in court for years, insists she has never answered why a private server was used in the first place. Last week, Judicial Watch released 44 previously undisclosed Clinton email exchanges that she failed to include among 30,000 private messages she turned over to the government last year.

These email exchanges cover Clinton's first three months as secretary of state in early 2009, a period for which Clinton did not turn over any emails to the State Department last year. The government found the newly disclosed messages during a search of agency computer files from her top aide, Huma Abedin.

While Judicial Watch argued that only Clinton could testify about the reasons behind her decision to set up a private server, the judge said it is possible for Clinton to offer her "unique, first-hand knowledge" of the basis for the server in writing.

"Judicial Watch's argument that a deposition is preferable in this case because of the ability to ask follow-up questions is not persuasive," the judge wrote. "Given the extensive public record related to the clintonemail.com system, a record which Judicial Watch has acknowledged, Judicial Watch will be able to anticipate many follow-up questions."

Title: Vatican-Reviewed Journal Criticizes Evangelical and Catholic Allies of President Trump for "Theocratic" Worldview and "Apocalyptic Geopolitics"

Article:

A recent article in the Vatican-reviewed journal La Civiltà Cattolica has criticized evangelical and Catholic allies of President Donald Trump for promoting a "theocratic" worldview and practicing "apocalyptic geopolitics." The article, authored by two confidants of Pope Francis, accused these voters of coming together over a "xenophobic and Islamophobic vision that wants walls and purifying deportations."

The authors of the article, who are close to Pope Francis, wrote that the "panorama of threats to their understanding of the American way of life have included modernist spirits, the black civil rights movement, the hippy movement, communism, feminist movements, and so on." They further stated, "And now in our day there are the migrants and the Muslims."

Specifically mentioned in the article was Trump's top White House strategist Steve Bannon, who the authors said wants a country where citizens submit to the Bible, which they called an idea "that is no different from the one that inspires Islamic fundamentalism."

The authors contrasted Trump supporters' visions with that of Pope Francis, who they praised for spreading a peaceful worldview. "Francis is carrying forward a systematic counter-narration with respect to the narrative of fear," the two wrote. "Francis is courageous here and gives no theological-political legitimacy to terrorists, avoiding any reduction of Islam to Islamic terrorism," they continued. "Nor does he give it to those who postulate and want a 'holy war' or to build barrier-fences crowned with barbed wire."

The "barrier-fence" reference seems a clear swipe at another Trump proposal to build a wall on the border with Mexico. Trump met with Pope Francis in May at the Vatican, where he presented Francis with first-edition copies of books written by Martin Luther King Jr. In February, Francis famously criticized Trump, appearing to say Trump was not a Christian due to his stance on the proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border. "To not respond to evil with evil. To defeat evil with good, the offense with forgiveness. A Christian would never say ‘ you will pay for that. ’ Never," Francis said in February. "That is not a Christian gesture," he added. "An offense you overcome with forgiveness. To live in peace with everyone."

Title: Pope Francis Named Time Magazine's Person of the Year: A Look at His Impact on the Church and the World

Article:

Pope Francis, whose real name is Jorge Mario Bergoglio, has been named Time Magazine's Person of the Year, further highlighting his significant impact on the Catholic Church and the world in a short span of nine months.

One of the iconic moments of Francis' historic papacy was when a boy walked onto the stage where he was speaking, hugged the pope, inspected his pectoral cross, and sat on the papal throne. This incident, among others, reveals the genuine character of Francis, who wants his church to serve, not strut.

Francis' public gestures, such as kissing disfigured visitors, lofting newborns, and washing the feet of prisoners, may have been staged, but they demonstrate the pope's desire for the church to focus on service rather than self-aggrandizement.

The pope's concern for the poor, a key aspect of his papacy given his Latin American origin, has been a source of misunderstanding. In his first solo papal exhortation, Evangelii Gaudium, Francis was quoted as criticizing capitalist economies. However, a closer reading reveals that his complaint is about the pursuit of wealth as a competing religion, a sentiment that many parents would likely share.

Before the exhortation, Francis caused a stir when he acknowledged that the Church, particularly the American Catholic Church, had overemphasized issues like abortion, homosexuality, and the ordination of women priests. This statement was misconstrued as an embrace of gay marriage, abortion on demand, and female priests, but Francis remains opposed to these practices.

Francis' beliefs can be summarized as a call for the church to focus on helping people, to care for the sick, disfigured, and war victims, and to challenge tradition when necessary. He encourages priests and bishops to walk among the people they are supposed to comfort, rather than remaining isolated in their limousines.

Francis' challenge to tradition and the entrenched bureaucracy within the church has been uncomfortable for some, but he has also been praised for speaking to people's better selves and calling them out when they fail to live up to their potential.

In Section 152 of Evangelii Gaudium, Francis recommended that Catholics worldwide, regardless of their wealth, education, or ethnicity, spend more time reading the Bible. It is lesser-known that Francis rises early to spend time alone, reading scripture, which provides the strength for his public persona to challenge tradition and rattle the entrenched bureaucracy around him.

The little girl who marched up to the altar in a parish may have embarrassed her mother, but Francis embodies an example that challenges and inspires. A few minutes of lost sleep, in the presence of divine wisdom, might benefit us all. Time's Person of the Year was probably awake before most of us today. Sleep on that.

Title: U.S. Role in the World Shifts Focus from Military Strength to Economic and Soft Power

Article:

The first round of questions during Monday night's foreign policy debate between President Obama and former Gov. Mitt Romney is expected to focus on America's role in the world. The candidates' answers are likely to emphasize military readiness and anti-terrorism efforts, given the country's continuous involvement in overseas combat since the terrorist attacks of 2001.

However, the U.S. role in the world encompasses more than just military might. Leadership is also defined by economic power and "soft" power, which refers to a country's ability to attract and persuade people to adopt its values, according to Joseph Nye, a Harvard professor.

In the early 1990s, Nye's book "Bound to Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power" sparked discussions about the need to further develop economic and soft power. The ideas gained traction as the Berlin Wall came down in 1989, and many Americans were eager to explore new ways to lead in a post-Cold War era.

After the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, the conversation shifted back to military strength, with drones and Humvees seeming more important than the attractive powers of Hollywood movies or mobile phones.

Now, with the Iraq War over and U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan winding down, Nye suggests the focus may be shifting back to economic and cultural leadership. "In the 21st century, the Iraq War caused a big drop in American soft power," Nye said. This was due to many people in other countries viewing the United States as being too aggressive.

Furthermore, the U.S. economic power declined after the 2008 subprime mortgage crisis. Before the financial crisis, "there was the idea that Americans really knew how to run an economic system," Nye said. After the crisis, that idea was no longer as prevalent.

However, the wheel is turning again, as both China and Europe are struggling with economic growth. "If you compare us with Europe's economic system, we're doing pretty well," Nye said. "The dollar is still the safe haven."

Moreover, U.S. college campuses are bolstering American soft power. "Most Chinese leaders have a kid at a university in the United States," Nye said. At this point, America is again the soft-power global leader "in everything from Hollywood to Harvard," he added.

Nariman Behravesh, chief economist of the forecasting firm IHS Global Insight and author of "Spin-Free Economics: A No-Nonsense, Nonpartisan Guide to Today's Global Economic Debates," agrees with Nye that U.S. economic and soft power are coming back.

"We still have the largest economy in the world; we are still the No. 1 export destination; we still have lots of innovative companies, like Apple; we have the world's reserve currency; we have a dynamic economy, with oil and gas production increasing," Behravesh said.

"We have a lot going for us," he said. "We've got our problems, but others have problems that are as bad or worse, and I include China in that. They have had a huge deceleration in their growth."

However, going forward, America's role in the world will be largely shaped by how well Congress handles the budget deficit problems in coming months, Behravesh said. As other countries, especially in Europe, grapple with the problem of too much government debt, people around the world are looking to the United States for moral leadership.

If the United States shows that it's possible for democracies to discipline themselves and control their debts, then its economic and soft power may surge, Behravesh said. "We need to tackle our domestic deficit problem," he said. "If we deal with it in a constructive way, people will view us favorably."

Title: RNC Chairman Urges Caution on Immigration Enforcement Discourse, Sparks Controversy

Article:

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus has called for a more measured approach to discussing strict immigration enforcement policies, sparking controversy among outspoken conservatives. At the RNC's annual summer meeting in Boston, Priebus criticized the use of self-deportation policies during the 2016 election season, labeling such rhetoric as "horrific" and harmful to the party.

Priebus's comments have raised questions about the party's stance on immigration enforcement, particularly in light of the ongoing debate over the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. The RNC chair has yet to clarify his position on self-deportation policies, and his remarks have been met with criticism from those who argue that such policies are a humane and reasonable response to illegal immigration.

One family that has been vocal in their opposition to the current immigration system is the Shaw family, whose 17-year-old son, Jamiel, was murdered in 2008 by an illegal alien Mexican gang member. Pedro Espinoza, the perpetrator, was smuggled into the U.S. illegally as a toddler, similar to many of the DREAMers often cited by open-borders advocates.

After Espinoza was released from jail for serving time for assault with a deadly weapon, he was back on the streets and went on to shoot and kill Jamiel execution-style in the head. The federal government failed to deport Espinoza, and local authorities failed to detain him. The Shaw family has since become vocal advocates for repealing sanctuary laws, highlighting lapses in detention and deportation policy, and opposing amnesty proposals.

In response to Priebus's comments at the GOP event, Anita Shaw, Jamiel's mother, tweeted, "How many Americans Have U Talked To Whose Kids were Killed by illegals?" The Shaw family's activism has been met with little recognition from mainstream media outlets, despite their efforts to raise awareness about the dangers of illegal immigration.

Priebus's comments have sparked a broader debate about the role of immigration enforcement in the Republican Party and the party's approach to outreach to minority communities. Some argue that the RNC's focus on minority outreach and diversity should not come at the expense of enforcing immigration laws, while others argue that a more measured approach is necessary to avoid alienating potential voters.

The Shaw family's story is a poignant reminder of the human toll of illegal immigration and the need for a comprehensive solution to the issue. As the debate over immigration policy continues, it is important to remember the real-world consequences of failed enforcement and the need for a system that prioritizes the safety and well-being of all Americans.

Title: CNN Analyst Phil Mudd Warns of Government Actions Against President Trump

Article:

CNN counterterrorism analyst Phil Mudd, a former deputy director to FBI Director Robert Mueller, has warned that the U.S. government may take action against President Trump. During a Thursday interview with CNN anchor Jake Tapper on "The Lead," Mudd stated, "Government is going to kill this guy."

Mudd's statement was in response to Trump's defense of Russian President Vladimir Putin, which, according to Mudd, has led federal employees at the CIA, State Department, and FBI to attempt to undermine Trump. Mudd emphasized his point by referring to the recent FBI raid on the home of former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort.

"What did the Department of Justice say on Paul Manafort?" Mudd asked. "You can say what you want, a judge told us we had cause to search his home early in the morning because we don’t trust the guy who was your campaign manager." He concluded, "The government is going to kill this guy because he does not support them."

Leaks from the White House and the intelligence community have been a regular occurrence since Trump took office. Last week, transcripts of Trump's phone calls with foreign leaders were leaked to The Washington Post, causing concern due to national security implications.

"This is beyond the pale and will have a chilling effect going forward on the ability of the commander in chief to have candid discussions with his counterparts," said Ned Price, a former National Security Council official under former President Obama. "Granted, the White House contributed to this atmosphere by welcoming the free-for-all environment, where anonymous leaks are commonplace. But we must draw the line somewhere."

Mudd also cited Trump's recent announcement of a ban on transgender soldiers in the military as another reason for government opposition. "We saw the same thing in his transgender comments. What is the military saying to him on transgender? 'Show us the policy.' You know what that means inside government? 'Ain’t going to happen,'" Mudd said.

Title: Congressional Spending Bill Includes Various Provisions Affecting Education, Healthcare, and Environmental Regulations

Article:

In a bid to avoid a government shutdown, Democratic and Republican negotiators have unveiled a $1.1 trillion spending bill that includes a range of provisions affecting various sectors, from education to healthcare and environmental regulations.

The bill, which sets the annual budgets for programs ranging from the Justice Department to NASA to the Food and Drug Administration, also serves as a vehicle for numerous provisions that might otherwise be vetoed. These provisions, which touch everything from union pensions to defense procurement, have resulted in one of the most consequential bills to come before Congress this year.

One of the provisions that would bar the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) from regulating methane emissions from livestock production has been included in the bill. Methane, a potent greenhouse gas, is released by livestock in their flatulence, accounting for about 10 percent of U.S. emissions, according to the EPA. On the other hand, any poultry processed in China that might have wound up in school lunches has been banned, with the Agriculture Department being prohibited from using it.

The bill also includes pension-related provisions sought by many unions, running more than 160 pages, thanks to the efforts of retiring Rep. George Miller, a close ally of House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi. Banks have also secured a rollback of a section of the 2010 Dodd-Frank law related to derivatives trading.

The defense industry has secured new funding for F-35s fighters the Pentagon didn't even ask for, while anti-environmental groups have won provisions targeting the administration's climate change policies. States, meanwhile, would have the option to let schools skip out on rules requiring serving whole grains, a blow to the first lady's child nutrition efforts.

The bill's release has sparked controversy, with some lawmakers expressing frustration over the process. Sen. Tom Coburn (R-Okla.) questioned, "Don't you think we ought to be able to read it? Shouldn't we know what we're voting on?"

Despite the inclusion of various goodies, it's still unclear whether lawmakers have the votes to pass the plan. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) has blasted the changes to Dodd-Frank, stating, "We all need to stand and fight this giveaway to the most powerful banks in this country." Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), the top Democrat on the House Budget Committee, has also announced his opposition to the plan due to changes that would allow the wealthy to donate up to $777,600, from the current $97,200, to the national party committees.

The administration, meanwhile, has stated it can abide by the school-lunch changes. Sam Kass, a senior adviser on nutrition, said in a statement, "In light of the effects to roll back school nutrition standards, we consider the minor adjustments to the standards a real win for kids and parents."

Title: Study Warns of Vulnerabilities in U.S. Nuclear Facility Security

Article:

A study commissioned by the Pentagon and conducted by researchers at the University of Texas has raised concerns about the vulnerability of nuclear facilities in the United States to terrorist attacks. The report, released on Thursday, suggests that the theft of enough nuclear material to construct an improvised fission bomb is a real possibility.

The study stands in contrast to the assertions made by the nuclear industry regarding its own security measures. The Nuclear Energy Institute (NEI) claims that following the events of September 11, 2001, the industry undertook a comprehensive reassessment of its plant security and bolstered protections. According to the NEI, a typical plant features a fenced outer security perimeter heavily patrolled, an inner double fence topped with razor wire also heavily patrolled, and a third layer of protection surrounding vital equipment. The containment vessel itself is further protected with multiple layers of steel and concrete.

However, one of the authors of the University of Texas report, Prof. Alan Kuperman, states that a study by the U.S. National Laboratory in 1982 produced different results. He explained that an impact of an airliner would breach the containment, potentially leading to a loss of coolant and, consequently, a meltdown, and a release of major levels of radiation.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) claims that its reactors could withstand such an impact. However, Prof. Kuperman notes that the industry lobbied against requiring such standards. "So on the one hand, the industry says, 'Oh, our facilities can withstand an airplane impact,' but on the other hand, they say, 'no, no no, do not regulate and require us to be able to withstand that impact,'" he said.

The new study acknowledges a history of widely divergent research about the likelihood of a terrorist attack on nuclear facilities. One expert puts the likelihood that a terrorist group will acquire a nuclear weapon at "very substantially less than one in a million," while another researcher "estimates a 50 percent chance of a nuclear terrorist attack on U.S. soil in the next decade."

The report also highlights significant variations in the level of security at different facilities and calls for greater uniformity of security at all nuclear facilities, whether they are power plants, places where nuclear weapons are stored, or where fissile material is stored.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Express Concern Over Funding for President-elect Trump's Agenda Amid National Debt Concerns

Article:

Republican lawmakers have expressed concern over potential obstacles in enacting President-elect Donald Trump's agenda due to the national debt. Trump's proposed $1 trillion infrastructure package, $5 trillion in tax cuts, increased military spending, and the repeal of Obamacare could cost more than $350 billion over 10 years, according to some estimates.

However, Trump has promised not to touch Social Security or make cuts to Medicare. The cost of Trump's plans, combined with the lack of concrete details on how to pay for them, could pose challenges for congressional Republicans, particularly when they are faced with raising the nation's $20 trillion borrowing limit after March.

Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) expressed his concerns, stating, "I was disappointed that it wasn't brought up in the campaign—anybody's campaign really—it really wasn't mentioned. So I'm very concerned about it. It's going to be tough to address if there's no push from outside of Congress."

Conservative groups share these concerns, emphasizing the importance of fiscal restraint as Republicans prepare to control the White House and Congress. Michael Sargent, a research associate at The Heritage Foundation, stated, "We did not hear anything about entitlement reform from either of the candidates, and that's a serious issue. You can't address the growth in spending without addressing entitlement issues."

Compounding the problem is the expected action by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which would increase the cost of the nation's debt. For every quarter point that interest rates rise, the federal government would have to spend an additional $50 billion annually to service the debt, according to Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), a member of the Environment and Public Works Committee, which has jurisdiction over infrastructure.

During the campaign, Trump focused on issues such as immigration, trade, and economic renewal, while discussing infrastructure, immigration reform, and campaign finance reform. The media largely focused on the personal attacks the candidates leveled against each other.

Trump advisers have suggested the new administration will be able to trigger massive private sector investments in infrastructure without a huge increase in spending. They propose federal expenditures in the form of tax credits could be enough to get projects underway.

In the absence of a specific plan, what has garnered more attention is the overall number attached to his infrastructure plan: $1 trillion. Sen. John Boozman (R-Ark.) noted, "Nobody really knows the details. As we talk about them, our conference will be very concerned about how they affect both the debt and the deficit."

Sargent, of the Heritage Foundation, has seen as many as four different iterations of Trump's infrastructure plan, all of which he says would raise the deficit. "I've seen everything ranging from direct stimulus to a $1 trillion in tax credits, both of which would obviously raise the deficit. The tax credits, he claims, would pay for themselves. I do not see that at all. The assumptions that are built into it I think are wildly optimistic," he said.

Lawmakers spent months negotiating ways to pay for a six-year, $300 billion highway bill that passed last year. The lack of concrete details on how to pay for Trump's infrastructure plan has raised concerns among Republicans, who are skeptical that additional infrastructure spending will provide a significant boost to the economy.

Trump could alleviate some of the concerns brewing in the Republican conference by pushing new proposals to curb spending. Already, he has modified his stance on Medicare, adopting language favored by Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) that Democrats interpret as a sign Trump will embrace Ryan's vision for a dramatic overhaul of the entitlement program.

The transition website states the incoming administration will act to "modernize Medicare so that it will be ready for the challenges of the coming retirement of the Baby Boom generation—and beyond." In addition, many Republicans believe that repealing Obamacare will have a positive fiscal impact beyond the 10-year window scored last year by the Congressional Budget Office.

Several Republicans said Trump's plan to replace Obamacare with healthcare reforms could open the door to overhauling Medicaid, which was expanded in 31 states under the healthcare law. "One of the things Donald Trump emphasized in his campaign was the risks of a $20 trillion debt and at the same time he put forth proposals that would increase the debt by another $5 trillion," said Maya MacGuineas, president of Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. "Some changes are definitely going to have to be made. The good news is he's shown a willingness to do that," she added, noting that Trump downsized his tax proposal, which initially stood at $10 trillion.

Boozman expressed hope that Trump will stimulate the economy through regulatory reform, which won't add to the deficit. "The real excitement is in the regulatory phase, getting rid of some of the unnecessary regulation that's really putting a wet blanket on the economy," he said. "That's going to save money."

Title: Former Iowa Governor Tom Vilsack's Tenure at the U.S. Department of Agriculture

Article:

In his final year at the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), former Iowa Governor Tom Vilsack has left a significant mark on the department, particularly in the areas of farm policy, school nutrition, and biofuels.

Vilsack, who once harbored presidential aspirations, saw his 2008 bid for the White House falter, eventually endorsing Hillary Clinton. Despite his efforts to secure Iowa for Clinton, her campaign was overshadowed by Barack Obama's Iowa juggernaut.

One of Vilsack's most notable achievements at the USDA was the negotiation of the 2014 farm bill, a nearly $1 trillion measure that ended four years of partisan fighting over farm subsidies and support for the food stamp program for the poor. He also played a central role in the passage of the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act in 2010. This legislation mandated the use of whole grains, vegetables, and fruits in schools and required students to select at least one portion of fruits or vegetables at every lunch.

Vilsack has also advocated for the use of biofuels. In a recent development, he joined Ray Mabus, the Secretary of the Navy, to fill the guided-missile destroyer William P. Lawrence with biofuel made from beef fat. Vilsack described this as an "extraordinary experience" and an example of the "series of partnerships that has extended the reach of the USDA."

Despite being a low-key, soft-spoken individual, Vilsack's job overseeing the nation's farmers has largely kept him out of the spotlight. However, an early low point in his career came during his second year in the job, when he reacted to a video showing seemingly racist comments from Shirley Sherrod, an Agriculture Department official in Georgia. Vilsack quickly fired Sherrod, but was later forced to publicly apologize when it was revealed that the video had been heavily edited by the operators of a conservative website. The full video showed Sherrod offering a lesson in racial tolerance and compassion.

Title: Three Rays of Hope for Bipartisanship and Compromise in U.S. Politics

Article:

Washington, D.C. - The United States appears to be in a state of deep division and political dysfunction, but journalist Michael Tomasky identifies three potential signs of hope for bipartisanship and compromise in the near future.

First, Tomasky points to a significant demographic shift in the U.S., specifically the growth of the Latino population. This demographic change is transforming the electorate in key presidential states, such as Florida. The state's Latino population is no longer primarily Cuban-American, and the growth of the Puerto Rican population has led to a split between Cubans and Puerto Ricans, with the latter being predominantly Democratic. This shift could make Florida increasingly difficult for Republican presidential candidates to win, potentially forcing the Republican Party to address immigration reform, including a path to citizenship.

Second, the Republican Party is at a crossroads due to Donald Trump's influence. Regardless of whether Trump wins or loses, the party is deeply divided over him. If Trump wins, the divide may continue, but an anti-Trump faction could emerge to oppose his more extreme measures, potentially leading to a more moderate party over time. If Clinton wins, the Republicans would have lost three elections in a row, which historically has led the party to reassess and move toward the center.

Third, Tomasky discusses the filibuster, a Congressional rule that allows a minority of senators to prevent the Senate from passing a piece of legislation. The filibuster has been a significant source of gridlock in Congress, as it requires 60 senators to agree on controversial legislation. Tomasky suggests that the Senate may change its rules in the near future, reducing the number of votes needed or limiting the frequency of filibusters, which would lead to more legislation being passed and increased cooperation between senators from both parties.

Tomasky acknowledges that there are reasons to be skeptical about these three developments, but he believes there is a decent chance they will occur. Even if they do, the political situation will not be perfect, but Tomasky suggests that it will be better, comparing the current state of U.S. politics to an egg that needs to learn to fly.

Title: Senate Reaches Deal to Avert "Nuclear Option" on Filibuster Rules, Allows Nominations to Proceed

Article:

Senators have reached a deal to avoid the "nuclear option" on filibuster rules regarding the confirmation of presidential nominees on Tuesday. Under the agreement, President Barack Obama will withdraw two nominees to the National Labor Relations Board, Sharon Block and Richard Griffin, and replace them with Nancy Schiffer and Kent Hirozawa.

Schiffer is the associate general counsel at the AFL-CIO, while Hirozawa is the chief counsel to NLRB Chairman Mark Gaston Pearce and would be nominated to the seat on the board that expires in 2014. The nominations are expected to move swiftly, as without the two new members, the National Labor Relations Board would cease to function in August.

The agreement allows for votes on the other five nominees to proceed, including Gina McCarthy as EPA administrator and Thomas Perez as Labor secretary. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid stated that these five nominees will receive confirmation votes in the next two weeks.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell commented that the agreement is a step in the right direction, as the majority has chosen not to exercise the nuclear option. Both sides have achieved their desired outcomes: Democrats will have seven of Obama's nominees in place, and Republicans were able to prevent the recess-appointed Block and Griffin from the NLRB. Republicans will still be able to force procedural votes on executive nominees at a 60-vote threshold, and Democrats retain the right to change the rules if necessary.

The agreement was facilitated by the efforts of Sen. John McCain, who was central in crafting the deal, and Democratic sources. Sen. Chuck Schumer stated that the agreement was sparked by McCain's doggedness and Sen. Roger Wicker's request to get all senators in one room together on Monday. The deal was crystallized on Tuesday morning.

In the Senate Democratic caucus after the agreement, Sen. Barbara Mikulski told Democrats not to celebrate excessively, stating, "No gloating, maximum dignity." Sen. Chuck Schumer stated that the nominations will have to go through the committee process but must be in place by the end of August, when the National Labor Relations Board will cease to function without Senate action.

Title: Progressive Push for Equal Rights Amendment Sparks Debate on Gender Equality and Constitutional Change

Article:

As the United States enters a new decade, a resurgence of the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) is underway, with progressives aiming to ratify the constitutional amendment that had previously been considered a dead issue. If successful, the ERA could enshrine left-wing gender dogmas into the highest law of the land.

The ERA's language appears unobjectionable, stating, "Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of sex." However, the amendment's broad language could potentially open the door to various constitutional claims that many Americans reject.

American women currently enjoy unprecedented freedom, prosperity, and opportunities. The Constitution protects their right to speak, worship, vote, bear arms, and more. Women hold the majority of wealth in the country and earn the lion's share of higher degrees. Women also make up the majority of voters in nearly every election.

While sex discrimination is already forbidden under federal and state laws, as well as by the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment, the ERA would not add to these protections but could be used to impose sex-sameness. The amendment's language could potentially be used to force women to be drafted into combat, disallow separate-sex bathrooms, or even pull government funding from women's shelters.

In some states, state-level ERAs have been interpreted as requiring government funding for abortion. The ERA could also threaten laws that don't explicitly distinguish between men and women but provide benefits to stay-at-home wives or young mothers. For example, a non-working spouse's ability to draw on Social Security or even grants encouraging girls' participation in scientific fields could be treated as barriers to "equality."

The meaning of "sex" is far from clear, and in the hands of a liberal judge, the ERA could become another weapon against women-only spaces and religious liberty, if "women" is interpreted to include men who subjectively claim to be female.

While many still view the ERA as a relic of history, the amendment will be a live issue going into 2020. ERA proponents claim that they can combine recent ratifications in Nevada and Illinois with those from the 1970s. If Virginia ratifies the ERA, proponents claim that they only need a bare majority in the House and Senate to undo the 1982 deadline set by Congress.

Courts have ruled that amendments must be ratified in a reasonable time frame, but the 27th amendment was ratified more than two centuries after James Madison proposed it. The unusual process for amending the Constitution, as well as legal questions regarding rescinded or expired ratifications, remain unresolved.

Opponents of the ERA argue that men and women are already equal under American law, but they are not the same. This difference is crucial, and it should be preserved. Inez Stepman, a senior policy analyst at the Independent Women's Forum and a senior contributor to The Federalist, has made this argument. The debate over the ERA is likely to continue into 2020 and beyond.

Title: Former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford Wins Special House Election

Article:

Former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford, who once faced a political downfall due to a personal scandal, has made a remarkable comeback, winning the state's open House seat in a special election held on Tuesday. Sanford captured 54 percent of the vote, compared to his opponent, Elizabeth Colbert Busch's 45 percent.

The South Carolina seat became vacant after Governor Nikki Haley appointed Rep. Tim Scott to the Senate seat previously held by Jim DeMint, who left to join the conservative Heritage Foundation, a Washington-based think tank.

The race between Sanford and Colbert Busch, the sister of TV comedian and political satirist Stephen Colbert, was initially considered a close contest by political analysts. However, Sanford's victory was decisive.

National Republican Congressional Committee Chairman Greg Walden of Oregon viewed the result as a sign of the unpopularity of President Barack Obama and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi among House Democrats in 2014.

"These results demonstrate just how devastating the policies of Barack Obama and Nancy Pelosi are for House Democrats in 2014," Mr. Walden said in a prepared statement. "Democrats spent more than $1 million trying to elect a candidate who was backed by the Democrat machine, but at the end of the day, running on the Obama-Pelosi ticket was just too toxic for Elizabeth Colbert Busch."

Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Chairman Steve Israel, on the other hand, praised Colbert Busch for making the race competitive in a Republican-dominated district, stating it was a "testament to the strength of Elizabeth Colbert Busch as a candidate and the Republican habit of nominating flawed candidates."

Sanford, who has never lost a political race, faced controversy in 2009 when he disappeared, supposedly to "hike the Appalachian Trail," but instead traveled to Argentina to visit his mistress. He completed his second term as governor in early 2011 and kept a low profile until his House campaign this year.

Recent troubles for Sanford included a complaint filed by his ex-wife, Jenny, accusing him of trespassing on her property during the Super Bowl, and the withdrawal of financial support from the National Republican Congressional Committee, the fundraising arm of House Republicans, weeks before the election.

However, Sanford gained momentum in the final days of the campaign with high-profile Republican endorsements, including those from Rep. Tim Scott, Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, and Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, a tea party favorite who is considering a 2016 presidential run.

By Sunday, a poll by Public Policy Polling showed the race as a tossup, with Sanford ahead 47 percent to 46 percent. Two weeks earlier, a PPP survey had Mr. Sanford trailing by 9 percentage points.

Sanford portrayed his opponent as an uncompromising liberal in lockstep with Pelosi and other national Democrats, a damaging charge in the staunchly Republican coastal Carolina district. Colbert Busch countered by positioning herself as an independent voice for the district.

However, political forces may make it difficult for Sanford to repeat his victory in the 2014 election, as he has been shunned by much of the Republican Party establishment since his 2009 scandal. The Republican establishment is expected to support a formidable opponent in the 2014 GOP primary.

"House leaders will isolate him to make it clear he is not in any way a spokesperson for the House GOP," said Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics.

As for the national political implications of Tuesday's special election, many political analysts say it has little significance. "I don't think this one reflects anything. It's all about Mark Sanford," Mr. Sabato said. "Does anyone believe that any other Republican wouldn't be winning this in a landslide? It's a one-party district."

Title: Cable Reveals U.S. Awareness of Benghazi Dangers Before 2012 Attack

Article:

A recently disclosed cable obtained by Fox News indicates that the U.S. Mission in Benghazi held an emergency meeting on Aug. 15, 2012, expressing concerns about the growing presence of al Qaeda and Islamist militias in the city. The cable, marked "SECRET," suggests that the U.S. consulate in Benghazi could not withstand a coordinated attack due to limited manpower, security measures, weapons capabilities, host nation support, and the overall size of the compound.

The cable, addressed to the Office of the Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, also mentions the presence of approximately ten Islamist militias and al Qaeda training camps within Benghazi. The cable further states that the Emergency Action Committee was briefed on these groups, which included the QRF Brigade, Ansar al-Sharia, and "Takfirist thugs."

The details in the cable seem to foreshadow the deadly Sept. 11 attack on the U.S. compound, which was a coordinated, commando-style assault using direct and indirect fire. Al Qaeda in North Africa and Ansar al-Sharia, both mentioned in the cable, have since been implicated in the consulate attack.

The cable also states that the U.S. Mission in Benghazi would submit specific requests for additional physical security upgrades and staffing needs to the U.S. Embassy in Tripoli.

The cable's contents seem to contradict the administration's public statements suggesting that the attack came without warning. The cable provides a direct warning to the State Department that the Benghazi consulate was vulnerable to attack and could not be defended.

In a separate cable on Sept. 11, the day Stevens and the three other Americans were killed, Stevens wrote about "growing problems with security" in Benghazi and "growing frustration" with the security forces and Libyan police. The ambassador saw both as "too weak to keep the country secure."

Title: Protests and Lawsuits Emerge as Nation Faces Economic Impact of Shutdown Measures

Article:

Across the United States, protests and lawsuits are escalating as citizens take to the streets and business owners file legal actions in response to shutdown rules. The prolonged shutdown is causing job losses, bankruptcies, and a growing sense of infringement on individual rights.

The liberal media has labeled the protesters as virus deniers, but the protesters argue they are supported by science, the U.S. Constitution, and common sense. In a statement on Monday, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo acknowledged, "This is not a sustainable situation. Close down everything, close down the economy, lock yourself in the house."

Starting with the science, data shows that almost all coronavirus fatalities are among the elderly and those with serious health problems. In Pennsylvania, 68% of deaths have been nursing-home residents, while in Rhode Island, it's 70%. Shutting down stores and restaurants did not save these high-risk individuals.

A targeted lockdown focusing on protecting the highest-risk group, individuals 65 and over, instead of confining all age groups would slash deaths by half but at only half the economic cost of a total shutdown, according to new National Bureau of Economic Research findings.

Unfortunately, social media platforms are censoring science that challenges the shutdown. YouTube's policy is to ban content that "disputes the efficacy of local health authority recommended guidance."

The shutdown's initial goal was to "flatten the curve," meaning buying time for hospitals to add beds and gather enough ventilators, masks, and other medical equipment. However, experts predict the virus will last another 18 months to two years, fading once most Americans have been exposed and developed immunity.

As Colorado lifted its shutdown last week, the governor explained it's a "balance" between keeping the virus "at a level that won't overwhelm our hospital systems and allowing people to still try and earn a living."

The biggest divide in the country is about who is getting a paycheck. Some government officials, who are paid, show no respect for working people who aren't. For example, Governor Janet Mills of Maine barred hotels from taking reservations for the summer season, and Michigan's Governor Gretchen Whitmer attempted to close grass-mowing businesses, though the virus is seldom transmitted outdoors.

When the shutdown was temporary and tied directly to hospital preparedness, lawsuits challenging it didn't stand a chance. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 1905 that a state "has the right to protect itself against an epidemic" using reasonable regulations.

However, shutdowns lose their reasonableness when they have no deadline or benchmark to meet. Their vagueness tramples on the public's rights, including the right to own property without the government making it worthless.

On Monday, Cuomo outlined a four-phase reopening plan. While not all of the benchmarks are wise, benchmarks pegged to hospital capacity are on the mark. He should also add nursing-home preparedness, as that's where deaths are occurring.

The public should shudder at Mayor Bill de Blasio's vague announcement that the city's reopening is "a few months away at a minimum." This could reduce the city to a wasteland of boarded-up storefronts, abandoned commercial buildings, landlords defaulting on taxes, and soaring tax rates for the taxpayers still in the city.

As for when New York schools reopen, science indicates schools are not a source of transmission. If schools are kept closed in defiance of this fact, say goodbye to the middle class with kids. New York will be for the poor and uber-rich only.

Betsy McCaughey, a former lieutenant governor of New York, is chairwoman of the Committee to Reduce Infection Deaths.

Title: Scotland's Call for Independence and the Global Trend of Secessionism

Article:

In the aftermath of Boris Johnson's "Get Brexit Done" campaign, the United Kingdom is facing a potential secession from the European Union. However, this move could lead to Scotland's secession from the United Kingdom, as warned by Scotland's First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon. Northern Ireland, which voted to remain in the EU in 2016, could also follow Scotland, leaving the UK with "Little England" and Wales.

Johnson's government has stated that they will not allow a second referendum on Scottish independence. However, the Scottish National Party won 48 of Scotland's 59 seats in Parliament, and Sturgeon argues that this is a mandate for a new vote to secede. She stated, "If [Johnson] thinks... saying no is the end of the matter then he is going to find himself completely and utterly wrong... You can not hold Scotland in the union against its will."

The issue of Scotland's potential secession raises questions about the right to self-determination in a democratic nation. If a majority of Scots wish to secede, how can a democratic Great Britain indefinitely deny them this right? Some argue that Scotland could become for Britain what Catalonia is to Spain, a region seeking independence.

The phenomenon of secessionism is not a new one. The most recent population explosion of new nations began three decades ago, when 15 republics of the USSR became independent nations. Since then, several of these new nations have further unraveled, leading to the secession of Transnistria from Moldova, South Ossetia and Abkhazia from Georgia, and the Donbass from Ukraine.

The first great secessionist cause was the American Revolution, when the 13 American colonies declared and won independence from the British crown. The Declaration of Independence, written by Thomas Jefferson, was not as egalitarian as it is often portrayed. Jefferson, a Virginia plantation owner, described Native Americans as "merciless Indian Savages" and referred to the British as "brethren" with whom they shared "ties of a common kindred," but who were "deaf to the voice of consanguinity."

The second secessionist movement in the United States created a second American nation, when Texans under Sam Houston seceded from Mexico. The third secessionist movement united 11 states that sought to create a new confederated nation outside the Union, as the revolutionary generation had created a new nation outside of Britain.

In the 19th century, a dozen new nations were created by Latin American secessionists of the Spanish and Portuguese empires who emulated the example of the Americans of 1776. After 1945, colonies of the British, French, Portuguese, and Belgian empires seceded to produce a baby boom of new nations, most of which receive foreign aid and have seats in the U.N. General Assembly.

If the secessionism epidemic is to someday expire, its causes will have to be addressed. Secessionism appears rooted principally in issues of national identity, such as ethnicity, religion, race, language, culture, and "the mystic chords of memory." These issues of identity appear not to be receding but rising in various regions around the world, including the Caucasus, the Middle East, Africa, and South Asia.

The Kurds, the Palestinians, the Baluch, and many more seek their own nations. Taiwan's secession is not recognized by China, and the secession of Russian-speaking Donbass is not recognized by a U.S.-armed Ukraine or by the international community. As more and more people identify themselves by who they are, and are not, secessions of people from each other will continue.

The potential secession of Scotland and the ongoing secessionist movements around the world highlight the complex and evolving nature of national identity and the right to self-determination. The peace of the 21st century may depend upon our ability to accommodate this inexorable secessionist drive to some degree. In June of 1945, the U.N. had 50 members. It begins 2020 with 193. Last week, Bougainville, a South Pacific island cluster of Papua New Guinea, voted 98% for independence to become the world's newest nation.

Title: FBI Director Christopher Wray Rallies Agents Amid Release of Controversial Memo

Article:

In response to the release of a controversial memo by a Republican-led House committee alleging surveillance abuses by the Justice Department and FBI, FBI Director Christopher Wray sought to rally agents and analysts with a memo of his own.

"Talk is cheap; the work you do is what will endure," FBI Chief Wray wrote in an internal message on Friday. "We speak through our work. One case at a time. One decision at a time."

The release of the memo, which focuses on a 2016 surveillance warrant approved to monitor former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page, has been a subject of controversy. The memo assails the bureau and Justice Department for relying on a dossier prepared by a British intelligence agent whose work was funded in part by Democrats.

President Trump approved the release of the memo, prepared at the direction of House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.), over the objections of Wray and Justice Department leadership. In an unusual statement this week, the FBI issued a public statement expressing "grave concerns" about the accuracy of the memo.

Late Friday, Wray urged the bureau to move on. "We're going to keep doing that work because we know who and what we are and because we know our mission comes first," the director said. "The American people come first."

The House Intelligence Committee voted to release the memo on Monday, and it has since been a topic of debate. The memo's release comes amid an ongoing investigation by Special Counsel Robert Mueller into Russian interference in the 2016 election and potential collusion with the Trump campaign.

The FBI was provided a limited opportunity to review the memo the day before the committee voted to release it, according to the bureau. "As expressed during our initial review, we have grave concerns about material omissions of fact that fundamentally impact the memo’s accuracy," the FBI said earlier this week.

Title: Record Number of Student Loans Utilize Income-Based Repayment Plans

Article:

A record 24.7% of student loans backed by the U.S. government, totaling $452 billion, were enrolled in income-based repayment plans during the fourth-quarter of 2019, according to DBRS Morningstar. This figure represents an increase from 21.8% in the same quarter of the previous year.

The Obama administration expanded income-based repayment options in 2009 for student borrowers in the Federal Family Educational Loan Program (FFELP) following the global financial crisis. The government offered a near 99% backstop on all principal and interest due on loans made under the program. The Obama administration ended FFELP in 2010, effectively cutting out private lenders.

Income-based repayment plans cap loan repayments at 10% to 15% of a qualifying borrower's discretionary income, with any remaining balance forgiven after 20 to 25 years. For lower-income students, this could mean no monthly payments at all, without causing borrower defaults or damaging their credit profile.

The initial expectation was that more than 1.6 million student loan borrowers would see reduced monthly loan payments, although the program does not offer a way for students to refinance debt and lock-in historically low rates.

Since 2011, the popularity of income-based payment options has soared. Meanwhile, addressing the nation's record $1.5 trillion pile of student loan debt has been a hot topic among some Democratic presidential hopefuls. The Trump administration's former top Education Department official, A. Wayne Johnson, called for a cancellation of most of the country's student loans upon his resignation from the department in October.

According to data from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, student debt has become the second-largest source of U.S. household debt behind mortgages. In the first quarter of 2010, the student loan total was only $760 billion, or roughly half its current total.

The New York Fed reported that 11.1% of all student loans were in default or seriously delinquent (more than 90 days past due) during the fourth-quarter. However, it is likely that this figure is actually twice as high, given that roughly half of student loans are in some form of deferment, grace period, or forbearance, and not counted as in "repayment."

DBRS Morningstar expects the combined utilization of deferment, forbearance, and income-based repayment to remain elevated for the foreseeable future.

Title: Virginia Gubernatorial Election: Third-Party Candidate Robert Sarvis Challenges Established Candidates

Article:

On November 5, Virginia will hold its gubernatorial election, with the potential for the game to air on Spike. The state's decision to hold gubernatorial elections in off years, without presidential or congressional races on the ballot, remains unclear.

The latest polls indicate a low level of voter enthusiasm for the two main candidates, Terry McAuliffe and Ken T. Cuccinelli II. McAuliffe, a political fundraiser with no prior elective office experience, is currently under federal investigation and has been involved in controversies regarding his business dealings and residency. Cuccinelli, a homegrown candidate, has faced criticism for his conservative stance on social issues and his monotone speaking style.

A third candidate, Robert Sarvis, offers a different option for voters. Sarvis, a 37-year-old Libertarian, was born in Fairfax and holds degrees from Harvard, the University of Cambridge, NYU, and George Mason University. He left a legal career to found a software development business and has advocated for issues such as gay marriage, marijuana legalization, and personal autonomy.

Sarvis's campaign has gained some traction, with the latest poll putting him at 13%. He has suggested that a vote for a third-party candidate could lead to a landslide victory, as many voters may be voting against the other candidates rather than for them. A Gallup poll in October found that 60% of Americans believe a third major party is needed due to the poor representation of the two major parties.

However, some argue that a vote for a third-party candidate may be considered futile and a waste of a vote, as Cuccinelli is considered the most qualified candidate in the field. The situation in Virginia has been compared to the conclusion reached by the Delta Tau Chi frat leaders in the movie "Animal House," who decided to make a "really futile and stupid gesture" in a do-or-die situation.

Joseph Curl, the editor of the Drudge Report and a former White House and politics reporter for The ███, can be reached at [email protected] and on Twitter @josephcurl.

Title: U.S. Prisoner of War Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Handed Over in Afghanistan in Authentic Video, Pentagon Says

Article:

A video of the handover of American prisoner of war Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in Afghanistan was posted online early Wednesday, showing the moment a Black Hawk helicopter swooped in to pick him up in a valley in Afghanistan's Khost province, near Pakistan. The Pentagon is reviewing the video, with no reason to question its authenticity, according to a spokesman.

The video shows Bergdahl sitting in the back of a pickup truck, wearing white clothing. More than a dozen fighters are positioned around the valley. In the video, the Black Hawk helicopter lands with its side facing the area where Bergdahl and the Taliban fighters wait. As several people come out of the helicopter, the American is led toward them under a white flag.

The exchange is over in seconds, as the participants hold up their hands to one another. The men—three from the helicopter and two from the Taliban force—engage in quick handshakes, then they wave their farewells. The scene was being filmed, with the photographer featuring the figure of Bergdahl and the helicopter.

The exchange of Bergdahl for five Taliban prisoners held in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, has sparked a series of questions, ranging from the circumstances of the soldier's capture in Afghanistan to the legality of the prisoner exchange. Members of Congress say they were not given advance notice of the deal.

President Obama says the White House had spoken "for some time" about a possible prisoner swap for Bergdahl; his administration says it had to act quickly to free him. A congressional hearing on the matter is slated for next week, with more expected to follow.

Yesterday, Secretary of the Army John McHugh said the service is happy to have Bergdahl back. He added that the Army will conduct "a comprehensive, coordinated effort that will include speaking with Sgt. Bergdahl to better learn from him the circumstances of his disappearance and captivity."

Title: High Earners' Response to Tax Hikes: A Look at the U.K. and U.S.

Article:

President Obama has been advocating for an increase in taxes on the highest-earning Americans as part of a solution to the ongoing fiscal crisis. However, history suggests that such tax hikes may not significantly reduce the deficit as expected, and may lead to unintended consequences.

A notable example can be found in then-British Prime Minister Gordon Brown's proposal in April 2010 to increase the marginal tax rate by 10 percent to 50 percent on residents earning over $1 million. This move resulted in a significant decrease in the number of people declaring such income or more, from 16,000 to 6,000 in the 2010-2011 tax year, according to Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs, the United Kingdom's tax collection agency.

Before Brown's proposal, Britain's wealthiest comprised approximately 9 percent of the country's tax pool. This percentage dropped by half—to roughly 4.4 percent—after the proposal. It is believed that wealthy Britons moved abroad or took steps to avoid paying the new levy by reducing their taxable incomes, according to a report in the London Telegraph.

The potential enactment of Obama's tax hike on high earners, raising the marginal rate to 39.6 percent from 35 percent, in exchange for preserving existing Bush-era rates on Americans earning less than $250,000 annually, could have a similar effect.

Daniel J. Mitchell, a fiscal policy expert at the Cato Institute, a Washington-based, libertarian think tank, stated, "Obama's main goal in the fiscal cliff negotiations is to impose a class-warfare tax hike." He further explained, "When you're trying to stick it to the 'rich,' you need to understand that they have tremendous control over the timing, level, and composition of their income. So unlike the rest of us, they can respond very easily when the government goes after them."

One option available to America's high earners to reduce taxable income in the face of any tax increases is to move their wealth into tax-free bonds, according to Mitchell.

However, economist Kent Smetters, an economics and public policy professor at the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, noted that existing tax laws make it difficult for high earners to avoid taxes. "It is very hard to do after the Tax Reform Act of 1986," Smetters told FoxNews.com. "You've basically got to figure out how to either reclassify the income as capital gains (to get a lower tax rate) or classify the money as earned outside of the United States. Both are nearly impossible, usually requiring tax shelters that the Treasury Department can deem as illegal."

Smetters added, "The reason why the rich already pay so much of the U.S. tax base is because they have a hard time avoiding it."

Title: Mother of El Paso Shooting Suspect Contacted Police About Rifle Before Attack

Article:

An attorney for the family of the man charged in the El Paso shootings revealed that the man's mother contacted the police in Allen, Texas, weeks before the rampage, expressing concern about a rifle he owned. The shooting resulted in the deaths of 22 people and left dozens injured after a white gunman targeted a Hispanic area at a Walmart in the border city on Saturday.

Dallas attorney Chris Ayres told The Associated Press that the call was made to the Allen Police Department. Ayres and fellow attorney R. Jack Ayres told CNN that the mother's concern was about an "AK"-type firearm her son owned. On Thursday, Chris Ayres confirmed the report to ███.

The attorneys stated that the mother's call was merely seeking information and was not motivated by a concern that her son was a threat to anyone. They also said the mother did not identify herself or her son in the call.

The lawyers told CNN the mother was concerned about her son's age, maturity level, and lack of experience. However, she was told by a public safety officer that her son, who is 21, was legally allowed to possess the weapon.

A family statement sent by Chris Ayres to ███ stated that the suspected shooter acted outside the family's teachings and values. "He was raised in a family that taught love, kindness, respect, and tolerance – rejecting all forms of racism, prejudice, hatred, and violence," the statement says. "There will never be a moment for the rest of our lives when we will forget each and every victim of this senseless tragedy."

Sgt. Jon Felty, Allen police spokesman, said he could not confirm the call. "I have nothing in the database to support this claim," he told ███ on Thursday.

Patrick Crusius, the suspected shooter, drove 580 miles from Allen to El Paso, which has a high concentration of Latinos, after posting a racist screed online. Authorities said he surrendered to police with his hands up about a quarter-mile from the El Paso Walmart where the attack happened. He faces charges of capital murder in state court and may face federal hate crime charges that could carry a death sentence if he's convicted.

Title: Kuwait Calls for Independent Investigation of Gaza Deaths; US Disagrees

Article:

Kuwait has criticized the United Nations Security Council for not agreeing to its request for an independent investigation into the deaths in Gaza. Ambassador Mansour Ayyad Al-Otaibi suggested that an investigation by the United Nations Human Rights Office may be pursued instead. Diplomats reported that Kuwait had circulated a statement calling for an independent inquiry, which requires unanimous approval, but the United States disagreed.

In response, the United States' Ambassador, Nikki R. Haley, defended Israel, denouncing what she termed as a double standard applied to Israel. She questioned, "Who among us would accept this type of activity on your border?" Haley asserted that no country acted "with more restraint than Israel."

Haley attributed the violence to Hamas, stating that the organization had incited protesters to storm the fence. She maintained that there was no connection between the violence and celebrations on Monday for the opening of the American embassy in Jerusalem.

Nickolay Mladenov, the U.N. special coordinator for Middle East peace, addressed the council, finding fault with both Israel and Hamas. Mladenov stated, "Israel has a responsibility to calibrate its use of force, to not use lethal force, except as a last resort, under imminent threat of death or serious injury." He added that Hamas "must not use the protests as cover to attempt to place bombs at the fence and create provocations; its operatives must not hide among the demonstrators and risk the lives of civilians."

Thousands of Palestinian refugees rallied in southern Lebanon on Tuesday in commemoration of the "Nakba" and in solidarity with the Gaza demonstrations. Many were bused in from the longstanding refugee camps of Lebanon. Palestinians have a complex history with Lebanon. The influx of refugees in 1948 exacerbated Lebanon's delicate sectarian balance, and their presence is often cited as a major contributing factor to Lebanon's 15-year civil war.

Currently, more than 450,000 of the five million registered Palestinian refugees worldwide live in Lebanon. Legally, their rights are limited; Palestinians cannot own property or attend public schools, and are banned from working in more than 30 professions.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Admits Errors in 2016 Election Investigation Procedures

Article:

In a recent interview on Fox News Sunday, former FBI Director James Comey admitted to being "wrong" and "overconfident" about the FBI's procedures during the investigation of the Trump campaign and Russia's meddling in the 2016 election. When asked about the damning report on the FBI's procedures delivered by Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz, Comey stated, "I'm responsible. I was wrong, I was overconfident on our procedures."

During the interview, Comey also said he would say exactly what current FBI Director Christopher Wray has said about the IG report, "We are going to get to the bottom of this." The most important thing, according to Comey, is to determine if the procedural errors are "systemic."

Host Chris Wallace challenged Comey on his previous statement that the unsubstantiated dossier put together by former British spy Christopher Steele, which was used to obtain a FISA warrant to surveil Trump campaign aide Carter Page, was merely part of the reason for the application. In his report, Horowitz called it a "central" component of the application. Comey responded, "I'm not sure [Horowitz] and I are saying different things," adding, "The FBI thought it was a close call... I don't think we're saying different things."

FBI Director Christopher Wray told The Associated Press last week that the report identified problems that are "unacceptable and unrepresentative of who we are as an institution." The FBI is taking more than 40 steps to fix those problems, he said.

In his report, Horowitz rejected claims of vindication that Comey had made in an opinion piece earlier in the week. Comey said Sunday that he simply meant that the report had debunked some of the gravest allegations that Trump and his supporters had made.

Comey also criticized Attorney General William Barr for saying in a separate interview last week that the many errors by the FBI left open the possibility that agents may have acted in bad faith. "The facts just aren't there," Comey said when asked whether Barr has a valid point. "That doesn't make it any less consequential, any less important, but that's an irresponsible statement."

Material from The Associated Press was used in this story.

Title: Obama Administration Mandates Free Contraceptive Coverage for Women, New York Attorney General Proposes Expanded Coverage for Men

Article:

The Obama administration on Monday issued a mandate requiring all health insurers to provide women with free access to a range of contraceptive methods, including intrauterine devices (IUDs), the contraceptive patch, and the contraceptive pill. This move comes in response to reports that some insurance carriers were refusing to cover all types of contraceptives, leaving women to pay out-of-pocket costs.

Under the new rules, insurers must cover at least one brand of contraception in each of 18 different methods outlined by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), such as one type of oral contraceptive pill, one version of the emergency contraceptive morning-after pill, and the vaginal ring. In New York, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman has proposed legislation that would go even further, requiring insurance companies to pay for men's sterilization procedures.

At the federal level, the Health and Human Services Department stated that the move was aimed at clarifying the rules after complaints from women and members of Congress that some insurers were refusing to cover the specific contraceptives their doctors recommended. Insurers can still impose costs to encourage the use of generics rather than brand-name drugs under the new guidance, but if a doctor or hospital recommends a particular drug or contraceptive device out of medical necessity, the plans must cover them without additional cost.

Sen. Patty Murray (D-WA) praised the move, stating, "Today's announcement is an important step toward making it clear that all insurance companies should follow the rules and provide women with the health care they are entitled to." Insurers had sought more specifics about what was required under the Affordable Care Act and its contraceptive coverage provisions, which have been among the most controversial parts of the law.

According to recent studies by the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation and other groups, some insurers were refusing to fully cover all types of contraceptives, meaning women who wanted a particular form of birth control had to pay some or all of the costs. "Insurance companies have been breaking the law, and today, the Obama administration underscored that it will not tolerate these violations," the National Women's Law Center said.

The contraceptive mandate has been controversial from the start, with most attention focused on the marathon court battle between the administration and employers who have religious objections to contraceptives. The Supreme Court last year ruled that closely held corporations do not have to insure types of birth control that violate their moral beliefs, and the Obama administration is expected to update its rules soon. Religious nonprofits are still pursuing their cases through the courts, arguing that the "accommodation" the administration designed for them still leaves them complicit in contraceptive coverage.

The contraception rules were released as part of broader guidance on women's health services, including free screenings for women susceptible to certain types of cancer and no extra charges for anesthesia services provided with preventive colonoscopies. The rewrite will apply to future plan years, with insurers able to argue they were using "good faith" in more narrowly interpreting the current rules.

Meanwhile, New York's top lawman tried to tackle the issue on his own, proposing legislation that would write Obamacare's coverage requirement into state law while piling on extra consumer protections—even for men. Mr. Schneiderman's bill would force every state-regulated health policy to cover all methods of FDA-approved contraceptives at no cost, akin to federal guidance, although consumers could also get a year's worth of contraception at a time. He also proposed that men's sterilization procedures should be covered without cost sharing. "New Yorkers should not be penalized by their insurance companies for using the birth control method that they and their medical provider agree is most appropriate for them," Mr. Schneiderman said.

Title: Trump's Cancellation of Taliban Summit: A Controversial Decision and Its Implications

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to cancel a planned summit with Taliban leaders aimed at finalizing a peace deal for Afghanistan has sparked criticism from some Democrats, who view it as a misstep in foreign policy. However, the underlying reasons for the cancellation and the potential consequences of the peace deal have been a subject of debate.

The cancellation of the summit has led to criticism from some political figures, with Democratic presidential candidate Amy Klobuchar comparing Trump's foreign policy approach to a "game show." However, the decision to cancel the summit has been defended on the grounds that negotiating with the Taliban, a group responsible for the deaths of nearly 2,000 American soldiers and countless Afghan civilians, is a complex and sensitive issue.

The United States' involvement in Afghanistan is not merely a matter of military intervention, but a matter of national security. The Taliban's history of harboring terrorist groups, such as al-Qaeda, before the 9/11 attacks, underscores the importance of ensuring that Afghanistan will not serve as a haven for terrorists in the future.

Furthermore, the United States must avoid signing a deal that would betray the Afghan government or allow the Taliban to take over the country and return it to a state of medieval barbarity. The potential consequences of such a deal, including the abandonment of women and children to the mercy of Taliban murderers, are a matter of concern.

Whether the United States can satisfy both of these concerns remains to be seen, but Trump should not be faulted for attempting to find a solution to a complex and long-standing conflict. Some Democrats have criticized Trump for using the recent car bomb attack that cost the life of a US soldier as an excuse for canceling the talks, but the Taliban's continued terrorist activities are a clear obstacle to any potential peace deal.

The criticism of Trump's decision-making process and theatrical style has been a recurring theme in the debate, but the underlying issue is the process itself, which may not be likely to accomplish anything but provide a diplomatic fig leaf to cover up a desire to withdraw from Afghanistan without a clear plan for the future.

Comparisons have been drawn between Trump's approach to foreign policy and that of former President Barack Obama, who was criticized for his handling of the Iran nuclear deal and the withdrawal from Iraq. However, Trump's decision to cancel the summit and reconsider the peace deal may indicate a recognition of the mistakes made in the past and a desire to avoid repeating them.

Jonathan Tobin, editor in chief of JNS.org and a contributor to National Review, has suggested that Trump's decision to cancel the summit may be a step towards wisdom, rather than a sign of undignified retreat. The pursuit of peace and the protection of American interests are complex and multifaceted, and a piece of paper signed at Camp David may not be enough to achieve these goals.

Title: President Obama Endorses Hillary Clinton, Vice President Biden Also Expresses Support

Article:

In a video message posted on Thursday, President Barack Obama endorsed Hillary Clinton to succeed him in the White House. The video was released shortly after Obama met with Clinton's primary rival, Bernie Sanders, in the Oval Office.

In the video, Obama stated, "I know how hard this job can be. That's why I know Hillary will be so good at it. In fact, I don't think there's ever been someone so qualified to hold this office."

The president made it clear that he would no longer stand on the sidelines, even as Vermont Sen. Sanders vows to stay in the race at least through the final primary in Washington, D.C., next Tuesday. The Clinton campaign separately announced that she and Obama would campaign together on June 15 in Green Bay.

Clinton tweeted, "Honored to have you with me, @POTUS. I'm fired up and ready to go!"

Meanwhile, Vice President Joe Biden voiced his support of Hillary Clinton Thursday evening at the American Constitution Society's national convention.

Sanders, after the meeting with Obama, struck a conciliatory tone, saying he plans to meet soon with Clinton to discuss how they can "work together to defeat Donald Trump." Sanders still plans to compete in next Tuesday's Washington, D.C., primary, the final contest on the calendar.

The meeting with Obama was private, and no staff or aides were present. The timing and tone of Sanders' remarks appeared to soften compared with his defiant speech early Wednesday after Clinton clinched the Democratic nomination.

Sanders offered no endorsement himself but congratulated Clinton "on her very strong campaign." He also thanked Obama for his "impartiality" throughout the process.

White House spokesman Josh Earnest later said Sanders has the right to make campaign decisions on his own timeline. Another former primary candidate, ex-Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, did endorse Clinton, saying "it is time now to unite our party."

Clinton and Obama, along with other party leaders, are eager to bring Sanders and his supporters into the fold. The president's endorsement reflects their desire to unify as the general election battle between Clinton and presumptive rival Donald Trump intensifies.

Sanders acknowledged a common political enemy, railing against Trump in his brief remarks to reporters Thursday afternoon and saying he'll do everything in his power to prevent Trump's election.

Speculation over the position of Democratic National Committee Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz has swirled for months, but so far, she has retained the public support of the White House. Obama also endorsed her earlier this year in her House primary battle.

Asked Wednesday about the possibility of Sanders seeking her removal, Wasserman Schultz said she's not worried about her job.
