"I'm going to be remaining as the chair of the Democratic National Committee as President Obama has asked me to do until January 21, 2017, and I appreciate the president's support," she said.

Title: Lobbying Activity in Washington Reaches Highest Level Since 2010 at $3.34 Billion in 2017

Article:

Washington, D.C. - Lobbying activity in the United States capital reached a record high of $3.34 billion in 2017, according to a report from the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics. This marks the highest level of lobbying activity since 2010.

Powerful trade groups, such as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Realtors, spent the most money to shape policy last year. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Realtors collectively spent over $100 million in 2017.

Sheila Krumholz, the center's executive director, commented on the high level of lobbying activity, stating, "Lobbyists appear not to have gotten the memo about draining the swamp." This is a reference to President Trump's campaign pledge to clean up Washington and rein in lobbyists.

Google's federal spending jumped to $18 million last year, a new high in the tech giant's lobbying history in Washington. Tech companies are facing increasing scrutiny as lawmakers consider regulating online advertising and investigating Russia's use of social media platforms to influence the 2016 presidential election. Google's lobbying efforts included cyber-security, tax legislation, immigration, and Trump's controversial executive orders on immigration and refugees.

The nonprofit Open Society Policy Center, aligned with liberal billionaire George Soros, reported $16.1 million in spending last year, a record for the organization since it began reporting federal lobbying in 2002. Much of the money was spent in the last three months of the year and reflects grants Open Society made to other, aligned groups to support their lobbying activity.

Congressional records show Open Society's lobbying efforts included a push to limit child trafficking and measures introduced by congressional Democrats that would prohibit President Trump from making a preemptive strike against North Korea without congressional approval.

Lobbying also soared during the last three months of the year for the National Association of Realtors, which spent $22.2 million during the fourth-quarter of 2017, double what it spent during the previous three months. The trade group waged an aggressive lobbying campaign to reshape the tax overhaul that sped through Congress at year's end.

The National Association of Realtors has touted several wins, including preserving an exemption from capital gains taxes when homeowners profit from the sale of their primary residence and beating back a provision that would have limited the mortgage interest deduction for home purchases to those with new loans of $500,000 or less. The trade group is already lobbying to ease other provisions that made it into the final law, such as a new, $10,000 cap on the deductions that individual taxpayers can take to offset local and state income, sales, and property taxes.

Title: Political Debate on Medicare Reform: Romney and Obama Clash Over Savings and Costs

 Article:

 In the ongoing political discourse, Presidential candidate Mitt Romney and his running mate, Paul Ryan, have accused President Barack Obama of reducing Medicare funding by $716 billion. Simultaneously, Obama has countered Ryan's plan by stating it aims to "end Medicare as we know it." These exchanges mark a significant part of the ongoing debate as both parties seek to find ways to manage costs within the entitlement program before Medicare runs out of funds.

 The primary difference between the two plans lies in their approach to savings. Obama's health reform law reduces payments to providers, including hospitals, insurers, and other healthcare facilities. In contrast, Ryan's plan proposes transitioning Medicare to a private sector model by providing senior citizens with vouchers to purchase coverage from insurance providers.

 Both plans incorporate spending caps. However, under Obama's Affordable Care Act, providers could face larger decreases if costs grow faster than projected, while Ryan's plan shifts any additional expenses to beneficiaries.

 Marilyn Moon, a former public trustee of Medicare who heads the health program at the American Institutes for Research, a social science research group, commented, "It's a different philosophy on who should be bearing the burdens."

 As the two parties vie for the crucial voting block of senior citizens, the future of Medicare has become a central issue. Both sides are seeking ways to prevent the program from becoming insolvent, which is projected to occur in 2024.

 Obama's health reform saves money by reducing payments to hospitals, skilled nursing facilities, home health care agencies, and insurers who provide Medicare Advantage managed care plans. It also establishes the Independent Payment Advisory Board, tasked with keeping Medicare costs under control. The law specifies that benefits cannot be cut to reduce expenses.

 Ryan's budget proposal maintains a traditional fee-for-service Medicare option, but also allows insurers to offer seniors a range of choices. At a minimum, the companies would have to provide benefits equivalent to traditional Medicare. The government would provide a "premium support" payment that would cover the cost of either traditional Medicare or the second-least expensive insurer's plan, whichever is less. Seniors can pay for additional coverage, such as dental or vision benefits.

 Romney has not fully adopted Ryan's plan, but has stated it "makes important strides in the right direction."

 Consumer advocates express concern that seniors would pay more for care under the Ryan plan. They point to a Congressional Budget Office report that shows spending would be between 35% and 42% lower for new enrollees under the Ryan plan versus traditional Medicare.

 Edwin Park, vice president for health policy at the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, stated, "By restructuring the program, it could have a very harmful effect on beneficiaries in the long run."

 Supporters of the Ryan plan argue that senior citizens will face higher costs under Obama's health reform law. They cite concerns that many providers could stop accepting Medicare if rates are slashed too low. Even the Medicare actuary has stated the cuts are unsustainable.

 Rea Hederman, research fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation, commented, "They may have traditional Medicare, but they won't have a doctor."

Title: Report Finds Half of 'Criminal Aliens' in Priority Enforcement Program Have No Criminal Convictions

Article:

A new report has revealed that the Priority Enforcement Program (PEP), a federal program intended to prioritize the deportation of immigrants with criminal records, is missing its target. An analysis of requests by federal officials for local jails to keep immigrants suspected of violating US immigration law in custody found that half of the individuals targeted had no criminal conviction.

The Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse (TRAC), a research organization based at Syracuse University, obtained the records through an open records request. The most common conviction was for drunk driving, followed by miscellaneous assaults and simple traffic offenses. Only one quarter of the individuals had committed the most serious types of offenses, such as murder or sexual assault.

The PEP was introduced in 2014 as a replacement for the Secure Communities program, which contributed to a record number of deportations under former President Barack Obama. Under the program, federal officials ask local jails to hold undocumented immigrants they arrest in custody so that they can be transferred to federal immigration detention centers.

However, the most recent data shows that ICE now targets people with no criminal record at a slightly higher rate than before. ICE spokeswoman Sarah Rodriguez said the agency "continues to make significant strides... through PEP to ensure a common-sense approach that focuses enforcement resources on convicted criminals and individuals who threaten public safety and national security."

Immigration advocates have criticized the program, with some arguing that it undermines community policing and leads to the detention of immigrants who are victims of crimes. Maria Sotomayor, an undocumented immigrant who lives in Philadelphia, met with Homeland Security director Jeh Johnson in May and expressed her concerns about the program.

"I told him that because of these detainers, an immigrant who is a victim of a crime will think many times before calling the police to make a report because we could get picked up too," Sotomayor recalled.

Before PEP was officially implemented last year, at least 377 local law enforcement agencies were refusing to honor some or all requests to hold immigrants in detention from ICE. The agency says 17 of the 25 jurisdictions with the highest number of declined detainers are now participating in the program.

Immigration in the US:
According to 2012 figures, there are about 8 million unauthorized migrants either working or looking for work, or 5.1% of the labor force. Since 2009, more Mexicans have been leaving the US than entering, likely due to a slow economic recovery since the recession and stricter border enforcement. Barack Obama has deported more than 2.5 million people, more than any other president. His executive orders protect at least 1.2 million people from deportations.

Meanwhile, immigration advocates have sued to obtain more details about how the PEP program actually differs from its predecessor. "We suspect this PEP program was just a name change," said Jessica Bansel, legal director of the National Day Laborers Organizing Network. Bansel noted that while ICE can now ask local jails to simply inform them when an immigrant is in custody, not to detain them, the agency also has two new detainer forms that are specifically designed to request custody of a person who recently entered the country illegally, but has not been convicted of a crime and is not a security risk.

"This sort of makes the whole thing a joke," said Bansel.

Title: Federal Judge Halts President Trump's Border Wall Construction Plans

Article:

President Donald Trump announced plans to appeal a federal court ruling that halted his plans to construct a border wall using funds from the Pentagon, following a national emergency declaration. The ruling, issued by U.S. District Judge Haywood Gilliam, an Obama appointee, found that the president and his administration overstepped their powers by rearranging Pentagon funds for border wall construction.

In a tweet from Japan, where he was traveling, President Trump criticized Judge Gilliam, stating that he was enabling criminals by ruling against the president's most prominent campaign promise. The judge issued a preliminary injunction, finding that Congress is likely to prevail as the case proceeds, and blocked the government from carrying out wall-building that Mr. Trump said was already underway near El Paso, Texas, and Yuma, Arizona.

Judge Gilliam's ruling is a significant setback for President Trump, who orchestrated a government shutdown to secure border wall funding, only to sign a bill to reopen the government without the wall money he sought. The judge wrote that Congress has repeatedly rejected legislation that would have funded substantially broader border barrier construction.

The ruling is based on the argument that the president is bound to spend only on what Congress authorizes. Judge Gilliam stated that the administration's reading of the relevant provisions, if accepted, would pose serious problems under the Constitution's separation of powers principles.

The Justice Department had argued that Congress did not explicitly deny the administration the ability to use the money, and in fact, included reprogramming abilities in the laws allowing the administration to shift substantial amounts of money within the Defense Department. However, Judge Gilliam ruled that the administration cannot siphon money from other accounts to fill the drug corridor fund, as it did to construct the border wall.

The ruling does not address the government's plans to tap the $3.6 billion in emergency declaration money, but given the tenor and reasoning in Friday's opinion, it is difficult to imagine Judge Gilliam would find the use of that money for a border wall legal at this point. Judge Gilliam is one of several courts hearing challenges to President Trump's emergency declaration, with cases in Texas and Washington, D.C., still ongoing.

Title: Obama Faces Challenges in Second Term as Approval Ratings Dip

Article:

President Barack Obama is facing challenges in his second term, with his approval ratings at a low ebb and a contentious political climate. A Gallup poll released Tuesday showed Obama's approval rating at 39 percent, marking a decline from previous polls.

The president's legislative agenda has faced obstacles, with major legislation such as the Affordable Care Act remaining contentious. The rollout of the health care law has been politically disastrous, putting the president on the defensive.

Obama and other Democrats have blamed Republicans for being intransigent, but the unceasing mode of castigating each other does not bode well for any future deal-making. House Republicans consider everything Obama proposes to be dead on arrival.

One of Obama's goals, a tax package enacted at the start of the year that raised income tax rates for top earners, only delayed the across-the-board spending cuts known as sequestration. The president has been unable to replace those cuts or reach any kind of broader budget agreement with Republicans.

Last month's deal that ended the partial government shutdown called for a joint House-Senate committee to address larger fiscal concerns. The committee met once publicly, then adjourned for a month.

On other issues, Obama has failed to get traction. The Senate-passed immigration bill, a major second-term priority for the president, appears to have no life in the House.

Obama and his agenda are "vastly more popular" than the GOP, says Democratic consultant Jim Jordan. "But we can count on the Republican Party to continue to obstruct policy that the public roundly supports," Jordan says. "The president's legislative prospects are not particularly bright, as I think the White House will concede."

Republicans look at Tuesday's election results and see no evidence they suddenly need to embrace the president. Instead, they look at the most important Democratic victory, in the Virginia gubernatorial race, and see hope for their side.

The health care law may ultimately prove a great boon for the country, but in political terms, there could be more pain to come for Obama and his party. Obama's broken promise about people being able to keep insurance plans they liked has so far applied only to the relatively small market of people who buy coverage as individuals. If Americans who are covered through employer-backed plans see cost increases or other changes, Republicans will be sure to blame the law that bears the president's name.

"For Republicans, it's like the anti-war movement was for Democrats in 2006 — it's what they live for, fighting Obamacare," says William Schneider, a senior fellow at Third Way, a centrist Democratic think tank. "They'll stop at nothing, including shutting down the government."

Obama remains in an ongoing campaign mode, trying to sell ideas that his opponents will never accept. "Very little is now possible that was not possible before," says Brendan Nyhan, a government professor at Dartmouth College. "He looks like a very typical second-term president — not so popular, the agenda's stuck, a little bit of scandal is starting to creep out, and he's hunkering down to ride out the rest of his term."

Title: Cruz Family's Investment in Senator Ted Cruz's 2012 Campaign

Article:

In a 2013 interview with The Times, Senator Ted Cruz recounted that his wife, Heidi Cruz, agreed without hesitation to invest their entire savings into his campaign, despite his trailing in the polls and being considered a long shot against Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst, who spent $24 million of his own money on the race. Heidi Cruz later suggested a more nuanced perspective, telling Politico in 2014 that they should have applied "common investment sense" and not use their own money for the campaign unless it made a significant difference in winning.

The financial support from the Cruzes allowed Cruz's campaign to continue airing television ads before the primary election, including a $300,000 ad buy highlighting the story of Cruz's father's escape from Cuba in the 1950s. Cruz earned enough votes in the primary to qualify for a runoff, where he defeated Dewhurst and went on to win the general election.

Candidates are required to list all assets they held at the close of the year or that generated income during the year in their filings with the Senate. According to Cruz's filings, at the close of 2011, he and his wife had cash and securities in bank, brokerage, and retirement accounts worth $1.3 million to $3.4 million. They also had mortgages and a loan against Cruz's partnership equity in his law firm. In 2012, they sold securities worth $82,000 to $355,000, and the value of other holdings was reduced by, at most, $155,000. However, they also added a money-market account with $250,000 to $500,000, and the value of other holdings increased by as much as $435,000. All told, the value of their cash and securities in 2012 saw a net increase of as much as $400,000—even as the Cruzes were supposedly liquidating everything to finance Cruz's Senate campaign. The article does not mention any loans from banks.

Title: President Obama's Statement on Muslim Rejection of Terrorism: A Fact-Check

Article:

In a recent statement, former U.S. President Barack Obama emphasized the rejection of terrorism by the majority of Muslims worldwide. However, a fact-check of the statement reveals discrepancies with the findings of various polls and research studies.

According to Pew Research, only 57% of Muslims in nine predominantly Islamic countries hold an unfavorable opinion of Al-Qaeda. This percentage is significantly lower than the 99.9% suggested by Obama. Similarly, Pew found that 33% of Muslims support Hamas, an organization responsible for a suicide bombing in a hotel in Netanya, Israel, that killed 30 and wounded 140 people.

It is important to note that Pew Research is a non-partisan organization that conducts extensive polling on what Muslims believe about current events. The findings suggest that a significant minority of Muslims hold favorable views towards extremist groups, contradicting Obama's statement.

Moreover, the statement that Muslims have fought in every American war and serve in the U.S. military today is factually correct. However, the implication that Muslims are not associated with terrorism is not supported by the available data.

In conclusion, while it is true that the majority of Muslims want a good life for themselves and their families, the minority that supports extremist ideologies and terrorism is significant and cannot be ignored. President Obama's statement that 99.9% of Muslims reject terrorism is not supported by the available data.

Title: Trump Acknowledges Reimbursement of Hush Money Payment to Stormy Daniels, Stresses Personal Nature of Transaction

Article:

President Donald Trump, in his first public comments since his lawyer Rudy Giuliani disclosed that the president reimbursed attorney Michael Cohen for a hush money payment to adult film star Stormy Daniels, stated that the money was intended to quash "false" allegations and emphasized that campaign funds were not involved in the transaction.

In a series of tweets on Thursday, Trump addressed the $130,000 payment Cohen made to Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, to maintain her silence regarding allegations of an affair in the weeks leading up to the 2016 election.

"Mr. Cohen, an attorney, received a monthly retainer, not from the campaign and having nothing to do with the campaign, from which he entered into, through reimbursement, a private contract between two parties, known as a non-disclosure agreement, or NDA," Trump tweeted.

The president continued, "These agreements are very common among celebrities and people of wealth. In this case, it is in full force and effect and will be used in Arbitration for damages against Ms. Clifford (Daniels). The agreement was used to stop the false and extortionist accusations made by her about an affair."

Trump added that the agreement was a private one and that money from the campaign or campaign contributions played no role in the transaction.

The president's tweets referred to a letter written and signed by Daniels in January, stating "with complete clarity" that allegations of an affair with Trump were "absolutely false." Daniels also wrote, at the time, that rumors that she received "hush money" from Trump were "completely false."

However, Trump also stated last month that he was not aware of the $130,000 payment. Giuliani, who recently joined Trump's legal team, revealed Wednesday night on Fox News' "Hannity" that Trump indeed made the reimbursement.

Giuliani clarified on "Fox & Friends" on Thursday that Trump "didn't know the details of this until we knew the details of this" a couple of weeks ago. He has said Trump thought it was to cover unspecified "expenses."

Giuliani stressed that this was a personal payment and disputed any suggestion that it was an unreported campaign contribution.

"[Cohen] was trying to help the family...I think he was just being a good lawyer," he said.

"That money was not campaign money," Giuliani also said on "Hannity." "It's not campaign money. No campaign finance violation."

Giuliani, who recently joined Trump's legal team, added that the money was "funneled" through a "law firm and the president repaid it."

Whether Giuliani's argument holds up remains to be seen. A candidate is allowed to contribute an unlimited amount to their campaign, but contributions are supposed to be officially reported. If the payments were wholly personal, there would be no campaign finance violations.

However, Giuliani's argument that the payment was unrelated to the campaign could well be challenged. If it's considered a campaign-related expense, the onus may have been on the president or his campaign to report it as a loan.

Richard L. Hasen, an expert in election law at the University of California, Irvine, stated that the greatest significance is that it implicates the president directly.

Daniels' attorney, Michael Avenatti, said on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" Thursday morning that if it's "true" that Trump reimbursed Cohen, it's a "crime" with "serious consequences."

Cohen previously has said the money he paid to Daniels came out of his own pocket. Both Trump's and Giuliani's statements now seem to contradict Cohen's account. Cohen is currently under criminal investigation as part of a grand jury probe looking into his personal business dealings.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Admits Error in Release of Illegal Immigrant, Urges Cooperation with Federal Agents

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson admitted on Tuesday that the administration erred in releasing an illegal immigrant to the sanctuary city of San Francisco before a shocking murder earlier this month. However, he stated that there is little the government can do to pressure sanctuary communities to change their policies.

Facing lawmakers for the first time since the death of Kathryn Steinle, a 32-year-old woman killed while walking with her father, Mr. Johnson made personal appeals to San Francisco to reconsider its refusal to allow police to cooperate with federal immigration agents. He also expressed his hope that more jurisdictions will cooperate with the new Priority Enforcement Program.

The suspect in Steinle's slaying, Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez, was an illegal immigrant who had been deported five times before and was out on the streets after San Francisco refused to hold him for pickup by immigration agents. Lopez-Sanchez had just completed a federal prison sentence for one of his many illegal entries into the U.S., and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents had asked the Bureau of Prisons to hold him for pickup. Instead, the bureau shipped him to San Francisco, which wanted him on a decades-old drug warrant. San Francisco canceled that charge and, despite another request from ICE, released him per its sanctuary policy.

Mr. Johnson stated that his department and the Bureau of Prisons should be discussing these issues better, and that some discretion is probably needed so the bureau would have prioritized the homeland security claim over San Francisco's. The Bureau of Prisons did not respond to messages seeking comment on how it handled the case.

Republican lawmakers questioned Mr. Johnson's approach, with Rep. Trey Gowdy demanding to know why he and President Obama haven't taken a tougher stance on recalcitrant sanctuary cities. Steinle's death has refocused the immigration debate, with attention now on victims of illegal immigration.

Beyond the sanctuary city issue, Mr. Johnson stated that border security is improving. Border Patrol agents are on pace to apprehend fewer than 400,000 illegal immigrants this year, which could be the lowest total since the 1970s. The agency says that means fewer people are even attempting to cross in the first place.

Homeland Security has focused on illegal immigrants with serious criminal histories, all but ignoring rank-and-file illegal immigrants. This causes deportations to plummet and detention beds to go unused. Mr. Johnson stated they are approaching 31,000 beds being used on an average day, more than the 27,000 being held at the beginning of the year but still short of the 34,000 beds that Congress has mandated the department keep.

Even as it leaves beds unused, the department continues to release immigrants with serious criminal records who go on to commit more crimes. More than 1,000 criminal aliens released into the community while awaiting deportation in 2014 were convicted of still more crimes after their release, including kidnapping, sexual assault against a child, and vehicular homicide, according to statistics released Tuesday by Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte.

Title: Edward Snowden's Whereabouts Remain Unclear as He Remains in Moscow Airport's Transit Zone

Article:

Edward Snowden, the infamous National Security Agency (NSA) leaker, is reportedly still in the Moscow airport's transit zone, according to Russian officials. Despite numerous attempts to locate him, Snowden has remained elusive, with no confirmed sightings since his arrival more than a week ago.

Reporters, including those from the Associated Press, have swarmed the airport, but Snowden has remained invisible. Even his father, Lonnie Snowden, is still trying to establish a "direct communications link" with him, according to his attorney Bruce Fein.

Ian Phillips, the Associated Press Eastern Europe news director, spent 21 hours in the Moscow transit zone last week in an unsuccessful attempt to find Snowden. Phillips believes Snowden may be holed up in the Novotel, a hotel with one wing jutting into the international transit zone. However, Phillips admitted that Snowden could be in many other places.

WikiLeaks, which is assisting Snowden, could potentially shed light on his whereabouts. On Monday, WikiLeaks announced it would make several important announcements during the day. Hours later, reports surfaced that the WikiLeaks adviser traveling with Snowden has submitted a request for political asylum to Russia. The details about his current whereabouts remain unclear.

Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, was cagey during a Sunday show interview about Snowden's circumstances. He stated that the situation is a matter of "international diplomatic negotiations." Last week, after Snowden landed in Moscow, Assange only said that Snowden and the WikiLeaks adviser are "healthy and safe."

Speculation swirls about Snowden's whereabouts, but U.S. officials still believe he is at the Moscow airport. Russian news reports claimed last week he was at a hotel in the terminal itself. However, the Associated Press could not find any sign of Snowden at the on-site hotel or any worker who would confirm he was staying there.

Snowden was not found in any of the VIP lounge areas. The Associated Press then sent Phillips to the Novotel on Thursday. Phillips described an "Orwellian" experience there, and on Monday, he recounted his visit to FoxNews.com.

Phillips arrived last week with the understanding "it was a long shot." He took a bus and "walked in a free man into the lobby of what looked like a fantastic hotel." However, a guard came and took him to the old wing of the hotel where travelers with no visas—like Snowden—are kept under tight security.

Phillips tried to call the other rooms and hang out in the corridor, hoping to catch a glimpse of Snowden. No luck. Any further movement was prohibited. "I walked out the first night and the guard jumped up as if to say 'what are you doing,'" Phillips said. "I think we expected a bit more freedom to roam."

With Russia and now Ecuador trying to distance themselves from Snowden's case, it's unclear who has actually had face-to-face contact with him besides the WikiLeaks adviser.

Fein, the attorney for Snowden's father, told Fox News that the family is currently trying to get information to Edward Snowden so he can make an informed decision about what legal options are available. The father last week sent a letter to the Justice Department in hopes of securing a few key conditions for Snowden to return. He asked that Snowden not be detained before trial, not be subject to a gag order, and have a trial in a venue of his choosing.

However, Fein clarified to Fox News that these are not "ultimatums" and that the father is also respecting his son's wishes. "He's an adult. He has to chart his own destiny, and his father's not going to dictate that," Fein said.

Title: Challenging Biased News Coverage: A Guide to Recognizing and Addressing Media Bias

Article:

Media outlets play a significant role in shaping cultural norms and political discourse. It is crucial for news media, along with other institutions, to strive for objectivity and accuracy. To challenge biased news coverage, one must first document instances of bias. Here are some questions to consider when evaluating newspaper, TV, and radio news:

1. Be aware of the political perspective of the sources used in a story. Media often rely heavily on "official" sources, such as government, corporate, and establishment think tank representatives. A study found that in 40 months of Nightline programming, the most frequent guests were Henry Kissinger, Alexander Haig, Elliott Abrams, and Jerry Falwell, while progressive and public interest voices were underrepresented.

2. To portray issues fairly and accurately, media must broaden their spectrum of sources. This includes counting the number of corporate and government sources versus the number of progressive, public interest, female, and minority voices. Demand that media expand their rolodexes, and provide them with lists of progressive and public interest experts in the community.

3. Examine the race and gender diversity at the news outlet you consume compared to the communities it serves. How many producers, editors, or decision-makers at news outlets are women, people of color, or openly gay or lesbian? In order to fairly represent different communities, news outlets should have members of those communities in decision-making positions.

4. Analyze the racial and gender composition of the experts media outlets cite. A study of Nightline's U.S. guests found they were 92 percent white and 89 percent male, while a similar survey of PBS's NewsHour found its guestlist was 90 percent white and 87 percent male.

5. Demand that those affected by the issue have a voice in coverage. Political coverage often focuses on how issues affect politicians or corporate executives rather than those directly affected by the issue. For example, many stories on parental notification of abortion emphasize the "tough choice" confronting male politicians while quoting no women under 18—those with the most at stake in the debate.

6. Expose double standards by coming up with a parallel example or citing similar stories that were covered differently. For instance, does coverage of the drug crisis focus almost exclusively on African Americans, despite the fact that the vast majority of drug users are white?

7. Educate journalists about misconceptions involved in stereotypes and how stereotypes characterize individuals unfairly.

8. Be aware of loaded terminology that helps shape public opinion. For example, media often use the right-wing buzzword "racial preference" to refer to affirmative action programs, which can significantly impact how the issue is perceived.

9. Challenge the assumption directly. Bringing assumptions to the surface often demonstrates their absurdity.

10. Provide context to help journalists understand the full picture. Misleading headlines have a significant impact, as many people only skim headlines.

11. Look at where stories appear. Newspaper articles on the most widely read pages (the front pages and the editorial pages) and lead stories on television and radio will have the greatest influence on public opinion.

By asking these questions and taking action when necessary, individuals can help challenge biased news coverage and promote a more accurate and fair representation of the world in media.

Title: Senate Candidates Distance Themselves from Obama in Debates Ahead of Election Day

Article:

In the final four weeks before Election Day, the influence of President Obama is prevalent in several key Senate races across Colorado, Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia, and West Virginia. During Tuesday's debates, Republican candidates frequently brought up Obama, attempting to distance their Democratic opponents from the unpopular president.

In races where an incumbent Democrat is running for reelection, the attacks were consistent: the candidates have voted with Obama 99%, 96%, or 97% of the time. In races for open seats, Democrats were portrayed as Obama's allies.

The responses from the Democrats were uniform: they disagreed with the characterization, stating they were running against their Republican opponents, not Obama.

In the North Carolina debate, Senator Kay Hagan (D) was asked for ways she disagrees with Obama and the Democrats. Hagan, who is in a tight race with state House Speaker Thom Tillis (R), outlined her disagreements on issues such as the use of military force in Syria, the Keystone XL pipeline, trade deals, and military budget cuts.

In Virginia, Senator Mark Warner (D) also distanced himself from Obama, despite his comfortable lead against GOP challenger Ed Gillespie. Like Hagan, Senator Warner expressed support for the Keystone pipeline and offshore drilling in Virginia, provided the state shares in the revenue.

In West Virginia, underdog candidate Natalie Tennant (D) joined her Republican opponent, Rep. Shelley Moore Capito (R), in opposing proposed regulations by the Environmental Protection Agency that would tighten standards on coal-burning power plants.

Political handicappers give Republicans a slight advantage in their quest to retake control of the Senate, but no one rules out the Democrats' chances of holding on. The debates saw no major gaffes, though North Carolina's Thom Tillis misstated Senator Hagan's committee assignments in the Senate multiple times before being corrected.

The bad news for Democrats is that Obama's low job approvals weigh heavily, particularly in red states. Obama himself invited the distancing when he declared that his policies are "on the ballot" on Nov. 4. However, Obama was already a significant factor, in spirit if not literally, well before he made that statement.

The news wasn't all bad for the president Tuesday. In Colorado, Senator Mark Udall (D), facing a stiff challenge from Rep. Cory Gardner (R), deflected efforts to get him to criticize the president. Udall also offered strong support for the Affordable Care Act (ACA), the president's signature initiative.

In Georgia, Democrat Michelle Nunn hesitated when asked her opinion of the ACA, before listing ways the law could be improved.

Democrats also came prepared with their own attack lines in Tuesday's debates, tailored to each state and candidate. In North Carolina, Hagan criticized the state General Assembly under Tillis's leadership, while in Georgia, Nunn went after her Republican opponent, David Perdue, for his business career. In Colorado, Udall attacked Congressman Gardner for his past support for "personhood" measures, which assert that life begins at conception and would ban some forms of contraception.

Gardner responded, "It's simply outrageous to believe that someone would try to ban birth control." Perdue, in response to criticism of his business career, called outsourcing a part of American business.

Title: US Attorney General Defends Border Separation Policy, UN Calls for Immediate Halt

Article:

In a recent radio interview, U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions defended the controversial policy of separating migrant children from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border. Sessions stated that while authorities prefer to keep children close to their parents, this is not always possible. The issue has sparked a growing controversy after U.S. officials confirmed hundreds of child migrants had been removed from their families.

On Tuesday, the United Nations called on the U.S. to "immediately halt" the separations. When asked whether it was "absolutely necessary" to separate children from their parents, Mr. Sessions replied in the affirmative. He argued that many U.S. children are taken away from their families if their parents are serving prison sentences.

Mr. Sessions also stated that migrant children were "being well taken care of." He added, "It's certainly not our goal to separate children, but I do think it's clear, it's legitimate to warn people who come to the country unlawfully bringing children with them that they can't expect that they'll always be kept together."

In early May, Mr. Sessions announced that anyone found crossing the border illegally would be prosecuted and face possible separation from their children. Previously, those crossing the border illegally for the first time were often charged with a misdemeanor offense, before often being released to face a court hearing. Most never turned up for those hearings, say Trump administration officials.

The UN Human Rights Office's spokeswoman, Ravina Shamdasani, criticized the policy on Tuesday and said that several hundred children, some as young as one, appeared to have been affected. "The use of immigration detention and family separation as a deterrent runs counter to human rights standards and principles," she said. "The child's best interest should always come first, including over migration management objectives or other administrative concerns."

US Customs and Border Protection has confirmed that more than 650 children were separated from parents at the border over a fortnight in May. US Ambassador Nikki Haley responded by accusing the UN of "hypocrisy" and said that "neither the United Nations nor anyone else will dictate how the United States upholds its borders."

President Donald Trump has tried to shift blame for family separations, claiming they were caused by bad legislation passed by Democrats. However, a fact check by the Associated Press news agency found there was no law requiring families to be separated at the border and that it was a new policy from the Trump administration.

However, the problem of children ending up in border immigration holding centers is not a new issue. Jon Favreau, a speechwriter for President Barack Obama, recently tweeted photos of young people being held in a chain-link fence enclosure at a facility in Texas, using the images to excoriate Mr. Trump. Mr. Favreau apparently did not realize the images were taken in 2014 when his former boss, Mr. Obama, was president.

Title: Deadly Shooting at Santa Fe High School in Texas Triggers Calls for Gun Reform

Article:

A shooting at Santa Fe High School in Texas on Friday left at least 10 people dead and another 10 injured, making it the deadliest school shooting since the February 14 massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The 17-year-old shooter carried a shotgun and a revolver, and explosive devices were found at the school and the areas surrounding it.

The tragedy in Santa Fe is still under investigation, and the police are piecing together what happened in the hallways of this high school on Friday morning. The shooting has reinvigorated the gun reform debate, with survivors of the Parkland shooting offering solidarity and support to the survivors of Santa Fe High School.

The Parkland activists, who have been vocal in their calls for gun control, have seized on this rampage at Santa Fe as another example of lawmakers' failure to act. They also offered solidarity and support to the survivors of Santa Fe High School, who have joined this sorrowful club.

Emma Gonzalez, one of the most vocal Parkland activists, wrote on Twitter, "You deserve more than Thoughts and Prayers, and after supporting us by walking out we will be there to support you by raising up your voices."

David Hogg, another Parkland activist, tweeted, "Get ready for two weeks of media coverage of politicians acting like they give a shit when in reality they just want to boost their approval ratings before midterms."

The Parkland shooting in February sparked a movement among teenagers across the country, with students organizing school walkouts in March and another in April, or marching for gun control in their cities and towns.

In the wake of the Santa Fe shooting, high school students in Washington, D.C. protested at the Capitol on Friday, and several were arrested. The group that organized the National School Walkout on April 20 called for a moment of silence at 2pm Friday in solidarity with the victims. A March for Our Lives chapter in Salt Lake City rallied at the Utah State Capitol.

The community's and the state's reaction to the shooting will likely determine if, and how, lawmakers respond, both in Texas and on the federal level. Santa Fe High School held a walkout on April 20, on the 19th anniversary of Columbine, to call for gun control. In a picture on social media, students hold up a sign that reads: "Santa Fe High School says # NeverAgain."

Title: Trump Calls for a War on Washington Waste in Bid to Regain Fiscal Responsibility

Article:

Republicans are seeking to regain the offensive on fiscal issues, as the GOP has reportedly allowed big-spending Democrats to appear more financially responsible in terms of balanced budgets. According to polls, Democrats are now more trusted on balancing the budget than Republicans, a situation likened to losing an arm wrestling contest with Nancy Pelosi.

To regain American trust on fiscal responsibility, President Donald Trump is expected to deliver a nationally televised prime-time speech from the Oval Office, announcing an "all-hands-on-deck War on Washington Waste." The proposed initiative aims to declare a debt-spending emergency, with Trump's commitment to this initiative potentially boosting his approval ratings.

The Congressional Budget Office recently announced that the government is now spending $2 billion more than it takes in every day. This spending trend is alarming, with the government's outlays now exceeding $4 trillion per year.

Several weeks ago, a taxpayer watchdog group called OpenTheBooks.com published an open letter signed by former Senator Tom Coburn and Tom Smith, urging a waste war and listing hundreds of examples of taxpayer dollars being wasted. The following table lists some of these instances:

| Item                   | Estimated Waste |
|------------------------|----------------|
| Pentagon               | $125 billion    |
| Unnecessary Earmarks    | $100 billion    |
| Duplicate Programs      | $ 50 billion    |
| Unused Property         | $ 25 billion    |
| Improper Payments      | $ 100 billion   |

When President Trump was shown these lists of white elephants, he reportedly responded, "I thought we already took care of this." Unfortunately, the bureaucratic blob ensured that it would not happen.

Fighting this war on waste won't be easy. In 1981, President Ronald Reagan appointed the Grace Commission to identify waste, duplication, and inefficiency in the federal government. This commission, composed of private-sector businesspeople, uncovered $420 billion in bureaucratic overspending and called for the elimination of hundreds of bureaus, agencies, and departments that served no purpose.

Trump has called for a 5% cut in the budget of every federal agency in 2019. OpenTheBooks wants Trump to require every agency to list all spending items as little as $100 on a government website, allowing for public monitoring of how the money is being spent. They also want the president to report to the American people each month on the progress made in every agency in cutting their budgets.

Almost nothing would do more to guarantee Donald Trump's reelection than a crusade to weed out the hundreds of billions of dollars of fraud, inefficiency, and duplication in Washington. A successful businessman, Trump is well-positioned to lead this initiative. A government that is going broke and yet still spends tens of thousands of dollars a year on pianos, hundreds of millions of dollars a year on public relations firms, and billions of dollars a year sending Social Security checks to dead people is not serious about balancing the budget or spending taxpayer money with the same care they spend their own.

Title: Hillary Clinton Becomes First Woman Nominated for U.S. Presidency by Major Party

Article:

In a historic moment at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders nominated Hillary Clinton as the party's nominee for the presidency of the United States. Clinton, who accepted the nomination later in the evening, became the first woman to be nominated by a major political party for the position of president.

Clinton, in her acceptance speech, acknowledged the significance of the moment, stating, "If there are any little girls out there who stayed up late to watch, let me just say: I may become the first woman president, but one of you is next."

The nomination of Clinton, which occurred 240 years into the existence of the United States, follows the 1919 amendment of the Constitution that gave women the right to vote. However, state restrictions made it difficult for women (and men of color) to exercise that right into the 1960s.

The Democratic National Convention, chaired by Ohio Representative Marcia Fudge, marked several precedents. Fudge, the first African-American and first female mayor of Warrensville Heights, Ohio, was joined at the helm by two other African-American women: Rev. Leah Daughtry, the chief executive officer of the convention, and Donna Brazile, the interim Democratic National Committee chair.

The convention also featured ground-breaking speakers such as Maryland Senator Barbara Mikulski, who was the first Democratic woman to be elected to the Senate in 1987, and Madeleine Albright, the country's first female secretary of state. Bill Clinton, the former president, was also a keynote speaker, offering a personal portrait of his wife to counter the narrative of corruption and scandal that has at times surrounded the campaign.

The theme of "firsts" will continue on Wednesday night, with President Obama, the first African-American president, offering his support of Clinton. On Monday, Clinton received the support of another history-maker, Michelle Obama, the nation's first African-American first lady.

This report includes material from the Associated Press and Reuters.

Title: Arkansas and New Hampshire Democrats Accuse Republican Senate Candidates of Threatening Health Care Coverage for Low-Income Residents

Article:

In the ongoing political battle over the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, Democrats in Arkansas and New Hampshire are accusing their Republican Senate candidates of potentially stripping health care coverage from the state's poorest residents.

Republican Tom Cotton, who is running against Democratic Sen. Mark L. Pryor, has an anti-Obamacare platform that could jeopardize the federal funds Arkansas is leveraging to provide private health insurance policies for low-income residents. If Obamacare is repealed, the coverage of at least 155,000 Arkansas residents could be affected, according to Democrats.

Similar criticisms are being leveled at Republican Scott Brown, who is vying for a U.S. Senate seat in New Hampshire. Brown is reportedly wary of a compromise that uses Medicaid dollars to buy commercial insurance for more than 50,000 residents.

The "private option," a method of insuring residents making up to 138 percent of the federal poverty level, was a palatable solution for some state Republicans, serving as a key, yet optional, component of President Obama's health care law. However, supporters of Senate Democrats in tight re-election races aim to portray Republican challengers as endangering low-income residents' health care coverage without significantly expanding traditional Medicaid rolls.

Erik Dorey, spokesman for Pryor's campaign, stated, "This is not an issue we’ve been shy about talking about."

Conservatives argue that Democrats should not equate state-level decisions with success in congressional races. If Democratic incumbents dismiss Republican calls to repeal Obamacare, Republican challengers will counter with stories of canceled health plans, higher premiums, and narrower doctor networks in the lead-up to November's mid-term elections, they said.

In New Hampshire, Greg Moore, state director for Americans for Prosperity in New Hampshire, which has run ads against incumbent Sen. Jeanne Shaheen, portrays her as the cause of limited health care choices in the state. Shaheen, however, has stated her commitment to assisting New Hampshire implement its Medicaid expansion plan to cover 58,000 people under the state's private option plan.

Arkansas pioneered the private option as a means to implement Obamacare's Medicaid expansion last year, attracting enough GOP support to overcome the three-fourths voting threshold needed to pass appropriations in Little Rock. As of March 31, about 155,567 people, or roughly 70 percent of 225,000 eligible residents, had signed up for coverage under the program.

In Arkansas, Anna Strong, health policy director at Arkansas Advocates for Children & Families, emphasized, "These are families that are working, they’re going to school, they’re supporting their families."

Cotton, who assumed his House seat in 2013, voted to repeal President Obama's health care law last May. If Obamacare is repealed, the funding for the state's private-option health care would also disappear, according to his opponents. However, the Cotton campaign asserts that Obamacare "is such bad policy that it has made every state choose between multiple bad options."

In New Hampshire, the initial wave of coverage under the state's Medicaid expansion is set to begin in July. The federal government is slated to pay for 100 percent of the expanded Medicaid population from 2014 to 2016, a contribution that decreases to 90 percent in 2020 and beyond.

Brown, who has made his home in Rye, N.H., his main residence ahead of the campaign, has expressed concerns about the state's Medicaid expansion, stating, "Their concerns are what happens at the end of three years? Is it then going to be an unfunded federal mandate, that the citizens of New Hampshire will have a whole new program that they didn’t really want?"

Title: EPA's Carbon Regulation: Flexible Approach for Kentucky with Potential Short-term Disruptions

Article:

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has endorsed a flexible approach for states, including Kentucky, to reduce carbon emissions, with the state having the autonomy to devise a plan to meet its carbon reduction target. In Kentucky's case, a 18% reduction of carbon pollution by 2030 is expected, taking into account the state's heavy reliance on coal, which accounts for 93% of its electricity.

The EPA's regulation is based on a 23-page "white paper" sent by Kentucky's energy department last year, requesting states be given wide flexibility in reducing carbon emissions. Instead of regulating emissions from every smokestack, the EPA is providing states with an overall target to meet.

Kentucky can achieve the goal by switching plants from coal to natural gas, developing renewable energy like solar, and encouraging the use of efficient home appliances and insulation to reduce demand. The implementation of these changes is not immediate, with any shutdowns years away, as the EPA's proposal faces a political and legal onslaught.

However, the implementation of the plan could lead to short-term disruptions, including to local economies tied to individual coal plants that might close, and in mining regions like eastern Kentucky, where the number of coal jobs is already at a historic low. The EPA estimated that coal production in central Appalachia would fall by up to 37% as a result of its proposal.

Residents in affected areas, such as Dionna Sizemore of Burgin, a mother of two, ages 11 and 16, who moved from Harlan County, the heart of Appalachian coal country, to escape dead-end prospects there, are concerned about the potential impact on their communities. "It's going to be devastating if the power plant goes down," said Sizemore. "We know the impact it's having on friends and family back home: people having to move off."

The exact number of Kentucky's 56 coal-fired generating units that might close is uncertain at this stage, as it is impossible to say which, if any, might close. Many have already installed costly upgrades to comply with earlier pollution rules.

Title: Andrew Tahmooressi Case: Questions Raised Over Former Marine's Story

Article:

The case of Andrew Tahmooressi, a former Marine who was arrested in Mexico on weapons charges in March, has gained significant attention from the Tea Party and conservative media. Tahmooressi's mother, Jill Tahmooressi, has frequently appeared on Fox News, and 74 Tea Party Congress members have signed a letter demanding his release from a Mexican jail and urging the closure of the border until Tahmooressi is freed.

The story has been extensively covered on Fox News and conservative websites, including the Drudge Report, WorldNetDaily, and Breitbart. All of these outlets echo Tahmooressi's claim that his entry into Mexico with a fully loaded AR-15 5.56 caliber assault-style rifle, a chrome-plated 1911 model Colt.45 caliber pistol, a 12-gauge shotgun, extra clips for the rifle and the pistol, and 457 rounds of ammunition was a simple mistake due to a wrong turn.

However, some facts are not in dispute. Andrew Tahmooressi served two tours in Iraq and Afghanistan and was promoted to sergeant before being honorably discharged from the Marine Corps. A native of Weston, Florida, he had recently moved to the San Diego area to receive treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder at the VA hospital in La Jolla. On March 31, Tahmooressi parked his pickup truck and walked across the border at the El Chaparral crossing from San Ysidro, California, to Tijuana, Mexico. He spent the day in Tijuana and later that night returned to the American side of the border. Then he got into his truck and drove back across the border, where he was arrested at 10:30 p.m. by Mexican authorities.

Tahmooressi and his mother have both consistently claimed that he was driving south on I-5 from La Jolla, on the way to have dinner with friends in San Ysidro, when he missed the last exit before the border and accidentally crossed into Mexico. However, new evidence has turned up, including cellphone records and a hotel receipt, that casts doubt on Tahmooressi's story.

Firstly, Tahmooressi now admits that he had parked his truck at a lot just north of the border earlier in the day and walked into Tijuana. This means when he walked back across the border to his truck, he was already as far south as it is possible to be and still be in the U.S. The second problem is the San Ysidro crossing is the busiest land border crossing in the world. It is large, well-marked, and brightly lit at night on both sides. Even had he been driving south on I-5, which we now know he was not, I-5 is a multilane freeway with numerous signs and ample opportunities to exit and turn around. Even had he somehow missed all of these, there are clearly marked turnaround lines only a few yards from the border.

In the past week, new evidence has turned up, including cellphone records and a hotel receipt, that casts even more doubt on Tahmooressi's story. Far from being unfamiliar with the San Ysidro crossing, as he originally claimed, cellphone and ATM records show that he had crossed the border five or six times in recent weeks. He has now admitted as much, saying he went to visit a Tijuana woman who works in the notorious Zona de Tolerancia, Tijuana's red light district, with whom he was developing a relationship.

Thanks to a receipt, a copy of which was published in the Tijuana news weekly Zeta, we now know that Tahmooressi had taken a room at the Hotel Nelson, a $24-a-night "hot sheet" hotel on the edge of the Zona de Tolerancia. His mother has confirmed that the receipt is authentic, but claims that Tahmooressi was afraid to spend the night there, which is why he returned to San Ysidro.

In the wake of this new evidence, Tahmooressi has secured new counsel to represent him, his third attorney in four months. Jill Tahmooressi, who had been ever present on Fox News and social media, has gone silent and returned to Florida. A press event scheduled for last week in San Diego to garner support for Tahmooressi was abruptly canceled without explanation. In the meantime, larger signs have been installed at approaches to the border warning that guns are illegal in Mexico and highlighting turnaround areas.

It is unclear why Tahmooressi would try to enter Mexico with a small arsenal and hundreds of rounds of ammunition if he did not make a wrong turn and cross the border accidentally, as the preponderance of evidence suggests. Whatever his reasons, one thing seems sure: Barring a decision by the Mexican government to pardon him, which seems unlikely at this point, it looks like Andrew Tahmooressi could spend a long time in a Mexican prison. It also seems certain that once again the conservative media machine has backed the wrong pony and sold its consumers a story that, to put it mildly, is simply not true. Whatever his intentions were, it's highly unlikely that this troubled young man suffering PTSD will find the help he needs in a Mexican prison.

Update: At an evidentiary hearing last week, presided over by Judge Victor Octavio Luna Escobedo, Tahmooressi's attorney, Fernando Benitez, began to lay out his defense. In Benitez's questioning of the border guards, it became clear that he believes the best hope for acquittal is to claim that proper procedures were not followed. Mexican authorities strenuously denied this claim, testifying that standard protocol was strictly followed, and that Tahmooressi's rights under Mexican law were protected at all times.

Both sides said the trial is likely to last at least until November. Tahmooressi's attorney has asked that a videotape be entered into evidence, hoping the tape, which the defense has not seen, will show the search of Tahmooressi's truck was somehow illegal. Experts on Mexican law say this is a long shot, but as Tahmooressi is facing a mandatory seven to 14 years in prison, his attorney told reporters his only hope was to secure an outright acquittal.

It is also expected that cellphone and ATM records, as well as additional evidence, including the hotel receipt, will be presented by prosecutors at the next hearing. After all of the evidence has been presented, it will be up to the judge to find Tahmooressi guilty or not guilty.

Title: Turkey Resumes Delivery of Russian S-400 Missile System Amidst US Sanctions Threat

Article:

Turkey has resumed the delivery of the Russian S-400 missile defense system, despite strong opposition and economic sanctions threats from the United States. The second shipment of equipment necessary to make the S-400s operational was delivered on Saturday, following the first delivery on Friday.

Defense Minister Hulusi Akar of Turkey stated that the acquisition of the S-400s was a necessity due to the country being under "serious threat." Akar made these comments during a phone call with his American counterpart, Mark Esper, on Friday.

The US has urged Turkey to abandon the deal, warning of economic sanctions that could reportedly cost over $2 billion. The S-400 deal marks the first such move between a NATO member and Russia.

Akar told Esper that Turkey's purchase of the controversial defense system does not signify a change in the country's strategic orientation. He emphasized that Turkey is still assessing a bid to acquire the US Patriot air-defense system and that deteriorating bilateral relations would not serve the interests of either country.

US officials have urged Turkey to purchase Patriot missiles instead of the S-400s from Russia. However, Ankara claims that the United States refused to sell Patriots to Turkey, leading it to seek other vendors. Russia offered a better deal, including technology transfers, according to Turkey.

The US has stated that Turkey will not be allowed to participate in the program to produce F-35 stealth fighter jets or buy them. Washington has repeatedly said the Russian missiles are incompatible with NATO systems and a threat to the F-35s.

The purchase of the S-400 system has raised concerns in Western circles that Turkey may be drifting closer to Russia's sphere of influence. Ankara has refused to yield to pressure from Washington, insisting that choosing defense equipment is a matter of national sovereignty.

NATO, which includes Turkey as a member, is reportedly "concerned about the potential consequences" of the S-400 purchase. Members of the US Congress have repeatedly voiced opposition to the move and threatened sanctions.

The New York-based ratings firm, Fitch Ratings, downgraded Turkey's sovereign rating to "BB-" on Friday and warned of the potential significant impact of sanctions on investor sentiment.

The purchase of the S-400 system has been described as a political statement by some analysts, with Afzal Ashraf, a professor of conflict security at the University of Nottingham in the UK, stating that it demonstrates that the US does not have hegemony and control over NATO members.

Mustafa Adyin, from Turkey's Kadir Has University, noted that Turkey has said it is "totally free" to use the defense system as it sees fit, but the extent of the restrictions imposed by Russia in the deal remains unclear.

The ongoing situation between Turkey and the US could mark a new low in their already-tense relations. Last year, the US imposed sanctions on Turkey over the detention of an American pastor, triggering a Turkish currency crisis. The sanctions were later lifted upon the pastor's release.

Title: Quote Approval Becomes Standard Practice in Political Campaigns and Government Agencies

Article:

Quote approval has become a common practice in political campaigns and government agencies, particularly in high-level interviews. This is evident in the Obama campaign, where almost all mid-level aides and top strategists, including the campaign manager Jim Messina and senior White House adviser David Plouffe, have their quotes approved by the press office before they are released to the media. The Romney campaign also insists that journalists interviewing any of Mitt Romney's five sons agree to use only quotations that are approved by the press office.

The practice of quote approval is not limited to the political sphere. It is also prevalent in Washington and on the campaign trail. Officials who speak out of school, fearing off-message remarks, often shroud even the most innocuous and anodyne quotations in anonymity by insisting they be referred to as a "top Democrat" or a "Republican strategist."

This practice poses a double-edged sword for journalists, who are getting the on-the-record quotes they have long asked for, but are losing much of the spontaneity and authenticity in their interviews. The changes made to quotes are usually small and seemingly unnecessary, according to those who spoke on the record.

The Obama campaign declined to make Plouffe or Messina available to explain their media practices. The White House, on the other hand, has made a concerted effort to make more officials available to the news media, according to Jay Carney, the White House press secretary.

Both presidential campaigns are keenly aware of what can happen when they speak too freely. Damaging sound bites can live on in the news cycle for days, as evidenced by President Obama's "the private sector is doing fine" remark and Eric Fehrnstrom's "Etch A Sketch" comment.

Reporters who have covered the Obama presidency say the quote-approval process fits a pattern by this White House of finding new ways to limit its exposure in the news media. The White House's latest innovation is a variation of the background briefing called the "deep-background briefing," which it holds for groups of reporters, sometimes several dozen at a time. Reporters may paraphrase what senior administration officials say, but they are forbidden to put anything in quotation marks or identify the speakers.

Title: Sen. Joe Manchin to Meet with Senators over Expanded Background Checks Proposal

Article:

Sen. Joe Manchin (D-West Virginia), a co-author of the expanded background checks proposal, is set to meet with individual senators next week in an attempt to garner more support for the legislation. The key question Manchin wants answered is whether a "minimal change" to the compromise background check proposal he co-authored with Republican Sen. Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania would entice more senators to support it.

Since the proposal failed to gain enough support in a vote last month, senators who voted against it have been confronted in their states during the current recess by outside proponents of expanding background checks. Sen. Kelly Ayotte (R-New Hampshire) has been the most high-profile target of such confrontations.

Gun-control activists, including Erica Lafferty, the daughter of Dawn Hochsprung, a school principal slain in the Newtown massacre last December, have questioned senators and run ads against lawmakers who voted against the Toomey-Manchin compromise and have supported senators who supported it.

The pressure tactics appear to be working, with polls showing most Americans favoring some sort of new gun restrictions. In order to pass any legislation around the issue, gun control advocates need to find 60 votes in the Senate. Fifty-four senators backed the Manchin-Toomey amendment while 46 opposed it.

Manchin's prime targets to flip are all Republicans, including Sen. Ayotte, Sen. Jeff Flake of Arizona, Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Sen. Dean Heller of Nevada. Proponents hope that if Murkowski flips, those in favor of tightening gun laws will have a good shot at getting her fellow Alaskan, Sen. Mark Begich, to do the same. However, a source close to Begich told CNN that it is very unlikely that he would change his vote.

The NRA is likely to be a significant factor in any deal on background checks, much like it was during the last debate. After the compromise background check proposal failed, the NRA Institute for Legislative Action released a statement decrying the "misguided" amendment. The NRA is expected to be a powerful force at the upcoming NRA annual convention in Houston this weekend, with several potential 2016 GOP nominees in attendance, including Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, Texas Gov. Rick Perry, former Sen. Rick Santorum (R-Pennsylvania), and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker. Former vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin also spoke to the group.

Republican Sen. John McCain (R-Arizona), asked by one of the other victims of the Giffords shooting if he thought background checks would come up again, said there was a "50-50" chance that it would. A spokeswoman for Democratic Sen. Max Baucus (D-Montana), one of the more high-profile Democrats to vote against the provision, told CNN that if such a bill were to come up, "Max will evaluate it based on the feedback he gathers from the people of Montana, just as he always does with any legislation." However, she also said that in his first vote, "Montanans told Max loud and clear they did not support new gun controls in the previous bill."

Title: "Panama Papers Expose Offshore Financial Dealings of World Leaders and Celebrities"

Article:

The publication of the so-called "Panama Papers" on Monday has led to a global backlash, with legal investigations launched in several European countries and the Obama administration calling for greater transparency in the global financial system. The leak, orchestrated by a Washington-based investigative group, exposed the offshore financial dealings of dozens of wealthy, famous, and powerful individuals worldwide.

The anonymous leak of confidential records from a high-powered Panamanian law firm revealed financial schemes to create shell companies and hide billions of dollars in taxable income and profits. Leaders from Iceland, Ukraine, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Russia, and the United States are among those implicated in the massive document trove.

French President Francois Hollande said the revelations could be beneficial, stating, "These revelations are good news because they will increase tax revenues from those who commit fraud." The names and records of at least 29 individuals on Forbes magazine's 500 richest people list have been found in the files, which include financial spreadsheets, client records, corporate registries, passports, and other documents.

The records expose apparent shell company dealings by world-famous celebrities such as Argentine soccer star Lionel Messi and his father. They raise questions about the financial maneuverings of many international leaders, including Chinese President Xi Jinping's brother-in-law and Russian President Vladimir Putin's inner circle.

In the United Kingdom, Prime Minister David Cameron is under fire amid questions about his late father's tax avoidance. In Russia, the scandal faced an effective coverage ban, but heads are already beginning to roll in other nations, with outrage particularly fierce in Iceland, where thousands of protesters called for the ouster of Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson.

The records indicate that Mr. Gunnlaugsson co-owned a company called Wintris Inc., set up in 2007 on the Caribbean island of Tortola in the British Virgin Islands, to hold investments for his now-wife, Anna Sigurlaug Palsdottir.

Mossack Fonseca, the Panamanian law firm at the heart of the scandal, has vehemently denied any illegal activity. Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela issued a statement saying his government has "zero tolerance" for illicit financial activities and would cooperate "vigorously" with any judicial investigation arising from the leak of the law firm's documents.

Details of the leak came to light Sunday through a slew of articles published by an international coalition of media outlets that worked with the Washington-based International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) to examine Mossack Fonseca records. While the firm has more than 35 international operations, including an office in Las Vegas and a representative in Miami, it is one of the world's top five creators of shell companies, which can have legitimate business uses but can also be used to dodge taxes and launder money.

Major international banks, including HSBC, UBS, Credit Suisse, and Deutsche Bank, were named as having worked with the Panamanian law firm to create offshore accounts. Carlos Sousa, a spokesman for the firm, told reporters, "We have not once in nearly 40 years of operation been charged with criminal wrongdoing. We're proud of the work we do, notwithstanding recent and willful attempts by some to mischaracterize it."

Blaming Mossack Fonseca for what people do with their companies, firm co-founder Ramon Fonseca told Panamanian television last month, would be like blaming an automaker "for an accident or if the car was used in a robbery." The Munich-based German newspaper Suddeutsche Zeitung said it was offered the data more than a year ago through an encrypted channel by an anonymous source. The source sought unspecified security measures but no compensation, said Bastian Obermayer, a reporter for the paper. Suddeutsche Zeitung ultimately shared the data with the ICIJ, which enlisted other partners and hundreds of investigative journalists from around the world to examine the files.

In total, the documents reference some 214,488 companies and 14,153 clients of the Panamanian firm, according to the ICIJ. "It allows a never-before-seen view inside the offshore world—providing a day-to-day, decade-by-decade look at how dark money flows through the global financial system, breeding crime and stripping national treasuries of tax revenues," the ICIJ said in a statement on Sunday.

Title: Clinton Foundation Accepts Donations from Foreign Governments, Former President Defends Relationships with Middle Eastern Nations

Article:

In a speech at the Clinton Global Initiative University at Miami University in Coral Gables, Florida, former President Bill Clinton addressed the Clinton Foundation's decision to accept donations from foreign governments. The foundation's choice to accept such donations has been questioned by critics as a potential conflict of interest, particularly since some of the funds were received during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, a position she held until 2013.

Regarding donations from Middle Eastern nations such as the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, President Clinton stated, "I believe they do a lot more good than harm." He cited the governments' and donations' role in combating the self-declared Islamic State or ISIS.

However, The Miami Herald reported that not all of the funds complied with recent fundraising pacts with the White House, despite President Clinton's defense of the countries as friendly donors. The former president acknowledged that a $500,000 contribution from the Algerian government was not in compliance with the agreement.

President Clinton made no mention of his wife's recent controversy surrounding her use of a personal email account while working for the State Department. Critics argue this lack of transparency, despite Hillary Clinton's request for the release of her emails, shows a lack of commitment to transparency. The Herald outlined the difference between using a private account as opposed to a public server, stating that it was "impossible to know which emails, if any, were deleted or not turned over."

So far, over 55,000 pages of correspondence have been reviewed. The AP quoted Republican National Committee spokesman Michael Short, who accused Hillary Clinton of "hiding from the press and voters." He stated he believes she lives by her own set of ethical rules.

In an effort to address recent PR issues, the Clintons have selected Donna Shalala, Bill Clinton's former Secretary of Health and Human Services, as the next CEO of their large and widely-respected foundation. Shalala, a close friend and ally of the Clintons, has not shied away from criticizing some of the administration's policies.

Known for her candor in the Clinton administration, Shalala disagreed with President Clinton's decision to run the ill-fated health care task force, led by Hillary Clinton, from the White House. Shalala has been president of Miami University for 14 years and is an accomplished fundraiser, having secured over $3 billion during her time with the university.

During the event on Saturday, Hillary Clinton avoided the recent controversies, focusing instead on issues like the Affordable Care Act, Saturday's 50-year anniversary of the march in Selma, Alabama, and her work promoting equal rights for women. She is soon expected to release a report titled "No Ceiling," part of the larger "Not There" program addressing gender inequality.

Title: Trump Hires Brad Parscale as Campaign Manager for 2020 Re-election Bid

Article:

President Donald Trump has appointed Brad Parscale, the digital media director of his 2016 campaign, to manage his re-election bid, the campaign announced on Tuesday. The announcement was initially reported by The Drudge Report, a conservative news website with significant influence within the White House.

The President's decision to run for re-election in 2020 was not unexpected, as he filed for re-election shortly after his 2017 inauguration. However, it is unusual for a sitting president to hire a campaign manager three years before the election.

Sarah Sanders, the White House press secretary, stated in June 2017 that Trump was planning to run for re-election in 2020. Eric Trump, one of the President's sons, praised Parscale as an "amazing talent" who was "pivotal to our success in 2016."

"He has our family's complete trust and is the perfect person to be at the helm of the campaign," Eric Trump said in a campaign release. Jared Kushner, the President's son-in-law and senior adviser, added that Parscale was "essential in bringing a disciplined technology and data-driven approach to how the 2016 campaign was run."

The campaign also announced that it would be involved in the 2018 midterm election by providing candidates with general support, endorsements, and rallying the support of political grassroots by engaging Trump supporters in districts and states. The midterm elections will be crucial for the future of Trump's presidency, as the party in control of the presidency historically suffers sizable losses in the first election after winning the White House. Trump has already begun mentioning this trend in speeches, hoping to spur his supporters to buck history.

Parscale has remained active in his political operation, America First, since Trump took office. Parscale's Florida-based firm, Parscale Strategy, has a contract with the Republican National Committee to help grow its database of small donors, among other things.

Before joining the Trump campaign in 2015, Parscale had no experience in politics. He worked for the Trump Organization for several years, designing websites and helping develop digital strategy for Trump businesses.
