Despite going through three campaign managers during Trump's tumultuous presidential bid, Parscale, a close associate of Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, was a constant, quiet presence.

Parscale's formal title during the Trump 2016 campaign was digital director, but behind the scenes, he grew into a more significant role, directing campaign spending on television ads as well as digital, building a small dollar donor operation, and having significant influence on the overall campaign, working closely with then-Republican National Committee chief of staff Katie Walsh and the RNC's get-out-the-vote operation.

On digital advertising, Parscale brought Facebook employees into the campaign to better take advantage of social media to promote Trump and tear down Hillary Clinton. The unprecedented spending on digital media did not sit well with the candidate, who angrily questioned Parscale about how he was spending campaign cash during the campaign.

"I don't believe in this mumbo-jumbo digital stuff," Parscale recalled Trump screaming at him. Despite getting dressed down, he kept focused on digital media spending. In fact, during the last week of the campaign, he says he saw data showing movement in Trump's favor in what were considered likely wins for Clinton, and he pounced, moving money out of Virginia, where he did not think Trump could win, and Ohio, where he felt confident Trump would win, and into Michigan and Wisconsin.

Parscale has said that after Trump won, the President-elect thanked him and made clear he then understood the power of what he had called "mumbo jumbo digital stuff."

Parscale has repeatedly insisted he had no knowledge of the Russian operation to influence the 2016 campaign in favor of Trump and against Clinton. He says that is what he told congressional investigators behind closed doors last year when he went before the Senate and House intelligence committees looking into Russian meddling.

However, Parscale has been caught up in controversial actions involving Cambridge Analytica, a prominent conservative data firm that he hired to work for the Trump campaign. In 2016, Cambridge Analytica CEO Alexander Nix tried to reach WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to help take better political advantage of the hacked Clinton emails. The company says Nix never reached Assange, though CNN reported Nix wanted to create a searchable database of the Clinton emails.

Parscale says he had no knowledge of that, and has insisted the only reason he brought in Cambridge Analytica was because a digital expert he wanted to hire—Matt Oczkowski—was under contract there. Parscale ended up bringing more than a dozen Cambridge Analytica employees into the Trump campaign as analysts. Parscale says the campaign never used Cambridge Analytica's raw data.

The Trump campaign's data analytics operation is also under scrutiny by special counsel Robert Mueller, CNN reported in May 2017. Parscale gave private testimony to the House Intelligence Committee last year as part of its investigation of Russian meddling.

Title: Clearview AI's Client List Stolen in Data Breach

Article:

Controversial facial-recognition company Clearview AI has reported a data breach, with The Daily Beast revealing that an unauthorized individual gained access to the company's entire client list. Clearview AI's tool allows law enforcement agencies to search a database of billions of images scraped from social media to identify suspects using facial recognition technology.

The breach, which was first reported by The Daily Beast, did not result from a hack into Clearview AI's servers but from a "flaw" that granted unauthorized access to the company's client list. Tor Ekeland, Clearview AI's attorney, confirmed the report in a statement to ███.

In January, The New York Times reported that the company's customers included hundreds of law-enforcement agencies across the US and Canada, including the FBI and Department of Homeland Security. Clearview AI's service has also received inquiries from law-enforcement agencies worldwide, according to a spokesperson who spoke to ███ in February.

Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, and other companies have threatened legal action against Clearview AI, demanding the company stop scraping public images from their platforms to build its face database. Clearview AI's founder and CEO, Hoan Ton-That, responded by stating that gathering publicly accessible photos is protected by the US Constitution's First Amendment.

If Clearview AI's client list is leaked to the public, analysts warn, it could lead to even broader backlash against the company. "It will likely bring the public awareness, and mistrust, of facial recognition to a new level," Kjell Carlsson, an analyst with Forrester specializing in AI, told ███.

AI startup CEO Albert Liu told ███ that the fact that Clearview maintains a database of faces raises inherent security concerns, especially after this breach. "One of the major risks with AI software, despite how groundbreaking it is, is that it relies on these massive databases and the amount of sensitive information stored on these platforms," Liu said.

Title: Christian Right Joins Immigration Reform Movement

Article:

A new ally has emerged in the ongoing debate over immigration reform: the Christian right. Traditionally, religious conservatives have either stayed neutral or opposed immigration reform, but they are now actively advocating for change.

Ralph Reed, head of the Faith and Freedom Coalition, has reported a significant shift in support for immigration reform among social conservatives. Reed's group released a letter on Tuesday outlining broad goals for reform, such as keeping families together, reforming the visa system, and securing the border.

High-profile leaders are also joining the cause. Mathew Staver, vice president of Liberty University, and Focus on the Family, which has historically focused on issues like opposing abortion rights and gay marriage, are now supporting immigration reform. Focus on the Family is even using its radio broadcast, which reaches millions, to push its message.

Social conservatives are targeting GOP offices, aiming to provide political cover for lawmakers in the South, West, and Midwest who are concerned about potential backlash at the ballot box in 2014. The shift in dynamics could provide Republican lawmakers with the political support they need to vote in favor of a deal.

However, the unity of the groups may be tested as the debate becomes more politically charged, particularly on issues like border enforcement, citizenship, and immigration rights for gays and lesbians. For now, the focus seems to be on raising visibility among social conservatives.

A coalition of nearly a dozen groups, including Bread for the World, Esperanza, Christian Community Development Association, and the National Association of Evangelicals, has launched a 40-day "I was a stranger" campaign, asking parishioners to read a Bible verse dealing with immigrants each day.

"We've moved beyond the religious leadership in our country on the evangelical side to begin influencing more of the pews," said Noel Castellanos of CCDA. "We need to inform them and expose them the way we did with our pastors."

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidate Cory Booker Proposes Clemency Program for Nonviolent Drug Offenders

Article:

Democratic presidential hopeful Cory Booker has announced a plan to release thousands of nonviolent drug offenders from federal prisons, utilizing the president's pardon power to address perceived inequalities in the justice system. The senator from New Jersey, who is one of two dozen Democrats vying for their party's nomination for the 2020 presidential election, aims to implement a comprehensive clemency program targeting individuals serving "unjust and excessive sentences" for drug crimes, including marijuana-related offenses.

Booker's proposal builds upon his longstanding focus on criminal justice reform. He was instrumental in the passage of the First Step Act, a bipartisan bill signed into law last year by President Donald Trump, which eased minimum sentences for drug crimes that disproportionately affected minorities.

In announcing the proposal, Booker stated, "The War on Drugs has been a war on people, tearing families apart, ruining lives, and disproportionately affecting people of color and low-income individuals—all without making us safer." Booker, who is African-American and a Yale-educated lawyer, previously served as the mayor of Newark, one of New Jersey's poorest cities.

The United States has the highest incarceration rate of any country in the world, according to researchers. Under Booker's plan, more than 11,000 people serving time for marijuana offenses would be eligible for clemency. Booker's campaign noted that while marijuana use is roughly equally prevalent across races, black people are nearly four times as likely to be arrested as white people for its use.

In addition, nearly 4,000 inmates serving the kind of minimum sentences now reduced under the First Step Act could receive clemency, as well as prisoners serving more time as a result of sentencing disparities between crack and powder cocaine.

Booker's proposal calls for an executive panel to review eligible cases. While the panel would start from a presumption of recommending clemency, it would decline any cases in which the defendant poses a threat to the public. The process would be more efficient than the current system, which includes a series of steps through the Justice Department and the White House Counsel's office.

Other Democratic candidates have weighed in on clemency, most notably U.S. Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, who proposed establishing an advisory board to streamline the process and focus primarily on drug offenders. U.S. Senator Kamala Harris of California, like Klobuchar a former prosecutor, has also stated she would look to pardon low-level drug offenders.

In 2014, President Barack Obama launched a more limited clemency initiative that encouraged certain nonviolent drug offenders serving mandatory minimum sentences to apply.

Booker is currently averaging between 2 and 3 percent in public polling, placing him around seventh place in the crowded field of candidates.

Title: Treasury and Federal Reserve Lend Minimal Amounts Under $500 Billion Coronavirus Aid Fund, Oversight Report Says

WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department and Federal Reserve have lent hardly any money under a $500 billion fund created by the economic rescue law passed in response to the coronavirus crisis, according to a new report from a congressional oversight panel. The report, issued Monday by the Congressional Oversight Commission, contains mostly questions about how the Treasury fund is going to function.

So far, only one of the new Fed programs has started operating, a lending fund likely to be tapped by large public companies. The program was started on May 11 with $37.5 billion from Treasury. The economic rescue law, also known as the Cares Act, imposed a number of restrictions on the use of the Treasury fund.

The report states that the Federal Reserve is setting up a Main Street Lending Program intended to facilitate lending by banks to small and medium-size businesses. The program would support lending up to $600 billion, with Treasury providing $75 billion to offset any potential losses. That program also has not disbursed any money, the report said.

The economic rescue law includes $46 billion to make loans and loan guarantees to the airline industry, which has been hit hard by the pandemic as air traffic has come to a near halt. None of that money has been disbursed.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is pledging to reveal names and other details of entities that borrow from emergency programs the central bank has set up to offset the economic hit from the pandemic. In prepared testimony for a Tuesday congressional hearing, Powell says the Fed will disclose amounts borrowed and interest rates levied under programs to provide credit for large corporations, state and local governments, and medium-sized businesses.

The Treasury Secretary, Steven Mnuchin, is set to testify along with Powell on Tuesday before the Senate Banking Committee. In prepared testimony, Mnuchin states that the Paycheck Protection Program to provide forgiveable loans to small businesses has processed more than 4.2 million loans worth over $530 billion. The program is working "to keep tens of millions of hardworking Americans on the payroll," Mnuchin says. The loans don't have to be paid back as long as the borrower uses 75% of the money to cover payroll.

Title: Investigators Search Saudi Consulate for Evidence in Khashoggi Disappearance; Pompeo Meets with Saudi Leaders

Article:

Investigators in Turkey have been searching the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul for traces of "toxic materials" in connection with the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to Turkish media reports. The search comes as U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo arrived in Saudi Arabia for talks regarding the matter.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan revealed some details about the consulate search while speaking to journalists on Tuesday, according to the Associated Press, citing Turkey's NTV. The AP also cited a high-level Turkish official as saying that during the search, "certain evidence" was found by police, proving that Khashoggi was killed at the consulate. However, the official did not elaborate on the nature of this evidence.

The announcements came as Khashoggi's family released a statement expressing their concern over his disappearance. The activist and opinion columnist, who was a critic of the Saudi government, was last seen entering the Saudi consulate on Oct. 2, reportedly to obtain documents related to his upcoming marriage to a Turkish woman.

Saudi Arabia, which has repeatedly claimed Khashoggi walked out of the building on his own, is now reportedly considering whether to say that rogue intelligence operatives murdered him by mistake during an interrogation.

In the family's statement, they expressed their anxiety and trauma over Khashoggi's disappearance. "Our family is traumatized and yearns to be together during this painful time," the statement said. "The strong moral and legal responsibility which our father instilled in us obliges us to call for the establishment of an independent and impartial international commission to inquire into the circumstances of his death."

In addition to the consulate search that took place on Monday, a Turkish official revealed on Tuesday that the top Saudi diplomat's home in Istanbul will also be investigated. The official did not specify when the search will occur, but Turkish media has reported that the diplomat, Mohammed al-Otaibi, left the country on an afternoon flight just hours after it was announced.

Surveillance footage leaked to Turkish media showed that shortly after Khashoggi disappeared, vehicles were seen moving between the consulate and the diplomat's home, according to the Associated Press.

Pompeo, who is currently meeting with Saudi King Salman over the Khashoggi case, arrived in Riyadh on Tuesday. "The Secretary and the King discussed a number of regional and bilateral issues," State Department spokesperson Heather Nauert said. "The Secretary also thanked the King for his commitment to supporting a thorough, transparent, and timely investigation of Jamal Khashoggi's disappearance."

Pompeo also met with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who is accused of ordering Khashoggi's detention. "We are strong and old allies," he told Pompeo. "So we face our challenges together, the past, the day of, tomorrow."

Title: Jared Kushner and Mike Rogers at Odds in Trump Transition Team

Article:

The transition team of President-elect Donald Trump is experiencing internal disagreements, with Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and close adviser, and former Congressman Mike Rogers at odds, according to multiple sources speaking to CNN. Trump, however, tweeted Tuesday night that the process was "very organized."

In a tweet, Trump said, "Very organized process taking place as I decide on Cabinet and many other positions. I am the only one who knows who the finalists are!"

Rogers, who had been working on the transition team for months under Chris Christie, was sidelined as the campaign and transition merged into one presidential team. Rogers, who chaired the House Intelligence Committee while in Congress and is an Army veteran and former FBI agent with an expertise in national security, was told Monday on the phone that he was out, according to a source familiar with the transition.

Rogers, in a statement to reporters, positively described his time with the transition team as a "privilege" and said he was handing off his responsibilities as a national security adviser to the transition organization to Vice President-elect Mike Pence and "the stellar new leadership team."

Speaking to CNN's Anderson Cooper Tuesday night, Rogers said, "Sometimes in politics... there are people who are in and people who are out. And the people who have been asked to move on have some relationship with Chris Christie."

Kushner has been rubbing allies the wrong way in his recent efforts to purge the transition team of Christie associates, sources say. Kushner's father was prosecuted by then-US Attorney Christie in 2004 for tax evasion, witness tampering, and illegal campaign contributions.

However, a longtime Christie associate cautioned that there was no "purge" of Christie staff, and that such a characterization is "overblown." While some Christie staff have left, others are continuing on with the transition team. A high-ranking Trump insider said the so-called "purge" focused only on lobbyists.

Rogers' departure was first reported by Bloomberg. Rogers' participation in the transition team was seen as a heartening sign for traditional GOP national security advisers. Rogers has been critical of Russia's role in recent hacking episodes, including the hacks of Democratic political groups during the election, which the US government attributed to high levels of Russian government. Trump repeatedly declined to acknowledge Russia's role, saying the evidence was inconclusive.

Amid the churn in Trump's transition team, the Obama White House Tuesday night said it's moving forward with a broader sharing of information. "We received the MOU signed by Vice President-elect Pence this evening," said Brandi Hoffine, a White House spokesperson. "The next step is for the President-elect's transition team to provide us with the names of the individuals they have authorized to represent their transition effort across the government. Once we have received those names and related materials, those individuals will be able to receive the briefing materials we have prepared and begin to communicate with their Obama administration agency counterparts as we continue our work to facilitate the transition to the next administration."

Title: Congress Averts Government Shutdown, Temporarily Funds Federal Agencies Through January 19

Article:

In a swift move on Thursday, the U.S. Congress managed to avert a government shutdown, sending a bill to President Donald Trump that provides temporary funding for federal agencies until January 19. The House of Representatives and Senate passed the hastily written bill by votes of 231-188 and 66-32, respectively, as lawmakers eagerly began a holiday recess until January 3.

The bill, which will keep agencies operating during the three-month-old fiscal year, is a precursor to a more comprehensive "omnibus" spending bill intended to fund the government from January 19 through September 30. Negotiators have been grappling with contentious issues such as defense-spending increases versus increases for other domestic programs, including medical research, opioid treatment, and "anti-terrorism" activities.

Fiscal hawks are displeased with Congress's decision to once again exceed spending caps designed to curb mounting federal debt. However, some of these same lawmakers earlier in the week voted for a sweeping tax bill that will add $1.5 trillion over the next 10 years to a national debt that already stands at $20 trillion.

Democrats in the House and Senate made a strong push for including protections for young immigrants who entered the country illegally as children, commonly known as "Dreamers." In the end, the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and immigration advocacy groups failed to secure these protections. Nearly all of the House's 193 Democrats and 29 of the Senate's 46 Democrats voted no, in part to protest the lack of action on the immigration measure.

The Senate also put the brakes on another bill that passed the House, which would provide $81 billion in new disaster aid to help Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and several states hit by this year's hurricanes or wildfires. The temporary spending bill does, however, give Trump a modest increase of $4.7 billion for the Department of Defense to be used for missile defense and ship repair.

The bill includes funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program through March, as well as funding for community health centers and the Indian Health Service. The plan also extends the National Security Agency's expiring internet surveillance program, known as Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, through January 19. Other provisions address funding for veterans, the Coast Guard, and flood insurance. Most government programs would be temporarily extended until January 19 at fiscal 2017 levels.

Title: Speaker Paul Ryan Breaks with Donald Trump, Refuses to Support the Republican Nominee

Article:

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan, the highest-ranking Republican in the United States, has refused to support Donald Trump as the party's nominee, marking a significant departure from the brash New York billionaire. In a bombshell interview with CNN, Ryan expressed his reservations about Trump's adherence to conservative values, limited government, and the Constitution.

Ryan's decision, made swiftly after Trump clinched the Republican nomination, was unexpected, as Ryan had been preparing for a contested convention at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland. The speaker's decision could potentially influence the outcome of the 2016 election, particularly for the 200-plus Republicans up for reelection, especially those in swing districts.

The Ryan-Trump relationship will now take center stage, potentially forcing Trump to prove his mettle on Capitol Hill. Trump's team is already trying to set up meetings in Washington, and Ryan's orbit is open to an audience with the presumptive nominee.

For the past four months, Ryan has watched Trump's rise in the polls warily, expressing opposition to Trump's stance on issues such as a ban on Muslims in the U.S., white supremacists, and free-trade agreements. Ryan's decision to break ranks with Trump was not due to any particular policy but rather opposition to Trump's principles, according to a source familiar with Ryan's thinking.

Ryan's move comes just hours after Trump tweeted "I love Hispanics!" along with a picture of him eating a taco bowl, not exactly the kind of fence-mending with the growing Hispanic voting bloc that GOP brass had in mind for Trump's general election pivot.

Ryan has ruled out launching a presidential bid this year, and giving Trump the cold shoulder is unlikely to change that calculus. However, the speaker has acknowledged that a bid in 2020 is possible, and this decision could be part of an effort to pick up the pieces if Republicans lose the White House this fall.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's positioning on the party's standard-bearer is more muddled compared to Ryan's. McConnell has committed to supporting the nominee chosen by Republican voters, but has not explicitly endorsed Trump.

Title: White House Proposes $15 Billion in Federal Spending Cuts, Including CHIP Funds

Article:

The White House will send a proposal to the House of Representatives on Tuesday, aiming to cut federal spending by $15 billion. The proposal, if approved, would see roughly half of the cuts coming from the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), a senior administration official stated on Monday.

The proposed cuts, often referred to as "rescissions," involve funds that were authorized by Congress but not spent. The plan is a shift from earlier discussions about rescinding funds that were part of a sweeping $1.3 trillion spending bill enacted in March. This proposal would instead seek to rescind funds that were authorized in previous fiscal years but not spent.

The most controversial element of the proposal is likely to be the $7 billion in proposed cuts to the Children's Health Insurance Program. The federal-state program provides health coverage to more than eight million low-income, uninsured children whose family incomes are too high to qualify for Medicaid.

The White House proposal would rescind $7 billion from that program, of which $5 billion would come from funds where the authority to spend them has expired. An additional $2 billion would come from a contingency fund that isn't projected to be tapped by states, the senior administration official said.

Democrats have criticized the proposal, stating that the contingency funds are necessary in case CHIP enrollment were to surge unexpectedly and the program, whose funding isn't open-ended, suddenly needed more money.

Under the Impoundment Control Act of 1974, President Donald Trump will be able to temporarily freeze funding for 45 days, but can't rescind it on his own unless Congress agrees. His proposal will head first to the House. Once drafted into a bill, the rescissions package can be considered under an expedited process and would only need a simple majority to pass both chambers.

The White House also plans to propose cutting funds that were previously authorized for two technology loan programs, rolling back funds set aside for responding to the 2014-2016 Ebola outbreak, now declared over, for a railroad unemployment-insurance-benefits program that expired, and for Hurricane Sandy-related emergency watershed programs.

Some lawmakers have expressed doubts that rolling back funds that haven't been spent wouldn't affect agencies. The final outcome of the proposal remains uncertain, as Congress isn't required to take action in response to the President's proposal of spending cuts. If lawmakers haven't taken any action, the funding would remain intact, according to the Congressional Research Service.

Title: Fact-Checking Claims Made During the Vice Presidential Debate

Article:

During the vice presidential debate, several claims made by both Mike Pence and Tim Kaine were fact-checked for accuracy.

Republican Mike Pence stated, "The fact that under this past administration, we've almost doubled the national debt is atrocious...Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want more of the same." However, as a share of the total U.S. economy, the national debt has increased by 35 percent, not a doubling. The national debt currently stands at $19.6 trillion. This increase is largely due to efforts by the Obama administration to combat the Great Recession. The Clinton plan, with its tax increases, would increase the gross debt by $450 billion over 10 years, according to an analysis by the independent Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. Donald Trump's tax-cut-heavy plan, on the other hand, would increase the gross debt by $4.3 trillion, nearly 10 times more than Clinton's plan.

Democrat Tim Kaine stated, "Donald Trump does not have a plan." Clinton also does not have a materially different plan than what President Barack Obama is already doing. Clinton has described a three-part strategy to combat the Islamic State, which includes crushing IS on its home turf, disrupting its infrastructure on the ground and online, and protecting America and its allies. All of these elements are currently part of the Obama administration's strategy, so it is not clear what would change or if Clinton would accelerate any portions of it.

Pence, in calling Clinton the "architect of the Obama administration's foreign policy," said the crisis in Syria was the result of a "failed and weak foreign policy that Hillary Clinton helped lead." However, Clinton, as secretary of state, actually pushed for increased U.S. intervention after Syrian President Bashar Assad used chemical weapons against rebels. Obama is the commander in chief, and nothing has swayed him thus far. Whatever Clinton's failings might be on foreign policy, it is a stretch to accuse her of helping to lead a weak policy on Syria.

Pence also stated, "We've seen an economy stifled by more taxes, more regulation, a war on coal." The coal industry's woes do not come solely from onerous federal regulations. Pence omitted the effects of steep competition from cheap natural gas. A string of major coal companies have filed for bankruptcy in recent years, including Arch Coal, Alpha Natural Resources, and Peabody Energy. Layoffs and cutbacks have spread economic suffering through coal country in the Appalachians and Wyoming's Powder River Basin. By contrast, these are boom times for natural gas extraction, mostly due to hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

Pence also stated, "I'm proud that 'the state of Indiana has balanced budgets.'" This is true, but a balanced budget is required by law, as it is in every state except Vermont.

Title: Jeb Bush's Immigration Stance: A Shift in Conservative Immigration Policy

Article:

In a recent profile published by The Weekly Standard, Andrew Ferguson suggests that Jeb Bush's political record in Florida indicates a more conservative stance than the national press and right-leaning activists perceive. Ferguson posits that Bush, while currently presenting as a moderate, may be a self-conscious, deep-dyed conservative.

While Ferguson's piece does not delve deeply into Bush's immigration reform stance, a video from Bush's Right to Rise PAC, titled "Conservative," offers insight into this area. The video showcases highlights from Bush's speech at CPAC, where he states, "There is no plan to deport 11 million people. We should give them a path to legal status where they work, where they do not receive government benefits, where they do not break the law, where they learn English, and where they make a contribution to our society."

This statement, contrasting with the immigration stances of other likely 2016 Republican candidates, indicates a more progressive approach to immigration reform. For instance, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has publicly stressed his opposition to "amnesty," while reportedly expressing support for a path to legal status in private conversations with elites.

Bush, however, is taking an opposite approach, not only publicly advocating for legal status but also arguing that it is the true conservative position on immigration reform. This positioning allows Bush to challenge his party's base, which is generally opposed to immigration reform that legalizes the status of unauthorized immigrants, while maintaining his conservative credentials.

By taking a more progressive stance on immigration, Bush can appear moderate to both the press and activists during the general election, as he does not need to emphasize moderation in other areas. This strategy is unusual in today's highly polarized political climate, as candidates typically avoid challenging their party's base.

However, it is essential to note that Bush's overall governing record is considered very conservative by both liberals and conservatives. In an interesting sense, Bush's immigration stance allows him to present as a moderate on one issue while maintaining his conservative identity, as his record demonstrates.

Title: Obama Defends Free Speech at United Nations, Emphasizes Importance of Freedom of Expression

Article:

President Barack Obama delivered a robust defense of free speech rights during a high-profile speech to the United Nations Tuesday, addressing the value of freedom of expression following the controversy sparked by an anti-Muslim video.

In his speech to the United Nations General Assembly, Obama emphasized the importance of free speech in the United States, stating that the U.S. Constitution protects the right to practice free speech. He also addressed recent criticism from Republicans who have accused him of failing to stand up for "American values" in response to the protests.

"I know there are some who ask why we don't just ban such a video," Obama said. "The answer is enshrined in our laws: Our Constitution protects the right to practice free speech."

Obama further explained that Americans have fought and died to protect the right of all people to express their views, even those that are offensive or disagreeable. He argued that efforts to suppress free expression are increasingly ineffective in an interconnected world.

"I know that not all countries in this body share this understanding of the protection of free speech," Obama said. "Yet in 2012, at a time when anyone with a cell phone can spread offensive views around the world with the click of a button, the notion that we can control the flow of information is obsolete."

The president made little mention of Afghanistan during his speech, devoting only a clause to a recent suicide bombing and a sentence to promising that "America and our allies will end our war on schedule in 2014."

Obama began his address with a tribute to Chris Stevens, the U.S. ambassador to Libya, who was killed earlier this month along with three other Americans in an attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi. The president sought to harness sympathy and outrage over the attack by describing it as a strike on diplomats of all nations and on the entire civilized world.

"The attacks of the last two weeks are not simply an assault on America," Obama said. "They are also an assault on the very ideals upon which the United Nations was founded."

The president's speech came amid fresh GOP attacks for his decision to delegate one-on-one meetings with world leaders to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, even as Obama made time Monday for a taping of "The View." Obama's forceful defense of free speech rights included a civics-class-style explanation of why allowing offensive speech and confronting it with other speech is preferable to trying to ban objectionable speech outright.

Title: Rubio's Shift on Immigration: From Advocate to Hardliner

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who once advocated for a comprehensive immigration reform bill, is now taking a harder line on illegal immigration. This shift in stance has left immigration activists, including Gaby Pacheco, who he consulted with two years ago, perplexed.

Rubio, a potential 2016 Republican presidential candidate, has abandoned the bill he co-authored and is now calling for an end to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which allows individuals like Pacheco to remain in the United States.

"It's another Marco Rubio that I just don't know," Pacheco said.

After experiencing a decline in political standing among conservatives who were critical of his immigration advocacy, Rubio is now focusing on border security, a stance more in line with GOP activists who hold significant influence in the selection of a White House nominee.

Last month, Rubio urged President Barack Obama not to take actions that would shield millions of people who entered the U.S. illegally. He argued that Congress should first "make real progress on stemming the tide of illegal immigration."

Immigrant advocates contend that Rubio's emphasis on border security and dismissal of his own bill amounts to a switch in sides in the heated immigration debate. However, Rubio's aides claim that he has always emphasized border security and insisted on tougher enforcement measures.

The shift in stance comes as potential 2016 rivals such as Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Rand Paul of Kentucky, who voted against the overhaul that Rubio helped write, take hard-line stands on immigration.

Rubio has begun visiting South Carolina and Iowa, early-voting states in the 2016 nominating calendar where immigration is a significant issue for White House hopefuls. In these appearances, Rubio has embraced GOP calls to bolster security and deploy the National Guard along the Mexican border in response to the arrival of tens of thousands of Central Americans.

Rubio was the only potential GOP candidate who helped write the immigration bill, which would strengthen border security while also offering a path to citizenship for many of the 11.5 million people who are in the U.S. illegally. Now, the party committee working to elect Republicans to the Senate is using that bill, which more than a dozen Republicans support, in ads to attack Democrats as pro-"amnesty."

The bill remains unpopular among some in the Republican base, and Rubio's popularity has plummeted in public polls. However, last month, Rubio won applause from conservatives in South Carolina when he scolded immigration activists for interrupting his speech at a Republican fundraiser.

In a series of appearances on Fox News and conservative talk radio, Rubio has emphasized the need for border security and the deployment of the National Guard along the Mexican border. When asked about his stance on a House bill that would phase out DACA, Rubio expressed concerns about the "unintended consequences" for youths who have already come forward and obtained work permits. Nevertheless, he said, "I certainly think at some point that will have to end too."

Title: Democrats' Uninterested in Viewing Unredacted Mueller Report Despite Calls for Transparency

Article:

Despite demands from Democrats for Attorney General William Barr to release the full unredacted report by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, key Democratic lawmakers have shown little interest in viewing the report themselves. In a move towards transparency, Barr allowed a dozen members of Congress, six Democrats and six Republicans, to access the report with most of the redactions removed.

While grand jury material had to be redacted to comply with federal requirements, this version of the report does include classified information, materials related to ongoing investigations, and information that could damage the reputations of individuals not charged with crimes.

Prior to the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing with Barr last week, only two lawmakers had taken advantage of the opportunity, and both were Republicans. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham and Representative Doug Collins, the ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee, reviewed the unredacted information, and both said the new details did not change their assessment of the report in any way.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler were also granted access to the document. Despite being some of the most vocal critics of the way Barr handled the release of the report, none of them bothered to review the information that they claim is so critical. Not even the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Dianne Feinstein, deigned to read the less redacted version of the report prior to the attorney general testifying in front of her own panel.

Since the Democrats are so determined for the public to have access to the unredacted report, along with all the underlying evidence no less, their unanimous refusal to inspect the redacted information themselves raises some serious questions about their true motives in making such a fuss about the release of the full report. The Democrats had evidently "boycotted en masse" the opportunity to review the unredacted report because they wanted Barr to also remove legally required redactions of grand jury material and grant access to a broader array of lawmakers.

However, that is just a sad excuse for their behavior. It is now abundantly clear, if it was not already, that the Democrats no longer truly believe there is anything significant hiding behind the redactions in the special counsel report. If they did then it would be grossly negligent of the Democrats to deliberately keep themselves in the dark about all those hidden details.

In fact, it increasingly appears that the Democrats would prefer that Barr never release the unredacted report at all. So long as the redactions are in place, they can keep making baseless insinuations about a nonexistent cover-up. That is why the Democrats who have a chance to do not want to read the unredacted report because without actually seeing it, they do not have to lie about it to fit their narrative. They can let their imaginations run wild and simply claim ignorance in case the truth ever does get out.

Barr has bent over backwards to satisfy the Democrats with all of their purported concerns about the redactions, but they have only escalated their attacks on his character in response to each concession that he has made. Until the Democrats are willing to find out the truth for themselves, they have no business telling the public that the redactions are shielding something nefarious. By their own choice, the top Democrats in Congress are as ignorant as everybody else. The reality is there is nothing there.

Madison Gesiotto, an attorney and a commentator who serves with the advisory board of the Donald Trump campaign, stated, "The Democrats who have a chance to do not want to read the unredacted report because without actually seeing it, they do not have to lie about it to fit their narrative. They can let their imaginations run wild and simply claim ignorance in case the truth ever does get out." Gesiotto is on Twitter @ MadisonGesiotto.

Title: Obama Shifts Focus to Middle Class, Economic Policies in Major Speech

Article:

In a speech billed as a reset after a series of political stumbles and a string of bad economic news, President Barack Obama focused on the middle class and economic policies during a major address on Thursday. The speech, delivered at Cuyahoga Community College outside Cleveland, Ohio, marked a shift in the president's campaign strategy, with the only new line being a call for voters to break the partisan deadlock in Washington.

The president emphasized his role as the champion of the middle class and warned of the potential economic consequences of Mitt Romney's proposed policies if the Republican presidential nominee were to be elected. Obama claimed that Romney's economic plan consists mainly of trillions of dollars more in tax cuts, severe spending cuts, and deregulation of corporations. However, he asserted that Romney's plan would not protect middle-income workers and would jeopardize programs that help them pay their bills, keep down health care costs, and send their children to college.

Mitt Romney delivered a stinging rebuke of President Obama's economic record earlier in the day in Cincinnati, accusing the president of being "long on words and short on action" with unemployment figures still above 8 percent. Romney criticized Obama for not delivering a recovery for the economy and for his recent comments that "the private sector is doing fine."

The president's re-election campaign decided to have Obama deliver a major economic address, as they believe he has not delivered a recovery for the economy. Romney stated, "He's going to be saying today that he wants four more years, but he may have forgotten he talked about a one-term proposition if he couldn't get the economy turned around in three years."

The president's speech at the same community college where Bill Clinton gave a campaign speech in 2010 was billed as a pivotal moment for the campaign, a way to regain the offensive after a rough couple of weeks following May's dismal jobs report, Governor Scott Walker's victory in the Wisconsin recall election, and the president's Friday comments that "the private sector is doing fine."

Obama made light of his recent political misstep at the beginning of his speech, acknowledging the criticism he has received for blaming former President George W. Bush and the economic crisis he inherited from his predecessor. However, the president hewed closely to that theme, denouncing the Bush-era economic and policy choices that he said Romney and Republicans support, which led to the global economic crisis of late 2008.

The crowd of roughly 1,500 chanted "Four more years" and "Fired up and ready to go" at the beginning of the speech and at times during it. However, there were few rousing applause lines, and at times the hour-long remarks seemed to ramble and repeat various refrains the president has been pushing for months, including his desire to "double-down on" spending on clean energy, technology, infrastructure, and education as a way to help boost the economy.

Both Obama's and Romney's campaigns have invested heavily in Ohio, and their dueling visits on Thursday demonstrate just how strongly the two are competing for the state's 18 electoral votes. Ohio has played a critical role in determining the winner in the past few presidential contests, with Obama winning the state in 2008, and George W. Bush taking it in 2004. No Republican has ever won the White House without carrying Ohio.

Polls show the two men running neck and neck in Ohio, with Obama ahead by a statistically insignificant 1 percentage point. However, Ohio, whose unemployment rate is 7.4 percent—nearly a full point below the national average—is faring better than many other areas of the country. The Obama team is eager to credit the auto bailout as one of the reasons for Ohio's relative economic stability.

"When my opponent was arguing that we should let Detroit go bankrupt, we made a bet on American ingenuity, and today our auto industry is back," Obama said. The president planned to spend the evening at a star-studded fundraiser in Manhattan at the home of Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick and co-hosted by Anna Wintour.

Title: FBI Documents Detail Clinton's Unrecalled Details During Email Server Interview

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, reportedly stated approximately three dozen times during an extensive FBI interview that she could not recall specific details or events related to her use of a private email server while serving as secretary of state. The FBI's interview, which concluded the agency's investigation without recommending criminal charges, was detailed in documents released on Friday.

The documents reveal that Clinton could not recall specific emails and details of briefings on handling classified information. The FBI noted that Clinton recalled being briefed on Specific Access Program (SAP) information but could not recall any specific briefings on handling information associated with the SAPs.

The documents also address Clinton's use of her BlackBerry after being advised about the risks of using her personal device. Clinton reportedly requested a secured BlackBerry while at State but could not recall why they were unable to provide one.

In December 2012, Clinton suffered a concussion from a fall and later developed a blood clot. The documents do not provide further details about this incident.

Campaign spokesman Brian Fallon stated after the documents were released, "While her use of a single email account was clearly a mistake and she has taken responsibility for it, these materials make clear why the Justice Department believed there was no basis to move forward with this case."

Jason Miller, spokesman for Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump, commented that the files "reinforce Clinton's tremendously bad judgment and dishonesty."

The documents show Clinton repeatedly claimed to have little training or understanding about the classification process, despite leading the department that handled such information on a regular basis and having a security clearance. The document dump also revealed gaps in the record, with numerous sections redacted and the FBI unable to obtain 13 Clinton mobile devices and two iPads that may have been used to send emails from her personal email address.

Clinton claimed to have relied on the judgment of her aides and other officials to handle classified material appropriately. She also stated that she did not know the meaning of the "C" marking before a paragraph in an email marked "Confidential," and when asked about different classification types like "Top Secret," Clinton could not recall the details.

The FBI document notes that the email in question was in fact marked "classified at the Confidential level." Clinton's server was found to have more than 2,000 emails with classified material, most of which were retroactively classified. However, FBI Director James Comey has disputed Clinton's insistence that none of them were marked as such at the time. Clinton has repeatedly stated that her use of private email was allowed. In July, she told FBI investigators she "did not explicitly request permission to use a private server or email address."

Title: President Obama Urges Support for Gun Control Package as Proposal Faces Resistance in Congress

Article:

President Barack Obama moved to rally support for a gun control package facing resistance in the Senate on Thursday, urging voters to pressure Congress into backing the proposal. In a speech at the White House, Obama expressed concern that the shock from the Newtown elementary school shooting could soon fade.

"Less than 100 days ago, that happened," Obama said. "Shame on us if we've forgotten." He added, "I haven't forgotten those kids. Shame on us if we've forgotten."

The president's remarks were made in the presence of the mothers of shooting victims, and he called on wavering lawmakers to "not get squishy." He accused opponents of drumming up "fear" and urged supporters to call members of Congress and pressure them into backing the package.

Republican Senator Mike Lee of Utah criticized the president for his remarks, suggesting he was exploiting the Newtown tragedy. "The proposals the president is calling for Congress to pass would primarily serve to reduce the constitutionally protected rights of law-abiding citizens while having little or no effect on violent crime," Lee said in a statement.

Senator Lee and his conservative colleagues plan to ensure that any firearms proposals require a 60-vote threshold in order to proceed, which could be a high hurdle for the Senate to clear. Already, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has dropped a proposal to renew and expand the expired assault weapons ban from the main package.

The base bill will instead cover universal background checks, strengthened punishments for illegal trafficking, and more money for school security. Items like school security enjoy broad support, but the move to include private sales—including gun show purchases—in the background check system remains controversial in some circles. The assault weapons ban, which Republicans most adamantly oppose, is still expected to get a vote as an amendment to the main bill.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) criticized the latest Obama push, accusing him of campaigning "against guns to please the fringe." New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg recently launched a $12 million ad buy in support of the legislation.

"It's not done until it's done," Obama said Thursday. "There are some powerful voices on the other side that are interested in running out the clock, or changing the subject... They're doing everything they can to make all our progress collapse under the weight of fear and frustration."

Title: President Obama's Statement on International Day to End Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists

Article:

In a statement issued over the weekend, former U.S. President Barack Obama recognized the first-annual International Day to End Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists. The day aims to highlight the critical role of a free press in fostering prosperous, open, and secure societies.

Obama emphasized the importance of a free press, stating that it allows citizens to access information and hold their governments accountable. He referenced the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which upholds the right to "seek, receive, and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers."

The former president acknowledged the risks journalists take daily, with hundreds killed in the past decade and countless more harassed, threatened, imprisoned, and tortured. In the majority of these cases, the perpetrators remain unpunished.

Obama called for governments to protect the freedom of journalists to write and speak freely. He commended the contributions of journalists, praising their role in shedding light on corruption, asking tough questions, and bearing witness to the plight of innocent people.

However, it is important to note that President Obama's relationship with the media has been a subject of controversy. Some reporters, including those from The New York Times, The Washington Post, USA Today, and others, have characterized him as the most anti-free press, "control freak" president in history. Critics point to his use of the Espionage Act to prosecute more sources than any other president and the monitoring of journalists' phones and emails by his Department of Justice.

According to the Reporters Without Borders Press Freedom Index, the United States currently ranks 46th, behind countries such as Botswana, Ghana, and the United Kingdom. This suggests that, despite the statement, concerns about press freedom in the U.S. persist.

Title: Impeachment Evidentiary Challenges Faced by Democrats in the Trump Investigation

Article:

The second volume of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report has highlighted an obstacle that impeachers may face: the requirement of proving corrupt intent in cases of obstruction of justice. According to Mueller, the obstruction-of-justice statute necessitates both obstructive acts and corrupt intent. While corrupt intent can often be inferred from the alleged conduct, it might not be possible when there is a plausible legitimate governmental motive for an official's actions. In such cases, the element of corrupt intent must be established separately, which presents a difficult evidentiary challenge.

Mueller left the question of President Donald Trump's intent for Congress to decide. The Constitution grants the House and the Senate the power to determine what constitutes "Treason, Bribery, or other High Crimes and Misdemeanors." In the current Congress, removing Trump would require the votes of 20 Republican senators, assuming all Democrats and independents voted in favor. This high hurdle is due to Trump's guarded support among Republican senators.

Despite this potential vulnerability, the Democrats have failed to carry this reduced burden. The evidence presented in the impeachment inquiry, primarily concerning President Trump's dealings with Ukraine, has left Democrats with the task of proving that any personal benefit derived from these acts was not merely incidental but was the purpose of the acts. This daunting evidentiary challenge has led Democrats to search for more promising grounds for impeachment.

However, the grounds they have alighted on, such as the alleged conditioning of aid to Ukraine and a White House meeting on a personal favor, also present an evidentiary challenge. The question remains whether the personal political benefit was the primary purpose or merely incidental to a legitimate government purpose. This is a question that has been raised in previous administrations, such as President Barack Obama's "hot mic" conversation with Russian President Dmitry Medvedev in 2012, which was not considered impeachable.

Title: House Speaker Ryan Declines Support for Trump Censure, Urges Bipartisan Approach to Charlottesville Response

Article:

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, in a town-hall meeting aired live on CNN on Monday, stated that President Donald Trump "messed up" in his response to the racial demonstrations in Charlottesville, Virginia, but cautioned against politicizing the response, saying it would "descend this issue into some partisan hack-fest."

Ryan, a Republican, expressed that he would not support a Congressional move to censure Mr. Trump. He emphasized the importance of avoiding a partisan divide, stating, "To make this us against them, Republicans against Democrats, pro-Trump, anti-Trump, that is a big mistake for our country."

Throughout the meeting, Ryan repeatedly referred to white supremacists as "fringe" and emphasized the need to keep them in that category. He acknowledged that Trump's response was correct on Monday, incorrect on Tuesday, and then correct again during the beginning of his speech on Afghanistan on Monday night.

CNN host Jake Tapper pressed Ryan to criticize Trump more directly for his handling, pointing out that the two times Trump's response was more acceptable, it was from prepared remarks, while his less acceptable response came during an impromptu press conference.

The questioners selected by CNN also attempted to provoke Ryan into criticizing Trump. When one man accused the president of "bullying" tweets and asked him to explain that to his own children, Ryan offered more practical advice: "I tell my kids to turn off the TV, get off the internet."

Tapper, a television host, jokingly questioned how to take the advice to turn off the TV.

Democrats have indicated that when Congress returns from vacation, they will attempt to vote to censure Trump. However, Ryan's rejection is likely to keep it a Democratic-led effort.

Ryan emphasized, "It should not be about the president. This is not about Republicans or Democrats. This shouldn't be about some vote in Congress or some partisan issue. This is so much more than that."

Ryan defended the House GOP's agenda under Mr. Trump, citing the passage of an Obamacare repeal (which has stalled in the Senate), legislation to overhaul the Wall Street reforms enacted after the 2008 collapse, and to boost job training. He noted that hundreds of other bills are awaiting Senate action.

On healthcare, Ryan stated that the House has done its part, and the Senate must return to work. However, he declined to set deadlines for senators, stating that there are other key votes coming up that must be addressed promptly, including raising the government's borrowing limit.

Title: Obama Administration's Foreign Policy Strategy Faces Setbacks in Second Term

Article:

The Obama Doctrine, the foreign policy strategy of President Barack Obama in his second term, is facing numerous challenges and setbacks around the globe. This year has seen setbacks in countries such as Egypt, Syria, Russia, and China. The most obvious failure was the cancellation of a planned summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin last week, following Russia's granting of asylum to fugitive National Security Agency leaker Edward Snowden.

The inability of the Obama administration to capture Mr. Snowden is just one of many unresolved foreign policy challenges since Mr. Obama's re-election. Some foreign affairs specialists attribute this to a president who is not devoting much time to hot spots overseas.

Aaron David Miller, a vice president at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, stated, "He’s one of only 17 presidents elected to a second term, and he’s clearly trying to figure out where he wants to put the majority of his time. He’s much more focused on the middle class than he is on the Middle East."

In April, the White House revealed reports of chemical weapons use in Syria's civil war, which Mr. Obama deemed a "game-changer." Four months later, the civil war continues, with fresh reports this week that an al Qaeda affiliate is infiltrating Syrian territory that was seized by rebel groups.

In Egypt, the military ousted President Mohammed Morsi in early July, who was elected after Mr. Obama encouraged democratic reforms in that country. Mr. Obama had major disagreements with Mr. Morsi, but the military's action left the White House in the awkward public position of denying that it met the legal definition of a "coup."

European allies such as Germany and France have criticized Mr. Obama over surveillance programs revealed by Mr. Snowden. At a Group of Eight summit in June in Northern Ireland, the news was Mr. Putin’s refusal to sign a communique calling for the ouster of Syrian President Bashar Assad, another setback for Mr. Obama.

A summit between Mr. Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping in June was overshadowed by the breaking news of Mr. Snowden’s revelations and by the Chinese leader’s ability to turn the tables on Mr. Obama and claim that China was a "victim" of U.S. cyberattacks.

As the summer progresses, Mr. Obama has parsed earlier statements that the U.S. has "decimated" al Qaeda. The administration closed 20 diplomatic facilities overseas because of threatened attacks by al Qaeda and its affiliates.

James Jay Carafano, an analyst on national security and foreign affairs at the conservative Heritage Foundation, said Mr. Obama's second-term problems internationally can be traced to the terrorist attack in September that killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, at the U.S. diplomatic post in Benghazi, Libya.

"Benghazi, I think, is a signature moment for the president," Mr. Carafano said. "If there were three [foreign policy successes] he could point to, they were winning the war with al Qaeda, resetting with the Russians, and not being George Bush doing everything with a heavy hand. Benghazi really kind of destroyed that mythology. Benghazi has made him incredibly risk-averse."

Russia’s decision to grant temporary asylum to Mr. Snowden was especially embarrassing for the White House because Mr. Obama had made personal appeals to Mr. Putin to send the fugitive back to the U.S. Relations between the two leaders have never been strong; Mr. Putin made a point of skipping a summit hosted by Mr. Obama at Camp David last summer.

"We’re going to assess where the relationship [with Russia] can advance U.S. interests and increase peace and stability and prosperity around the world," Mr. Obama said at a news conference Friday. "Where it can, we’re going to keep on working with them. Where we have differences, we’re going to say so clearly. And my hope is, is that over time, Mr. Putin and Russia recognize that rather than a zero-sum competition, in fact, if the two countries are working together we can probably advance the betterment of both peoples."

One of the few foreign policy bright spots for Mr. Obama was the agreement this month of Palestinians and Israelis for renewed peace talks. Mr. Obama encouraged both sides to resume talks during a trip to the Middle East in March.

Lawrence Korb, senior fellow at the left-leaning Center for American Progress, said the development is "not going to solve all the problems" in the Middle East and suggested that the progress is more style than substance.

"It shows [administration officials] are willing to spend some political capital," Mr. Korb said. "Even if it doesn’t work, it undermines the narrative that we don’t care."

Mr. Miller said the president can point to three major foreign policy accomplishments in his first term: extricating U.S. troops from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, reducing U.S. dependence on "Arab hydrocarbons," and preventing another terrorist attack in the U.S. on the scale of 9/11—notwithstanding the Fort Hood shootings and the Boston Marathon bombings.

"On balance, you’re dealing with a guy whose foreign policy has had no spectacular successes, other than the killing of bin Laden," Mr. Miller said. "But it’s been pretty disciplined, with no spectacular failures, either. Given the limitations on American power and our own domestic difficulties, that’s actually not so bad."

Title: U.S. Agency for Global Media Chief's Actions Raise Concerns over Editorial Independence of International Broadcasters

Article:

Reports suggest that the new chief executive of Voice of America and its sister organizations is refusing to renew visas for hundreds of foreign journalists, potentially exposing them to retaliation for their reporting. This development has reignited concerns that the individual may be attempting to co-opt the foreign broadcasters for political ends.

Voice of America, along with other publicly funded international broadcasters, is a trusted and popular news source globally due to its independence from political pressure. These reports follow other indications that the Trump administration may be interfering with the broadcasters' editorial independence. In late April, the White House baselessly attacked VOA as Chinese "propaganda." More recently, Michael Pack, the new chief executive at the U.S. Agency for Global Media (USAGM), which administers the broadcasters, has reportedly fired senior leadership and is refusing to act on visa applications, effectively terminating these foreign journalists and depriving the USAGM broadcasters of essential expertise for their reporting.

While Pack has the authority to manage the USAGM, he cannot interfere with the legal "firewall" that has been established to safeguard the editorial independence of U.S. international broadcasters from political influence. This firewall is based on two fundamental pillars: international broadcasters must adhere to the highest standards of journalism, including transparency, comprehensiveness, balance, accuracy, and strict autonomy; and political appointees, like Pack and the secretary of state, are barred from interfering in the "professional independence and integrity" of the broadcasting services. Any attempt by Pack or others in the administration to dictate news content would likely be illegal.

Further, journalists and editors at the USAGM broadcasters have First Amendment rights independent of their status as government employees and contractors. The news staff at VOA and the other broadcasters are members of the media, and efforts to interfere with their work could trigger basic First Amendment protections, such as the right to gather news, the right to be free from a "prior restraint" (were Pack to try and block a story's publication, for instance), and prohibitions on official retaliation for protected speech.

Moreover, particularly with respect to the foreign journalists now facing what amounts to firing as their visas expire, Pack's moves may violate civil service protections. It is well established, for instance, that career government employees may not be terminated based on national origin. Additionally, the firewall itself may protect journalists and editors to the extent the decision not to renew their visas is an attempt to interfere with the broadcasters' independence.

Setting aside the legal implications, efforts to interfere with the independence of publicly funded international broadcasters are practically unwise. During the Cold War, autonomy, credibility, and professionalism were identified as essential factors in the success of U.S. international broadcasting. The ability of broadcasters like VOA, Radio Free Europe, and Radio Liberty to relay both good news and bad (including bad news about the U.S.) drove massive audience engagement and trust. The appeal was so pressing for officials in the Soviet Union and the Eastern Bloc that they spent the equivalent of hundreds of millions of dollars trying to jam the broadcasters' signals.

The public broadcasters also provided an essential counterweight to state-controlled media. For example, when the nuclear reactor at Chernobyl suffered a catastrophic meltdown in 1986, foreign broadcasters were the first source of hard news on the disaster for millions of people behind the Iron Curtain, and it forced state-controlled media to grudgingly acknowledge the accident.

Finally, and of particular relevance to the foreign journalists who now face a forced return to countries where their reporting may have angered government officials, one other crucial factor for success was the ability of the public broadcasters to tailor their news to the audience. Émigré broadcasters with an intimate knowledge of the language and culture of listeners again bolstered credibility and thus advanced the effectiveness of U.S. public diplomacy. That talent is invaluable and irreplaceable, and for it to be squandered today for political reasons would be tragic.

The Reporters Committee regularly files friend-of-the-court briefs and its attorneys represent journalists and news organizations pro bono in court cases that involve First Amendment freedoms, the newsgathering rights of journalists, and access to public information. Stay up-to-date on their work by signing up for their monthly newsletter and following them on Twitter or Instagram.

Title: Rising Costs of Necessities Contrast with Falling Prices of Discretionary Items During the COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The Consumer Price Index (CPI) reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Wednesday showed a 0.1% decrease in May, primarily due to discounting in energy, car insurance, public transportation, and clothing prices. The core rate of inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, also decreased by 0.1%, marking the first time it has fallen for three consecutive months.

However, the CPI data may not accurately reflect the experiences of many households, as most households spend a significant portion of their income on necessities such as food, shelter, transportation, healthcare, and clothing. According to researchers at the Brookings Institution, low-income households typically spend 82% of their income on these five categories, while middle-class families spend 78%. Even high-income families spend about two-thirds of their income on necessities.

While some discretionary items, such as gasoline, clothing, transportation, and hotel rooms, have seen decreases in price, the cost of necessities, such as food and shelter, has increased. This trend can be attributed to supply and demand dynamics, exacerbated by the unique challenges the coronavirus has imposed on supply chains. Shortages are common.

In May, grocery prices rose 1% compared to April, and have increased by 4.1% over the past three months, equivalent to an annual rate of 17.5%. Beef prices have risen by 11% in just three months. Shelter prices, including both rental and ownership costs, are not increasing as rapidly as they were at the beginning of the year but are still rising, up 2.6% in the past year compared with a 0.9% drop in the prices of all other goods.

The increase in shelter costs, which take up a significant portion of household incomes, translates into a substantial impact on budgets, particularly for low-income families, who spend, on average, 41% of their income on housing.

While overall savings have soared to a record 33% of disposable incomes in April (with May figures not yet available), households that have lost more than 25% of their income may be feeling the pinch, especially if they are relying on one-time $1,200 checks or the soon-to-expire $600 unemployment bonus. If grocery prices continue to rise 1% every month, this could further strain their budgets.

While the country as a whole may be experiencing deflation, not everyone is benefiting from falling prices in the items they need to survive. As the pandemic continues, it remains to be seen how these trends will evolve and how they will impact households across income levels.

Title: Visualizing Two Centuries of U.S. Immigration: A Data-Driven Analysis

Article:

From 1820 to 2013, approximately 79 million people obtained lawful permanent resident status in the United States. An interactive map, available for viewing as a video or a full-screen interactive version, visualizes this migration based on the immigrants' prior country of residence. The brightness of a country corresponds to its total migration to the U.S. at the given time.

Over the two centuries, the sources of immigration have traced a clear path across the world. Through most of the 1800s, immigration came predominantly from Western Europe, including Ireland, Germany, and the United Kingdom. Toward the end of the century, countries further east in Europe, such as Italy, Russia, and Hungary, became the largest sources of migration. Beginning in the early 1900s, most immigrants arrived from the Americas, including Canada and Mexico. The last few decades have seen a rise in migration from Asia.

The same trends are clear when examining the history of New York City's foreign-born population. The largest immigration "waves" have been charted over time, showing the progression. While it may seem that immigration over the last few decades has been higher than ever before, the picture looks very different when viewed relative to the size of the U.S. population.

The data used for the map is "persons obtaining lawful permanent resident status," which does not include illegal immigration or, as pointed out by @ artsyTrish, people brought to the U.S. as slaves ("forced immigration"). World borders for the map were provided by Natural Earth.

For those interested in learning more about the causes behind these immigration waves, this graphic summarizes some of the major events that led to migration from specific countries. The role of the United States as a sanctuary for troubled people across the world is a significant part of its history.

The data for this analysis was obtained from the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Immigration Statistics, available in a full report and in Excel format. The author, Max Galka (@galka_max), has also created a project called Elementus, which aims to bring transparency to the cryptocurrency market. More information about this project can be found on their blog.

Title: U.S. Unemployment Rate Drops Below 6 Percent for First Time Since 2008, Adding 248,000 Jobs in September

Article:

The U.S. unemployment rate has dipped below 6 percent for the first time since July 2008, with nonfarm payrolls adding 248,000 new jobs in September, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). The jobless rate fell 0.2 percentage points to 5.9 percent.

Employment increased in professional and business services, retail trade, and health care, as reported by the BLS. The data were stronger than expected, with employers adding about 69,000 more jobs in July and August than the government initially reported.

The median forecast among economists surveyed by Bloomberg had called for 215,000 new jobs in September.

Jason Furman, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement that the report extends the "longest streak of private-sector job growth on record."

"The data underscore that six years after the Great Recession — thanks to the hard work of the American people and in part to the policies the President has pursued — our economy has bounced back more strongly than most others around the world," Furman said.

Many economists consider 5.5 percent unemployment a "healthy number," and as the unemployment rate moves closer to that figure, The Associated Press says it "could ratchet up pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise its benchmark interest rate."

As NPR's John Ydstie reports, "Over the past few years, much of the decline in the unemployment rate has been attributed to people leaving the labor force. But, Jim O'Sullivan of High Frequency Economics says in 2014 it's largely job growth that's has pushed unemployment down."

Dean Maki, chief U.S. economist at Barclays PLC in New York, is quoted by Bloomberg as calling the latest data "strong across the board."

"The labor market continues to grow fast enough to keep pushing the unemployment rate down," Maki told Bloomberg.

Even with the new jobs, nearly 100,000 people stopped looking for work. The number of Americans working or looking for work was at 62.7 percent, the lowest proportion since February 1978, according to The Associated Press.

Title: President Trump Vetoes Bipartisan Resolution to Block Border Emergency Declaration

Article:

President Donald Trump on Friday used the first veto of his administration to reject a bipartisan resolution that sought to block his declaration of a national emergency at the border. The veto is likely to kill the measure, as lawmakers are unlikely to muster the two-thirds majority required to override.

Trump's veto came a day after 12 Senate Republicans joined Democrats in voting for the resolution, despite last-minute efforts between the White House and GOP lawmakers to keep the Republican Party united. The measure ultimately passed 59-41.

In the Oval Office, Trump, surrounded by law enforcement officials and families of those killed by illegal immigrants, said, "I am vetoing this resolution." He added, "Congress has the freedom to pass this resolution, and I have the duty to veto it."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., said that the veto was a sign that Trump "had chosen to trample all over the Constitution." House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said the House will vote to override the veto on March 26.

Trump originally declared a national emergency on the border last month after Congress granted only a fraction of the $5.7 billion he requested for a wall on the border. Declaring a national emergency allows Trump to steer an extra $3.6 billion to the wall.

Senate Democrats, who have consistently opposed many of Trump's hardline immigration policies, were joined by Republicans who expressed support for Trump's calls to build a wall but cited concern about the expansion of presidential power. The resolution had previously passed the Democrat-controlled House.

In a separate development, the Senate also voted to end U.S. support for Saudi forces in Yemen. The vote was not related to the border emergency declaration.

Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, who voted against the border emergency declaration, said the vote was a question of the balance of power that is core to the U.S. Constitution. "This is not about the president or border security, in fact, I support border security, I support a barrier," Romney told reporters.

The other Republicans who voted against the border emergency declaration were Sens. Mike Lee, R-Utah; Rob Portman, R-Ohio; Susan Collins, R-Maine; Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska; Marco Rubio, R-Fla.; Rand Paul, R-Ky.; Lamar Alexander, R-Tenn.; Roger Wicker, R-Miss.; Roy Blunt, R-Mo.; Jerry Moran, R-Kan.; and Pat Toomey, R-Pa. Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., had initially said he would oppose the declaration but reversed course on the Senate floor. Sen. Mike Lee had introduced a bill that would end future emergency declarations after 30 days, but after Trump said he opposed that legislation, Lee eventually backed the measure to rebuff Trump.

Title: Protesters Breach U.S. Embassy Compound in Yemen's Capital, Sanaa

Article:

Protesters in Yemen's capital, Sanaa, have stormed the U.S. Embassy compound, marking the latest attack on U.S. diplomatic posts in the Middle East. The protesters breached the embassy perimeter and reached the compound grounds, although they did not enter the main building housing the offices. Angry young men brought down the U.S. flag, burned it, and replaced it with a black banner bearing Islam's declaration of faith.
