Yemeni security forces, who rushed to the scene, fired in the air and used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, driving them out of the compound after about 45 minutes and sealing off the surrounding streets. It was not immediately clear whether anyone was inside the embassy at the time of the attack.

Demonstrators removed the embassy's sign on the outer wall, set tires ablaze, and pelted the compound with rocks. Yemeni President Abed Rabbo Mansour Hadi ordered an investigation into the attack, avowing to bring the culprits to justice, stating the attack by a "rowdy crowd" was part of a conspiracy to derail Yemen's close relations with Washington.

The movie cited in the attacks, "Innocence of Muslims," came to attention in Egypt after its trailer was dubbed into Arabic and posted on YouTube. The video-sharing website blocked access to it Wednesday. The trailer depicts Muhammad as a fraud, a womanizer, and a madman in an overtly ridiculing way, showing him having sex and calling for massacres.

The Yemen incident was similar to an attack on the U.S. Embassy in the Egyptian capital of Cairo on Tuesday night. A mob in Libya also attacked the U.S. consulate in the eastern city of Benghazi on Tuesday, killing American Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans.

Three diplomats injured in the Libyan attack are being treated at an American military hospital in Germany, and one of the two most seriously wounded is expected to leave the intensive care unit on Thursday. A State Department status report obtained by The Associated Press says the third injured staffer is awake and alert at the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center near the Ramstein Air Base, where 33 uninjured consulate personnel are staying and receiving military counseling. All were evacuated from Benghazi early Wednesday and arrived in Germany late that afternoon along with the remains of the four diplomats.

According to the report, the injured staffers "are doing relatively well" and most want to return to Libya. In Iraq, several hundred Shiite hardliners protested in Baghdad's Shiite stronghold of Sadr City. The leader of an Iranian-backed Shiite militia that previously attacked U.S. troops, Asaib Ahl al-Haq, threatened anti-U.S. attacks. The movie "will put all the American interests in Iraq in danger," the militia leader, Qais al-Khazali, told The Associated Press.

In Iran, about 50 protesters shouted, "Death to America," outside the Swiss Embassy, which looks after U.S. diplomatic interests in Iran. Riot police kept the crowd away from the building. On Thursday, Egyptian protesters also clashed with police near the U.S. Embassy in Cairo for the third day in a row. Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters, and the two sides pelted each other with rocks. But unlike Tuesday, the police kept the protesters away from the embassy's compound. The Interior Ministry, which is in charge of police, said 16 protesters and 13 policemen were wounded in the clashes, which broke out overnight and were ongoing. Twelve protesters have been arrested, it said. Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi criticized the movie Thursday during a visit to the European Union in Brussels. "We condemn strongly... all those who launch such provocations and who stand behind that hatred," Morsi said, adding that he had asked Obama "to put an end to such behavior." But Morsi also urged the Egyptian people to not engage in "unlawful acts."

Title: Ted Cruz's Ivy League Background Adds to Liberal Disdain

Article:

Ted Cruz, the freshman senator from Texas, has been a subject of disdain for liberals over the past year, with his political views being a significant source of contention. The article notes that Texas, as a state, is known for producing Republican figures reviled by the other side, and Cruz is no exception.

Unlike his predecessors George W. Bush and Rick Perry, Cruz is an Ivy Leaguer, having graduated magna cum laude from Harvard and excelling as a debater at Princeton. This pedigree, however, seems to add an extra element of disbelief to the disdain Cruz faces from Democrats and liberal pundits.

Cruz's political views are considered gauche at the prestigious universities where he studied, and he is often portrayed as a constitutionalist conservative who is a "traitor to his class." A Daily Beast piece quoted fellow Princetonians who expressed surprise at Cruz's political transformation, describing him as a man of "calcified thinking, dangerously impervious to facts."

The left's deepest prejudice is that its opponents are unintelligent, and Cruz challenges this stereotype. Chris Hayes of MSNBC has even expressed fear of Cruz's brilliance, while Attorney General Eric Holder was reportedly cornered during a hearing on the administration's drone policy.

Cruz has not shied away from making his presence felt in the Senate, entering the upper chamber with the boldness of a SWAT team. This assertiveness has been met with disapproval from senators who are used to wielding intellectual and moral superiority.

The article acknowledges that Cruz's tactics are not without criticism, particularly his push to defund Obamacare, which some view as a slogan without a realistic path to legislative success. The strategy of a government shutdown to achieve this goal is seen as unrealistic, and Cruz has been criticized for not providing a clear explanation of how such a strategy would lead to the desired outcome.

Despite the criticism, the article suggests that Cruz will be a significant force in the Senate, potentially shaping policy for decades to come and continuing to elicit strong reactions from both sides of the aisle.

Title: Mortgage Rates in the U.S. Reach All-Time Low Amid COVID-19 Concerns

Article:

Mortgage rates in the United States have reached an all-time low, dropping to 3.29% during the week ending March 5, according to Freddie Mac. This significant decrease of 16 basis points from the previous week was primarily in response to concerns related to the economic impact of the COVID-19 outbreak.

The 15-year fixed-rate mortgage also fell 16 basis points to 2.79%, while the 5/1 adjustable-rate mortgage dropped only two basis points to an average of 3.18%. The decline in rates presents a major opportunity for millions of homeowners across the country, who could potentially save thousands of dollars in interest by refinancing.

An estimated 44.7 million homeowners have $6.2 trillion in home equity that they could access through a cash-out refinance, according to real-estate data firm Black Knight. With the chance to access that cash at a lower interest rate, many homeowners may take advantage of this opportunity.

Mortgage rates have been following the yield on the 10-year Treasury, which dropped below 1% for the first time ever this week after the Federal Reserve announced it was cutting its benchmark interest rate in response to the potential economic impact of the illness outbreak.

The decline in rates has stoked another refinancing boom, with mortgage applications increasing 10% last week from one year ago and showing no signs of slowing down. However, lenders have been hesitant to trim rates at such a fast pace, as they need to maintain their margins and don't want to cut into their profits too much by reducing rates.

An emerging risk that those looking to refinance may want to consider is the possibility of government orders to shelter in place amid the coronavirus outbreak. This could potentially create friction in the system, as some of the work can be done remotely but may not be possible if loan processing centers are closed.

Home buyers may also be hard-pressed to take advantage of low rates due to the low inventory of homes for sale. In recent months, the inventory of homes for sale has hit an all-time low amid the high demand from buyers. This low inventory is largely the result of depressed home construction activity in the wake of the recession, which did not keep pace with household formation across the country.

Overall, the drop in rates could help push some people to sell their homes, but it remains to be seen whether this will be enough to meet the demand in the market. If the broader economy weakens due to the coronavirus outbreak, it may be challenging for the housing market to remain above the fray.

Title: Vice Presidential Candidates Deliver Polarized Performances in Debate, Addressing Campaign Vulnerabilities and Policy Differences

Article:

In the highly anticipated vice presidential debate on Tuesday, Mike Pence and Tim Kaine delivered polarized performances, each using the opportunity to address campaign vulnerabilities and delve into policy differences. The debate served as a valuable service for both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, as it advanced the narrative and provided a platform for fresh attacks on each other's running mates.

For Governor Mike Pence (R-IN), the debate was a welcome opportunity to move beyond the worst week of the Trump campaign. The Republican nominee was widely seen as having lost to Clinton in their first debate, and his subsequent comments about a former Miss Universe and the release of old Trump tax return details further damaged his image.

Pence faced a barrage of incoming from Senator Kaine (D-VA), and in many cases, declined to defend Trump. This strategy may have been the smart move, as Pence might have spent the entire debate playing defense, responding to accusations about Trump's taxes, admiration for Russian President Vladimir Putin, demeaning comments about women, and birtherism.

Instead, Pence deflected and ignored much of Kaine's assault. When Kaine asked Pence why he wasn't defending Trump, Pence replied, "I'm happy to defend him," and then continued to not defend him on many of the points.

When Kaine accused Trump of running an "insult-driven" campaign, Pence ignored the vast catalog of evidence and turned the slam back on his opponent. "Ours is an insult-driven campaign?" Pence interjected, with mock incredulity. Then he ran for daylight, countering Clinton's labeling half of Trump supporters as a "basket of deplorables."

Pence also raised the controversies around Clinton's private email server and the family's charitable foundation. In a way, for Pence, it was a do-over debate – a chance to score some points against Clinton that Trump failed to do last week and show him how to keep his cool during a debate.

For Kaine, the debate was a chance to unload a torrent of sound bites against a Trump candidacy loaded with vulnerabilities. However, he came in so aggressive, and interrupted so much, especially at first, that Pence was widely seen as winning on temperament – an important measure of whether a candidate is "presidential."

"Kaine wins on substance, loses on style," wrote independent pollster John Zogby.

Kaine got off some obviously rehearsed one-liners that may turn up in future Clinton campaign ads. More than once, he referred to Trump as the "you're fired" candidate and Clinton, the "you're hired" candidate. And he accused Trump of having a "personal Mount Rushmore" – President Putin, Kim Jong-un, Muammar Qaddafi, Saddam Hussein.

The tenor of the debate shifted markedly when the subject of faith came up. Both men are deeply religious – Kaine is Roman Catholic, Pence is a born-again Evangelical – and they spoke from the heart. Moderator Elaine Quijano of CBS News asked each to discuss a time when faith conflicted with governing. Kaine spoke of his struggle, as governor of Virginia, with the death penalty, which he opposes.

"It was very, very difficult to allow executions to go forward, but in circumstances where I did not feel like there was a case for clemency, I told Virginia voters I would uphold the law, and I did," Kaine said.

Pence didn't offer a similar example, and instead used the opportunity to speak on "the sanctity of life." He also offered warm words for Kaine. "I have a great deal of respect for Senator Kaine's sincere faith. I truly do," he said.

Pence then turned to the Clinton-Kaine ticket's support for abortion rights, including so-called "partial-birth abortion" (which Kaine had, in fact, once opposed). But it was a respectful critique. And in a campaign nearly devoid of discussion on issues that matter to religious conservatives, a crucial element of the Republican base, Pence surely in that moment did his ticket some good.

Title: Connecticut School Shooting: President Obama Vows Action Against Gun Violence

Article:

President Barack Obama, in response to the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, which left at least 25 people dead, including 20 children, expressed his condolences and vowed to press for meaningful action to prevent similar incidents.

In a statement made on Friday, Mr. Obama said, "We've endured too many of these tragedies in the past few years." The comments echoed those he made in the aftermath of the 2011 shooting in Tucson, Arizona, that severely wounded then-Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and killed six. However, no new federal gun laws were enacted in the aftermath of that incident.

The Connecticut school shootings, in which 27 people were killed, have raised questions about the origin of the firearms believed to have been used in the massacre. According to two federal law-enforcement officials, authorities recovered a Glock, a Sig Sauer, and a.223 Bushmaster rifle near the body of the suspected shooter, Adam Lanza, 20 years old. The guns were registered to Lanza's mother, Nancy Lanza, who was among Friday's victims.

The AR-15, one of the most popular rifles in America, is under scrutiny after police say the weapon was used in the massacre in Newtown, Connecticut. The registration answers one of the questions about the origin of the firearms believed used in the mass shooting. Under federal law, Lanza would have been prohibited from buying handguns from a licensed dealer because of his age. An 18-year-old, however, can get a handgun as a gift or from a private seller.

The shootings come one day after Michigan lawmakers voted to allow trained gun owners to carry concealed weapons into places once prohibited. Under the bill, which is now on the desk of Republican Gov. Rick Snyder, schools can opt out if they wish. Gov. Snyder said through spokeswoman Sara Wurfel that the bill "was going to be already going through a careful review and analysis."

The most prominent federal gun law to go into effect during the Obama administration was one that eased restrictions, allowing gun owners to carry loaded weapons into National Parks and wildlife refuges as long as the relevant state's laws permitted it.

In the comments Mr. Obama delivered from the White House, he spoke of the children who were killed. "The majority of those who died today were children—beautiful little kids between the ages of 5 and 10 years old. They had their entire lives ahead of them—birthdays, graduations, weddings, kids of their own."

The shootings have sparked calls for tougher federal legislation on gun control. Some legal and policy experts believe the Connecticut shootings could prompt tougher federal legislation on gun control. Adam Winkler, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, said, "This is the cap to an awful year of horrific shootings. And if anything's going to cause politicians to act, it's a roomful of child victims."

However, gun-rights supporters argue that restrictive gun-control regimes, such as that in place in Connecticut, are ineffective. Dave Workman, the editor of TheGunMag.com, a magazine owned by the Second Amendment Foundation, a pro-gun-rights lobby group, said, "It's a very restrictive state, and this presumably occurred in a gun-free school zone. It creates a situation where the criminals have guns, and everyone else is defenseless."

The debate over gun control is likely to continue in the aftermath of the Connecticut school shootings. The full facts of the incident are still emerging, and the impact on federal and state gun laws remains to be seen.

Title: Court Rules Against Trump Administration in Lawsuit Over Federal Grant Funds for Sanctuary Cities

Article:

The 7th Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled against the Trump administration in a lawsuit filed by the city of Chicago over the withholding of federal grant funds due to the city's status as a sanctuary city. The court found that the administration's threat to withhold public safety grants from jurisdictions that do not cooperate with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) violates the Constitution's separation-of-powers provisions.

The court battle dates back to 2017 when the Department of Justice (DOJ) moved to withhold Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grants from Chicago, a city that has refused to honor ICE detainer requests, share information, or cooperate with immigration agents. Then-Mayor Rahm Emanuel sued the DOJ in response.

In a 95-page ruling, Judge Ilana Rovner, writing on behalf of the three-judge panel, stated that the executive branch's authority on immigration policy does not include withholding funds from cities that were allocated from the legislative branch. The court found that such a move would concentrate power and potentially lead to tyranny, which the Founding Fathers intended to prevent.

Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot, Rahm Emanuel's successor and a major opponent of Trump's immigration agenda, celebrated the court's decision. "When I got the news from our corporation counsel earlier this morning, I let out a cheer," Lightfoot said, according to CBS Chicago. "This is a great victory, not only for Chicago, but for our immigrant and refugee communities everywhere in the country."

The grant money at stake was a mere fraction of 1% of Chicago's budget, but the drawn-out court fight indicated that the lawsuit was much more for Chicago leaders than receiving federal funds. The Justice Department has the option of appealing the decision to the Supreme Court, but it's not clear yet how the DOJ will proceed.

Chicago authorities have specifically instructed local law enforcement not to work with ICE agents in many circumstances. The city does not honor ICE detainer requests, and has even allowed illegal aliens charged of heinous crimes to walk free without notifying the agency, which has led to some gruesome consequences. In response to public backlash over such incidents, Lightfoot has put blame back on ICE.

Title: White House Scrambles to Address Ongoing Confusion and Humanitarian Concerns Over Family Separation Policy

Article:

The White House is currently grappling with the fallout from President Donald Trump's reversal on the separation of parents and children who cross the southern border as undocumented migrants. The President's executive order, aimed at resolving a growing political crisis, has created its own set of problems, particularly as it does not address the 2,300 children already separated from their parents who are awaiting prosecution.

The Trump administration faces a potential legal challenge, with one scenario potentially allowing the separations to be reapplied. The uncertainty surrounding the reunification of families has led to Trump's hopes of quelling the political uproar over the separations being dashed.

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen responded to criticism by stating that the administration is working to reunite split families. "We have a plan to do that," Nielsen told CNN's Tal Kopan. "So a combination of DHS, DOJ, HHS [Department of Health and Human Services] reuniting as quickly as we can."

However, CNN reported Wednesday that the order did not contain any procedures for how to reunite children currently in the care of the federal government with their parents. The agency later walked back the statement but said any further plans to reunite families were still in development.

John Sandweg, a former director of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement, expressed his concerns about the executive order's execution. "I think the intention was to change things [but] I think the way the order is drafted is not executable," Sandweg told CNN's Anderson Cooper.

Trump's critics accuse him of creating the problem by adopting a "zero-tolerance" policy of prosecuting undocumented migrants, which led to restrictions on children being held in jail with their parents, triggering the separations.

"He created a crisis, he said he solved the crisis. He has not," said Democratic House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer to CNN's Kate Bolduan. Immigration was a foundational issue of Trump's 2016 campaign, and it forms the essential link between the President and his base. While his retreat is embarrassing, it's unlikely to signal any softening of his broader stance on undocumented immigrants.

Thursday morning, Trump continued to express his displeasure with current immigration laws and mislead about the state of US immigration courts. The President mentioned the reversal only in passing at a campaign event in Minnesota on Wednesday night.

While the political situation is murky, the legal challenges to the executive order may be even more complex. Under the Trump administration's new policy adopted earlier this year, many people are funneled into the criminal justice system when they cross the border illegally—and US guidelines mandate at that point that children are separated from their parents. The executive order lays down new guidelines, requiring families to be kept together in the custody of the Department of Homeland Security. However, this position is almost certain to be challenged in court due to a 1997 consent agreement that stipulates that children can be kept in detention only for 20 days. That decision could even lead to families being separated again.

"It's absolutely a possibility," said Jonathan Turley, a George Washington University professor of law, outlining two possibilities if the administration could not get the consent agreement modified, a scenario he judged as doubtful. "You reunite the family; a clock is ticking. If it goes beyond 20 days, you either release the entire family, which is similar to the Obama policy that the President wants to change, or you once again separate the family and send the child into some type of custodial care."

Title: Boris Johnson Elected as Britain's Prime Minister, Faces Challenges on Brexit and Iran Crisis

Article:

Boris Johnson, a known supporter of the United States and defender of President Trump at times, has been elected as the new Prime Minister of Britain. Johnson, who has pledged to complete Brexit in three months, now faces an escalating naval crisis with Iran.

Last Friday, Iran's Revolutionary Guards seized a British-flagged oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz in retaliation for the British seizure of an Iranian tanker off Gibraltar earlier this month. Johnson, however, has signaled his opposition to a hawkish stance towards Iran. During last week's TV debates, Johnson stated that he would not support US military action against Iran.

In 2018, when he was foreign minister, Johnson traveled to Washington to try to persuade President Trump to stay in the Iran nuclear deal, stating that the British government remained committed to the agreement.

Johnson's pledge to leave the European Union by October 31, regardless of circumstances, is a challenge he inherits from the same divided Conservative Party and Parliament that helped bring down Prime Minister Theresa May. Johnson may also face a 'no-confidence vote' and early elections within weeks.

President Trump expressed his support for Johnson, stating, "I like him. I like Boris Johnson. I spoke to him yesterday. I think he's going to do a great job. I think we're going to have a great relationship."

During an interview, Johnson was asked if he would be as submissive as prime minister, to which he responded, "I've been, towards the United States of America, craven? Do not be ridiculous. If I may say so. When it comes to sticking up for UK interests, whether it's over climate change, over disputes with Iran, over the Iran nuclear deal, we have been very, very forthright with the United States of America, and I will continue to be forthright."

In 2015, Johnson accused Trump of having "stupefying ignorance" and said Trump was "unfit to hold the office of president of the United States." Johnson, a former mayor of London known for his occasionally unconventional ways, has adopted a populist style that has served him well.

However, as prime minister, Johnson must navigate through an international crisis, with possible war clouds looming.

Title: Five Common-Sense Policies to Cut Spending, Boost Revenue, and Stimulate Economic Growth

Article:

Americans have expressed a desire for lower deficits and increased economic growth, but reaching a consensus on policies to achieve these goals remains challenging due to partisan differences. Republicans oppose new taxes, while Democrats are averse to cuts in entitlement spending. Even the sequester, which included minimal spending cuts of 8% for defense and 5% for other spending, was met with significant opposition.

In an effort to find common ground and stimulate economic growth, this article presents five practical policies that could be implemented with bipartisan support:

1. Reduce Medicare and Medicaid spending: Encourage competition between U.S. pricing and international pricing for drugs, as Americans currently pay the highest prices in the world. This competition would lead pharmaceutical companies to lower drug prices in the U.S. Additionally, doctors should be reimbursed based on procedures rather than a percentage of drug costs or tests performed. To reduce end-of-life procedures for terminally ill patients, Americans should be asked to state their end-of-life wishes when they renew their driver's licenses.

2. End the war on drugs: The war on drugs has proven ineffective, similar to Prohibition. Legalizing and taxing marijuana would generate new revenue and reduce spending on overcrowded jails. State lawmakers in Washington are anticipating hundreds of millions of dollars a year in new tax revenue due to a now-legal pot market. Legalization would also create job opportunities for the unemployed.

3. Grant Green Cards to the best and brightest: Encourage those who receive advanced degrees in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to stay in the U.S. by offering them Green Cards. These individuals contribute to the success of U.S. companies, create jobs, and generate new tax revenue.

4. Require unemployment benefits recipients to volunteer: Research indicates that the longer unemployment benefits are provided, the longer the jobless remain unemployed. Instead of incentivizing the jobless to find work, we continue to pay them benefits. By requiring the unemployed to volunteer 20 hours a week at a non-profit, the unemployment rolls would decrease, and those volunteering would develop skills and create job networks.

5. Allow companies to bring back foreign profits: American companies have parked over a trillion dollars overseas due to taxes on profits made abroad. The U.S. uniquely taxes these profits again at one of the highest corporate tax rates in the developed world. To stimulate the economy, jobs, and tax revenue, companies should be allowed to return their profits at a lower rate (e.g., 10%) if at least half the money is spent on new U.S. jobs or capital investment.

To balance the budget and put the U.S. on a path to prosperity, creative and bipartisan thinking is required. Adopting these common-sense solutions could help meet sequestration goals without raising taxes or cutting entitlements.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Invokes "Nuclear Option" to Alter Filibuster Rules

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, known for his hard-ball style of leadership, has taken an unprecedented step by altering the filibuster rules for presidential nominees in the Senate. This move, which was carried out on a straight party-line vote, could have significant implications for future presidents, reshape the Senate, and define Reid's legacy as one of the longest-serving Democratic leaders in history.

On the weekend of Nov. 9, Reid consulted with his top lieutenants, Sens. Chuck Schumer of New York and Dick Durbin of Illinois, to gauge the caucus's sentiment. Despite several weeks of vote counting, Reid encountered skepticism from some of his confidants as late as Monday evening. However, after personal intervention from President Barack Obama, Reid won the vote on a slim margin, 52-48.

The move, which was emblematic of Reid's leadership style, has been criticized by both parties. Three Democrats, the retiring Carl Levin of Michigan, the moderate Joe Manchin of West Virginia, and the vulnerable Mark Pryor of Arkansas, broke ranks with Reid.

The "nuclear option" allows the Senate to set a new precedent by a simple majority of 51 senators, rather than the typical 67 votes needed to change the rules by regular order. This means any majority can fundamentally weaken the filibuster without consensus of the minority party, effectively weakening its ability to block, delay, or shape legislation.

Under the new rules, senators can no longer filibuster nominees to executive branch posts or the courts, with the exception of the Supreme Court. Legislation could still be filibustered, as could many other Senate actions. However, both sides acknowledge that future majorities will cite Reid's precedent to continue weakening the filibuster, potentially ending the delaying tactic on all bills and Supreme Court nominees and allowing a simple majority of senators to work their will.

Reid's decision to alter the filibuster rules has been met with criticism from Republicans, who warn that Reid will ultimately come to regret it. Democrats, on the other hand, argue that the move was necessary due to Republican obstruction of Obama's judicial picks and the ongoing gridlock in the Senate.

The latest move has left both parties grappling with the far-reaching ramifications of Reid's decision. When asked about the potential impact of his move on his legacy, Reid stated, "I don't write history."

Title: Republicans Push for Consensus on Obamacare Replacement as Supreme Court Case Looms

Article:

Republicans have been advocating for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, for nearly five years. However, 2015 could be the year that Republicans define their replacement plan. In March, the Supreme Court will hear a case, King v. Burwell, that threatens subsidies that form a core of the Affordable Care Act. If King prevails, subsidies could be abruptly cut off to millions of people in states relying on the federal health exchange.

Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, stated, "What the King case does is give us an opportunity and a reason to come to a consensus sooner so, when we get the ruling of the Supreme Court in June, we are then prepared to say, 'Here is what is better for the American people in terms of affordability, quality, and choice.'"

The Republican discussions are preliminary, and a breakthrough isn't imminent. Various Republican proposals have been put forth over the years, but forging agreement requires bridging deep ideological differences among Republicans about the scope of a plan, the role and responsibility of the federal government in health care, and how much to spend.

Senators such as Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) and Richard Burr of North Carolina, along with Representatives Fred Upton (R-Mich.) and Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.), are working on a replacement draft. They aim to present a logical solution prior to the Supreme Court case being heard.

The Republican moves come as the Affordable Care Act is working fairly well. The three-month enrollment season for 2015 is going smoothly and will likely surpass the administration's modest second-year goals of having 9 million covered in exchange plans. As of mid-December, more than 6 million had signed up in the federal exchange, a tally that will rise when the state numbers are added in.

If the Supreme Court rules against the White House in the King case, it would hobble President Barack Obama's signature law and spill over into the rest of the U.S. health insurance system. Without subsidies in two-thirds of the states, the uninsured rate would probably rise, reversing its sharp decline. Premiums could soar if only the sickest people stick with their more expensive coverage.

The GOP could face a political backlash if people lose coverage from a lawsuit it supported, reminiscent of the fury Obama faced over last year's plan cancellations. The uncertainty surrounding the court case also adds complexity to the Republican attempts to undermine the law through repeal votes as well as the budget process known as reconciliation. Republicans may wait until the court's ruling to decide how they want to use reconciliation.

No matter what strategy they adopt, they won't be able to get rid of the law legislatively while Obama is in the White House—although they hope that the Supreme Court could create an opening for significant changes.

Title: Trump Compares Approval Ratings to Obama's at End of First Year in Office

Article:

President Donald Trump took to Twitter on Friday morning to compare his approval ratings to those of former President Barack Obama at the end of Obama's first year in office. Trump's tweet came after a discussion on the Fox News program "Fox & Friends" concerning a new Rasmussen poll showing Trump's approval rating at 46 percent, with Obama's at 47 percent for the same time period.

Beverly Hallberg, president of the District Media Group and a fellow for the conservative Heritage Foundation, commented on the program that the poll "kind of reinforces what [Trump] would refer to as the 'fake news.'" Trump's tweet followed shortly after.

Hallberg continued, stating that Trump ended December with landmark tax reform legislation being passed, which was "huge for his presidency." She also pointed out that Trump's media coverage has been negative, citing ABC's Brian Ross's suspension for an incorrect story about the former national security adviser in Finland and CNN's retractions of some stories.

Fox News contributor Rachel Campos-Duffy, guest-hosting on the program, commented that she could "just imagine what Obama's poll numbers would be if he had endured the abuse" Trump "has endured."

Hallberg added that Trump's tweets sometimes make it harder for himself, and he has faced multiple Russia investigations and staff turnover throughout 2017. Despite these challenges, she noted that Trump's high approval numbers, especially in light of Democratic claims that he could not be re-elected, suggest that some in the media may not be taking the numbers seriously.

Hallberg also pointed out that media stories about Trump were six times more negative than those about Obama, with Obama's coverage being "far more favorable." She concluded that Trump's presidency has been controversial when it comes to his relationship with the media, but the high approval numbers were largely due to a fantastic December and the passage of tax reform.

Title: Obama Faces Challenges in Domestic and Foreign Policy as Second Term Begins

Article:

As Americans continue their post-Labor Day return to work, President Barack Obama has resumed his duties in the White House, facing a series of significant and complex issues that could shape his presidential legacy. The following outlines some of the most pressing challenges Obama will encounter in both domestic and foreign policy, as well as the qualities he may need to address them effectively.

In the short term, the most critical issue is reaching a new spending plan in collaboration with Congress by September 30 to avoid a government shutdown on October 1 and to raise the debt ceiling. The United States must also address its debt ceiling to prevent a potential default. While GOP leaders may not wish to cause a shutdown, they would like to see more spending cuts as part of the debt-ceiling deal. To navigate this situation, Obama will need to demonstrate patience and diplomacy.

In the long term, the economy remains a significant challenge. Obama plans to embark on a bus tour of the Northeastern United States to present his ideas for economic recovery. When he leaves office in January 2017, Americans will evaluate his performance based on whether they are better off than they were in 2009, when he took office. To achieve economic growth, Obama will need to demonstrate persuasive abilities, as he and the GOP have differing views on economic policy.

Foreign policy challenges include the humanitarian crisis in Syria and the political instability in Egypt. Both situations require concerted effort to uncover solutions, reduce human suffering, and move toward peace. Obama has shown caution in addressing these issues, which is generally a prudent approach when no clear best option presents itself. To navigate these challenges, Obama will need to demonstrate wisdom, courage, and diplomacy.

Another domestic challenge is funding and implementing the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as "Obamacare." Republicans feel they have a good chance to stop the ACA before it starts by withholding funding and slowing implementation at the state level. Obama will need determination, flexibility, and open-mindedness to find enough consensus to move forward.

Passing immigration reform legislation is another significant challenge. While GOP senators support bipartisan legislation, GOP representatives in the House are divided on the issue. They first want to address border security and find the idea of "amnesty" for those already illegally in the U.S. unacceptable. To win over GOP opponents, Obama will need determination, flexibility, and open-mindedness, looking for enough consensus to move forward.

Entertaining the 1972 Super Bowl champion Miami Dolphins football team on August 20 will provide a welcome relief for an embattled president who is also a sports fan. The most satisfying event for Obama may be helping to mark the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech on August 28. The connection between King's call for racial equality in 1963 and the nation's first African-American president makes an eloquent statement, regardless of the words the president chooses for the occasion.

Title: Debate Analysis: President Obama and Governor Romney's Foreign Policy Face-Off

Article:

In the third and final presidential debate of the 2012 election, President Barack Obama and Governor Mitt Romney engaged in a foreign policy discussion that, according to several news outlets, resulted in a draw. Both candidates presented strong arguments on various issues, with Romney demonstrating poise and preparedness, while Obama took a more aggressive approach.

Romney, as anticipated, aimed to present himself as informed, composed, and credible as a potential president. He effectively countered Obama's attacks, particularly those perceived as dishonest, and emphasized the need for solutions rather than confrontation.

Obama, on the other hand, often appeared to be the aggressor, challenging Romney in most of his responses. The candidates found common ground on several issues, such as Syria and Iran sanctions, leading to smaller disagreements over timing and the intensity of their respective responses.

Romney's strongest answers were on the economy, the national debt, Israel, and the so-called "apology tour." He concluded the debate effectively, while Obama shared a touching anecdote about meeting a 9/11 orphan and repeatedly emphasized his role as Commander-in-Chief.

In the post-debate analysis, several media outlets, including CNN and The New York Times, fact-checked a disagreement over the number of troops remaining in Iraq, with Romney being correct and Obama being wrong. The New York Times also supported Romney's contentions regarding the auto industry.

CBS's instant poll gave a substantial advantage to Obama, 53-23, with 24 percent calling it a tie. However, CNN's snap poll indicated a narrow Obama debate win, 48-40, with Romney running neck-and-neck with the sitting president on the Commander-in-Chief test.

The moderator, Bob Schieffer, was widely praised for his performance, executing his responsibilities effectively. Twitter volume suggested a significant decrease in viewership and interest compared to the first and second debates.

The president's team has already backpedaled from Obama's assertion that the sequestration defense cuts "will not happen." A bizarre moment on CNN involved swing voters in a focus group who claimed they had made up their minds but were not asked in which direction.

PPP insta-poll respondents gave the debate to Obama 53-42, but the poll appeared to be biased toward Democrats, and the results were relatively undramatic. The Romney team is likely to find this data point favorable, particularly among independent voters.

John Harris from Politico was not impressed with the president, stating that his performance "diminished" the presidency. CNN's post-debate poll indicated a narrow Obama debate win, but Romney was competitive on the Commander-in-Chief test.

Charles Krauthammer and Ross Douthat, prominent political commentators, agreed that Romney won the debate tactically and strategically. The big picture, according to Douthat, is that the snap polls will give a clear edge to Obama, but Romney's polling may not suffer significantly as a result.

Title: Reuters Media Columnist Jack Shafer Questions 'War on the Press' Narrative

Article:

Reuters media columnist Jack Shafer has raised questions about the notion of a "war on the press" in a May 24 piece, arguing that while there have been legal actions against the media, they do not amount to a full-scale war.

In the article, Shafer discusses the investigation of journalist James Rosen's emails, which he uses as a primary example of the alleged war on the press. He cites a George Washington University Law School professor who states that the labeling of journalism as a "criminal offense" in the affidavit for the search warrant does not necessarily indicate a prelude to prosecution.

Shafer's defense focuses on the language in the affidavit for the search warrant, but he also acknowledges that there has been a leak crackdown, albeit primarily among bureaucrats rather than journalists. He notes that the administration has been compared to an information "black hole" by his colleagues in the media.

However, Shafer's argument is nuanced, and he undercuts the arguments against President Obama at several points. He suggests that the press also lobbies like any other interest group and uses the traditional liberal defense of blaming Republicans for similar actions.

Despite Shafer's self-proclaimed non-liberal stance, his career and actions suggest otherwise. He has worked for left-wing publications such as The Washington City Paper and Slate, and his personal website features a prominent link to a "Hot Topic" called "Everything Murdoch," which includes columns critical of Fox and Rupert Murdoch.

In a previous column published on May 21, Shafer criticized Fox reporter James Rosen for poor journalistic practices. This column was a long critique of Rosen's reporting, despite Shafer's defense of the concept of Rosen's journalism in his later piece.

Shafer's columns carry the tagline: "Jack Shafer is a Reuters columnist, but his opinions are his own." In the media landscape, this statement remains largely accurate, as Shafer's defense of Obama's actions towards the press appears to be a singular perspective.

Title: Senate Democrats Pursue "Nuclear Option" to Alter Senate Rules on Executive Nominees

Article:

Senate Democrats have initiated a process to change the Senate rules regarding filibusters on executive branch nominees, setting up a potential showdown on Tuesday. This move, known as the "nuclear option," would allow the confirmation of President Obama's controversial appointments without the need for a supermajority, or 60 votes, to end a filibuster.

The decision to pursue the nuclear option follows Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's (D-NV) announcement that he would not use the option at the beginning of the year. However, after Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) delayed confirmation of some of President Obama's nominees, Mr. Reid changed his stance.

In a morning floor speech, Mr. Reid stated, "A deal is a deal, a contract is a contract, an arrangement is an arrangement, a bargain is a bargain, as long as each party to such an agreement holds up his end of the bargain."

Republicans have warned that they may retaliate if they regain the majority by ending other filibusters, allowing them to push through their own priorities without fear of minority obstruction.

The term "nuclear option" refers to changing the rules by a majority vote, rather than the two-thirds vote the Senate usually requires, which guarantees the minority certain rights that have defined the chamber throughout its history. If Republicans filibuster the nominees, Mr. Reid is expected to ask for a parliamentarian ruling on the legality of the filibuster. Based on Senate history, the parliamentarian will rule that it is legal, and Mr. Reid will move to overturn that ruling, which requires a simple majority and sets official precedent.

The nuclear option would apply only to executive branch and independent agency nominations, not judicial nominations or legislation. Democrats have historically used partisan filibusters of judicial nominees, but both parties have a long history of filibustering each other's executive branch appointments.

Seven nominees are scheduled for filibuster votes on Tuesday: the Labor Department secretary, Environmental Protection Agency administrator, three members of the National Labor Relations Board, the president of the Export-Import Bank, and the director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

Republicans have been slow-walking or outright blocking many of President Obama's nominees, but they signaled Thursday that they would be willing to relent and allow votes on most of them. The only nominees Republicans are reluctant to approve speedily are two NLRB nominees and the consumer bureau nominee, each of whom President Obama has installed to temporary appointments using his recess powers. A federal court ruled that this maneuver violated the Constitution.

It takes only a majority vote to approve a nominee on a final vote, but the minority is allowed to filibuster to prevent that final vote, and it takes 60 votes to end the filibuster. The increasing use of filibusters, or their threat, has shifted power from the president, whom the Constitution gives the right to nominate officers of the United States with the "advice and consent" of the Senate.

President Obama tried to regain some of that power by using his recess appointment powers in an unprecedented way. He appointed members to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the National Labor Relations Board even though the Senate did not consider itself in recess. Two federal appeals courts have ruled that President Obama's NLRB appointments violated the Constitution. The Supreme Court is set to hear one of the cases, and the ruling could dramatically circumscribe the president's power.

Mr. Reid waited until after he cleared a major immigration bill through his chamber to raise the filibuster issue, knowing it would be so contentious that it could have ruined his chances to win the bipartisan vote on that bill. Republicans contemplated using the nuclear option in 2005 to end Democratic filibusters of judicial nominees, but backed off after a bipartisan "Gang of 14" senators struck a deal that preserved the filibuster in limited circumstances. That deal has since dissipated.

Title: Kavanaugh Denies Sexual Misconduct Allegations in Fox News Interview

Article:

In an interview aired on Fox News' "The Story with Martha MacCallum" on Monday night, Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, sitting next to his wife Ashley Estes Kavanaugh, refuted allegations of sexual misconduct made by two women. The interview came days before the Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to hold another hearing on his confirmation. President Donald Trump nominated Kavanaugh in July to succeed Justice Anthony Kennedy on the high court.

The vote on Kavanaugh's nomination has been delayed due to allegations leveled by one of his accusers, psychology researcher and Palo Alto University professor Christine Blasey Ford. She alleges that while both were in high school, Kavanaugh held her down, put his hand over her mouth to silence her, and tried to remove her clothes.

A second woman, Deborah Ramirez, a Yale University classmate of Kavanaugh's, claims that he exposed himself to her and shoved his penis in her face at a dorm room party in their freshman year at the Ivy League school. She said they were playing a drinking game at the time and admits there are gaps in her memory of that night.

During the interview, Kavanaugh stated that he never had sexual intercourse "or anything close to (it)" until long after he left Georgetown Prep, the elite all-boys Catholic high school he attended in Rockville, Maryland. When asked about his sexual activity during the years in question, he answered, "Many years after."

Kavanaugh also denied the allegations made by Ford, stating, "I was never at any such party," and that the other people who were alleged to be present have said they do not remember any such party. He further stated, "I am not going to let false accusations drive us out of this process and we’re looking for a fair process where I can be heard and defend my integrity, my lifelong record."

President Trump is standing by his pick, stating during an appearance at the United Nations General Assembly in New York that Kavanaugh "is an absolutely outstanding person. Hopefully he will be confirmed quickly." Ashley Kavanaugh, who was the personal secretary to President George W. Bush when Brett Kavanaugh worked in the White House, sat next to her husband as he forcefully defended himself.

MacCallum asked Kavanaugh to address the specific allegations, whether he had ever blacked out from drinking too much in high school, and whether similar allegations by someone in high school should count against them later in life. Kavanaugh repeatedly refuted the allegations, stated that he never blacked out from drinking too much in high school, and responded, "I think everyone's judged on their whole life."

Shaunna Thomas, executive director of UltraViolet Action, a progressive group that opposes Kavanaugh's confirmation, criticized the judge for choosing the "comfort of a partisan network" to air his denials. "If Kavanaugh really wanted to get to the truth, he’d go to the FBI, not Fox News," she said. "This was the move of a political hack, not a nominee to the Supreme Court."

Title: Florida State University Shooting Leaves Three Injured, Gunman Identified as FSU Alum

Article:

A shooting incident at Florida State University (FSU) in Tallahassee left three people injured on Thursday, according to Tallahassee Police Chief Michael DeLeo. The gunman, identified as Myron May, a 2005 FSU graduate who had recently moved back to the area, was fatally shot by police.

May, who had written documents and made videos discussing being targeted by the government, was shot and killed by officers after refusing to surrender, according to DeLeo. The police chief did not confirm whether May fired at police.

May had written documents and made videos discussing being targeted by the government, and his Facebook page includes Bible verses and links to conspiracy theories about the government reading people's minds.

One victim was hospitalized in critical condition, another in good condition, and a third was treated at the scene and released. More than 300 students were in the Strozier Library when the shooting began at about 12:15 a.m.

Campus Police Chief David Perry said classes will resume on Friday, and the library will reopen. He promised a strong police presence. Officials canceled classes on Thursday but kept the campus open and made counseling available to students and staff.

Jason Derfuss, 21, was leaving the library when the shooter opened fire near him. Derfuss posted on Facebook pictures of a bullet and a book, Great Medieval Thinkers: John Wyclif, which the bullet had torn through. Derfuss says in his post he was near the gunman when the shooting started, but never felt the shot and only discovered the damage three hours later.

Allison Kope, a freshman from Cocoa Beach, Fla., said she ran for her life when she heard someone say, "Somebody's got a gun." She ran right out the back door and left her laptop and other belongings behind.

University President John Thrasher described the shootings as an isolated incident but also said police did "an extraordinary job taking quick and decisive action to prevent further tragedy."

Daniel Morales, a 19-year-old freshman from Fort Pierce, Fla., said that when he first heard someone say, "Somebody's got a gun," he thought they were joking. But after realizing a gunman was in the library, Morales and others raced to a back room on the second floor where they barricaded a door with desks.

Three freshmen who were in the DeGraff Hall dormitory at the time said they began getting reports from friends locked down in the library.

"We know there are definitely people who saw the shooter," Anthony Coons said.

"You hear all these stories on the news, then it happens," Martin said. "This is something you never want to happen."

Nikolai Hernandez, who was in another dorm room nearby, said he heard "consecutive gunshots" that sounded as if they came from an automatic rifle.

"That was confirmed when I went outside and talked to someone who said they saw police open fire on a shooter who was armed right on the front steps of the library," the freshman said.

The video below was posted on Facebook by Jessica Davis. An individual can be heard over the intercom saying, "There has been a shooting in the library. Stay where you are," and instructing people to call 911 if they have been shot.

Students were allowed to leave the library about 3 a.m. Before that, students were on lockdown at the campus' library and in dorms. FSU police issued an alert warning its 40,000 students that read: "Dangerous Situation! Main Campus - Tallahassee. Seek shelter immediately, away from doors and windows."

"If there is any positive news we can take from this occurrence, (it) is that the victim count was not higher," Tallahassee Mayor-elect Andrew Gillum said.

Social media immediately lit up with messages of concern and prayer requests.

Title: The Misrepresentation of Pre-existing Conditions and the Affordable Care Act

Article:

A new AP-NORC poll indicates that approximately half of Americans support the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. However, many Americans want the health care law repealed, and few want to maintain it in its current form. The social media narrative surrounding the ACA has been a subject of debate, with hashtags like #MakeAmericaSickAgain and #CoverageMatters emerging as rhetorical weapons for Obamacare defenders.

One such hashtag, #the27percent, claims that 27% of Americans under the age of 65 with pre-existing conditions could lose coverage if Obamacare is repealed. This statistic is based on a new report from the Kaiser Family Foundation. However, a closer examination of the data reveals that the pre-existing condition crisis used to sell Obamacare to voters never actually existed.

The ACA requires insurers to sell to all applicants, regardless of their health status or history. This "guaranteed issue" provision has been popular among Democrats and Republicans alike. Obamacare's defenders argue that repealing this provision will cause millions of people with pre-existing conditions to lose their coverage.

However, the Kaiser report estimates that 52 million non-elderly people, or 27% of the population, have uninsurable health conditions. Yet, even this smaller figure is an exaggeration. According to the Kaiser report, the vast majority of these individuals with declinable pre-existing conditions have coverage through an employer or through public programs like Medicaid.

Individuals insured through a government program have long been protected from coverage denials based on pre-existing conditions. Since 1996, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act has provided the same protection to Americans insured through their employers. Therefore, denials of coverage were only ever possible in the individual market pre-Obamacare.

A 2010 congressional investigation found that the nation's four largest insurers denied coverage to only one in seven applicants because of a pre-existing condition. Assuming the same denial rate in a post-Obamacare world, roughly 1% of the non-elderly population is actually at risk of losing coverage.

The GOP's replacement plan will still protect those with pre-existing conditions. The plan will bar insurers from raising people's premiums significantly, provided they maintain continuous coverage. If they cannot find affordable insurance on the open market, they'll be able to turn to state-based high-risk pools supported by $25 billion in federal funding over 10 years for subsidized coverage.

This network of high-risk pools will guarantee affordable coverage for those with pre-existing conditions without raising premiums for everyone else in the general insurance pool, as Obamacare did. The social media campaigners behind #the27percent are perpetuating precisely the false narrative about pre-existing conditions that gave rise to Obamacare in the first place. Instead of opting for #FakeNews, Obamacare's partisans should stick to the facts.

Sally C. Pipes, president and Thomas W. Smith Fellow in Health Care Policy at the Pacific Research Institute, is the author of The Way Out of Obamacare (Encounter 2016). Follow her on Twitter @sallypipes. You can read diverse opinions from our Board of Contributors and other writers on the Opinion front page, on Twitter @USATOpinion and in our daily Opinion newsletter. To submit a letter, comment, or column, check our submission guidelines.

Title: Hollywood Faces Challenges as Cinemas Reopen Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

As the United States gradually eases restrictions imposed during the COVID-19 pandemic, a semblance of normalcy returns, albeit in a limited capacity. Restaurants, stores, salons, and small gatherings are resuming their roles in weekly routines. However, one traditional aspect of American life remains absent: going to the movies.

Theaters, which were already struggling in an era of home streaming, are preparing to reopen in July. Yet, the movie industry faces significant challenges. Production of new movies has stalled during the pandemic, resulting in fewer releases than usual. Theaters are also implementing safety measures such as capacity limits and strict guidelines, including mandatory mask-wearing and temperature checks.

These precautions aim to ensure the safety of moviegoers, but they may hinder the immersive experience that draws audiences to the cinema. The fear of an infectious disease, the concession stand, the restroom, and the theater seat may detract from the intended 90-minute escape from reality.

Hollywood, like the rest of society, has been disoriented by the pandemic. Attempts to create content during this time, such as the widely criticized "Imagine" performance, have fallen short. Now, more than ever, the public seeks escapism from the anxiety and gloom of the past few months, not a reminder of it.

Several upcoming film releases, such as "Unhinged," "Tenet," and "The Rental," may be well-crafted, but they do not offer the desired escape from reality. These films, featuring themes of road rage, World War III, and surveillance, are not the desired antidote to the current climate.

However, there are glimmers of hope. Films like "The Little People," an Irish horror flick about a young couple besieged by 2-foot-tall goblins, and the rumored return of Michael Keaton as Batman in "The Flash," may provide the escapism audiences crave.

Despite the new realities of watching movies safely, there is faith that Hollywood can deliver another essential form of protection: perfectly pure escapism. S.E. Cupp, the host of "S.E. Cupp Unfiltered" on CNN, expresses this sentiment.

Title: District of Columbia's Political Lean Remains Steadfast Despite Demographic Shifts

Article:

The District of Columbia, the nation's capital, has maintained a consistent Democratic voting pattern in presidential elections, as reported by FiveThirtyEight in a recent article. Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton, the district's sole member of Congress, provided insights into the factors contributing to this political lean.

Historically, the District of Columbia has shown a significant Democratic bias, with the closest Republican victory being Ronald Reagan's loss by 61 percentage points in 1980. This trend is expected to continue in the 2012 election, with President Obama predicted to win an overwhelming majority of the vote on November 6.

The reason for this Democratic bias lies in the district's urban nature and its large black community. Cities, particularly those with a high black population, tend to vote Democratic, and Washington, D.C., fits this description. Black residents became a majority in Washington in the 1960 census, but they have always constituted a significant portion of the city's population. In the 1790s, about 25% of Washington residents were black. The black population peaked at 71% in the 1970s, after many white residents moved to suburbs.

However, over the last decade, Washington's economy has thrived, attracting young, affluent, mostly white professionals. These new residents have formed white pluralities in downtown neighborhoods like Chinatown and the Penn Quarter. Currently, 49% of adults in the District of Columbia have a college degree.

Simultaneously, many middle-class black families have moved to suburban communities in Maryland and Virginia. The high-income newcomers have caused rents and property taxes to rise in many neighborhoods, pushing out less wealthy longtime residents, many of them black. The 2010 census found the city's black majority barely intact, and demographers have reported that the black share of the population may have fallen below 50% since then.

Despite these demographic shifts, the changing racial makeup of Washington has not altered its voting patterns. The city has a large number of students and faculty members at colleges and universities, as well as a significant number of public-sector workers, both core Democratic constituencies.

Both longtime and new Washingtonians share a common dissatisfaction over the district's lack of a voting member of Congress. Delegate Norton, who can serve on committees and speak on the House floor but cannot vote on legislation, has been a vocal advocate for giving Washington's representative voting rights in Congress.

On Independence Day, a holiday marking the struggle for political representation, Delegate Norton planned to walk in a Fourth of July parade, symbolizing Washingtonians' struggle for full voting rights. Unless Mitt Romney personally defeats an alien invasion—and maybe not even then—President Obama is expected to win the District of Columbia's three electoral votes.

Title: South Korea Denies Imminent Nuclear Test by North Korea, Tensions Escalate

Article:

Military and government officials in South Korea have denied reports that Seoul had detected signs North Korea was preparing for an imminent nuclear arms test. However, a mid-range, conventional missile test by the North remains highly likely, and may occur within the next week, according to analysts in the South.

Strategic provocation, such as a missile or nuclear test, is considered "more probable" than military provocation, such as a direct attack against South Korea, said Kim Sung-han, an international relations expert at Korea University in Seoul. The former does not have to invite immediate retaliation, but the latter will provoke "massive retaliation" from South Korea, Kim added.

The United States' top military commander in South Korea, Gen. James Thurman, and South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman, Gen. Jung Seung-jo, have both canceled separate, long-scheduled trips to Washington in the next week.

North Korea said Monday it will recall 51,000 North Korean workers and suspend operations at a factory complex it has jointly run with South Korea, moving closer to severing its last economic link with its rival as tensions escalate. The statement from Kim Yang Gon, secretary of a key decision-making body, the Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea, did not specify what would happen to the 475 South Korean managers still at the Kaesong industrial complex in North Korea.

The statement comes amid weeks of North Korean war threats and other efforts to punish South Korea and the U.S. for ongoing joint military drills. North Korea is also angry over the U.S.-led push for United Nations sanctions over its Feb. 12 nuclear test.

Pyongyang may launch a missile at some point in the next seven days. Wednesday is the day beyond which Pyongyang warned last week it can not guarantee the safety of diplomatic staff for the limited number of countries that maintain diplomatic representation there.

Next Monday, April 15, is the anniversary of the birth of Kim Il Sung, a key date in a state whose main religion is the cult of the Kim family.

If the North fires missiles or conducts another nuclear test, "I think South Korea and international society will rely on the United Nations Security Council," Kim said. "This type of diplomatic response is more probable."

South Korea is concerned about a provocative attack near the border areas or a possible terrorist attack from the North that is difficult to identify quickly, as with the sinking of the South Korean navy ship Cheonan in 2010.

Of great concern is not knowing how the North's relatively new leadership will act. The North began hurling threats and curtailing ties after new economic sanctions were imposed on it by the U.N. to get it to halt its nuclear program. The threats were increased during routine annual training exercises between the U.S. and South Korean militaries.

Unlike his father Kim Jong Il, who had more than 15 years to prepare for stepping into the shoes of his father Kim Il Sung, the current leader Kim Jong Un, 30, is ill-prepared for his role, and rushing to deepen his power base, say analysts.

"This problem of power consolidation is his gigantic task to accomplish in a short period of time," Kim said.

The current crisis "should culminate around 15 April, but will remain noisy until late April," predicted Andrei Lankov, a North Korea specialist at Koomkin University in Seoul. From the North Korean perspective, a missile test is "cheap and necessary," compared to a nuclear test that will deplete the North's limited plutonium supply, he said.

The North Korean regime is "gradually losing domestic support. There is a chance of an outbreak of public discontent," he said. "It's always helpful to remind the people that their country is surrounded by evil and scheming enemies, and only the leader and the army can keep the country secure."

There is a "high possibility" of an imminent provocation from North Korea, but a mid-range missile test is "more likely" than another nuclear test, said Shin Jong Dae, a professor at the University of North Korean Studies in Seoul.

"The Park Geun-hye administration are taking the threat from North Korea seriously, but they don't see signs North Korea is preparing to attack South Korea. I think the South Korean government will preserve a cool stance," even if the North conducts a missile test, he said.

While some analysts insist domestic concerns guide Kim Jong Un's actions, Shin said foreign policy goals drive Pyongyang's recent threats and tests.

"They want to force South Korea and United States to offer dialogue, and to extract concessions from Washington and Seoul," he said.

The industrial complex that Pyongyang said would be shut down combines cheap North Korean labor and South Korean know-how and technology. It is the last remaining inter-Korean rapprochement project from previous eras of cooperation.

North Korea closed the border to northbound South Korean managers and cargo last week, though managers already there were allowed to stay. About a dozen of the more than 120 South Korean companies at Kaesong have already shut down because they can no longer get needed supplies.

"The zone is now in the grip of a serious crisis," Kim said, according to state media. He said it "has been reduced to a theater of confrontation with fellow countrymen and military provocation, quite contrary to its original nature and mission."

Title: Reagan's Landslide Victory over Carter in 1980 and Parallels to the 2016 Presidential Debate

Article:

In the 1980 presidential election, Ronald Reagan's victory over Jimmy Carter was attributed to several factors, including economic "misery," public anxiety over American hostages in Iran, and the splintering of the Democratic voting coalition. A significant factor, as reported by ███, was a televised debate in which Carter attempted to portray Reagan as a "simpleton" and hard-right war-monger, but failed. Instead, Reagan was perceived as "calm and reasonable," a decisive achievement for him with many undecided voters.

Fast forward to the 1984 election, Reagan's second debate against Walter Mondale was also highlighted for its impact. Reagan's performance was described as "relaxed" and included an "eye-twinkling one-liner" about not exploiting Mondale's "youth and inexperience." The second debate was considered "indispensable" because the first debate had seen the president floundering after being urged to show off a mastery of technical policy details, only to seem overwhelmed. However, a new tactic was employed by the Reagan White House to spin the debate in their favor, with high-ranking insiders fanning out across the press room to press their verdict on reporters.

As the first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton approaches, some historical parallels are emerging. Candidates can mangle facts and botch details and still win if a debate performance conveys a simple message: this is someone presidential.

In 2000, a TV debate between George W. Bush and Al Gore showed both candidates fighting against negative stereotypes of themselves. Bush was fighting the idea that he knew nothing, while Gore was fighting the idea that he was obnoxious or a liar.

In the 2016 election, both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton need to fight not just with each other, but to slay their own monsters. Trump needs to reassure voters who worry that he is too ignorant, too divisive, and too hot-headed to lead, while Clinton needs to win over voters who dislike her as a calculating avatar for everything they resent about politics.

The test set by Monday's debate is the same for both: can Americans imagine waking on the morning after election day, feeling happy, comfortable, or even safe as they contemplate President Trump or President Clinton in the Oval Office?

███'s correspondents in America will live-tweet their analyses of the debate from 9pm New York time (2am London, 9am Hong Kong). Follow our coverage here.

Title: New Yorker Publishes Allegations Against Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh, Raising Questions About Credibility

Article:

The New Yorker magazine has published an account alleging that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh exposed himself to a woman while they were both students at Yale University. The alleged incident, which reportedly occurred during a drunken party in their freshman year, has been met with skepticism due to the accuser's shifting recollections and the lack of corroborating evidence.

The woman making the charge, Deborah Ramirez, initially expressed uncertainty about Kavanaugh's role in the incident, according to the magazine. She only decided to speak out after six days of assessing her memories and consulting with her attorney. However, her account still contains gaps, as she was drunk and did not directly see Kavanaugh during the incident.

The only other corroboration comes from an unidentified classmate who reportedly told the magazine that they heard about the incident later. The New Yorker has not confirmed with other eyewitnesses that Kavanaugh was present at the party, a significant omission if the story is to be used as evidence in an attempt to damage Kavanaugh's reputation. Two male students identified by Ramirez as being present at the party have stated they have no recollection of any such incident.

The New Yorker story comes after another blow to the credibility of Christine Blasey Ford's account, who has accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault when they were both teenagers. Ford has identified four other people who were present at the high-school party, all of whom have denied the allegations. Leland Keyser, a long-time friend of Ford's and a Democrat, has stated through her lawyer that she does not know Kavanaugh and has no recollection of ever being at a party or gathering where he was present.

The opposition to Kavanaugh is reportedly hoping that the two stories, with potentially more on the way, will support each other despite their inherent weakness. If Democrats manage to derail Kavanaugh's nomination on the basis of these charges, they will have achieved a miraculous feat by stopping a Supreme Court nominee with two unproven and probably unprovable charges, in what some are calling a disgraceful episode that makes Borking look above-board and responsible by comparison.

If Republicans choose to withdraw Kavanaugh's nomination based on the current evidence, they may face the ire of their own voters, who have expressed strong support for the nominee. The facts, as they currently stand, lead to the belief that this is a questionable episode that raises serious questions about the credibility of the allegations against Kavanaugh.

Title: Environmental Lobbies and Climate Activists Call for Ban on CO2 Coalition

Article:

Stacey Abrams, former gubernatorial candidate of Georgia, and Tom Steyer, former presidential candidate, are advocating for the ban of the CO2 Coalition, a research group that focuses on the benefits of carbon dioxide emissions. The CO2 Coalition, which consists of 55 climate scientists and energy economists, has an annual budget of half a million dollars, in contrast to the combined annual budgets of the 17 large environmental lobbies, totaling over half a billion dollars, and Steyer's personal wealth of $1.6 billion.

The CO2 Coalition's primary focus is on the role of carbon dioxide, a non-polluting, mild warming gas, as a source of plant and plankton food. The group's budget is significantly smaller compared to the environmental lobbies, and their views on climate change are often excluded from mainstream media discussions.

The campaign to ban the CO2 Coalition is led by Eric Michelman, a Silicon Valley computer entrepreneur who has been advocating for climate change alarmism for over a decade. Michelman is the founding and lead funder of Climate Feedback, a group that "fact-checks" and labels as "false" any deviant thoughts about fossil-fueled climate catastrophe. Climate Feedback is certified as an unbiased source on climate issues by the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, which operates the left-leaning PolitiFact.

In 2019, a "false" label was placed on a Washington Examiner article written by Dr. Patrick Michaels, a senior fellow at the CO2 Coalition, and the article's author, Dr. Caleb Rossiter, the executive director of the CO2 Coalition. The label triggered a wave of censorship from Facebook's algorithms, blocking reposting and advertising. The detailed, scientifically referenced letter written by the CO2 Coalition to Facebook was almost identical in form and argument to responses this summer to similar Climate Feedback censorship written by environmental writer Michael Shellenberger, Dr. Michaels, and climate statistician Dr. Roger Pielke Jr.

Climate Feedback has been criticized for its bias, sloppiness, and inaccuracies. For example, the group contradicts the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's finding that there has been no statistically significant increase in rates of sea-level rise, hurricanes, droughts, and floods during the carbon emissions era.

Michelman's Climate Feedback is his third major attempt at promoting climate alarmism and silencing opposing views. Previous attempts include the Climate Change Education Project in 2008 and the More than Scientists campaign in 2015. Michelman's group should never have been let into a network of "unbiased" reviewers, and its performance shows why.

Dr. Caleb Rossiter, the executive director of the CO2 Coalition, is open to debating with Climate Feedback but believes that the cancel culture does not believe in debate. Instead, it aims to silence its opponents by denying them a platform. The CO2 Coalition intends to hold on as long as possible, believing that the truth will eventually prevail, even against "fact-checkers."

Title: Military Background of George Washington's First Cabinet

Article:

George Washington's first cabinet, the first in the history of the United States, consisted of 80% members with military experience, if Washington is included in the count. Thomas Jefferson, the Secretary of State, was the sole civilian member.

Washington hand-picked every member of his cabinet. For the Secretary of the Treasury, he chose Alexander Hamilton, who was born on the island of Nevis in the Caribbean and was illegitimate. Hamilton, who had no military training, joined the Continental Army as an artillery officer during the American Revolution and met Washington in this capacity.

Thomas Jefferson and Patrick Henry wrote to Washington, recommending Edmund Randolph, another aide-de-camp, as a young patriot with no military training but eager to serve. Randolph, however, was called home to settle his uncle's estate and take over management of the Randolph fortune.

Henry Knox, America's first Secretary of War, was from Boston and had no military training before the Revolution. He made his living as a bookbinder but studied engineering and military tactics in his spare time. Knox enlisted in the Revolution and designed an artillery rampart in Roxbury, which Washington admired. He was named the chief of artillery and played a significant role in the American victory at the Battle of Yorktown.

Samuel Osgood, the first Postmaster General, led a company of local militia at the Battle of Lexington and Concord and was promoted to Major during the Siege of Boston.

The article concludes by stating that the concern over the generals Trump has appointed or is considering for his cabinet is unwarranted, given the ongoing wars in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Syria, as well as the threat posed by the Islamic State. The article argues that military men have leadership skills, are loyal, and have been defending the American people and the Constitution for 227 years.
