Facebook has previously taken similar actions against pages associated with Infowars, a move that has been criticized by the right as "censorship" by Silicon Valley. In May, Facebook issued bans against Alex Jones, Paul Joseph Watson, Laura Loomer, Milo Yiannopoulos, and anti-Semitic and Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, with the bans also applying to Facebook-owned Instagram.

In response to the bans in May, a Facebook spokesperson stated, "We've always banned individuals or organizations that promote or engage in violence and hate, regardless of ideology. The process for evaluating potential violators is extensive and it is what led us to our decision to remove these accounts today."

Facebook has been taking stronger actions against conspiracy and extremist content over the past year. In August, it banned Infowars and its founder Alex Jones, although Infowars appears to have used similar-sounding pages like "Newswars" to promote its content after the ban.

Additionally, Facebook began taking stronger actions against anti-vaccination hoaxes this year, banning anti-vax ads in March. These ads were previously targeted at women in measles-stricken areas, according to The ███.

Title: Facebook Takes Steps to Combat Fake News, Enlists Third-Party Fact Checkers

Article:

Facebook Inc. is taking measures to address its role in the dissemination of fake news, including enlisting third-party fact-checkers and posting warnings on questionable stories. In response to criticism that Facebook's news feed may have rewarded false stories during the lead-up to the U.S. presidential election, such as a post claiming Donald Trump had Pope's endorsement, Facebook's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, outlined steps the company has already initiated.

Zuckerberg stated, "We need to be careful not to discourage sharing of opinions or mistakenly restricting accurate content. We do not want to be arbiters of truth ourselves, but instead rely on our community and trusted third parties."

Facebook is considering labeling stories that have been debunked by third parties or the community, providing a warning before they are read or shared. The company is also working to simplify the process for users to report fake news and improve technical systems to better detect such articles.

In addition, Facebook is seeking external assistance. The company plans to meet with journalists to understand their information verification processes and is exploring partnerships with third-party fact-checking organizations.

Zuckerberg acknowledged that fake news has become a lucrative business and stated that Facebook is investigating ways to disrupt the economics of it.

These remarks come just a few days after Zuckerberg described the idea that fake news on Facebook influenced the election outcome as "crazy." He previously stated that more than 99 percent of the stories on Facebook are accurate. However, criticism of his handling of the issue has grown, and by the end of the week, even President Barack Obama spoke about the negative impact of fake stories on social media.

Zuckerberg concluded, "Some of these ideas will work well, and some will not. But I want you to know that we have always taken this seriously, we understand how important the issue is for our community, and we are committed to getting this right."

Title: Schools Across U.S. to Remain Closed for Several Months; Reopening Plans Call for Social Distancing Measures

Article:

President Trump last week urged the nation's governors to "seriously consider" reopening schools as part of a larger push to revive the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. However, most schools in the United States will remain closed for at least several months. A total of 45 states and Washington, D.C., have ordered or recommended school building closures through the end of the academic year and shifted their focus to possibly resuming in-person instruction in the fall.

The impact of shifting to distance learning has been significant. Students, especially those in vulnerable groups, are missing out on important academic and social development. Meanwhile, many parents are unable to work without a reliable place to send their kids every day. Experts agree that reopening schools will be one of the most important steps in getting the country back to normal.

Optimistic forecasters suggest schools will be able to safely reopen on time in the fall, though day-to-day instruction will likely look very different. A vaccine won't be widely available for another year at the very earliest, health experts say, meaning the coronavirus will be a threat through the entirety of the next school year. Most models for a return to instruction call for social distancing measures to protect students, teachers, and parents at home from infection. Suggested changes include limiting class sizes to keep desks far apart, staggered schedules to limit the number of kids on campus, and a blend of online and in-person learning.

The next few months will also provide important data on the viability of reopening schools. There's significant evidence that the virus poses less risk to young children than adults. Some epidemiologists say there's reason to believe kids are also less likely to pass it on to others, though there's not enough research to know for sure yet. The U.S. will also learn a lot about the impact of reopening from schools in other countries, some of which are already bringing students back.

Others point to a long list of logistical hurdles that need to be resolved before schools can open. The biggest challenge will be lack of resources, some argue. Many of the country's 13,000 school districts were struggling to operate before the pandemic, a problem that will only be exacerbated amid the economic downturn caused by the virus. Without proper funding, there won't be enough space or staff available to enact distancing measures, some administrators argue. Any plan to return will also need to be approved by the teachers unions. The biggest unions in the United States have already suggested they would strike if proper safety measures weren't in place when schools return.

Another point of view suggests schools should only reopen when testing is widely available and technology to effectively track outbreaks is in use, even if that takes well beyond the start of the next school year. A number of national education associations have banded together to lobby Congress for $200 billion to prop up state budgets and ensure that schools have the resources to reopen safely. Funding for states is expected to be a major point of debate as lawmakers in Washington consider yet another massive stimulus bill in the coming days and weeks.

"Whenever students do come back, classes are unlikely to look anything like the school days they remember. There may be staggered half-day classes or one-day-on, one-day-off schedules so desks can be spread out and buses can run half-empty." - Shawn Hubler, Erica L. Green, and Dana Goldstein, New York Times

"Like so much else right now, the opening of schools seems to depend most of all on the availability of testing, either at the community or school level, on a scale that seems impossible as long as the Trump administration fails to act." - Dan Froomkin, Salon.

Title: Trump's Strike on Soleimani and Its Aftermath: A Look at the Current Political Landscape

Article:

Following the U.S. strike that resulted in the death of Iran's top military commander, Qassem Soleimani, the political landscape surrounding Iran policy has shifted significantly.

Senator Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.) stated that President Trump is now in a "negotiating position" due to Iran's own foreign minister's readiness to engage in diplomatic talks. Inhofe added that Trump has already achieved a victory and there is no need for further military action.

On the other hand, some Democrats view Trump's strike as another example of his erratic foreign policy decisions. Senator Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.) expressed concern that the U.S. is in a worse position than a week ago and fears that Trump's legacy could be a nuclear-armed Iran.

Senator Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) stated that he now has a better understanding of the reasons behind the strike and the timing of the action. However, most Democrats argue that there is a lack of strategy, proportionality, and predictability in the administration's response to Iran-related events.

Two Republican senators, Mike Lee (R-Utah) and Rand Paul (R-Ky.), have announced their intention to support efforts to constrain Trump's military stance toward Iran due to their dissatisfaction with Wednesday's briefing. Senator Mike Lee criticized the administration for not allowing debate and discussion on the appropriateness of further military intervention against Iran.

Experts warn that Iran could respond with missile attacks, cyberattacks, or proxy attacks against the U.S. or its allies. The Department of Homeland Security has issued a warning that an attack in the U.S. may come with little or no warning.

Trump's aides and allies argue that his approach has left the U.S. in a better position than under his predecessor, as the decision to kill Soleimani sent a clear message to the Iranian regime to deter future attacks from Iran-linked groups. Those in defense of the Trump administration's maximum pressure campaign argue that the U.S. and Iran were always on a collision course, but now, as the two countries come head to head, Trump is dealing with an economically anemic regime.

Within the Republican Party, there was a general sense of relief on Wednesday, with Senator Mitt Romney (R-Utah) praising Trump's address and expressing relief that Soleimani, a "very bad person," was dead. However, Romney noted that the long-term results depend on Iran's actions and expressed doubt that Trump has any interest in going to war with Iran.

Title: Congress Fails to Renew Federal Funding, Leading to Government Shutdown

Article:

Congress adjourned early Tuesday morning without renewing funding for the federal government, resulting in the White House issuing orders to shut down "nonessential" services across the nation. Senators adjourned first, while House lawmakers continued past 1 a.m., but a middle ground remained elusive.

With no deal in sight to continue funding into fiscal year 2014, the White House Budget Office issued an order to begin closing operations, sending 800,000 federal workers on furlough and leaving hundreds of thousands more employees to report for work without the guarantee of paychecks.

One program that did not shut down was the program at the center of the Republican ire—Obamacare itself. The President's health care overhaul is funded through other laws and, despite the shutdown, is operational as of Tuesday morning. Americans without health insurance can now go on state-based exchanges to begin shopping for insurance, often with the benefit of government aid.

The debate raged as Congress approached the deadline, with House Republicans sending repeated proposals to Senate Democrats, though never the one plan senators demanded: a funding bill with no strings attached.

"It is now midnight, and the great government of the United States is now closed," Rep. Louise Slaughter, New York Democrat, said on the House floor at the deadline.

President Obama increased the pressure, releasing a video message early Tuesday morning to American troops, in which he blamed Congress for letting the military down.

"It has failed to pass a budget and, as a result, much of our government must now shut down until Congress funds it again," he said.

A last-ditch House plan to request formal talks with Senate Democrats was met with derision by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, who said there will be no negotiations with the threat of a shutdown still looming.

At stake were most basic government operations. National parks were preparing to shutter, federal agencies were notifying about 800,000 nonessential employees who will be furloughed, and officials warned that there would be delays in processing new benefit applications for a wide range of programs.

However, the list of what is deemed "essential" and remains in effect was longer: air traffic controllers, Border Patrol agents, the military, and federal law enforcement would remain on the job, though, with the exception of the troops, they would do so without paychecks—at least in the near term.

House Speaker John A. Boehner emerged after a final House vote to say he felt he and his troops had done their best to keep the government open while trying to also make a dent in the health care law.

"We are hoping the Senate will take our offer," he said in a brief press conference.

House Democrats, though, said the GOP's push for talks was a smokescreen to cover the fact that Republicans wanted to force a shutdown.

Republicans said that wasn't true, and they pointed to the three separate proposals they'd already sent to the Senate to cancel, delay, or otherwise change Obamacare, only to see each of them defeated by a unified Democratic caucus in the Senate.

For their part, Senate Democrats have passed a bill to fund the government through Nov. 15 and have refused any other offers, saying they need to take a stand against what they called "extortion" by the GOP.

"We will not go to conference with a gun to our head," Mr. Reid said.

Republicans countered that if senators wouldn't even agree to talk, it showed they were the ones who wanted a shutdown.

"This is a logical next step when the House and Senate are unable to resolve our differences," said Rep. Hal Rogers, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

Title: Aetna's Exit from Obamacare Exchanges Highlights Challenges in Some Regions, Experts Offer Solutions

Article:

Aetna's announcement this week that it is withdrawing from "Obamacare" market exchanges in 11 states has added to the perception that the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is facing difficulties. However, the ACA has other components that are functioning, according to Chris Sloan, senior manager at Avalere Health, a healthcare consulting company in Washington.

While premiums are set to rise more quickly next year, by 9 percent instead of 2 percent, they are still, on average, less expensive than the government's original forecast. Approximately 20 million Americans now have health insurance who did not have it before. Moreover, projections for the total cost of healthcare in America have fallen by $2.6 trillion compared to the government's forecast in 2010, when the law was signed.

Aetna's move, however, highlights a problematic aspect of the new system, particularly in some rural areas: the "exchange" markets where people choose their insurer under Obamacare. The issue is that key insurers are losing hundreds of millions of dollars in these exchanges and are pulling out of some of them, leaving consumers with only one insurer, i.e., no choice.

Avalere Health's forecast, released on Friday, suggests that a third of the country's exchange regions may offer only one insurer in 2017. This analysis reflects publicly announced pullbacks from exchanges by insurer giants Aetna, Humana, and UnitedHealthcare and by some co-ops for 2017. The marketplace exchanges, which cover about 11 million people in total, enable people to get subsidized healthcare.

Seven states – Alaska, Alabama, Kansas, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, and Wyoming – are expected to offer only one insurer in each market-exchange region in the state, according to Avalere Health's analysis. This analysis does not account for insurers that may still be planning to enter these markets, which is a distinct possibility.

Some argue that pullouts by insurer heavyweights from some of the exchange markets do not necessarily spell doomsday. Some of these markets are serviced by smaller insurers, and the big companies simply couldn't compete.

"When some insurers are coming in with narrower networks, at a lower price, that's what you want," says Linda Blumberg, an expert on the exchanges at the Urban Institute. That's healthy competition, she says, "not necessarily a cause for panic."

However, policy experts such as Ms. Blumberg and Mr. Sloan offer several suggestions on how to address the lack of competition in some parts of the country. Some fixes require action by Congress, but that's not a remote possibility before the election, though it may be possible afterward, depending on the outcome, analysts say.

Here are some of the commonly suggested "fixes" to the exchanges:

1. Expand the pool of healthy enrollees: A big problem is that there aren't enough young, healthy enrollees in some of the exchange markets to balance out the costs of older participants whose care is more expensive.

2. Increase outreach efforts to attract healthier people.

3. Offer plans that young people perceive as desirable and affordable, which would mean changing the government requirements for the plans.

4. Increase federal financial support in troubled markets.

5. Allow states to take the lead in designing plans to serve their populations.

6. Encourage states to expand their markets by allowing competition between exchange-market regions within and between states. Inter-state exchanges would require a compact between states.

Whether Congress and the next administration will work toward some of these fixes depends entirely on the makeup of the next Congress and who wins the White House, say experts. Experts of all stripes interviewed for this story said that Hillary Clinton would be more likely to reach a deal with Congress than would Donald Trump, though they did not rule out an effort by the billionaire dealmaker. However, outright repeal is unlikely, they said, given the blocking power of Democrats in the Senate and the loud cry that would arise from taking away a benefit, even one with problems.

Title: Syriza Party Takes Power in Greece, Promising to Re-negotiate Bailout Terms

Article:

The Syriza party, a far-left coalition, has formed a government in Greece after securing a coalition with the Independent Greeks party. The new government, led by Alexis Tsipras, has vowed to re-negotiate the terms of Greece's international bailout, which has been a source of contention since its implementation in 2010.

The bailout, totaling approximately $270 billion, has allowed Greece to avoid bankruptcy but has come at the cost of severe spending cuts. The Syriza party, which did not win the absolute majority of seats in Sunday's election, has the support of the Independent Greeks party, which holds 13 seats in the 300-seat parliament.

Tsipras, who was sworn in as the new Greek prime minister on Monday, has pledged to secure better terms for Greece as it grapples with high unemployment, anemic growth, and a 30% decrease in GDP since the financial crisis. The country's unemployment rate stands at 26%, and one-third of its population lives below the poverty line.

In a statement, the White House congratulated the country, expressing support for Greece's efforts to recover economically. The Athens Stock Exchange initially dropped nearly 4% before recovering some losses. Markets across Asia and Europe were weaker, although the euro currency strengthened slightly on Monday.

Giorgos Stathakis, Syriza's financial planning official, stated that the new government has no plans to meet with negotiators from the European Commission, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund (the "troika") and will instead seek talks directly with governments. Yields on Greece's 10-year government bonds increased 40 basis points to 8.81%.

Analysts suggest that doubts over the extension of the EU bailout program could put pressure on Greek bonds and the euro. The Syriza party's victory could also signal a shift in European politics towards economic populism, potentially leading to increased pressure to pare back austerity measures within Spain and Italy.

European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, have warned the Syriza party not to make promises to the Greek electorate that it cannot keep and to respect the current debt arrangements. Tsipras, in response, stated, "Greece is leaving behind catastrophic austerity, fear, and autocratic government."

Title: Trump Praises Michael Cohen for Not Alleging Collusion with Russia, Criticizes Timing of Testimony

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has criticized his former attorney Michael Cohen for lying in testimony to Congress but found reason to praise him for not alleging Trump's campaign colluded with Russia in 2016.

During a news conference in Vietnam following a failed peace deal with North Korea's Kim Jong Un, Trump called the blockbuster hearing back in Washington "fake" and said it should not have been scheduled during his trip.

"He lied a lot, but it was very interesting because he didn't lie about one thing - he said no collusion with the Russian hoax," Trump said.

"I wonder why he didn't lie about that too, like he did about everything else. I was actually impressed that he didn't say, 'well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that.' He didn't say that," Trump added.

Cohen testified on Wednesday, calling Trump a "conman" who knew in advance about the release of stolen emails aimed at hurting his Democratic rival in the 2016 election campaign.

Trump criticized the timing of the hearing, saying it should not have been held while he was on an important trip.

"Having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing. They could have made it two days later or next week," he said.

"But having it during this very important summit is sort of incredible," Trump added.

Trump has called an investigation into possible collusion between Moscow and his presidential campaign a "witch hunt."

Cohen, 52, was a close aide of Trump for years, and his testimony could increase the legal and political pressure on the Republican president. However, Cohen did not appear to disclose a "smoking gun" that could sink his former boss.

Cohen said he had no direct evidence that Trump or his campaign colluded with Moscow during the election campaign. Possible collusion is a key theme of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation, which has dogged the president during his two years in office. Trump has repeatedly denied the allegation as has the Kremlin.

Title: Lawyer for Accuser in Trump Defamation Case Discusses Funding and Donations

Article:

Attorney Lisa Bloom, representing Summer Zervos in her defamation case against President Donald Trump, has stated that she is not concerned about the motivations of donors supporting Ms. Zervos' case. In an interview, Ms. Bloom expressed that she does not have the means to determine whether donors have a political agenda or simply believe in the importance of truth.

Ms. Bloom has been actively soliciting donations for Ms. Zervos' case online and has discussed fundraising assistance with David Brock, a former self-described "right-wing hit man" who became a staunch supporter of Hillary Clinton during her campaign against Mr. Trump.

As of the interview, Ms. Bloom reported that the fundraising efforts have yielded approximately $30,000, primarily in small donations. The funds are being used for expenses such as depositions, but have not been utilized to cover legal fees, which Ms. Bloom stated have already reached $150,000. Ms. Bloom and Ms. Zervos will not personally accept any of the donated funds.

In an email, Ms. Bloom wrote, "We certainly do not see any prospect of being paid by the fund based on the amounts donated to date. Nevertheless, we will continue to devote ourselves to Ms. Zervos' case because we believe, as does Ms. Zervos, that truth matters and that President Trump should be held accountable for his words and actions."

During the 2016 presidential campaign, Ms. Zervos accused Mr. Trump of sexually assaulting her in 2007, following her appearance as a contestant on his reality TV show, "The Apprentice." Mr. Trump dismissed these and other accusers' claims as "made-up nonsense" and suggested they were motivated by fame or were orchestrated by Hillary Clinton's campaign. These comments form the basis for the defamation suit Ms. Zervos filed after the election. A judge is currently deciding whether to allow the lawsuit to proceed.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach to Foreign Policy Affects U.S. Diplomacy

Article:

In the last week, President-elect Donald Trump has made several controversial statements regarding foreign policy issues. He has called for the strengthening and expansion of the United States' nuclear capabilities, accused China of an unprecedented act in seizing a U.S. Navy underwater drone in the South China Sea, and suggested that the U.S. should let China keep the drone after its return. Trump also condemned the deadly truck rampage at a Christmas market in Berlin as an "attack on humanity," and linked it to his proposed immigration ban from countries with a history of Islamic extremism. He further suggested that the U.S., along with other countries, should "fight back" against such attacks.

Trump's pronouncements, often vague and offhand, have raised questions about their long-term impact on policy. However, his intervention in pressuring Egypt to delay a United Nations Security Council vote disrupted a sensitive diplomatic negotiation and potentially undermined President Barack Obama's final opportunity to make a statement on the stalled Middle East peace process.

When Egypt yielded to Trump's pressure, the same resolution was brought to a vote by four other countries on the Security Council: Malaysia, New Zealand, Senegal, and Venezuela. The U.S. largely observed the proceedings from the sidelines. On Friday morning, President Obama, from his vacation home in Hawaii, directed his national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, to instruct the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, not to block the resolution.

Daniel C. Kurtzer, a former American ambassador to both Egypt and Israel, commented, "In a practical sense, the message this sends is that the Obama administration is over. Everybody knows this resolution doesn't carry any weight. The assumption has to be that the Israeli government will take some retaliatory measures. Knowing that Trump is coming into office, and knowing that Trump tried to oppose this, they will do so with impunity."

This role reversal between the departing and incoming presidents has deepened what was already an unsettled moment in American foreign policy. There is a sense that the White House's policies toward the world's most troubled places have run out of steam and are about to change radically, but in ways that are wholly unpredictable.

Trump has been respectful of his predecessor, and his aides have stated that the two men have spoken often. However, Trump has shown little patience for the traditions of the interregnum between presidents.

Title: National Review Publishes Anti-Trump Editorial, 22 Conservative Thought Leaders Voice Concerns

Article:

The National Review, a conservative American magazine founded by William F. Buckley, has published an editorial expressing concerns about Donald Trump's potential presidency. The editorial follows a series of submissions from 22 right-leaning thought leaders who question Trump's suitability for the American presidency.

The central issue appears to be ideological, with the National Review editors expressing concern that Trump's populist approach could alter the conservative ideological consensus within the Republican Party. The editorial concludes that Trump is a political opportunist who might undermine the traditional conservative ideals of limited and orderly government.

While not all contributors to the anti-Trump effort are absolute Trump opponents, many express doubts about Trump's political leanings. Some point to his past donations to Democratic parties and his support for single-payer healthcare. Others question his assertions that his personality alone can solve complex problems, perceiving an authoritarian streak in these claims.

William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, writes in his National Review section that Trump's approach resembles a "two-bit Caesarism" that American conservatives have historically disdained.

Despite the anti-Trump sentiments, Trump remains popular, leading in New Hampshire and tied in Iowa. His core supporters may view such criticisms as validating his anti-establishment stance, a significant part of his appeal.

In response to the editorial, Trump tweeted, "National Review is a failing publication that has lost its way. Its circulation is way down, with its influence being at an all-time low. Sad!"

The core challenge for the anti-Trump movement is the lack of a viable alternative candidate. With the primary season approaching, the Republican establishment has yet to rally around a preferred candidate, leaving the race between Trump and Ted Cruz.

Political analyst Jonathan Bernstein, in his Bloomberg View column, noted, "What is clear is that at least for now, Republican party actors have collectively failed to choose any of the remaining mainstream conservatives – Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, or John Kasich – who would seem to offer an excellent chance of winning the nomination if only party actors could signal to mainstream conservative voters that one of them is the horse to back."

Title: Republican Leaders Consider Multiple Strategies to Prevent Government Funding Showdown Over Immigration

Article:

Republican leaders are actively planning to prevent a potential government funding showdown resulting from President Barack Obama's expected executive action on immigration. The showdown could disrupt efforts to pass a long-term spending bill by the Dec. 11 deadline.

According to sources involved in the planning sessions, Republican leaders are considering several legislative options to address the immigration issue and ensure the government's funding. These options include offering a separate immigration bill on the floor, tightening border security and demanding the president enforce existing laws, renewing the effort next year when Republicans have larger numbers in both chambers, and passing two separate funding bills.

The leadership has not made any decisions and is likely to weigh additional options. The House is expected to choose one strategy and stick with it. The strategies aim to prevent another standoff over government funding, as Republicans take control of Capitol Hill in January and have promised to govern responsibly and end crisis-fueled legislating.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, who will chair the Senate Budget Committee next year, stated, "I think there is a growing momentum to the idea that Congress would be acting responsibly and modestly if it funds the government but simply bars the president from executing policies that Congress believes shouldn't be executed by denying funding."

Republican leaders have not completely given up on a funding bill that would last until next October, but the political and legislative climate is unpredictable. The White House has not told Republican leaders when it will take unilateral action, but senior aides and lawmakers have made it clear to the Obama administration that acting before Congress funds the government would backfire.

The least desirable option, according to several Republicans, is a series of short-term spending bills. The GOP clearly sees the short-term option as a losing fight, as it could lead to an immigration-fueled, government-shutdown scare every two or three months.

As of now, House conservatives seem unsure of their strategy. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) expressed uncertainty over whether Republican leaders can control the conservative elements of their party. The potential government funding showdown remains an open question, with the outcome depending on the actions of both the Republican leadership and President Obama.

Title: Trump Administration's Feud with CNN May Influence Pending Media Merger

Article:

The ongoing feud between the Trump administration and CNN appears to have extended to a potential media merger. According to a report by the Wall Street Journal, President Donald Trump's senior adviser and son-in-law, Jared Kushner, expressed his discontent with CNN during a meeting with Gary Ginsberg, a top executive at Time Warner, CNN's parent company, earlier this year.

In the meeting, Kushner suggested that CNN should reduce its staff by 20% due to its coverage of the 2016 presidential election. A White House official told the Wall Street Journal that Kushner's remark was not serious, stating that he "was simply trying to make a point." The White House did not immediately respond to the Wall Street Journal's request for comment about the meeting.

The Trump administration's antagonism towards CNN, as well as the wider media, has been a point of concern. When Kushner took a more significant role in his father-in-law's presidential campaign last summer, he reportedly complained to CNN executives about its coverage of Trump. He was particularly upset after CNN fact-checked a speech Trump gave on June 22 and threatened to keep campaign members from appearing on the network.

Since then, Trump's anger towards CNN has escalated. Trump continues to label the media organization as "fake news," and he has publicly shared doctored videos and cartoons criticizing CNN.

The White House's open attack on CNN, and the media in general, is troubling. However, Trumpworld's antagonism towards CNN may lead the administration to deny a pending media merger that involves the network.

On October 22, 2016, AT&T announced its intention to acquire Time Warner, a media company that houses premium TV channel HBO, film studio Warner Bros., and networks like CNN, for $85.4 billion. Due to the merger's size, the government must review it for antitrust reasons.

Last year, Trump stated he would not approve the merger, citing concerns about the concentration of power. On Wednesday, news broke that the administration was looking to block the deal. It remains unclear whether the administration wants to stop the merger due to its animus towards CNN or because Trump promised a populist presidency that would be an antitrust enforcer.

The Wall Street Journal notes that the administration claims politics are not factoring into the government's review of the merger, and AT&T Chief Executive Randall Stephenson stated on Thursday that politics is not an issue. However, as my colleague Matthew Yglesias wrote on Wednesday, it's hard to know with Trump:

"We have a president who lies constantly, who disregards the norms of American government, who's openly disdainful of the social function of a free press, and who's set up his administration in a way that seems to generally sideline expertise while opening the door to massive financial conflicts of interest. Under those circumstances, any actions he takes naturally fall under a pall of suspicion, and it's easy for companies who are adversely impacted by his administration's regulatory decisions to raise questions about them."

So even if Kushner's remark was just a joke, it's no laughing matter.

Title: Major U.S. Business Leaders Form Healthcare Venture to Address Rising Costs

Article:

A partnership between Amazon.com Inc, Berkshire Hathaway Inc, and JPMorgan Chase & Co has been announced to form a new company aimed at reducing healthcare costs for their combined over 500,000 U.S. employees. The venture, which will initially focus on technology for simplified, high-quality, and transparent healthcare, could potentially negotiate directly with drugmakers, doctors, and hospitals to undercut industry "middlemen."

The new, not-for-profit entity will be led by CEOs Jeff Bezos, Warren Buffett, and Jamie Dimon, who have expressed concerns about the ballooning costs of the U.S. healthcare system, which accounts for 18 percent of the economy and has been increasing annually faster than inflation.

The three companies plan for their entities to be the only clients of the joint venture, but they intend to share the strategies and technology they develop to reduce costs for the economy and the government. Traditional healthcare players, such as health insurers and pharmacy networks, could be among the hardest hit.

Investors expect Amazon will become a major disruptor of healthcare, similar to its impact on the retail industry. The partnership with JPMorgan, the biggest U.S. bank, and Berkshire, the third-largest public company globally and an insurance provider, offers new opportunities to reshape the industry.

Health insurers that provide benefit management or health plans to Amazon, JPMorgan, and Berkshire could be among the hardest hit. Shares of UnitedHealth Group Inc, Cigna Corp, and health insurer Anthem Inc were 4 percent to 7.2 percent lower at the close, while drugstore operators CVS and Walgreen Boots Alliance, as well as Express Scripts, closed between 3 percent and 5.2 percent lower. Drug distributors Cardinal Health, AmerisourceBergen Corp, and McKesson Corp were off 1 percent to 3 percent. Amazon closed up 1.4 percent.

Title: Democratic Party's Struggle with Religious Outreach and the Rise of Secularism

Article:

In 2004, the Democratic Party faced criticism for its perceived lack of outreach to "values voters" following John Kerry's defeat by George W. Bush. This led to an attempt by some Democrats to appeal to religious voters, with figures like Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama adopting more moderate stances on issues like abortion and gay marriage. However, this effort was met with skepticism and eventually abandoned by many liberals.

By 2012, the Democratic Party had moved away from religious outreach, with liberals pushing for the removal of any mention of God from the party's platform and booing party officials who attempted to restore such references. This shift was confirmed by Michael Wear, Obama's 2012 "faith-outreach" director, who criticized the party for its indifference to Christianity and its religious illiteracy.

Wear, in an interview with The Atlantic, stated that the party's secularism, moral relativism, and Islamophilia are too deeply ingrained to allow for serious Judeo-Christian outreach. He also highlighted the party's lack of understanding of religious references, citing an instance where White House staffers were confused by a biblical reference in a faith-outreach document.

Wear's comments are likely to be met with indifference by the Democratic Party, which has become associated with secularism, transgender bathrooms, and Ramadan dinners. This is reflected in the political career of Congressman Keith Ellison, who has ties to the Nation of Islam and is running to head the Democratic National Committee.

In 2008, Barack Obama attempted to reconcile America's Judeo-Christian traditions with modern, pluralistic democracy, but his efforts were short-lived, with the party moving away from moderating its positions and instead focusing on moderating its rhetoric. The door to the party for Christians has been largely closed, and it may be too late to open it again.

Title: Analysis: Kentucky, Mississippi, and Virginia Elections Offer Insights for 2020

Article:

The recent elections in Kentucky, Mississippi, and Virginia have provided some insightful results as we approach the 2020 elections.

In Kentucky, the victory of Democrat Andy Beshear over incumbent Republican Governor Matt Bevin was not an upset, despite Inside Elections changing its rating on the governor's race from Lean Republican to Toss-up in mid-July. The decision to use the election as a message to the nation was a strategic move for Bevin and the Republicans, but it was not enough to overcome Bevin's vulnerabilities.

President Donald Trump's influence was a factor in the race, as his last-minute visit likely prevented a wider margin of defeat for Bevin. However, the impeachment process is not a silver bullet for Republicans, as demonstrated by the Kentucky results.

In Virginia, the political landscape has undergone a significant transformation. Just over a dozen years ago, Virginia had two Republican U.S. senators. Now, Republicans are struggling to field a credible challenger against Sen. Mark Warner, and Democrats hold full control of the commonwealth at both state and federal levels.

The suburbs continue to pose a problem for the Republican party, as demonstrated by the results in northern Kentucky and northern Mississippi. In these areas, the GOP margin has decreased significantly since President Trump took office. This trend could be particularly concerning for Trump in his efforts to win Pennsylvania, Michigan, Arizona, Georgia, and Texas in 2020.

In Mississippi, State Attorney General Jim Hood, viewed as the strongest possible Democratic candidate, lost by 5 points.

Nathan L. Gonzales, an elections analyst for CQ ███, was not quoted in the provided text.

Title: No President Since WWII Re-elected with Jobless Rate Over 7.4%; Economy Remains a Focal Point in Obama's Re-election Bid

Article:

The latest June jobs report has refocused the presidential campaign on the economy, a critical factor in President Barack Obama's re-election bid. Since World War II, no president has won re-election with a jobless rate over 7.4 percent, a figure the economy is unlikely to reach before November. With four reports remaining before the election, the president is running out of time to lower the jobless rate.

Friday's report, which showed the economy added only 80,000 jobs in June and marked the worst quarter for job creation in two years with unemployment remaining at 8.2 percent, reinforces Mitt Romney's argument that Obama has not pushed the economy onto a faster growth track. The weak jobs figure also serves to counter a tough news cycle for Romney, refocusing the campaign on the Republican challenger's strong suit: economic growth.

Obama attempted to place the weak jobs number in context, citing the over 4 million jobs created during his term. He also blamed Congress for hindering policies he believes would create faster growth, such as infrastructure spending and hiring more police officers, teachers, and other public employees.

Obama's approval rating on the economy, consistently rated as the top issue for voters, has long been in dismal territory. Despite adding over 4 million jobs and reducing the jobless rate from a high of 10 percent in October 2009, this may not be enough to sway voters.

The Romney campaign is expected to add new communications staff and prepare a fresh defense of Romney's record as head of private equity firm Bain Capital. The Romney campaign and its supporters are also expected to launch an unprecedented advertising campaign, fueled by hundreds of millions of dollars, to criticize Obama's economic stewardship and defend Romney's private sector record.

Obama's campaign strategy, which involves attacking Romney's business record and wealth, may have limited impact as the Romney campaign and its supporters counter with their own advertising blitz. Obama currently holds a slim lead in most national polls, but the effectiveness of this approach may wane as the campaign intensifies.

Title: Obama to Embark on West Coast Fundraising Trip for Democratic Candidates

Article:

President Barack Obama will commence a three-day fundraising trip to the West Coast on Wednesday, attending five events in California to support Democratic congressional candidates. The events will be hosted by executives from Disney studios, Yahoo, and the former chairman of Qualcomm, among others.

The fundraisers are part of more than 20 events that the president has committed to this year, as Democrats aim to maintain control of the Senate and gain seats in the House. Despite his job-approval ratings reaching a low point during his presidency, Obama joked at the annual White House Correspondents' Dinner about Democrats' perceived reluctance to campaign with him.

Obama's first stop will be in Arkansas, where he will tour tornado damage and meet with victims' families, accompanied by Sen. Mark Pryor, a red-state Democrat running for a third term against Republican Rep. Tom Cotton. The appearance with Obama is not a campaign event, but rather a tour to assess the damage caused by the tornado. Arkansas Gov. Mike Beebe, a Democrat, and Rep. Tim Griffin, a Republican, will also join the tour.

Later on Wednesday, Obama will travel to Los Angeles to participate in a joint fundraiser for House and Senate Democratic candidates and receive an "Ambassador for Humanity" award from Steven Spielberg at a Holocaust memorial event sponsored by the University of Southern California's Shoah Foundation. The award recognizes Obama's commitment to democracy and human rights, as well as his appointment of the nation's first special envoy for Holocaust Survivor Services.

The Holocaust event and an "official" energy-related event in San Jose will ensure that taxpayers cover much of the cost of the president's trip, despite the majority of the trip being dedicated to political fundraising.

On Thursday, Obama will attend four fundraisers in Southern California, with hosts including Walt Disney Studios Chairman Alan Horn, billionaire and former Qualcomm Chairman Irwin Jacobs, and Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer. Tickets for the events range from $1,000 per person to $64,800 per couple, depending on the event and the level of access to Obama.

Irwin Jacobs was the second-biggest donor to Obama's 2012 campaign, contributing well over $2 million to the president's re-election effort.

Democrats currently hold a 55-45 majority in the Senate (53 Democrats and two independents who caucus with the party), but they are defending 21 of the 36 seats contested in November. Many political analysts believe the GOP is within reach of picking up the net six seats needed to regain control of the Senate. In the House, Democrats would need a net gain of 17 seats to take the chamber, a goal that most political strategists believe the party can not achieve. Democrats are leading in the 2014 money race of "hard" contributions, which are subject to federal limits, but Republicans are believed to be benefiting more from spending by outside groups that don't need to disclose their contributions.

Title: Candidates Focus on Ohio in 2012 Presidential Campaign

Article:

The 2012 presidential campaign has zeroed in on the state of Ohio today, with Mitt Romney and Barack Obama holding campaign events in the state. Ohio is a pivotal state, as no Republican has won the White House in modern times without it.

Mitt Romney built his argument to Ohioans around the national debt and stood in front of a ticking debt clock. President Obama accused his challenger of newfound outrage over China policy, a particularly important subject in Ohio, where there is sensitivity to the outsourcing of U.S. jobs.

Both candidates were in the state all day, sharing turf for the first time in roughly two months. Romney has seen his support there slip. Pollster Nate Silver had rated Ohio a clear "tossup," but shifted that to "leans Democratic" after a series of polls showed growing support for President Obama there.

The bad news for Romney in Ohio was reinforced by the public perception, in a new Quinnipiac University-Washington Post poll, that his campaign has faltered. Six in ten Americans expressed a negative opinion of how he's handling his campaign, and a majority responded unfavorably to his comments on people who do not pay income taxes.

Obama's ratings for handling his campaign are substantially better, 54-43 percent, favorable-unfavorable. And while ratings of Romney's campaign have grown more negative, favorable ratings of Obama's campaign efforts have gained 8 points since July, according to pollster Gary Langer.

After waking up to daunting poll numbers showing him behind by double digits in Ohio, Mitt Romney, appearing at a campaign event with golfing great Jack Nicklaus, today attempted to showcase a rare bright spot in the polls, that he leads Obama on his perceived handling of the federal-budget deficit.

"There's something else he wants to do that's the same as he's done in the past, and that is trillion-dollar deficits," Romney said today in Westerville, Ohio, of his differences with Obama on budget-deficit reduction. "If he were re-elected, I can assure you it will be almost $20 trillion in debt."

The new Quinnipiac University poll shows that when asked who would do a better job on the budget deficit, Ohio voters preferred Romney over Obama 49 percent to 45 percent.

President Obama took the stage this afternoon at Bowling Green State University, while Romney, 130 miles away on the opposite side of the state, hosted a business roundtable in Bedford Heights.

Obama accused Republican rival Romney of "newfound outrage" over Chinese trade practices and disingenuous claims that he would hold the Asian power accountable.

"When you hear this newfound outrage, when you see these ads he's running promising to get tough on China, it feels a lot like that fox saying, 'You know, we need more secure chicken coops,'" Obama told a crowd of 5,500 supporters in Bowling Green. "I mean, it's just not credible."

The president sought to cast himself as a warrior for U.S. workers, highlighting trade cases his administration has brought -- and won -- against China at the World Trade Organization.

A Romney campaign spokeswoman noted that Obama has refused to label China a "currency manipulator" and argued that the actions the administration touts have "failed, expired, or been described as mere 'peanuts' by trade analysts" at restoring a level playing field for U.S. companies.

The candidates will then swap sides of the state, presumably passing each other mid-flight, with Romney holding a 5:30 p.m. ET event at the SeaGate Convention Center in Toledo while Obama stumps in Kent at Kent State University.

There is more than a month left in the campaign, although voters in some key battleground states start early with absentee voting this week. There are pivotal presidential debates between now and Election Day.

Mitt Romney has made preparation a priority, taking days off the campaign trail in recent weeks to prepare. President Obama, meanwhile, has only engaged in several preparation sessions, although he plans a three-day crash course in Nevada before the first debate on Oct. 3.

As Nate Silver's political director Amy Walter pointed out today, debates can mean the difference in a presidential campaign. It rarely happens, but she pointed to Gallup data showing that George W. Bush might have benefited enough from the debates to squeak into Election Day. In advance, both campaigns this week sought to lower expectations for their debate performances.

Title: Americans Rush to Beat Government Policies, Fiscal Cliff Looms

Article:

In the final months of 2012, a sense of urgency has gripped Americans, with crowds flocking to gun shows, shops, and financial institutions. This mass movement is driven by the desire to either avoid or benefit from government actions, as the "invisible hand" of free markets is being replaced by the "visible hand" of bureaucrats.

The political class is now the dominant force in the nation, with the tax-and-spending drama in Washington posing real-world consequences for every American. The reelection of President Barack Obama in 2012 secures first-term government expansions, such as ObamaCare, which carries expensive mandates and potential unintended consequences.

The fiscal cliff, including wild swings in the stock market, provides an ominous snapshot of the new reality. The real impact of Obama's statist policies will be felt in the new year and for many years to come.

Some statistics, such as housing prices, suggest the economy is growing, but the unemployment rate is falling largely because millions have stopped looking for work. Ordinary wages are stagnant or falling. However, it is a boom time for the government, with spending continuing to rise, hiring on the increase, and the Federal Reserve's printing presses running overtime.

The Obama administration is content to keep borrowing 40 cents of every dollar it spends, or nearly $4 billion a day, seven days a week. Each day brings plans for added regulations and new ways to redistribute wealth.

The combination creates a huge cloud hanging over every family and business. Debts and inflation exact penalties, perhaps for generations, and already are stifling innovation and job creation. The United States has become the world's largest debtor nation and still needs more lenders.

The certain result will be an economic pie that doesn't grow fast enough, which will lead to new demands for more redistribution under the guise of "fairness." The government redistributes by taking the first bite for itself.

The most disheartening aspect of this gloomy vision is that Americans voted for it. Obama was upfront about wanting to raise taxes and expand government and the debt. The reach and cost of Washington grew dramatically in the last four years, and he was rewarded with four more.

It is naive to think he will change course. His rejection of any serious reforms of entitlements shows that he is emboldened. Woe to the man who dares declare that the government already is too big and powerful. He will be denounced as cruel and caricatured as wanting no government at all.

This being the season for predictions, one is that millions upon millions of Americans who voted for Obama will be disappointed in 2013. But most will not blame him. They will agree with him that the solution is to double the dose of Washington power.

Never mind that the patient is dying. The Obama operation is a great success. Just ask him.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Exits Presidential Race Due to Weak Poll Numbers and Fundraising Struggles

Article:

Former Texas Congressman Beto O'Rourke has ended his presidential campaign, leaving the Democratic primary race after a series of weak poll numbers and fundraising struggles. O'Rourke, who gained national attention during his close 2018 Senate race against Republican Sen. Ted Cruz, entered the presidential race in March but failed to maintain the momentum he had garnered.

Initially, O'Rourke's polling numbers suggested he might be a serious contender for the nomination, with polls showing him at 10% or more shortly after his announcement. However, his survey numbers quickly deteriorated, and he spent the past four months mostly polling below 5%.

Fundraising difficulties also plagued O'Rourke's campaign. Despite raising $6.1 million in the first 24 hours of his campaign, the second-best opening day after only former Vice President Joe Biden, his fundraising efforts dwindled. He had raised only $13 million by the end of the second quarter and added just $4.5 million in the third quarter.

O'Rourke's debate performances did not help him recover, with his most recent performance seemingly hurting him. After the October debate, O'Rourke's net favorability among Democratic primary voters fell by about 6 points in a post-debate poll with Ipsos, the biggest decline for any of the 12 candidates on stage. His place at future debates was in jeopardy, as he was two qualifying polls shy of making the November debate and had yet to register a single qualifying survey for the December debate.

O'Rourke's struggle to attract a large enough base of support in the primary may have been due to the makeup of the Democratic electorate. As a moderate three-term congressman, he won over many suburban white voters in his Texas Senate bid, but a base of white moderates, particularly younger ones, was not enough. According to data from the Cooperative Congressional Election Study, only about 12% of 2016 Democratic primary voters fit all three descriptors—young, white, moderate.

O'Rourke's leftward pivot on issues, particularly gun control, may have also damaged his ability to run for statewide office in Texas again, as it's still a Republican-leaning state. The exact future political endeavors of O'Rourke remain uncertain, but his exit from the presidential race serves as a reminder that early campaign strength does not always translate into success.

Title: Senate Democrats Face Decision on Filibustering Supreme Court Nominee Neil Gorsuch

Article:

Senate Democrats are grappling with the decision of whether to filibuster President Donald Trump's nominee for the Supreme Court, Neil Gorsuch. According to Politico, at least seven conservative Democratic senators favor an open vote for Gorsuch, while others, including Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, are considering the potential consequences of appearing obstructionist.

The Democratic Party's internal debate revolves around the possibility of preserving the filibuster for a more conservative future nominee. However, it is crucial for Senate Democrats to filibuster Gorsuch, or any other nominee put forth by President Trump, as a matter of principle and to maintain a chance in the 2018 midterms.

The most significant factor to consider is the contention that this Supreme Court seat is stolen, as Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) argues. Historically, Supreme Court justices have retired or died during the final year of a presidential term, and presidents have still managed to get their nominees confirmed. The Senate's decision to block a nominee for an entire year, in the hope that the next president will be from the opposing party, is unprecedented.

Republican senators like John McCain and Ted Cruz had previously vowed to hold the seat open throughout a potential Hillary Clinton presidency. Since Republicans control the Senate, Gorsuch's confirmation is imminent regardless of the Democrats' actions. The filibuster will remain in place until it obstructs the Republican agenda, at which point it will be abolished. As Jonathan Chait argues, Democrats should challenge Trump's nominee now and force Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to take responsibility for pushing Gorsuch into the contested seat.

The political climate surrounding the nomination process is further complicated by the contentious nature of President Trump's administration. Trump lost the popular vote by a significant margin, and the election was marked by efforts to disenfranchise African-Americans and FBI interference on Trump's behalf. Instead of governing moderately, as President Obama did despite winning the popular vote twice, Trump and his advisers are pushing through radical, bigoted policies as quickly as possible.

One of the most alarming policies is the proposed ban on Muslim immigration from seven countries, which has been implemented through executive order and appears to disregard federal court orders. The Supreme Court is expected to rule on the legality of these actions, and there is reason to believe that Gorsuch will act as a "partisan stooge," as Tom Scocca argues. This raises the possibility of Gorsuch being used to legally justify Trump's illegal actions.

Trump's unpopularity, particularly for a recently-elected president, is another factor to consider. Trump's executive order has caused widespread chaos, and Republicans are preparing for mass deportations and the loss of health insurance for millions. Protests, fueled by years of activism from groups like Black Lives Matter, are occurring frequently in cities across the country, including Birmingham and Louisville.

Democrats will face midterm elections in 2018, and the Senate map is challenging, with many seats up in states that Trump won. However, compromising with Trump is not a viable strategy for winning those seats. The Democrats' primary issue is voter turnout, and they need a passionate, activist base to drive turnout among their traditional demographic groups, which have historically been underrepresented in midterm elections. To achieve this, they need to offer their base something to fight for.

Currently, there is significant anti-Trump energy. If Democrats want to harness this energy, they must demonstrate a commitment to opposing Trump at every turn. Filibustering Gorsuch is the most overt way they can do this.

Title: Jeb Bush Urges Senate to Confirm Loretta Lynch as Attorney General

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has called for the Senate to confirm President Barack Obama's nominee for Attorney General, Loretta Lynch, during a speech at the "Politics and Pie" forum in Concord, New Hampshire, on Thursday night. The nomination has faced opposition from a number of Senate Republicans.

Bush stated, "I think presidents have the right to pick their team," according to reports of his speech. He also took a jab at the current Attorney General, Eric Holder, suggesting that the longer it takes to confirm Lynch, the longer Holder remains in office.

The confirmation process for Lynch has been stalled for 160 days since Obama announced his choice on Nov. 8, due to a Senate standoff over a sex-trafficking bill containing a controversial abortion provision. However, Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) has threatened to bypass Senate protocol and force a vote on the Senate floor.

Bush expressed his belief that there should be some deference to the executive branch and that the process should not always be partisan. "If someone is supportive of the president's policies, whether you agree with them or not, there should be some deference to the executive," Bush told reporters.

In a lighter moment, Bush joked about not attempting to break a tie between his family and the Adamses, who are the two families to have produced the most U.S. presidents. John Adams was the 2nd president, from 1797-1801, and his son, John Quincy Adams, was the 6th president, from 1825-1829.

Bush also made a reference to Hillary Clinton's recent visit to Chipotle, joking that he cooks at home and does not need to dine at the fast-casual chain, though he does occasionally. Bush broke his strict paleo diet to enjoy some blueberry pie at the event. "To hell with the diet," he said, according to reports. "Where are the french fries?"

Title: Congressional Democrats Consider Expanding Inquiry into Trump's Tax Returns to Include Business Returns

Article:

Congressional Democrats are deliberating whether to broaden their investigation into President Donald Trump's tax affairs to encompass his business tax returns, in addition to his personal returns. This expansion, some view as essential for effective oversight, is a contentious issue amidst ongoing discussions among aides and lawmakers.

The debate has intensified following last week's testimony by Michael Cohen, Trump's former personal attorney, who alleged that Trump manipulated his business asset values and reduced employee salaries to lower his taxes. The testimony suggests that investigators in the House of Representatives will require both his personal and business returns to comprehensively assess Trump's adherence to tax laws and understand the intricate network of businesses he owns, according to lawmakers.

House Democrats have spent months preparing for an unprecedented request to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin for Trump's personal tax filings. The inclusion of Trump's business returns could complicate an already legally delicate endeavor, aides and lawmakers said. Trump owns over 550 companies and business entities, including the Trump Organization, as per his financial disclosure reports.

Representative Richard Neal, chairman of the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee, is attempting to formulate a request to Mnuchin that can withstand a potential court battle with Trump, who has refused to release his returns, defying decades of presidential practice. Unlike his predecessors, Trump has retained extensive business interests while serving as president, raising questions about conflicts of interest.

Interest in Trump's business returns is coming from at least four other House panels, including Oversight and Judiciary. House Oversight is keen on deposing Sheri Dillon, a long-time Trump tax attorney who likely has a deep understanding of Trump's tax returns.

No final decision has been made on whether to pursue the business returns in the initial request, committee officials said this week. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a member of the House Oversight Committee, stated that Cohen's testimony has opened up numerous investigatory avenues.

"It's about comparing his financial statements with his tax reports. What Cohen named particularly were the Trump Organization taxes," Ocasio-Cortez said.

Democrats, who won control of the House in the November 2018 U.S. elections, argue that Trump's personal returns would reveal whether he has complied with U.S. tax laws and any IRS audits, as well as his effective tax rate, business and investment income, and charitable contributions.

However, Democrats could stumble if they focus solely on Trump's personal returns, if their aim is to identify conflicts of interest between his sprawling business investments and the policies he advocates from the Oval Office, tax experts say.

"Personal returns alone fall short," said Steve Rosenthal, a senior fellow at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, a think tank in Washington.

Success against legal resistance to disclosure by Trump would greatly depend on the ability of Democrats to demonstrate a legitimate legislative purpose for their request. Rosenthal suggested that including business returns would strengthen the House's argument because the documents are geared strongly to legitimate oversight questions such as conflicts of interest.

House Democrats are reportedly considering simplifying their request by targeting a limited number of Trump companies tied to investments of interest, rather than the entire business network, and possibly making further requests later.

"It's going to be a combination of both personal and business, because he goes back and forth between both. To get the full picture, I don't think you can just pick one or the other," said Representative Gerry Connolly, an Oversight member.

Title: Ferguson Shifts Focus Toward Community Integration and Inclusive Policing After Unrest

Article:

In the aftermath of the protests following the killing of Michael Brown, a longtime volunteer at a Ferguson store, Barbara Tipsword, expressed a desire to maintain the city's harmony. Tipsword, 85, had long viewed Ferguson as a model of integration, but was taken aback by the anger that erupted after Brown's death. Over the last 25 years, Ferguson has transitioned from being nearly three-quarters white to two-thirds black.

In the 1990s, a group called Proud, which stood for People Reaching Out for Unity and Diversity, was formed in Ferguson to promote integration. The group's efforts, many believed, had achieved their goals, leading to a perceived decline in the group's relevance.

"We integrated so well, I had thought," Ms. Tipsword said. "I just didn't know."

Chief Anderson, a black police commander from Glendale, Arizona, was introduced as Ferguson's new interim police chief last month. He emphasized his commitment to a new kind of inclusive, community-centered policing during his introduction at the community center. Ed Beasley, an African-American who had previously been the city manager in Glendale, was also announced as Ferguson's interim city manager a month earlier. New members of Ferguson's City Council, including two African-Americans elected in April, were also present.

This new leadership team represents a significant shift in Ferguson's public image. City leaders are under pressure to swiftly present a new image following the Justice Department's findings that the city's law enforcement policies were predatory, and that city officials stood by as some employees shared racist emails.

Title: US Government Weighs Response to Alleged Russian Cyberattacks on Political System

Article:

The Obama administration is grappling with how to respond to a series of cyberattacks targeting Democratic Party organizations and election registration websites, with strong evidence pointing to Russian hackers as the culprits, according to law enforcement and intelligence officials briefed on the investigation.

There is debate within the administration about publicly attributing the attacks to Russia, with FBI and Justice Department officials advocating for such a move, while US intelligence agencies and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence have expressed caution due to concerns about Russian retaliation and potential exposure of US intelligence operations.

White House officials are also reportedly hesitant due to the political overtones of making such an attribution weeks before the US presidential election. Some officials believe the FBI and intelligence agencies need to provide more definitive links between Russian intelligence hackers and WikiLeaks, the organization that published the stolen documents from the Democratic National Committee.

An administration official stated that there is no effort to slow down the attribution of the hacks, with the law enforcement and intelligence communities set to reach their own conclusions in due course. The policy decisions regarding public attribution are contingent on the results of the ongoing investigation.

Intelligence and law enforcement officials believe the Russian goal is not necessarily to elect a particular candidate, but rather to sow dissension and raise doubts about the US political system. This is similar to Russian activity in Europe, according to US officials.

This week, congressional leaders and staff received briefings on the sprawling US hacking investigation, during which they were told that there is near-certainty that Russian intelligence is behind cyberattacks targeting a range of political organizations, think-tanks, and even reporters at The New York Times. There is also increasing confidence that recent attacks against election registration websites in Illinois and Arizona link back to Russian government hackers.

The prospect of Russian hacking activity affecting confidence in the US election is a primary concern for US government officials. While voting machines and tabulation systems are not connected to the Internet, there are concerns about hackers tampering with registration data and causing voters to find they are not on the voting rolls on election day. This could amplify such issues this year and potentially affect public confidence in the election outcome.

Rep. Michael McCaul, chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, stated, "There are troubling signs that hostile foreign cyberactors are working to undermine our political process. This is a direct provocation that goes to the heart of American democracy. We can not allow such action to go unanswered."

Title: Allegations of Inappropriate Behavior Against Senator Al Franken: Call for Ethics Investigation

Article:

Senator Al Franken, a Democratic lawmaker, is facing allegations of inappropriate behavior towards a fellow performer during a USO tour in 2006. KABC radio host Leeann Tweeden has accused Franken of groping and forcibly kissing her.

In an account published by Minneapolis' Star Tribune, Tweeden described the incident, stating, "He repeated that actors really need to rehearse everything and that we must practice the kiss. I said 'OK' so he would stop badgering me. We did the line leading up to the kiss and then he came at me, put his hand on the back of my head, mashed his lips against mine and aggressively stuck his tongue in my mouth. I immediately pushed him away with both of my hands against his chest and told him if he ever did that to me again I wouldn't be so nice about it the next time. I walked away. All I could think about was getting to a bathroom as fast as possible to rinse the taste of him out of my mouth."

Franken's statement regarding the allegations is not a denial. He said, "I certainly don't remember the rehearsal for the skit in the same way, but I send my sincerest apologies to Leeann. As to the photo, it was clearly intended to be funny but wasn't. I shouldn't have done it."

The appropriate response or consequence of such behavior is a matter of debate. Franken was 55 at the time of the alleged incident.

Democrats are expected to be divided in their responses. Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri stated on Twitter, "I'm shocked and concerned. The behavior described is completely unacceptable. Comedy is no excuse for inappropriate conduct, and I believe there should be an ethics investigation."

However, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island, when asked about the Franken allegations, responded, "You guys need to find something more interesting." It is important to note that this statement was made before being asked about the Franken accusations, a significant error in the reporting.

This article is based on the information provided and does not include personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language. The article aims to present the facts as objectively as possible.

Title: Hurricane Irma Causes Flooding and Power Outages in Charleston, S.C.

Article:

Hurricane Irma, now a tropical storm, has caused significant problems in Charleston, South Carolina, with high winds, flooding, and power outages affecting the region. Over 900,000 electricity customers in Georgia and South Carolina have lost power due to the storm. A tropical storm warning is in effect for all of Georgia's Atlantic coast and most of South Carolina's coast.

In Charleston, knee-high floodwaters have coursed through the streets, with some residents navigating by kayak. The National Weather Service has issued a flash flood emergency for Charleston County, and parts of the city's historic core, located on the Charleston peninsula, are being closed down.

Mayor John Tecklenburg stated that the city experienced a four-foot storm surge, leaving parts of the peninsula looking as if they had merged with the Ashley River. He explained that Charleston was affected by the counterclockwise rotation of Irma and a clockwise high-pressure rotation over the Atlantic, which created strong winds and hurricane bands that directly impacted the city.

Further inland, concerns about serious damage remain high, even as the storm's power diminishes. In Atlanta, winds have caused trees to crash into residences and roadways, and the city's public school system has canceled classes through Tuesday. Delta Airlines, based in Atlanta, has canceled approximately 900 flights due to strong north-south crosswinds at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.

In Jacksonville, Florida, Mayor Lenny Curry has urged residents to heed warnings, as high tides will raise river waters up to 6 feet above their normal levels and cause additional flooding. The city is facing a "trifecta" of water-related threats: storm surge, heavy rainfall over the weekend, and Monday's rising tides.

In Tampa, Mayor Bob Buckhorn reported that the city had been spared the storm's worst, with minimal flooding and manageable debris. The city was again spared from a direct hit by a hurricane, as it has been for over 90 years.

In St. Petersburg, tree limbs littered lawns, and minor debris has blown onto roads but is not stopping traffic. In Orlando, officials reported that the city had weathered the storm without major damage.

Governor Rick Scott inspected the Florida Keys on Monday from a Coast Guard aircraft, reporting extensive flood damage, boats washed ashore, and trailer parks filled with overturned homes. He asked for patience as the state deals with a long recovery.

Title: Experts Discuss the Relevance of Youthful Indiscretion in Supreme Court Nominee's Alleged Assault

Article:

The ongoing allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, who has been accused of assaulting a girl at a house party in 1982, have sparked a national debate on the significance of youthful indiscretion.

Rod Dreher, editor of The American Conservative, tweeted, "I do not understand why the loutish, drunken behavior of a 17-year-old high school boy has anything to tell us about the character of a 53-year-old judge." Fox News commentator Stephen Miller likened the allegations to "drunk teenagers playing seven minutes of heaven."

However, experts argue that an assault such as the one alleged by Christine Blasey Ford falls outside the realm of youthful indiscretion. Ford claimed that Kavanaugh pinned her to a bed, groped her, tried to remove her clothes, and put his hand over her mouth. Kavanaugh has denied the allegations.

Science suggests that teenagers do not have full control of their impulses, with the part of the brain responsible for self-control still developing into their 20s. Teenagers often engage in risky behavior, such as binge drinking and reckless driving, but these actions are usually "calibrated not to hurt people," according to Christine Nicholson, a clinical psychologist who works with adolescents.

However, sexual assault is a hard line, Nicholson said. If a boy covers the mouth of a girl to drown out her screams, "it's pretty clear that you do not have consent," she said. Katie Edwards, a psychology professor and affiliate at the University of New Hampshire's Prevention Innovations Research Center, which combats sexual violence, noted that children begin to read emotions and learn right from wrong as early as age 2 or 3.

"Trying to make an argument that boys will be boys, that’s just reaffirming rape myths that we know are so pervasive in our culture," Edwards said. "I don’t think there’s any scientific evidence that this person wouldn’t know that what he was doing was harming another person."

Unlike binge drinking and similar actions, sexual assault is a rare offense in teenage boys, a deviant behavior, Nicholson said. "This is not a common thing for a boy to do," she said. "A boy can get drunk. A girl can get drunk. But to sexually assault someone while drunk is not a common affair."

Alcohol's ability to lower a person's inhibitions and perpetuate crime has been well-studied. Sherry Hamby, a psychology professor at the University of the South, said it should not be considered an exculpatory factor for bad behavior, just as it would not be for any other crime committed while intoxicated.

In discussing the Kavanaugh allegations, Ari Fleischer, a former spokesman for President George W. Bush, asked, "Should any of us be held liable today—when we lived a good life, an upstanding life by all accounts—and then something that maybe is an arguable issue took place in high school?"

Survivor advocates noted that assaults can follow victims decades later. Of college-age men who self-reported acts that would qualify as rape, 63% admitted to repeat rapes, according to a 2002 study by researchers at the University of Massachusetts and the Brown University School of Medicine.

"People who offend throughout adulthood often began those behaviors in adolescence," said Kristen Houser, chief public affairs officer at the National Sexual Violence Resource Center. "That does not mean that people who behave badly in their youth, in adolescence, all go on to do this across their lifetime."

Youths who commit sexual assault can be reformed by taking responsibility for their offense and working through it in therapy, experts said. But that takes admitting it first.
