"There would be a big difference if this guy said, 'Look, I did this. It was so godawful, and I'm embarrassed and ashamed, and I have never done it again' and apologized profusely," said Yale psychiatry professor Joan Cook.

Nicholson said that sexual assault, even if perpetrated in elementary school, would invalidate someone from serving on the Supreme Court. "You can't attempt to rape someone and go on to become a Supreme Court justice," she said. "People don't do that."

Title: Senate Democrats Navigate Delicate Balance on Immigration Reform and Midterm Elections

Article:

Senate Democratic leaders are grappling with the extent to which they should pressure President Barack Obama to take action on immigration reform before the midterm elections, as they seek to avoid potentially complicating the reelection bids of Democrats in red states.

The dynamic leaves the Senate's most powerful Democrats in a challenging position. Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada, Majority Whip Dick Durbin of Illinois, Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York, and Sen. Patty Murray of Washington have all called for executive action to halt deportations, with Schumer even suggesting in March that the White House should move on the matter in October.

However, the leaders are now evasive about whether they want the president to act before November or wait until after the elections. Representatives for each of the senators declined to comment this week on the timing of the president's action.

"The timing of it is entirely up to him," said Ben Marter, spokesman for Sen. Durbin, regarding the president's decision.

Democrats are attempting to redirect focus towards the Republican-controlled House, where Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) has stated that he has no plans to act on immigration this year.

"If House Republicans would just do their job and pass an immigration reform bill that fixes a broken system, then we wouldn't even be having this conversation," said Adam Jentleson, spokesman for Sen. Reid, who declined to comment further.

A spokesman for Sen. Schumer echoed this sentiment, stating, "The president would not be forced to even contemplate taking independent action to cope with our broken system had House Republicans not spent more than a year blocking the Senate's already-passed bipartisan immigration reform legislation."

The debate underscores the delicate balance that Democrats are maintaining on both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue regarding immigration. Obama and Democratic congressional leaders are weighing calls for action to stem deportations, but risk going too far and potentially flipping the Senate to the GOP, giving Republicans full control of Congress and a more powerful platform to block immigration reform.

The GOP is already capitalizing on the issue, making immigration reform a topic in key Senate races.

Obama administration officials are currently reviewing immigration enforcement practices and are expected to take steps within weeks to ease deportations of certain immigrants living in the United States illegally, though the exact timing remains a subject of speculation.

Though he previously maintained that he had little legal authority to act on immigration, Obama stated in June that he would take executive action on deportations this summer after it became clear that House Republicans would not move a bill. The president is unlikely to halt deportations for all undocumented immigrants who would have become legalized under the Senate's comprehensive reform bill that passed last year, but the administration is considering relief for smaller populations based on criteria such as family ties or how long they have lived in the United States.

In a Univision interview this week, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) emphasized family ties, stating that parents of U.S. citizens or young undocumented immigrants should be granted the same protections as the so-called "Dreamers" who were shielded under a 2012 Obama administration directive. Pelosi also supports the call from Latino lawmakers to protect the estimated 8 million undocumented immigrants who would have qualified under the Senate bill, a position that Durbin and Schumer have also endorsed.

"It would be my hope that the president's lawyers would advise him on the broadest possible prosecutorial discretion," Pelosi said during the interview.

With the potential for fallout to impact their incumbents in conservative states, Democratic leaders in the Senate want little ownership of the timing of the president's decision. At the same time, they do not want to alienate pro-immigration groups by publicly siding with red-state Democrats, even though the Senate leadership has aggressively tried to protect their vulnerable members from taking tough votes and being cornered into uncomfortable positions all year. Endangered Democrats have already pushed back on the president's upcoming move. In an interview before the August recess, Sen. Mark Pryor of Arkansas insisted that Obama needs statutory authority to act on deportations, stating, "I'm not for government by executive order."

Title: Supporting Protesters: A Guide to Local Bail Funds and Other Organizations

Article:

In the wake of ongoing protests against police brutality and systemic racism, many individuals are seeking ways to support protesters and the cause. One method to consider is making a donation to a local bail fund. The importance of releasing protesters from jail quickly, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, is highlighted due to the increased risk of exposure in detention facilities.

Several local bail funds have been established to assist protesters in securing their release. Due to an outpouring of support, some of these funds, such as the Minneapolis Freedom Fund and the Brooklyn Bail Fund, have asked donors to redirect their funds to other nonprofits. A variety of funds, many within your own community, require financial support.

A starting point for deciding where to send your donations can be found in this thread compiled by filmmaker Matthew A. Cherry, which lists funds for major cities across the country. As Cherry notes, this is a starting point for deciding where to send your donations, but it is essential to conduct a background check on an organization before sending money.

Another possible first step is to check out the National Bail Fund Network, which offers a directory of community bail funds—including a listing of dedicated bail funds for protesters—organized by state. Additionally, ActBlue's donation portal provides the option of splitting your donation among 38 different community bail funds.

In the short-term, getting protesters out of jail quickly is critical. In the longer-term, police brutality is a systemic issue that requires comprehensive reform. If you have a little extra money to spare, it's also worth donating to organizations working on solutions for ending police brutality, such as Campaign Zero. In addition to accepting donations, Campaign Zero is also a good resource for understanding possible solutions and learning what actions you can take right now to address police violence.

For those looking for ways to advocate for Black lives, a list of resources is available. These resources provide information on various aspects of the Black Lives Matter movement and offer guidance on how to take action.

Title: Sarah Palin Endorses Donald Trump for President, Joins Campaign in Iowa

Article:

Former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin has endorsed Donald Trump for the presidency, marking her first foray into the 2016 presidential race. In a statement from the Trump campaign, Palin expressed her support for Trump, stating, "I am proud to endorse Donald J. Trump for President of the United States of America."

At a campaign event at Iowa State University in Ames, Iowa, Palin appeared alongside Trump, where she praised the real estate mogul and praised his commitment to making America great again. "You’re putting relationships on the line for this country because you’re willing to make America great again," she said at the rally.

Trump, in turn, expressed his gratitude for Palin's support, stating, "She’s the woman that from day one I said I needed to get her support." Palin, who became a symbol of the Tea Party movement following the 2008 presidential election, is the highest-profile backer for a Republican contender so far in the race.

In her endorsement speech, Palin praised Trump for bringing up controversial issues to create "a good, heated primary," while taking aim at what she called "establishment candidates" in the race. "They’ve been wearing political correctness kind of like a suicide vest," she said.

The endorsement comes less than two weeks ahead of the critical lead-off Iowa caucus, where Trump is locked in a dead heat with Texas Sen. Ted Cruz. In the statement announcing the endorsement, Trump's campaign described Palin as a conservative who "helped launch the careers of several key future leaders of the Republican Party and conservative movement."

Campaigning in New Hampshire, Tuesday, Cruz responded to Palin's endorsement of Trump, saying "regardless of what Sarah intends to do in 2016, I will remain a big, big fan of Sarah Palin."

Palin is expected to join Trump on Wednesday for campaign events in Norwalk, Iowa, and Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Democratic National Committee responded to the endorsement, stating, "Even with a record number of candidates and internal calls to become more inclusive as a party, Donald Trump and Sarah Palin remain two of the GOP’s most influential leaders."

The Democratic National Committee also criticized the divisive rhetoric of Trump and Palin, stating, "Their divisive rhetoric is now peddled by everyone from Ted Cruz to Marco Rubio. Americans deserve better than what Trump and Palin have to offer, but it seems like the other Republican candidates would rather follow in their footsteps."

In addition to Palin's endorsement, Trump received an endorsement from Aissa Wayne, the daughter of the western film actor John Wayne, while campaigning at Iowa's John Wayne Birthplace Museum. Wayne said the country needs a strong and courageous leader like her father, and that he would be offering his endorsement if he were still alive.

Title: Technological Unemployment: A Closer Look at the Impact of Automation on Jobs

Article:

The ongoing technological advancements have led to a shift in jobs away from cities like Youngstown, Ohio, with most of the jobs moving to other American cities such as Houston or Chattanooga. The decline in jobs in coal mining industries is not due to foreign competition but rather new techniques that have made natural gas production cheaper.

The fear of technological unemployment, where automation replaces human jobs, is a concern for some, including economists like Robert Gordon and Tyler Cowen. They argue that we may face challenges when jobs are lost, such as the potential replacement of America's 3.5 million truck drivers by autonomous vehicles.

However, the overall results of automation are positive. Workers move from assembly-line jobs to better ones monitoring robots, earning higher wages due to the higher technology. Alternatively, they may move to jobs outside the auto industry, earning pay that goes further due to the cheaper goods produced by robots.

Critics, such as Robert Reich, attribute the decline in American wages to automation, computers, software, robotics, computer-controlled machine tools, and widespread digitization. However, these innovations have actually raised real wages, as a human with a better tool can produce more outputs. The point of an economy is production for consumption, not the protection of existing jobs.

Historically, if the fear of technological unemployment were true, it would have already occurred on a massive scale. In 1800, four out of five Americans worked on farms, but only one in 50 do so now, despite mechanical harvesting and hybrid corn. Similarly, the decline in jobs in sectors like railways, manual telephone operators, and elevator operators has not led to high unemployment rates.

Each month in the United States, approximately 1.7 million jobs disappear, with over 1% of jobs lost per month due to creative destruction. This is a normal occurrence, as companies go out of business, get merged or downsized, or decide that an extra salesperson on the floor of a big-box store is not worth the costs of employment.

The net increase or decrease in jobs reported on the evening news is misleading, as the relevant figure for concerns about technological unemployment is the gross figure of 1% of jobs lost per month. This equates to over 10% per year at simple interest. At such rates, in just a few years, a third of the labor force would be unemployed, and the fraction would continue to rise.

To "save people's jobs" by stopping all innovation would result in perpetual employment of capital and labor in the same way, leading to stagnant income. This is not ideal for those who are poor or young. Job protections for the old have already created a dangerous class of unemployed youths in some parts of the world, such as Greece and black South Africa.

Helping the poverty-stricken is commendable, but it is not feasible to subsidize 1.7 million people a month. Nor is job retraining a good idea when directed from above, as the wise heads in Washington do not know the future and may end up teaching people skills for companies that no longer exist. Workers themselves know best how to retrain and relocate, as demonstrated by the hundreds of thousands who moved to North Dakota during the brief oil boom there.

In conclusion, the labor force should be as flexible as the capital force. This requires liberty, not government programs. When considering which society we'd rather enter at birth, without knowing where within that society we'd end up, one with all jobs protected and a stagnant economy, or one with flexible labor laws and an economy that lifts up the poorest among us, the latter seems more desirable.

Title: Presidential Interference in Military Justice: Bergdahl Case Raises Concerns

Article:

A controversy surrounding the court-martial of Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl has sparked debate over the influence of political figures on military justice proceedings. The case, which concluded on Friday, has been criticized for its outcome, with Bergdahl receiving a minor fine and a dishonorable discharge.

During the trial, President Donald Trump, then a candidate, had publicly criticized Bergdahl, calling him a "dirty rotten traitor" and suggesting he should be executed. These comments, made before Trump's presidency, were a concern for some due to the potential for inappropriate command influence on military proceedings.

After Bergdahl pled guilty, questions were raised about the impact of Trump's pre-election tweets on the prosecution. Andrew McCarthy, a legal analyst for National Review and former federal prosecutor, noted that the seated Commander in Chief's only reasonable response would be "No comment." However, Trump responded, stating, "People heard what I said."

The presiding judge, Col. Jeffery R. Nance of the Army, stated during a hearing at Fort Bragg that he would consider the president's comments as mitigation evidence when determining an appropriate sentence. This decision has been met with criticism, as the president's comments do not provide any factual, legal, or moral justification for a lenient sentence.

The concern is that the president's comments may have unlawfully pressured the military and its court-martial system. Federal rules of evidence allow the exclusion of evidence that may be more prejudicial than relevant or probative, but the primary concern is usually about improperly influencing lay jurors. Col. Nance, as a judge, is not an impressionable member of a jury who needs to be protected from sensational headlines.

Col. Nance's statement is being criticized as an illogical disgrace, and Bergdahl's sentence is being labeled a travesty. The president's comments do not mitigate in favor of Bergdahl; they weigh against continuing the case and risk tainting the prosecution by undue influence. The case should either be deemed compromised and dismissed, or the statements excluded and ignored, and justice administered by the book.

This controversy has sparked calls for reform in the military justice system to prevent political interference in future cases. The families of the soldiers who died searching for Bergdahl and the millions of informed Americans who bear witness to this case are left to grapple with the outcome.

Title: Investigators Examine ACS64 Locomotive and Train Speed in Philadelphia Derailment

Article:

Investigators and experts are focusing on the actions of the engineer, Brandon Bostian, in the moments and days leading up to the derailment of Northeast Regional Train 188, which occurred Tuesday night north of Center City Philadelphia. The train was traveling at 106 m.p.h., more than twice the speed limit, before it derailed, resulting in eight fatalities and over 200 injuries.

Investigators reviewed a video shot from the front of the train until the moment it left the track. National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) Chairman Robert Sumwalt stated that with 65 seconds remaining on the video, the train's speed was 70 m.p.h. With 16 seconds left, the speed was 100 m.p.h., and the train reached 106 m.p.h. before the engineer applied emergency brakes, causing a slight decrease in speed.

"Mere seconds into the turn, we see the train tilting approximately 10 degrees to the right," Mr. Sumwalt told reporters at a news conference. "And then the screen went blank."

The ACS64 locomotive, which had been in use for less than a year, had no reported issues, according to Mr. Sumwalt. Similarly, there were no problems with the track, which was inspected by the railroad the day before the accident, or with the signals that have been checked since, with the exception of those in the immediate vicinity of the wreckage.

Although railroads like Amtrak continue to rely on decades-old infrastructure, the locomotive involved was a new addition—a "Cities Sprinter" electric locomotive that was introduced only last year, with design roots in Germany and Austria. The locomotive was built by Siemens and delivered to Amtrak in 2014 specifically for its Northeast Corridor service.

Title: Democrats' Opposition to Education Secretary Betsy DeVos: A Closer Look

Article:

This week, Vice President Mike Pence was compelled to cast the deciding vote for Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, marking a significant moment in American politics. The intense opposition from Democrats towards an education secretary has raised questions about the reasons behind this all-out war.

Some Democrats and mainstream media outlets have focused their opposition on Betsy DeVos' alleged "radical" views. However, as noted by New York Times columnist Ross Douthat, Secretary DeVos' views are not significantly different from the Obama administration's pro-charter schools position and are similar to the perspectives of centrist Democrats such as Senator Cory Booker.

Other Democrats and media outlets have opposed DeVos due to her lack of experience as a government bureaucrat or school administrator, as well as her inability to answer certain questions during the confirmation hearings. However, a deeper analysis suggests that these factors may not be the primary reasons for the heightened opposition.

Opinion pieces in the New York Times and Wall Street Journal argue that the overheated Democratic opposition is motivated by:

1. The influence of powerful interest groups, such as teachers' unions, who recognize that they will no longer have a near-monopoly on education with the introduction of charter schools and vouchers.
2. The Democratic Party's upper-middle-class suburbanite constituency, who understand that DeVos' charters and vouchers will be attractive to families with financial disadvantages, ethnic minority heritage, or ideological and religious convictions that differ from the mainstream. In other words, private schooling will be accessible to children who are very different than the Democratic Party's upper-middle-class suburbanites.

Four reasons have been proposed as to why Betsy DeVos may prove to be a beneficial remedy for America's educational challenges:

1. Liberation from Bureaucracy: DeVos' educational philosophy could enable her to liberate American education from federal bureaucracy. Under the Obama administration, the federal government functioned as a giant octopus, bypassing families, communities, and states to impose its will on school curriculum, teacher evaluation, values conformity, and even restroom policies. DeVos signals a departure from this era, with her stated educational philosophy suggesting a reduction in federal encroachment to empower families, local communities, and states.
2. Pluralistic Education: DeVos' educational philosophy aligns with the values of Dutch Calvinism, a religious tradition that emphasizes the rights and freedoms of families, communities, and religions. This philosophy would allow financially-disadvantaged children to choose the education that fits their unique needs and abilities, increasing educational diversity and accessibility.
3. Increased Influence: Under DeVos' potential system of vouchers and charters, citizens will be able to exercise more influence over their own child's education, sending their children to a wider variety of schools, including those that would have been financially prohibitive without the vouchers.
4. Qualifications: Despite criticism that DeVos lacks the traditional qualifications for the position, her extensive involvement in education and interactions with politicians and educational policy makers demonstrate a unique path to the post of secretary that qualifies her for the role.

In conclusion, while Betsy DeVos may face challenges as Education Secretary, her philanthropic background, commitment to education, and potential to reduce bureaucracy, increase free thinking, and empower the financially disadvantaged make her a promising candidate for reforming America's education system.

Title: President Trump Continues to Use "Chinese Virus" Term, Sparks Controversy

Article:

President Donald Trump again used the term "Chinese virus" to refer to the novel coronavirus on Wednesday, despite calls from global health officials to avoid labels associating the disease with a particular nation or ethnic group. The president's rhetoric has drawn backlash and raised concerns about stigmatizing Asian-Americans.

On Tuesday, Mr. Trump's comments gained growing attention after he used the phrase in a tweet about supporting the airline industry as travel restrictions decimate their business. "The United States will be powerfully supporting those industries, like Airlines and others, that are particularly affected by the Chinese Virus. We will be stronger than ever before!" he wrote.

Scientists say the virus originated in Wuhan, China, late last year, but the World Health Organization has warned against using terms that associate diseases with certain groups of people. Despite this, Mr. Trump again referred to the coronavirus as "Chinese virus" on Twitter Wednesday morning and later at a White House press conference.

When asked by a reporter why he continues to use a phrase that some consider to be racist, the president defended his terminology. "Because it comes from China," Mr. Trump said. "It's not racist at all. It comes from China, that's why. I want to be accurate."

The White House also noted that similar names for illnesses have been used in the past. "Spanish Flu. West Nile Virus. Zika. Ebola. All named for places. Before the media's fake outrage, even CNN called it 'Chinese Coronavirus.' Those trying to divide us must stop rooting for America to fail and give Americans real info they need to get through the crisis," the White House said in a tweet.

On social media, many critics condemned the president's use of the term. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted, "Our Asian-American communities—people YOU serve—are already suffering. They do not need you fueling more bigotry." The NYPD is investigating several cases of potential hate crime attacks on Asian-Americans in recent days, and Asian-Americans across the country have reported experiencing heightened discrimination, bullying, and harassment.

Dr. Eugene Gu responded, "I've been deathly afraid of this exact moment where Trump turns to racism and xenophobia and calls COVID-19 the 'Chinese Virus.' We are in deep trouble as a nation now that the President of the United States makes the conscious decision to go down this dark path of hate."

Evangelical pastor Eugene Cho called for the president to set an example of unity instead of finger-pointing. "Mr. President: This is not acceptable. Calling it the 'Chinese virus' only instigates blame, racism, and hatred against Asians—here and abroad. We need leadership that speaks clearly against racism; Leadership that brings the nation and world together. Not further divides."

However, at least one TV personality came out in support of Mr. Trump's remark Tuesday night. Fox News Channel host Tucker Carlson praised the president, saying, "How is it inaccurate to call a virus from China 'Chinese?'" "Good for him," Carlson said. "That was Trump at his very best."

The president has used such rhetoric before. In his Oval Office address last week, Mr. Trump made a point of referring to it as a "foreign virus" that "started in China." At a congressional hearing on March 10, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Robert Redfield, agreed when asked by Congresswoman Lois Frankel that it was "absolutely wrong and inappropriate" to call COVID-19 the "Chinese coronavirus."

"This painful rhetoric has consequences," Democratic Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley said at another hearing on March 12, calling out an unnamed Republican colleague who'd also referred to it as the "Chinese coronavirus." "Since the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak, we've seen not only the spreading of the virus but also a rapid spreading of racism and xenophobia."

Title: President Trump Affirms Belief in U.S. Intelligence Agencies' Assessment on Russian Election Interference, Yet Accepts Putin's Denials

Article:

President Donald Trump clarified on Sunday that he accepts the assessment of U.S. intelligence agencies that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election, but also stated that he believes Russian President Vladimir Putin is sincere in his denials of such interference.

During a news conference in Hanoi with Vietnam's president, Mr. Trump said, "I believe that he [Putin] feels that he and Russia did not meddle in the election." He added, "As to whether I believe it, I'm with our agencies. As currently led by fine people, I believe very much in our intelligence agencies."

On Saturday, Mr. Trump had criticized the former heads of the FBI, the CIA, and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, labeling them as "hacks" and questioning their judgment on the matter of Russian meddling. The president, who now has new leadership in all three agencies, said on Sunday that he has worked "very strongly" with the new leadership in U.S. intelligence.

The CIA and other U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia meddled in the 2016 election to help Mr. Trump defeat Democrat Hillary Clinton. A special counsel's examination of potential collusion between Moscow and Trump campaign aides has led to indictments against Mr. Trump's former campaign chairman and another top aide for crimes unrelated to the campaign, and a guilty plea from a Trump foreign policy adviser.

Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) criticized Mr. Trump's belief in Mr. Putin's denial as "naive." McCain stated, "There's nothing 'America First' about taking the word of a KGB colonel over that of the American intelligence community." He added, "Vladimir Putin does not have America's interests at heart."

In a tweet on Sunday, the president criticized his critics, accusing them of "playing politics" and hurting the U.S. Referring to his earlier comments about Mr. Putin's denials, Mr. Trump told reporters on Sunday, "What I said there is that I believe he believes that, and that's very important for somebody to believe. What he believes is what he believes. What I believe is that we have to get to work."

He reiterated that the U.S. needs Russia's help on issues ranging from North Korea to Syria. "We have to get to work to solve Syria, to solve North Korea, to solve Ukraine, to solve terrorism," the president said. He also pointed to recent U.S. sanctions against Moscow over the election meddling, stating, "People don't realize Russia has been very, very heavily sanctioned. They were sanctioned at a very high level, and that took place very recently. It's now time to get back to healing a world that is shattered and broken."

Mr. Trump commented on the Russia election issue for the second straight day on Sunday before arriving in the Philippines, the final stop on a five-country trip to Asia. In Manila, Mr. Trump is meeting with Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte and will attend a pair of international summits.

Title: Arizona Primary: Sanders' Prospects in Question After Super Tuesday Losses

Article:

Bernie Sanders' campaign, which was initially expected to gain momentum in Arizona, has faced a significant setback following his losses in the Super Tuesday primaries. The Vermont senator, who has invested resources in Arizona and attracted large crowds to his events, is now facing doubts from Arizona Democrats about his ability to recover in time for the March 22 contest against Hillary Clinton.

D.J. Quinlan, an unaligned Arizona Democratic strategist and former executive director of the state Democratic Party, stated, "I think he needed a lot of momentum heading into the last week of voting here. Hillary's sweep definitely took away any momentum they had."

Sanders faced a challenging situation in Arizona even before the Super Tuesday losses. In 2008, Clinton won 13 of the state's 15 counties in her primary race against Barack Obama, and the state's sizable Hispanic population tends to favor Clinton. The recent visit by Sanders' wife, Jane, to Sheriff Joe Arpaio's "Tent City" outdoor jail, an event that went awry when Arpaio unexpectedly joined the senator's wife on the tour, further complicated matters.

The Clinton campaign quickly capitalized on the Arpaio visit, with Illinois Congressman Luis Gutierrez, a leading immigration rights advocate, stating, "When Jane Sanders visited Joe Arpaio's inhumane detention center, the Sanders campaign had a chance to tell Arpaio to his face that he was wrong and that he needed to resign -- as many of us have said for years."

The Clinton campaign also released a series of ads, including a 60-second spot highlighting Clinton's work on immigration reform and contrasting her record with real estate mogul Donald Trump and Arpaio, who has endorsed Trump.

In response, the Sanders campaign has been active in its Latino outreach efforts. Sanders has secured endorsements from more than a dozen prominent Latino Democrats in the state and released ads featuring Tucson-based Congressman Raul Grijalva, a leading progressive who represents much of southern Arizona.

The pattern in Democratic primaries and caucuses so far is that Sanders has had the advantage among younger voters and less diverse electorates, while Clinton has had the upper hand in more diverse electorates and among older voters. Arizona is closer to the latter.

"She's doing very well with whites over 50, which is most whites," Quinlan said, pointing to this as a positive sign for Clinton. "Frankly, I just think Hillary's organization is stronger, and the fact is I just think she has a built-in demographic advantage."

Sanders isn't just fighting demographics in Arizona – he's also fighting against a candidate who is well-known in the state. "The Clintons have been very popular in Arizona. President Bill Clinton has visited on multiple occasions to campaign on behalf of Democrats over the last two, four cycles," said Arizona Democratic Party chairwoman Alexis Tameron.

Clinton, who currently leads by 26 percentage points in the only recent polling, has yet to campaign in the state, while Sanders has made stops three times and his campaign has attracted large crowds. Early voting, which in Arizona starts about two weeks before the primary election, may offer some clues as to the eventual outcome.

Early voting numbers have provided some positive signs for Clinton: According to figures provided by the Arizona Democratic Party, of the 601,049 early ballot requests, 262,547 were returned, with 121,374 from voters 65 and over and another 75,504 from voters between the ages 50-64. Both age groups have been friendly to Clinton in other states.

By contrast, just 18,842 ballots have been returned from voters between the ages of 25 to 34 and 8,959 from voters between 18 and 24 – ominous signs for Sanders, who runs best among younger voters.

Sanders' chief strategist Tad Devine acknowledged the challenges facing the campaign in Arizona but remained optimistic that Sanders might pull out a victory. "I think Hillary's ahead. I concede that. I think she had a bump out of Tuesday there as well," Devine said. "There's a lot of early vote and she tends to be very much ahead with the early vote. I think about half the people have already voted in Arizona. So I think she has an advantage. But I think we're closing hard."

Title: Republican Presidential Debate Highlights the Rivalry Between Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio

Article:

The final Republican presidential debate of 2015 focused on the growing feud between Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida. The two senators, both Cuban-American and first-term, have emerged as the main alternatives to front-runner Donald Trump as the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 1 approach.

Senator Cruz, who is surging in the polls, is an anti-GOP-establishment outsider with strong conservative credentials and significant appeal among evangelicals. Senator Rubio, now polling third nationally, represents a kinder, gentler face of Republicanism, with a more collegial relationship with fellow senators and the potential to attract swing voters in the general election.

The debate, held in Las Vegas, focused on national security and immigration, the dominant themes in the wake of terror attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, California. The battle between Cruz and Rubio did not involve attacks on Trump, as both senators may be attempting to woo his supporters should they cool to his unorthodox campaign persona and style.

The exchange on NSA phone record surveillance centered on Rubio's criticism of Cruz's vote for the USA Freedom Act, which imposed new limits on the collection of phone metadata by US intelligence agencies. Rubio argued that the legislation could hinder the government's ability to identify potential terrorists before they attack. Cruz defended the legislation as expanding the potential universe of records the government has access to, but did not mention the requirement for a court order to access them.

On defense spending and approach to the Islamic State, Rubio criticized Cruz for voting against legislation that authorizes defense spending, stating that air forces alone cannot defeat ISIS. Cruz has promised to "carpet bomb" ISIS with air strikes and is less enamored of sending US ground troops to Syria and Iraq than is Rubio.

Cruz also tried to distance himself from Rubio by associating him with the policies of President Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination. Cruz argued that the focus should be on killing the bad guys, not getting stuck in Middle Eastern civil wars.

Immigration was a fraught issue for Rubio, as it gives some conservatives pause over his candidacy. As a new senator, he co-authored comprehensive immigration reform legislation, only to renounce the bill, which included a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. Rubio has sought to paint Cruz as favoring "legalization" of the undocumented, over his support for big increases in the caps on green cards and the number of visas for high-tech workers. Cruz has since backed off that position, and in the debate, he fought back, stating that he led the fight against Rubio's "legalization and amnesty."

In debate post-mortems, both senators were deemed to have had strong performances, and their duel is likely to intensify in the weeks ahead. The Cuban-American background of both senators may be an accident of history, but it matters to a Republican Party anxious to showcase diversity. Whether either candidate could make major inroads into the Hispanic vote is an open question, particularly for Cruz, who does not speak Spanish and who only uses his heritage to highlight his Cuban-born father's journey to freedom in the US. Rubio, on the other hand, is fluent in Spanish and has made his Cuban-immigrant parents' humble lives as service-workers a central part of his optimistic view of the American dream.

If any of the Republican candidates are capable of channeling Ronald Reagan, whose sunny demeanor helped him to the presidency twice, it may be Rubio. Likability is a key ingredient to presidential campaign success, and if support for Trump begins to wane, one can't assume that his voters go to Cruz. "Too often [Cruz's] message seems negative," says Henry Barbour, Republican national committeeman from Mississippi, speaking before Tuesday's debate. "The key is to come across as the guy with the positive agenda – the Ronald Reagan of the group. And everybody wants to be the Ronald Reagan."

Title: Brazil's President-elect Jair Bolsonaro's Policies and International Reactions

Article:

Brazil's president-elect Jair Bolsonaro, often referred to as the "Trump of the tropics," has been met with concern from the Western liberal elite following his election. The UK Spectator notes that Brazilians, tired of years of leftist governance, have chosen military discipline over a corrupt left-wing regime.

Bolsonaro's policies have been met with criticism from some media outlets, with coverage focusing on his perceived anti-environmental stance and his diplomatic appointments. For instance, the appointment of Ernesto Araujo, Bolsonaro's choice for foreign minister, has been met with disapproval due to Araujo's views on climate change and the environment.

Araujo, in an article, has been critical of climate change activism, labeling it as a Marxist ideology. He also criticizes the green movement as anti-Christian and a tool used by anti-Western countries to stifle economic growth. This has led to headlines such as "Brazil's Bolsonaro names Trump fan top diplomat as Cuba relations sour."

Bolsonaro has also been criticized for his stance on the Paris climate accord, with some media outlets portraying his potential withdrawal as a threat to the environment. However, Bolsonaro has expressed concerns about the accord's potential negative impact on Brazil's agribusiness sector.

The media has also expressed concern over Bolsonaro's pre-inauguration meetings with John Bolton, the former U.S. National Security Advisor. The meetings have been portrayed as a shift in Brazil's foreign policy, with some outlets suggesting that Bolsonaro is favoring relations with the United States over regional communist nations.

Despite the media's portrayal of Bolsonaro's policies as monstrous or odd, many Brazilians view them as long-overdue common sense. The country's high homicide rate and historical leftist governance have led some to view Bolsonaro's emphasis on beef, bibles, and bullets as a means of addressing the country's unique challenges.

In contrast, France, under President Macron, has been grappling with environmental issues, with Macron threatening to retaliate against Brazil if it withdraws from the Paris climate accord. Bolsonaro, however, has shown no signs of backing down from his stance on the issue.

Title: Esquire's Cover Story Sparks Controversy During Black History Month

Article:

In an unexpected move, Esquire magazine debuted a cover story on Tuesday that has sparked controversy, particularly during Black History Month. The March issue features a lengthy profile about 17-year-old Ryan Morgan, a high school senior from West Bend, Wisconsin, under the headline "An American Boy." The subhead reads, "What it's like to grow up white, middle class, and male in the era of social media, school shootings, toxic masculinity, #MeToo, and a divided country."

The cover choice has been widely criticized on Twitter as tone-deaf. One user, @seanieviola, tweeted, "Inside Esquire conference room: 'We should probably do a cover story for Black History Month, any suggestions?' 'There's a white boy in Wisconsin who's sad.' Esquire CEO: 'Run it.'"

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's daughter, Christine Pelosi, also voiced her disapproval, writing, "Esquire: 'Let's use a white teen boy as our foil to lament the rising power of #MeToo and of gun violence prevention advocacy in a cover photo above an inside look at Harvey Weinstein's rape defense for #BlackHistoryMonth.' - @esquire making a series of bad choices."

A follower replied, "Esquire: 'Have you dry heaved this morning? Let us help you.'"

The Esquire piece about Morgan chronicles his daily life and the adversity he's faced for being a supporter of President Trump. "I couldn't say anything without pissing someone off... Lots of drama over politics," he told the magazine. "It ruined friendships and changed social groups. People were making friends based on their politics more than anything."

In a separate story titled "Why Your Ideological Echo Chamber Isn't Just Bad For You," Esquire editor-in-chief Jay Fielden explained that Morgan's cover story is part of a series on growing up in today's society, featuring different demographics. "What we asked [author Jennifer Percy] to do—and she did brilliantly—was to look at our divided country through the eyes of one kid," Fielden said. "Ryan Morgan is his name. He's white, lives in the middle of the reddest county in Wisconsin, and, as you will see, he is an unusually mature, intelligent, and determined young man."

Title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on China over Uighur Repression; China Threatens Countermeasures

Article:

The United States has imposed sanctions on China over the repression of Uighurs, a Muslim minority in China's Xinjiang region, following the signing of a bill by President Donald Trump on Wednesday. The bill, which passed with only one "no" vote in Congress, mandates sanctions against those responsible for the oppression of Uighurs.

The United Nations estimates that over a million Muslims have been detained in camps in the Xinjiang region. The U.S. State Department has accused Chinese officials of subjecting Muslims to torture, abuse, and attempting to erase their culture and religion.

China, which denies the mistreatment and claims the camps provide vocational training and are needed to fight extremism, responded to the signing of the law with anger. China's Foreign Ministry stated that the U.S. was "vilifying" the human rights situation in Xinjiang and launching a malicious attack against China. China threatened countermeasures, without providing details.

The U.S. and China are already at odds over various issues, including China's handling of the coronavirus pandemic and U.S. support for Chinese-claimed Taiwan. The main exile group, the World Uyghur Congress, thanked Trump for signing the law, stating it "gave hope to the desperate Uighur people."

Trump signed the bill as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo held his first face-to-face meeting since last year with China's top diplomat, Yang Jiechi. Trump issued a signing statement, stating that some of the bill's requirements might limit his constitutional authority to conduct diplomacy, regarding them as advisory, not mandatory.

The signing came as newspapers published excerpts from the new book by former national security adviser John Bolton. Among other allegations, Bolton claims that Trump sought Chinese President Xi Jinping's help to win re-election during a closed-door 2019 meeting and that Trump approved of the construction of the camps in Xinjiang.

The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The Uighur law for the first time calls for sanctions on a member of China's powerful Politburo, Xinjiang's Communist Party secretary, Chen Quanguo, as responsible for "gross human rights violations." It also calls on U.S. companies operating in Xinjiang to take steps to ensure they do not use parts made with forced labor.

Title: House Budget Plans Reveal Divergent Visions for the Future

Article:

This week, two contrasting budget plans were unveiled by conservative House Republicans, led by Budget Chairman Paul Ryan, and the House Progressive Caucus, led by Reps. Raul Grijalva and Keith Ellison. The plans offer a glimpse into two distinct visions for the nation's future.

The Republican budget, outlined in a 91-page document, aims to balance the federal budget within a decade. The plan involves tax reform, which lowers rates for individuals and corporations, including high-income earners, while eliminating deductions and credits. National defense is fully funded, but Medicare is essentially voucherized for individuals turning 55 now, with the program surviving through cost containment measures. The plan also includes the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, also known as "Obamacare," and tort reform to reduce frivolous lawsuits.

The House Progressive Caucus' 19-page blueprint, on the other hand, reduces the deficit but does not eliminate it. The plan involves raising taxes and investing in infrastructure, education, and public welfare programs. The Bush tax cuts would expire for those earning over $250,000, and tax rates for millionaires and billionaires would increase. The plan also includes a public-option health system, expanded unemployment benefits, and increased funding for infrastructure, Medicaid, and state law enforcement.

Both budgets represent extreme positions, and their full implementation is unlikely due to the political makeup of Congress. The prospects for cap-and-trade, voucherizing Medicare, the public option, and repealing the Affordable Care Act are all uncertain. These two documents serve as a reminder of the deep partisan divide in the House, with Republicans being fiscally conservative and the House Progressive Caucus being liberal in their spending priorities.

Over the next 10 years, a compromise between the two parties is expected, representing a middle ground between the two visions. The budget plans illustrate the significant differences between liberals and conservatives in their views of the future and the challenges they face in finding common ground.

Title: Democratic Candidates Adopt Republican-Style Campaign Tactics in 2014 Elections

Article:

In the 2014 midterm elections, several Democratic candidates are adopting campaign strategies that traditionally align with the Republican Party, particularly in districts that were favorable to President Barack Obama in previous elections. This shift in strategy is a response to the challenging political environment, characterized by Obama's rising unpopularity and the tendency for conservatives to have higher voter turnout in midterm years.

In a competitive district that Obama won in 2012 and 2008, Colorado Democrat Andrew Romanoff has launched a campaign ad that emphasizes his record in balancing the state's budget. The ad, which carries a tea party theme, features Romanoff stating, "It's really pretty simple. You don't buy things you can't pay for."

New Hampshire Rep. Ann McLane Kuster, whose district favored Obama by a significant margin in 2012, is running an ad that highlights her support for small-business tax cuts and shows her touring a local microbrewery. Separately, former Iowa state Sen. Staci Appel, who won her district by 4 percentage points two years ago, emphasizes her record of fighting overspending in state government, a theme often heard from tea party-aligned conservatives.

Democratic Rep. Ron Barber, in a swing district in southern Arizona, has highlighted his support for increasing border security funds in his first TV spot. The ad, which includes an image of a border patrol car, does not mention elements of immigration reform that are typically more popular among Democratic voters.

In deep-red districts, Democratic candidates are adopting multiple conservative themes. For instance, North Little Rock Mayor Patrick Henry Hays, who is running in an Arkansas district that Mitt Romney won in 2012, discusses the need for a balanced budget, limited government regulations, and less wasteful spending in his first TV ad. Like Romanoff, Hays includes a graphic to depict the national debt.

These campaign ads, similar to those aired by Romanoff, Kuster, Appel, and Barber, do not mention the candidates' Democratic Party affiliation. The strategy adopted by these candidates is a reflection of the need to appeal to more conservative voters in the upcoming 2014 midterm elections.

"It's a different kind of electorate," said Ben Tulchin, a San Francisco-based Democratic pollster. "If you're running in a competitive district as a Democrat in a nonpresidential year, you want to strike a more moderate tone."

Title: Obama Clarifies Economic Remark, Acknowledges Weak Economy

Article:

President Barack Obama, during a press conference on Friday, found himself in a swift retreat after his comment that "the private sector is doing fine" became a focal point for criticism from Mitt Romney and congressional Republicans. The statement contradicted the consensus of economists who view the current recovery as the weakest in modern American history.

Obama's original comment was intended to highlight private-sector job growth outpacing public payrolls, but it was quickly seized upon by his opponents as evidence of his alleged disconnect from the state of the economy.

Within hours, Obama clarified his statement, acknowledging that "it is absolutely clear the economy is not doing fine." He made these remarks during a photo spray in the Oval Office for his meeting with the president of the Philippines.

The ensuing controversy provided a counterpoint to Mitt Romney's own economic gaffe, his off-key declaration that "corporations are people." Despite this, Republicans did not hesitate to capitalize on the situation.

Mitt Romney, speaking at a midday rally in Iowa, stated, "For the president of the United States to stand up and say the private sector is doing fine is going to go down in history as an extraordinary miscalculation and misunderstanding by a president who’s out of touch."

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) and House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) also weighed in, expressing their disagreement with Obama's initial statement. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) went so far as to say, "The president must be on another planet."

In his afternoon remarks, Obama decried the "political games" that had amplified his morning comments into controversy. He reiterated his awareness of the economy's weakness, stating, "The economy is not doing fine. There are too many people out of work. The housing market is still weak, too many homes underwater and that’s precisely why I asked Congress to start taking some steps that can make a difference."

Initially, Obama's appearance in the White House briefing room was intended to offer assurances that he was working to address Europe's economic troubles while still pushing for growth at home. He also used the opportunity to denounce rumors of leaks of key national security information as "offensive."

Title: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s March on Washington Speech: A Symphony of Biblical Rhythms and Historical Allusions

Article:

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the son, grandson, and great-grandson of Baptist ministers, was adept at blending the oral tradition of the black church with the cadences of the King James Bible. His speeches, including the iconic "Dream" speech delivered at the March on Washington, were a fusion of his own words, those of others, and biblical passages.

In the "Dream" speech, Dr. King referenced a passage from Galatians when he spoke of a future where "all of God's children—black men and white men, Jews and Gentiles, Protestants and Catholics—will be able to join hands." He also drew parallels between the African-American struggle and the Israelites' journey from Egypt to the Promised Land, as depicted in the book of Exodus.

The March on Washington speech was replete with biblical rhythms and historical allusions, resonating with listeners through references to the prophets Isaiah and Amos, the Declaration of Independence, Shakespeare, and popular songs like Woody Guthrie's "This Land Is Your Land." These references added depth and layers of meaning to the speech, much like the myriad allusions in T. S. Eliot's "The Waste Land."

Dr. King, who held a doctorate in theology and had contemplated an academic career, was influenced by his childhood in his father's church and his later studies of thinkers like Reinhold Niebuhr, Gandhi, and Hegel. He developed a gift for synthesizing diverse ideas and making them his own, enabling him to address multiple audiences simultaneously while making radical ideas familiar and accessible.

In addition to his ability to unite disparate factions within the civil rights movement, Dr. King was also adept at nestling his arguments within a historical continuum, lending them the authority of tradition and the weight of association. For some in his audience, the articulation of his dream for America would have evoked memories of Langston Hughes' call in a 1935 poem to "let America be the dream the dreamers dreamed" and W.E.B. Du Bois' description of the "wonderful America, which the founding fathers dreamed." His final lines in the March on Washington speech were a reference to a Negro spiritual, reminding listeners of slaves' sustaining faith in the possibility of liberation: "Free at last, free at last; thank God Almighty, we are free at last."

Title: Congress Aims to Finalize Spending Bill by Tuesday, Avoiding Government Shutdown

Article:

As the deadline for government funding approaches, House Speaker Paul Ryan expressed hope that negotiators will finalize an agreement for the $1.3 trillion spending bill by Tuesday. Ryan stated that congressional leaders are not yet discussing a continuing resolution as a backup plan.

"There are some unresolved issues. We're working through them as we speak, and we're hoping to post it today," Ryan, R-Wis., said.

Appropriators are working tirelessly to complete the spending bill, with one top GOP aide close to the negotiations reporting that they worked past 1 a.m. on Tuesday before taking a break and resuming at 7:30 a.m. The agreement requires bipartisan agreement from the White House and all four corners of Congress—Senate and House Democrats as well as Senate and House Republicans.

A top Democratic aide reported that there are approximately 20 riders still in play and at least a dozen other major issues under discussion during the negotiations. "This process just takes time," the aide added.

Ryan signaled that Republicans may attach the Fix NICs gun purchase background checks bill to the spending package, a move that could help build bipartisan consensus around the package. "That's something we're discussing with our colleagues. I think we should do Fix NICS. I agree with Fix NICS. That's something we're discussing with our friends on the other side of the aisle," Ryan said.

Rep. Dan Donovan, a New York Republican, is hoping to attach the Gateway Tunnel project to the spending bill. Donovan believes President Trump could be backing off his veto threat if the omnibus helps fund the project.

"This is important. It's important to the nation. It'd be an economic stimulus," Donovan said. "Certainly after Hurricane Sandy, our two tunnels were deteriorating because of the storm, and building two new ones and retrofitting those two old ones will be an incredible boom to the country."

Rep. Dave Brat, a Virginia Republican and member of the Freedom Caucus, has announced he will vote no due to the $1.3 trillion price tag. "I'm not happy with the product that's going to be there in four days, but we can get there. That's the problem is we're going to get there," Brat said. "I'm a no on just the spending piece alone."

With government funding set to lapse at the end of the day on Friday, time is running out for Donovan and the rest of Congress. "We have to keep our government open. Nobody sent us to Washington to shut their government down. They sent us to make it work better for them," Donovan said.

Title: Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Admits to Misleading Investigators About Media Leak

Article:

In a revelation from transcripts released by the Justice Department's inspector general on Thursday, former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe admitted to misleading investigators about his role in a media leak. The transcripts were made public in response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

According to the transcripts, an unidentified FBI investigator expressed frustration over the time spent investigating the leak, only to discover that the leak originated from McCabe himself. McCabe had repeatedly denied being the source of the leak, but later confessed and apologized when confronted by the investigator.

An FBI agent recounted the conversation, stating, "I remember saying to him, 'Sir, you understand that we've put a lot of work into this based on what you told us.' I mean, and I even said, long nights and weekends working on this trying to find out who amongst your ranks of trusted people would, would do something like that. And [McCabe] kind of just looked down, kind of nodded and said, 'Yeah, I'm sorry.'"

Last year, Justice Department Inspector General Michael E. Horowitz concluded that McCabe "lacked candor" with investigators probing a leak to The Wall Street Journal that revealed the FBI was investigating Hillary Clinton's emails and the Clinton Foundation. The Justice Department fired McCabe in the spring of 2018, citing Horowitz's conclusions. McCabe is currently suing the Justice Department for wrongful termination, alleging President Trump ordered his firing.

When confronted by FBI investigators about the leak, McCabe denied authorizing the disclosure to The Wall Street Journal. He also presented himself as a "victim," according to the agent who conducted the interview. After receiving "conflicting information" on whether he ordered the leak, McCabe confessed in a follow-up interview, the transcripts said.

The U.S. Attorney in D.C. is currently considering criminal charges against McCabe based on Horowitz's conclusions. His attorneys have denied any wrongdoing. McCabe has stated he would refuse a plea deal.

Title: Supreme Court Sends Oregon Bakery Discrimination Case Back to Lower Court

Article:

The Supreme Court has sent back a case involving an Oregon bakery that claims it was driven out of business due to state fines for refusing to bake a wedding cake for a lesbian couple based on religious beliefs. The top court scrapped a ruling from the Oregon Court of Appeals in favor of the same-sex couple.

In an order, the Supreme Court asked the appeals court to reconsider the case in light of a top court holding from last year, the Masterpiece Cakeshop case. In that case, the court ruled 7-2 in favor of a baker who refused to serve a same-sex couple, stating that the state of Colorado was impermissibly hostile to the baker's religious beliefs.

The court in the Masterpiece case did not decide on the underlying question of whether a wedding cake qualifies as the type of artistic expression that is entitled to the Constitution's most stringent protections under the First Amendment. By sending the case back to the lower court, the justices handed an incremental win to the owners of the bakery while avoiding hearing the divisive case in the midst of the 2020 election campaign.

The court's term beginning in October is already expected to be significant for LGBT rights. In April, the court agreed to hear a set of cases that could settle whether federal antidiscrimination laws apply to LGBT employees. An opinion in the case is expected by June 2020, just months before Americans go to the polls in the next presidential election.

The court has now effectively punted twice in two years on the issue of whether a bakery may refuse service to a same-sex couple. In the Masterpiece case, Justice Anthony Kennedy, who has since retired and has been replaced by Brett Kavanaugh, emphasized the difficulty of deciding the issue. He wrote that a baker's religious rights "might" be violated by antidiscrimination laws, but noted the difficulty of pinpointing the moment when a customer's right to not be discriminated against could give way to the business owner's own First Amendment rights.

Justice Kennedy also provided examples of situations that seem all but endless, such as a baker's refusal to attend a wedding to ensure that the cake is cut the right way, or a refusal to put certain religious words or decorations on the cake, or even a refusal to sell a cake that has been baked for the public generally but includes certain religious words or symbols on it. Ultimately, Kennedy predicted the issue would be addressed in "some future controversy involving facts similar to these."

Title: Shale Gas Replacement of Coal and Its Implications for Climate Change

Article:

The shift from coal to shale gas as a source of electricity has been noted due to the former's lower carbon dioxide emissions. According to oil economist Philip Verleger Jr., this transition will lead to an increase in oil and gas production at lower prices, benefiting American consumers, manufacturers, and jobs. However, Verleger also warns that as hydrocarbon prices decrease, it may become increasingly challenging to promote renewable energy programs. Additionally, improper extraction methods could potentially release large quantities of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, into the atmosphere.

In the context of the Keystone pipeline approval, environmentalists are urged to advocate for policies that discourage the use of carbon-intensive fuels and promote low-carbon energy. A carbon tax is suggested as a means to achieve this, as it would not only clean the air, drive clean-tech innovation, weaken petro-dictators, and reduce the deficit but also be part of the budget debate.

Presidential authority under the Clean Air Act can be utilized to order reductions in CO2 emissions from existing coal power plants and refiners by up to 25 percent. The president could then negotiate with power companies to achieve these reductions in different regions of the country.

The president is also encouraged to uphold his commitment to halve energy waste in homes and businesses over the next 20 years, as approximately 30 percent of energy in buildings is wasted.

Lastly, the concept of "natural infrastructure" has been proposed by Mark Tercek, the president and CEO of The Nature Conservancy. This concept emphasizes the role of forests, wetlands, and other ecosystems in controlling floods, supplying water, and adapting to climate change. Investment in natural infrastructure, such as restoring dunes and wetlands, can provide storm protection and wildlife habitat, as demonstrated by Cape May, New Jersey, which was spared significant damage during Hurricane Sandy due to its pre-restoration efforts. The president is urged to emphasize natural infrastructure investment, expanding federal programs like the Land and Water Conservation Fund and the Farm Bill to make communities more resilient, and incentivizing private investment through changes in the tax code and other federal rules.

Title: Obama Defends NSA Data Collection as Modest Encroachment on Privacy

Article:

In a hastily arranged news conference in San Jose, California on Friday, President Barack Obama defended his administration's massive seizure of private citizens' phone records, emails, and Internet activities, describing them as "modest encroachments on privacy" necessary for the war on terrorism.

The president stated, "Nobody is listening to your telephone calls. They're not looking at peoples' names and they're not looking at content. We have established a process and a procedure that the American people should feel comfortable about."

The controversy arose Wednesday night when it was revealed that the National Security Agency (NSA), at the request of the FBI, was routinely collecting the phone records of millions of Verizon customers in the U.S. On Thursday, the government acknowledged that the NSA is also gathering Internet users' personal data, such as emails, photos, and online chats in real-time, from the computer servers of at least nine large web service providers under a top-secret program called "Prism."

The revelations have sparked a wave of protest among privacy advocates and in Congress, where many lawmakers expressed surprise about the scope of the programs. Mr. Obama stated that lawmakers are "fully briefed" on the programs periodically.

Regarding the surveillance of web data and emails, Mr. Obama insisted, "This does not apply to U.S. citizens, and it does not apply to people living in the United States."

While Mr. Obama sought to reassure the public that government agents aren't targeting individuals without probable cause, he also acknowledged the possibility that he himself might be on such a "list" after he leaves office.

"I will leave this office at some point, sometime in the next three and a half years," Mr. Obama said. "After that I will be a private citizen. And I suspect that, on a list of people who might be targeted so that somebody could read their emails, or listen to their phone calls, I'd probably be pretty high on that list. So it's not as though I don't have a personal interest in making sure my privacy is protected."

Mr. Obama emphasized the need to balance national security interests with the protections of individual freedom guaranteed in the Constitution. "I came in with a healthy skepticism about these programs," he said. "My team evaluated them. My assessment, and my team's assessment, was that they help us prevent terrorist attacks."

The president stated that there is a system of checks and balances in place among federal judges, Congress, and the executive branch to ensure the surveillance programs are not abused. "We've got congressional oversight and judicial oversight," he said. "If people can't trust not only the executive branch but also don't trust Congress and don't trust federal judges to make sure that we're abiding by the Constitution and due process and rule of law, then we're going to have some problems here."

He concluded by stating, "The government employees involved in America's national security 'take this work very seriously.' They cherish our Constitution. They operate like professionals. The last thing they'd be doing is taking programs like this to listen to somebody's phone calls."

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Agencies Believe COVID-19 Originated in Wuhan Laboratory as an Accidental Leak

Article:

The majority of the U.S. intelligence community agencies have reportedly concluded that the COVID-19 virus is natural and accidentally leaked out of a laboratory in Wuhan, China, according to a senior intelligence official speaking to ███ News Foundation. While not all of the 17 agencies that make up the Intelligence Community (IC) are fully behind this theory, most believe it to be the case. The holdouts are still open to the possibility that the virus leaked from a laboratory.

The IC's unanimous view is that the virus was not the result of an intentional act, the senior official noted. This account confirms what Fox News White House reporter John Roberts reported on Saturday, and aligns with what President Donald Trump has said publicly.

Roberts cited a senior intelligence official in reporting that "there is agreement among most of the 17 Intelligence agencies that COVID-19 originated in the Wuhan lab. The source stressed that the release is believed to be a mistake, and was not intentional."

The Office of the Director of National Intelligence confirmed in a statement on Thursday that the IC is "rigorously" investigating whether the virus was a result of a lab leak, while making clear that COVID-19 is not believed to be "manmade or genetically modified."

During a press conference on Thursday, Trump stated that he has seen information that indicates with a high degree of confidence that the virus originated from the Wuhan Institute of Virology. When asked by Roberts if he had seen anything that gave him a high degree of confidence that the Wuhan Institute of Virology was the origin of the virus, Trump answered, "Yes, I have." Trump also criticized the World Health Organization for being "like the public relations agency for China."

Title: President Obama Showcases Families Benefiting from Health Care Law, Criticizes Repeal Attempts

Article:

In a display at the White House, President Barack Obama highlighted families who have received rebate checks from their insurance companies due to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The president criticized Republican lawmakers who are attempting to repeal the program.

"I recognize that there's still a lot of folks in this town at least who are rooting for this law to fail," Mr. Obama said. "Some of them seem to think this law is about me. It's not—I already have really good health care."

The president mocked Republican lawmakers for their repeated votes to repeal parts or all of the 2010 ACA, stating, "Sometimes I just try to figure out why." He suggested that they might be engaging in political maneuvers.

The president was joined by families who have benefited from the ACA provision that provides consumers with a refund if their insurance company doesn't spend a set percentage of premium dollars on medical care and improving health care quality, rather than administrative costs or overhead.

Morgan Theriot, a self-employed woman from Silver Spring, MD, was introduced by the president. She received a $267 refund check from her insurance company last summer after it didn't meet the requirement to spend at least 80 percent of her premium dollars on her health care.

"I'm curious—what do opponents of this law think that folks here today should do with the money they were reimbursed?" Mr. Obama asked. "Should they send it back to the insurance companies? Do they think that was a bad idea, to make sure that insurance companies are being held accountable?"

However, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, countered that the president isn't telling Americans the full story.

"What he won't say is that next year, Obamacare will impose a new sales tax on the purchase of health insurance that will cost Americans about $8 billion," Mr. McConnell said Thursday. "If the administration is concerned with saving people money on their health care, I have some advice for them. Work with us to repeal Obamacare and start over."

Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, reaffirmed the GOP's commitment to repealing the law.

"The picture that the president paints of his health care law looks nothing like the reality facing struggling American families," Mr. Boehner said. "The law is costing American jobs; it's forcing people to give up health plans they like; and it's driving up the cost of care for families across America. In my home state, many Ohioans will pay nearly $200 more a month, on average, for individual plans. This law has to go."

For the law to work as its supporters envision, more young and healthy people need to sign up for insurance under the various health exchanges being set up in states. The audience at the White House included community groups who will be working at the grassroots level across the country to help enroll Americans in the new health insurance marketplaces this fall.

The president's pitch came a day after the House voted to delay mandates in the federal health care law requiring individuals and large employers to have coverage. Thirty-five Democrats joined with House Republicans to give large businesses a one-year reprieve on the requirement to provide health insurance for full-time employees, helping pass that provision on a 264-161 vote. The House also voted 251-174 to give individuals the same one-year break, with 22 Democratic lawmakers joining Republicans. The measures are certain to go nowhere in the Democrat-controlled Senate.

The president chuckled at Republican lawmakers for repeatedly voting to repeal provisions of the law.

"Yesterday, despite all the evidence that the law is working the way it was supposed to for middle-class Americans, Republicans in the House of Representatives voted for nearly the 40th time to dismantle it," he said. "We've got a lot of problems in this country, and there's a lot of work that Congress needs to do."

Mr. Obama pointed out that individuals buying insurance on the state-based health care exchange in 2014 will see their premiums drop by an average of 50 percent compared with last year's direct-pay individual rates in New York.

The administration announced in July that it was postponing for one year, until 2015, the law's requirement for employers with more than 50 workers to provide health insurance for all full-time employees. Sharon Stiller, an employment law specialist at the New York firm of Abrams, Fensterman, said many of her employer-clients expect the law's definition of "part-time" employee to be changed. Currently, the law defines a part-timer as any employee who works less than 30 hours per week.

"The word on the street is that there may be some changes with respect to the definition of 'part-time,'" Ms. Stiller said. "It's harder for employers to decide to do the necessary planning because they're not sure exactly what the final criterion will be."

Progressive allies of the president launched a TV ad campaign timed to coincide with the president's message. Americans United for Change went on the air with a new TV ad, "Hands Off Obamacare," attempting to put the GOP on the defensive for trying to strip away provisions of the health law.

"Republicans want to take your benefits away and put insurance companies back in charge," says the announcer in the ad. "Obamacare is working. Tell Republicans—hands off Obamacare."

Title: Heritage Action's "Key Vote" on Obamacare Repeal Bill Complicates Republican Efforts

Article:

Heritage Action, the political arm of the conservative Heritage Foundation, has announced a "key vote" on a bill the House is set to consider, which aims to repeal several components of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The bill, H.R. 3762, does not fully repeal Obamacare, including its major spending provisions such as the expansion of Medicaid and subsidies for individuals to purchase insurance on the exchanges.

The move by Heritage Action could complicate the Republican effort to repeal Obamacare, as it puts pressure on conservatives to vote against a bill they had otherwise been enthusiastic about. By using the budget reconciliation process, Republicans can pass the bill with a simple majority in the Senate, but only provisions tied to spending can be included in the measure.

Policy experts agree that using budget reconciliation rules to repeal Obamacare is Republicans' best chance to put a repeal bill on President Obama's desk, even though the president is virtually guaranteed to veto it. The bill repeals the individual and employer mandates, several taxes, and an independent panel to cut Medicare costs, among other components. It also defunds the bulk of Planned Parenthood's taxpayer subsidies, redirecting those dollars to women's health centers that are not scandal-tainted abortion factories.

The bill is a net tax cut, a net spending cut, and a net cut in the deficit and debt. It causes heartburn in the other team and will force President Obama to double down on the most unpopular parts of his healthcare law. The organization laid out its reasoning in an online post earlier this week.

However, some important context is that in order to use the "reconciliation" budgetary tool to roll back much of Obamacare, the maneuver must result in a net reduction of the deficit, according to the Congressional Budget Office's math. The only provisions of Obamacare that are eligible for repeal through this process are the ones directly pertaining to fiscal and budgetary issues. A House Ways and Means Committee spokesman told ███ that the legislation that is slated to be voted on this week, and against which Heritage Action is lobbying, represents "the best way to repeal the worst parts of the law." The constraints of reconciliation prohibit a repeal of the entire law.

Title: Presidential Candidates Court Latino Voters as Immigration Policy Takes Center Stage

Article:

In the lead-up to the 2012 presidential election, both President Barack Obama and presumptive GOP nominee Mitt Romney are addressing the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials (NALEO) this week. Obama will speak on Friday, while Romney will address the group on Thursday.

The appearances come a week after President Obama announced a new policy allowing some undocumented young people to remain in the U.S. Romney has not denounced the move, and both candidates view garnering Latino votes as crucial to their electoral success.

Matt Barreto, of political opinion research group Latino Decisions, has conducted a new survey. According to Barreto, Obama's move on immigration policy has resulted in a significant shift in Latino voter enthusiasm. "Obama went from a 19-point deficit on an enthusiasm measure to a plus-35," Barreto said, referring to a 50-point turnaround in just one announcement.

Romney's stance on the issue remains unclear, and he has repeatedly refused to say whether he would continue President Obama's policy. During a conference call on the economy, the Romney campaign shut down the discussion after receiving three questions about immigration.

The immigration issue has become a significant wedge issue for Romney, as the president's policy is popular with independent voters and Hispanics, but unpopular with many Republican base voters who view it as a form of amnesty. During the primaries, Romney himself condemned a similar policy known as the DREAM Act.

In an election that may be decided by base voter turnout, Romney cannot afford to alienate anti-amnesty conservatives while still needing Hispanic votes. "Of all the 10 or 12 states that are theoretically in play, all of them have enough of a Hispanic population—for the most part—that could make a difference in a very close election," said Republican Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida.

In 2008, Obama won two-thirds of the Latino vote. Polls show he is still getting the same share of that vote, but with his support among white voters declining, he will need to register more Latinos and get them to the polls. That will be a challenge, as Latino registration has declined since 2008.
