However, the president's decision to suspend certain deportations gives him something to campaign on, according to Barreto. "There's something he can go out and campaign on. It's not just promises or 'I'll do this next time.' He actually has done something," Barreto said. "And if there's a clear contrast there, with the other candidate saying, 'I don't know how I think about that,' that's a clear decision for Latinos. This is an important personal symbolic issue."

Sen. Rubio does not agree that immigration policy is the key to the Hispanic vote. "This idea that Hispanics, all they think about is immigration 24 hours a day, seven days a week, is just not true," he said. "They're like everybody else in the country."

Ed Gillespie, a senior adviser to the Romney campaign, believes there is a way for Republicans to improve on the 31 percent of the Hispanic vote Sen. John McCain of Arizona received in 2008. "I believe a pro-legal immigration message, a pro-economic growth, a pro-job creation message, a pro-education reform message will be very resonant with Americans of Hispanic descent," Gillespie said. "I believe as a result of that, we're going to see Gov. Romney's share of the Latino vote rise from the baseline of Sen. McCain's share."

When Romney attends NALEO's political convention in Orlando, Florida, on Thursday, he will have an opportunity to make his case to the Hispanic community.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Rejects Trump's Proposal for Simultaneous ObamaCare Repeal and Replace

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has rejected President Trump's suggestion for the Senate to pass its ObamaCare overhaul measure by first repealing the 2010 health care law and then replacing it later. McConnell, the leader of the GOP-controlled Senate, stated on Friday night that the bill, which includes significant and complex changes to ObamaCare, remains challenging, but "we are going to stick with that path."

Trump's suggestion, made in a tweet earlier in the day, revives an approach that GOP leaders and the president himself considered but dismissed months ago as impractical and politically unwise. The Senate introduced its bill about two weeks ago but left Washington for the July 4 recess without enough support from the chamber's 52 GOP senators to pass the measure. McConnell will need support from at least 50 of them because the bill has no support among Senate Democrats.

The president's tweet followed a suggestion made by Nebraska Republican Sen. Ben Sasse on Fox & Friends, in which he proposed a vote on repealing former President Barack Obama's health law followed by a new effort at working out a replacement. Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., also claimed credit for recommending the tactic to the president in a conversation earlier in the week.

Trump's suggestion has the potential to harden divisions within the GOP as conservatives like Paul and Sasse complain that McConnell's bill does not go far enough in repealing former President Barack Obama's health care law, while moderates criticize it as overly harsh in kicking people off insurance rolls, shrinking the Medicaid safety net, and increasing premiums for older Americans.

McConnell has been trying to strike deals with members of both factions in order to finalize a rewritten bill that lawmakers can vote on when they return to the Capitol the second week of July. Even before Trump was inaugurated in January, Republicans had debated and ultimately discarded the idea of repealing the overhaul before replacing it, concluding that both must happen simultaneously. Doing otherwise would invite accusations that Republicans were simply tossing people off coverage and would roil insurance markets by raising the question of whether, when, and how Congress might replace Obama's law once it was gone.

The idea also would leave unresolved the quandary lawmakers are struggling with now, about how to replace Obama's system of online insurance markets, tax subsidies, and an expanded Medicaid with something that could get enough Republican votes to pass Congress. House Republicans barely passed their version of a replacement bill in May, and the task is proving even tougher in the Senate, where McConnell has almost no margin for error.

Moderates were spooked as the week began with a Congressional Budget Office finding that McConnell's draft bill would result in 22 million people losing insurance over the next decade, only 1 million fewer than under the House-passed legislation, which Trump privately told senators was "mean." However, conservatives continue to insist that the bill must go further than just repealing some of the mandates and taxes in Obama's law.

Underscoring the fissures within the GOP, conservative group leaders on that call welcomed Trump's suggestion but said it did not go far enough because it could open the door to a subsequent bipartisan compromise to replace Obama's law. At the same time, a key House Republican, Rep. Kevin Brady, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, rejected Trump's suggestion, contending that it "does not achieve what President Trump set out to do."

Title: President Obama Previews State of the Union Address, Blames Washington Decisions for Economic Contraction

Article:

In his weekly radio and Internet address, President Barack Obama, in what is likely a preview of his upcoming State of the Union address on February 12, attributed the recent disappointing economic news, including the unexpected contraction of the U.S. gross domestic product (GDP) in the fourth quarter of 2012, to "bad decisions in Washington."

The president defended the overall economy and cautioned against excessive focus on cutting government spending, stating that such measures could hinder recovery and potentially lead to job losses.

"We all agree that it's critical to cut unnecessary spending," Obama said. "But we can't just cut our way to prosperity. It hasn't worked in the past, and it won't work today. It could slow down our recovery. It could weaken our economy. And it could cost us jobs—now, and in the future."

The president proposed a balanced approach to economic policy, advocating for spending cuts where possible, while also advocating for investments in areas such as education, infrastructure, research, and development. He argued that these investments are essential for America's competitiveness in the global economy.

The president's remarks come in response to Wednesday's news that the American economy contracted by 0.1% in the last quarter of 2012. This contraction has been increasingly attributed to the Republican Party's "austerity politics" by Democrats.

Republicans have emphasized reining in government spending since their party took control of the House in 2010, arguing that government bailouts, stimulus projects, and higher taxes are detrimental to the economy.

Democrats counter that the economy would have been worse without government spending, and they advocate for continued stimulus measures. In his Saturday remarks, Mr. Obama defended the overall health of the economy.

"We began this year with economists and business leaders saying that we are poised to grow in 2013," he said. "And there are real signs of progress: Home prices are starting to climb again. Car sales are at a five-year high. Manufacturing is roaring back. Our businesses created 2.2 million jobs last year. And we just learned that our economy created more jobs over the last few months than economists originally thought."

However, the president also acknowledged the recent economic contraction, stating, "This week, we also received the first estimate of America's economic growth over the last few months. And it reminded us that bad decisions in Washington can get in the way of our economic progress."

The president predicted that 2013 would be a year of "solid growth," if Washington could avoid "self-inflicted wounds."

Title: "Constitutional Challenge to Obamacare's Individual Mandate: A Look at the Origination Clause and the Affordable Care Act"

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, often referred to as "Obamacare," has been a subject of intense debate since its inception. One of its contentious features, the individual mandate, is set to take effect in 2014. This mandate, which requires nearly everyone who is not covered by an employer to buy health insurance or face a penalty, was labeled a "tax" by the Supreme Court in its decision on Obamacare last June. However, the Obama administration never argued that the individual mandate is an exercise of Congress' taxing authority.

The individual mandate's classification as a "tax" has sparked new debates about semantics and created a potential constitutional issue. Article I, Section 7 of the U.S. Constitution states that "all bills for raising revenue" must originate in the House of Representatives. This "Origination Clause" was designed to keep the taxing power close to voters and entrust it to members of the House, who are elected every two years and have smaller constituencies than senators.

However, Obamacare did not follow this constitutional script. Instead of originating in the lower chamber, it started in the Senate when Majority Leader Harry Reid took an old bill the House had passed that would have given veterans tax credits to buy homes, struck out all of that bill's language, and inserted instead the confusing web of provisions that became the Affordable Care Act.

This question is now before U.S. District Judge Beryl Howell in Washington, D.C., in a challenge to Obamacare filed on behalf of Matt Sissel, an Iowa small business owner who was decorated for service as a medic in the Iraq war.

Obamacare was passed hastily, by lawmakers who admitted they had not read the bill. The legislation was passed during the holiday season, through questionable procedural tricks. It was never popular, and a recent Kaiser Family Foundation poll found that only 36 percent of Americans currently support the law. Even the Supreme Court's liberal wing agreed that large parts of it were unconstitutional.

The Constitution's procedural guidelines might seem like dry formalities, but such procedures were designed to safeguard the rights of the American people. If last June's Supreme Court decision is not to become a precedent for Congress to impose any variety of mandates on Americans under the taxing power, courts should take care to enforce democratic controls over that power.

Timothy Sandefur, a principal attorney with Pacific Legal Foundation, a public-interest legal organization that litigates for limited government, individual rights, and free enterprise, represents small business owner Matt Sissel in challenging the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act's individual mandate "tax."

Title: Nike Announces Colin Kaepernick as Face of 30th Anniversary "Just Do It" Campaign

Article:

Former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick has been unveiled as one of the faces in Nike's "Just Do It" 30th anniversary campaign. In 2016, Kaepernick, who is known for his activism, refused to stand for the national anthem in protest of police violence against African-Americans. This action sparked a divisive response, with some players following suit and others, including U.S. President Donald Trump, expressing criticism.

Kaepernick has not played in the National Football League (NFL) since last year and is currently suing the organization, arguing that team owners deliberately froze him out because of his activism. The Nike advertisements feature Kaepernick with the slogan, "Believe in something. Even if it means sacrificing everything."

Other sports stars, including fellow NFL players Odell Beckham Jr and Shaquem Griffin, are also part of the 30th anniversary "Just Doit" campaign. On Monday, Kaepernick posted the advert and the slogan on his Twitter account.

Gino Fisanotti, Nike's vice president of branding for North America, was quoted by cable sports network ESPN as saying, "We believe Colin is one of the most inspirational athletes of this generation, who has leveraged the power of sport to help move the world forward."

Tennis great Serena Williams, another star of the Nike campaign, expressed her support. However, some on social media have used the #BoycottNike and #JustBurnIt hashtags, a play on the company's slogan. Country star John Rich posted a photo of a pair of socks with the Nike emblem cut off.

Kaepernick, 30, remained on a contract with Nike throughout the kneeling controversy, but it has now been renegotiated to make him part of the anniversary campaign. In May this year, the NFL announced that teams whose players who knelt for the national anthem would be fined under a new policy. The league said players not willing to stand for The Star-Spangled Banner could stay in the changing rooms until it had been performed. However, the new policy is yet to be imposed as negotiations between the league and the players' union are ongoing.

Title: First Lady Melania Trump and Greta Thunberg: A Comparative Analysis of Public Criticism

Article:

The White House has refuted allegations of hypocrisy leveled against First Lady Melania Trump for criticizing attacks on her son Barron Trump, while not publicly condemning her husband's criticism of 16-year-old climate activist Greta Thunberg. White House Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham stated on Friday that Barron and Thunberg are in different categories, with the latter being a global climate activist who delivers speeches.

The statement from Grisham followed President Trump's tweet on Thursday, criticizing TIME Magazine's decision to name Thunberg as their "Person of the Year." Trump's tweet read, "So ridiculous. Greta must work on her Anger Management problem, then go to a good old fashioned movie with a friend! Chill Greta, Chill!"

The criticism of Melania Trump escalated after her husband's attack, as some perceived the first lady's defense of her son, who was mentioned by Stanford University law professor Pamela Karlan during a House Judiciary Committee impeachment hearing, as hypocritical. In response to Karlan's quip, Melania Trump stated, "A minor child deserves privacy and should be kept out of politics. Pamela Karlan, you should be ashamed of your very angry and obviously biased public pandering, and using a child to do it."

TIME named Greta Thunberg as their 2019 "Person of the Year" earlier this year. The first lady's frequent criticism over the apparent irony in her fronting the "Be Best" anti-cyberbullying campaign given her husband's habit of mocking political opponents and others on Twitter has been a recurring theme.

Grisham's statement emphasized the difference between the president and first lady's communication styles, stating, "It is no secret that the president and first lady often communicate differently—as most married couples do."

Former first lady Michelle Obama encouraged Thunberg while traveling in Vietnam this week, stating, "Don't let anyone dim your light," and adding, "Like the girls I've met in Vietnam and all over the world, you have so much to offer us all. Ignore the doubters and know that millions of people are cheering you on."

Thunberg responded to Trump's attack by changing her Twitter profile description to describe herself as a "teenager working on her anger management problem."

Title: Democratic National Committee Eliminates Superdelegates, Shifts Power to Social Media Activists

Article:

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has announced plans to eliminate superdelegates, elected officials and party elites who traditionally help determine presidential nominees. This move is expected to shift more authority to activists on social media, who are increasingly influencing the party's agenda.

Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington, who was among those arrested during a recent immigration protest, commented on the change, stating, "We have to pay attention to our base." She pointed to a series of special elections and primaries, including that of Rep. Joe Crowley, as evidence of a rising liberal coalition asserting its power. Jayapal added, "That energy, combined with the real threat of a second Supreme Court justice that could strip away women's reproductive rights and a lot of other rights that people have come to rely on — I think it is an even bigger call to action."

The current situation within the Democratic Party mirrors the turmoil experienced by Republicans during the first two years of President Obama's administration, when Democrats controlled all branches of government and left the Tea Party-influenced Republican Party to protest ineffectually.

Some Democrats view this moment as a significant turning point, akin to the era following the Vietnam War and Watergate, when a backlash against a controversial Republican president led to a moderate and liberal resurgence. This movement resulted in the gain of dozens of new seats but also initiated a generational shift in party leadership.

Former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, who was elected during the Democratic wave of 1974 and was a leader in the effort to reinvent the Democratic Party in the 1980s, believes the party is approaching an overdue moment of self-reflection. According to Hart, the party has failed for years to define a forward-looking vision. The pressure of the midterm election, heightened by the Supreme Court vacancy, could create a new moment of definition.

"There almost has to be a generational renewal of belief systems," said Hart, a two-time presidential candidate, who is now 81. "When we were in power, under Obama and Clinton, I don't believe party leaders did what should have been done, and that is come up with a manifesto for the 21st century."

Title: House Passes $1.37 Trillion Spending Package, Averting Government Shutdown

Article:

The United States House of Representatives has passed a $1.37 trillion spending package, averting a potential government shutdown scheduled for this Friday. The package, which will now move to the Senate for approval before President Donald Trump's signature, includes funding for President Trump's border wall, increased tobacco purchasing age, and funding for gun violence research.

The spending package, broken down into two bills, marks the first of three significant votes scheduled this week in the House. The remaining votes include a historic vote on two articles of impeachment against President Trump and a new North American trade deal.

President Trump has yet to comment on the spending deal, reached after months of negotiations between House and Senate leaders. The administration will retain the ability to reallocate funds from other government accounts, a trade-off since Democrats sought to rein in the administration's power to adjust spending after it was denied by Congress.

The deal maintains funding for the border wall, one of President Trump's campaign promises, at $1.375 billion, similar to last year's allocation. However, the amount is significantly less than the $8.6 billion the president requested. Some House Democrats remain opposed to the agreement, with the Hispanic Caucus stating that the benefits of the bill do not outweigh the "serious issues that remain."

The deal includes a 3.1% raise for federal workers, upgrades to election systems, and $25 million in gun violence research after decades of resistance from the gun lobby. House Appropriations Chairwoman Nita Lowey (D-N.Y.) stated, "With higher spending levels in line with the bipartisan budget agreement, we are scaling up funding for priorities that will make our country safer and stronger and help hardworking families get ahead."

The deal also includes a ban on flavored vape products, expected soon, with menthol and vape stores potentially being spared. The increased use of vaping and e-cigarettes among youth has prompted this measure. As of the end of October, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported 34 deaths and 1,604 lung injury cases related to vaping.

The package also includes $22 billion more in funding for the Pentagon and the preservation of restrictions related to abortion. The deal would raise the age to purchase tobacco products from 18 to 21, a move that gained support after the increased use of vaping and e-cigarettes.

Title: Social Media and Adolescent Mental Health: A Call for Change

Article:

A study by the Pew Research Center reveals that 92% of teenagers go online daily, with 24% stating they are online "constantly." However, contrary to popular belief, Facebook is not the preferred social network for most American teens, with only 15% choosing it as their favorite. Instead, 33% prefer Instagram, 20% opt for Twitter, and 19% select Snapchat. The latter app, which allows users to post pictures that disappear after viewing, has been linked to anxiety and depression in adolescents and young adults.

A 2014 National College Health Assessment survey of nearly 80,000 college students in the United States found that 54% of students reported experiencing overwhelming anxiety in the past 12 months, and 32.6% "felt so depressed that it was difficult to function." The study also reported that 6.4% had intentionally harmed themselves, 8.1% had seriously considered suicide, and 1.3% had attempted suicide.

These statistics are alarming, and the blame is placed on the advent of social technology. The rapid pace of social media can exacerbate the difficulties of growing up, making them more public and potentially leading to anxiety and depression.

To address this issue, several remedies are suggested:

1. Creating more structured forms of social media that prevent children from diving headfirst into the world of social technology.
2. Implementing a mechanism for parents and administrators to receive feedback on their children's online activities without infringing on privacy and alerting them to potential dangers.
3. Incorporating courses on social technology and responsibility into school curricula to educate adolescents about the long-term effects of their online actions.
4. Reducing the pressure on adolescents to constantly perform and market themselves.
5. Providing more mental health support and awareness in schools and colleges to address mental health issues before they become critical.

Title: Congressional Leaders Invited to White House Briefing as Government Shutdown Enters Second Week

Article:

Washington, D.C. - President Donald Trump invited Republican and Democratic congressional leaders to a border security briefing at the White House on Tuesday as the federal government remained partially shut down over the president's demand for funding a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

The president's invitation, described by congressional sources as a briefing and not a negotiating session, was sent to the top two Democrats and Republicans in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's office confirmed that he would attend the briefing, scheduled for Wednesday. It was unclear whether the other leaders would participate, one source said.

The House and Senate will reconvene briefly on Wednesday to mark the last day of the Republican-controlled 2017-2018 Congress, with no signs of a workable plan to end the shutdown, which is now in its second week. Approximately a quarter of the federal government is shut down, with roughly 800,000 workers affected.

Democrats, who won control of the House in the November elections, plan to approve on Thursday a two-part spending package meant to end the shutdown. However, its prospects are grim in the Republican-led Senate, which previously approved similar measures on the floor or in committee but has since fallen in line with Trump's demands for funding for the border wall.

The legislation will set the stage for the first major battle of the new Congress between House Democrats led by Nancy Pelosi and Senate Republicans led by Mitch McConnell.

"We are giving the Republicans the opportunity to take yes for an answer," Pelosi, who is expected to be the House speaker, said in a letter to colleagues released by her office on Tuesday.

"Senate Republicans have already supported this legislation, and if they reject it now, they will be fully complicit in chaos and destruction of the president's third shutdown of his term," Pelosi added.

Trump triggered the shutdown, which began on Dec. 22, by insisting that $5 billion in funding for the border wall be part of any spending measure.

"Border Security and the Wall'thing' and Shutdown is not where Nancy Pelosi wanted to start her tenure as Speaker! Let's make a deal?" Trump tweeted on Tuesday.

Trump considers the wall crucial to curbing illegal immigration, echoing his 2016 presidential campaign pledge. During his run for the White House, Trump insisted Mexico would pay for the wall.

The Democrats' two-part spending package includes a bill to fund the Department of Homeland Security at current levels through Feb. 8 and provide $1.3 billion for border fencing and $300 million for other border security items including technology and cameras.

The second part of the package would fund federal agencies that are now unfunded, such as the Justice, Commerce, and Transportation departments, through Sept. 30, the end of the federal fiscal year. The House Democrats' measure does not contain the $5 billion Trump wants in wall funding. McConnell has said Senate Republicans will not approve a spending measure not supported by Trump.

Title: Retailers See Strong Black Friday Sales Amid Reduced Inventories

Article:

Retailers across the United States reported strong sales on Black Friday, with pared-down inventories and less need to slash prices to attract shoppers. The National Retail Federation expects sales for November and December to climb by about 4% to some $682 billion, making 2017 the strongest holiday season since 2014.

Black Friday sales are expected to come in at around $33 billion, representing a 4.8% advance over Black Friday last year, according to Customer Growth Partners, a market research and analysis firm. Macy's Inc. Chief Executive Jeff Gennette said the retailer had made adjustments based on past years and was well-positioned for the shopping bonanza.

Macy's is offering fewer promotions, Mr. Gennette said. "We're in good shape," he added, but cautioned, "we've still got five weeks ahead of us" until Christmas. The average Black Friday advertised discount across 17 categories was 45% this year compared with 48% last year, according to price-tracking firm Market Track LLC.

Shoppers found many of the same promotions that were on offer last year, including 30% off at Coach and 50% off at the Gap. Kevin Krause, 27, was first in line outside the Kohl's store in Medford, Ore. on Thanksgiving afternoon. He bought an Xbox One videogame console that was on sale for $189.

Analysts have been predicting robust holiday sales amid rising wages, low unemployment, and strong consumer confidence. Another bonus, especially in the Northeast, is cooler weather compared with a year ago, when temperatures edged into the 60s.

Jena Thomas, a university student shopping with her mother at a Target in Chicago, bought two TVs that she couldn't get earlier at Best Buy. She also splurged on a PlayStation 4 console and videogames. "I caught up with all my Christmas shopping," she said.

Traditional stores continue to grapple with a host of problems including sluggish sales as more shopping takes place online. And there is the broad shift in consumer spending away from apparel and accessories and toward dining, travel, and entertainment.

However, a bright spot has emerged: stores, having reduced inventories, aren't sitting on piles of excess goods like they were a year ago. "Because inventory management was quite good coming out of the third quarter, there's not going to be a need for aggressive promotions in the fourth quarter to clear out unsold goods," said Bill Dreher, a retail research analyst with Susquehanna International, a trading firm.

In an interview earlier this week, Neiman Marcus Group CEO Karen Katz attributed a jump in the luxury retailer's gross margin in the latest quarter to stronger full-priced sales. "We've gotten our inventory in perfect alignment with our sales," she said.

However, in the days leading up to Christmas, shoppers have been trained to wait for deals, a practice made easier by online price comparisons. If they hold off on many purchases, retailers will likely have to slash prices more than planned as the season progresses.

In a Wal-Mart on Long Island Thursday evening, Andre Valadas, a 34-year-old software engineer, said it was hard to snag a discounted Sharp TVs being sold at the store and at a Best Buy across the parking lot. He glanced at his phone often to text with friends looking for a similar deal nearby. "I hope that if they don't have deals right now they will have them in a few weeks closer to Christmas," he said.

Black Friday is expected to be the third-busiest shopping day of the year, behind the Saturday before Christmas and Cyber Monday, according to Customer Growth Partners. Online sales on Thanksgiving increased 18% to $2.87 billion, and as of 8 p.m. Friday, shoppers had spent $3.54 billion, up 16%. Adobe expects online sales to increase 14% to $107.4 billion for the November-December period, compared with the previous year.

Amazon said Thanksgiving was one of its biggest mobile shopping days, as orders placed through its app increased more than 50% over last year. Best-selling items included Keurig coffee makers and its Echo speaker devices. "If you go back to the creation of Black Friday, it was this amazing opportunity for customers to get great deals," Dorion Carroll, vice president of mobile shopping at Amazon, said earlier this week. "So they would flock to the stores and all of that would be great, until it wasn't. It got too crowded."

A few technical problems popped up on Friday. Nike Inc. customers complained about error messages when using the sportswear maker's website, and Macy's said it experienced a "slowdown" with its credit-card system. Both retailers said they were working on the issues. Even so, there are still plenty of shoppers making the post-Thanksgiving pilgrimage to stores.

Title: Female Venture Capitalists Play a Crucial Role in Boosting Female Entrepreneurship

Article:

In a recent trial, Professor Gompers, a paid witness for the defense, stated that investment returns are not solely dependent on an individual's track record but also on the presence of good colleagues. He further noted that, on average, women do not benefit from their male colleagues in the venture capital industry.

Venture capitalists serve as gatekeepers to Silicon Valley, and if they are predominantly white men who studied at institutions like Stanford, it is not surprising that the majority of entrepreneurs fit the same mold. According to a report from Babson College, venture firms with women as partners are three times as likely to invest in a company with a female CEO and twice as likely to invest in one with women on the management team.

The lack of female investors has a ripple effect. Start-ups' boards are often composed of venture capitalists, leading to a predominantly male composition. A Fortune analysis found that of the 81 start-ups worth more than $1 billion, 5 percent had a female CEO and 6 percent had a woman on the board. Other studies have found that male founders and directors are less likely to hire women as executives and engineers, or pay men and women equally.

Brit Morin, founder and CEO of Brit & Co, stated, "Honestly, there will be more female entrepreneurs if there are more female venture capitalists." Female investors reported that they did not specifically seek to invest in companies founded by women, but because of their networks, they received more pitches from female entrepreneurs.

Forty percent of the angel investments made by Sonja Hoel Perkins, a founder of Broadway Angels, have been in companies started by women, a significantly higher proportion than is typical for venture funds. This is also the case with a third of Cowboy Ventures' 30 investments, and more than 40 percent of Aspect Ventures' 13 investments.

Theresia Gouw, a founder of Aspect and a former partner at Accel, stated, "We are getting a first look at an unfair share of these amazing, oftentimes repeat entrepreneurs, who happen to be female." Since more than half of the users of many mobile and social services are women, she added, companies can benefit from having female investors evaluate their products and serve on their boards.

Title: Ongoing Transfers Reduce Guantanamo Prison Population

Article:

The United States prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, is yet to be closed, contrary to a promise made by President Obama during the early days of his administration. However, detainees are being released. In May, five Taliban prisoners were swapped for U.S. Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. Since the November midterm elections, there has been a new batch of transfers from Guantanamo, and more releases are in the works.

Seven low-level detainees have been moved to other nations this month, reducing the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 142. More than half of the remaining detainees are also approved for some kind of transfer.

David Rothkopf, CEO of the FP Group which publishes Foreign Policy magazine, states, "The Obama administration came in with some stated goals with regard to dismantling Guantanamo that they have not been able to follow through on thus far, and we are six years in, so I think they're feeling the pressure."

Laura Pitter, from advocacy group Human Rights Watch, comments, "It does seem like there is a renewed effort to reinvigorate the transfers out of Guantanamo." Pitter notes that transfers stalled after the prisoner swap for the release of Sergeant Bergdahl, with GOP lawmakers expressing outrage over the administration's failure to provide the required 30 days notice of that transfer.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, in a statement to the House Intelligence Committee, emphasized his responsibility for signing off on all prisoner transfers from Guantanamo. Nearly five months passed without further transfers, a period that coincided with the rise of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, and a new House Armed Services Committee Chairman Buck McKeon's statement that continuing such releases was unwise.

At a recent hearing, McKeon asked, "Secretary Hagel, isn't this in conflict with your policy of stemming the flow of terrorists?" Hagel replied, "The intelligence community assessed that more than 90 percent of those detainees had not intended to or had in fact, we had not received credible evidence of recidivism."

Ten days later, Hagel announced he was stepping down. He had already notified Congress of more transfers. However, a new Congress run entirely by Republicans could potentially stall the new drive to empty Guantanamo.

Title: Senate Leaders Call for Full, Clean Repeal of Obamacare After Repeal-and-Replace Bill Fails

Article:

In a late-night development on Monday, President Donald Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have called for the full and clean repeal of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The call comes after four Republican senators withdrew their support for the repeal-and-replace bill, leaving McConnell without the 50 votes necessary to pass the Obamacare rewrite.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell released a statement at 11:48 p.m., stating, "Regrettably, it is not apparent that the effort to repeal and immediately replace the failure Obamacare will not be successful. So, in the coming days, the Senate will vote to take up the House bill with the first amendment in order being what a majority of the Senate already supported in 2015 and that was vetoed by then-President Obama: a repeal of Obamacare with a two-year delay to provide for a state transition period to a patient-centered health care system that gives Americans access to quality, affordable care."

Four Republican senators, including Rand Paul of Kentucky and Susan Collins of Maine, had previously opposed the Senate's second repeal-and-replace bill. They were joined by Sens. Mike Lee of Utah and Jerry Moran of Kansas on Monday.

President Trump had previously tweeted on June 30, "If Republican Senators are unable to pass what they are working on now, they should immediately REPEAL, and then REPLACE at a later date!"

The plan to pass a clean repeal bill was initially supported by conservatives, including Sen. Paul and Heritage Action, who believed the horse-trading necessary to accomplish both repeal and replace at the same time would hobble the effort. Their plan was to push for a two-year window where congressmen and senators could craft replacement legislation after Obamacare's fate was set.

Democrats, who have vowed to torpedo any GOP effort to repeal Obamacare, might then be pulled to the negotiation table, enabling Washington to pass a bill with support from both parties. However, the likelihood of bipartisan support is still low, given the current atmosphere in Washington, the parties' widely differing agendas, and the polarized mood of the parties' supporters.

Title: Trump Administration's Paris Accord Stance May Soften as Tillerson Suggests Possibility of Remaining in Agreement

Article:

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has indicated that the United States may remain in the Paris Agreement on climate change, contradicting previous statements from the White House. Tillerson stated that the U.S. would stay in the agreement "if we can construct a set of terms that we believe is fair."

His comments come after the White House earlier denied reports of a softening stance on the accord. In June, President Donald Trump announced the U.S. would withdraw from the pact, citing the need to protect American interests. Trump had portrayed the agreement as one that would hinder the U.S. economy while benefiting countries like China and India.

Speaking to US network CBS, Tillerson suggested the U.S. might not leave the accord at all. When asked if there was a chance the U.S. could stay in the accord, Tillerson replied, "I think, under the right conditions, the president has said he's open to finding those conditions where we can remain engaged with others, on what we all agree is still a challenging issue."

This statement aligns with reports on Saturday suggesting Trump had softened his attitude towards the agreement. After a meeting of environment ministers, the EU's top climate official, Miguel Arias Canete, said Trump officials had indicated the U.S. would not renegotiate the Paris accord but "try to review the terms on which they could be engaged under this agreement."

However, White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders later stated, "There has been no change in the United States' position on the Paris agreement." Sanders added, "As the president has made abundantly clear, the United States is withdrawing unless we can re-enter on terms that are more favorable to our country."

National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster echoed Sanders' words more closely when he appeared on ABC's This Week program on Sunday. "He left the door open to re-entering at some later time if there can be a better deal for the United States," McMaster said.

However, even an improved deal is likely to be a hard sell to Trump's base support, many of whom are vehemently opposed to the 2015 agreement. The Paris accord commits the U.S. and 187 other countries to keeping rising global temperatures "well below" 2°C above pre-industrial levels and "endeavor to limit" them even more, to 1.5°C. Opponents say withdrawing from the accord is an abdication of U.S. leadership on a key global challenge.

Title: San Jose Mayor Proposes Mandatory Liability Insurance for Gun Owners

Article:

San Jose, California's mayor, Sam Liccardo (D), has announced a proposal that would require all gun owners in the city to carry liability insurance for their firearms. The proposal, if enacted, would cover accidental discharges and actions taken by third parties who borrow, steal, or obtain the guns through other means.

Mayor Liccardo stated, "We have to solve problems. While this is far from a complete solution, it is something we can do to reduce the harms of firearms, without waiting for Congress to take action."

The proposal is being referred to as a "harm reduction" approach, modeled after existing insurance requirements for automobiles and tobacco consumption. Mayor Liccardo compared the idea to the requirement of motorists to carry automobile insurance and the subsequent encouragement of safe driving behavior. He also likened it to taxing tobacco consumption to discourage risky behavior and subsidize public health costs generated by smoking-related illnesses and deaths.

Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) praised the move in a Monday tweet, calling it "another tremendous step" in addressing the high costs of gun violence. He questioned, "If you need to have insurance to drive an automobile and follow safety guidelines, then why shouldn't you need insurance to operate and keep a gun safely?"

Opponents of the proposal argue that it would be an onerous burden on people legally exercising their Second Amendment rights. City council member Johnny Khamis stated, "The move could be seen by gun owners who are doing everything legally as a punishment."

The National Rifle Association (NRA) responded to the proposal as "another tax on law-abiding gun owners" in a statement. NRA spokesperson Amy Hunter stated, "Criminals are already ignoring California's more than 800 gun laws, so it's doubtful many of them would rush out and get liability insurance."

Two victims of the recent shooting at the Gilroy Garlic Festival, which took place in California, were children from San Jose: 13-year-old Keyla Salazar and 6-year-old Stephen Romero. Mayor Liccardo called the idea a "harm reduction" approach meant to emulate other models already in effect.

Title: Trump Jr. Emails Reveal Meeting with Russian Lawyer Was Part of Russian Government's Support for Trump Campaign

Article:

Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of President Donald Trump, was informed ahead of a June 2016 meeting with a Kremlin-linked lawyer that material damaging to Hillary Clinton that he was offered was "part of a Russian government effort to aid his father's candidacy," according to a report by The New York Times on Monday evening.

Trump Jr. published the emails detailing the meeting on Twitter Tuesday morning, shortly before the Times was set to publish them. In the messages, he was told by publicist Rob Goldstone, who set up the meeting, that "This is obviously very high level and sensitive information but is part of Russia and its government's support for Mr. Trump."

"If it's what you say, I love it," Trump Jr. replied.

The latest report comes after the White House spent Monday defending Trump Jr. following another Times report that the meeting last summer was intended to get damaging information about Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. In a statement Sunday, Trump Jr. said he did not know who he was meeting with beforehand, but had been told the person "might have information helpful to the campaign." He said the meeting with Russian attorney Natalia Veselnitskaya yielded no useful details.

The meeting was also attended by Trump's then-campaign chairman, Paul Manafort—who would later briefly serve as campaign manager—and Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, who now serves as a White House senior adviser.

"Don Jr. did not collude with anybody to influence the election," White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said on Monday. "The only thing I see inappropriate about the meeting was the people that leaked the information on the meeting after it was voluntarily disclosed."

Sanders added during the daily press briefing, which was not televised, that "the people that leaked the information on the meeting after it was voluntarily disclosed" was inappropriate.

After dismissing such a meeting as routine opposition research gathering that typically happens during campaigns—although typically such meetings would not happen with a foreign government—Trump Jr. also tweeted Monday that he would be happy to "pass on what I know" to Senate and House Intelligence Committees investigating Russia's interference in the 2016 elections and possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. That statement came after Maine GOP Sen. Susan Collins said the president's son needs to speak to the committee.

Senate Intelligence Committee Vice Chairman Mark Warner, D-Va., told reporters at the Capitol on Monday that he "absolutely" wanted to talk to Trump's son, calling it part of a "continuing pattern we've seen since the election of Trump campaign and Trump administration officials who have conveniently forgotten meetings with Russians."

"If I was a campaign manager and had been contacted by what may be an agent of a foreign power and was told that agent may have damaging information about a potential candidate, I think I would remember that meeting," Warner said. "And I think it's also a little strange, as a candidate, if my son or son-in-law met with an official or an agent of a foreign power I think I'd probably want to hear about that information."

White House counselor Kellyanne Conway defended the president's son on CNN Monday morning, emphasizing that there was "no action taken. Nothing" that resulted from the meeting.

"Don Jr. has very explicitly stated he did not even know the name of the person with whom he was meeting," Conway said. "He agreed to the meeting based on a contact from the Miss Universe Pageant." That contact was music publicist Rob Goldstone, who told the Washington Post that he had arranged the gathering.

Politico reported earlier Monday that Trump Jr.'s actions and statements "put him potentially in legal cross hairs for violating federal criminal statutes prohibiting solicitation or acceptance of anything of value from a foreign national, as well as a conspiracy to defraud the United States," and he, Manafort, and Kushner "may have also exposed themselves to future blackmail threats," according to legal experts.

Trump Jr. has hired New York attorney Alan Futerfas to represent himself in matters regarding the Russia investigations, Reuters reported on Monday. The Daily Caller reported that Futerfas has previously represented Nikita Kuzmin, a Russian national who was found guilty of creating a malware virus that infected over 40,000 U.S. computers, including ones at NASA.

"In my view, this is much ado about nothing. During this busy period, Robert Goldstone contacted Don Jr. in an email and suggested that people had information concerning alleged wrongdoing by Democratic Party front-runner, Hillary Clinton, in her dealings with Russia," Futerfas told the Times following the Monday evening story. "Don Jr.'s takeaway from this communication was that someone had information potentially helpful to the campaign and it was coming from someone he knew. Don Jr. had no knowledge as to what specific information, if any, would be discussed."

Title: Cory Booker Announces Presidential Campaign, Cites Vulnerability and Strength

Article:

New Jersey Senator Cory Booker announced his candidacy for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination on Friday, emphasizing vulnerability and strength in his speech.

In a press conference, Booker expressed his thoughts on strength, stating, "What is real strength? Is it bombast? Is it swagger, braggadociousness? Is it strut? No, I think strength is seen in vulnerability. It's seen in those people who stood before fire hoses and armed troopers unarmed."

Booker further discussed his campaign, expressing his intentions to offer a spirit of love, kindness, grace, and decency, in addition to his policy ideas. He concluded by expressing his faith in America and his readiness to compete in the primary race.

The announcement came after weeks of speculation about Booker's intentions, with his delayed entry into the race becoming a running joke among Democratic operatives. Initially, it was believed that Booker would announce in December, but his entry was delayed. The entry of other candidates, such as Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris, further fueled the speculation.

Booker's team stated that the delay was due to a strategic decision to take more time to build and finesse their organization and plan. The team emphasized that the benefits of moving more quickly would not have outweighed the benefits of having more time to prepare.

The announcement was made on Martin Luther King Jr. Day, and Booker spent the day in South Carolina, a state that is expected to play a crucial role in the primary race. The timing of his announcement and his visit to South Carolina had led to assumptions that he was trying to box out Harris, who is also African-American and is seen as a strong competitor in the primary race. However, Booker's team insists that the timing was a strategic move and not an attempt to compete with Harris.

Title: Californian Secessionists Rally on Independence Day, Push for State Split or Secession

Article:

California secessionists, led by the Yes California independence campaign, also known as Calexit, are rallying at the state capitol in Sacramento on Wednesday, advocating for a separate California and urging Trump supporters to leave the state. The Fourth of July, traditionally celebrated with picnics and parades by many Americans, is being viewed by Calexit as a day to stand against the "American occupation of California."

Calexit, which is collecting signatures to place a secession measure on the 2020 ballot, has generated controversy with its efforts to separate California as a separate country. Billionaire Tim Draper generated the most significant attention in April when he qualified his three-Californias measure for the November ballot. This initiative, now named Proposition 9, aims to divide California into three more manageable states: Southern California, Northern California, and California, each holding major cities like San Diego, San Francisco, and Los Angeles, respectively.

Proposition 9 has shown little support in the polls, but Draper maintains the proposal is gaining momentum. "It started at 13 percent in favor and then it went to 17 percent in favor and now you said 27 percent in favor," Draper said. "What happens is as people start thinking about it, they say, yeah, I'd like to see my kids have a better education, yeah I'd like to have better infrastructure, yeah, I'd like to have lower taxes, and I think you could have all that."

Meanwhile, the Fourth of July holds special significance for New California, which seeks to split the state along rural-urban lines, following procedures outlined in Article IV, Section 3 of the U.S. Constitution. About 200 members of New California fanned out Tuesday to read the organization's latest "grievance against the state of California" on the steps of 18 county court and government buildings.

New California co-founder Paul Preston said, "The Founding Fathers laid down their grievances in the Declaration of Independence, and that's the process we're following. It's really kind of exciting to see the Declaration of Independence utilized again." New California issued its own declaration of independence on Jan. 15 and has since relayed 24 grievances, one per week, as it seeks to gain county support and ultimately persuade the state legislature to divide the state.

In a separate movement, the State of Jefferson, which has filed a federal lawsuit in search of a two-state solution, also shares similar goals. Spokesman Terry Gherardi said, "As we celebrate the 4th of July and our independence, the 23 Counties of the State of Jefferson remind everyone, the importance of equal representation for all citizens in the 58 Counties of California and other states, we the people of Jefferson also seek our independence from the oligarchy governing the State of California, forming the new State of Jefferson."

The tone is notably different at Calexit, where organizers Louis Marinelli and Marcus Ruiz Evans have framed their independence campaign as a reaction to American imperialism and the Trump administration. Calexit's Fourth of July message criticized the "ancestors of those undocumented immigrants from the United States who settled in California without invitation, decimated the local population through disease and genocide, stole the natural resources from under their feet, and declared California an American territory." Calexit aims to qualify a ballot measure that would direct California's governor to work with Congress on separating the state from the rest of the nation.

Title: Vice President Pence Announces 20 Million Antibody Tests Per Month for Economic Reopening

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence announced on Monday that 20 million antibody tests are now being produced monthly, a key component in reopening the economy. During the White House Coronavirus Task Force briefing, Pence stated that beyond the new 15-minute tests by Abbott Laboratories, a new antibody test, which may be FDA-approved in a few days, will be produced at the rate of 20 million tests a month.

Pence also mentioned that commercial laboratories, which have been producing hundreds of thousands of tests each week, are not utilizing 20% of Roche's high-speed testing capacity and 75% of Abbott Laboratories' m2000 systems' capacity. If governors and state labs were to activate these existing machines, testing capacity would reportedly double overnight.

The Vice President's comments may refer to Abacus Pharma International (API), a company that produces a coronavirus antibody test called "COVID-Rapid." The test, a simple blood test that can return results in 15 minutes, has a 100% accuracy for detecting old infections but is not designed to diagnose COVID-19. Tens of thousands of tests are currently in a warehouse in Pompano Beach, waiting to be distributed. Puerto Rico has already ordered 3 million tests, and the company also plans to donate 10,000 to the city of Miami. API claims it will have the capacity to make 20 million tests a month.

"We're excited to be able to contribute," said API CEO Vincent DeGennaro. "This is not about selling tests for us, this is about getting people back to work and helping repair our damaged economy and to try and minimize the impact the disease can have in our community here in Miami."

Earlier in the press conference, Pence highlighted Dr. Deborah Birx's efforts in expanding testing capabilities nationwide. "Dr. Birx has been leading an effort for the task force from early on on rapidly expanding testing," Pence said. "It was early on that the president formed that public-private partnership with commercial labs and as we stand here today more than 2.5 million tests have been performed and when we add in the estimates of labs that we have to assume with reasonable projections have not yet reported into the CDC, we think that number could be closer to 3 million tests that have been performed."

Pence also mentioned the new 15-minute test by Abbott Laboratories, stating that they are working closely with the company to rapidly increase the availability of cartridges. Abbott is producing approximately 50,000 cartridges a day, with FEMA acquiring an initial supply and distributing them to the states. The Vice President also mentioned efforts to distribute what is being made and work with other suppliers to create additional cartridges.

This is a breaking news story, please refresh the page for updates.

Title: Fort Worth Police Officer Shoots and Kills Black Woman in Her Home, Family Seeks Transparent Investigation

Article:

FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) — A white Fort Worth police officer shot and killed a black woman, Atatiana Jefferson, 28, inside her home on Saturday, following a call about an open front door. The incident has sparked calls for a thorough investigation and transparency from the family of the victim and Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders.

According to attorney Lee Merritt, who represents Jefferson's family, the officer "didn't have time to perceive a threat" before opening fire. Merritt stated that the bodycam video, which was released by the Fort Worth Police Department, does not show the officer shouting "Gun, gun, gun" before firing.

Jefferson was watching her 8-year-old nephew when she was killed, her family told KXAS television. The Fort Worth Police Department stated in a statement that officers saw someone near a window inside the home and that one of them drew his duty weapon and fired after "perceiving a threat." The bodycam video released by police shows two officers searching the home from the outside with flashlights before one shouts, "Put your hands up, show me your hands." One shot is then fired through a window.

Jefferson's sister, Amber Carr, expressed her grief and frustration, stating, "It's another one of those situations where the people that are supposed to protect us are actually not here to protect us." Carr added, "You know, you want to see justice, but justice doesn't bring my sister back."

An aunt, Venitta Body, stated that the family does not understand why Jefferson was killed. "It's like from the moment we got the call, it's been more and more inconceivable and more confusing," Body said. "And there has nothing been done in order to take away that confusion."

The Fort Worth Police Department has placed the officer, who has been on the force since April 2018, on administrative leave pending the outcome of an investigation. The officer's name has not been released, and he is scheduled to be interviewed about the fatal shooting on Monday.

At a brief news conference at police headquarters, Fort Worth Police Lt. Brandon O'Neil confirmed that the officer did not announce he was police before he fired the fatal shot and that his failure to do so is part of the department's investigation. O'Neil also confirmed that Jefferson's 8-year-old nephew was in the room with her when she was shot.

James Smith, who called a police non-emergency number about the open door, told reporters he was just trying to be a good neighbor. "I'm shaken. I'm mad. I'm upset. And I feel it's partly my fault," Smith said. "If I had never dialed the police department, she'd still be alive."

Smith stated that Jefferson and her nephew typically lived with an older woman, who has been in the hospital. "It makes you not want to call the police department," he said.

In an audio recording of Smith's call that was released by police, the neighbor said it was "not normal" for the house to leave its front door open for hours at that time of day.

Merritt stated that Jefferson's family expects "a thorough and expedient investigation." The Fort Worth Police Department stated it released bodycam footage soon after the shooting to provide transparency, but that any "camera footage inside the residence" could not be distributed due to state law. However, the bodycam video released to media included blurred still frames showing a gun inside a bedroom at the home. It's unclear if the firearm was found near the woman, and police have not said that the officer who shot her thought she had a gun. The police statement released Saturday said only that officers who entered the residence after the shooting found a firearm. Police did not immediately respond to a message seeking comment Sunday.

Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders on Sunday called on the Justice Department to investigate. "The killings of unarmed Black Americans have got to end," Sanders tweeted. "Atatiana Jefferson should be alive."

The shooting comes less than two weeks after a white former Dallas police officer was sentenced to 10 years in prison after being convicted of murder in the fatal shooting of her black neighbor inside his own apartment. Amber Guyger, 31, said during her trial that she mistook Jean's apartment for her own, which was one floor below Jean's. Merritt also represents Jean's family.

Title: Mueller Subpoenas Trump Organization for Documents, Including Russia-Related Materials

Article:

U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller has issued a subpoena to the Trump Organization for documents, including some related to Russia, according to a report by the New York Times on Thursday. The details of the subpoena were not available, and the Trump Organization played down the significance of any subpoena, with a lawyer stating that the company has been cooperative with the special counsel's investigation since July.

Mueller is investigating Russian attempts to influence the 2016 U.S. election and potential collusion by Trump aides. Russia has denied U.S. intelligence agencies' conclusion that it meddled in the election, and U.S. President Donald Trump has stated there was no collusion between his campaign and Moscow officials. Mueller has charged several Trump associates and more than a dozen Russians.

Peter Carr, a spokesman for Mueller, declined to comment on the Times report about a subpoena, which is the first known time Mueller has demanded materials directly related to Trump's businesses. The S&P 500 ended slightly lower on Thursday in choppy trade, with strong jobs and manufacturing data balanced by the Times report on Mueller's subpoena.

New York lawyer Alan Futerfas, who represents the Trump Organization in the Russia probe, stated, "This is old news, and our assistance and cooperation with the various investigations remains the same today." Futerfas also represents Donald Trump Jr. and other Trump Organization officers and employees.

Congressional committees are also investigating Russia and the 2016 election and possible collusion with the Trump campaign. The White House declined to comment specifically on the report and referred questions to the Trump Organization. "We're going to continue to fully cooperate. Out of respect for the special counsel, we're not going to comment," White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said.

Title: Israeli Airstrikes Disrupt Muslim Holiday in Gaza as International Efforts Intensify for a Ceasefire

Article:

Israeli jets targeted three Hamas sites in Gaza on Monday, marking a disruption to a relative lull in the war-torn territory during the start of the Muslim holiday, Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of the fasting month of Ramadan. The strikes followed an almost 12-hour pause in fighting and came as international efforts intensified to end the three-week conflict between Israel and Hamas.

The U.N. called for an "immediate" cease-fire. Israel's military stated that it struck two rocket launchers and a rocket manufacturing facility in central and northern Gaza after a rocket hit southern Israel early Monday. The rocket caused no damage or injuries.

Earlier, the Israeli military reported that it had not conducted any attacks in Gaza since 9:30 p.m. on Sunday, but troops on the ground were continuing efforts to destroy the cross-border tunnels constructed by Hamas for attacks inside Israel. The military opened artillery fire on Beit Lahiya in northern Gaza in response to the rocket fired at Ashkelon.

Muslims began celebrating Eid al-Fitr on Monday, but there was fear and mourning instead of holiday cheer in the Gaza Strip. Palestinian families huddled inside their homes, fearing more airstrikes, while those who came to a cemetery in Gaza City's Sheik Radwan neighborhood to pay traditional respects at their ancestors' graves gathered around a large crater from an airstrike a week ago that had broken up several graves.

An emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council called for "an immediate and unconditional humanitarian cease-fire." While it was the council's strongest statement yet on the conflict that has already killed 1,030 Palestinians, 43 Israeli soldiers, and three civilians on the Israeli side, it was not a resolution and therefore not binding.

Palestinian U.N. Ambassador Riyad Mansour expressed his disappointment, stating that the council should have adopted a strong and legally binding resolution a long time ago demanding an immediate halt to Israel's "aggression," providing the Palestinian people with protection, and lifting the siege in the Gaza Strip so goods and people can move freely.

"You cannot keep 1.8 million Palestinian civilians in the Gaza Strip in this huge prison," Mansour told reporters. "That is a recipe for disaster. It is inhumane, and it has to be stopped and it has to be lifted."

Israeli U.N. ambassador Ron Prosor also criticized the statement—though from a very different perspective—saying it lacked balance because it did not mention Hamas, the firing of rockets into Israel, or Israel's right to defend itself.

Israel says it started its Gaza operation on July 8 to stop the rocket fire from the coastal territory and intensified it on July 17 to neutralize Hamas cross-border tunnels built to carry out attacks on Israeli territory.

The pressure for a cease-fire followed new attacks launched by Israel and Hamas on Sunday despite the back-and-forth over proposals for another temporary halt to the fighting. The Security Council urged Israel and Hamas "to accept and fully implement the humanitarian cease-fire into the Eid period and beyond." It said this would allow for the delivery of urgently needed assistance.

The council's presidential statement also called on the parties "to engage in efforts to achieve a durable and fully respected cease-fire, based on the Egyptian initiative."

On Sunday, President Obama telephoned Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to express his concern over the mounting Palestinian casualties. The White House stated that Obama reiterated that Israel has a right to defend itself and condemned Hamas' rocket attacks. Obama said a lasting peace will ultimately require a demilitarized Gaza and dismantling of terror groups. The U.S. president also pushed for an immediate, unconditional cease-fire that would allow Israeli and Palestinian civilians to return to normalcy.

International diplomats have hoped that a temporary lull in the fighting could be expanded into a more sustainable truce to end the bloodshed.

Title: Merck CEO Resigns from President's Manufacturing Council in Response to Charlottesville Remarks

Article:

Merck chairman and CEO Kenneth Frazier has resigned from President Trump's American Manufacturing Council, citing the need for U.S. leaders to reject expressions of hatred, bigotry, and group supremacy. In a statement, Frazier emphasized the strength of the U.S. stems from its diversity and the contributions made by individuals of different faiths, races, sexual orientations, and political beliefs.

"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations, and political beliefs," Frazier stated, without mentioning Trump by name.

"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry, and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal," he continued. "As CEO of Merck, and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism."

In response, Trump tweeted, "Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!"

Frazier previously served as the chairman of a commission that investigated the pedophilia scandal at Pennsylvania State University. The commission's report found that Penn State administrators failed to take action to stop Jerry Sandusky, a football coach convicted of sexual abuse.

Trump faced backlash this weekend for denouncing the violence in Charlottesville, where one person died and numerous more were injured in clashes between white supremacists and counterprotesters. Trump's initial statement did not directly place blame on any particular group, stating, "We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry, and violence on many sides — on many sides."

The White House sought to clarify Trump's position on Sunday, stating, "The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together."

Title: Supreme Court Confirmation Process Transformed: Ford's Allegations and Kavanaugh's Denial Lead to Dramatic Shift

Article:

In a rapid turn of events, the Supreme Court confirmation process for Brett Kavanaugh has evolved from a seemingly certain confirmation to a contentious dilemma. Initially, when only an unnamed accuser emerged with vague allegations from Kavanaugh's high school years, the Republicans showed no signs of slowing the confirmation process. However, the emergence of Christine Blasey Ford, who came forward to The Washington Post, has significantly altered the landscape.

Ford's lawyer, in statements on two morning shows, confirmed that Ford is willing to testify, creating an unstoppable momentum that has led Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley to invite both Ford and Kavanaugh to testify next Monday. The support of Jeff Flake and Susan Collins for hearings has further solidified this change, making it impossible to revert to Grassley's initial proposal of a phone interview.

Kavanaugh, too, has issued an expanded denial and expressed his willingness to testify, effectively rendering Grassley's initial proposal obsolete. President Trump, while praising Kavanaugh, acknowledged the delay in addressing the allegations and expressed a willingness to proceed with the process.

In the Post interview, Ford detailed her account, stating that Kavanaugh groped her, tried to remove her bathing suit, and covered her mouth when she screamed. Ford described the incident as an attempted rape, with her lawyer, Debra Katz, adding that Ford believes Kavanaugh would have raped her if he had not been severely intoxicated.

The Post also reported on therapist's notes from 2012, which do not mention Kavanaugh's name but describe an attack by students from an elite boys' school, with four boys involved. Ford attributes this discrepancy to an error by her therapist.

Senator Orrin Hatch suggests that Kavanaugh was not at such a party and may be a victim of mistaken identity. The outcome of the allegations, the ensuing hearings, and the public's response remain uncertain at this point. The serious nature of the allegation, the potential long-term trauma for Ford, and the stellar career Kavanaugh has built since his high school years present complex questions for lawmakers and the public. Kavanaugh maintains his innocence, and any determination of his guilt could potentially be seen as a lie on his part as an adult. The upcoming testimony is expected to captivate the nation under the glare of television lights.

Title: Bipartisan Agreement Reached on VA Health Care Legislation to Address Scandals and Improve Services

Article:

The leaders of the House and Senate Veterans Affairs committees have reached a tentative agreement on legislation aimed at improving veterans' health care and addressing the numerous issues plaguing the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). The proposed bill, if passed, would authorize at least $17 billion in spending over the next three years to rectify the veterans' health program.

The agreement includes funding to facilitate prompt appointments for veterans with VA doctors and to hire additional medical staff, such as doctors, nurses, and other medical professionals. The plan also grants the VA secretary the authority to immediately dismiss senior executives and provides employees with streamlined appeal rights.

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), chairman of the Senate veterans panel, had proposed a bill last week that would cost approximately $25 billion over three years. In response, Rep. Jeff Miller (R-Fla.), the House veterans committee leader, proposed a plan to approve $10 billion in emergency spending, with a promise of additional spending in future years.

The differences between the two lawmakers threatened to derail negotiations last week, but they negotiated over the weekend and produced the plan announced on Monday. The leaders of both parties in both chambers will now need to gauge the support of their respective caucuses for the plan, which still requires approval from the House and Senate.

The agreement comes amid widespread national outrage over problems within the VA, such as the case of 18 veterans who died while on a secret waiting list for care at the VA facility in Phoenix. An inspector general's report in May found that roughly 1,700 veterans in Phoenix were on an unauthorized list, with some waiting as long as 115 days for treatment.

The VA Secretary, Eric Shinseki, resigned shortly after the release of that report. The Obama administration has stated that it needs approximately $17.6 billion to hire thousands of doctors, nurses, and other health professionals, lease new facilities, and upgrade its computers to reduce the backlog of veterans awaiting care at VA hospitals and clinics.

The proposed legislation includes funding to give veterans who cannot get a VA appointment the option of receiving non-VA care, funding for the VA itself, and authority for the VA secretary to immediately fire corrupt or incompetent senior executives. The plan also includes funding for construction projects to improve safety or patient access, computer enhancements, and additional staff to address the agency's backlog of benefits claims.

Title: Hillary Clinton Compares President Trump to Richard Nixon, Criticizes Administration Policies at Wellesley College Commencement

Article:

In her third commencement address at Wellesley College, former First Lady and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton did not shy away from criticizing the current administration. During her speech, she made several allusions to President Trump, comparing his presidency to that of Richard Nixon, and took aim at various controversies surrounding the Trump administration.

Clinton, who previously delivered the commencement speech at Wellesley in 1969 and 1992, spoke about the dangers of leaders who manipulate facts and attack their critics. "When people in power invent their own facts and attack those who question them, it can mark the beginning of the end of a free society," she said. "That is not hyperbole, it is what authoritarian regimes throughout history have done... They attempt to control reality."

The former Secretary of State also criticized the Trump administration's budget blueprint, describing it as "an attack of unimaginable cruelty on the most vulnerable among us—the youngest, the oldest, the poorest, and hard-working people who need a little help to gain or hang on to a decent, middle-class life."

Clinton warned the graduating students that they are "graduating at a time when there’s a full-fledged assault on truth and reason." She cited examples of people denying scientific facts, spreading conspiracy theories, and sowing division among the public.

One specific example she mentioned was the controversy surrounding the size of the crowd at President Trump's inauguration. In January 2017, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer claimed that Trump's inauguration was "the largest audience to ever witness an inauguration, period, both in person and around the globe." However, side-by-side images seemed to contradict this claim, leading to widespread media scrutiny. White House counselor Kellyanne Conway attempted to defend Spicer by referring to "alternative facts" about the crowd size.

Following Clinton's speech, Republican National Committee chairwoman Ronna McDaniel issued a statement accusing Clinton of using "partisan talking points" and suggesting that her comments were a "stark reminder why [she] lost in 2016."

Title: Macedonian Group Launches Initiative to Counter George Soros' Influence

Article:

A new initiative called Stop Operation Soros (SOS) has been launched in the Balkan nation of Macedonia with the aim of countering the influence of globalist billionaire George Soros. The group, which calls on "free-minded citizens" to join, claims that Soros-funded non-government organizations have monopolized civil society in Macedonia and used their influence to suppress dissenting views.

In a press conference on Tuesday, SOS co-founder Nikola Srbov accused the Open Society Foundation, operating under the Soros umbrella, of using its funding and personnel to support violent processes in Macedonia. He stated that this is unacceptable and goes beyond the principles of civic organizing.

The Open Society Foundation was established by Soros in the 1980s with the stated goal of helping former Soviet bloc countries transition from communism. However, Srbov and others claim that the foundation is used to destabilize governments and foment discontent within countries.

This is not the first time that Macedonia has taken action against Soros. Earlier this month, Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced that the Hungarian government would begin cracking down on any organizations linked to Soros. In December, Orban stated, "In every country, they will want to displace Soros. In the coming year, Soros and his forces will be squeezed out."

In 2014, Soros openly admitted on CNN that the OSF was involved in the violent overthrow of Ukraine's government, which resulted in Russia banning Soros and his NGOs from the country the following year, citing him as a "security threat" to the former Soviet nation.

As nationalism continues to rise around the world, it is reasonable to assume that this will not be the last instance a European country takes action against Soros and his organizations. The specific details of the SOS initiative and its impact on Macedonia's civil society remain to be seen.

Title: Bernie Sanders Discusses 2020 Race, Clinton Relationship, and Presidential Election

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate for 2020, stated on Friday that he has not sought advice from former Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton regarding the current race and has no plans to meet with her. In an interview on "The View," Sanders expressed that he and Clinton have "fundamental differences."

When asked about potential meetings with Clinton, Sanders responded, "I suspect not." This statement comes amid reports that Clinton has met with several 2020 hopefuls to offer advice on the race.

In 2016, Sanders joined a crowded field of Democratic candidates, and his defense of democratic socialism drew criticism from allies of President Donald Trump and other conservatives. However, Sanders enters the 2020 race largely free of the characterizations as an idealistic fringe candidate, as he was three years ago.

In her book, "What Happened," Clinton placed blame on Sanders for contributing to her 2016 loss, arguing that he detracted several would-be voters. The apparent tension between the two was evident in Sanders' Friday interview.

"Hillary has not called me," Sanders said. "Look, we have differences," he continued, trailing off before conceding, "Hillary has played a very important role in modern American politics."

Despite the ideological differences, Sanders expressed support for other Democratic candidates, stating his main objective in 2020 is to vote out Trump. He added that he would support any candidate the Democrats choose to do so.
