"I hope to be the Democratic nominee and have the support of the whole Democratic Party behind me," Sanders said. "If I am not and somebody else is, I will support that candidate because what's most important is that Trump be defeated."

Sanders campaigned for Clinton in 2016 after losing the party's nomination.

Title: Conservative Scholars Debate Paid Family Leave Compatibility with Conservative Principles

Article:

Washington, D.C. - The debate on paid family leave has taken center stage in the political arena, with the Democratic party advocating for comprehensive legislation, and the Republican party yet to coalesce around a unified stance. This week, the Ethics and Public Policy Center hosted an event titled "Is Paid Family Leave Compatible with Conservative Principles?" to discuss the issue.

The event's first panel featured a debate on the title question. Aparna Mathur, a scholar in economic policy at the American Enterprise Institute, and Kristin Shapiro of the Independent Women's Forum argued in favor of paid leave, while Rachel Greszler, a research fellow at the Heritage Foundation, and Veronique de Rugy, a research fellow at the Mercatus Center, opposed the idea.

The opposition from Greszler and de Rugy primarily stemmed from slippery-slope concerns, expressing doubts that even a limited parental-leave program would not expand to cover other forms of leave, increasing the size and scope of the federal government. They argued that proposals, such as Shapiro's, to allow new parents to collect some of their Social Security benefits after the birth or adoption of a child, would eventually become a large-scale, costly program.

Shapiro and Mathur, on the other hand, maintained that paid parental leave is popular with most Americans and warned that if conservatives refuse to propose their own solutions, they will be left behind as the public coalesces around the expansive Democratic solution. Shapiro also argued that a conservative plan would be a pro-life policy, helping those most in need and reducing infant mortality, particularly for low-income families who don't already have paid leave through their employers.

The second panel of the morning featured policy advisers from three Senate offices outlining the differences between the two Republican proposals for paid leave. The CRADLE Act, sponsored by Senators Joni Ernst (Iowa) and Mike Lee (Utah), would permit new parents to receive one, two, or three months of paid-leave benefits in exchange for postponing their Social Security benefits for two, four, or six months. The New Parents Act, from Marco Rubio (Fla.) and Mitt Romney (Utah), allows new parents to use some of their Social Security benefits to finance up to three months of parental leave but also allows parents to take benefits even if they were not employed at the time of a child's birth (so long as they had a sufficient earnings history).

Representatives Dan Crenshaw (Texas) and Ann Wagner (Mo.) are co-sponsoring the New Parents Act in the House. Caleb Orr, a policy adviser for Rubio, explained the distinction between the two bills by noting that requiring a set period of leave to obtain the benefit, as the Lee-Ernst bill would do, might discourage at least some families or parents from choosing to take leave at all, which would undermine the goal of the policy.

The event highlighted the ongoing debate within the Republican party regarding paid family leave and the conservative principles that should guide any potential legislation. As of now, only four Republican senators have signed on to a particular parental-leave policy, but supporters of the idea point to Ivanka Trump's interest and argue that now is the time for conservatives to gain public support before Democrats beat them to it.

Title: Supreme Court Vacancy and the Test of Divided Government in the American Political System

Article:

The death of Justice Antonin Scalia has presented a significant challenge to the American political system, as it tests the ability of divided government to function effectively in today's more polarized political climate. In the past, divided government has shown the capacity to govern, as demonstrated by the unanimous approval of President Ronald Reagan's nomination of Anthony Kennedy to the Supreme Court in 1988, despite a divided party control of the government.

However, in the wake of Scalia's death, senior Republicans have stated that they will not consider a nomination from President Obama, despite his almost year remaining in office. This stance was most notably expressed by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who argued that the vacancy should not be filled until a new president is elected.

The American people have already expressed their preference for Scalia's replacement through their votes, reelecting Barack Obama in 2012. However, they also elected Mitch McConnell as majority leader in 2014. Both leaders' claims of democratic legitimacy are valid, but the American political system lacks a mechanism for resolving the conflicting mandates.

This lack of resolution is a common issue in political systems, as noted by the late sociologist Juan Linz. Linz argued that, aside from the United States and Chile, few other presidential governments have managed to maintain constitutional continuity for over a century. Chilean democracy, however, broke down in the 1970s.

Linz attributed the American political system's strength to the lack of clear ideological distinction within its parties, making compromise easier. However, in recent decades, the political parties have become increasingly distinct, with liberals clustered in the Democratic Party and conservatives in the Republican Party. This level of party polarization is unprecedented in American politics.

The inability of the divided political system to fill a Supreme Court nomination during presidential election years is a cause for concern. If this inability persists, it may indicate a narrowing of the space for effective governance due to party polarization. This could potentially lead to a serious crisis, as suggested by Matt Yglesias in his essay on these underlying forces.

Divided government is a common occurrence in American politics and has not historically signaled disaster for the system's ability to solve problems. If it does so now, the country will, over time, pay a serious price for a political system that no longer fits its political parties. The future of the American political system remains uncertain, as the answer Republicans are currently providing—that the nomination should not be filled—may set a strange precedent and potentially lead to further political instability.

Title: Trump Criticizes NATO Nations for Insufficient Defense Spending

Article:

President Donald Trump's criticism of NATO and its member nations regarding their defense spending has been a recurring theme in his speeches. In a recent address at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, he emphasized that the U.S. supports NATO but expects all members to contribute their fair share to the alliance.

"We strongly support NATO; we only ask that all of the NATO members make their full and proper contributions to the NATO alliance, which many of them have not been doing—many of them have not been even close," Trump said.

According to the article, Trump's criticism is based on the fact that many NATO countries do not meet the agreed-upon defense spending target of 2% of their GDP. The article also points out that the military capabilities of many NATO nations are significantly lower compared to the Tampa Police Department.

The article also provides historical context, stating that the U.S. has historically shouldered a significant portion of the defense burden for NATO countries, while many of these countries have relied on American service members and taxpayers to defend them. The article suggests that European countries often prioritize extensive and expensive welfare programs over their own defense.

The article also mentions that this issue is not a new one, with the U.S. having obliged its young men to serve in uniform to ensure the defense of Western Europe while many European countries did not have national service. The article also notes that some European countries, such as the Netherlands, have unionized armies, and questions the effectiveness of their military capabilities.

The article also mentions that in the 1960s, Europe had been rebuilt and was nearly as prosperous as the U.S., but chose not to use its resources for defense. The article also notes that European countries spend less on their own defense than Imelda Marcos spent on shoes.

The article concludes by stating that Trump is not telling NATO to leave, but rather to shape up and do the honorable thing by meeting their defense spending obligations. The article also suggests that European officials who attempt to make their countries responsible for their defense may face opposition from their own citizens. The article also notes the decline in the military capabilities of some NATO countries, such as the Royal Navy of the United Kingdom.

Title: Senate's Better Care Reconciliation Act: A Market-Based Approach to Healthcare

Article:

The Better Care Reconciliation Act, the latest health-care bill unveiled by Senate Republicans, has received mixed reactions from both political sides. The proposal, as drafted, preserves key features of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) while addressing some of its flaws.

Critics on the right, such as Senator Rand Paul and Americans for Prosperity, have criticized the plan as a watered-down version of ObamaCare. Meanwhile, many liberals have denounced Better Care as an unmitigated evil. However, a closer examination of the bill reveals that it shares many similarities with the Republican Party's go-to health-care policy expert, Avik Roy's, plan.

The bill's passage would have significant implications, but Republicans could make similar normative claims about the ACA itself. While the ACA has helped millions of Americans, it has also left millions uninsured and many more with higher premiums and deductibles than in 2009, when Democrats promised their plan would deliver the opposite.

The left's default position is that the ACA's shortcomings are due to Republican obstructionism before its passage and subsequent refusal to cooperate. Former President Obama, in a statement criticizing the Senate health-care bill, noted that while the ACA represented a significant step forward, it was not perfect. He expressed a willingness to support Republicans if they could present a better plan that covered as many people at less cost.

The Better Care Reconciliation Act, like the ACA, is a market-oriented plan that acknowledges the trade-offs involved in such an approach. If some bureaucratic hurdles and government largesse are removed from the health-care market, as many conservatives desire, some people will lose coverage, and others will see an increase in their out-of-pocket costs.

The bill also recognizes the government's role in situations where the market, if left to its own devices, has merciless implications. It largely preserves the protections the 2009 law established for Americans with pre-existing conditions and provides reinsurance for insurers who might have balked at doing so. This was a humane and worthwhile achievement, for which Democrats deserve credit, even if they are criticized for leaving millions of Americans uninsured.

On Monday, the Congressional Budget Office released its score of the bill, which found that passage of the legislation would result in an additional 22 million Americans being uninsured in 2026, compared to projections based on the current law. The logic underlying this projection was debatable, but its political implications are clear-cut. The Democrats who touted ObamaCare as a plan that would make comprehensive health insurance affordable to the average American are out of power, at least for the time being. However, they may regain control of Congress in 2018, and we can all look forward to seeing them unveil their secret plan.

Title: Huffman Urges Calm on Superdelegate Issue, Warns of Election Consequences

Article:

Representative Jared Huffman (D-CA) called for voters to remain calm about the superdelegate system during a visit to his constituency in California's second congressional district on Saturday. Huffman, a superdelegate who has endorsed former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, represents a district that is likely to support Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT).

In a speech to approximately 120 supporters at the Bayside Grange event hall in Humboldt County, Huffman emphasized party unity and criticized the ongoing election season as "crass," "juvenile," and "depressing." He also warned that the makeup of the Supreme Court and its decisions on issues such as abortion, campaign finance reform, and climate change are "hanging in the balance."

Huffman urged voters to consider the potential consequences of a President Donald Trump, stating, "There are fundamental different directions this country will take depending on the outcome of this election." He also emphasized the importance of the election, stating, "We have an opportunity to make this an absolute landslide for Democrats."

Regarding the superdelegate system, in which members of Congress and party officials are free to vote for whomever they choose in the primary, regardless of the results of the primary in their state, Huffman sought to reassure a wary progressive constituency. Currently, Hillary Clinton holds a narrow lead in delegates chosen by the electorate, but a wide lead in superdelegates.

Earlier in his speech, Huffman criticized the Westlands Water District of the Central Valley for what he called "bad ideas that are designed to take away our water." Last week, Huffman and several other California House Democrats called for congressional hearings into the Central Valley water agency's recent settlement with the federal government over drainage for its farms.

In response to Huffman's comments, Westlands Water District deputy general manager Johnny Amaral stated, "There is way more to the Trinity River issue than [Huffman] is letting on." Amaral added, "What was on the menu tonight [at the Huffman event]? Salad? Vegetables? Fruit? Meats? Nuts? All of it came from farmers in the Westlands Water District. A thank-you would have been sufficient."

Title: Treasury Inspector General Discloses IRS Probe Known to Obama Administration in 2012

Article:

WASHINGTON — In a testimony on Friday, J. Russell George, the Treasury inspector general for tax administration, revealed that senior Treasury officials were aware in June 2012 that investigators were looking into complaints from tea party groups alleging harassment by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). This disclosure indicates that Obama administration officials were aware of the probe during the heat of the presidential campaign.

During the hearing, both George and ousted IRS head Steven Miller testified. Miller, who faced intense questioning from Republican lawmakers, acknowledged agency mistakes in targeting tea party groups for special scrutiny when they applied for tax-exempt status. However, he insisted that agents broke no laws and that there was no effort to cover up their actions.

The revelation has stoked the criticism of many Republicans, who are assailing the administration amid a sudden spate of other controversies, including the Benghazi attack and the government's seizure of Associated Press telephone records.

In his testimony, George stated that he informed the department's general counsel about his investigation on June 4, 2012, and Deputy Treasury Secretary Neal Wolin was informed "shortly thereafter." However, George clarified that these discussions were not to inform them of the results of the audit but to inform them of the fact that the audit was being conducted.

After the hearing, inspector general spokeswoman Karen Kraushaar said George "informed Department of Treasury officials that we were looking into the IRS's handling of applications for tax-exempt status, partly due to allegations raised by conservative organizations."

The Treasury Department issued a statement on Friday stating that officials first became aware of the actual results of the investigation in March of this year, when they were provided a draft of George's report, a standard practice.

George's disclosure was made before the House Ways and Means Committee in the first of several congressional hearings on the matter. Miller, who spoke publicly about the controversy for the first time, was contrite as he apologized for the actions of agents who singled out conservative political groups for additional, often burdensome scrutiny.

However, the hearing turned prickly when Miller insisted he did not deceive Congress, though he repeatedly failed to reveal the controversy last year when he was asked about it by lawmakers—even after he had been briefed.

"I did not mislead Congress or the American people," Miller said.

Title: Mia Love's Defeat in Utah House Race Highlights Republican Challenges in Attracting Minority and Women Voters

Article:

House candidate Mia Love, who was seen as a promising figure for the Republican Party, lost her race in Utah's 4th Congressional District to Democrat Jim Matheson on November 6. Love's defeat, which occurred in a deep-red state, has been identified as a significant indicator of the challenges faced by the Republican Party in appealing to minority and women voters.

Love, a black Republican who delivered a prime-time convention speech and received support from Mitt Romney, lost to Matheson by a narrow margin of approximately 1 percentage point. However, Love won only 27 percent of the Hispanic vote compared to Matheson's 71 percent, a disparity that mirrors the presidential race between Romney and President Obama.

The defeat of Love, who represents the growing diversity within the GOP, underscores the party's need to attract more support from minority voting blocs. In the 2012 elections, Hispanics made up 10 percent of the electorate, and Republicans won a smaller percentage of the Hispanic vote than they did in 2004 with George W. Bush, who won 44 percent of the Hispanic vote.

Another concern for the Republican Party is their ability to appeal to women voters. Females made up roughly 53 percent of the electorate this cycle, and roughly 55 percent of them voted for Obama. The controversial remarks made by Senate candidates Todd Akin in Missouri and Richard Mourdock in Indiana, who both made comments about rape and/or pregnancy that were used by Democrats to portray GOP candidates as a threat to women, have been identified as a significant factor in this trend.

In response to these challenges, the Republican Party is taking steps to analyze the 2012 elections and develop strategies to broaden their base. Reince Priebus, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has ordered a full analysis of the elections that will include talking to campaign volunteers and outside groups. The audit will focus on key voting blocs such as women, younger voters, and Hispanics.

The Republican Party is also considering comprehensive immigration reform, with House Speaker John Boehner urging Obama to come up with a plan and Senate Lindsey Graham proposing a plan similar to those being put forward by Democrats. Meanwhile, Romney has suggested that the administration went too far in appealing to Latinos and other groups, accusing the president of winning favor with "gifts."

Some Republicans, such as Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, Ohio Sen. Rob Portman, and Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, are being identified as potential 2016 candidates who could help the party grow by appealing to Hispanics, women, and young voters. Taylor Griffin, a Republican strategist, stated, "Each has the ability to appeal to the moderate voter."

Title: GOP Tax Cuts Advance Despite Deficit Concerns: Unpaid-For Measures Approved by House Ways and Means Committee

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, the House Ways and Means Committee, controlled by Republicans, has voted to advance hundreds of billions in tax cuts, adding to the federal deficit. The committee approved six tax breaks on Tuesday, at a cost of $310 billion over the next decade.

The vote was almost entirely along party lines, with the committee's Republican chairman, Dave Camp, leading the charge. The approved tax breaks include the research and experimentation deduction, a credit that helps small businesses with major equipment costs, and the break for businesses earning rent and interest overseas.

Republican opponents argue that these tax breaks have been passed year after year without offsetting their costs, and that the jobs generated by these tax breaks are worth the added deficit. However, Democrats and some fiscal conservatives have criticized the move, citing a perceived double standard in the GOP's approach to tax cuts and spending.

Chuck Marr, director of tax policy at the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, stated, "It's a clear double standard, particularly when you hold up unemployment."

Republicans, on the other hand, maintain that their decision to prioritize tax cuts over deficit reduction is consistent with their long-standing position. Sarah Swinehart, spokeswoman for Camp, said, "Pay-fors are for spending. New spending. That's his position."

The six tax breaks approved on Tuesday were part of a larger group of 55 tax breaks that expired at the end of 2013 and have been waiting for congressional renewal. The full House is expected to vote on all six tax credit bills, with multiple GOP sources telling CNN that they expect all bills to receive votes on the House floor. The exact timing is still being worked out.

Title: Bipartisan Lawmakers Unveil Immigration Proposal Amidst Government Funding Impasse

Article:

A bipartisan group of 48 lawmakers, evenly split by party, have unveiled a proposal to address the ongoing immigration standoff in Washington. The group, known as the Problem Solvers Caucus, aims to include their immigration-border security outline in a budget deal that has been elusive due to the impasse on immigration and other issues.

The caucus has been working since last fall to find a solution for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which protects young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children from deportation. President Donald Trump decided in September to terminate the program by March 5.

The Problem Solvers Caucus' proposal bears resemblance to an offer from a bipartisan Senate group led by Sens. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) and Dick Durbin (D-Illinois), which was rejected by Trump and deemed dead in the Senate by GOP leadership.

While the White House unveiled its own proposal last week, offering a pathway to citizenship for nearly 2 million undocumented immigrants, it contains other sweeping immigration changes that have faced immediate resistance from the left.

The success of the Problem Solvers Caucus proposal remains uncertain, but the bipartisan group has been negotiating for months in the hope that if enough rank-and-file members can show consensus across the aisle, it could gain traction with leadership as a viable option as funding talks continue without success. The latest short-term government funding is set to expire on February 8.

In the deal, qualifying young undocumented immigrants would have a 10- to 12-year pathway to citizenship, provided they have a clean criminal record and have paid taxes. The border security piece of the deal would allocate the President's request for this coming fiscal year: $1.6 billion for physical barriers, such as walls and fencing, and $1.1 billion for technology and other measures. It would also appropriate money for drug screening, border access roads, and personnel, and authorize a study on adding fees to related activities that can then be spent on border security.

To address the other two "pillars" of the White House's demands - ending the diversity lottery and curtailing family migration - the bill would eliminate the diversity visa but create a new merit-based visa for underrepresented countries with education, work, and language requirements. Half of the visas would also go initially toward allowing recipients of Temporary Protected Status to stay in the U.S. after the Trump administration ended their protections.

The bill would prevent parents who brought their children illegally to the U.S. from being sponsored for citizenship by those children once they become citizens, but would give them three-year legal work permits to stay in the U.S. without citizenship.

Title: South Korea's Successful Containment of COVID-19 Compared to the U.S. Disaster

Article:

South Korea, a country with a population of 51 million, effectively contained the COVID-19 outbreak within a month. The daily new cases fell from 800 to fewer than 100 in the first two weeks of March. As of this morning, the nation reported zero new domestic infections for the third consecutive day.

In contrast, the United States, with a population approximately six times larger, has experienced a significant number of COVID-19 fatalities. In mid-March, the U.S. and South Korea had the same number of coronavirus-caused fatalities, approximately 90. However, as of April, South Korea lost a total of 85 souls to COVID-19, while the U.S. lost 62,000—an average of 85 deaths every hour.

The stark contrast between the two countries' responses has led some commentators to attribute South Korea's success to an ancient culture of collectivism and Confucianism. However, this observation is not only racially insensitive but also oversimplifies the factors contributing to South Korea's success.

The South Korean government and its citizens have learned from their past experiences with public health crises. In 2002, the SARS outbreak killed several hundred people in East Asia. In 2009, the H1N1 influenza, which likely originated in Mexico, spread to more than 1 million people globally and killed several hundred South Koreans. From these epidemics, South Korean public-health officials recognized the necessity of early testing and the importance of isolating new patients to prevent secondary infections.

The 2015 Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak created the playbook that the country has used to break the back of COVID-19. The South Korean government's response to MERS involved extensive testing, contact tracing, and quarantining of infected individuals and their close contacts. This approach, combined with public education and transparency, has been instrumental in South Korea's success in containing the COVID-19 outbreak.

In conclusion, South Korea's ability to effectively contain the COVID-19 outbreak is a result of its past experiences with public health crises and the government's swift and comprehensive response. The country's success serves as a model for other nations to learn from and adapt to their own circumstances.

Title: First U.S. Case of Ebola Confirmed, Health System Prepared for Isolation and Control

Article:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced on Tuesday the first confirmed case of Ebola in the United States. The patient, who traveled from Liberia, developed symptoms upon arrival in the U.S. However, there is no evidence that anyone on the patient's flights from Liberia to the U.S. was exposed to the virus.

Since the outbreak began in Africa, the CDC has consulted with state and local health departments on nearly 100 cases involving travelers who returned from West Africa and showed symptoms that might have been caused by Ebola. Of those cases, 14 were considered to be truly at risk. Specimens from 13 were tested, and Ebola was ruled out in all 13 cases.

The U.S. has a strong healthcare system and dedicated public health professionals working to ensure the case will not threaten the community at large or the nation. A person who is sick from Ebola virus disease can be cared for in U.S. hospitals with the patient isolated in a private room with a private bathroom, and contact with them is highly controlled. Every health care worker must meticulously follow every single infection control protection recommended.

Public health officials are also identifying people who have had close personal contact with the newly diagnosed patient and will follow up with them for 21 days, the longest known incubation period for Ebola. If they develop any signs of the disease, those people will be isolated, tested, and cared for.

The CDC has been preparing for this day, working around the clock with local and state health departments to enhance surveillance and laboratory testing capacity, provide recommendations for health care infection control and other measures to prevent disease spread, and deliver guidance and tools for health departments to conduct public health investigations.

Although the CDC cannot promise that they can stop the disease at just one case, they are confident that the right steps are being taken to stop Ebola in its tracks in the U.S. It is essential to remember that the U.S. must be relentless in stopping the spread of Ebola in West Africa, as that is the only way to truly and completely protect the health security of America and the world.

Title: Former FBI Deputy Director McCabe and Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein Allegedly Discussed Removing President Trump

Article:

In a series of tweets on Monday, President Donald Trump accused Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe of pursuing an alleged "illegal and treasonous" plot against him. The allegations stem from discussions about secretly recording the president and potentially invoking the 25th Amendment, which allows for the removal of a president if they are deemed mentally unfit.

McCabe, in promotional interviews for his forthcoming book, told CBS News' "60 Minutes" that Rosenstein was "absolutely serious" when he suggested recording Trump in the days following the firing of former FBI Director James Comey. Trump responded to the comments, calling McCabe a liar and accusing top DOJ and FBI officials of orchestrating a "deranged" plan.

While Trump fumed at McCabe, the former FBI deputy director claimed he never seriously considered Rosenstein's offer to secretly record the president. McCabe said he did discuss the matter with the FBI's then-general counsel, James A. Baker. Last fall, as reported by Fox News, Baker told lawmakers during a closed-door deposition that McCabe and Page had told him details of the meeting where Rosenstein made the comments. Baker reportedly told congressional investigators he took the word of McCabe and Page "seriously."

McCabe told CBS News that "I think the general counsel had a heart attack" when he told him of Rosenstein's plan. "And when he got up off the floor, he said, 'I, I, that's a bridge too far. We're not there yet,'" McCabe added. Days later, Rosenstein appointed former FBI Director Robert Mueller as a special counsel to oversee the bureau's investigation into allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials.

Rosenstein has repeatedly denied pursuing or authorizing the recording of the president and has also denied McCabe's suggestion that he had broached the idea of invoking the 25th Amendment. The Justice Department echoed both denials in a statement released last week, saying Rosenstein "was not in a position to consider invoking the 25th Amendment."

However, McCabe said in the interview, "Rod raised the [25th Amendment] issue and discussed it with me in the context of thinking about how many other Cabinet officials might support such an effort." He added that he believed Rosenstein was "counting votes or possible votes" to remove Trump from office.

Fox News reported Sunday that Baker, in his testimony to Congress, provided even more details about the alleged 25th Amendment discussions, saying two Cabinet officials were "ready to support" such an effort.

Title: US Democrats' Use of Kente Cloth in Congress Sparks Controversy and Debate

Article:

In the aftermath of the death of African American George Floyd at the hands of a white police officer, the United States Congress proposed legislation to reform the police. However, the attire of some Democratic lawmakers during the announcement of the proposed reforms has become a topic of discussion on social media.

On Monday, several Democratic lawmakers, including Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi, were seen wearing kente scarves, a colorful geometric cloth originating from Ghana. The Congressional Black Caucus, a group that meets to pursue legislative goals around greater equality for black people, provided the scarves, according to NBC News reporter Leigh Ann Caldwell.

Karen Bass, the chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus, explained the significance of the kente cloth, stating, "The significance of the kente cloth is our African heritage, and for those of you without that heritage who are acting in solidarity." She further added, "That is the significance of the kente cloth - our origins and respecting our past."

Kente cloth has been used in the US to reflect a pride in African heritage, including at graduation ceremonies for students in historically black fraternities or sororities. Modern kente is characterized by intricately woven and richly colorful geometric designs, often seen in bold shades of yellow, blue, green, red, and orange.

The kente cloth is associated with the Ashanti people in central Ghana and is linked with special occasions as it is expensive to make. The skills of the finest weavers are reserved for the use of Ashanti royalty, and certain patterns are reserved for the king. Otumfuo Osei Tutu II is the current king, or Asantehene, who ascended to the throne in 1999. He is a revered figurehead who adjudicates in disputes and is closely involved in local issues. However, like other traditional leaders, he is barred by the constitution from taking part in Ghanaian politics.

The use of kente cloth by the Democrats has sparked a debate on social media, with some finding it a symbol of solidarity and pride, while others view it as a distraction from the proposed police reforms. Some celebrities, such as the drummer for the Roots, Questlove, and singer John Legend, have commented on the trending topic on Twitter.

However, the reaction in Ghana has not been as noticeable, with some Ghanaians viewing it as an opportunity to promote the cloth. On the other hand, Kenyan writer Nanjala Nyabola sees the Democrats' use of kente as an insult to Africans, stating, "We are not your props."

Some critics in the US argue that the focus on the kente cloth is diverting attention from the proposed police reforms, with one tweeter saying, "Now is NOT the time to learn the history of kente cloth. I assure this too is a distraction."

The Democrats' proposed Justice in Policing Act of 2020 aims to reform the police in America to make it easier to prosecute officers for misconduct, ban chokeholds, and address racism. As she unveiled the bill, Mrs. Pelosi read the names of black men and women who have died at the hands of police in recent years.

It remains unclear whether Republicans, who control the US Senate, will support the proposed legislation. US President Donald Trump wrote on Twitter that "the Radical Left Democrats want to Defund and Abandon our Police. Sorry, I want LAW & ORDER!"

Title: Canadian Parliament Unanimously Condemns U.S. Officials' Criticism of Prime Minister Trudeau

Article:

Canada's House of Commons unanimously condemned U.S. President Donald Trump and his aides for their attacks targeting Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday. The parliament passed a motion rejecting "disparaging ad hominem statements by U.S. officials which do a disservice to bilateral relations," according to Reuters.

The symbolic move followed comments made by Peter Navarro, the White House National Trade Council director, who said there is a "special place in hell" for any leader who engages in bad faith diplomacy with Trump. A number of other Trump officials and the president himself also criticized Trudeau following the Group of Seven (G-7) summit in Canada last weekend.

Trump refused to sign the G-7 joint agreement after Trudeau severely criticized Trump following the international summit. Trump officials have suggested that Trudeau double-crossed Trump by criticizing him on television after he left the gathering. Trump took to Twitter to criticize Trudeau, stating, "PM Justin Trudeau of Canada acted so meek and mild during our @G7 meetings only to give a news conference after I left saying that, ‘US Tariffs were kind of insulting’ and he ‘will not be pushed around.’"

Trump added, "Very dishonest & weak. Our Tariffs are in response to his of 270% on dairy!" Canadian lawmakers also approved a motion that supports the Canadian steel and aluminum industry that has been impacted by Trump's massive tariffs, according to Reuters.

Prime Minister Trudeau kept a low profile on Monday after the verbal sparring and was not in the House of Commons during the parliament's unanimous vote.

Title: Primary Challenges to President Trump: An Analysis of the Likelihood and Implications

Article:

The recent announcement of former Illinois Representative Joe Walsh's primary challenge to President Donald Trump has sparked debate over the President's vulnerability to a primary challenge. However, historical data suggests that primary challenges to sitting presidents are rare and often unsuccessful.

In the last 70 years, only three presidents faced muscular primary challenges in the modern primary era: Gerald Ford in 1976, Jimmy Carter in 1980, and George H.W. Bush in 1992. All three went on to lose the general election. It is important to note that these presidents were under 75% approval with members of their own party, while President Trump currently enjoys overwhelming intraparty support, with 88% approval in the latest Gallup poll.

Head-to-head polls of the Republican primary give Trump massive leads over any primary challengers. He leads former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld, who was the first notable candidate to jump in the race, by anywhere from 60 to 85 points, and he even leads high-profile hypothetical challengers like Utah Senator Mitt Romney and former Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley by up to 80 points.

While these facts do not seem to deter challengers, it is unclear if their primary goal is to beat Trump or to spur a conversation about the party's direction. In addition to Walsh and Weld, former South Carolina Representative Mark Sanford is considering jumping in. The success of these candidates in terms of their impact on the party's direction, rather than their chances of winning the primary, is a topic of debate.

The potential success of these primary challengers in terms of their impact on the party's direction is a topic of debate. My colleague Geoffrey Skelley devised a scale for rating the "success" of presidential primary challengers, from 1 (no-name candidates) to 5 (the as-yet hypothetical candidate who manages to successfully topple a sitting president). Right now, I would think that Walsh, Weld, and potentially Sanford are somewhere between Levels 1 and 2.

The success of these primary challengers in terms of their impact on the party's direction is a topic of debate. My colleague Geoffrey Skelley devised a scale for rating the "success" of presidential primary challengers, from 1 (no-name candidates) to 5 (the as-yet hypothetical candidate who manages to successfully topple a sitting president). Right now, I would think that Walsh, Weld, and potentially Sanford are somewhere between Levels 1 and 2. They are known commodities and could put together a professional campaign apparatus, but it seems unlikely that they will attract as much support as Pat Buchanan did against Bush in 1992, the model for a Level 2 primary challenge.

The risk of Republican challengers splitting the anti-Trump sentiment in the party into even smaller pieces is also a concern. For example, a HarrisX national poll from May, when Trump and Weld were the only notable Republicans in the race, gave Trump a 73-7 lead. But HarrisX's latest national poll, the first to include Walsh, puts Trump at 76%, Walsh at 5%, and Weld at 3%. Any additional candidates who jump into the race saying they want to "stop Trump" may make it harder to do just that.

In conclusion, while primary challenges to President Trump are rare and often unsuccessful, the recent announcement of Joe Walsh's primary challenge has sparked debate over the President's vulnerability to a primary challenge. The success of these primary challengers in terms of their impact on the party's direction, rather than their chances of winning the primary, is a topic of debate. The risk of Republican challengers splitting the anti-Trump sentiment in the party into even smaller pieces is also a concern. The most important takeaway from Walsh's and other primary challengers' campaigns may be the level of anti-Trump sentiment in the party, rather than the President's chances of losing the primary.

Title: Former President George H.W. Bush's Final Hours and National Mourning

Article:

Former President George H.W. Bush, the 41st President of the United States, passed away peacefully on Friday at the age of 94. In an interview on Fox News Sunday, former Vice President Dick Cheney and former Secretary of State and Treasury James Baker joined anchor Chris Wallace to reflect on Bush's life and career.

During the discussion, Baker revealed details of Bush's final hours. He described Bush's passing as "gentle and peaceful," stating that arrangements were made for all of his children to call in to say their goodbyes. In his last words, Bush expressed love to his son, former President George W. Bush, who had called in to say, "Dad, I love you. I will see you on the other side," to which Bush responded, "I love you."

The New York Times provided additional details, reporting that Bush had been fading in the last few days, spending most of his time sleeping. On Friday morning, his longtime friend and former Secretary of State, James A. Baker III, arrived at his Houston home to check on him. Bush suddenly grew alert, asking, "Where are we going, Bake?" to which Baker replied, "We're going to heaven." Bush responded, "That's where I want to go." He passed away barely 13 hours later, surrounded by friends, family, doctors, and a minister.

Outgoing House Speaker Paul Ryan announced that Bush will lie in state at the Capitol rotunda from 7:30 pm on Monday until Wednesday morning. The public is invited to pay their respects from Monday, December 3, at 7:30 pm ET until Wednesday, December 5, at 7:00 am ET.

Several touching tributes to Bush have emerged since his death, including an editorial cartoon depicting him reuniting in heaven with his beloved wife and the daughter they lost at a young age. The cartoon went viral, bringing tears to many eyes.

Bush, a war hero, Congressman from Texas, US Ambassador to the United Nations, Republican National Committee Chairman, Director of the CIA, Vice President, and President, will be remembered for his extensive record of public service. A handwritten note he wrote to his successor, Bill Clinton, on Inaugural Day 1993, expressing well-wishes, has also circulated online.

Title: "Republican Leadership Embraces Counter-Punch Tactics in Kavanaugh Confirmation Process"

Article:

In a historic turn of events, the United States Senate has confirmed Brett Kavanaugh as the 114th Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. The confirmation process, marked by allegations of sexual assault, has been a significant display of political maneuvering and counter-punch tactics.

Democrats, led by Senator Diane Feinstein (D-CA), attempted to delay the confirmation process, but their efforts were unsuccessful. The party, in an attempt to discredit Kavanaugh, promoted a leaked letter alleging sexual assault against Christine Ford in 1982. However, the accuser's four witnesses could not corroborate her story, leading to the fall of the allegations.

The Democratic Party's strategy was met with resistance, as the FBI conducted an investigation, but it concluded within days with no new evidence. The process was widely criticized, with many viewing it as a national disgrace orchestrated by the left.

President Trump, known for his counter-punching style, expressed admiration for Kavanaugh's defense and defiance during his testimony before the Judiciary Committee. Trump's approach, which was initially met with criticism, seems to have influenced Republican leadership, who have adopted a more assertive stance in response to Democratic Party attacks.

Senator Orrin Hatch (R-UT) was verbally attacked by anti-Kavanaugh protestors in the Senate building, a response that was met with a wave of his hand and a comment about being ready for them when they grow up. Similarly, Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Chuck Grassley (R-IA), criticized the media for their bias against Kavanaugh, citing instances where pro-Kavanaugh individuals were denied interviews while the media focused on those opposed to the nominee.

The confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh marks a significant victory for President Trump, demonstrating the effectiveness of his counter-punch tactics and the newfound assertiveness of Republican leadership in the face of Democratic Party attacks.

Title: Protesters Demand End to Racial Profiling by Police in Washington D.C.

Article:

Protesters, rallying under the banner of "Justice for All," will gather in Washington D.C. on Saturday, aiming to pressure federal authorities to address racial profiling by police and enact legislation to protect citizens from state grand jury decisions. The march, organized by civil rights leader Rev. Al Sharpton, will bring together the families of Eric Garner and Michael Brown, two black men whose deaths at the hands of police have sparked nationwide protests.

In a statement, NAACP President and CEO Cornell William Brooks expressed the purpose of the march, stating, "This march is one of many demonstrations to show Congress, the country, and the world that we will not stand down until systemic change, accountability, and justice in cases of police misconduct are served."

The march will commence with a rally at Freedom Plaza, located just a block from the White House. The event will honor the memory of Eric Garner, who died in July after police attempted to arrest him for selling loose cigarettes on Staten Island, and Michael Brown, who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri. Grand juries in both cases declined to indict the white officers involved.

Rev. Sharpton, addressing a crowd in anticipation of the march, asked, "Why are we going to Washington?" He continued, "Because all over the country we all need to come together and demand this Congress deal with the issues, that we need laws to protect the citizens in these states from these state grand jurors."

A recent poll by the Pew Research Center found that 57% of Americans believed a New York City grand jury should have indicted police officer Daniel Pantaleo in the death of Garner, who was seen in a cell phone video with his arms around Garner's neck, and could be heard gasping, "I can't breathe." The grand jury's decision in Staten Island led to protests in New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco, and Atlanta. On Thursday, congressional aides in Washington walked off their jobs in protest.

Gwen Carr, Garner's mother, expressed her support for the upcoming march, stating, "I am so proud that everybody is doing what they have just done. Keep on doing it but just do it in peace." The mother of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, who was shot and killed by police last month, will also attend the event. In that incident, a 911 caller told dispatchers a gun Tamir was pointing at people outside a recreation center in Cleveland, Ohio, was likely not real. Police said Tamir had an airsoft gun, which shot pellets but resembled a semi-automatic pistol, and did not follow orders to put his hands up.

The protests, which began in Ferguson, Missouri, were ignited by demonstrations following a grand jury's decision not to indict officer Darren Wilson in the August shooting death of Michael Brown. In Ferguson, demonstrators burned buildings, looted stores, and smashed police cars.

Title: Democrats Restore References to God and Jerusalem in Platform Amid Controversy

Article:

Democrats have reinstated references to God and Jerusalem as Israel's capital in their official party platform following a contentious floor fight at their convention on Wednesday. The debate, marked by shouts and boos, has sparked criticism and raised questions about party unity and the Democrats' stance on religion and Israel.

The platform committee head, former Ohio Governor Ted Strickland, initially described the move as a "clarification" rather than an "error." However, President Obama's deputy campaign manager, Stephanie Cutter, contradicted this in an interview with a media outlet, stating that Obama personally intervened to restore the references.

Rashida Tlaib, a member of the Michigan delegation and the state's House of Representatives, criticized the process, calling it "irresponsible" and "wrong." She argued that the party did not have the votes to change the language and was "shammed."

The visuals from the floor, showing delegates shouting down the convention chairman as he called the vote, are likely to be used by Republicans to portray Democrats as hostile to religion and Israel. The Republican campaign used the scene to question the party's unity, stating, "After yesterday's convention floor fight over Jerusalem as Israel's capital and the mention of God in the platform, it's pretty hard to call this 'a unified party.'"

Rep. Sander Levin (D-Mich.) pushed for the restoration of the Jerusalem language, stating he had spoken to several people close to the president without specifying whether he spoke to the president himself.

The battle marked the biggest platform fight in either party's convention so far and signaled Democrats' concerns that the prior language could have been politically damaging in a tight election year.

The change in the section referencing God effectively restored language that had been in the 2008 platform. The updated text now reads: "We need a government that stands up for the hopes, values, and interests of working people, and gives everyone willing to work hard the chance to make the most of their God-given potential."

The initial 2012 platform language stated: "We gather to reclaim the basic bargain that built the largest middle class and the most prosperous nation on Earth -- the simple principle that in America, hard work should pay off, responsibility should be rewarded, and each one of us should be able to go as far as our talent and drive take us."

The change came after both Mitt Romney and GOP running mate Paul Ryan criticized the omission. Romney described the omission as the "party veering further and further away into an extreme wing that Americans do not recognize."

Democrats also reinstated a section stating that Jerusalem "is and will remain the capital of Israel. The parties have agreed that Jerusalem is a matter for final status negotiations. It should remain an undivided city accessible to people of all faiths." This is consistent with Obama's personal stance, though the administration's stance is for the status to be worked out between the Israelis and Palestinians.

Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz stated that the changes were made "to maintain consistency with the personal views expressed by the president and in the Democratic Party platform in 2008." She noted that administrations of both parties have said the status of Jerusalem should be negotiated by the Israelis and Palestinians.

Title: Trump and Obama Dispute Credit for Economic Growth

Article:

In a series of tweets on Presidents' Day, former President Barack Obama touted his role in the current economic boom, while President Donald Trump responded by accusing his predecessor of attempting to claim credit for the economic achievements of the Trump Administration.

On Monday, Mr. Obama tweeted, "Eleven years ago today, near the bottom of the worst recession in generations, I signed the Recovery Act, paving the way for more than a decade of economic growth and the longest streak of job creation in American history."

President Trump responded Monday evening, accusing Mr. Obama of "trying to take credit" for the economic boom under his administration.

"Did you hear the latest con job?" the president tweeted. "President Obama is now trying to take credit for the Economic Boom taking place under the Trump Administration. He had the WEAKEST recovery since the Great Depression, despite Zero Fed Rate & MASSIVE quantitative easing."

The president continued, "NOW, best jobs numbers ever, Had to rebuild our military, which was totally depleted. Fed Rate UP, taxes and regulations WAY DOWN. If Dems won in 2016, the USA would be in big economic (Depression?) & military trouble right now. THE BEST IS YET TO COME. KEEP AMERICA GREAT!"

The Trump campaign also issued a statement criticizing Mr. Obama's tweet, stating that Mr. Trump "reversed the floundering Obama/Biden economy" following "the worst economic recovery in modern history."

"By contrast, though, deregulating, lowering taxes, and supporting free-market policies, President Trump has created the hottest economy on record, with unemployment hitting generational lows and all-time lows for African Americans, Hispanics, the disabled, veterans, and many other hard-working Americans," Trump campaign national press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said, according to Fox News.

"Paychecks are growing at the fastest pace in a decade and twice as fast for low- and middle-income Americans," she continued. "It's no wonder Democrats seek to take credit for the Trump economy after eight years of betraying blue-collar workers and inflicting pain upon the middle class as Americans everywhere suffered. But the failed days of Democrat stagnation are over, and the soaring Trump economy is here to stay."

Title: Senate Democrats Approve Budget After Late-Night Vote, Facing Internal Disagreements

Article:

Senate Democrats passed their first budget in four years early Saturday morning, but the vote was close, with a 50-49 margin. The budget proposal, which underwent a marathon session of amendments, exposed internal divisions among Democrats, particularly among lawmakers facing re-election who criticized the plan's failure to address the deficit.

Sen. Mark Begich, a moderate Democrat from Alaska, was among those who opposed the Senate's plan due to its high deficit. "While I am happy that Congress is finally talking seriously about our fiscal crisis, this budget did not go far enough," Begich said. "Alaskans expect us to finish the job and make this staggering deficit manageable. Passing this problem off to our children is not an option."

The Democratic budget includes $975 billion in new taxes, matched by an equal amount of spending reductions primarily from health programs, defense, and reduced interest payments as deficits decrease more than previously anticipated. The deficit over the next decade never dips below $400 billion and would hover at or near $600 billion by 2023. This would add $7.3 trillion to the national debt over that period, according to Republican Sen. Jeff Sessions.

House Republicans also faced defections, with ten Republicans opposing House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan's 2014 plan earlier this week. However, the Republicans' budget resolution passed with a more comfortable margin in the House than the Democrats' did in the Senate. The four Senate Democrats who voted against the Democrats' bill were Kay Hagan, D-N.C.; Max Baucus, D-Mont.; Mark Pryor, D-Ark.; and Begich.

President Obama is expected to release his own 2014 budget next month, which will be closely watched for signs of engagement with Republicans in negotiations or a more confrontational approach. The Democratic and Republican plans will not clear Congress in their current form and are merely blueprints that do not appropriate money.

Democrats and Republicans will now enter into hard bargaining, making sacrifices if they are to settle on a bona fide budget rather than passing stopgap spending bills to fund the government year after year. The White House reiterated its displeasure with the House Republican plan, which does not call for tax hikes on the wealthy.

Title: Apple Challenges Court Order to Assist FBI in Breaking into Encrypted iPhone

Article:

Apple has announced its intention to contest a federal magistrate's order compelling the tech giant to help the U.S. government access data on an encrypted iPhone belonging to one of the shooters involved in the deadly December 2015 San Bernardino terror attack. In a statement published on Apple's website, CEO Tim Cook expressed concerns about the implications of the order, stating that it has far-reaching consequences beyond the immediate case.

In the statement, Cook acknowledged the FBI's good intentions but expressed concern about the government's request to create a "backdoor" to the iPhone. He stated, "We have great respect for the professionals at the FBI, and we believe their intentions are good. Up to this point, we have done everything that is both within our power and within the law to help them. But now the U.S. government has asked us for something we simply do not have, and something we consider too dangerous to create."

The order, issued by U.S. Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym, marks a significant victory for the Justice Department in a technology policy debate that pits digital privacy against national security interests. A federal agent involved in the San Bernardino terror investigation told Fox News that the phone's carrier, Verizon, would not be able to provide authorities with the necessary information.

FBI Director James Comey told members of Congress last week that encryption is a major problem for law enforcement who "find a device that cannot be opened even when a judge says there is probable cause to open it." The ruling on Tuesday is linked to the deadliest terrorist attack on U.S. soil since the 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Syed Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, killed 14 people in a December 2 shooting at a holiday luncheon for Farook's co-workers. The couple later died in a gun battle with police.

Federal prosecutors told the judge in Tuesday's court proceeding that investigators cannot access a work phone used by Farook because they do not know his passcode and Apple has not cooperated. Under U.S. law, a work phone is generally the property of a person's employer. The judge told Apple to provide an estimate of its cost to comply with her order, suggesting that the government will be expected to pay for the work.

In his statement, Cook said, "This moment calls for public discussion, and we want our customers and people around the country to understand what is at stake." Apple has provided default encryption on its iPhones since 2014, allowing any device's contents to be accessed only by the user who knows the phone's passcode. Previously, the company could use an extraction tool that would physically plug into the phone and allow it to respond to search warrant requests from the government.

The ruling by Pym requires Apple to supply highly specialized software the FBI can load onto the county-owned work iPhone to bypass a self-destruct feature, which erases the phone's data after too many unsuccessful attempts to unlock it. The FBI wants to be able to try different combinations in rapid sequence until it finds the right one.

It is not immediately clear what investigators believe they might find on Farook's work phone or why the information would not be available from third-party service providers, such as Google or Facebook. Investigators think the device may hold clues about whom the couple communicated with and where they may have traveled.

Farook was not carrying his work iPhone during the attack. It was discovered after a subsequent search. It was not known whether Farook forgot about the iPhone or did not care whether investigators found it. The phone was running the newest version of Apple's iPhone operating system, which requires a passcode and cannot be accessed by Apple, unlike earlier operating systems or older phone models. San Bernardino County provided Farook with an iPhone configured to erase data after 10 consecutive unsuccessful unlocking attempts. The FBI said that feature appeared to be active on Farook's iPhone as of the last time he performed a backup.

The judge did not spell out her rationale in her three-page order, but the ruling comes amid a similar case in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York. Investigators are still working to piece together a missing 18 minutes in Farook and Malik's timeline from December 2. Investigators have concluded they were at least partly inspired by the Islamic State group; Malik's Facebook page included a note pledging allegiance to the group's leader around the time of the attack.

Title: Presidential Candidates' Responses to Orlando Shooting Contrast in Tone and Approach

Article:

In the aftermath of the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history, presumptive presidential nominees Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton offered contrasting responses, each reflecting their distinct political stances and approaches to addressing terrorism and gun violence.

As details about the motive behind the early morning rampage at a gay nightclub in Orlando remained unclear, both candidates began to weigh in. By the end of the day, authorities were still investigating the circumstances that led Omar Mateen, a 29-year-old American citizen from Florida, to open fire, killing 50 people and critically wounding dozens more.

Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, expressed his condolences on Twitter, stating, "When will we get tough, smart & vigilant?" Later, he took credit for his stance on radical Islamic terrorism, saying he appreciated the congratulations for being right on the issue. In a more provocative response, Trump suggested that President Barack Obama should step down, a statement that exceeded typical Republican criticism of Obama's approach to extremism.

Trump's comments, while often criticized for being jarring and crass, have resonated with some voters who believe Obama has been constrained in his response to terror threats due to political correctness. "We can't afford to be politically correct anymore," Trump declared on Sunday. He canceled a rally scheduled for Monday but planned to proceed with a speech in New Hampshire, shifting the focus from his case against Clinton to national security.

Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, adopted a more measured tone in her initial comments. She also made her first remarks on Twitter, writing, "As we wait for more information, my thoughts are with those affected by this horrific act." Like Obama, Clinton tends to avoid early missteps, even if it leaves her appearing overly cautious. On Sunday, she waited for the president to declare the shooting an "act of terror" before doing the same.

Clinton and Obama postponed plans to campaign together in Wisconsin, a decision driven by both political considerations and the expectation that the president would need to oversee the government's response to the shooting. Clinton, however, planned to continue with solo campaign stops in Ohio on Monday and in Pennsylvania on Tuesday.

Clinton did not shy away from the possibility of a link to international terrorism in her statement, though she used vague language. She has made stricter gun control legislation a central theme of her presidential campaign and was more direct in raising the shooting as an example of the nation's failure to keep guns "out of the hands of terrorists or other violent criminals." Federal authorities later confirmed that Mateen had purchased at least two firearms legally within the last week or so.

The ultimate impact of the Orlando shooting on the trajectory of the general election campaign remains uncertain. If current trends hold, there may be more deadly mass shootings in the U.S. before voters head to the polls in November. Other unforeseen events will likely also shape the race over the next five months, as the 2008 economic collapse did in the closing weeks of that year's presidential campaign.

However, as voters begin to seriously consider Clinton and Trump as their next commander in chief, Sunday's shooting left little doubt that the choice between the two candidates is stark.

Title: Obama Anticipates Immigration Bill on Senate Floor Next Month, Discusses Upcoming Trips to Mexico and Costa Rica

Article:

U.S. President Barack Obama expressed optimism about the upcoming immigration reform in interviews with two major Spanish-language broadcast television networks, Telemundo and Univision, on Wednesday. According to Obama, a group of lawmakers are close to finalizing the details of their proposal, and he expects a bill to be ready for the Senate floor next month.

In the interviews, conducted in English and aired in dubbed Spanish, Obama stated, "My expectation is we'll see a bill on the floor of the Senate next month." He also expressed confidence that, if a bill is introduced in April, it can be passed before the end of the summer.

However, the president acknowledged that one key issue still needs to be resolved: the construction of a guest worker program for the future. The senators are reportedly debating details such as the wages for low-skilled guest workers and the annual number of workers allowed into the country.

The eight senators, four Democrats and four Republicans, who released the framework for their plan in January, are said to be confident that they will unveil the highly anticipated immigration bill early in the week of April 8, when Congress returns to work.

Regarding concerns that the debate over guest workers might derail reform efforts, Obama told Telemundo, "I disagree that it's threatening to doom the legislation... I think there is commitment among this group of Democratic and Republican senators to get this done."

In addition to discussing immigration reform, Obama also touched on his upcoming trips to Mexico and Costa Rica. He stated, "I'm really looking forward to the opportunity to visit Mexico. I'm going to be there in early May." He emphasized that the relationship between the U.S. and Latin American countries is not limited to border issues or drug cartels, but also encompasses commerce, trade, and energy.

Title: Rep. Eric Swalwell Continues to Claim Trump-Russia Collusion Despite Mueller Report

Article:

Representative Eric Swalwell (D-CA) has continued to assert that there was collusion between President Trump's campaign and Russia during the 2016 election, despite the recent release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report that found no such collusion.

During an interview on Fox News, Swalwell was asked about the debunked Steele dossier, a document that was largely unverified and has been discredited. Swalwell maintained that nothing in the dossier had been disproven. This assertion was met with disbelief by Fox News host Martha MacCallum, who asked, "Are you serious?"

In a separate interview on MSNBC, Swalwell stated that he is ready for President Trump to sue him if he continues to assert that there was collusion. Swalwell also claimed that the only person who has made false statements about Russia is Donald Trump.

Representative Devin Nunes (R-CA), who was chair of the House Intelligence Committee, was on Fox after Swalwell's interview and criticized his Democratic colleague for his continued focus on the Russia collusion narrative. Nunes suggested that Swalwell should have used his interview to discuss other issues, as over 2,500 subpoenas were issued and 500 witnesses were interviewed during the investigation, and there was no evidence of Trump-Russia collusion.

Swalwell is not alone in his continued focus on the Russia collusion narrative. Many members of the Democratic Party and their allies in the media have been criticized for their obsession with the issue, even after the Mueller report's summary all but torpedoed the dossier's credibility.

UPDATE: During an interview with Chris Matthews, Swalwell still maintained that Trump is a Russian agent.

Title: Trump's Border Wall Promise Faces Skepticism as Funding Negotiations Stall

Article:

During the 2016 presidential campaign, candidates often make promises to win voter support. One such promise, made by Donald Trump, was the construction of a wall on the southern border to stop illegal immigration. However, the likelihood of this promise being fulfilled is becoming increasingly uncertain.

In a recent interview, conservative commentator and early Trump supporter Ann Coulter expressed her disillusionment with President Trump's commitment to the border wall. Coulter, who wrote the book "In Trump We Trust" and whose book "Adios, America" informed the Trump campaign's immigration policy, stated that she would not vote for Trump's reelection in 2020 if the wall is not built.

The border wall was a key issue during the government shutdown negotiations last week. Trump had demanded $5 billion for border wall construction, and threatened a government shutdown if the funding was not provided. However, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, in an interview with Fox News, seemed to indicate a willingness to compromise on the $5 billion demand, suggesting a potential shift of funds from other sources for wall construction.

Coulter's stance is a reflection of the growing skepticism among Trump's supporters regarding his commitment to the border wall. Without the wall, Coulter stated, "Trump will just have been a joke presidency who scammed the American people, amused the populists for a while, but he’ll have no legacy whatsoever."

The border wall was a central campaign promise for Trump, and its lack of progress has raised concerns among his supporters. The threat of a government shutdown was the only leverage the White House had to force Democrats to go on record opposing the wall. However, it appears that the White House may have given up this leverage without a fight.

With Democrats set to take control of the House in January, there is little chance of securing funding for the border wall in the near future. If the White House does not make the border wall a priority, it is unlikely to be built. And if Ann Coulter's assessment is correct, Trump may not have another opportunity to fulfill this campaign promise.

Title: Migrant Caravan Seeking Asylum in US Halted at Mexico-US Border

Article:

Dozens of migrants traveling in a caravan to seek asylum in the United States have been stopped at the border near San Diego, according to US border officials. Approximately 150 people, many traveling with children, were informed that the border crossing was full. The status of the Central American migrants, whether they will be allowed in later or turned back, remains uncertain, but the group appears to be staying put.

President Donald Trump has labeled the caravan a threat to the safety of the US. The group has been a frequent target for the US president, who has argued in his tweets that it demonstrates the need to tighten immigration laws.

The caravan set off for the US on March 25 in southern Mexico, near the Guatemala border, and at one point numbered more than 1,000 people. The group traveled by bus, train, and on foot during its 2,000-mile (3,200km) trek to the US border, with many stating they were fleeing persecution and violence in their home countries.

As of now, no members of the group have been processed by the US Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) at the San Ysidro crossing. Some members were allowed to cross a long bridge that led to US processing buildings but had to stop outside. In a statement, CBP Commissioner Kevin McAleenan said, "we have reached capacity at the San Ysidro port of entry."

Under US immigration law, inspectors have the power to quickly deport individuals who do not have the proper travel or visa documents at the time that they request entry or if the inspector believes that the person requesting entry has committed fraud or misrepresented the truth. However, if an individual expresses a fear of return to his or her home country, they will not be immediately deported but instead be detained until they undergo a "credible fear interview."

The aim of the interview is for the asylum officer to try to establish if the asylum request is based on a fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political beliefs, or membership of a particular group. If the officer finds that the individual has a chance of proving fear of persecution, the applicant is referred to a judge.

The patience of the many children among the migrants was striking, although perhaps weariness was the real explanation. One little girl stood quietly as a woman fixed the child's hair for an interview at the border, which could determine the direction of her life. A small boy in an oversized checked coat sucked his fingers and gazed around at the crowd as he sat on a man's shoulders.

Constructing a "big, beautiful wall" along the Mexican border was a signature campaign promise for Mr. Trump, but so far, the plan to erect a new physical barrier has been thwarted by lawmakers and appears to have stalled. A major government spending bill which he signed last month included $1.2bn for the border wall - far short of the $25bn the White House sought. And there were strings attached to the funding Congress did approve. Most of it can only be used to repair stretches of the border where there already is a wall, not to build new segments.

Last month, the Pentagon confirmed Mr. Trump had held "initial" talks with Defense Secretary James Mattis about using some of the Pentagon's budget for constructing a wall. However, Democratic Senators Dick Durbin and Jack Reed wrote to the defense secretary on Monday saying his department had "no legal authority" to use its funds for such a purpose.

In December, US Border Patrol announced arrests at the southern border had fallen to their lowest level since 1971, apparently indicating that fewer people were attempting the crossing.

Title: Trump Campaign Advisers Criticize Candidate's Debate Performance, Express Concern for Second Debate Preparation

Article:

Donald Trump's advisers have reportedly criticized his performance during the first presidential debate, with some describing it as "erratic" and expressing concern for his preparation for the upcoming debate in St. Louis. According to a report by The New York Times, campaign aides and advisers, who spoke anonymously to the media, were frustrated and discouraged by Trump's performance during the debate.

The sources reportedly criticized Trump for stopping his attacks on Hillary Clinton on trade and character issues and instead growing erratic, impatient, and subdued as the night went on. The advisers also expressed concern that Trump was not meticulously prepared for the debate, with some suggesting that there were too many people in the room during the preparation sessions, and that the team had not agreed internally on the best strategies.

The report also mentioned that Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell, who are not unabashed Trump fans, provided debate advice by phone. The advisers are reportedly using the press to send a message to Trump that he needs to change his approach for the second debate.

Trump's supporters have expressed anger over the media coverage portraying him as having lost the debate, according to Twitter feedback. However, a story in which some of Trump's own advisers are anonymously quoted as saying he was "erratic" in a debate watched by 84 million people does not help the cause.

The report comes as Trump is in an extremely competitive race against Clinton and could potentially win the presidency. The campaign advisers plan to more rigorously prepare Trump for the next debate, but there is concern about whether he will be open to practicing meticulously.

The report also mentions a separate issue involving former Democratic National Committee Chair Howard Dean, who suggested that Trump might have a cocaine problem. Dean's comments have been criticized as smear merchandising, and MSNBC's Joe Scarborough has called on Dean to apologize.

Finally, the article also mentions a testimony by a former Chris Christie ally, David Wildstein, who claimed that Christie laughed when Wildstein told him the George Washington Bridge lanes were being closed as an act of political retaliation. The former presidential candidate has denied the allegations.

Title: California Golf Course Conserves Water Through Innovative Methods

 Article:

 In the drought-stricken state of California, the golf industry, with an estimated value of $6 billion and nearly 130,000 employees, is often criticized for watering vast expanses of grass while residents are urged to reduce their water usage and farmers struggle with depleted wells. However, some golf courses, such as The Resort At Pelican Hill in Newport Coast, south of Los Angeles, are taking steps to conserve water.

 Stephen Friedlander, vice president of golf at Pelican Hill, explains their water conservation efforts: "When people say, 'Well, that golf course is watering their grass,' if they are talking about Pelican Hill, yes we are, and we're using reclaimed water. And we're using reclaimed water in a very specific, measured way."

 Pelican Hill differentiates itself by using warm-season Bermuda grass, which requires less water and grows slower, in a large, 10-acre area. In non-playing areas, the course uses native bushes that do not require water. Despite the course's upscale image, Friedlander assures that players paying over $300 for a round should not notice any differences in the greens and fairways due to the course's advanced irrigation system.

 The irrigation system allows course managers to monitor and control irrigation from their smartphones, enabling them to water specific areas without overwatering others. Pelican Hill claims to save 50 million gallons of water each year through these measures, using recycled water.

 Another unique aspect of Pelican Hill's water conservation is the capture and use of rainwater. Rain that falls on buildings, pavement, and cart paths is collected in course reservoirs, which also serve as the course's major water features. Underground, there are giant cisterns that hold millions of gallons of runoff water from the course.

 "As it turns out, because our cistern system and the lake systems are so large, ever since the work was done, no stormwater has left the golf course," says Sat Tamaribuchi, who designed the course's conservation system.

 Steve Friedlander, a golf pro at Pelican Hill, acknowledges that a golf course in a wealthy town like Newport Coast has a strong incentive to save water.
