However, the article warns that this spending, while it may stimulate growth in the short term, could lead to a further enlargement of the national debt and a greater burden on future generations. The article suggests that this approach, while politically appealing, is not the responsible way forward.

Title: Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts Shifts Role as Swing Vote in Recent Decisions

Article:

Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts' role as the court's new swing vote has become increasingly apparent in recent weeks, as he has been the deciding justice in several high-profile 5-4 decisions. In Monday's decision in June Medical Services v. Russo, Roberts sided with the liberal members to rule against a Louisiana law restricting who can perform abortions, upholding precedent from a similar case in 2016 in which he was on the other side. This followed his vote in rejecting the Trump administration's attempt to rescind DACA and his vote in a 6-3 decision that prohibited employment discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.

In a recent school choice case, Roberts sided with the conservatives, delivering a win for the school choice movement on Tuesday. However, Monday's decision in June Medical Services v. Russo marked a significant victory for reproductive rights, as the Supreme Court confirmed the decision to get an abortion as a constitutional right.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., called the decision a "major victory for reproductive rights," while Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, observed a similar trend in Roberts' decisions but was less enthusiastic about it. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., celebrated Monday's ruling while pointing out that it went against Republican political preferences.

Roberts' history of separating himself from the court's conservative contingent in key cases goes back years. In 2012, by siding with the liberal wing and reinterpreting an individual mandate as a tax, he allowed ObamaCare to be found constitutional. Additionally, last year he joined with liberals again in shutting down the Trump administration's efforts to add a citizenship question to the census.

President Trump called the recent decisions "shotgun blasts into the face of people that are proud to call themselves Republicans or Conservatives." Trump indicated that he was not confident in the current makeup of the court, despite the majority of justices being Republican appointees.

Justices Anthony Kennedy and Sandra Day O'Connor, both recent examples of swing vote justices, were appointed by President Ronald Reagan. Justice David Souter, who was chosen by President George H.W. Bush, often sided with the court's liberal contingent. In 1992's landmark Planned Parenthood v. Casey, the Supreme Court upheld the right to an abortion in a 5-4 decision. All five majority votes – O'Connor, Kennedy, Souter, John Paul Stevens, and Harry Blackmun -- were appointed by Republicans.

Despite the attention to Roberts' recent left-leaning votes, he has on many occasions remained with conservatives in 5-4 decisions. According to statistics compiled by SCOTUSBlog, the court's October 2018 term featured 17 cases that resulted in 5-4 decisions where all four liberal justices voted together. Of these, Roberts turned out to be a deciding vote in 10 of them, sticking with his fellow conservatives seven times and voting with liberal justices three times.

The Supreme Court still has nearly a dozen cases left to decide this term, with several having significant political implications. Their issues include whether states can force members of the Electoral College to vote in accordance with the state's popular vote, and whether President Trump's tax returns can be released to House committees or Manhattan prosecutors.

Title: Worldwide Threats to Free Speech Amidst the Coronavirus Crisis

Article:

In the midst of the global coronavirus pandemic, liberal democratic institutions and values are under threat from potential authoritarian power grabs, often referred to as "corona coups." One of the first casualties, as history has shown, is freedom of speech. This current attack on free speech, however, is particularly dangerous as it not only targets "fake news" related to the coronavirus, but also criticism of inadequacies in hospitals by healthcare workers.

The term "fake news" gained prominence during the 2016 U.S. presidential elections, leading to a surge in concern and pressure on social media platforms to "fight fake news." Despite the ongoing debate about the actual impact of "fake news" and "Russian interference," many mainstream politicians attribute their loss of votes and power to populists to the spread of such misinformation.

Recent calls for the suppression of "fake news" have intensified with the coronavirus crisis, providing an opportunity for populist leaders to pass draconian new laws under the guise of preventing misinformation. One of the most extreme examples comes from Hungary, where the parliament, without facing an actual emergency, has passed "emergency measures" to grant far-right Prime Minister Viktor Orbán "dictatorial powers." Under these measures, anything deemed "fake news" is punishable by up to five years in prison, effectively silencing independent media in Hungary.

Another concerning development is the suppression of free speech from healthcare workers on the frontlines of the coronavirus fight. These individuals are best informed about the situation and could potentially counteract fake news. However, in some countries, including the UK and the U.S., healthcare workers are being silenced over issues such as protective equipment shortages. In the U.S., private hospitals are prioritizing their brand and profits over the health of their patients and staff, threatening termination for those who speak out about the lack of protective gear.

Censoring healthcare professionals is not only a violation of free speech but also poses a danger to the broader community. These individuals risk their lives daily to help others, particularly if their employers do not provide them with adequate protective gear.

The irony lies in the fact that some of the same politicians who support or allow the censorship of healthcare professionals in their own countries have been vocal critics of China's approach. For instance, British cabinet minister Michael Gove and U.S. Representative Michael McCaul have accused China of failing to stop the spread of coronavirus and of orchestrating one of the worst cover-ups in history, respectively.

To avoid repeating the mistakes made in China and to protect the health and lives of healthcare workers, it is crucial to resist these attacks on free speech and unnecessary authoritarian measures during the coronavirus crisis. Free speech not only makes us safer as citizens but also as patients, even during a health crisis.

Title: Texas Senator Ted Cruz Announces Early Presidential Campaign

Article:

Texas Senator Ted Cruz has officially announced his candidacy for the 2016 U.S. Presidential election, making him the first major candidate to declare his intention to run. The announcement, made via a midnight tweet and video, comes earlier than most presidential candidates' unofficial spring costume declarations, a move that aligns with Cruz's bold and unconventional political style.

Cruz, who has been a controversial figure in the Republican party since his 2012 Senate campaign, has not been a frontrunner in the party's 2016 discussions. However, he maintains an undeniable appeal to the party's base voters, who are influential in primary elections, particularly in red states.

There are at least five reasons for Cruz to make his move as the first major candidate, according to political analysts.

1. Cutting through the noise and confusion created by the expanding GOP field: Cruz's early announcement aims to give the media a relatively fresh face to focus on, helping him stand out amidst the growing list of potential candidates.

2. Raising funds: Cruz's campaign faces a significant challenge in fundraising. By launching a full-fledged campaign early, Cruz can begin actively soliciting donations, particularly from his home state of Texas, which is a significant source of political funding.

3. Skipping the exploratory committee phase: Cruz's decision to forego the exploratory committee phase eliminates the usual pre-campaign formalities, positioning his bid as more serious and reinforcing his image as a straightforward candidate.

4. Bolstering his bid for the conservative activists' support: Cruz's early announcement serves to establish himself as a leader among the party's conservative activists, helping him stand out from other potential candidates vying for the same support.

5. Maximizing media exposure: Cruz's early announcement allows him to test the political market and maximize his media exposure, even if not all attention is positive. Cruz thrives on controversy and uses it to bolster his image as a crusader for conservative causes.

The presidential nominating game, it is said, has two winners: the presidential nominee and the running mate. Cruz's early announcement may serve to discourage some of his natural rivals on the right and eclipse some of the lesser-known candidates. Even if Cruz's candidacy does not succeed, the early announcement ensures he will have had 10 months of formal candidacy, providing ample opportunity to test the political market and maximize media exposure.

Title: "The Importance of Nuanced Political Discourse in a Divided America"

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent election, philosopher Alasdair MacIntyre's description of modern politics as "civil war carried on by other means" resonates deeply. The United States continues to grapple with political disagreements, but the question looming in the background is whether the nation will maintain a "modest unity" or slip into a darker period of division.

The nature of Donald Trump's campaign and the subsequent reaction to him have raised the stakes. Some reactions include cathartic rants, insisting "there's no such thing as a good Trump voter," and equating critiques of identity politics with endorsements of white nationalism. As the less qualified person ever to hold the presidency, Trump's erratic Twitter diplomacy, sensitive reactions to late-night comedy, and undisciplined remarks have raised concerns about his judgment and temperament.

However, some failures weaken political power and sideline political agendas, while others result in international crises and catastrophic loss of life. Insisting "he's not my president" and excoriating anyone willing to work for him puts the nation on a path toward the wrong kind of failure.

Instead of simply blaming others or pledging unqualified resistance, those uncomfortable with the state of the country and the prospects of a Trump administration might first look inward. Rather than denouncing this impending presidency out of hand, we could begin by asking concretely and individually how we should become more engaged in our politics.

For some of us, this will involve voicing dissent and monitoring from afar. For others, it will involve risky partnerships with those ascending to power. All of us could stand to extend a little grace to those who pursue either dissent or partnership for the sake of maintaining our modest unity. Those focused on dissent might recognize prudential limits to their posture, forgoing absolute resistance to publicly support sensible nominees who do not share all of their politics but who will help govern effectively.

Moreover, it is essential to remember that not all political opponents are the face of evil, the belly of racism, or the pit of depravity. Critics of Trump rightly denounced his caricatures of "the blacks" and his unconscionable flirtation with a "Muslim registry." However, we should also question the elitist rage now targeting and demonizing "working-class whites" or "white evangelicals," as though the responsibility for the fate of the country now rests solely with some category of people constructed by exit polls.

Anyone still confident that "those people" are the proximate cause of Trump's victory might think more carefully about the 28% of Latino voters or the 13% of black male voters who cast their ballots for Trump. Or spend a few minutes reading interviews with Trump voters. Resist the urge to read only those stories that confirm your priors, and you'll encounter gay Millennial women, Muslim immigrants, and disabled veterans who voted for him. This election, like all elections, is a complicated story.

The more we neglect political nuance and the more we simply blame "those people" for the current state of affairs, the less likely we are to see in others a shared humanity, to say nothing of a shared project of self-governance. For the sake of our modest unity, we can do better. We must do better.

We must remind ourselves that people—and voters—are more complex than labels. We must speak, write, and tweet with care, depth, and nuance. We must avoid the lazy thinking that encourages stereotyping. We might also try to listen to what "those people" have to say. Too often, we expect them to hear what we have to say without bothering to return the favor.

Along the way, we might come to see that "those people" are "our people," too. And that politics, as MacIntyre reminds us, is still far preferable to the alternative. John Inazu, the Sally D. Danforth Distinguished Professor of Law and Religion at Washington University in St. Louis, is the author of "Confident Pluralism: Surviving and Thriving Through Deep Difference."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Seeks Full Scope of Mueller's Russia Investigation Document from Justice Department

Article:

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley, an Iowa Republican, has requested the Justice Department to provide a document detailing the full scope of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. In a letter sent to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein on May 18, Grassley stated that the special counsel's team recently provided an unredacted copy of the memo, which Rosenstein wrote on Aug. 2, 2017, to Paul Manafort, President Donald Trump's former campaign chairman who was indicted for bank and tax fraud related to his work in Ukraine.

Grassley argued that Congress, like the Judiciary, is a separate branch of government with its own constitutional duties that often require access to Executive Branch information. He stated that the interests of the committee relate to both legislative and oversight responsibilities.

Mueller's team has argued that he did not have the jurisdiction to investigate areas not related to possible collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russian government. Manafort's lawyers have also questioned the timing of the memo, which Rosenstein wrote nearly three months after Mueller was appointed special counsel.

Grassley also expressed interest in the timing of the Rosenstein memo, asking, "The August Memorandum states that it addresses the special counsel's authorization as of the date he was appointed. Why was this memorandum not drafted until August 2017?"

Grassley has been a supporter of the Mueller investigation, and he has publicly warned President Trump against taking steps to shut down the investigation or fire Mueller. He stated, "As I have said numerous times, that investigation should be free to follow the facts wherever they lead without any improper outside interference. However, that does not mean that it is immune from oversight or that information about the scope of its authority under existing Department regulations should be withheld from Congress."

Title: Crowdfunding Campaign Raises Over $3 Million to Oppose Sen. Susan Collins in 2020 Election

Article:

In the aftermath of Sen. Susan Collins' announcement that she would vote "yes" on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, a crowdfunding campaign has raised over $3 million to support her opponent in the 2020 election. The campaign, initiated by three activist groups, including Be A Hero Team, Maine People's Alliance, and Mainers for Accountable Leadership, has been criticized for potentially attempting to bribe Collins into voting against Kavanaugh.

The donation page, titled "Either Sen. Collins VOTES NO on Kavanaugh OR we fund her future opponent," went down briefly on crowdfunding website crowdpac.com Friday afternoon due to "overwhelming" traffic. The groups are also raising money on the website ActBlue and claim that donations are coming in every three seconds.

Sen. Collins' decision to vote in favor of Kavanaugh, following a nearly 45-minute speech on the Senate floor, has drawn criticism from protesters and praise from the GOP. The campaign organizers stated, "Susan Collins has betrayed the people, and especially the women and survivors, of Maine." They added, "For years she has claimed to be an independent, a different kind of Republican, but today she shattered that facade forever."

The organizers have pledged to "never let her forget" this decision and are committed to defeating Collins in 2020. They argue, "Maine deserves a Senator who would recoil at the idea of confirming a proven liar, an emotionally unstable partisan, to the Supreme Court."

During her speech on the Senate floor, Collins discussed various issues, including Obamacare, same-sex marriage, and abortion rights, and stated that Kavanaugh's record and pledges before Congress were sufficient to secure her vote. She also addressed the allegations made by Christine Blasey Ford, stating that the allegations "fail to meet the'more likely than not' standard."

A watchdog group, the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust (FACT), has asked the Justice Department to investigate the campaign against Collins out of concern that the donated money may have been an attempt to bribe Collins' vote, which is considered illegal if "the payments are made in return for an explicit promise or undertaking by the official to perform or not to perform an official act."

Title: Iran-Backed Militias Continue Attacks on U.S. Outposts in Iraq, According to U.S. Officials

Article:

Iran-backed militias have reportedly continued to wage attacks on American outposts in Iraq, according to James Jeffrey, the Trump administration's special representative for Syria engagement and special envoy for the global coalition to defeat ISIS.

In a briefing, Jeffrey stated that the United States has experienced targeted strikes by Iran-backed militia groups seeking to create unrest in Iraq since the U.S. forces killed top Iranian general Qassem Soleimani. In the weeks since Soleimani's death, Iran-backed militants have scaled down their attacks but have continued to launch strikes at U.S. positions in Iraq.

Jeffrey described the attacks as "a few shellings of coalition—or bases where coalition forces are located." He added that, with the exception of several incidents at the American embassy compound a few days ago, these attacks have been intermittent and similar to what the U.S. has experienced in their years in Iraq.

When asked if these attacks have been orchestrated by Iran, Jeffrey responded, "We think so."

The United States, while still engaged in the fight against the ISIS terror group in Iraq, remains primarily focused on protecting American forces in the region from retaliatory strikes by Iran. "The focus of our forces right now is force protection," Jeffrey said. "They suffered first 11 quite serious attacks from Iranian-supported militias, who are by and large parts of the Iraqi security system, then the assault on the embassy, then the two Iranian long-range intermediate missile strikes on our forces in Erbil and Ayn al-Asad. So in a situation like that, obviously, the commanders are going to focus, as they have so successfully, on force protection. And as the threat diminishes, they’ll review that."

In addition to the threat posed by Iran, U.S. officials remain concerned about the potential resurgence of ISIS following major territorial defeats in the past year. "The risk of the resurgence of ISIS is a very big problem," Jeffrey said. "We have emphasized that ever since the physical caliphate was defeated along the Euphrates in March of last year. We are very concerned about the number of forces there and how they coordinate among each other. The Iraqis are concerned about that. Our SDF partners in northeast Syria are concerned about that. The Turks are concerned about that because they now have forces in the northeast. Everyone is looking into this and watching it closely."

Title: Dr. Rick Bright Warns of Potential Darkest Winter in Modern History Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

Dr. Rick Bright, the former director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA), testified before a House subcommittee on Thursday, warning that without better planning, 2020 could be the darkest winter in modern history due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

Bright, who was removed from his post last month, urged lawmakers to take "simple but critical steps" to control the pandemic and prevent a disastrous second wave of infections this winter. He emphasized the need for widespread testing, contact tracing, isolation, and quarantine, while striving to develop a cure.

In his testimony, Bright stated, "Our window of opportunity is closing... I fear the pandemic will get worse and be prolonged... Without better planning, 2020 could be the darkest winter in modern history."

Bright also expressed his belief that a Covid-19 vaccine is a question of when, not if, but cautioned that "12 to 18 months is an aggressive schedule and I think it will take longer than that" to manufacture a vaccine.

In his opening statement, Bright supported Tuesday's Senate testimony by Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation's leading infectious disease expert and a member of the White House coronavirus task force. He urged increased public education about handwashing, social distancing, and appropriate face coverings.

In his written testimony submitted ahead of Thursday's hearing, Bright warned that without clear planning and quick action, the coming winter will be the darkest in recent history. He also described "dismissive" HHS leadership, stating that his warnings about the need to ramp up production of ventilators, personal protective equipment, and testing swabs in anticipation of a pandemic were ignored.

Bright also claimed that he was "cut out of key high-level meetings to combat COVID-19." In April, he filed a whistleblower complaint over his removal from the top BARDA job, alleging that he resisted a White House push to promote and fund the now-discredited antimalarial drug hydroxychloroquine as a potential coronavirus remedy over more promising solutions.

The Office of the Special Counsel has concluded that there are "reasonable grounds" to believe that Bright was retaliated against and should be reinstated to his former job as BARDA director. During Thursday's hearing, Republicans focused more on defending President Trump's promotion of hydroxychloroquine than on getting to the bottom of the circumstances surrounding Bright's removal.

In a statement released Thursday, Bright's lawyers reportedly found a "substantial likelihood of wrongdoing" in his removal. The hearing was marked by attacks on Bright from some Republican lawmakers, while administration officials attempted to undercut his testimony. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar, for instance, stated, "While we are launching Operation Warp Speed, he is not showing up for work."

Title: Trump's Decision on DACA Program Sparks Controversy, Leaves Future Uncertain

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to phase out the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in six months has sparked controversy, with the move largely satisfying neither supporters nor opponents of the policy. The DACA program, established by former President Barack Obama in 2012, allows certain individuals who were brought to the United States illegally as children to remain in the country and work legally.

The media has been critical of Trump's decision, with the DACA program being one of the few issues this year on which they have been consistently aligned against the president. The climate change agreement is a close second, but that is more abstract compared to the 800,000 young immigrants who have become integrated into American society through the DACA program.

Trump, during his campaign, had promised to end the DACA program. However, he has shown ambivalence towards the issue, with statements such as, "We think the dreamers are terrific," made as recently as Friday. In 2011, Trump expressed support for those who had been in the country for 20 years, stating, "I don't believe in that [sending them out of the country]."

Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced the administration's decision to end the DACA program on constitutional grounds on Tuesday. Sessions, a leading anti-illegal immigration voice, took no questions from reporters. The administration's decision comes in response to a lawsuit filed by numerous state attorneys general.

The administration is immediately halting any new applications, but existing DACA recipients will not be deported for at least six months. This six-month delay has been portrayed by some pundits as Trump passing the decision to Congress. However, the administration's decision to end the program is not reversible, and no new applications will be accepted during this period.

The future of the DACA program remains uncertain, with Democrats ratcheting up the pressure on Trump and Republicans to find a solution. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi described Trump's decision as "ready to break the hearts and offend the morals of all who believe in justice and human dignity."

The notion that Congress, which has struggled to agree on many issues, will rescue the program over the next six months may be wishful thinking. The DACA program's future will likely depend on the ability of the president and Congress to find a compromise on immigration reform, a task that has proven difficult in the past.

Title: Immigrant Rights Activists Convene on Capitol Hill to Demand Action on Immigration Reform

Article:

Tens of thousands of immigrant rights supporters will gather on Capitol Hill on Wednesday to demand action on immigration reform, a key issue in the ongoing legislative debate. The rally comes as negotiators struggle to finalize legislation that would legalize the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the U.S., rewrite the system for future legal immigrants, and bolster enforcement at the borders and the interior.

Activists have been organizing similar protests since 2003, with the goal of highlighting the growing immigrant rights movement in the U.S. This year, activists will lobby their members of Congress before gathering on the West Lawn to demonstrate their political influence.

Gustavo Torres, executive director of Casa de Maryland, an advocacy group that is helping organize the rally, stated, "We have been here before. But this time is different. We are different. Washington is different. Politicians learned their lesson this past election cycle."

The immediate goal of the marchers is to pressure Senate and House negotiators to finalize the details of the legislation. Activists will demand a simple and quick legalization process and argue against the need for additional border security measures or increased deportations.

The rally on Wednesday will also serve to demonstrate the growing political power of the immigrant rights movement, which has been ascending for years but finally forced lawmakers to take notice after the 2012 elections. Jorge-Mario Cabrera, director of communications at the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights of Los Angeles, said, "Our vote, along with the stars aligning in our favor in Congress, leads us to be very optimistic about the impact our presence in D.C. will have this week."

In 2003, with the Bush administration backing away from immigration reform after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, activists staged the Immigrant Worker Freedom Rides, in which hundreds of immigrants traveled from city to city to make the case for legalization. The rides served as a key early test of the emerging coalition, as religious leaders, labor unions, and minority rights activists joined together to boost immigrant rights groups.

Massive marches in the spring of 2006 grabbed national headlines, as up to 5 million supporters turned out in cities across the nation to protest a House Republican bill that would have cracked down on illegal immigration and imposed penalties on those deemed to be aiding illegal immigrants. The rallies made headlines for their sheer size, including an estimated 500,000 at a Los Angeles rally on March 25. However, they also earned bad publicity after some participants carried foreign flags, particularly Mexican flags, spurring a backlash among voters.

Douglas Rivlin, who worked for the National Immigration Forum at the time, said those rallies served for many Americans as a first glimpse at the power of the movement. "The marches, just as the debate, probably hardened some positions on each side, but I think for the vast majority in the middle there was an awakening that there was this huge issue out there they hadn't paid much attention to," said Mr. Rivlin, who now works for Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, one of the movement's leaders.

Indeed, it was soon after the 2006 marches that senators struck a deal on a legalization bill and brought it to the Senate floor, where it passed 62-36. However, they were unable to hammer out a compromise between their broad legalization and House Republicans' crackdown bill. A year later, senators tried again—only to see their bill fall to a bipartisan filibuster.

The issue simmered, serving as a dividing line in the 2008 election, with then-candidate Barack Obama promising to make immigration a top priority in his first year in the White House. Mr. Obama won the election but turned instead to health care, angering Hispanic voters who felt betrayed. The anger was boosted by the president's push to step up deportations.

In 2010, activists again staged a mass rally—this time on the Mall in Washington, where many had harsh words for Mr. Obama. "It was an important moment in sending the signal to Democrats again that this was an issue that was not going away, and kept the pressure on Democrats to deal with immigration in 2010," Mr. Rivlin said.

Wary of losing Hispanic voters in 2012, Mr. Obama granted tentative legal status to most young adult illegal immigrants last year—something he had for years said he lacked the authority to do. The president also vowed that if he was re-elected he would renew his efforts to pass a broad legalization bill. Now, activists say that promise is due, and the rally Wednesday will serve as a reminder of the power the movement can bring.

"This is a point of escalation, and the show of force in my mind is the overall effort that began the day after the election in 2012," said Mary Kay Henry, president of the Service Employees International Union, which is helping organize the rally. Alfonso Aguilar, president of the Latino Partnership for Conservative Principles, which advocates for legalization from the conservative side, said the rallies have served a purpose, but he said they work best when they target both sides. He said that means being willing to criticize Mr. Obama on enforcement as well as Republicans who oppose legalization and pushing for action on all sides of the immigration equation, including a guest-worker program for future foreign workers. "Put pressure on both sides," he said. "Put pressure on Republicans, but put pressure on Obama as well."

Title: Bipartisan Group of U.S. Lawmakers Urge Obama to Provide Lethal Arms to Ukraine

Article:

A bipartisan group of top U.S. lawmakers, including House Speaker John A. Boehner and key members of the Armed Services, Foreign Affairs, and Intelligence committees, have called on President Obama to provide lethal American arms to Ukraine in a letter sent Thursday. The lawmakers argue that Congress has already granted permission for such transfers, and they urge the President to act swiftly to counter Russian aggression.

In the letter, the lawmakers assert that Ukraine represents a significant geopolitical test for the U.S., and that inaction could result in a loss for the nation. They describe the ongoing conflict in Ukraine as more than just a component of Russian strategic ambitions, but as a violation of international law, a challenge to the West, and an assault on the post-World War II international order.

Congress passed a law last year allowing for the transfer of defensive military equipment to Ukraine, and Ukrainian officials have recently provided the Pentagon and President Obama's national security staff with a list of military equipment they require. However, despite having the necessary authorization, President Obama has yet to take advantage of this provision.

Vice President Joseph R. Biden spoke with Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk on Thursday, expressing concern over continued separatist attacks against Ukrainian forces and civilian areas despite a cease-fire agreement. The lawmakers argue that the cease-fire has been abused by Russian-backed separatists, who have used it to consolidate their positions and push Ukrainian forces out of the territory.

The lawmakers urge President Obama to act quickly on arms transfers, stating that a decision on the matter is already overdue. They acknowledge President Obama's desire to coordinate with Europe, but they argue that his approach has not been effective in influencing European leaders. The lawmakers call on the President to take a more assertive role in challenging Russian aggression and to lead Europe in upholding the international order.

Some analysts have expressed concern that providing lethal arms to Ukraine could provoke a stronger response from Russia, which is backing separatists in the eastern part of the former Soviet republic. President Obama has been cautious in his approach, viewing the decision on arms as a delicate balancing act. Assistant Secretary of State Victoria Nuland testified before the House on Wednesday that the issue is whether to increase the lethality of the aid provided, and whether such aid would escalate the conflict or serve to strengthen Ukraine's defensive capabilities.

President Obama's top military advisers have reportedly weighed in favor of providing lethal aid, with Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Martin Dempsey stating that Ukraine's geographic proximity to Russia and its size give Russia an advantage in the conflict. Dempsey also noted that certain capability gaps in Ukraine's military put their forces at a disadvantage, and that the U.S. should explore opportunities to provide the necessary capabilities to Ukraine.

The stakes, according to the lawmakers, go beyond Ukraine and include the Baltic countries that are part of NATO. An attack on these countries would trigger NATO's collective defense pact, which requires all member countries to step up in defense.

Title: AllSides Dictionary Aims to Provide Balanced Definitions of Controversial Terms

Article:

A new online dictionary, the AllSides Dictionary, has been created by AllSides, a news hub that offers guidance on the potential political bias of articles and news providers. The dictionary aims to provide balanced definitions of 400 controversial terms, revealing how they are perceived differently by people with different political perspectives.

The AllSides Dictionary includes definitions for terms such as "abortion," "Black Lives Matter," "truth," and "white privilege." Phil Neisser, one of the editors of the dictionary and a professor in the department of politics at the State University of New York at Potsdam, believes the dictionary can help students become more rounded in their understanding of controversial topics.

Neisser stated that universities are places of potential conflict, where students from different political perspectives come together. He believes the dictionary can help build mutual understanding in society by encouraging students to engage in conversations with people who have different political views.

Mikhail Lyubansky, another contributor on the project and a teaching associate professor in the department of psychology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, also sees the dictionary as a means to get students to think differently. Lyubansky teaches a course on race and believes the dictionary can help students understand the perspectives of people who think differently about race-related ideas.

Professor Neisser pointed out that although the dictionary has clear educational potential, it is "one thing to have a dictionary and hope people read it, and another thing to require people to read it who are taking a class." He also noted that the dictionary "should be something that grows."

The dictionary definitions provided by Professors Neisser and Lyubansky reveal the challenges they faced in finding the right words to describe viewpoints that are not their own and in capturing the spirit and nuance of each particular political orientation. The definitions were based on courses they have been teaching for many years and their engagement with both progressive and conservative discourses on social media.

Title: QAnon: A Conspiracy Theory Gaining Popularity Among President Trump's Supporters

Article:

A fringe conspiracy theory known as QAnon has gained traction among some supporters of President Donald Trump, as evidenced by attendees at his recent rally in Florida donning QAnon-themed apparel. The theory, which originated on the 4Chan and 8Chan internet message boards, posits that a person known as "Q" is a high-ranking government official who is about to expose a cabal of pedophiles, globalists, and celebrities who secretly control America.

The central premise of QAnon is that President Trump is on the verge of exposing this cabal, and that a "deep state" has been in control for decades. Q's posts, which are often cryptic and open to interpretation, are believed to be a kind of parallel history that ties together various events, such as the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, the prevalence of mass shootings, and the existence of ISIS.

QAnon believers also hold the belief that President Kennedy was set to reveal the existence of the secret government before his assassination, and that President Reagan was shot on the orders of the deep state. They also believe that all presidents since Reagan, with the exception of Trump, have been deep state agents.

According to QAnon lore, the military recruited Trump to run for president, and the deep state, which controls the media, has attempted to smear him through "fake news" and unfounded allegations of collusion with Russia. The deep state's efforts, however, have been unsuccessful, as Trump is winning and is on the verge of arresting the leaders of the deep state and sending them to Guantanamo Bay. This process is referred to as "The Storm" and is seen as a kind of Judgment Day in which the evildoers are punished and the faithful are redeemed.

Q's posts are often vague or incomprehensible, but QAnon followers are eager to decipher them. Last year, for example, Q posted a photo of an unnamed island chain, and QAnon adherents tried to prove that the photo must have been taken on Air Force One, which in turn meant that Q was traveling with the president. The Q posts are known as "breadcrumbs," and the people who try to figure out what they mean are called "bakers."

QAnon has gained a following among some celebrities, including Roseanne Barr and former Red Sox pitcher and current right-wing radio host Curt Schilling. The name "WWG1WGA," which Barr tweeted in June, is a rallying cry for QAnon followers and refers to Q-level clearance at the Energy Department. The true identity of the person behind the Q posts is unknown.

Title: Congressional Impasse Leads to Government Shutdown, Healthcare Law Implementation Continues

Article:

Congressional Republicans and Democrats are at an impasse over the funding of the government, with the former refusing to approve funding unless the latter agrees to alter the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. President Obama criticized this stance in a Rose Garden address, stating, "They're shutting down the government over an ideological crusade to deny affordable health care to many Americans."

The president's remarks followed a meeting with 12 individuals who have benefited from the Affordable Care Act's changes to health insurance coverage or plan to enroll in coverage through the new insurance marketplaces that went online today. Obama condemned Republicans for making the dismantling of the health care law the "centerpiece of their agenda."

The government shutdown, which left nearly 800,000 federal employees out of work without pay this morning, and more than a million other "essential" employees on the job with many of their paychecks delayed, is the result of this impasse. National parks and war memorials are closed, and some government services are operating at reduced staffing levels.

With the next, potentially disastrous deadline - the debt ceiling - looming, Obama urged lawmakers to raise the debt ceiling, warning, "it'd be far more dangerous than a government shutdown, as bad as a shutdown is; it would be an economic shutdown."

On the first day of the health insurance marketplaces' opening to accept new enrollment, Obama acknowledged that the online system was experiencing "glitches" due to unexpected high demand. He compared these initial problems to issues with Apple's rollout of a new operating system.

In response to the government shutdown, House Republicans are considering approving smaller spending bills that would fully fund veterans programs, the National Park Service, and the District of Columbia. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid rejected this strategy, stating, "We cannot and we will not be forced to choose between the parks and cancer research."

Republicans argue that Democrats are the ones refusing to negotiate over funding the government, as previous presidents and Congresses have done in the past. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell stated, "Democratic leaders in Congress finally have their prize, a government shutdown that no one seems to want but them."

Despite the Republican strategy to put the brakes on the health care bill, the law was implemented, starting today, regardless of the government shutdown. The impact of the shutdown, however, is being felt in other ways, with national parks closed to the public, Federal Housing Administration home loans delayed, and courts in Washington stopping the issuance of marriage licenses and performing weddings.

The political consequences of this impasse could be grave for both parties in Congress, but especially for Republicans. According to a Washington Post-ABC News poll released Monday, 63 percent disapprove of Republicans' handling of the budget debate compared to 50 percent who disapprove of Obama's handling of the situation.

Sarah Binder, an expert in Congress and legislative politics and a professor at George Washington University, stated, "We underestimate some of the networks within which lawmakers will find themselves back home."

Title: "American Sniper's Depiction of Chris Kyle and the Broader Issues of Delusion and Violence in Clint Eastwood's Work"

Article:

The film "American Sniper," based on the life of Chris Kyle, has been criticized for its inaccurate portrayal of the real-life American sniper. However, this article will argue that the film's issues extend beyond the representation of Kyle, delving into the larger problems of the film and its director, Clint Eastwood.

Two key moments in Eastwood's public appearances highlight the director's troubling representation of a dark and disturbing feature of the GOP mindset. In 2005, at the National Board of Review dinner, Eastwood threatened filmmaker Michael Moore, stating that he would kill Moore if he showed up at his door with a camera. This statement, made in response to Moore's documentary on the Iraq War, "Fahrenheit 9/11," reveals a disturbing attitude towards free expression and those with differing political views.

In 2012, at the Republican National Convention, Eastwood delivered a bizarre, improvised monologue to an empty chair, which was supposed to represent an invisible Barack Obama. This performance, watched by more than 30 million Americans, left many bewildered and struggling to make sense of it.

These two events, taken together, help explain what's wrong with "American Sniper." They illustrate the combination of delusion and aggressive violence that governs too much of GOP politics.

The film draws a direct link between the events of 9/11 and the war in Iraq, forgetting that the war in Iraq had nothing to do with 9/11. This connection is delusional, as not one of the 9/11 attackers was in any way connected to Iraq. The 9/11-Iraq link is a common link in public perceptions of those on the right who watch Fox News, and it is one that makes sense to Eastwood and those who think like him.

The second problem is the culture of violence. The film portrays Kyle wrestling with some of his kills, but still very clearly divides the world into categories. Iraqis are almost all depicted as "wolves," even women and children. Kyle's first two kills are a young boy and his mother, who posed a threat and thus needed to be killed. The film fails to consider the fact that the war was based on false justifications, or that those in Iraq might have seen U.S. soldiers as invaders in their homeland. The logic of war is completely unquestioned, making this the most simplistic war film nominated for an Oscar in decades.

The lack of nuance, context, and subtlety in the film should not surprise us. It is a terrifying glimpse into a GOP mindset that couples delusion with violence. "American Sniper" is not just about a sniper, but also about an attitude that threatens to destroy any chance in our nation for political compromise and productive debate. And that's what makes this movie really disturbing.

Title: National and State Polls Show Romney Leading Obama in Final Presidential Debate Pre-Debate Analysis

Article:

As the third and final 2012 presidential debate approaches, foreign policy takes center stage. However, foreign policy is not the top concern for voters this year. According to a cross-section of polls, Republican challenger Mitt Romney has established a modest lead over President Barack Obama nationally and in critical battleground states.

1. Rasmussen and Gallup: Both Rasmussen and Gallup daily tracking polls show Romney in the lead among likely voters. Rasmussen's edge is two points (49% for Romney and 47% for Obama), while Gallup shows a larger cushion (51% for Romney and 45% for Obama). For the third consecutive day, Rasmussen's swing state tracker shows Romney ahead by a handful of points (49% for Romney and 46% for Obama).

2. NBC/WSJ: This national survey, which has been less favorable to Republicans in recent months, shows a 47% tie between the two candidates.

3. Politico/GWU: Romney has a slight lead in this poll for the first time, at 49% for Romney and 47% for Obama. The partisan sample is D+4, which might overstate Democrats' turnout edge by a hair. In the poll's swing state sub-sample, Romney leads by the same margin, but hits the 50% mark.

4. Monmouth University: Romney leads Obama by three points (48% for Romney and 45% for Obama). The sitting president's 45% is the bigger result. Romney carries independents handily on every major question, including a 52% to 33% lead in head-to-head, a +22 favorability rating compared to Obama's -15, and a 57% to 34% lead on the economy and jobs.

In the Monmouth poll, Romney also leads on Medicare and Social Security (53% for Romney and 33% for Obama), budget and deficits (57% for Romney and 29% for Obama), and foreign policy (49% for Romney and 39% for Obama).

Fresh state polls show Romney ahead in Colorado (50% for Romney and 46% for Obama), Iowa (47% for Romney and 47% for Obama), and Ohio (48% for Romney and 48% for Obama). The first two surveys are from Rasmussen, while the Ohio data is from Angus Reid.

In the Gravis Marketing poll, Romney leads Obama by 19 points among independents (52% for Romney and 33% for Obama), and holds 92% of his base compared to Obama's 87%. Obama is underwater in job approval (44% approval and 50% disapproval), and independents disapprove of him overwhelmingly (31% approval and 58% disapproval).

Another Ohio poll released today by Quinnipiac shows Obama ahead by 5 points, but Romney gaining ground. Despite its ludicrous D+9 breakdown, the survey shows Romney gaining.

UPDATE: More red flags for Team Obama from the NBC/WSJ poll. A large majority of voters say that if Obama is re-elected, they want to see him dramatically alter his policies.

UPDATE II: Another Ohio poll shows the race exactly tied.

Title: American Missionary Among 28 Killed in Terrorist Attack in Burkina Faso's Capital

Article:

An American missionary, identified as Mike Riddering, was among at least 28 people killed in a terrorist attack in the capital of Burkina Faso that ended on Saturday. The attack occurred at the Hotel Splendid and the nearby Cappuccino Cafe in Ouagadougou, where the terrorists set fire to several cars.

According to Reuters, the other victims were six Canadians, two French, two Swiss, and a Dutch citizen. Mike Riddering, 45, had traveled to the capital from the orphanage he and his wife Amy worked at in Yako, a town about 60 miles northwest of Ouagadougou.

In a Facebook post on Saturday, Amy Boyle Riddering, Mike's wife, wrote, "My best friend, partner in crime and love of my life. The best husband ever. An amazing father to his children and a papa to everyone. My heart is so heavy and I am having trouble believing he is gone. Mike was an example in the way he lived and loved."

Two of the attackers were women, according to President Roch Marc Christian Kabore, as reported by the Associated Press. Three of the terrorists, believed to belong to a local al-Qaeda affiliate, were killed in the assault on the Hotel Splendid. A fourth attacker was killed nearby at the Hotel Yibi.

The raid to end the siege was mounted after dozens of French special forces arrived overnight from neighboring Mali. One U.S. military member was embedded with French forces at the scene, and the United States was working to help provide France with surveillance and reconnaissance support, according to a U.S. senior defense official who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.

The terrorist group known as AQIM, or al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, claimed responsibility for the attack online as it was unfolding, according to SITE Intelligence Group, a U.S.-based organization that monitors jihadists' online activity.

In a message posted in Arabic on the extremists' "Muslim Africa" Telegram account, the group said fighters "broke into a restaurant of one of the biggest hotels in the capital of Burkina Faso, and are now entrenched and the clashes are continuing with the enemies of the religion." Fighters who spoke by phone later "asserted the fall of many dead Crusaders," AQIM said, according to SITE.

The same group is believed responsible for a similar siege at an upscale hotel in Bamako, Mali, in November that left 20 dead. While Burkina Faso, a largely Muslim country, has largely been spared the violence wracked by Islamic extremist groups in Mali, a Romanian national was abducted last April.

The attacks follow growing tension in Burkina Faso in the wake of a coup attempt by presidential guards that collapsed in September. The newly installed government of President Kabore recently issued an arrest warrant for Guillaume Soro, the head of the National Assembly in neighboring Ivory Coast, for his alleged involvement in the failed coup attempt.

In addition, Kabore broke with the past Wednesday by picking a cabinet packed with ministers who had not served under the previous administration of Blaise Compaore, who was president for 27 years. Compaore went into exile in Ivory Coast after being ousted in an uprising in 2014.

In a separate development, an Australian doctor and his wife were kidnapped on Friday night by extremists in Burkina Faso's north near its border with Mali, according to President Kabore. The ministry had originally identified them as Austrian. The couple was abducted in Djibo, the capital of the northern Soum province. The had been living in the region since 1972, volunteering in health services, a local journalist told AP.

Denmark's Crown Princess Mary had been scheduled to visit Burkina Faso later this month on an official visit to visit women's rights and health groups. Danish Foreign Minister Kristian Jensen said the country is assessing whether it will be safe for her to make the trip, AP reported.

Title: Congressional Members Prioritize Media Appearances Over Governing Duties

Article:

The role of members of Congress is being redefined, with some willingly forgoing their legislative responsibilities for the allure of television appearances on networks like MSNBC and Fox News, according to a Commentary essay by Yuval Levin.

The essay, titled "Congress is Weak Because Its Members Want it to be Weak," argues that the 21st century's technologies enabling transparency have had both positive and negative effects. The increased visibility of politics has led to a shift in focus from actual governing and the necessary compromises it entails, to performance art-like grandstanding and posturing as brave truth-tellers condemning the perceived dysfunction of their own institution.

This tendency among legislators to prioritize media exposure over legislative work is identified as the true dysfunction. When nearly every member seeks to be a cable- or local-TV star rather than a lawmaker, it is no wonder that little actual legislating gets done. As Levin notes, even controlling both chambers and having a Republican president poised to sign anything they send up, the Republican Congress has achieved very little. They passed a tax cut, but concerning other priorities they campaigned on for years—reforming the health-care system, adjusting the immigration laws, and confronting the entitlement crisis—they have done nothing and seem to have no plans.

As for the chief job of Congress, developing a budget, neither chamber has even considered a budget resolution for the first time in 40 years. And while Republican leaders demur, the president is again threatening a government shutdown.

The essay also highlights the case of Paul Manafort, who is alleged to have sold his political services to sketchy foreign powers, evaded American taxes, and spent millions on luxury items. The president has defended Manafort, who worked for him for a short time, stating that Manafort worked for other prominent political leaders and that the allegations have nothing to do with collusion.

The article concludes by stating that the founders did not anticipate this shift in focus from governing to media exposure, and that it is likely to outlast the current administration.

Title: Republicans Face Political Quandary Over Deficit Reduction

Article:

Republicans, according to political analyst Julian Zelizer, may be wary of a grand bargain to cut the federal deficit due to internal party dynamics. The party is unified by the defining theme of fighting against deficits, but many are aware that entitlement cuts are unpopular in red states, Zelizer notes.

At the recent Conservative Political Action Convention, Republicans criticized President Obama's budgetary policies and emphasized the need for deficit reduction. Congressman Paul Ryan, with an eye towards 2016, stated, "Our debt is a threat to this country. We have to tackle this problem before it tackles us. So today, I want to make the case for balance. That case, in a nutshell, is that a balanced budget will promote a healthier economy."

However, for many reasons, Republicans do not seem to genuinely want a "grand bargain" over deficit reduction, according to Zelizer. Deficit reduction is an issue that the party likes to discuss more than it has an interest in actually addressing.

Deficit reduction has become a unifying theme for Republicans since the 2010 elections, providing a common ground for various conservative factions. Without deficit reduction as a central issue, the party's internal divisions become more apparent, including neoconservatives versus realists on foreign policy, social conservatives versus libertarians, proponents of immigration reform and hard-line anti-immigration activists, and fiscal conservatives versus supply-side economists.

If deficit reduction loses its prominence as an issue due to a deal between the president and Congress, Republicans will have less to unite over and more time to fight among themselves. President Obama could potentially follow President Bill Clinton's example in 1996, when he signed a historic welfare reform bill, effectively taking away one of the main issues that the GOP had used to attack Democrats for decades.

A genuine deficit reduction deal would require Congress to accept some form of revenue increase, which goes against the Republican party's fiscal orthodoxy, as many experts agree that no matter how many spending cuts are implemented, eliminating deficits would require a combination of tax increases and loophole-closing reforms.

If President Obama were to agree to a grand bargain that included deep cuts in entitlement spending, the political backlash against the Republican party could be intense, especially in red states and districts where elderly voters rely on Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security. The political backlash from Republican voters against substantive cuts, as proposed by Congressman Paul Ryan, could be severe.

In summary, while Republicans are vocal about the need for deficit reduction, they may not be willing to accept the political and economic consequences of a grand bargain that includes revenue increases and entitlement cuts. The party's internal divisions could become more apparent if deficit reduction is no longer a central issue, and President Obama could potentially capitalize on this opportunity, as President Clinton did in the late 1990s.

Title: Top 2016 Presidential Prospects Raise Over $86 Million for Campaign Committees

Article:

Political outfits associated with top prospects for the 2016 presidential election have raised at least $86 million for committees that could support their campaigns, according to a recent analysis of campaign reports and interviews with allies. The funds were raised for state and federal reelection campaign committees, leadership PACs, super PACs, and nonprofit groups created to boost pet causes.

In the Democratic party, Hillary Clinton is attracting significant support from major donors and top campaign operatives, but potential rivals are also assembling campaign-style operations. Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley, for instance, recently hired a top New York fundraiser to solicit big checks from Wall Street.

The early money is crucial in the Citizens United era, as prospective candidates need a stable of rich allies to bolster their efforts before the campaign starts and fend off attacks from opponents. Paul Begala, a top strategist to Priorities USA, a super PAC and sister nonprofit group, likened the process to planting a tree, stating, "The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is today. And this is 20 years ago. This is why we’re starting now."

The 2016 Democratic presidential nomination is widely considered Hillary Clinton's for the taking. The infrastructure that has arisen around her, without her involvement or any surefire indication that she is even going to run, dwarfs anything any other Democrat could possibly muster and is unique in the annals of modern campaign finance.

Clinton's inner circle has been keeping close tabs on a network of groups that together form a sort of Hillary shadow campaign. These groups combined to raise more than $12 million in 2013 to build a voter database and a grass-roots army, and later to air ads for a presumptive 2016 run.

On the Republican side, Senators Ted Cruz, Rand Paul, and Marco Rubio, along with Representative Paul Ryan, are stretching the potential of hard-dollar fundraising through innovative joint committees that merge their various accounts and increase the maximum size of the donations they can accept to $10,000 a pop. Rubio and Ryan, favorites of GOP establishment donors, raised $8 million and $4.8 million last year, respectively, through their various accounts. Both men spent heavily on digital operations and ads defending their political stances.

Cruz, a favorite of the anti-establishment tea party, pulled in $4.1 million primarily from small donors, but he has worked to make inroads with deeper pockets who could subsidize a 2016 presidential run. Supporters of Texas Governor Rick Perry, who raised $5.6 million into a super PAC supporting his 2012 campaign for the GOP nomination, recently transferred $200,000 in leftover cash into a nonprofit expected to set the stage for another presidential campaign.

Title: Democratic Debate Highlights No Distinguishable Differences on Immigration Between Clinton and Sanders

Article:

The Democratic debate held on Wednesday at Miami Dade College primarily focused on immigration, border security, and legalization, with the first hour being almost entirely dedicated to these topics. The debate, hosted by Univision and moderated by Latino journalists, was marked by pandering to Latino voters and promises to use executive power on their behalf, which could potentially impact the Democratic nominee, likely Hillary Clinton, in a general election.

In terms of immigration policy, there was little discernible difference between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. Both candidates expressed sympathy for the plight of illegal aliens and stated their intention to establish a pathway to citizenship, even if it meant bypassing Congress and using executive orders. The candidates avoided using the term "amnesty," but the result of any "pathway" for illegals is inevitably amnesty.

On the issue of deportations, both candidates deviated from standard Democratic National Committee talking points and promised lawlessness. When pressed by the moderators, Clinton suggested that deportations would end for all "non-criminal" illegal immigrants if she were to become president. Sanders appeared to agree.

The implications of such a promise are significant: if only serious criminals are to be deported, would everyone else who comes to America or is already here illegally be allowed to stay? What about newly arrived illegals? Do they not have families too? And what precedent would it set for the country if the commander in chief felt entitled to ignore a huge body of existing federal law?

In their efforts to outdo each other as champions of illegal immigrants, who have in fact broken U.S. federal law, Clinton and Sanders seemed to entertain the idea that it is possible to secure our borders without enforcing laws against a vast majority of illegal entrants. They were not just peddling amnesty on that stage, they were in effect dabbling in open borders.

Title: Trump's Executive Order on Anti-Semitism and Its Potential Impact on Campus Speech

Article:

President Donald Trump's recent executive order has sparked controversy, with concerns that it may be used to suppress criticism of Israel on college campuses. The order directs federal agencies to consider the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance's (IHRA) definition of anti-Semitism, which includes speech critical of Israel.

In a speech before the Israeli American Council, President Trump made several anti-Semitic remarks, including calling American Jews "not nice people" who would vote Republican to protect their wealth. This has led to skepticism about Trump's motives regarding the executive order.

The executive order has been criticized for potentially expanding ongoing efforts to suppress free speech on college campuses, particularly regarding pro-Palestinian protests. The Trump Administration has already launched several investigations into pro-Palestinian speech on college campuses under Title VI, and the executive order could escalate these efforts.

The IHRA's definition of anti-Semitism includes speech that is protected by the First Amendment, such as claiming that the existence of a State of Israel is a racist endeavor. Kenneth Stern, the lead author of the definition, has stated that it should not be applied to higher education.

However, the executive order only directs agencies to consider the IHRA's list as evidence of discriminatory intent in cases of overt anti-Semitism with an ethnic component. It does not mean that criticism of Israel alone would trigger a Title VI investigation.

The impact of the executive order is unclear, as it mostly reaffirms the federal government's long-standing interpretation of Title VI to encompass some anti-Jewish bias. It is also unclear whether the order will have any significant impact on the pro-Palestine movement on college campuses or impose an unwanted classification on American Jews.

The main question about the strike on Qassem Soleimani is strategic, rather than legal or moral. Soleimani was a powerful leader, but he was not a terror kingpin, and his death does not decapitate anything. The only reason to kill Soleimani is to enter a new war that the United States can win. However, there is no sign that anyone in power, least of all the president, has thought past the action itself, leading to concerns about the strategic implications of the strike.

It is crucial that influential Republican senators remind President Trump of his promise to keep America out of foreign quagmires and keep him from stumbling further into war with Iran.

Title: Media's Preferred Candidates Struggle in 2020 Democratic Presidential Race

Article:

As the Democratic presidential nomination process narrows down to a binary choice between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders, it is worth reflecting on the performance of the media's preferred candidates in the 2020 race.

The New York Times' dual endorsements for Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) had minimal impact, much like the points in the improvisational comedy show "Whose Line Is It Anyway?". Similarly, the media's enthusiasm for South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, early interest in Beto O'Rourke, and adoration for Senator Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) failed to resonate with the majority of American voters outside the Acela corridor.

Instead, Democratic voters consistently expressed interest in the former vice president and the iconoclastic runner-up from the 2016 Democratic race. Before the actual primaries, Biden consistently led in polls, and Sanders performed well. The primaries followed this pattern, with early wins for Sanders and a comeback surge from Biden.

The idea that any other candidate had a particularly likely shot at the nomination was often perceived as pundit-driven misdirection from a class of commentators who were more interested in presenting more interesting, intersectional characters, as they themselves are more interested in identity-based diversity than the rest of the country.

The media's support for Warren was so strong that Matt Yglesias, a writer for Vox, felt compelled to write a post explaining why she was losing, despite her popularity among Vox's readership. Yglesias described Vox's audience as "a graduate of or student at a selective college (which also describes the staff and our social peers)" and lamented that "if you assigned me the job of serving a less-educated audience, I'd probably need to think about how to change things up." He is correct; outside the Vox bubble, there was little interest in the kind of cultural progressivism represented by Warren.

At present, Biden and Sanders are in a battle for delegates, with both candidates having a good shot at the nomination. However, this was true a year ago as well. They were both better-known and better-liked than many in the media seemed to grasp, and an endless series of magazine covers, fluff pieces, and editorial board endorsements aimed at other candidates could not make any difference whatsoever.

Title: White House Denies Allegations of Russian Connection in Trump Campaign

Article:

White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus has stated that high-ranking U.S. intelligence officials have assured the administration that no members of President Trump's campaign had contact with Russian spies. The assertion was made during an interview on "Fox News Sunday" in response to reports suggesting otherwise that have dominated news coverage for several days.

Priebus claimed that the top levels of the intelligence community have assured him that the story is inaccurate and grossly overstated. He described the allegations as "complete garbage" and expressed frustration over the constant speculation, stating, "To accuse an organization of being in constant contact with Russian spies is outrageous."

The allegations of a Russian connection began shortly after Trump's election victory in November. Democrats have used the story to question the legitimacy of the election results. Since then, the story has become the focus of major news organizations and has prompted calls for investigations into Russian email hacking during the campaign and potential links to Trump.

The news reports, some based on anonymous sources within the intelligence community, have alarmed the White House and top Republican lawmakers who believe leaks are emanating from Obama loyalists within the government. At a press conference last week, Trump himself ruled out any ties to Russia, stating, "I own nothing in Russia. I have no loans in Russia. I don't have any deals in Russia."

Rep. Devin Nunes, California Republican and chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, has bolstered the president's argument by saying Obama administration holdovers appear to be illegally leaking information designed to damage Trump. Nunes stated, "We do have people in the last administration, people who have burrowed in, perhaps all throughout the government, who clearly are leaking to the press—and it is against the law."

The Washington Post story revealed that Michael Flynn, whom Trump had chosen as national security adviser, misled White House officials about his conversations with the Russian ambassador during the transition. As a result, Flynn was forced to resign. The White House insists that Flynn's downfall was failing to tell Vice President Mike Pence that the discussion included recent U.S. sanctions against Russia, not because of illegal or improper conduct for a national security adviser.

Nunes also stated that the problem started with Obama-era holdovers, not a rift between Trump and the intelligence community, as some news organizations reported. He emphasized that the rank-and-file people in the intelligence agencies are not paying attention to what is going on in Washington.

Priebus described the constant focus on the Russian connection as "fake news" and expressed frustration over the media's focus on the issue, stating, "All I'm saying is if you're going to come out with a story that says Russian spies are talking to your campaign—oh my God—I think you should in most cases actually have a named source." He also highlighted the administration's accomplishments, such as the repeal of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the signing of a coal bill, the nomination of Neil Gorsuch for the Supreme Court, and deregulation of the federal government.

Title: Democratic Strategy for 2020 Election: Balancing Progressive Policies and Swing State Appeal

Article:

The Democratic party is expressing concern as the 2020 presidential election approaches, with a year still remaining before the vote. The focus is not on predicting which Democrat will win or lose, but rather on the strategy required for a Democratic candidate to secure at least some of the battleground states that President Trump won in the last election.

The Times poll indicates that Senator Bernie Sanders, who supports policies like raising taxes on the rich, addressing political corruption, providing universal day care, and guaranteeing healthcare to all, is leading Trump by two points in Michigan. An anti-establishment, populist approach that emphasizes bread-and-butter issues can garner broad popular support.

The 2018 midterm elections saw Democrats win by running a populist campaign, focusing on reducing health care costs and helping ordinary families. They avoided supporting unpopular progressive policy dreams, such as mandatory Medicare and border decriminalization. The 2020 presidential candidates are being criticized for ignoring the lessons of 2018.

However, to win over voters outside the liberal spectrum, candidates must demonstrate their concern for winning the votes of those who do not consider themselves very liberal. Some argue that Senator Elizabeth Warren's efforts to persuade Iowa voters and high-information Democrats nationally that she is not too extreme or shrewish to be president may not translate to a larger audience.

Others contend that Warren's stance, which includes promising to 'fight' rather than compromise and insisting on the most radical health-care plan ever proposed by a major-party nominee, is turning off the very voters she would need in key swing states. The Democratic party risks nominating a candidate with less appeal than Hillary Clinton in these crucial swing states, leading to a loss.

Vice President Joe Biden has a head start with the moderate or conservative half of the Democratic electorate due to his established identity. However, a newer moderate Democrat lacking that identity faces challenges in building a national constituency. The only avenue that has seemed to be open for a candidate to break into the top has been to excite activists, who are demanding positions far to the left of the median voter.

The article concludes by stating that Warren and Sanders are still close enough to Trump that they can compete, and new events, like a recession or another scandal, could erode Trump's base. However, the party should view its position a year before the election with real fear.

In a separate but related development, the impeachment inquiry against President Trump is underway. While there is no explicit quid pro quo proposal in the current evidence, the context and circumstances are expected to become the focus of the investigation. The article suggests that the absence of an explicit quid pro quo over restarting aid does not weaken the evidence, as circumstantial evidence can be enough to support impeachment. Whether it is also enough to convince Republicans and lead to removal is another matter.

Title: Trump's Actions and Potential Impeachable Offenses Detailed in Article of Impeachment

Article:

The second impeachment article against former President Donald Trump, which detailed his efforts to leverage the federal government for personal gain, draws parallels with President Nixon's abuse of power. This article focuses on Trump's alleged misuse of investigatory powers, as opposed to the previous article's focus on obstruction of Congress.

Trump has been accused of repeatedly calling for investigations against his political opponents, both publicly and privately with aides. For instance, as documented in the Mueller report, he pressured then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions to investigate Hillary Clinton, stating, "You'd be a hero." This behavior has been criticized for violating the constitutional rights of American citizens and undermining the credibility of the judicial system.

The Constitution prohibits the president from profiting off the office by accepting "emoluments." However, Trump continues to own his hotels, allowing politicians, lobbyists, and foreigners to enrich him and curry favor with him by staying there. On Sunday, Attorney General William Barr personally paid for a 200-person holiday party at Trump's hotel in downtown Washington.

The Democratic-controlled House has been criticized for its handling of these allegations. According to Bob Bauer, an NYU law professor and former White House counsel, the lack of oversight hearings is "astonishing."

In the 2016 election, $280,000 in undisclosed hush-money payments during the final weeks of the campaign is not a typical campaign-finance violation. Given the close margin of victory (decided by fewer than 80,000 votes across three swing states), the silence these payments bought may have influenced the election's outcome.

While the president has wide latitude to issue pardons, Trump has reportedly encouraged people to break the law (or impede investigations) with a promise of future pardons. This practice is not explicitly mentioned as an impeachable offense, but it has raised concerns about the integrity of the legal system.

Title: Bobby Jindal Urges Republicans to Rethink Strategy, Emphasize Growth and Outreach

Article:

In a sharp rebuke to his own party, Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal called on Republicans to reconsider their approach to politics and voters during the Republican National Committee's Winter Meeting on Thursday. Jindal, who is considered a potential contender for the 2016 presidential race, urged Republicans to move away from a focus on government bookkeeping and austerity, and instead, boldly showcase the benefits of free-market policies.

Jindal criticized the Republican Party's obsession with government number crunching, stating that it is not the solution to the nation's problems. He emphasized the need for Republicans to compete for every vote, regardless of political affiliations, and to reject the notion that demography dictates voter behavior.

In a notable reference to the 2012 Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney's controversial comments about voters, Jindal said, "We must compete for every single vote: the 47 percent and the 53 percent and any other combination of numbers that adds up to 100 percent."

Jindal also criticized Romney's comments in a November interview with CNN, stating that one of the seven points for the Republican Party's future is to demonstrate that Republicans like voters. He further criticized Romney's comments about certain voter demographics during a closed-door fundraiser.

Jindal's remarks come as the Republican National Committee has directed a five-member panel, known as the "Growth and Opportunity Project," to identify winning political strategies, particularly in the area of minority outreach.

Jindal's speech was laced with criticism of Democrats, including a jab at the economic stimulus programs of President Barack Obama's administration and the Solyndra scandal. However, he was also critical of the Republican Party, stating that they have not only lost elections but also lost issue arguments with Democrats.
