Jindal called for a shift in the ambition of the conservative movement from managing government to growth. He criticized the notion that a well-prepared spreadsheet, power point presentation, or TV ad would solve the party's problems.

Jindal was elected last year to lead the Republican Governor's Association. RNC Chairman Reince Priebus will be up for re-election as RNC chairman on Friday. Jindal joked that Priebus should not use the Romney campaign's voter turnout technology, ORCA, for his election.

Title: Chicago Loses Second Amendment Case Over Gun Range Restrictions

Article:

The city of Chicago has lost another Second Amendment case, this time over its attempt to make it virtually impossible for private gun ranges to operate within the city. The latest lawsuit stems from Chicago's recalcitrance in complying with the U.S. Supreme Court's 2010 decision in McDonald v. City of Chicago.

The McDonald decision overturned the city's virtual ban on firearms. In response, Chicago enacted a series of city ordinances that were so restrictive that they were intended to make it difficult to purchase, own, or carry a gun. Many of these ordinances have been challenged in court.

The city's latest loss came in Ezell v. City of Chicago, a case that has come before the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals twice. Chicago lost the first round in 2011, when the court found that the city's complete ban on shooting ranges violated the Second Amendment.

In response to that loss, the city passed a new ordinance, described by the Seventh Circuit as "an elaborate scheme of regulations." The range ordinance was so restrictive that only 2.2 percent of the city's entire acreage was "even theoretically available" for a gun range. The court noted that the commercial viability of any of these parcels was so questionable that no shooting range yet exists in the city of Chicago.

Rhonda Ezell, the plaintiff in the first case, along with several other Chicago residents, the Second Amendment Foundation, and the Illinois Rifle Association, went back to court and won again.

At issue were three zoning provisions that:

1. Allowed gun ranges only as special uses in manufacturing districts.
2. Prohibited gun ranges within 100 feet of another range or within 500 feet of a residential district, school, place of worship, or multiple other places.
3. Barred anyone under the age of 18 from even entering a shooting range.

The only facilities exempted from these provisions were gun ranges operated by law-enforcement agencies and private security firms, of which there are 11 in Chicago.

The majority opinion was written by Judge Diane Sykes, one of the judges listed as a possible Supreme Court pick by Donald Trump. Judge Ilana Rovner wrote a partial dissent. The majority concluded that the zoning provisions on manufacturing districts and the distance rule are so restrictive that they "severely limit [ ] Chicagoans' Second Amendment right to maintain proficiency in firearm use via target practice at a range."

In trying to defend these restrictions, the city "raised only speculative claims of harm to public health and safety," Sykes wrote. There was no valid reason to restrict gun ranges to manufacturing areas as opposed to commercial areas, which is where other cities zone gun ranges. The city also had to admit that many of the existing gun ranges operated by law enforcement and private security firms do so safely near schools, churches, parks, and stores.

The city tried to argue that gun ranges cause secondary harmful effects such as gun theft, fire hazards, and airborne lead contamination. But, Sykes noted, Chicago "produced no evidentiary support for these claims beyond the speculative testimony of three city officials." Moreover, she wrote, the city "failed to establish that target practice is wholly unprotected as a matter of history and legal tradition in the founding era or when the Fourteenth Amendment was ratified."

Also rejected was the city's claim that no one under 18 has a Second Amendment right. Again, Sykes wrote, it was "an extraordinarily broad claim" and the city "failed to back it up." In fact, the city's own witness "agreed that the age restriction is overbroad because teenagers can safely be taught to shoot, and youth firearm instruction is both prudent and can be conducted in a safe manner."

The key to this decision was the court's conclusion that "the core individual right of armed defense" that the Supreme Court recognized in the McDonald and Heller decisions "includes a corresponding right to acquire and maintain proficiency in firearm use through target practice at a range." Thus, contrary to the city's arguments, the Second Amendment does protect the citizen's right to practice at a gun range.

The court affirmed that the city of Chicago has a right to "regulate the construction and operation of firing ranges to address genuine risks to public health and safety." But the city failed to justify any of the "risks" it claimed to be addressing with the gun-range ordinance.

Hopefully, this latest loss will cause Chicago to stop trying to restrict the Second Amendment rights of its residents. But given its defiant behavior since the original McDonald case was decided, that may be a forlorn hope.

Title: Macron's Trip to the US: A Test of Influence on Global Liberal Order and European Unity

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron's first presidential trip to the United States has sparked a flurry of interest, as the leader known for his speeches about Europe seeks to navigate the complex relationship with the 71-year-old U.S. President, Donald Trump. The power dynamics between the two leaders, who represent contrasting ideologies, have been a topic of discussion, with Macron's influence on global liberal order and European unity at stake.

Macron's visit to the U.S. is framed by the narrative of French exceptionalism, emphasizing France's unique importance in the world. The trip offers an opportunity for a French president to share the global stage with the leader of the world's most powerful country, a scenario that appeals to Gallic pride.

The contrasting styles and ideologies of Macron and Trump have added intrigue to the encounter. As the U.S. grapples with the aftermath of the 2016 presidential election, some in liberal America have sought solace in Macron, viewing him as a potential savior for the liberal order and European unity. Macron's recent speeches on Europe, warning of the dangers of nationalism and the importance of a united Europe, have resonated with many in the U.S.

However, the question of Macron's ability to influence Trump on issues such as Iran, trade, and climate change remains uncertain. Macron's European plans and centrist ideology have been the subject of debate, with some dismissing them as doomed or disingenuous.

Macron's European ambitions are not only dependent on his domestic reform agenda but also on his ability to raise his profile in Washington and draw credibility from that in Europe. Macron is aware that his presidency was made possible by the 1958 Gaullist constitution, which allows for the circumvention of established parties and the rise of an outsider.

Macron's road to Europe, in this historical context, goes through Washington, as he seeks to navigate the complex relationship with the U.S. and position himself as a leader who can protect Europe from strategic, economic, and ideological threats. The outcome of Macron's trip to the U.S. will be closely watched, as it may determine the future of the global liberal order and European unity.

Title: Trump to Roll Back Obama-Era Clean Power Plan, Signals New Direction for EPA

Article:

President Donald Trump will visit the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on Tuesday, where he is expected to sign an executive order that will initiate the process of rolling back the Obama-era Clean Power Plan. The visit marks a significant step in EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt's efforts to restore the EPA to its original, limited authorities.

In an interview with an unspecified news outlet, Pruitt stated, "We're going to roll back those things that were unlawful, we're going to roll back those things that were an overreach, we're going to roll back the steps taken by the previous administration." The EPA's federal building, where the meeting will take place, is situated across the street from the Trump International Hotel, which was previously the Old Post Office building.

The executive order will not only review the Clean Power Plan but also change Obama-era executive orders on climate change and carbon emissions regulations. This shift represents a dramatic departure from Obama's legacy, which prioritized a regulatory agenda focused on climate change.

Pruitt expressed optimism about the president's visit, stating that it signaled a new set of priorities for the agency. During Trump's tenure, Pruitt plans to sign a series of rules and procedures to reform the EPA.

Rescinding the Clean Power Plan, Pruitt explained, was a reflection of the Trump administration's approach to regulatory reform. Under the Obama administration, Pruitt claimed that the oil, coal, and natural gas industries were subjected to a "regulatory assault" that led to job losses across the country.

Pruitt believes that regulatory uncertainty has been a significant impediment to economic growth. He stated, "I think the greatest impediment we've had on economic growth is regulatory uncertainty." Trump, he explained, understands that the regulatory process has become so complex that it hinders companies from investing and growing.

Pruitt's philosophy aligns with the Trump administration's goal to reduce the federal government's overbearing bureaucracy in order to stimulate economic growth. He stated, "We have situations here, and this is not just unique to the EPA, it's other agencies at the federal level as well that do permitting, where it takes eight or nine years to get a permit to do something. Well, that's not a decision, that's obstructionism."

Pruitt aims to restore confidence among businesses and workers in the energy industry, particularly in coal, natural gas, and oil. He stated, "Agencies at the federal level are part of the executive branch, they exist to enforce the law, not make the law."

Pruitt described his philosophy as "EPA originalism," and his goal is to refocus the agency toward Congress's original authorities. This shift in focus is intended to send a different message to the industries regulated by the EPA.

Pruitt believes that the agency should return its focus to tackling big environmental cleanup projects. He plans to address the 1300 hazardous "superfund sites" designated by the agency as priority areas for cleanup. Many of these sites, he noted, have been on the national priority list for 30-40 years, which he considers a sign that they are not being addressed effectively.

The executive order will not repeal the EPA's Endangerment Finding on CO2 emissions, but Pruitt expressed openness to addressing it in the future. He stated, "I think that if there are petitions for reconsideration for the endangering findings, we'll have to address those at some point."

Pruitt led the legal charge against the EPA as the Attorney General of Oklahoma, suing the agency 13 different times. He has a reputation for challenging environmentalist priorities, but some critics have questioned his stance on climate change.

Title: Putin Expresses Concern Over U.S.-Russia Relations, Threatens No Contact with Trump

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin has expressed concern that ongoing investigations in the United States are hindering improved relations with Moscow. In a speech at an economic forum in St. Petersburg, Putin stated, "We are hostages to this internal strife in the United States." He added, "I hope that it will end some day and the objective need for the development of Russian-American relationships will prevail."

During the forum, attended by world leaders such as French President Emmanuel Macron and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, Putin also announced his intention to step down from his post in 2024, adhering to the Russian constitution's ban on anyone serving two consecutive presidential terms. However, Putin's pledge does not necessarily mean he will retire, as he previously stepped down after two terms to become prime minister before returning to the presidency in 2012.

Putin criticized U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the international nuclear agreement with Iran, stating, "What should it be punished for, then?" The move has also strained relations between Washington and Europe. Putin also criticized U.S. sanctions against Russia over its annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and its alleged interference in the 2016 U.S. elections.

The Russian president bemoaned the "chaotic" situation of economic punishment and said the "sanctions baton" is being used more often in the world, not just toward Moscow. Putin also took a jab at Macron over Europe's rift with Trump regarding Iran, stating, "Don’t you worry, we will help ensure your security." Macron responded on a serious note that France and its allies could stand for themselves.

In addition to his comments on U.S.-Russia relations and the Iran nuclear deal, Putin also addressed the ongoing investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. elections, stating that the situation is "as though everyone is playing football, but at the same time, they are applying judo rules to it [the match]." Putin added, "It's neither football, nor judo. It's just chaos."

Title: U.S. Surpasses 3 Million Coronavirus Cases as Infections Surge in More Than Half of States

Article:

The United States surpassed 3 million confirmed coronavirus cases on Wednesday, according to data from the John Hopkins University Coronavirus Resource Center. The U.S. reported 3,009,611 cases at midday on Wednesday, with Tuesday marking a record of 60,000 new cases.

California and Texas both reported over 10,000 new cases in a single day, shattering previous records. Arizona, Florida, and South Carolina have led the world in new cases over the last seven days, according to data from the New York Times.

Hospitals in Florida have run out of beds in their intensive care units, despite Gov. Ron DeSantis' continued downplaying of the situation and refusal to release critical information about hospitalizations. Florida recorded more than 15,000 new COVID-19 cases in one day, the highest single-day increase in any state.

Experts previously predicted a summer lull in infections, but that never materialized. Many states, facing pressure from business leaders and the White House, rushed to reopen without fully anticipating the impact on new infections.

White House coronavirus task force coordinator Deborah Birx stated in a Sirius XM interview on Tuesday that states ignored guidelines put in place by federal and local public health officials and "stepped on the gas" while reopening, causing this new surge.

After calling on governors to reopen state economies, the Trump administration has now shifted its attention to pressuring schools to fully reopen in the fall. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently released guidance for safely reopening schools, but President Trump tweeted his displeasure with his own public health agency on Wednesday, stating the guidelines were too burdensome and "expensive."

Testing capacity is being strained in those states with the largest number of new infections, and supply chain issues that plagued the country early in the pandemic have resurfaced.

While Trump and other administration officials have latched onto a declining fatality rate as a sign of progress, Anthony Fauci, the nation's leading infectious disease expert, said focusing on that one statistic is a "false narrative."

"There's so many other things that are very dangerous and bad about this virus, don't get yourself into a false complacency," Fauci said.

Deaths are a lagging indicator in an outbreak, and will rise as people generally don't die until weeks after they become sick. In addition, many of the newly infected have been young people, who generally tend to be healthier.

"But that doesn't mean that you could not get seriously ill," Fauci said.

Title: Reliance Industries Launches JioMart, Moves Closer to Competing with Amazon in Indian E-commerce Market

Article:

Reliance Industries Ltd., an Indian conglomerate controlled by Asia's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, has started testing its online shopping portal, JioMart. This move signifies a step towards Ambani's goal of establishing a digital platform to compete with e-commerce giants such as Amazon.com Inc. and Walmart Inc.'s Flipkart Online Services Pvt. in India.

JioMart, currently available in three neighborhoods surrounding Mumbai, offers more than 50,000 grocery products, free home delivery, and a lenient return policy. The portal, labeled as "the nation's new store," is a prelude to how Reliance Industries is expanding its consumer offerings, pivoting towards newer businesses.

With the launch of JioMart, Reliance Industries enters the e-commerce market, which KPMG predicts will grow to $200 billion by 2027. Ambani, who is 62, is investing billions of dollars in a series of small acquisitions to realize his online retail ambitions. These newer businesses, including telecommunications and retail, are expected to contribute 50% of Reliance Industries' earnings in a few years, up from the current 32%.

Ambani's previous project, requiring nearly $50 billion of capital expenditure, is already showing signs of success. Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd., the group's wireless carrier started in 2016, is India's No.1 operator today and has more than 350 million users. The company entered the world's second-largest market by subscribers with free calls and cheap data, forcing some incumbents to exit or merge with rivals.

Ambani aims to replicate this success in online retail, terming it "new commerce." In August, he stated his goal is to "completely transform" India's unorganized retail market, which accounts for 90% of the nation's industry.

Amazon and Walmart face competition from this tech-enabled partnership, as Ambani plans to link producers, traders, small merchants, consumer brands, and consumers through JioMart. After beta trials with thousands of merchants across the country showed promise, Reliance Industries is now preparing to roll out the platform on a larger scale.

Reliance Industries has also unveiled a plan to create a $24 billion digital-services holding firm and has vowed to list the new businesses within five years. Investors have responded positively, with Reliance Industries shares soaring 36% this year, compared to the 15% advance in the benchmark index. The gains have added more than $15 billion to Ambani's wealth, making him the wealthiest person in Asia with a net worth of almost $60 billion, according to the Billionaires Index.

Title: Uninsured Americans Decrease by About 25 Percent Due to Affordable Care Act

Article:

The number of uninsured Americans has decreased by approximately 25 percent this year, according to various private sector surveys and a government report. This equates to eight million to eleven million people who have gained health insurance.

Of these newly insured individuals, it appears that more than half have enrolled in Medicaid, particularly in states that expanded eligibility for the government health care program for lower-income residents. The remaining individuals have enrolled in private health plans through the new state insurance marketplaces.

In addition to the recent changes, three to four million people, primarily young adults, became newly insured through provisions of the Affordable Care Act that took effect before this year.

Dan Witters, the research director of the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index, which has been surveying Americans about their health insurance status since 2008, stated, "There's no question it's come down." Gallup has recorded a drop in the percentage of American adults without insurance from 18 percent in mid-2013 to 13.4 percent by the end of May. These results are consistent with other polls.

The reduction in the uninsured population is still a topic of debate, with some considering it a success and others viewing it as a disappointment. When the health care law passed in 2010, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that by 2017 about 32 million more Americans would gain insurance through the law. Due to policy changes, the budget office's current estimate is now lower, about 26 million people. The nation appears to be at least a third of the way to that target.

Detailed demographic data from large government surveys, which are generally considered the most reliable, lag behind the private surveys. However, a few trends are clear. Most notably, Medicaid expansion has significantly impacted the reduction in the uninsured population. States that expanded their programs have seen a substantially larger reduction in their uninsured population than states that did not expand.

Critics have raised concerns about the sustainability of the coverage gains, with worries that some people may have signed up and then cycled out of coverage quickly due to failed premium payments, or that many of the health plans people bought covered too few doctors or required too high a payment out of pocket to provide meaningful access to coverage.

Over the next four years, the law is projected to expand coverage to millions more Americans. However, it is expected that about 30 million people will remain uninsured even after several years, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Some of this is by design, as people in the country illegally are excluded from coverage under the law. Additionally, about four million low-income Americans are caught in a policy gap in those states that have not expanded Medicaid.

Title: Tom Brokaw Apologizes for Assimilation Remarks on Hispanics

Article:

Tom Brokaw, the longtime NBC anchor and journalist known for his work on the "greatest generation" of Americans, has issued an apology for his remarks on the assimilation of Hispanics in the United States.

During a recent appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press," Brokaw stated that "Hispanics should work harder at assimilation. They ought not to be just codified in their communities, but make sure that all their kids are learning to speak English."

The response to Brokaw's comments was swift and critical. Aura Bogado, an investigative immigration reporter at Reveal, described his remarks as a "deeply racist rant." Julio Ricardo Varela, the founder of LatinoRebels.com, called the comments "xenophobic."

Liberal commentator Maria Cardona described Brokaw as "a little out of touch" and insisted that "Latinos absolutely assimilate." However, many Hispanics do not speak English, contradicting Cardona's assertion.

Brokaw's fellow panelist on "Meet the Press," Yamiche Alcindor, argued that the idea that Americans can only speak English is "troubling." She added that "Spanish and other languages were always part of America."

However, the Founding Fathers did not speak or write in Spanish, and those who cannot speak, understand, read, and write English will likely face challenges in advancing socially, economically, or politically in the United States.

Within a few hours of the backlash, Brokaw issued an apology on Twitter, stating that his remarks were "offensive to many" and that he never intended to disparage any segment of society. He also apologized to Yamiche Alcindor, despite their contradictory views on assimilation.

On Fox News, Geraldo Rivera argued that Hispanics are assimilating at a faster rate than any other ethnic group in U.S. history. However, data from the Census Bureau shows that the fraction of U.S. households answering yes to the question of speaking a language other than English at home has risen steadily over the last three decades, reaching 22 percent in 2017.

Many of those who speak another language at home claim they also speak English well or very well, but further studies have shown that is not the case. Nearly half were found to speak English at a level below basic, also known as functional illiteracy.

The American Community Survey enables the Census Bureau to track the number of households who self-report that they speak a language other than English at home. In 39 U.S. counties, a majority of residents report that they speak a language other than English at home.

Brokaw's sons, John and Andy Schlafly, lead the continuing Phyllis Schlafly Eagles organizations with writing and policy work. Phyllis Schlafly (1924-2016) was a conservative activist and author who opposed the Equal Rights Amendment and was a prominent figure in the anti-feminist movement.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Faces Challenges in Steering Tax Reform and Year-End Deal

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner is facing the task of steering reluctant Republicans toward a year-end tax reform deal and a broader budget agreement. The focus in Washington is on the top rates for upper-income households, but before any tax reform, two critical questions need to be addressed: the revenue target and the standard of progressivity that will govern the revised code.

The 1980s tax reformers did not initially aim to eliminate the preferential treatment for capital gains; the capital gains rate ended up at 28 percent, nearly double what Mitt Romney has been paying and 8 points higher than what President Barack Obama wants. The 1986 tax reform effort, as counsel to the Joint Tax Committee, David Brockway testified in September, demonstrated that the same pressures will be even greater on any reform effort now.

The speaker's office admits that neither the revenue target nor the aggregate revenue commitment has been determined yet. Until these questions are answered, all the Washington talk is primarily speculation. Friday's White House meeting offers a fresh start, but Obama will have to show more give on the spending side of the ledger if he expects Boehner to steer reluctant Republicans toward a year-end deal.

The White House will have to address two contentious issues to change the tone: reforms in the food stamp program and action on a long-discussed change in the inflation index used to adjust government benefits as well as tax brackets. Each option risks the ire of certain groups, but thoughtful people in both parties can agree that long-range changes are needed.

The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has developed a model for a new CPI that eases the impact on the most elderly Social Security recipients and still saves about $150 billion over 10 years. In the case of food stamps, Obama bears responsibility for having turned a nutrition program into an economic stimulus machine. Reforms here could also make it easier to advance a long-delayed farm bill that promises billions in additional savings by ending an outdated system of direct cash payments to producers.

The House Agriculture Committee leadership got little credit for trying, but a bipartisan plan was developed that would have set a new national standard for food stamps to replace the patchwork quilt that has developed as cash-strapped governors bent the rules to help low-income families—all at federal expense.

Title: California Provides $75 Million in Cash Aid to Unauthorized Immigrants Excluded from Federal Aid Programs

Article:

California is implementing a taxpayer-funded program to provide $500 cash payments to unauthorized immigrants who have been excluded from traditional government aid programs due to their immigration status. The program, which is expected to benefit 150,000 individuals, is set to roll out on Monday, according to The New York Times.

Governor Gavin Newsom announced the program in a statement, stating, "Every Californian, including our undocumented neighbors and friends, should know that California is here to support them during this crisis." The $75 million program is funded by taxpayer dollars and will be conducted by phone to minimize in-person contacts. The maximum amount awarded per household is $1,000.

Applicants must demonstrate that they are unauthorized, jobless due to the pandemic, and do not qualify for unemployment programs or stimulus checks. The state has directed the funding to 12 nonprofit organizations, who will be responsible for evaluating applicants and distributing aid.

Over 2 million unauthorized immigrants reside in California, according to the California Public Policy Institute, and they constitute around 9% of its labor force. Many work in low-wage jobs in hotels and restaurants, which have been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

House Democrats approved a $3 trillion coronavirus spending package on Friday, which includes a provision that would allow unauthorized immigrants left out of the initial wave of $1,200 stimulus checks to qualify for a direct federal payment with their Taxpayer Identification Numbers. However, the legislation is facing opposition from Republicans, who have declared the Heroes Act dead on arrival in the Senate and consider the legislation mostly symbolic.

Around 11 million unauthorized immigrants reside in the US, according to the Pew Research Center.

Title: White House Adviser Urges GOP Support for President's Gun Control Plan

Article:

The Obama administration has called on Republicans to back the President's gun control plan, as expressed in interviews on Sunday morning. Dan Pfeiffer, a senior White House adviser, emphasized that 90% of Americans support the President's proposal to expand background checks for citizens purchasing guns.

Pfeiffer, in interviews on Fox News Sunday and ABC's This Week, urged Republicans to support what he termed as "common-sense measures." He stated, "You can’t get 90 percent of Americans to agree on the weather."

Pfeiffer expressed concern over a potential Republican filibuster, which he believes is obstructing the passage of significant and meaningful gun-reform legislation. He said, "It can get done, but what’s it’s going to require is for Republicans not to filibuster."

Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) may be a potential ally in this endeavor, as he suggested his party should not filibuster gun-control debates. McCain stated, "Everybody wants the same goal, which is to keep the guns out of the hands of criminals and people who are mentally disabled."

Former Rep. Asa Hutchinson (R-AR), now the director of the National Rifle Association's National School Shield Task Force, advocated for armed guards in schools to protect teachers and students. Hutchinson argued, "Whatever you do, even if you have universal background checks, bad guys are going to get guns, and it’s not going to diminish the need for security in schools."

However, Pfeiffer criticized the NRA's suggestions, which are supported by many Republicans, arguing that more guns would escalate the situation. He said, "There is no one who’s looked at these issues who thinks that that is the best response."

Pfeiffer concluded, "We should do more to make our schools safe, absolutely, but that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t also take common-sense measures that are supported by the majority of Americans."

Title: Scotland's Historic Referendum: Scotland's Future in Question

Article:

Scotland is deciding today whether to end 300 years of union with Great Britain and become an independent nation. The referendum, expected to have a significant impact regardless of the outcome, is taking place with a historically high turnout of 4,285,323 registered voters at 2,608 polling stations across the country. The result is expected early on Friday morning.

The question posed to voters is simple: "Should Scotland be an independent country?" Public opinion polls suggest a close vote, with the outcome uncertain. British Prime Minister David Cameron, in an emotional appeal, warned that a vote for independence would lead to a "painful divorce." He acknowledged the unpopularity of his conservative government among more liberal-minded Scots, stating, "If you don't like me—I won't be here forever. But if you leave the U.K., that will be forever."

President Obama and former President Bill Clinton have also weighed in, urging a "no" vote. Alex Salmond, the leader of the campaign for independence, cast his ballot in his home village of Aberdeenshire. He expressed optimism, stating, "We're in the hands of the people of Scotland, and there's no safer place to be than in the hands of the Scottish people."

The outcome of the vote is being closely watched in other independence-minded regions of the world, including Quebec, Catalonia, and Kashmir. Leighton Andrews, the public services minister for Wales, predicted "radical" constitutional change for the U.K. as a direct result of the vote. He stated, "I think it will have major implications for the U.K. regardless of the result of the referendum."

The referendum is a significant event in Scottish and British history, and the outcome will shape the future of Scotland and the United Kingdom.

Title: Former Pentagon Official's Criticism of Whistleblowing System Sparks Calls for Justice Department Reform

Article:

In an interview with the Financial Times, former CIA head David Petraeus, when asked about Edward Snowden, stated that Snowden should be prosecuted. Snowden, in response, has called for a whistleblower shield after a new Pentagon source's account undermines the idea that the inspector general's office offers a safe route for whistleblowers.

John Crane, who supervised the whistleblower-protection unit of the Pentagon inspector general, has provided a detailed account in Mark Hertsgaard's book, "Bravehearts: Whistle-Blowing in the Age of Snowden." Crane's account suggests that the inspector general's office, meant to aid whistleblowers, may instead put them in danger.

One of the cases Crane discusses is that of Thomas Drake, an NSA employee who took his concerns about warrantless surveillance to the inspector-general's office after the 9/11 attacks. Crane suspects that instead of protecting Drake, his identity was passed to the justice department.

The stakes for an inquiry at the US justice department, set to launch on 1 June, are high. The future of national security whistleblowing depends on the outcome. Will it follow Snowden's model or Drake's?

Snowden told ███ that there are no examples of whistleblowers who have faced no retaliation after disclosing classified information. Many in US national security circles dismiss Snowden as a traitor, a spy, or a Russian stooge. Others acknowledge that episodes like Drake's indicate the institutional deck is stacked against an insider seeking to warn of the dangers to freedom represented by bulk surveillance carried out by the US intelligence apparatus.

Crane, who lost his career for defending Drake, is conflicted about Snowden. He hopes that the US justice department inquiry will deter future Snowdens and convince them that they can work within the system. However, some, like Jesselyn Radack, a prominent whistleblower lawyer who represented Crane and Drake, are skeptical that the inquiry will yield the necessary reforms.

Tom Devine, another of Crane's attorneys, believes the inquiry is a step necessary to save a broken whistleblower system. Once the inquiry ends, probably next year, the office will alert Congress and the White House and post its work product online, providing a foundation for long-term efforts for reform.

One of the routes supposedly open to Snowden would have been to go to Congress. The problem with this is that the critical figures in Congress already knew about the scale of mass surveillance but did not act. It was left to Snowden to make his flight to Hong Kong.

Title: FBI Investigation into Alleged Russian Connections in Trump Campaign

Article:

FBI officials declined to comment on Monday regarding the ongoing investigation into potential links between the Russian government and the 2016 Republican presidential candidate, Donald Trump. Intelligence officials have stated in interviews over the past six weeks that apparent connections between some of Trump's aides and Moscow initially prompted the broad investigation. However, they have emphasized that Trump himself has not become a target of the investigation, and no evidence has emerged linking him or his associates directly to Russia's election operations.

At least one part of the investigation has involved Paul Manafort, Trump's campaign chairman for much of the year. Manafort, a veteran Republican political strategist, has had extensive business ties in Russia and other former Soviet states, particularly Ukraine, where he served as an adviser to the ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. The focus in Manafort's case was on his ties with a kleptocratic government in Ukraine—and whether he had declared the income in the United States—and not necessarily on any Russian influence over Trump's campaign, one official said.

In classified sessions in August and September, intelligence officials briefed congressional leaders on the possibility of financial ties between Russians and people connected to Trump. They focused particular attention on what cyberexperts said appeared to be a mysterious computer back channel between the Trump Organization and Alfa Bank, one of Russia's biggest banks, whose owners have longstanding ties to Putin.

FBI officials spent weeks examining computer data showing an odd stream of activity to a Trump Organization server and Alfa Bank. Computer logs obtained by The New York Times show that two servers at Alfa Bank sent more than 2,700 "look-up" messages—a first step for one system's computers to talk to another—to a Trump-connected server beginning in the spring. However, the FBI ultimately concluded that there could be an innocuous explanation, such as a marketing email or spam, for the computer contacts.

The most serious part of the FBI's investigation has focused on the computer hacks that the Obama administration now formally blames on Russia. That investigation also involves numerous officials from the intelligence agencies. Investigators have become increasingly confident, based on the evidence they have uncovered, that Russia's direct goal is not to support the election of Trump, as many Democrats have asserted, but rather to disrupt the integrity of the political system and undermine America's standing in the world more broadly.

The hacking reflected an intensification of spy-versus-spy operations that never entirely abated after the Cold War but that have become more aggressive in recent years as relations with Putin's Russia have soured.

Title: Former Northern Ireland First Minister and IRA Commander Martin McGuinness Dies

Article:

Martin McGuinness, the former first minister of Northern Ireland and a former commander of the Irish Republican Army (IRA), has passed away. His death was not unexpected, as he had stepped down as first minister in January due to a scandal involving his coalition partner, the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). However, McGuinness stated that he was stepping down for health reasons and would not seek re-election.

Throughout his life, McGuinness was a controversial figure due to his past as an IRA commander. In the latter half of his life, he transitioned from a violent revolutionary to a statesman. For many Irish people in their late 30s, McGuinness was known as one half of a double-act with Sinn Féin leader Gerry Adams during the early years of the peace process in the 1990s. McGuinness was often referred to as the "sinister minister" during this time.

In the latter part of his career, McGuinness became deputy first minister of Northern Ireland and worked alongside unionist leaders such as Ian Paisley, who was known as "Dr. No" due to his refusal to speak to Irish republicans for three decades. McGuinness and Paisley were later referred to as "the Chuckle Brothers" due to their apparent camaraderie.

McGuinness's tactics changed from violence to politics, with the ballot box replacing the gun, and symbolic measures taking on more and more significance. In 2011, he ran for the presidency of Ireland but did not win. Despite this, McGuinness's stock rose in the years following his political career, while Adams's stock fell.

McGuinness's IRA membership was not a secret, and he admitted his membership. Unlike Adams, who has been dogged by accusations of authorizing the murder of Jean McConville, one of the most controversial killings in the Irish conflict, McGuinness's past was viewed in a more sympathetic light, particularly as he was from and active in Derry during the Bloody Sunday massacre in 1972, when 26 unarmed civilians were shot, 14 of them fatally, by British soldiers.

McGuinness's IRA membership was not a secret, and a photographer who had been in a rival republican group once showed the author a letter, dated from the 1970s, that described the young IRA commander in Derry as a likely future major player. McGuinness's journey from gunman to statesman was real, and his legacy proves that even in this era of post-modern "plural narratives" and "fake news," brute facts and truth still matter.

Title: Senate Confirms Loretta Lynch as Attorney General, First Black Woman to Hold Post

Article:

Senators have confirmed Loretta Lynch as the new Attorney General, defeating an early filibuster attempt on Thursday morning. The final vote is scheduled for later in the afternoon, marking a significant milestone in civil rights history.

Loretta Lynch, a federal prosecutor in New York, will replace Eric H. Holder Jr. and become the first black woman to hold the top law enforcement post in the country. She cleared the filibuster with a 66-34 vote, with Republican opposition primarily directed at President Obama, whose policies she will be tasked with defending.

The opposition to Ms. Lynch stems from President Obama's clashes with Congress over immigration, health care, and environmental policy. Sen. John Cornyn, a Texas Republican who voted against Ms. Lynch, expressed concerns about her stance on the president's executive action on immigration.

President Obama nominated Ms. Lynch following the 2014 elections, hoping for quick action. However, Democrats delayed action on her during the lame-duck session of Congress, believing she would easily clear when the GOP took control in January. Instead, she languished as both sides clashed over abortion-funding provisions in a bill against human trafficking. An agreement this week cleared that snag, setting up the final Lynch vote.

Democrats have criticized the delays as a black mark for Republicans, whom they accused of thwarting civil rights history. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, stated, "At long last this embarrassment for the Senate is over and this triumph for the American people will occur."

Loretta Lynch grew up in a North Carolina still grappling with civil rights issues. She was the valedictorian at her high school but was denied sole recognition due to her race. She graduated from Harvard College and obtained her law degree from Harvard Law School. She has twice served as U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York—first under President Clinton and beginning again under President Obama.

None of her opponents questioned her qualifications, and she has headed some of the Justice Department's highest-profile cases, including terrorism prosecutions and the case against former Rep. Michael Grimm, a New York Republican who resigned his seat and pleaded guilty.

The opposition to Ms. Lynch primarily stems from her defense of President Obama's policies, particularly his executive actions, which have drawn fierce pushback from Republicans. At her confirmation hearing, Ms. Lynch defended the Justice Department's legal reasoning underpinning Mr. Obama's deportation amnesty programs and refused to second-guess the president on a series of other actions.

Republicans also demanded to know how Ms. Lynch would be different from Mr. Holder, who has repeatedly clashed with the GOP, accused Mr. Obama's opponents of being motivated by race, and withheld documents from Congress—resulting in him being the first attorney general in history to be held in contempt of Congress.

At her confirmation hearing and in written responses to follow-up questions, Ms. Lynch insisted she would be different from Mr. Holder, though the only area she specifically identified where she might draw distinctions was on her willingness to be transparent.

Democrats said opposing Ms. Lynch because she defended the president was a troubling precedent to set. Sen. Claire McCaskill, a Missouri Democrat, stated, "This defies common sense... You must vote against a nominee for the Cabinet of the duly elected president of the United States because she agrees with the duly elected president of the United States? Think of the consequences of that vote. Think what that means to the future of advise and consent in the Senate."

However, Republicans argued that her agreement with Mr. Obama went beyond normal bounds and suggested she would not be the independent officer they insisted the attorney general needs to be. They contrasted her with Sally Quillian Yates, whom Mr. Obama nominated to be deputy attorney general and who cleared the Senate Judiciary Committee on an 18-2 vote Thursday morning, just minutes before the filibuster vote on Ms. Lynch.

Ms. Yates, who is white, is a prosecutor in Georgia, and had strong support of that state's two Republican senators, which helped her nomination. During her confirmation hearings, she generally defended the president's policies but did say she viewed the role of the Justice Department as being an independent constitutional authority whose clients are the American people, not the president or Congress.

"This may seem to some like a small point," said Sen. Charles E. Grassley, Iowa Republican and chairman of the committee, who helped shepherd Ms. Yates's nomination through the panel but said he was opposing Ms. Lynch.

Title: Senate Republicans Release Revised Obamacare Replacement Bill, Uncertainty Remains

Article:

In a revised version of their plan to replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), Senate Republicans have dropped some tax cuts for the wealthy, allowed for more insurance policies with limited coverage, and increased funding to fight the opioid addiction epidemic. However, it remains unclear whether the changes are sufficient to win over moderates concerned about the bill's cuts to Medicaid and private insurance subsidies, or whether conservatives are satisfied with the bill's repeal of enough of the Affordable Care Act's taxes and regulations.

The revised bill retains taxes on investment income and high earners imposed by the Affordable Care Act (ACA). It no longer eliminates the ACA's limit on executive pay that insurance companies can write off as a corporate tax deduction. The bill still repeals other ACA taxes, including those on tanning beds, sectors of the health care industry, and on high-cost employer-provided insurance plans.

The bill would still provide subsidies to reduce the cost of premiums, but these subsidies could be reduced for some individuals. The income limit for subsidies would be lowered slightly and would become less generous. People with tax-advantaged Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) can use their HSA contributions to pay for premiums, instead of just for health services and products as they can now.

The bill would allow anyone to buy catastrophic plans, including those who qualify for subsidies. These plans have low premiums but high deductibles and limited benefits.

If an insurer offers plans that meet the ACA's requirements, including covering minimum benefits and not charging sicker people more, the insurer could receive funding to help cover the cost of sick customers. However, it's unclear whether the funding would be enough to keep the plans affordable. Because insurers would also be able to sell plans that don't meet the ACA's requirements, this could segment the market into sick and healthy people, potentially increasing costs for those with pre-existing conditions.

The bill would not change the ACA's rule that dependent children can stay on a parent's plan until age 26. However, enhanced federal funding for the low-income adults who became newly qualified would be phased out, ending after 2024. Federal support for traditional Medicaid would also still be scaled back.

The revised bill does include changes to the way hospitals are paid by the federal government to help cover the bills of the uninsured, which are expected to increase. If a state has a health emergency, the extra spending needed would not count toward the state's new limit on federal Medicaid dollars.

The bill still effectively removes the ACA's requirement that most people buy insurance by eliminating the tax penalties for failing to do so. Those who have a gap in their insurance coverage would have to wait six months before they can re-enroll.

The bill would still end the ACA's penalties for larger employers who do not offer insurance to workers. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has said fewer employers will offer coverage if that change is made.

The revised bill increases funding to states for addiction services, including $45 billion instead of the $2 billion in the initial version. However, it could still fall short of what's needed.

As in the original version, insurance plans sold through the exchanges could not cover abortion services. There's an exception for abortions performed to save the life of the mother, or to end a pregnancy that resulted from rape or incest. The bill would also continue to block Planned Parenthood from receiving Medicaid funding for a year. GOP Sens. Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska oppose this provision.

Title: Republican Congressman Justin Amash's Call for Impeachment of President Trump Based on Mueller Report

Article:

Republican Congressman Justin Amash of Michigan has stated that President Donald Trump's actions, as detailed in the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report, constitute "impeachable conduct." The House of Representatives defines impeachable conduct, and this point seems to be a subject of debate among Trump's supporters and critics.

Amash's assertion, which makes him the first Republican legislator to publicly support this view, has received mixed reactions. Senator Mitt Romney, the former Republican presidential nominee, praised Amash's "courageous statement" but disagreed with his conclusion, arguing that there are insufficient elements to establish a case for obstruction of justice.

However, the Mueller report suggests that at least some of Trump's attempts to interfere with the investigation of Russian efforts to influence the 2016 presidential election could be considered obstruction of justice. These attempts include Trump's efforts to stop the FBI investigation of his former national security adviser, repeated demands for Mueller's removal, pressuring White House Counsel Donald McGahn to deny Trump's attempts to fire Mueller, urging his attorney general to take control of the Russia investigation and limit its scope, and discouraging witnesses from cooperating with it.

Mueller's report also makes it clear that the president cannot obstruct justice by exercising his constitutional powers, which include control of the Justice Department. However, this does not cover Trump's attempts to influence the testimony of witnesses such as McGahn, his former lawyer Michael Cohen, and his former campaign chairman Paul Manafort.

The fact that Trump's efforts to impede federal investigations were mostly unsuccessful does not exonerate him, as attempted obstruction is also a crime. Furthermore, the report did not find evidence that anyone in the Trump campaign illegally conspired with Russian agents, but Trump's actions could still be seen as an abuse of power that betrays the public trust.

Amash argues that impeachable offenses extend beyond provable statutory violations to abuses of power that betray the public trust. Trump's own lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, has admitted that it would be "unthinkable" for Trump to pardon himself, which could lead to immediate impeachment.

While both parties seem to agree that impeachment might be politically unwise given the current political climate, the decision to tolerate presidential behavior that potentially obstructs justice could send a significant message about the standards of presidential conduct that Congress is willing to accept.

Title: Senate Overcomes Filibuster, Advances Kavanaugh Nomination Amidst Controversy

Article:

The United States Senate overcame a Democrat-led filibuster on Friday, moving Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh one step closer to confirmation. The 51-49 vote saw one defection from each party, resulting in a 50-50 tie that was broken by the Vice President, allowing Kavanaugh to clear the procedural hurdle. A final confirmation vote is scheduled for Saturday, but its outcome remains uncertain.

The vote was a significant milestone for Republicans, who viewed it as an opportunity to send a message of unity amidst deep political divisions and partisan rancor. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stated, "We know the Senate is better than this. We know the nation deserves better than this."

Four senators were undecided leading up to the vote: Republican Sens. Susan Collins, Jeff Flake, and Lisa Murkowski, and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin. Murkowski joined Democrats in the filibuster, but the other three voted to end debate and advance to a final vote. Collins, however, has indicated that her vote Friday morning was only to overcome the filibuster, and she will announce her final stance on confirming Judge Kavanaugh later in the day.

Democratic leaders criticized the confirmation process, accusing Republicans of rushing the judge through too quickly, questioning his conservatism, and suggesting that President Trump chose Kavanaugh to shield himself from legal troubles related to the special counsel's Russia probe. They also cited the recent sexual misconduct allegations against Kavanaugh.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat at the center of the confirmation battle, stated, "Based on all the factors we have before us, I do not believe Judge Kavanaugh has earned this seat." However, Democrats acknowledged that they would likely have faced similar opposition to any pick made by President Trump.

Republicans had initially hoped to have Kavanaugh on the high court in time for the justices' new session, which began earlier this week. However, last-minute sexual assault allegations disrupted this schedule, necessitating new hearings and an updated FBI investigation.

The hearing and the FBI probe did not appear to resolve the deep divide among Americans regarding Kavanaugh's credibility. Christine Blasey Ford, Kavanaugh's chief accuser, alleges he assaulted her at a high school party in 1982. Witnesses identified by Ford have refuted her story, and Kavanaugh has vehemently denied her claim.

Despite this, support for Ford remains strong, particularly among anti-Trump activists who view Kavanaugh's confirmation as an opportunity to deal a significant blow to the president. They also fear that Kavanaugh's conservative views could shift the court's balance and lead to right-wing activism.

The controversy surrounding Kavanaugh's nomination has sparked protests both inside and outside the Senate, with hundreds being arrested inside congressional office buildings on Thursday. For Democratic senators, there was little they liked about the judge or the process.

Despite the production of a record number of documents for review, millions of pages were not produced, leading to suspicions that significant information remains hidden. Democrats also complained about Kavanaugh's behavior during the confirmation hearings, citing his angry denunciation of the allegations against him as non-judicial.

Friday's vote to overcome the filibuster sets up a final vote on Saturday, although there are potential complications. One Republican senator plans to attend his daughter's wedding on Saturday, which could affect the timing of the vote. Additionally, Sen. Jeff Merkley is pursuing a lawsuit to request a judge to intervene and order the release of more documents from Kavanaugh's past, which the Oregon Democrat hopes will delay the confirmation process.

Title: U.S. Loses Leverage in Syria Chemical Weapons Negotiations, According to Rep. Mike Rogers

Article:

Washington, CNN - Republican Rep. Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, argued Sunday that the United States lost its leverage in the negotiations over chemical weapons in Syria, giving Russia a strategic advantage. If Congress had authorized the president to strike Syria, things would have looked more favorable for the U.S., according to Rogers.

Rogers, speaking on CNN's "State of the Union," said, "I think [the president's] hand would have been strengthened significantly if Congress would have given him the authority for a surgical strike to degrade [Syria's] chemical weapons use and he look like a commander in chief."

Rogers criticized the president for failing to adequately explain why an attack against Syria would be in the United States' security interests. He stated, "All of that confusion allowed Putin to step in and fill the void."

On Saturday, the U.S. and Russia reached a deal on a framework that would allow Syria to hand over control of its chemical weapons. The deal, however, does not include a threat of military force should Syria fail to follow through with giving up its stockpiles.

Rogers told CNN chief political correspondent Candy Crowley, "Not one ounce of chemical weapons came off the battlefield, but we've given up every ounce of our leverage when it comes to trying to solve the broader Syrian problem, because we've taken away a credible military threat."

Rogers warned of the "indecisiveness" of the Obama administration in the past few weeks, stating that it "gave the diplomatic advantage" to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff of California was less pessimistic about the diplomatic deal, calling it a "very positive step." Schiff acknowledged it's been an "ugly" process and it's going to be "tough" to ensure Syria follows through, but he said it's "the best pathway we've seen in the last couple years."

On Putin, Schiff downplayed the Russian president's strategic abilities, saying he's less like a master chess player and more like "a lawyer who lost control of his client."

President Barack Obama, in an interview that aired Sunday, said he's not concerned with criticism of his handling of the Syria situation, stating that Washington tends to make judgments based on style rather than substance.

Obama said, "We know that, 'cause that's exactly how they graded the Iraq War - until it ended up… blowing up in our face." He added, "I'm less concerned about style points, I'm much more concerned about getting the policy right."

Watch State of the Union with Candy Crowley Sundays at 9am ET. For the latest from State of the Union, click here.

Title: "Economic Recovery and the 2016 Presidential Election: An Analysis of Obama's Legacy and Clinton's Loss"

Article:

The article discusses the economic recovery under President Barack Obama and the 2016 presidential election, focusing on the role of the economy in the election outcome and the legacy of Obama's policies.

The article asserts that the economy, under Obama's administration, has recovered more quickly and strongly than other wealthy countries following the 2008 financial crisis. It is noted that Donald Trump, the eventual winner of the 2016 presidential election, will inherit an economy that is vastly different from the one Obama inherited in 2009.

The article argues that Obama's policies, such as the stimulus, making the tax code more progressive, protecting consumers and the environment, and ensuring greater access to healthcare, contributed to the strong job and wage growth. It is suggested that the Republican Party, and not Trump, should not be given credit for the economic improvements achieved under Obama's policies.

The article also discusses the role of Hillary Clinton's campaign in the 2016 election, stating that Clinton lost the election due to a small number of votes in three states. It is noted that Clinton's campaign chose to focus more on Trump's bigotry rather than on the economy and her plans to help the economically vulnerable.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of the economy in future elections and the need for Democrats to focus on the economy and talk about their record of creating an economy that works for the majority of Americans. It is suggested that Republican policies cause economic messes and benefit the wealthy, while Democratic policies help the economically vulnerable and create an economy that benefits the 99%.

The article also mentions Ian Reifowitz, the author of "Obama's America: A Transformative Vision of Our National Identity." The article does not provide specific details about the book or its content.

Title: Obama and Romney Disagree on U.S. Troop Presence in Iraq During 2012 Debate

Article:

During Monday night's presidential debate, former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama disagreed on the U.S. troop presence in Iraq. The nearly nine-year war in Iraq remains a contentious issue, and the candidates' claims were examined.

The Status of Forces Agreement signed in 2008 called for U.S. troops to withdraw from Iraqi cities by 2009 and leave the country entirely by the end of 2011. Obama, who opposed the 2003 U.S.-led invasion of Iraq while still a state legislator in Illinois, ran for president on a platform of ending that war. However, his administration, which took office after the agreement was signed, tried to negotiate with Iraq to keep between 3,000 and 5,000 American troops in the country to help train Iraqi security forces.

Obama stated during the debate that Romney wanted more troops in Iraq, but Romney, who supported the invasion, said Obama wanted to keep U.S. troops there longer but couldn't get the Iraqis to agree. Romney said, "There was an effort on the part of the president to have a Status of Forces Agreement, and I concurred in that, and said that we should have some number of troops that stayed on."

Romney also stated that Obama's approach to keeping troops in Iraq was precipitous, and he believed a larger force should have remained in Baghdad. In December 2011, with the final pullout looming, Romney told Fox News Sunday that the Obama administration was ending the American presence "in a precipitous way, and we should have left 10,000, 20,000, 30,000 personnel there to help transition to the Iraqis' own military capabilities."

The last U.S. convoy left Iraq in December 2011, and Obama touted that as a promise kept, saying Americans would be leaving "with their heads held high." The president has also emphasized this point during his re-election campaign. However, Romney has consistently criticized the Obama administration for its failure to reach a deal with the Iraqi government on keeping those troops there.

In December 2011, with the final pullout approaching, Romney stated that the "costly gains" made in Iraq were slipping away. He said, "The president tried -- and failed -- to secure a responsible and gradual drawdown that would have better secured our gains."

Both candidates' statements are based on factual events. The Obama administration did attempt, unsuccessfully, to extend the presence of a scaled-back U.S. training mission in Iraq, while Romney has said Washington should have kept a considerably larger force in Baghdad. The information provided in this article is neutral and factual, avoiding personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language.

Title: Sioux Tribes in South Dakota Refuse to Remove Coronavirus Checkpoints on Reservation Roads

Article:

The Sioux tribes in the U.S. state of South Dakota are maintaining their coronavirus checkpoints on roads that pass through their reservations, despite a request from Governor Kristi Noem to remove them. In a letter sent to several tribal leaders last week, Governor Noem stated that the checkpoints were illegal. However, the Sioux tribes argue that these checkpoints are necessary to prevent the virus from entering their reservations, as their limited healthcare facilities would not be able to handle an outbreak.

Currently, only essential travel is allowed into the reservations for individuals who have not traveled from a Covid-19 hotspot. Those entering must also complete a health questionnaire. Governor Noem has threatened to take the Oglala Sioux and Cheyenne River Sioux tribes to federal court if they do not comply with her demand to remove the checkpoints.

In response to the governor's letter, Harold Frazier, chairman of the Cheyenne River Sioux tribe, stated, "We will not apologize for being an island of safety in a sea of uncertainty and death." He added, "You continuing to interfere in our efforts to do what science and facts dictate seriously undermines our ability to protect everyone on the reservation."

Oglala Sioux President Julian Bear Runner stated that Governor Noem's decision "threatened the sovereign interest of the Oglala people." The main purpose of the checkpoints, according to Mr. Frazier, is to monitor and track the virus. He told CNN, "We want to ensure that people coming from 'hotspots' or highly infected areas, we ask them to go around our land."

The reservations are ill-equipped to deal with a coronavirus outbreak, with the nearest critical care facilities three hours away. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe only operates an eight-bed facility on the reservation and has no intensive care unit for the 12,000 people that live on the reservation.

South Dakota is one of a handful of U.S. states that have not issued stay-at-home orders to their residents. As of Sunday, there were 198 cases of Covid-19 among Native Americans in the state, according to state health department figures quoted by CNN. The state has more than 3,500 confirmed cases and at least 34 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University. The U.S. has the highest number of virus deaths and cases in the world, but it also has one of the biggest populations and widespread testing.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Constitutionality of Independent Payment Advisory Board in Obamacare Case

Article:

The Supreme Court is set to review a case challenging the constitutionality of the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), a health care rationing agency established under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The case, Coons v. Lew, argues that IPAB's broad authority to control Medicare costs and implement price controls, levy taxes, and take actions related to the Medicare program without presidential, congressional, or judicial oversight, represents the most extreme consolidation of government power in American history.

The IPAB is tasked with controlling Medicare costs, and the law grants it broad authority to implement price controls, levy taxes, and take actions deemed "related to the Medicare program." The law makes this group of unelected, unaccountable bureaucrats immune from control by the president, Congress, or the courts.

The law requires IPAB to publish annual "recommendations" for controlling Medicare spending, but these recommendations automatically become law without the president's signature, and the law bars Congress from stopping them unless Congress presents an alternative plan that can meet IPAB's spending reductions. The law even prohibits Congress from abolishing IPAB outside of a short window in 2017, and repeal must be supported by an unprecedented supermajority. Furthermore, the law blocks the courts from reviewing IPAB decisions.

The administration argues that IPAB is not a danger because Obamacare explicitly prohibits it from rationing health care. However, the law does not define "rationing care," and it is unclear whether IPAB's actions would qualify as rationing if they set the price of a lifesaving surgery so low that no doctor would perform it or taxed a drug or device so much that no patient could pay for it.

Proponents argue that it was necessary to surrender Congress' role in setting Medicare policy because Congress cannot stand up to the political pressure it receives when members try to cut Medicare spending and services. However, in the case of IPAB, the cure is argued to be far more dangerous than the disease.

The Constitution's authors intended public pressure to be a key feature of the constitutional government, not a bug, because it serves as an important check on power. Legislators are responsible to their constituents and checked by the other branches of government, but bureaucrats face no such accountability.

Earlier this year, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed this challenge to IPAB's constitutionality, stating that because President Obama has not yet appointed anyone to IPAB, it would decline to rule until IPAB flexes its muscles. The unconstitutional lawmaking process itself, though, not any particular edict, must be reviewed.

Obamacare states that if the president does not appoint anyone to the board, the secretary of health and human services—a single unelected official—gets to exercise IPAB's vast powers alone. The president's failure to act, therefore, only worsens IPAB's already egregious violations of the Constitution. Given IPAB's unprecedented immunity from control by any of the three constitutional branches of government, if the court does not act now, it may be too late to decide the case later.

Christina Sandefur, a senior lawyer at the Goldwater Institute, argues that the Supreme Court should take up the IPAB case. Never before has Congress gone to such an extreme length to relinquish so much power over such an important matter to an agency that is not answerable to the American people.

Title: Russian National Charged for Conspiring to Interfere in 2018 Midterm Elections

Article:

A Russian national, Elena Alekseevna Khusyaynova, has been charged by the U.S. for conspiring to interfere in the 2018 midterm elections, according to the FBI and the Department of Justice. Khusyaynova, a 44-year-old from St. Petersburg, is alleged to have participated in a conspiracy to "sow discord in the U.S. political system and to undermine faith in our democratic institutions."

The government claims that the conspiracy is part of a 2016 influence operation that dates back to at least May 2014. Khusyaynova, who is the chief accountant of "Project Lakhta," reportedly oversaw a $35 million budget from 2014 to 2018, covering expenses related to activists, social media advertising, and promoting news postings on social networks. The Justice Department states that the proposed operating budget for 2018 alone was over $10 million.

John Carlin, former head of the Justice Department's National Security division and author of "Dawn of the Code War," told ███ that Russia is spending millions to undermine American democracy. "We're under attack now, and our elections are at risk," he said. "There is no way this is taking place without the knowledge of Putin himself."

The indictment describes a large-scale operation overseen by a management group, with several departments, including graphics and design, analysis, search engine optimization, IT, and finance. The conspiracy allegedly attempted to appear as American political activists, hiding the fact that they were Russian. The operation "inflamed passions" on various topics, including immigration, gun control, the Confederate flag, race relations, LGBT issues, the Women's March, and the NFL national anthem controversy.

The conspiracy provided guidance to social media writers, suggesting that people of color who are LGBT are "less sophisticated" than those who are white. The indictment also states that infographics "work well among LGBT and their liberal allies," but not so well with conservatives.

President Trump, when addressing the news with reporters on Thursday, stated that it had nothing to do with his campaign. "It had nothing to do with my campaign," the president said. "All of the hackers and all everybody that you see—nothing to do with my campaign. If they're hackers, a lot of them probably liked Hillary Clinton better than me."

Earlier in the day, in a rare joint statement, the nation's top law enforcement and intelligence agencies issued a warning against ongoing campaigns by Russia, China, and other foreign actors, including Iran, to undermine confidence in democratic institutions and influence public sentiment and government policies. The statement noted that there had not been any evidence, to date, of a compromise or disruption of election infrastructure.

Title: Senator Bernie Sanders Accuses President Trump of Lying, Highlights Government Shutdown Impact

Article:

Independent Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who previously ran for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2016, accused President Donald Trump of lying during a live YouTube stream. In his address, Sanders pointed out several instances of misstatements made by the president regarding immigration and the border wall.

"It gives me no pleasure to tell you what most of you already know, and that is that President Trump lies all of the time," Mr. Sanders said. "In remarks tonight and in recent weeks regarding immigration and the wall, he continues to lie."

Sanders then discussed various pressing issues in the United States, such as the lack of health insurance for millions of Americans, the lack of retirement savings for elderly people, the burden of student debt for millions more, and the threat of global climate change. He argued that these challenges were more critical than the issue of illegal immigration.

"We don't need to create artificial crises," Mr. Sanders said. "We have enough real crises."

President Trump is scheduled to visit McAllen, Texas, on Thursday, while Democrats plan to bring up a series of bills this week to reopen shuttered parts of the government, including the Internal Revenue Service to allow tax refunds to be paid and the Agriculture Department to ensure food assistance and farmer support payments can be made.

The Treasury Department and the I.R.S. will be addressed first on Thursday, followed by the Agriculture and Interior Department programs, including national parks, on Thursday, and transportation and housing programs on Friday.

"We are going to, daily, urge and take efforts to open up the government," said Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the majority leader. "Whatever problems confront us, they are exacerbated—not relieved—by shutting down government."

A group of Senate Democrats spent Tuesday evening taking turns on the Senate floor, urging Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky to bring up the House-passed legislation to reopen the government. The dozen Democrats, led by Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia and Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, aim to highlight the harm from the shutdown on federal workers and those who benefit from government programs.

Title: Bill Maher Apologizes for Using Racial Slur on 'Real Time'

Article:

Bill Maher, the host of HBO's Real Time, offered an on-air apology for using a racial slur during a conversation about race with political activist and Georgetown professor Michael E. Dyson on the show last week. The apology came during an extended conversation where Maher aimed to clear the air over his use of the racial epithet during an interview with Sen. Ben Sasse (R-Neb.).

Maher expressed remorse, stating, "I wanted you to come by here because I want you to school me. I did a bad thing." Dyson responded, "A very bad thing."

Maher acknowledged the harm caused by the slur, stating, "That word, I do not care who you are, has caused pain." He added that his apology was "sincere" and that he regretted using the word, regardless of any malice intended.

The entire conversation between Maher and Dyson can be watched below.

Later in the show, hip-hop artist turned actor Ice Cube addressed Maher's use of the racial slur. Ice Cube said, "When I hear my homies say it, it doesn't feel like venom. When I hear a white person say it, it's like a knife."

Last weekend, Maher issued an apology in which he admitted "the word was offensive" and expressed regret for using it. HBO called the comment "inexcusable and tasteless" and announced they would edit that part out for future airings of the episode.

However, the fallout did not stop. Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.) canceled his appearance on Friday's episode. He was to have appeared in the same post-monologue, single-guest interview in which Sasse participated.

In an interview that aired Thursday on SiriusXM's Family Politics, Franken, who still considers Maher a friend, said, "He's been around long enough to know that that's not a word white people can use. It just is not. And he should have known that." Franken added that he did not want to be associated with the controversy before appearing on the show.

Title: Psychological Research Suggests News Media Reinforces Selection Biases in Politics and Race

Article:

A growing body of psychological research indicates that news media may inadvertently reinforce selection biases in politics and race, leading to less empathy and understanding among different groups of people. This selection bias, according to researchers, is not a result of an explicit desire to hate, but rather a more insidious fact that it seems correct.

David Pietraszewski, a postdoctoral fellow at the Max Planck Institute in Germany, explains that when people express opinions that reflect different political parties, our minds automatically and spontaneously assign them to rival coalitions. This phenomenon, he says, is due to our needs for certainty and sameness, which can overshadow our ability to consider alternate possibilities.

In a recent study published in the journal Cognition, Pietraszewski and a team of evolutionary psychologists found that politics and race demarcate the groups people form the most, and in a mutually exclusive way. If politics divide people, race does not play a significant factor unless it causes people to form groups.

John Tooby, study co-author and professor of anthropology at the University of California, Santa Barbara, notes that successful politicians like Benjamin Disraeli, Arnold Schwarzenegger, or Barack Obama need not be ethnically the same as the majority of their supporters. "Coalition is the real coin of the evolved mind, not race," Tooby said.

Temple Northup, an assistant professor at the University of New Hampshire's Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, argues that the brain's susceptibility to picking sides may not deserve blame. Instead, he suggests that the quality of our thoughts is only as good as the information it's fed.

Northup recently investigated the extent to which news media can influence people's implicit racial bias. In several studies using the Implicit Association Test (IAT), he found that reading a newspaper about poor race relations or watching a newscast about foreign tension increased people's implicit bias on the IAT. This did not mean people were strictly racist, but it did reveal hints of the news' influence.
