Northup concluded that given that long-term exposure to media stereotypes seems to influence evaluations of African-Americans and foreigners, more research investigating this implicit effect is needed. Among other duties, news organizations have a responsibility to inform with neutrality, not just in how they cover stories but what it is they're covering. The emerging research suggests that goal is seldom achieved.

According to Pietraszewski, consumers of news have a simple and effective way to avoid the traps of ugly selection biases: cooperation. By crossing the previously formed boundaries, people can reduce racial discrimination and political polarization. "Reducing racial discrimination or political polarization will be no easier or harder than changing patterns of cooperation," Pietraszewski said.

Title: Washington State Legalizes Marijuana Use, but Driving Under the Influence Remains Illegal

Article:

As of Thursday, the possession and use of marijuana is legal in the state of Washington. However, driving under the influence of marijuana is not. This fine line is a topic of discussion among law enforcement and prosecutors.

Seattle Deputy City Attorney Craig Sims stated, "I don't feel we are in uncharted territory -- I know we are." Possessing marijuana is now legal in Washington, Colorado, and 17 other states for medical use. Unlike alcohol, there is no national legal limit for marijuana. Some states have a zero-tolerance policy, while others, like Colorado and California, leave it up to the discretion of the arresting officer.

Research shows that marijuana can cause dizziness, slowed reaction time, and affect coordination and judgment. Drivers under the influence of marijuana are more likely to drift and swerve, according to research in the Netherlands.

California Highway Patrol drug recognition expert Sgt. Tyler Eccles explained, "First and most important is an inability or reduced ability to divide one's attention." He also noted that those driving under the influence of marijuana have a reduced ability to perceive time and distance.

Supporters of legalization argue that marijuana is less debilitating than alcohol, and that marijuana smokers are more aware of being impaired than those who drink. This debate was prominent in Colorado this summer, which considered adopting a standard of five nanograms per milliliter of blood, above which would have qualified as DUI-D, or driving while under the influence of drugs.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration states that peak THC concentrations are reached during the act of smoking, and within three hours, they generally fall to less than 5 nanograms. However, researchers say THC is stored in body fat and can remain detectable weeks after use in heavy pot smokers.

In Colorado, the pot lobby successfully argued that innocent people could be found guilty based on prior use and show no signs of impairment. The legislature there agreed and defeated the bill. In Washington state, advocates knew the ballot measure would only pass with voters, especially those in conservative eastern Washington, with the 5-nanogram standard.

Sims stated, "Because we are early on in the research phase, it is very difficult to tell if that 5-nanogram level will change, similar to how DUI standards have evolved over the years." He added, "There absolutely needs to be some public education campaign to educate John Q. citizen on the effects of marijuana."

The exact amount of marijuana needed to reach five nanograms is unknown, as THC concentrations vary based on where and how the marijuana is grown, and how much is consumed. Eccles stated, "People always want to know how much does it take to reach five nanograms. That is nearly impossible to determine."

In practical terms, in Washington, police will still have to observe signs of impaired driving before pulling someone over. Drivers will likely undergo some type of field test. If the officer believes the driver is impaired, they would be taken to a hospital where blood would be drawn. Tests above five nanograms would automatically subject the driver to a DUI conviction. With no priors, they may receive a day in jail and a fine.

Title: Colorado Baker Faces Third Legal Attack Over Refusal to Bake Cake for Gender Transition Celebration

Article:

Jack Phillips, a baker in Lakewood, Colorado, is facing a third legal action after declining to bake a cake for a gender transition celebration. The U.S. Supreme Court previously ruled that Colorado's Civil Rights Commission had acted with "religious hostility" in targeting Phillips for his refusal to bake a wedding cake for a same-sex couple in 2017.

Autumn Scardina, the complainant in the second action against Phillips, is the individual behind the third legal attack. Scardina, who is also a lawyer, requested a birthday cake to celebrate her gender transition.

The legal doctrine of "public accommodations" was initially used to address racial segregation during the civil-rights era. However, the author argues that the situation of gay Americans in the 21st century is not comparable to that of African Americans in the 1940s. The author suggests that accommodating religious principles of those with traditional views of marriage in this matter requires only a "trivial and largely symbolic concession."

The author criticizes the legal actions against Phillips as harassment and coercion, stating that the goal is not to integrate gay Americans into civil life but to bully and force dissidents into conformity. The author labels this harassment as "persecution" and calls for legal and political measures to stop it.

The article concludes with a call for maturity from a few people in Colorado, suggesting that the ongoing legal actions against Phillips are unjust and unwarranted.

Title: US Implements Ban on Certain E-Cigarette Flavors Amid Health Concerns for Teens

Article:

The United States has implemented a nationwide ban on mint and fruit-flavored e-cigarette cartridges, following concerns regarding the increasing vaping prevalence among teenagers. The ban applies to these flavors offered in cartridge-based e-cigarettes, including popular pods sold by Juul.

Menthol and tobacco flavors, as well as fruit flavors delivered in other ways, will still be allowed. The action has been under consideration for over a year, with several states passing similar rules. South Korea, India, and Brazil are among the numerous countries that have announced sweeping vaping bans, while others, like China, have imposed restrictions.

Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar stated that the Trump administration aims to offer adults an alternative to traditional cigarettes while addressing growing addiction to e-cigarettes among teenagers. He said, "By prioritizing enforcement against the products most widely used by children, our action today seeks to strike the right public health balance."

According to US health regulators, 55 people have died, and more than 2,500 people have been hospitalized with injuries linked to vaping. Investigators believe vitamin E acetate, which is sometimes added to marijuana vaping products, is playing a role in the crisis.

In September, President Trump announced the US would ban all e-cigarette flavors except tobacco, but the administration softened its stance after industry pushback. "We have to protect our families. At the same time, it's a big industry. We want to protect the industry," Mr. Trump said this week.

Juul, the largest e-cigarette company in the US, had already withdrawn its flavored pods from the market, but Thursday's action compels competitors to make a similar move within 30 days. Advocates for stricter rules have expressed concerns that teens may switch to menthol if other options are eliminated. However, officials stated they would take action against menthol and tobacco-flavored e-cigarettes if the Food and Drug Administration observes a rise in their use among teens.

The US also recently increased the age for purchasing tobacco products to 21. E-cigarettes are also subject to these rules.

Title: Social Security Benefits Projected to Reduce by 23% by 2034

Article:

The Social Security Administration has warned that by 2034, the payroll taxes collected will be sufficient to pay only about 77% of scheduled benefits. This impending crisis, often referred to as an "economic tsunami," is a result of the declining ratio of workers to beneficiaries and the increasing number of Social Security beneficiaries.

According to the Trustees of Social Security, the problem is fueled by two factors. First, from now until 2034, the ratio of workers paying taxes to support each Social Security beneficiary will decline significantly from 3:1 to 2:1. In 1970, this ratio was nearly 4:1. Second, by 2034, the total number of beneficiaries is projected to reach 87 million—41% more than the number in 2017.

The issue is particularly relevant to Baby Boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, as they account for a significant portion of the beneficiaries. In 2019, there will be 72 million Baby Boomers. Beginning in 2026, the so-called "bulge years" will occur, when all Boomers, including the youngest born in 1964, will have turned 62 and be eligible to collect retirement benefits.

In 2034, when the oldest Boomers turn 88, the "bulge" is projected to burst, and only 77% of benefits can be paid. This reduction has the potential to significantly impact the nation, especially considering that Social Security is the government's second-largest annual budget expense at $967.5 billion, surpassed only by Medicare/Medicaid at $1.085 trillion.

The cost of Social Security is projected to increase to $1.166 trillion by 2022, surpassing Medicare/Medicaid. Meanwhile, Social Security's liability is currently $17 trillion but is projected to grow to $24 trillion by 2022. The liability of Medicare/Medicaid, on the other hand, is currently $27.8 trillion and is expected to increase to $28.4 trillion by 2022.

The answer, according to the article, is bold leadership while the economic tsunami is still offshore. The article also notes that other government benefit programs, such as disability benefits, may also be forced to cut smaller monthly checks in the ensuing decades. The question is when and how the elected leaders will break the news to the American people, as Congress refuses to take any action to reform Social Security.

Title: Russian Warplanes Enter Ukrainian Airspace: Pentagon Calls for De-escalation

Article:

Russian military aircraft have reportedly entered Ukrainian airspace multiple times within the past 24 hours, according to a Pentagon official who described these incidents as "small probes." Army Col. Steve Warren, Pentagon spokesman, stated Friday evening that these incursions constitute a "handful of incidents" into Ukrainian airspace.

Col. Warren told The ███ that the Pentagon is urging Russia to take immediate steps to reduce tensions along the Ukraine border. "We call on the Russians to help deescalate the situation and not contribute to the deepening of this crisis," he said.

Earlier on Friday, Mr. Warren reported that Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel had attempted to contact Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu regarding the escalating tension between the two countries, but to no avail. Mr. Shoigu expressed concern among Defense Department officials after he announced Thursday that Russia planned to engage in a new series of military exercises near the Ukraine border. The military move, Mr. Shoigu said, is in response to ongoing NATO training exercises in Poland and the death of at least two pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine.

Currently, Ukraine reportedly has "a broad array of forces aligned along the Ukrainian border," Col. Warren said. Meanwhile, Ukraine's acting Defense Minister Mikhail Koval has stated that neither Russian troops nor aircraft have crossed into Ukraine during a military exercise. He made this comment while speaking to reporters on Saturday, according to the InSerbia Network Foundation website.

A separate Defense Department official declined to comment on Mr. Koval's contradicting statement. The Daily Beast is reporting that high-level contact between the Obama administration and the Kremlin has ceased. The last known conversation between President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin was on April 14, according to The Daily Beast.

However, Col. Warren told The Times that the relationship between the United States and Russia has not yet frozen over. Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey reportedly spoke with his counterpart, Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia Gen. Valery Gerasimov, on the same day.

Title: Commerce Department Reduces Tariffs on Canadian Newsprint Imports, but Publishers Call for Complete Abolition

Article:

The Commerce Department has announced a rollback of the tariff it imposed on newsprint imported from Canada, reducing the rate by as much as a third. The new tariffs range from 8 percent to 20 percent, down from the initial 30 percent imposed in May.

Publishers, however, are still advocating for the complete abolition of the tariffs, arguing that they are causing harm to the printing and publishing sectors, as well as local communities. David Chavern, president and CEO of the News Media Alliance, an umbrella industry group, stated, "These import duties on newsprint have already caused job losses in the printing and publishing sectors and have resulted in decreased news coverage in local communities."

Paul Boyle, head of Stop Tariffs on Printers & Publishers (STOPP), echoed this sentiment, saying, "It's a step in the right direction, but these tariffs are still causing damage and need to be repealed to protect newspapers."

Newsprint, the second biggest cost to publishers after workers, is now close to $800 a metric ton, according to Boyle. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette is one of the largest big-city dailies to take a dramatic step in response to the paper hike, reducing its print edition to five days from seven.

Other papers are also reducing the number of pages, chopping the trim size, and in some cases, dropping Sunday comics. The tariff is also affecting advertisers, who are printing fewer circulars to insert into papers, Boyle said.

Boyle argued that the financial harm to US paper mills is not due to Canadian paper, but rather a decade-long shift to digital advertising. He also noted that North American newsprint demand has decreased by 75 percent from 2000 to 2018. With tariffs forcing publishers to use less paper, demand will further erode, potentially harming the very paper producers the tariffs are intended to protect, Boyle warned.

The International Trade Commission is expected to hand down a ruling on the tariffs on Aug. 28, and Boyle is hoping for a complete abolition of the tariffs.

Title: Obama Nominates First African-American for Second Term Cabinet as Transportation Secretary

Article:

President Barack Obama's choice for transportation secretary, Anthony Foxx, will be the first African-American pick for his second term cabinet. The nomination was announced on Monday, following criticism for the lack of diversity within his administration's initial cabinet picks.

If confirmed by the Senate, Foxx, who is currently the mayor of Charlotte, North Carolina, would bring to two the number of African-Americans currently heading Cabinet agencies under Obama, joining Attorney General Eric Holder. In his first term, two other African-Americans – U.S. Trade Representative Ron Kirk and EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson – served in Obama's Cabinet.

The White House highlighted Foxx's achievements in opening a new runway at Charlotte/Douglas International Airport and his role in championing a new streetcar system in the city. He also played a significant part in organizing last summer's Democratic National Convention without any major logistical issues.

"As mayor of one of America's most vibrant cities, Anthony Foxx knows firsthand that investing in world-class infrastructure is vital to creating good jobs and ensuring American businesses can grow and compete in the global economy," the White House official said.

The nomination of Foxx is expected to help dispel the image of Obama naming only white men to top posts in his administration. The criticism began earlier this year, when the first cabinet picks of Obama's second term – Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, and Treasury Secretary Jack Lew – were all white men.

After taking heat, Obama named several women to prominent roles, including Sylvia Mathews Burwell as director of his budget office and Mary Schapiro as the chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission. However, groups like the Congressional Black Caucus criticized the lack of African-American nominees, with Rep. Bennie Thompson, D-Mississippi, stating that Obama "has once again overlooked his most loyal constituency."

Obama himself disputed the notion that his inner circle was lacking diversity, urging patience at a news conference in January. "I'm very proud that in the first four years we had as diverse, if not more diverse, a White House and a Cabinet than any in history," he said on January 14. "And I intend to continue that, because it turns out that when you look for the very best people, given the incredible diversity of this country, you're going to end up with a diverse staff and a diverse team."

"I think until you've seen what my overall team looks like, it's premature to assume that somehow we're going backwards," he added later. "We're not going backwards, we're going forward."

Title: Chinese State-Controlled Newspaper Spends Nearly $19 Million on U.S. Advertising and Printing Expenses Over Four Years

Article:

China Daily, an English-language newspaper controlled by the Chinese Communist Party, has paid American newspapers nearly $19 million for advertising and printing expenses over the past four years, according to documents filed with the Justice Department. The outlet has paid more than $4.6 million to The Washington Post and nearly $6 million to The Wall Street Journal since November 2016, the records show.

The newspaper has published paid supplements called "China Watch" in both The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal. These inserts, designed to resemble real news articles, often contain a pro-Beijing spin on contemporary news events.

For instance, a September 2018 insert touted an initiative pushed by Chinese President Xi Jinping with the headline: "Belt and Road aligns with African nations." The same insert ran a story titled "Tariffs to take toll on U.S. homebuyers" that asserted that U.S. tariffs on Chinese lumber would raise the cost of building homes in the United States.

In addition to The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal, China Daily paid for advertising in several other newspapers, including The New York Times ($50,000), Foreign Policy ($240,000), The Des Moines Register ($34,600), and CQ-Roll Call ($76,000). The outlet spent a total of $11,002,628 on advertising in U.S. newspapers, and another $265,822 on advertising with Twitter.

China Daily also paid out more than $7.6 million to newspapers and printing companies for its newspaper for U.S.-based readers, the Justice Department’s filings show. The Los Angeles Times, The Seattle Times, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, The Chicago Tribune, The Houston Chronicle, and The Boston Globe are all listed as clients of China Daily. The Chinese outlet paid the Los Angeles Times $657,523 for printing services, according to the FARA filings.

The Justice Department has required China Daily to disclose its activities semi-annually under the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA) since years. The most recent filing, which China Daily submitted on June 1, is the first to include detailed breakdowns of payments to American news outlets. The outlet disclosed those expenditures for the period between November 2016 and April 2020.

It is unclear if China Daily submitted the more detailed filings under pressure from the Justice Department or on its own. Pro-democracy groups have long warned about the Chinese government's attempts to push propaganda through American news outlets. Freedom House and the Hoover Institution have both drawn attention to China Daily's paid inserts in reports on the Chinese government's efforts to influence the media.

China Daily and other Beijing-controlled propaganda mills have come under intense scrutiny amid the coronavirus pandemic. Chinese government officials have tried to divert blame for the spread of the virus to the United States and other Western nations. Many of the regime-controlled outlets, including China Daily, have echoed the communist leaders' talking points.

China Daily has slowed its advertising expenditures in recent months, the filings show. China Daily last paid The Washington Post for advertising in December 2019. Its payments to The Wall Street Journal have been less than half their average amount since February 2020, the documents show. China Daily did not respond to a request for comment.

Title: U.S. Senators Attempt Temporary Funding Bill to End Government Shutdown; Trump Demands Border Wall Funding

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. senators made a renewed effort on Thursday to end a partial month-long government shutdown through a temporary funding bill, but President Donald Trump demanded a "down payment" for a border wall that Democrats reject. After the Republican-led Senate failed to advance two measures to reopen shuttered agencies, Democratic and Republican lawmakers urged quick passage of a three-week, stopgap funding bill to create time for talks on border security.

White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said such a measure would only work "if there is a large down payment on the wall." However, a spokesman for Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said Senate Democrats had made clear to Republicans that "they will not support funding for the wall."

Trump, who sparked the shutdown with his demand for $5.7 billion in funding for the U.S.-Mexico border wall, told reporters after the votes in the Senate: "We have no choice but to have a wall or a barrier, and if we don't have that, it's just not going to work."

Trump said that if Schumer and Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell come to a "reasonable" agreement to end the partial government shutdown, "I would support it, yes." McConnell said late on Thursday that talks were ongoing.

Democratic House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Trump's demand for a large down payment on a border wall "is not a reasonable agreement." The shutdown has left 800,000 federal workers without pay and struggling to make ends meet, as the effects on government services and the economy reverberate nationwide.

Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said he had spoken to Trump about a short-term funding bill. "All of us believe if we have three weeks with the government open, that we could find a way forward to produce a bill that he would sign, that would be good for everybody in the country," Graham said on the Senate floor.

Earlier, a bill backed by Trump to end the shutdown by funding the wall and a separate bill supported by Democrats to reopen shuttered agencies without such funding did not get the votes required to advance in the 100-member chamber. Trump has touted Republican unity during the longest shutdown in U.S. history, but in a sign of cracks in that resolve, or just a desire for compromise, six Republican senators voted with Democrats on their measure to reopen government agencies temporarily without money for a wall.

U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on Thursday urged furloughed federal workers to seek loans to pay their bills while adding in a CNBC interview that he could not understand why they were having trouble getting by. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi criticized Ross's comment, saying, "I don't understand why Ross would make the comment as hundreds of thousands of men and women are about to miss a second paycheck tomorrow."

Trump and Pelosi have been engaged in a standoff over border security funding, with Pelosi inviting Trump to give his State of the Union address in the House chamber next Tuesday, only to withdraw the invitation later due to the shutdown. Trump conceded late on Wednesday and said he would deliver the speech in the House in the "near future."

Title: Green New Deal: A Look at the Future of Climate Policy and Its Implications

Article:

The agricultural sector accounts for approximately 40% of the land in the United States, with the soil primarily functioning as a food factory. The food system is significantly influenced by the Farm Bill, which spends nearly $15 billion annually on subsidies and $10 billion on conservation measures. This legislation shapes what farmers grow and where, often benefiting large, industrially oriented operations.

Transitioning to a less carbon-intensive food production system is possible through changes in cropping, fertilizing, irrigation, and waste management, practices that are often more suitable for small farming. However, moving in this direction would challenge the status quo of big American agriculture.

The Green New Deal is one approach to addressing climate change, with its broad ambitions outlining the battleground for future climate policy debates. As reshaping environmental impact necessitates reworking the economy, there will inevitably be competing visions about who should benefit and what kind of economy we should build.

Centrist proposals focus on promoting investment in new technologies, with profits going to private researchers and manufacturers. If Trumpist nationalism survives its climate denialism, it may double down on supporting national energy industries and deny ethical responsibilities of global interdependence by building border walls against climate refugees. To the left of the Green New Deal, there may be louder calls to nationalize fossil fuels to keep them in the ground.

The idea that environmental policy could be separate from the larger economic order or from debates over fairness is a recent development, a product of a technocratic period in American politics. In 1970, Senator Edmund Muskie, a Democrat from Maine and the lead drafter of the Clean Air Act, argued that "man's environment" included "the shape of the communities in which he lives" and that "the only kind of society that has a chance" was "a society that will not tolerate slums for some and decent houses for others, rats for some and playgrounds for others, clean air for some and filth for others."

For Senator Muskie, environmentalism meant that no neighborhood or job should be toxic. In the three years that followed, the country adopted the most ambitious and effective environmental legislation in its history, including the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, and the Endangered Species Act. Senator Muskie's approach remains a model of visionary environmental lawmaking.

Jedediah Britton-Purdy, a professor of law at Columbia and the author of "After Nature: A Politics for the Anthropocene," is one such voice advocating for a reevaluation of our environmental policies. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook, Twitter (@NYTopinion), and Instagram for more perspectives on this and other environmental issues.

Title: Islamic Extremists Seize Radisson Hotel in Mali, Dozens of Hostages Taken

Article:

Heavily armed Islamic extremists seized control of the Radisson Blu hotel in the Malian capital of Bamako on Friday, taking 170 hostages, including 30 hotel staff and 140 guests. At least three hostages were killed during the more than seven-hour siege, and two gunmen were also killed.

According to The Associated Press, 10 gunmen stormed the hotel, shouting "Allahu Akbar" or "God is great" in Arabic, before firing on hotel guards. The Malian military, with assistance from United Nations peacekeeping troops, currently have the hotel surrounded.

As of now, three deaths have been confirmed, with two being Malian and one being a French national, according to CNN. It appears that those who have been released were made to recite Koranic verses first, according to Reuters reports. The gunmen are reportedly making their way through the hotel floor by floor.

The Rezidor Hotel Group, which operates the Radisson Blu, has stated that the hostages include Turkish Airlines crew members, as well as Chinese, French, and Belgian nationals.

There has been no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, but this year has seen an increase in jihadist violence across Mali. An attack on a restaurant in Bamako in March was the first time the capital had been attacked in years.

In 2012, after a coup in Bamako, Mali's north fell under the control of Islamic extremists who took advantage of a Tuareg uprising. In 2013, the French Army took control of the north, and a UN-brokered peace deal was signed with Tuareg separatists.

France and other Western nations have been working with the Malian government to prevent the Islamist militants from regaining a foothold in the north. A UN spokesman stated that the Radisson Blu was host to a large delegation of UN workers involved in the ongoing peace process.

In August, nine people, including four members of the UN mission, were killed in a hotel attack in the central town of Sevare after heavily armed gunmen entered a hotel popular with European military officers. The attack was significant because the popular tourist town was the demarcation line between government-controlled areas of Mali and those that were controlled by Islamist militants, according to the Wall Street Journal.

In August, The ███ reported that there were signs that militants were strategically moving south to places like Bamako, after having been confined to cities such as Timbuktu in the north.

Bruce Whitehouse, a Mali expert and associate professor at Lehigh University, told AP, "It's a troubling sign that the armed Islamist groups are intent on stepping up the pressure both on the Malian government and on the UN and French presence. They want to show they are not just contained within the north and that they're not afraid to confront their primary enemies where they're strongest."

Title: Texas Seeks to Exclude Planned Parenthood from Federal Family Planning Funding, Potentially Setting National Precedent

Article:

Texas is pursuing a request that, if approved by the Trump administration, would allow the state to exclude Planned Parenthood and other abortion providers from receiving some federal family planning dollars. This move could potentially set a precedent for other states to follow.

Jennifer Popik, federal legislative director with National Right to Life, an anti-abortion group, stated, "This would have implications nationwide if this gets approved." Popik further explained, "For an administration with a pro-life focus, this is something they could do to divert funding from Planned Parenthood."

The push in Texas is the latest effort against Planned Parenthood, which stands to lose federal funding for one year under the Republican healthcare bill currently being considered in the Senate. Republicans have long sought to block Planned Parenthood from being reimbursed by the government for medical services. Most of the federal funding is paid out through Medicaid, the healthcare program for the poor.

The GOP's principal objection to Planned Parenthood is its provision of abortions, though the Hyde Amendment prohibits the use of federal funds for the procedure. President Trump has indicated his support for efforts to block federal funds to Planned Parenthood. In April, he signed a bill passed by Congress that rolled back an Obama-era rule that banned states from withholding separate federal family planning funds, known as Title X Funding, from providers for political reasons.

Texas is seeking federal Medicaid funding it lost four years ago when it excluded Planned Parenthood and other abortion providers from participating in a family planning program for low-income women who are not otherwise eligible for Medicaid. The Obama administration halted the funding to Texas—about $35 million a year—stating that federal law requires states to allow Medicaid patients their choice of "any willing provider," including those that provide abortions.

If approved, the program would take effect for five years beginning Sept. 1. The federal comment period is open until Aug. 4, after which the Centers for Medicaid and Medicare Services (CMS) would make a decision. If CMS were to approve this waiver and offer federal funding for this program, it would open the floodgates for this to be implemented in other states, according to Kinsey Hasstedt, a senior policy manager at the Guttmacher Institute, a liberal reproductive rights group.

Since 1972, family planning services have been a mandatory benefit for Medicaid recipients, with healthcare providers reimbursed by the federal government at a 90 percent matching rate, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. In the 1990s, several states, led by California, sought waivers to create programs to serve low-income women not eligible for Medicaid. Now, 26 states have similar family planning programs, which are mostly funded by the federal government.

Two states—Iowa and Missouri—recently created their own state-funded programs that exclude Planned Parenthood. Republican lawmakers in Iowa agreed this year to give up millions of federal dollars to create a state-run family planning program that excludes abortion providers and their affiliates. Four Planned Parenthood centers in the state are now closed because of the lost funding. Missouri lawmakers, meanwhile, decided in April to reject more than $8 million in federal funding the state was going to receive for its family planning program and will create a state-funded program that bans abortion providers.

The reduced funding in Texas has led to some negative consequences, including a drop in women receiving services. The state also has the fourth-highest birth rate in the U.S. State officials hope that getting the federal money back will improve the Healthy Texas Women program. However, experts warn that more money will not help the problem, as community health centers in the state are already facing limited resources and facilities.

Sara Rosenbaum, a professor of health law and policy at George Washington University, and her colleagues concluded in an analysis that Texas's proposal would diminish access to care for low-income women because health centers cannot grow fast enough to replace services provided by Planned Parenthood and other centers. If the Texas request is approved, the issue could end up in the courts, as federal law states that Medicaid beneficiaries may go to any provider who is "qualified to perform the service." Courts have previously sided with Planned Parenthood in cases where states have tried to block the organization from receiving Medicaid funding.

In a statement, Planned Parenthood spokeswoman Danielle Wells called the proposal an "underhanded attempt to cut off care at Planned Parenthood with devastating consequences for our patients." Mara Gandal-Powers, senior counsel at the National Women's Law Center, expressed concern about the proposal and its potential impact on women's healthcare access. "We are very concerned about this proposal and how it might be received by this administration, which has been very hostile to women's health and to women's healthcare providers like Planned Parenthood," Gandal-Powers said. "We're very concerned, but it's hard to go down the road of what might happen."

Title: Taylor University Faces Backlash Over Mike Pence's Commencement Speech

Article:

Taylor University, a small evangelical Christian school, is facing pushback from students and alumni after inviting Vice President Mike Pence to speak at this year's commencement ceremony. Over 3,300 people have signed a change.org petition to rescind Pence's invitation, citing the "Trump-Pence Administration's policies" as "not consistent with the Christian ethic of love we hold dear."

One Taylor graduate expressed their dismay, stating, "The school should be ashamed... I am physically shaking... I feel personally attacked." However, not all alumni agree, and Taylor officials have stated they are standing by their decision.

The controversy has escalated as South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, a Democratic presidential hopeful and an openly gay man, criticized Pence. During an event hosted by the LGBTQ Victory Fund, Buttigieg discussed his sexual orientation, saying, "If being gay was a choice, it was made far, far above my pay grade... That’s the thing that I wish the Mike Pence’s of the world would understand – that if you have a problem with who I am – your problem is not with me, your quarrel sir, is with my creator."

Kevin Holtsberry, a Taylor alumnus, spoke on "Fox & Friends" Monday morning, stating that the outraged alumni and students are mistaking disagreement on political issues with personal attacks. Holtsberry also thanked the school for "standing firm" and not pulling Pence's invitation.

Division among pastors regarding speaking out on hot-button issues was also highlighted, with half of them expressing concerns about offending people. Kevin Holtsberry stated, "I was very nervous initially that the very vocal overwhelming minority might sort of sway Taylor to take a different stance so I’m very glad they’re taking that solid stance."

Taylor University has defended the decision, with President Paul Lowell Haines praising Pence as a "good friend to the University over many years" and "a Christian brother whose life and values have exemplified what we strive to instill in our graduates."

In a statement, Taylor University spokesman, James Garringer, said, "We look forward to hosting the Vice President next month." The university stated that they encourage positive, respectful, and meaningful dialogue within their community.

Title: America's Regime Struggle: A Chart of Dueling Concepts in the Ongoing Cold Civil War

Article:

The United States is currently experiencing a profound divide, often referred to as a "cold civil war" or a "culture war." This conflict, according to the Claremont Institute's Angelo Codevilla, is not merely a disagreement over policy but a fundamental disagreement over the meaning of principles such as liberty, equality, and justice.

The divide can be characterized as a struggle between those who aim to transmit the American regime to future generations and those who seek to transform it fundamentally. The former emphasizes the positive aspects of the "American way of life," acknowledging past failures, while the latter heavily qualifies any affirmation of America as it has existed and criticizes the nation's past and present for perceived flaws.

The argument over "first principles" has been brewing for decades. Traditional American history, which focused on English colonists and their influence, has been replaced with a multicultural narrative that portrays the United States as the result of a "convergence" of three civilizations: the Amerindian native culture, European culture, and the civilization of Islamic West Africa. This narrative, often referred to as the "Atlantic World" or the "three worlds meeting," has led to a focus on diversity based on race, ethnicity, and gender, rather than equality of American citizenship.

Meanwhile, the promotion of "global education" has obfuscated the rights and responsibilities of national citizenship in a constitutional democracy. This new narrative, although historically inaccurate and antithetical to responsible American citizenship, serves the political purposes of its proponents, who aim to delegitimize the concept of Western civilization and deconstruct the American way of life.

Since politics is said to be "downstream from culture," these transformist concepts have slowly and steadily spread to the mainstream media, major corporations, and elected officials. However, Americanism, far from being a "dirty word," is a term that should be proudly embraced, and the fundamental transformation of the country should be resisted.

The conflict between the transmission and transformation of the American regime continues to heat up. Recent events, such as the city council of Charlottesville, Virginia, canceling Thomas Jefferson's birthday holiday, Nike recalling the Betsy Ross flag sneakers, and the San Francisco School board covering up a painting of George Washington, highlight this ongoing struggle.

To better understand this contemporary conflict in America over transmitting or transforming the American regime, a chart of 36 dueling concepts has been developed. This chart, examining the "regime conflict," the "cold civil war" or the "culture war," compresses the struggle into a table for easy comparison. Americanism forces are beginning to push back against the multicultural Left, which has a large megaphone but little popular support. Americanism is not a dirty word; it's a good thing. We should be proud to say so and say no to the fundamental transformation of our country.

Title: CNN Ferguson Panel Discussion Erupts in Controversy

Article:

A heated discussion on CNN's "Newsroom" about the recent shooting in Ferguson, Missouri, turned chaotic on Wednesday as host Brooke Baldwin moderated a conversation between University of Pennsylvania professor and CNN contributor Marc Lamont Hill and conservative radio host Larry Elder. The conversation, initially focused on the mental health of young men of color, escalated into a verbal altercation.

The discord began when Baldwin asked why the mental health of young men of color was not being discussed, to which Hill responded by stating that the stigma surrounding mental illness and the assumption that black men are prone to violence and irrationality contribute to the dismissal of their mental health issues.

Elder, in response, argued that the media and the left perceive racism as a more significant problem in America, citing the attention given to controversial figures like Donald Sterling, Cliven Bundy, and Paul Ryan. Hill interjected, reminding Elder that the initial question was about mental health.

Elder continued, suggesting that the left perpetuates the belief in racism to maintain a monolithic black vote and keep the Democratic Party alive. This statement prompted Baldwin to ask if Elder believed that racism was not a major problem in the country. Elder denied this, instead recounting his father's experiences building a small business.

When Hill reminded Elder of the original question, Elder responded angrily, questioning why he was being insulted and expressing a desire for a more civil discussion between the two black men. The rest of the interview reportedly contained some good points, but Elder's defensive demeanor persisted.

Title: Fiscal Cliff Deal Fails to Address Overspending, Experts Warn

Article:

The Senate passed a "fiscal cliff" deal on January 1, 2013, in a 257-167 vote, marking the end of the 2012 fiscal cliff negotiations. However, critics argue that this deal, rather than solving the issue, merely postpones it. The focus of the negotiations, primarily on taxes for the top 1% or 2% of income earners, has been misplaced, according to experts.

The real problem, they contend, is not insufficient revenue from taxes but rather overspending. Overspending is defined as spending more than one takes in. The president's tax-the-rich plan, it was argued, would not address the issue, and the last-minute deal cannot avert the principal disaster.

The deficit for fiscal 2013 is estimated by the Congressional Budget Office to exceed $1 trillion for the fifth consecutive year. The revenue generated by the tax increases on high-income earners in the fiscal cliff deal is estimated to be about $60 billion, which is just 6% of the $1 trillion annual deficit.

To close the gap, income tax rates would need to rise significantly, requiring a tax increase of more than 65% on all taxpayers, including low-, middle-, and upper-income earners, corporations, and others. Such a tax increase would tank the economy and cause incomes and the taxes on them to fall far short of the levels necessary to produce the projected revenue increase.

Experts argue that rapid economic growth, coupled with real, substantive expenditure cuts, is the only practical route to reducing the deficit. The economy will not grow when a massive tax increase is imposed. Growth requires low taxes, which in turn require smaller government. The only way out of the unsustainable fiscal mess, they contend, is to focus on reducing spending and stimulating growth. The looming debt-ceiling debate may be what is needed to turn the focus to the real problem of overspending.

Title: Obama and Kaine Deliver Stinging Rebuttal to Trump at Democratic Convention

Article:

In a scorching warm-up for Hillary Clinton's acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention, President Barack Obama and Vice Presidential nominee Tim Kaine delivered a series of stinging rebukes against Republican nominee Donald Trump. The speeches, delivered on the convention's third night, emphasized the election as a choice between optimism and pessimism, with Obama endorsing Clinton as a tough and tenacious leader.

Framing the election as a choice between two contrasting visions, Obama praised Clinton as a qualified and experienced candidate, stating, "There has never been a man or a woman – not me, not Bill, nobody – more qualified than Hillary Clinton to serve as president of the United States of America."

Obama's speech, marking a passing of the torch to the woman he defeated for the nomination eight years ago, was delivered shortly after delegates finalized the party's 2016 ticket, nominating Virginia Sen. Kaine for vice president. Kaine, in his acceptance speech, shifted gears in the second half and delivered a broadside against Trump, mocking his New York bravado and questioning his qualifications.

The speeches intensified attacks on Trump, as they talked up Clinton's qualifications. Obama criticized Trump for lacking plans and facts, stating, "The Donald is not really a plans guy. He’s not really a facts guy, either." He also defended his record in office, declaring he's "more optimistic about the future of America than ever before."

Trump countered on Twitter, stating, "Our country does not feel 'great already' to the millions of wonderful people living in poverty, violence, and despair." The night in Philadelphia was replete with barbed insults, even as the musical acts kept returning to themes of "love" and understanding.

Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid called Trump a "hateful con man" and "egomaniac," while former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, an ex-Clinton primary rival, gave a fiery speech calling Trump a "bully racist." The sitting vice president, Joe Biden, also went after Trump on all fronts, stating that the billionaire businessman would endanger national security and lacks compassion.

The focus of the third convention night was heavy on gun control, global warming, and national security, an issue largely absent from the first two nights. Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who had considered an independent presidential run before ruling it out, made a late appearance Wednesday, with an endorsement that could help Clinton reach out to vital independents whom Trump also is courting. Bloomberg called Trump a "dangerous demagogue" and claimed it's "imperative" to elect Clinton.

Together, the speakers Wednesday set the stage for Clinton to deliver her nomination acceptance speech and close out the convention Thursday night, after becoming Tuesday the first woman in U.S. history nominated for president by a major party. The president's speech Wednesday effectively kicks off Obama's general election role as a chief Clinton surrogate. The New York Times reported that aides mostly have cleared his calendar for October and expect him to be on the trail regularly for Clinton until the election.

Title: Bernie Sanders Addresses Allegations of Sexual Harassment and Pay Discrimination in 2016 Campaign

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has responded to a New York Times report that nearly a dozen female staffers on his 2016 presidential campaign claim to have experienced harassment and their superiors handled their claims improperly. In an interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper, Sanders stated that he was unaware of the allegations at the time.

"I was a little bit busy running around the country, trying to make the case," Sanders said regarding his knowledge of the allegations.

Sanders noted that if he ran for president again in 2020, he would "do better next time." The progressive senator also added that he was "very proud of the campaign we ran in 2016."

However, Sanders acknowledged that his campaign did not handle human resources and addressing the needs of women who felt disrespected or experienced sexual harassment effectively. He stated, "I am not going to sit here and tell you that we did everything right in terms of human resources, in terms of addressing the needs that I am hearing from now that women felt disrespected, that there was sexual harassment, which was not dealt with as effectively as possible."

The Times report included detailed accounts from several staffers, including one instance where a staffer working in Nevada said a supervisor ran his hands through her hair in a "sexual way," and her reports of the incident were laughed off.

The report comes just days after more than two dozen alumni of Sanders’ 2016 campaign said they sent him a letter requesting a meeting to discuss "sexual violence and harassment" that took place while working on the campaign. Sanders' campaign has not yet responded to the letter.

Title: Virginia Governor's Assault Weapons Ban Proposal Fails in Senate

Article:

Virginia Governor Ralph Northam's attempt to ban the sale of assault weapons has been unsuccessful following opposition from members of his own party. In a committee vote on Monday, senators decided to shelve the bill for the year and task the state crime commission with studying the issue. This outcome was met with applause from a room filled with gun advocates.

Four moderate Democrats joined forces with Republicans in the committee vote, rejecting a bill that would have prohibited the sale of certain semiautomatic firearms, including AR-15 style rifles, and banned the possession of magazines holding more than 12 rounds.

The bill was a key priority for Northam, a Democrat who has advocated for a comprehensive package of gun control measures. The legislation faced significant pushback from gun owners and gun-rights advocates, who accused the governor and others of seeking to confiscate commonly owned guns and accessories from law-abiding gun owners. Northam has consistently stated that he does not intend to confiscate guns, but argues that banning new sales of assault weapons and high-capacity magazines would help prevent mass shootings.

Virginia has become the focal point of the nation's ongoing debate over gun control and mass shootings. Tens of thousands of gun-rights activists from across the country gathered at the state Capitol and surrounding area in protest, some wearing tactical gear and carrying military-style rifles.

Northam has been successful in passing much of his gun control agenda this year, but has faced challenges with the proposed assault weapon ban. Earlier proposals to ban the possession of AR-15-style rifles or to require owners to register them with state police have been abandoned. The governor had hoped a watered-down version of the bill would win over enough Democratic moderates for passage.

An estimated 8 million AR-style guns have been sold since they were introduced to the public in the 1960s. The weapons are known for being easy to use, easy to clean, and easy to modify with a variety of scopes, stocks, and rails.

Lawmakers in both the House and Senate have already advanced several other gun-control measures and are expected to finalize passage in the coming days. These bills include limiting handgun purchases to once a month, implementing universal background checks on gun purchases, allowing localities to ban guns in public buildings, parks, and other areas, and a red flag bill that would allow authorities to temporarily take guns away from anyone deemed to be dangerous to themselves or others.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Urges Vote for Democrats in Midterm Elections

Article:

Former FBI Director James Comey has called on voters to support the Democratic Party in the upcoming midterm elections, stating that the current Republican-led Congress has failed to uphold the Founders' design of a system where "Ambition must counteract ambition."

In a tweet on Tuesday, Comey wrote, "This Republican Congress has proven incapable of fulfilling the Founders' design that 'Ambition must... counteract ambition.' All who believe in this country's values must vote for Democrats this fall. Policy differences don't matter right now. History has its eyes on us."

This call to action follows a Department of Justice Inspector General report from June 2018 that found Comey was "insubordinate" and defied authority while he was director of the FBI. The report also revealed that Comey is under investigation for his handling of classified reports about his meetings with President Donald Trump.

In a previous tweet on Monday, Comey criticized President Trump's handling of the Helsinki summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin, stating, "This American president stood on foreign soil next to a murderous lying thug and refused to back his own country."

It is important to note that Comey was previously a registered Republican. The full context and implications of Comey's statements should be considered in the broader political landscape.

Title: Impact of Ideological Extremism on Presidential Elections: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

A recent analysis of ideological extremism in presidential elections over the past several decades has concluded that the electoral cost of extremism is "negligible" compared to the effects of other economic and political factors. The study suggests that the landslide defeats of Barry Goldwater in 1964 and George McGovern in 1972 were not primarily due to their extreme ideologies but rather their challenging of incumbents who presided over election-year economic booms.

Conversely, Ronald Reagan in 1980 and Barack Obama in 2008, who ran in years with economic recessions, won easily despite their moderate policy positions. In the current race, Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton is leading in the polls despite her "hard-core liberal" campaign stands and a voting record to the left of most Senate Democrats. Republican candidate Donald Trump is trailing despite moderating some of his party's conservative stands on issues like social spending and gay rights, with his policy positions likely closer to the "center" of the electorate than those of previous Republican presidential candidates.

However, many voters who might find Trump's positions appealing have been alienated by his bombast and political inexperience. The study also highlights that the single largest difference in positions between either party's presidential candidates and swing voters over the past three decades has been on the issue of racial policy. On average, Republican candidates have been seen as just six points to the right of the political center on the question of government assistance to African-Americans, while Democratic candidates have been 26 points to the left.

Title: Conservative's Perspective on the 2016 Presidential Election: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

As the 2016 presidential election approaches, the American political landscape is witnessing a significant shift with Donald Trump emerging as the presumptive Republican nominee. This development has prompted many on the political right to declare their stance on Trump's candidacy. One such individual, identified as #NeverTrump and #NeverHillary, has shared their views on the upcoming election.

The individual, who has historically voted for third-party candidates, plans to abstain from voting this November. They express a sense of resignation towards the two major parties and the political system as a whole. If Hillary Clinton were to win the presidency, they anticipate a consolidation of liberal gains in the judiciary, potentially leading to the reversal of pro-life gains on the state level and more battles over religious liberty.

In the case of a Trump presidency, the individual expresses apprehension, citing Trump's questionable foreign policy judgment and nationalist views on immigration and trade as concerns. They also highlight Trump's shamelessness, ignorance, touchy ego, and freedom from political norms as potential dangers, particularly in the context of a president wielding the awesome powers of the office.

The individual's stance underscores the complexities and nuances of the 2016 presidential election, reflecting a deep-seated dissatisfaction with both major party candidates and the political system at large. The author's decision to abstain from voting serves as a testament to their desire to send a message of discontent with the status quo, echoing a sentiment shared by many Americans.

Title: Trump to Nominate Conservative Successor for Supreme Court Justice Kennedy

Article:

A political battle is brewing over the replacement of Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, who announced his retirement from the US top court on Wednesday. Mr. Kennedy, 81, retires on July 31, giving President Donald Trump a chance to cement a conservative majority on the high court for decades to come.

Democrats argue that the Republican-controlled Congress should wait until after mid-term elections to confirm a successor. However, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has already cancelled a scheduled recess for the upper chamber in August, suggested Mr. Kennedy's replacement would be confirmed before November's mid-term elections.

"The Senate stands ready to fulfill its constitutional role by offering advice and consent on President Trump's nominee to fill this vacancy," he said on Wednesday. His comments came after President Trump said the process to find a replacement would "begin immediately."

Mr. Kennedy made the announcement earlier on Wednesday, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family after 30 years on the top court. Although he was a conservative justice, Mr. Kennedy sided with liberals on certain key votes, including abortion and gay marriage.

The Senate, which votes to confirm Mr. Trump's nominee, is currently controlled by Republicans with a slim 51-seat majority. However, that could change after mid-term elections in November.

Speaking at a rally in Fargo, North Dakota on Wednesday evening, Mr. Trump warned his supporters that Democrats would "rewrite the Constitution any way they want" unless Republicans could quickly confirm a conservative justice. "We have to pick one that's going to be there for 40 years, 45 years," he said of Mr. Kennedy's successor.

The president has promised to draw names from the same list of 25 conservative candidates from which he picked Justice Neil Gorsuch in February last year. When asked by reporters on Wednesday if he would wait until after the mid-term elections to nominate a successor, Mr. Trump said: "I think you want to go as quickly as possible."

The long-simmering tensions over Supreme Court picks became a political flashpoint in 2016 when the Republicans successfully blocked President Barack Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, to replace the late Justice Anthony Scalia. At the time, Republicans said it was unfair to confirm a judge during an election year. Democrats are now pointing to that argument in an effort to halt the confirmation of Justice Kennedy's replacement.

Earlier on Wednesday, Mr. Schumer, in a televised speech on the floor of the Senate, called for delaying a confirmation vote until after the mid-terms, adding that "anything but that would be the absolute height of hypocrisy" from Republicans.

The Supreme Court plays a key role in American life and is often the final word on highly contentious laws, disputes between states and the federal government, and final appeals to stay executions. Rather than serving fixed terms, the justices serve for life unless they decide to retire. This makes their appointments particularly significant.

This week, the court upheld Mr. Trump's travel ban, which covers people from several Muslim-majority countries, in a 5-4 conservative majority ruling. Earlier this month, it ruled in favor of a baker in Colorado who refused to make a wedding cake for a gay couple.

"Hopefully we are going to pick somebody who will be as outstanding," Mr. Trump told reporters at the White House shortly after Justice Kennedy's retirement was announced. Vice-President Mike Pence said on Twitter that the president would nominate "a strong conservative, in the tradition of the late Justice Scalia" who would uphold the "God-given liberties" of the constitution.

Mr. Kennedy, who is the second-oldest justice on the nine-member US Supreme Court, earned a reputation as a swing vote conservative who supported liberal arguments on key decisions, including the 5-4 rulings that decided same-sex marriage and upheld abortion rights. As a result, news of his retirement has raised fears among pro-choice groups that access to legal abortions in several states could be under threat.

Mr. Trump, during his presidential campaign, vowed to attempt to overturn Roe v Wade, the 1973 decision legalizing abortion throughout the US. "If we put another two or perhaps three justices on, that is really what will happen," Mr. Trump said during an October 2016 debate with Hillary Clinton.

Mr. Kennedy, who was raised in California, was nominated by President Ronald Reagan and began his term in 1988. He voted conservative on issues of campaign finance, voting rights, and gun rights. Mr. Kennedy penned the Supreme Court's first major gay-rights decision in 1996, protecting LGBT Americans from discrimination. In 2015, he authored the landmark opinion which gave LGBT citizens the right to marry, writing: "They ask for equal dignity in the eyes of the law and the Constitution grants them that right."

As a justice, he routinely favored personal liberty and the limiting of federal power. Mr. Trump said Mr. Kennedy had "displayed great vision" and "tremendous heart." The White House also released a statement thanking Mr. Kennedy for his 30 years of service as a "tireless voice for individual rights."

From the list of 25 judges that Mr. Trump has said he would draw from, US media report several front runners. Most candidates are appointees of President George W. Bush, and only one of the supposed top-picks is a woman. Brett Kavanaugh, who is at the top of most lists, is a Washington, DC appeals court judge and was a former clerk to Mr. Kennedy. He represented Mr. Bush during the Florida vote recount in 2000 that won Mr. Bush the presidential election. However, the American Bar Association recently downgraded his qualifications based on a lack of experience and concerns over partisan bias. Amul Thapar, a Kentucky judge handpicked by Mr. McConnell, and Amy Comey Barrett, a former professor at Catholic university Notre Dame, are other likely nominees.

Title: Trump Administration Lifts Ban on Transfer of Military Equipment to Local Police Departments

Article:

The Trump administration announced on Monday that it will lift the ban on the transfer of surplus military equipment to state and local police departments, a move that was put in place by the Obama administration in 2015. Attorney General Jeff Sessions made the announcement, stating, "We will not put superficial concerns above public safety."

President Trump is expected to sign an executive order on Monday reinstating the Pentagon's 1033 program, which was halted by the Obama administration after images of heavily armed police responding to protests in Ferguson, Missouri, shocked the nation. The ban blocked the transfer of armored vehicles, grenade launchers, armed aircraft, bayonets, and guns and ammunition of.50 caliber or higher.

Sessions argued that the restrictions went too far and that the program will "make it easier to protect yourselves and your communities." He cited the ongoing rescue efforts in Houston, Texas, as an example of the need for such equipment.

The ban was part of the previous administration's efforts to re-establish trust between law enforcement and the communities they police, following a string of police-related deaths of black men in Ferguson, Baltimore, Charleston, S.C., and elsewhere. At the time, Obama warned that such equipment cast the police in the role of an "occupying force," deepening divisions with distrustful communities.

Trump has positioned himself as a "law and order" president who will restore an American way of life that the administration has warned is beset by worsening violence, including rising levels of violence against law enforcement.

The announcement comes as the role and conduct of police, particularly where it intersects with issues of race, continues to captivate national interest and spark fierce debate. Critics have accused state police officers in Charlottesville, Virginia, of standing by idly while a white nationalist fired into a crowd during violent clashes between demonstrators earlier this month.

Congress established the 1033 program almost three decades ago as part of the annual defense authorization bill as part of an effort to help local law enforcement pursue drug investigations. However, in 1997, the program was expanded to include all local law enforcement operations, including counterterrorism. More than $5 billion of military equipment has been transferred to police departments since then.

Some law enforcement groups, including the Fraternal Order of Police (FOP), have been pushing for the rollback of the Obama-era ban. Supporters of the program argue that the equipment was protective and defensive, and in addition to saving lives and reducing crime rates, saved money by repurposing equipment for which taxpayers had already paid. Sessions argued on Monday that the program also provided first responder and rescue equipment "like what they're using in Texas right now."

Critics, meanwhile, argue that the program allowed police departments to stockpile military-grade equipment and increased the instances of violent encounters. Almost 150 law enforcement agencies were suspended over the six-year period prior to the ban for losing track of equipment, according to ABC News and Fusion. The FOP president, Chuck Canterbury, celebrated the new order in a Monday statement, saying, "The previous administration was more concerned about the image of law enforcement being too'militarized' than they were about our safety."

Title: Facebook Reduces Distribution and Adds Disclaimer to Altered Pelosi Video

Article:

Facebook has issued a statement regarding the controversy surrounding an altered video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., that went viral, appearing to show her slurring her words. The social media giant did not remove the video but reduced its distribution and added a disclaimer stating that the video was "false."

In a statement on Friday, Facebook explained that it removes content that violates its Community Standards but does not have a policy requiring that information posted on the platform be true. The company stated, "We work hard to find the right balance between encouraging free expression and promoting a safe and authentic community. We believe that reducing the distribution of inauthentic content strikes that balance."

Facebook clarified that it does not distribute all content but allows some content as forms of expression. The company stated, "But just because something is allowed to be on Facebook does not mean it should get distribution. In other words, we allow people to post it as a form of expression, but we're not going to show it at the top of News Feed."

The platform also outlined its methods for combating misleading content. It removes content that violates its Community Standards, reduces the distribution of content that does not directly violate Community Standards but still undermines the authenticity of the platform, and empowers users to decide for themselves what to read, trust, and share by informing them with more context in-product and promoting news literacy.

The controversy arose amid growing scrutiny of Facebook and other social media companies regarding their handling of content on their platforms. Facebook and Twitter have faced criticism for apparent bias against conservatives and for allowing content promoted by Russians during the 2016 election.

Monika Bickert, Facebook's vice president for product policy and counterterrorism, stated on CNN that the company "dramatically" reduced the video's distribution and informed users that the video was false. When CNN's Anderson Cooper pressed Bickert on why the video was not removed, Bickert responded, "We think it's important for people to make their own informed choice about what to believe. Our job is to make sure that we are getting them accurate information and that's why we work with more than 50 fact-checking organizations around the world."

She added that the company would remove misinformation related to ongoing riots or some kind of threat to physical violence.

Title: Millennials Strongly Support School Choice, National Surveys Show

Article:

Two national surveys, conducted eight months apart by different pollsters, have found strong support for school choice among Millennials. In January, Beck Research, on behalf of the American Federation for Children, reported that 75 percent of Millennials support school choice. Yesterday, USA Today released a poll from GenForward with nearly identical results.

In the GenForward poll, support for vouchers for low-income children is high among Millennials across racial and ethnic lines. Seventy-nine percent of African Americans, 76 percent of Asian Americans, 77 percent of Latinos, and 66 percent of whites support the concept. Charter schools enjoy support from 65 percent of African Americans, 61 percent of Asian Americans, 58 percent of Latinos, and 55 percent of whites.

This could be a winning issue for Republicans and Democrats willing to seize the moment and push bold reforms. In a Gallup poll from April of this year that gauged public opinion on 15 different policy proposals, federal funding for school vouchers was one of just four that Republicans and Democrats both supported on balance.

Legislative momentum has grown in recent years, with states like Florida, Nevada, Louisiana, North Carolina, Illinois, Arizona, and Wisconsin, among others, enacting or expanding educational choice for K–12 students. On the national level, many are working to create an education tax credit that would enable many more children to access the school of their parents' choice. Federal school-choice initiatives are already available in higher education, in the form of grants and loans that a student may use at any eligible college.

Twenty-six states with private-school-choice programs and 44 states with charter schools clearly show the nationwide support for educational choice. Research also shows that school choice works. Eleven of the 17 empirical studies using the random-assignment method, the "gold standard" for social-science research, show that students using private-school-choice programs do better academically. Charter-school research from Stanford's Center for Research on Education Outcomes (CREDO) shows significantly improved academic results, especially for students in urban charter schools.

For the Millennial generation, having many educational options make sense. They grew up with abundant options across most aspects of their lives, saw rapid advancements in technology, and distrust institutions. Many of them graduated high school or college during the 2008 financial crisis, and thus struggled to find work after earning degrees they'd been promised would lead to good jobs. Some were forced to move back in with their parents. So why would they continue to trust a bulky, monolithic K–12 system that hasn't been truly reformed in generations and produces meager results on international tests?

Millennials do not believe that their five-digit ZIP code should determine whether they go to the good school, the bad school, the best school, or the failing school. With the growing popularity of online and personalized learning that can give them front-row access to some of the best teachers and best courses on the planet, Millennials are naturally inclined to think even more expansively when it comes to what's possible in education.

The future of education in America could be bright and dynamic, with better outcomes for our students. All we—and our leaders—have to do is choose that future. Tommy Schultz, the national communications director for the American Federation for Children, the nation's largest educational-choice advocacy organization, made this statement.

Title: Study Shows Liberal Democrats More Likely to Strain Friendships Over Political Differences

Article:

A recent Pew Research Center study indicates that nearly half of liberal Democrats, 47 percent, say that a friend's support for former President Donald Trump would strain their friendship. In contrast, only 13 percent of Republicans say a friend's support for former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton would have the same effect.

The poll also shows that among Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters, 35 percent say a friend's support for Trump would put a strain on their relationship. The study suggests that part of the reason for the imbalance is that liberals tend to live in more homogeneous areas and do not associate with conservatives.

Another Pew study from last year showed that 47 percent of people who planned to vote for Clinton did not have any close friends who were Trump supporters, while 31 percent of Trump supporters said they did not have any friends who backed Clinton.

The study also found that 68 percent of Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters say they find it "stressful and frustrating" to talk to people who have a different opinion of Trump. About half, 52 percent, of Republican and GOP-leaning voters say the same.

The study's findings have sparked debate and criticism, with some arguing that the results reflect a growing tribalism in American politics. However, the Pew Research Center emphasizes that the study is based on self-reported data and may not fully capture the complexity of real-life relationships and interactions.

The study's findings come amid ongoing political polarization in the United States, with many Americans reporting that they have fewer friends and acquaintances with opposing political views. The study does not provide insight into the reasons behind this trend, but it suggests that political differences can create significant strain in personal relationships.

Title: White House Press Secretary Corrects Job Creation Claim for African-Americans During Obama and Trump Administrations

Article:

White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders issued a rare correction and apology on Tuesday after providing inaccurate information during a press briefing regarding the number of jobs created for African-Americans during the Obama and Trump administrations.

Initially, Sanders stated that President Donald Trump had created three times as many jobs for African-Americans as former President Barack Obama during his entire eight years in the White House. However, in a tweet, Sanders later clarified, "Correction from today’s briefing: Jobs numbers for Pres Trump and Pres Obama were correct, but the time frame for Pres Obama wasn’t."

According to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, when Obama was president, he created nearly 3 million jobs for blacks, about 15 times what Sanders initially claimed. Sanders had attempted to demonstrate that Trump's record with the African-American population was not only great but even better than Obama's, explaining that Trump tripled Obama's job creation record for the black community.

During the briefing, Sanders stated, "This President, since he took office, in the year and a half that he's been here, has created 700,000 new jobs for African-Americans." She continued, "That's 700,000 African-Americans that are working now that weren't working when this President took office. When President Obama left, after eight years in office, he had only created 195,000 jobs for African-Americans."

The claim was made during Sanders' defense of Trump on race after the president was accused of using the N-word on tape and called former White House aide Omarosa Manigault Newman a "dog" on Twitter. The White House Council of Economic Advisers also posted an apology on Twitter, stating there was a miscommunication to Sanders.

Title: New Jersey Senator Robert Menendez's Natural Gas Bill Sponsorship Sparks Ethics Controversy

Article:

More trouble is looming for Sen. Robert Menendez (D-NJ) as an Associated Press (AP) investigation has revealed that the embattled New Jersey Democrat sponsored legislation that, if passed, would have aided one of his biggest donor's investment in a natural gas vehicle conversion company. The AP report, published on Monday, states that Senator Menendez sponsored a bill to provide tax credits and grants to truck and heavy vehicle fleets that converted to natural gas. The bill could have benefited Salomon Melgen, the Florida eye doctor whose close relationship with Menendez has spurred a Senate ethics investigation. Dr. Melgen is an investor and member of the board of directors of Gaseous Fuel Systems Corp., which designs, manufactures, and sells products to convert diesel- and gas-fuel vehicles to natural gas.

Menendez's backing of the natural-gas bill marks another convergence of interest between the politician and a major donor, and is a concern for the senator. However, political watchers in New Jersey say the bill sponsorship is one part of a larger clean-energy agenda from the senator, who has a history of supporting environmental causes. As such, it is unlikely this latest allegation represents a conflict of interest, says Brigid Harrison, a political scientist at Montclair State University, who predicts that Menendez will survive the latest storm.

"I'm still not convinced... that this kind of behavior reaches to the status where it becomes enormously problematic in voters' minds," says Professor Harrison. "I'm not seeing any illegality or conflict of interest here."

The bill-sponsorship revelation revives the larger issue of the senator's relationship with Melgen, with recent reports suggesting that Menendez was providing political favors for Melgen in exchange for campaign support. Menendez used Melgen's private jet for two personal trips to the Dominican Republic in 2010, flights that were not reimbursed until three years later, when news reports called the senator's conduct into question.
