Menendez also intervened in a Medicare billing dispute between Melgen and federal authorities, as well as a port security contract, allegedly in order to protect the interests of his friend and donor, according to news reports. The allegations are compounded by a $700,000 donation Melgen made to Majority PAC, a "super political-action committee" created to elect Senate Democrats that ultimately made a $582,500 contribution to Menendez's 2012 reelection campaign, according to the Center for Responsive Politics.

Menendez has vehemently denied all allegations of impropriety, including any allegations of conflict-of-interest stemming from this latest report. His office did not respond to calls regarding his sponsorship of the natural gas bill. According to the AP report, Menendez joined Senate majority leader Harry Reid (D-NV) and Utah Sen. Orrin Hatch (R) as a key backer of the natural gas bill. Soon after, Melgen joined the board of directors of Gaseous Fuel Systems Corp. Though his investment in the company is confidential under US Securities and Exchange Commission rules, the company required a minimum investment of $51,500, according to the AP.

Ultimately, the bill didn't get enough votes to make it out of the Senate. However, while it was under consideration, a consultant for Gaseous Fuel Systems spent $220,000 lobbying Menendez and other congressional officials, according to interviews and Senate records as reported by the AP. "There is no evidence that Menendez offered direct help or intervened on behalf of the company or Melgen," the AP said in its report. "Instead, the connection between the two men's interests in natural gas is the latest example of the close symmetry between the senator... and his millionaire backer."

Evidence of "close symmetry" in this latest development, say analysts, is not enough to topple Menendez. "Menendez has been involved in clean-energy technology for a long time," says Ross Baker, a political scientist at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. "In light of Melgen's apparently limited and distant role in GFS, I think it is more of a coincidence than anything more sinister. I think it is as likely that Menendez got Melgen interested in converting truck fleets to natural gas as it was the other way around."

Other clean-energy initiatives the senator has supported include co-sponsoring legislation aimed at jump-starting offshore wind energy, extending solar energy tax credits, and creating block grants to spur green-energy projects. Menendez recently reintroduced the Repeal Big Oil Tax Subsidies Act and Close Big Oil Tax Loopholes Act, legislation he originally introduced in the 112th Congress to end tax subsidies for the "Big 5" oil companies.

"It isn't that this came out of the blue, it's part of a larger cohesive agenda... to deal with energy issues the country is facing," says Harrison of Montclair State University. "His record is an accurate reflection of his policy concerns, and this is one part of that."

And though the AP report singled out Menendez, the senator isn't alone in supporting the natural gas bill – or in sharing a passion with supporters for similar causes. In fact, the House version of the natural gas legislation had 181 co-sponsors. The natural gas industry spends hundreds of thousands of dollars lobbying members of Congress, including Menendez and his staff. "They are not alone in being lobbied," says Harrison.

Menendez's ethics controversy has had an impact on his poll numbers, and this latest development may further damage the senator's image. A Quinnipiac University poll found Menendez's approval ratings plummeted 15 percentage points between January and February, as news reports emerged about his relationship with Melgen. His approval rating dropped from 51 percent in mid-January to 36 percent in mid-February. The same poll found only 28 percent of New Jersey voters said the senator was "honest and trustworthy."

Title: Obama Administration to Implement 100% Income Verification for Health Care Subsidies

Article:

The Obama administration is set to unveil new procedures that will enable the government to verify the income of Americans who seek government subsidies under the federal health care law. Gary Cohen, deputy director of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, made this assurance during a hearing with the House Ways and Means Committee on Thursday.

Concerns were raised by Chairman Dave Camp, a Michigan Republican, regarding self-certification of income by enrollees in state health exchanges. The administration would have to cross-check this information much later, when the enrollees file their tax returns.

Cohen stated that the government will verify the income of everyone who applies for subsidies on the state-based exchanges, where those without employer-based insurance can shop for private health coverage with the help of premium tax credits. Daniel Werfel, acting director of the IRS, added that the tax credits will be delivered through the health exchanges, not directly to the individual enrollees.

In his opening remarks, Mr. Camp expressed concerns about the increasing uncertainty and confusion surrounding the Affordable Care Act, with roughly 60 days remaining until state-based insurance markets begin enrollment for coverage that takes effect in January. He cited government accountability reports suggesting the federal government is lagging in its efforts to set up exchanges in more than half the states, and the White House's decision to delay the employer mandate by one year.

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius reportedly told the committee that the Obama administration was on track to meet the October 1 deadline for the new health care law, but Mr. Camp stated that evidence shows the opposite is true.

On Friday, the House is scheduled to vote on a bill that would prevent the IRS from implementing and enforcing the health care law, in response to mounting distrust of the agency following a political targeting scandal in its tax-exempt organizations branch.

Werfel clarified on Thursday that at no time will tax data be displayed to anyone outside of the marketplace itself. Michigan Rep. Sander Levin, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means panel, stated that the hearing had been convened "under the pretense that House Republicans are interested in learning about the implementation of the landmark law." He added that the Republican mission is to "don't implement, destroy."

Levin further questioned the motives of Republicans, stating that they have leaned on outside organizations, including the National Football League, to discourage them from helping to educate Americans about current health insurance opportunities and assistance that will be available through the marketplaces.

Title: Democratic Concerns Emerge Over Obamacare Implementation and Potential Political Backlash

Article:

Democratic senators have expressed concerns about the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, during a caucus meeting with White House officials. The concerns center around the law's impact on small businesses, compliance difficulties, and potential political repercussions if the rollout is messy or if premiums increase significantly.

Senator Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH), who is up for re-election next year, stated that small businesses in New Hampshire are uncertain about how to comply with the law, and some restaurants are considering reducing workers' hours to avoid the law's requirement to offer health coverage to full-time employees.

Senator Tom Harkin (D-IA), chairman of the appropriations subcommittee on health care, expressed his displeasure with President Obama's decision to use funds from public health prevention programs to publicize the new law.

Senator Benjamin L. Cardin (D-MD) voiced his concern about large rate increases being sought by the largest health insurer in his state, CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield. The company has requested premium increases averaging 25 percent for individual insurance policies and about 15 percent for small businesses.

The White House officials acknowledged these concerns and pledged to address them, according to Senator Shaheen.

Recent reports suggest that Obamacare may be facing growing opposition, with some Democrats expressing concerns about its impact on small businesses and premium increases. The law remains unpopular, and there are growing fears of a potential political backlash in the 2014 midterm elections, similar to the one that followed its initial passage in 2010.

Further complications have arisen, with reports of problematic elements of the law set to roll out next year, while the supposedly popular aspects were front-loaded for political reasons. The law's implementation and potential political consequences continue to be a source of concern for Democrats.

Additional issues have surfaced, with Politico describing "Obamacare fires flaring up all over," and Fox's Chris Stirewalt highlighting a problematic and impending Medicaid assessment deadline the administration may miss.

Title: U.S. Economy Grows 2.9% in 2018, but Slower Growth Expected in 2019

Article:

The United States economy grew by 2.9% in 2018, marking its best performance since the Great Recession of 2007-09. However, economists predict slower growth of 2% to 2.5% in 2019 due to the expected fade-out of federal tax cuts and spending increases, a sluggish global economy, and lingering U.S. trade tensions with China.

In the October-December period, the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.6%. This followed an average 3.7% advance in the prior two quarters. For the year, the economy's growth matched its performance since 2015, which was a post-recession high.

Consumer spending grew a sturdy 2.8%, down from 3.5% in the third quarter. The showing was dampened by a surprising 1.2% retail sales decline in December, which some economists question and expect to be revised higher. Incomes also have been rising, with employers adding an average 223,000 jobs a month last year, up from 182,000 in 2017.

Business investment increased 6.2%, up from 2.5% in the third quarter, largely because of a big jump in software and research and development. Equipment spending also rose 6.7%. The solid performance defied the drop in stock prices late last year that rattled business confidence, slowing global growth, and President Trump's trade standoff with China.

Government spending edged up 0.4% after rising 2.6% in the second quarter. Federal spending increased 1.6%, bolstered by a 6.9% jump in defense outlays, while state and local government spending fell 0.3%. The budget deal Congress passed early last year is boosting government outlays, though the effects are likely to fade by the second half of 2019.

The nation's trade deficit widened as exports increased 1.6% while imports grew 2.7%. As a result, trade overall was a slight drag on economic growth. China has hit U.S. imports such as soybeans with tariffs in retaliation for broad U.S. tariffs on Chinese shipments. Trump recently delayed plans to increase a 10% tariff on $200 billion in Chinese goods to 25%, raising hopes for a resolution to the impasse.

Residential investment fell for the fourth straight month, slipping 3.5%. While low housing supplies reflect a need for more construction, builders have faced severe worker shortages and higher material costs that have slowed projects. Also, existing home sales slowed noticeably late last year amid higher mortgage rates and home prices, leading many builders to pull back. Both prices and rates have moderated recently, possibly heralding a recovery in housing starts.

Title: Former White House Strategist Steve Bannon Predicts Government Shutdown Over Border Wall Funding

Article:

Former White House strategist Steve Bannon has predicted another potential government shutdown before the midterm elections due to President Trump's insistence on funding his long-promised border wall. In an interview with CNN's Fareed Zakaria, Bannon stated, "I believe the government will actually shut down in the run-up to the election."

Bannon emphasized the significance of the wall, stating, "The wall is not just totemic; the wall is absolutely central to his program." Although President Trump has claimed that the wall is already being built, Congress has yet to allocate funding for it. To date, only existing fences have been repaired, and several prototypes of a possible wall have been constructed.

In January, CNN reported that the Trump administration had requested $33 billion to cover the costs of securing the border, with $18 billion allocated for the wall, according to Customs and Border Protection documents obtained by CNN and sent to lawmakers on Capitol Hill. In March, Congress passed a $1.3 trillion spending plan that did not include any funds for the wall. The president has been pressing for Congress to revisit the issue this fall.

Bannon suggested that President Trump may shut down the government if lawmakers again refuse to allocate funds for the wall. "I believe that what he's going to do is, as we come up on September 30, if that appropriations bill does not include spending to fully build his wall—not some $1.6 billion for prototypes, I mean to build the southern wall—I believe he will shut down the government," Bannon said.

Trump's demand for a wall was a central theme of his 2016 presidential campaign. In his Trump Tower announcement of a White House bid, Trump stated, "I would build a great wall, and nobody builds walls better than me, believe me, and I'll build them very inexpensively. I will build a great, great wall on our southern border. And I will have Mexico pay for that wall. Mark my words."

Until last week, Trump had largely avoided public statements on his demand that Mexico pay for the wall following his insistence on the issue leading to the cancellation of Mexico President Enrique Pena Nieto's planned visit to Washington in early 2017. Trump mentioned the wall again last week in his rally in Nashville, prompting another quick response from the Mexican president: "NO. Mexico will NEVER pay for a wall. Not now, not ever."

Title: US Deploys Military Resources to Middle East Amid Tensions with Iran; Iran Threatens to Resume Uranium Enrichment

Article:

The United States is deploying a Patriot missile-defense system to the Middle East in response to potential threats from Iran, according to the Pentagon. The USS Arlington, a warship carrying amphibious vehicles and aircraft, is also joining the USS Abraham Lincoln strike group in the Gulf. Additionally, US B-52 bombers have arrived at a base in Qatar.

The US has not specified the nature of the potential threats, but Iran has dismissed the deployments as "psychological warfare" aimed at intimidating the country. Iran has also suggested it may resume uranium enrichment nuclear activities.

The US currently has approximately 5,200 troops deployed in neighboring Iraq. The Patriot system is capable of countering ballistic missiles, cruise missiles, and advanced aircraft. The USS Arlington's deployment was reportedly brought forward to provide enhanced command and control capabilities.

Last year, US President Donald Trump unilaterally withdrew from a landmark nuclear deal between America and Iran, which limited Iran's sensitive nuclear activities in exchange for sanctions relief. In response to the US's economic sanctions, Iran's economy has experienced a sharp downturn, leading to record lows in the value of its currency, a decrease in foreign investment, and protests.

The Trump administration aims to compel Iran to negotiate a "new deal" that would cover not only its nuclear activities but also its ballistic missile program and "malign behavior" across the Middle East. Iran has repeatedly threatened to retaliate, including by potentially blocking the Strait of Hormuz, through which about a fifth of all oil consumed globally passes.

Earlier this week, Iran announced that it had suspended two commitments under the 2015 accord in response to the economic sanctions re-imposed by the US. The European powers remain committed to the Iran nuclear deal but "reject any ultimatums" from Iran to prevent its collapse. The real battle for the fate of the Iran nuclear deal is ongoing, with no guarantee of success and a growing risk of conflict.

Title: Differences Between Obama and Netanyahu Rooted in Policy Disagreements, Not Personalities

Article:

Yaakov Amidror, a former national security adviser to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, has stated that the differences between the Israeli leader and former U.S. President Barack Obama are more substantive than personal. Amidror noted that while there may be personal issues, the primary cause of their disagreements lies in their differing evaluations of the situation rather than their personal opinions of each other.

Given their contrasting political ideologies, friction between the liberal Democrat and the conservative Likud leader was inevitable. Critics suggest that Mr. Obama was not adequately sensitive to the nuances of the alliance, and had difficulty understanding Mr. Netanyahu's distrust. Additionally, Mr. Obama's decisions were sometimes worsened by a lack of preparation for the Israeli leader.

On the other hand, Mr. Netanyahu chose to interpret Mr. Obama's policies in the most incendiary manner, expressing outrage rather than emphasizing common ground. His suspicions were fueled by visits from Republican lawmakers and conservative patrons, such as casino mogul Sheldon Adelson, who had their own criticisms of the president.

When they communicate, their conversations are robust and pointed, with Mr. Netanyahu delivering his points bluntly and restraining his "monumental rage," as described by his former ambassador, Michael Oren, in a memoir. Mr. Obama is more reserved but may come off as condescending and rarely lets a point go unchallenged.

A phone call between them can last up to 90 minutes, with Benjamin J. Rhodes, the president's deputy national security adviser, noting that they enjoy debating each other to an extent. Mr. Obama and Mr. Netanyahu first met in 2007, when their aides hastily arranged a meeting at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in a janitor's office. Mr. Netanyahu, then in the opposition, was returning home, while Mr. Obama, running for president, was coming from the campaign trail. According to Rhodes, they "actually had chemistry."

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Address LGBTQ Issues, Foreign Aid, and HIV/AIDS

Article:

In a televised townhall event in Los Angeles, California, on October 10, 2019, eight Democratic presidential candidates, including former Vice President Joe Biden, discussed LGBTQ issues, foreign aid, and HIV/AIDS. The event, dedicated to LGBTQ issues, was the second major forum during the Democratic nominating campaign, following an event in Iowa last month.

Joe Biden, the front-runner in the Democratic race, addressed his past positions, particularly his vote for a military funding bill that included the "don't ask, don't tell" policy, which banned harassment of closeted gay soldiers but barred those who were out from military service. Biden later backed repeal of that policy and supported same-sex marriage before President Barack Obama, under whom he served as vice president.

Biden pledged to withhold foreign aid from countries that persecute LGBTQ people and establish an office in the State Department to promote LGBTQ rights globally. He also defended his record on LGBTQ issues and criticized efforts to curb LGBTQ rights.

South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who is vying to become the first openly gay U.S. president, spoke about his experience as a gay man, including serving in the military in Afghanistan while closeted. He also addressed the public health rules that bar gay men from giving blood, stating that the policy is based on prejudice rather than science. Buttigieg promised to change the policy if elected president.

U.S. Senator Cory Booker opened the forum, emphasizing inclusion and acceptance. Senator Bernie Sanders, a top Democratic contender, missed the event while recovering from a heart attack.

Gay rights advocates have expressed dismay at the Trump administration's record on LGBTQ issues, including a ban on transgender individuals serving in the U.S. military. Lawyers for the Department of Justice argued at the U.S. Supreme Court this week that federal civil rights law does not prohibit employers from firing workers based on their transgender identity or sexual orientation.

Ahead of the forum, Buttigieg, U.S. Senators Elizabeth Warren, and Kamala Harris released plans to secure equality for LGBTQ people. All three support the Equality Act, which would add LGBTQ protections to federal anti-discrimination law. They also vowed to make pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a drug that helps lower the risk of contracting the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), accessible and affordable to all who want it. Buttigieg aims to eliminate the HIV/AIDS epidemic by 2030, in part by restoring the White House Office of National AIDS Policy that has gone dormant under Trump.

All three candidates promised to elevate LGBTQ concerns as president. Warren said she would appoint a special envoy at the State Department, while Harris said she would create a White House position, chief advocate for LGBTQ+ Affairs, to coordinate efforts across the entire federal government. Warren, who has risen steadily in the polls to challenge Biden as the frontrunner, drew the biggest applause of the night as she addressed issues most of the candidates agreed on in a down-to-earth way.

Title: Supreme Court Faces Calls to Unseal Documents in Alabama Execution Case

Article:

The United States Supreme Court refused to grant a stay of execution to convicted murderer Christopher Price last week, just hours before his execution by the state of Alabama. The unusual aspect of the case lies in the fact that half of the briefs in the case were blacked out, preventing public view, and virtually all of the record in the case was sealed.

The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press and NPR have since filed a motion with the Supreme Court, requesting the unsealing of the material that was blocked from public view. The sealed information does not pertain to the defendant's guilt but rather concerns the drugs and execution protocol used by Alabama.

The Supreme Court has historically been open about its debates regarding the death penalty, but this case marks a departure from that transparency. All deletions were at the insistence of Alabama, according to the reporters' committee. The state provided no explanation for its need for secrecy.

In the past, the Supreme Court has upheld the right of access to a wide range of judicial proceedings and records, citing that such access "enhances the quality and safeguards the integrity of the fact-finding process" and allows "the public to participate in and serve as a check upon the judicial process—an essential component in our structure of self-government."

Defense lawyer Aaron Katz agreed to let the record be closed to the public and press in the lower courts due to time constraints, with the execution date set for May 30. Katz stated, "You can't afford any sideshow" in such circumstances. "You've essentially got to agree to whatever terms the state forces on you to get the information you need to prove your case."

The Reporters Committee is now asking the Supreme Court to unseal the briefs filed in the Supreme Court. Katie Townsend, legal director for the reporters committee, stated, "Alabama's claim that it needs to keep all that information secret is 'crazy.' How can it be 'that the state gets away with saying to the public, 'We're not going to tell you our legal arguments, or allow you to see our evidence, which goes to the heart of the legal issue'?'"

Mike Lewis, a spokesman for the Alabama attorney general, stated that the state sought to keep the records and arguments secret "out of concern for the safety of correctional officers as well as inmates." However, defense lawyer Aaron Katz has never sought to disclose the names of corrections officers or anyone else involved in the execution.

The reporters committee points to the availability of appellate records that extend "far back in the nation's history," and to a more recent opinion issued by the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. That decision declared that "the public can not have confidence that the nation's appellate courts issue well-reasoned and fair opinions derived from facts and legal arguments the parties present if the case proceeds with key argument and evidence under seal." The circuit court opinion was written by President Barack Obama's failed Supreme Court nominee, Merrick Garland, and joined by his then-colleague Brett Kavanaugh, later appointed to the Supreme Court by President Trump.

Title: Abortion Restrictions and Midterm Elections: A Divisive Issue in U.S. Politics

Article:

In the lead-up to the midterm elections, the issue of abortion has become a significant point of contention between the two major political parties in the United States. President Donald Trump and anti-abortion activists have touted recent actions restricting abortion as a means to galvanize Republican voters, while Democrats argue that these actions will hurt, not help, Republican candidates in November.

The Trump administration recently announced a proposal to ban recipients of federal family planning money from referring patients for abortions or sharing locations with abortion providers. This move, supporters argue, is a direct attack on federal support for Planned Parenthood, which receives millions annually from Title X, a $286 million program that funds organizations providing family planning services to low-income women and men.

Anti-abortion groups, such as the Susan B. Anthony List, have pushed for these changes to energize the grassroots ahead of the midterms, following Congress's failure to defund Planned Parenthood legislatively. On the other hand, Democrats, who refer to the restrictions as a "gag rule," hope to portray the proposal as another example of Republicans taking extreme actions to limit women's healthcare.

Groups on both sides of the abortion debate are pouring millions into the midterms, breaking their own records for campaign spending. Planned Parenthood announced a $20 million campaign targeting eight states in March, the largest such effort it has ever undertaken. The anti-abortion Susan B. Anthony List is aiming to surpass this amount, with a goal of raising and spending $25 million. NARAL Pro-Choice America announced its largest-ever midterm investment of $5 million in 19 states this week.

The stakes in the election are high for both sides. Anti-abortion advocates want more Republicans in the Senate to pass a ban on abortions after 20 weeks, defund Planned Parenthood, and approve any future Supreme Court nominees. Democrats, on the other hand, aim to gain control of both chambers to block such bills and fight back against policy changes from the administration.

In his year and a half in office, Trump has already given anti-abortion activists several reasons to celebrate. He has banned the use of tax dollars for foreign nongovernmental organizations that provide or promote abortions, broadened exemptions for employers who have moral or religious objections to providing birth control to their employees, and rescinded Obama-era guidance that sought to protect Planned Parenthood from state defunding efforts.

Fresh off these victories, anti-abortion groups are openly discussing ways to roll back Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court ruling that enshrined abortion rights. However, a January poll from the Pew Research Center showed 69 percent of Americans oppose overturning Roe v. Wade, with 28 percent supporting.

Both parties claim to have the upper hand, making the election a litmus test for public opinion that could shape the messaging of both parties heading into the 2020 presidential election. The outcome of the midterms could significantly impact the future of abortion policies in the United States.

Title: Trump Expresses Willingness to Engage with North Korea, Criticizes Paris Climate Accord, Dodd-Frank Regulations

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has expressed his willingness to engage in discussions with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in an attempt to halt Pyongyang's nuclear program. In an interview with Reuters on Tuesday, Trump also criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin's actions in eastern Ukraine, called for a renegotiation of the Paris climate accord, and stated his intention to dismantle most of the Dodd-Frank financial regulations if elected president.

Trump declined to provide specifics regarding his plans to address North Korea, but a meeting with Kim would represent a significant shift in U.S. policy towards the secluded nation. "I would speak to him. I would have no problem speaking to him," Trump said of Kim. Trump also emphasized the economic leverage the United States holds over China and stated that he would apply pressure on Beijing in this regard.

Regarding the Paris climate accord, Trump expressed disapproval, stating that the United States is treated unfairly by the agreement, which mandates carbon emissions reductions for over 170 countries. A renegotiation of the pact would constitute a major setback for the first truly global climate accord, which committed both rich and poor nations to limiting greenhouse gas emissions.

Turning to the economy, Trump indicated that he would release a detailed policy platform in two weeks. He stated that the platform would dismantle nearly all of Dodd-Frank, a package of financial reforms enacted following the 2007-2008 financial crisis. "I would say it'll be close to a dismantling of Dodd-Frank. Dodd-Frank is a very negative force, which has developed a very bad name," Trump said.

The New York billionaire also expressed concern about a financial bubble within the tech startup industry, stating that tech companies were achieving high valuations without ever turning a profit. Trump also mentioned his desire for a Republican to lead the U.S. Federal Reserve, but stated that he is not an adversary of current chair Janet Yellen. "I'm not a person that thinks Janet Yellen is doing a bad job. I happen to be a low-interest rate person unless inflation rears its ugly head, which can happen at some point," he said, adding that inflation "doesn't seem like it's happening any time soon."

Title: Jeff Bezos's Minimum Wage Stance Sparks Controversy

Article:

The ongoing debate surrounding the minimum wage has taken a new turn with the involvement of Jeff Bezos, the world's richest man and the founder of Amazon. The controversy stems from Sen. Bernie Sanders' criticism of Bezos due to some of Amazon's workers' eligibility for food stamps.

Initially, Amazon defended itself, labeling the criticisms as "inaccurate" and "misleading." However, the company's stance shifted when it announced plans to pay all its workers at least $15 per hour. This decision was met with approval from some quarters, but it has also sparked concerns about the potential impact on entry-level workers.

California restaurant manager Merv Crist, in a recent interview, expressed her view that a higher minimum wage could price less-skilled workers out of the job market. She argued that had a higher minimum wage existed when she was a teenager, her labor might not have been worth it to her employer, and she might not have had the opportunity to work her way up the career ladder.

Furthermore, Amazon's announcement that it would lobby for government intervention to enforce the higher wage has raised eyebrows. Critics argue that this move could create an unfair advantage for Amazon over its competitors, particularly smaller businesses that may not be able to afford the higher wage.

The debate highlights the complexities of minimum wage policies and their potential effects on employment opportunities for less-skilled workers. It also underscores the need for careful consideration when implementing policies aimed at addressing income inequality, as the unintended consequences can sometimes be far-reaching.

Title: Analysis of the 40th Republican National Convention: Romney and Ryan's Post-Convention Bounce in Tight Polls

Article:

The 40th Republican National Convention has concluded, and political analysts are examining the poll numbers to determine if Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan have experienced a post-convention surge in the closely divided polls.

Romney's convention managers made several strategic decisions. They chose not to revisit the 2008 election, as some conservatives might have preferred. Instead, Romney and Ryan acknowledged the desire for change that motivated many former Barack Obama voters and reflected on his record in office with a sense of sorrow rather than anger.

Former Democratic Representative Artur Davis eloquently expressed his disillusionment with the president. His speech was so compelling that it would have been inappropriate to air it on MSNBC, as it would have contradicted the cable channel's persistent narrative that Republicans are racists.

The convention also targeted young voters, who voted 66 to 32 percent for Obama in the last election, with Ryan's reference to twenty-somethings in their childhood bedrooms, "staring up at fading Obama posters and wondering when they can move out and get going with life." Additionally, the convention reached out to the significant number of voters who may feel uncomfortable with the idea of Americans rejecting the first black president.

An unexpected decision was the inclusion of Clint Eastwood at 10:00 Eastern, when the broadcast networks began their hour of coverage. This decision may have been motivated by the desire to address the one reason for rejecting a president: inadequate performance in office.

The convention was not as tightly scripted as previous conventions, with Clint Eastwood speaking without a teleprompter and Condoleezza Rice delivering her speech in the same manner. In back-to-back speeches, Ann Romney spoke about "love" and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie emphasized the importance of respect. This seemed discordant, but the two themes can be reconciled: a leader acts out of love for the people but prefers to be feared rather than loved.

The convention aimed to humanize Romney by revealing personal details about his and his wife's lives, emphasizing their relatability to the average person. The testimonies of fellow church members about the Romneys' service and caring were particularly moving. The convention floor was almost silent as they spoke, and their testimonies will likely appear in future TV ads.

The convention also addressed concerns that have undoubtedly surfaced in focus groups. Yes, the candidate is open to women taking a lead role, as they have on his staff. Yes, the candidate did help create businesses that employ tens of thousands and provide goods and services that people found they needed. Yes, Republicans care about education, and education choice, so that disadvantaged children have a chance to move upward.

Coming off the convention floor, there were raves about Romney's speech from rank-and-file delegates and limited praise from those with more experience. Not spectacular, they said, but good enough. This is actually high praise, as Democrats expect their presidential candidates to be intellectually dazzling and oratorically thrilling. Republicans, on the other hand, are satisfied if their politicians are competent enough to do the job.

Mitt Romney, in selecting Paul Ryan, in staging an inspiring rather than slick convention, and in delivering his acceptance speech, has convinced Republicans in the hall and around the nation, and probably many undecideds, that he is a more than sufficient tool to do the job.

Title: White House Aide David Sorensen Resigns Amid Domestic Abuse Allegations; Second White House Official to Depart Over Abuse Claims in a Week

Article:

David Sorensen, a speechwriter for the White House, has resigned following allegations of domestic abuse from his ex-wife, Jessica Corbett. This marks the second White House aide to resign this week over domestic abuse allegations. The other official, Rob Porter, also denied the accusations made by his two ex-wives.

According to a report by the Washington Post, Corbett stated that Sorensen was physically abusive during their marriage. She claimed that on separate occasions, her former husband ran a car over her foot, threw her against a wall, and extinguished a cigarette on her hand.

In response, Sorensen released a statement denying the allegations, saying, "I have never committed violence of any kind against any woman in my entire life." He added that he was considering legal action but resigned because he "did not want the White House to have to deal with this distraction."

White House officials learned of the allegations against Sorensen on Thursday, and deputy press secretary Raj Shah said, "We immediately confronted the staffer, he denied the allegations, and he resigned today."

Allegations of domestic abuse involving two of Porter's ex-wives surfaced on Tuesday. It is alleged that the former White House staff secretary gave one ex-wife a black eye while another filed a restraining order. Porter also denies the allegations.

On Friday, President Trump paid tribute to Porter, who resigned his White House position on Wednesday. Speaking in the Oval Office, Trump said, "We found out about it recently and I was surprised by it, but we certainly wish him well and it's a tough time for him." However, Trump did not refer to Porter's accusers.

The case has put pressure on White House Chief-of-Staff John Kelly, who has denied reports he offered to resign over his handling of the accusations. After initially praising Porter as a man of "integrity," Kelly later released a statement saying he was shocked by the claims and stressed domestic violence was unacceptable.

US media report that Kelly and other White House officials were aware for several months of the domestic abuse allegations because they were holding up Porter's security clearance application. It is unclear how long it took the White House to act on the accusations facing Mr. Porter.

White House communications director Hope Hicks' handling of the controversy has reportedly displeased President Trump. The 29-year-old aide has recently been in a relationship with Porter, a Harvard graduate and former Oxford Rhodes Scholar.

According to CBS News, Porter approached White House Counsel Don McGahn in January 2017 to inform him his ex-wives might say unflattering things about him to background check investigators. In June 2017, Porter's preliminary file was sent from the FBI to the White House security office, containing the abuse allegations. In November, McGahn received a call from an ex-girlfriend of Porter alleging physical violence by the aide.

It is unavailable whether the White House was aware of the extent of the allegations against Porter before Tuesday, as the article does not provide further information on this matter.

Title: Media Bias and Government Influence: A Critical Analysis of News Reporting

Article:

In a reflection on the state of media, the article discusses the author's concerns about the accuracy and objectivity of news reporting, particularly during natural disasters and political events. The author argues that sensationalism and government-centric thinking are prevalent in media coverage, citing examples such as the breathless coverage of a storm on the East Coast and the closure of government buildings during a weather event, while many private businesses remain open.

The author also criticizes the New York Times for its headline "What Happens When You Fight a 'Deep State' that Doesn't Exist?" The article argues that the deep state, often referred to as the administrative or regulatory state, does exist and is a significant force in shaping policy and stifling innovation. The author claims that the deep state consists of hundreds of new rules issued by regulators and that these rules often work against economic growth and individual freedom.

The author also takes issue with the Times' portrayal of President Donald Trump's appointee Scott Pruitt as being "at odds with the established scientific consensus" on climate change. The author argues that Pruitt's statement that he does not agree that man is the "primary contributor" to global warming is not necessarily at odds with the scientific consensus, as there is significant uncertainty in climate measurements and many scientists question the extent to which human activities are responsible for global warming.

The author also criticizes the media for failing to accurately portray the negative effects of socialism, citing the example of Venezuela's economic crisis. The author argues that socialism, characterized by caps on corporate profits, abolition of property rights, and regulation of car production, is the root cause of Venezuela's misery, but that this is not acknowledged in media coverage.

Overall, the author expresses frustration with the media's tendency to sensationalize events, to overlook the negative consequences of government intervention, and to fail to accurately portray the realities of socialism. The author calls for a more critical and objective approach to news reporting.

Title: Divisions Emerge Over Health Care Repeal as Election Nears

Article:

As the midterm elections approach, divisions are emerging among Republicans over the wisdom of repealing the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, root and branch. Some Republicans, particularly those facing re-election in swing districts, are suggesting that certain provisions of the law should be retained.

Representative Nan Hayworth, an ophthalmologist and a freshman Republican from New York, has proposed a framework for replacement that includes bolstered health savings accounts, the option to purchase insurance across state lines, medical malpractice limits, and a government-subsidized insurance pool for sick people who cannot buy insurance on their own. However, these alternatives have not been broadly aired.

"We need to start expressing our principles promptly," Representative Hayworth said.

In contrast, during the first repeal vote, a new, vigorous Republican majority was confident that they owed their triumph to voter anger over the health care law. Democrats were on the defensive, with all eyes on which survivors of the 2010 midterm tsunami would switch their votes for the law and embrace repeal. The House voted 245-to-189 to undo President Obama's signature domestic achievement, with three Democrats joining in.

Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said the health care law was passed "with deception at its core"—a penalty for those who fail to purchase insurance has been unmasked by the Supreme Court as a tax on the middle class. He believes the issue will be "probably the biggest driver" ensuring Republican victory in November, outside of the tax increases that could come next year with the expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts.

However, his deputy at the Republican Congressional Committee, Representative Greg Walden of Oregon, was more circumspect. "We’re going to be talking about jobs and economy, but there are lots of elements to that discussion, one of them being health care," Mr. Walden said.

Democrats, on the other hand, say they will be playing offense. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee started an advertising campaign Monday morning portraying Republicans as controlled by insurance companies and intent on taking away the popular consumer protections in the law. A series of news conferences are planned that will include real-life families whom Democrats say would be harmed by repeal.

But they will also frame the repeal vote as a political stunt, taking Congress's time away from job-creating legislation. A video to be released Monday will use Speaker John A. Boehner's oft-repeated phrase, "Mr. President, where are the jobs?" to mock the repeal exercise.

"There’s a strong sense that we don’t want to carry on this fight, over and over," said former Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia, a Democrat who is running for the Senate. "Let’s move on."

For Republicans in solidly conservative districts—a majority of Republicans in the House—the repeal vote is a no-cost way to energize the base and prove to angry constituents that the fight has not ended.

Representative Patrick McHenry, a Republican from western North Carolina, spoke of "fire and passion for repeal" still seething in his district. "Activist and average folks regularly bring up full repeal," he said. "They’re still keenly aware of it, demand it and understand this law is holding back economic growth."

However, Republican campaign consultants are more cautious. Those voters are already energized by the prospect of voting against President Obama in November. How a rehashing of the health care debate will affect independent voters is less clear.

Democrats are driving the narrative that voters are ready to move on. Dan Maffei, a former House Democrat from upstate New York who is campaigning to get his seat back, is using the Supreme Court's decision to push the debate toward improving the health care law he helped pass, not whether it should stay or go. To him, another vote—the 30th this Congress has held to repeal or partially repeal the law—is more evidence of the rut Washington is in.

"They’re stuck in this eternal recurrence, rerunning the debate on the bill over and over again instead of moving forward," Mr. Maffei said.

Title: Union City, New Jersey: The Enduring Legacy of the "Embroidery Capital of the World"

Article:

Union City, New Jersey, a one-square-mile city with a rich industrial history, has survived the decline of its once-thriving embroidery industry, earning it the title of the "Embroidery Capital of the World." Despite the city's close proximity to New York City and its bustling metropolitan area, it remains largely unnoticed by many passersby.

The city's transformation into an embroidery hub began at the turn of the 20th century, driven by its geological advantages and proximity to New York's shipping harbors. Union City welcomed immigrants from various European countries, including the Swiss, Germans, Italians, and Irish, and later, Cubans and a diverse array of Latin American communities.

Embroidery was not the only industry in Union City; breweries, industrial material manufacturers, a giant soap factory, and numerous other goods populated the North Jersey factory ecosystem. However, the city's unique social fabric was woven by the embroidery industry, which brought workers together and created a vibrant, interconnected community.

Unionization in Union City was a gradual process, with the city becoming a hotbed of union activity in the early 1900s. The Teamsters union, which has a legendary reputation for its alleged role in the mysterious disappearance of Jimmy Hoffa, still maintains a presence in the city.

The collapse of the embroidery industry in Union City, like many other American factory towns, was accelerated by globalization and the implementation of trade agreements such as NAFTA. The city, however, managed to adapt and thrive, with small businesses, New York jobs, and an aggressive push by the municipal government filling the void left by the embroidery industry.

Today, a few embroidery businesses still operate in Union City, producing silk and lace. This is the story of a city that has survived economically following the destruction of its core industry, yet not without loss—the city has lost a critical cultural institution due to business decisions made far beyond its control.

Union City's story serves as a testament to the resilience of communities faced with the economic consequences of globalization and federal policies. It is a reminder of the far-reaching impact of decisions made at the federal and global level, even when local politicians act in good faith. Yet, it is not a tragedy, nor a rebuke of the local government for growing in the face of external pressures. The alternative was destitution, regression to a ghost town, a fate Union City narrowly escaped in the aftermath of World War II.

Title: Federal Reserve Expected to Raise Federal Funds Rate, Impact on Economy and Stock Prices Discussed

Article:

The Federal Reserve is anticipated to increase the federal funds rate following its two-day meeting on Wednesday. This move, which has not occurred since the financial crisis in 2008, could potentially increase the cost of mortgages, slow job creation, and curb stock prices, but not always.

The impact of the Fed's tightening largely depends on whether a higher federal funds rate causes an increase in the 10-year Treasury rate. Rates on mortgages, corporate, and municipal bonds generally follow the 10-year Treasury rate up and down.

During Ben Bernanke's tenure when the federal funds rate was raised in 2004-2006, those rates remained relatively stable due to the Chinese government's rapid purchase of U.S. bonds to keep the yuan cheap against the dollar. Currently, both the Chinese and European economies are experiencing troubles, and their monetary authorities are printing money to lower borrowing costs. This increased purchasing of U.S. securities by private investors seeking safer and better returns could limit any increase in U.S. long rates.

Household balance sheets are in their best shape since the recovery began, and lower gasoline prices provide consumers with more disposable income. These factors should offset the effects of marginally higher short-term interest rates on consumer spending, and economic growth is expected to accelerate to 2.5 to 3 percent in the New Year.

Bank fees and car loans will become more expensive due to tighter banking regulations and higher short-term borrowing rates for banks. Banks may attempt to increase fees on checking accounts and other services, and charge higher rates for short-term credit, such as credit cards, car loans, and home improvements. However, banks may also start competing more for deposits and pay higher rates on 1 to 5-year CDs.

The stronger dollar and lower oil prices are impacting corporate profits, and hiring has slowed this year to about 210,000 new jobs a month—less than the 260,000 monthly average in 2014. Small businesses, a significant source of new jobs in an economic recovery, have already faced tighter federal regulations that have led large banks to curtail lending to these entities. Slightly higher short rates are not likely to have a significant additional impact on their access to credit.

Finding a job remains challenging for the long-term unemployed, whose skills may have atrophied during the Great Recession and slow recovery. Government benefits, such as expanded Medicaid and food stamps for healthy men, have often overshadowed incentives to reskill.

Overall, if Beijing can implement an adequate stimulus program to stabilize its economy, the global economy will not sink America's boat, and job gains will continue. Once gasoline prices have bottomed, overall inflation will rise to about 2 percent.

Problems in China and shifts in the broader global economy have caused equity prices to fluctuate recently. However, the Fed rate increase is widely anticipated and is likely already built into equity prices. The market is more likely to react positively to a rate increase simply because uncertainty about timing has been removed.

The economy has emerged from a tough recession and slow recovery in which the Fed deemed ultra-low interest rates necessary. However, conditions have improved, and in past decades, stock prices have often moved up even as the Fed raised interest rates. This remains a good time to be in stocks, and if you are an investor on the sidelines, gradually start buying in.

Title: Supreme Court Blocks Enforcement of Strict New Asylum Policy

Article:

The Supreme Court has blocked the Trump administration from immediately enforcing a strict new asylum policy in a 5-4 decision. This marks the second legal setback this week for efforts to tighten immigration rules.

The court, in a brief written order, denied a bid to begin enforcing an asylum ban for any immigrants who illegally cross the U.S.-Mexico border. The decision leaves in place lower-court rulings that blocked the administration from automatically denying asylum to people who do not go through official border crossings.

An open-ended nationwide injunction on enforcement issued by a San Francisco-based federal judge this week prompted the Justice Department to seek immediate relief from the Supreme Court. Chief Justice John Roberts provided the critical vote against the administration, siding with the four liberal justices. Newly confirmed Justice Brett Kavanaugh and three other conservatives on the bench sided with the administration, the order said.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, despite having surgery in New York on Friday to remove cancerous nodules in her lung, apparently voted with the majority, avoiding a 4-4 tie.

The current legal challenge originated in California, where the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals also recently ruled against the administration and said the policy was likely “inconsistent” with existing law.

Trump has said he was acting in response to caravans of migrants making their way to the border. The Supreme Court order comes after a federal judge in a separate case took the extraordinary step this week of ordering that asylum seekers who sued after their deportation be returned to the U.S. to have their claims heard anew.

U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan, in doing so, blocked policies that could prevent immigrants who claim to have suffered gang violence or domestic abuse in their home countries from seeking asylum. The White House said in response that Wednesday's ruling "will further overwhelm our immigration courts with meritless cases, making the existing massive backlog even worse."

Despite setbacks in the courts, the administration is moving forward with other changes. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen announced Thursday that the U.S. has secured an agreement with Mexico so that immigrants claiming asylum will be returned to Mexico as their cases are processed—a bid to end the practice known as “catch-and-release.” Nielsen made the announcement at a House Judiciary Committee hearing, telling the committee that the goal is to crack down on migrants falsely claiming asylum, only to be released into the U.S. and escape the radar of immigration officials.

"But by the time the courts have issued their orders, most of these illegal aliens have vanished within our country for good," she said. "They have escaped the law, undermined the system, and made it harder for us to actually help real asylum-seekers by flooding the system with false claims."

Title: Senator Chris Van Hollen Proposes Motion for Supreme Court Chief Justice to Decide on Witnesses in Impeachment Trial

Article:

Senator Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) has announced plans to make a motion on Friday that would require Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts to decide whether the Senate will hear from witnesses in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial. In a statement, Van Hollen stated, "A fair trial includes documents and witnesses. In a fair trial, the judge determines what evidence is admitted. My motion ensures the Chief Justice will serve the same role as a judge in any trial across our country – to allow the Senate access to the facts they need to get to the truth."

The motion, according to Van Hollen, would require the Chief Justice to subpoena witnesses and documents if he determines they are likely to provide evidence relevant to the articles of impeachment. It would also require the Chief Justice to rule on any executive privilege, to prevent efforts by the Administration to stonewall and delay access to the facts.

Van Hollen stated that the motion is consistent with Senate rules and could pass with a majority vote, and would preserve the right of the Senate to overrule the Chief Justice if the majority disagrees. He added, "No Republican can question the fairness of this approach – the Chief Justice oversees the highest court in our land and was nominated by a Republican President."

The senator further stated, "Given his authority to rule on questions of privilege, they should not fear a drawn-out process. I urge my colleagues to seek out truth and the facts and to vote in support of my motion. Anything else constitutes an effort to hide the truth."

Democrats have repeatedly argued that hearing from witnesses will clear up the air on the president's so-called wrongdoing. Two of the main people they want to hear from are former National Security Adviser John Bolton and Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney.

Republicans have argued that any witnesses should have been called in the House. When these officials were slapped with Congressional subpoenas, the White House invoked executive privilege. Instead of waiting for the courts to rule whether or not these officials' testimony was a matter of national security, Speaker Nancy Pelosi pushed full steam ahead. She admitted that the courts could "take a very long time" to make a determination.

Title: Obama Proposes College Ranking Plan Based on Work-Ready Skills, Sparks Debate

Article:

President Obama recently embarked on a two-day bus tour of schools, advocating for a new plan to rank colleges that rely on federal funding. The proposal, which has received mixed reactions, aims to evaluate institutions based on metrics such as the percentage of students who complete their education and the earnings of graduates. The objective is to facilitate the flow of federal aid to colleges with higher rankings, particularly those with lower tuition rates.

One of the criticisms leveled against the Obama plan is that it may not address the primary concern of the modern job market: employers' skepticism towards college credentials. The issue is not merely grade inflation, although it is a significant concern, with the percentage of A's given by teachers nearly tripling in recent decades. Instead, today's employers are seeking graduates with a set of cognitive skills suitable for a rapidly changing global economy.

These skills, often referred to as competency-based learning, encompass critical thinking, problem-solving, quantitative reasoning, and the ability to critique arguments. In essence, graduates should possess the ability to ask the right questions for creative solutions in competitive businesses.

A graduate's grade-point average, primarily based on discipline-specific information, may not necessarily indicate a good thinker. Nor does graduating from a highly ranked school. A 2011 study titled "Academically Adrift" by Richard Arum and Josipa Roksa found that at least 45 percent of college students showed little or no improvement in critical-thinking skills after their first two years in college.

This could explain why 57 percent of Americans told Pew pollsters last year that colleges fail to provide students with good value for the money. Additionally, a 2010 survey by the Association of American Colleges and Universities found that only 1 in 4 employers believes colleges prepare students for the global economy.

If lawmakers aim to assist colleges, students, and employers in the education sector, they should consider objective scorecards that measure a graduate's work-ready skills. These tests offer an alternative credential for graduates to present to potential employers. They also help hold colleges and universities accountable for the quality of their teaching.

One of the most promising tests is the Collegiate Learning Assessment (CLA+), produced by the New York-based nonprofit research organization Council for Aid to Education. The CLA+ offers a credible benchmark on an individual's ability to "access, structure, and use information." The test costs $35 and takes approximately 90 minutes to complete.

Several states have already tied government aid for colleges to such tests and other measures of "learning outcomes." Additionally, a few hundred colleges plan to administer the CLA+ tests this year. The tests also provide a means for students who take free or for-profit online courses to earn a credible credential for employment.

Advanced economies that rely on innovation require advanced thinkers, or those adept at higher-order skills such as perception and creativity. Mr. Obama and Congress should consider changing the meaning and purpose of the college degree by focusing on the development of these skills.

Title: McConnell's Decision to Alter Supreme Court Nomination Rules Sparks Controversy

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is pursuing a controversial move to change the rules for Supreme Court nominations, potentially ending the use of the filibuster for such appointments. This decision comes in response to Democratic opposition to the confirmation of President Trump's nominee, Neil Gorsuch.

During an interview with NBC's "Meet the Press," McConnell stated that if Democrats had been in power, they would not have filled a Republican president's vacancy. He did not confirm whether Republicans would unilaterally change the Senate rules via the "nuclear option" to confirm Gorsuch.

Adam Jentleson, a former deputy chief of staff to Senator Harry Reid, wrote in a New York Times op-ed that McConnell's relentless opposition to President Obama's policies led to Reid's decision to end the filibuster on lower court nominees. McConnell's actions, according to Jentleson, included arm-twisting his fellow Republicans to obstruct Obama's policies, regardless of their substance.

This approach extended to the Affordable Care Act, where McConnell reportedly pressured his Republican colleagues to refuse cooperation with Democrats, arguing that a bipartisan bill would be perceived as acceptable by the public.

Critics argue that McConnell's actions embody a "party before country" philosophy that contributed to the election of President Trump. If McConnell invokes the "nuclear option," it would be a significant shift in Senate procedure and could further polarize an already divided Senate.

Title: Clinton Invokes Sanders' Rhetoric on Income Inequality, Declines to Release Wall Street Speech Transcripts

Article:

In the aftermath of her victory in the New York primary, securing her near-assured nomination as the Democratic presidential candidate, Hillary Clinton adopted a tone reminiscent of her rival, Bernie Sanders, during a "Good Morning America" Town Hall. Clinton and Sanders, she stated, share a common goal of addressing income inequality, raising the minimum wage, and regulating financial institutions.

"Senator Sanders and I both want to tackle inequality," Clinton said. "We want to raise the minimum wage. We want to make sure that people who are putting our economy at risk are reined in, regulated."

However, Clinton's stance on income inequality has been a subject of criticism, particularly from the left, due to her past highly-paid speeches to financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs, during her tenure as Secretary of State. The content of these speeches remains private, and Sanders has called on Clinton to release them. Clinton has declined to do so.

When asked about the new demand to disclose transcripts of her speeches, Clinton responded, "When everybody agrees to do that, I will as well. Because I think it's important we all abide by the same standard."

Clinton defended her decision to give speeches after leaving the Secretary of State office, citing her unique perspective and the interest in her insights on global affairs. She compared herself to other former secretaries of state, such as Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice, who have also given speeches post-office.

"When you leave the secretary of state office, people from all perspectives want to know, 'What do you think's going on in the world?' I think that's actually a useful conversation," Clinton said. "Like all my predecessors, I gave speeches to a wide variety of groups, and it was predominantly about what's going on in the world."

Title: House Republicans Delay August Recess as Border Security Bill Faces Uncertain Future

Article:

The House of Representatives is facing a delay in their August recess as they scramble to pass a border security bill. The chaotic situation unfolded on Thursday, with House leadership suddenly pulling their legislation from the House floor due to flagging support. A meeting is scheduled for Friday morning at 9 a.m. to discuss a potential path forward, but plans are subject to change at any moment.

Speaker John Boehner, Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, and Majority Whip Steve Scalise heard from numerous Republicans during a Thursday afternoon meeting who did not want to leave Washington without a bill passing. Representative Matt Salmon (R-Ariz.) expressed his willingness to stay "till the cows come home."

However, the votes in support of the original $ 659 million border bill have been dwindling, and it remains unclear if Scalise, who is the new GOP whip, will be able to regain support for the package. The political impact of this decision is not yet clear, but if the House does not vote, Democrats will be able to say that the GOP left Washington for an entire month without passing legislation to address the influx of migrants across the U.S.-Mexico border.

The challenges facing the House bill were evident earlier Thursday, as hard-right conservatives indicated that they were still not appeased by the last-minute offer of a vote on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in exchange for moving forward on the border funding bill. This bloc demanded tougher border-security and immigration provisions in the supplemental package, as well as the inclusion of language rolling back DACA in the funding bill.

More than 57,000 unaccompanied children, mostly from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, have been apprehended at the southern border since October, exhausting government resources and leading federal agencies to warn that they will begin running out of money in August to deal with the crisis. The House bill would have provided funds for the border, revised a 2008 anti-trafficking law, and called for bolstering National Guard presence on the border.

The White House criticized the House's plan after leaders tacked on the DACA vote. The deferral program, announced by President Barack Obama in June 2012 during his reelection bid, has protected more than 550,000 young undocumented immigrants who grew up in the United States from deportation and provided work permits. However, Republicans have blamed DACA for contributing to the current crisis on the border, arguing that it sends a message to children from abroad that they, too, could be allowed to stay here lawfully.

CORRECTION: Due to an editing error, an earlier version of this piece misstated the cost of the border bill.
CORRECTION: Due to an editing error, an earlier version of this piece misstated the cost of the border bill.

Title: Sanders Narrows Gap with Clinton in California Ahead of Primary Election

Article:

As Tuesday's primary election in California approaches, the campaign of Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders is gaining momentum, with the candidate inching closer to an upset victory over former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. According to Real Clear Politics, Clinton currently holds an overall average lead of 10.8 points over Sanders, but in California, that lead narrows significantly, with Sanders trailing Clinton by 4.7 points overall and by just two points in two recent polls. In one recent poll reported on Friday, Sanders led Clinton by one point.

The Sanders campaign is citing a potential win in the most populous state as a reason to continue their bid, as they believe a victory will encourage superdelegates who currently support Clinton to switch their allegiances. Jeff Weaver, Sanders' campaign manager, told MSNBC on Friday, "The truth of the matter is, there are hundreds and hundreds of Clinton's so-called superdelegates who announced their support for her before there was a race, before we have seen all these recent and consistent polls."

Meanwhile, Donald Trump's campaign is keeping a close eye on the ongoing battle. Sam Clovis, Trump's national co-chairman and chief policy adviser, commented to Fox News on Friday that Sanders is "right over her shoulder," and Clinton is making a drastic pivot to the left as a result.

Even with a decisive win in California, it's unlikely that Sanders will be able to catch Clinton, as California is not a winner-take-all delegates race, and its 475 delegates are awarded proportionally. Clinton only needs 256 pledged delegates to clinch the nomination, meaning the superdelegates would not play a significant role. There are 763 pledged delegates still available between now and the Tuesday primaries in California and five other states, meaning Clinton needs to secure just one out of every three delegates. This means she can secure the nomination even before California's polls close on Tuesday.

However, if Sanders defeats Clinton, Republicans could use her loss to depict her as a flawed general election candidate, and Sanders could use the victory to stay in the race through the July convention, forcing Clinton to fight a two-front battle for a longer period than she had anticipated. Sanders has been campaigning hard in California since May 17, and Clinton has also opted to spend the last few days in the state, including with a headline-making speech in San Diego where she criticized Trump's foreign policy.

Title: Supreme Court Allows Indiana to Enforce Fetal Remains Disposal, Rejects Abortion Restrictions Based on Race, Sex, or Disability

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States decided on Tuesday to allow a provision of an Indiana law that requires the burial or cremation of fetal remains to take effect, while blocking a more controversial provision that would prohibit abortions motivated solely by race, sex, or disability. The court's decision not to take up the more contentious provision suggests a reluctance to challenge the core abortion precedents of Roe v. Wade and Casey v. Planned Parenthood.

The law, signed in March 2016 by then-Indiana Governor Mike Pence, was blocked last year from going into effect by the 7th US Circuit Court of Appeals. Pence's office did not respond to CNN's request for comment on Tuesday. In a pair of tweets, the vice president defended his signing of the law three years ago, saying in one tweet that he was "proud" to support the measure and calling the high court's decision "a victory for life!"

Justice Clarence Thomas, in a concurring opinion, argued that the court should revisit the issue of abortion rights, stating that the Constitution is silent on abortion and that the court is "duty bound to address its scope." Thomas also wrote extensively about the history of eugenics, suggesting that laws like Indiana's are necessary to prevent abortion from becoming a tool of modern-day eugenics.

No other justice, including Thomas's four fellow conservatives who are seen as backing more restrictive access to abortions, joined him in his opinion. Steve Vladeck, CNN Supreme Court analyst and professor at the University of Texas School of Law, said Thomas's opinion does not necessarily indicate the court will immediately take up the issue.

"Although Justice Thomas argues that the court will soon have to take up the issue it ducked today, I think it's telling that none of the other conservative justices -- John Roberts, Samuel Alito, Neil Gorsuch, and Brett Kavanaugh -- joined his separate opinion," Vladeck said. "It's quite possible that Thomas's opinion is therefore less a prediction of where the court is likely to go than an aspiration."

The court also declined to take up the more controversial provision of the Indiana law, which would prohibit abortions based on the race, sex, or disability of the fetus. In his decision last year, Judge William Bauer wrote that provisions in the law that bar women from seeking abortions in certain cases "clearly violate" well-established Supreme Court precedent and are therefore unconstitutional.

The law requires that fetal remains be disposed of in the same manner as other human remains (i.e., burial and cremation), and the state can prohibit abortion that is solely motivated by the race, sex, or disability of the fetus. The law has been blocked from going into effect by lower courts. Indiana's attorney general, Curtis Hill Jr., said the language "expands on long-established legal and cultural traditions of recognizing the dignity and humanity of the fetus."

Title: Congressional Disapproval of Iran Nuclear Deal Does Not Hinder President Obama's Implementation

Article:

The upcoming vote in Congress regarding the Iranian nuclear deal is shaping up as a warning to Europe against resuming business with Tehran before the next U.S. president is elected. Despite strong bipartisan disapproval, President Obama is expected to implement the agreement, as he has broad executive authority to ease many sanctions on Iran by himself.

Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, the highest-profile Democrat to endorse the deal, has stated that he will attempt to sway other members of his party. However, clear bipartisan majorities in the House and Senate are lining up against the deal.

President Obama, acting on his own, can delist Iranian banks, commercial entities, and individuals targeted for sanctions. He can also order the Treasury Department to give out licenses allowing financial and commercial transactions with Iranian businesses. The president could provide sanctions relief for Iranian oil exports by treating legislation passed by Congress in 2012 as unconstitutional.

Section 1245 of the National Defense Authorization Act required the president to freeze assets of Iranian banks, including the Central Bank of Iran, and aimed to reduce Iranian oil revenue by imposing sanctions on foreign banks that carry out "significant financial transactions" with the central bank. However, President Obama issued a "signing statement" on Section 1245 when he approved the overall legislation, stating that he could treat that section as nonbinding because it "would interfere with my constitutional authority to conduct foreign relations."

"He would challenge Republicans to fight him in the courts," said Mark Dubowitz, executive director of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies and a critic of the agreement. "He would essentially just circumvent that statutory designation and provide significant sanctions relief."

President Obama will continue to make his case for the Iranian deal on Friday when he addresses Jewish organizations and takes questions in a webcast. In addition to Senator Reid, the White House has picked up the support of Rep. Jerrold Nadler, a New York Democrat, after President Obama wrote a letter to the lawmaker offering specific assurances that the U.S. would "take whatever means are necessary" to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon, including possible military action.

While the president was on vacation, more lawmakers announced which way they will vote when Congress takes up the Iran agreement in mid-September. So far, 29 senators, including two Democrats, are voting against the agreement. Twenty-six senators are supporting it, with 45 uncommitted, but it's almost a certainty that all 54 Republican senators will vote against the deal.

In the House, 225 lawmakers—including 16 Democrats—have announced that they would vote against the deal, according to a tally compiled by the Bipartisan Policy Center. There are 69 House lawmakers in favor of the deal so far, and 140 are uncommitted.

Despite the opposition, lawmakers would need to muster a two-thirds majority vote in the House and the Senate to override President Obama's expected veto of the Iran resolution. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, has said a veto override is unlikely.

However, the ultimate size of the vote against the agreement will influence European governments and industries about the prospects of U.S. policymakers seeking a tougher deal after President Obama leaves office. European leaders and business chiefs "would be reticent to rush back in if there was a resounding vote of disapproval," said Mr. Dubowitz. "They would want to know what the next president is going to do before they found themselves on the wrong end of an enforcement action."

Title: Liberal Journalists' Definition of 'Fake News' Sparks Controversy and Concerns of Censorship

Article:

In the aftermath of Donald Trump's election victory last month, a debate on the concept of 'fake news' has intensified among liberal journalists. The term has been used to explain the disconnect between political journalists and the general public, with some blaming it for the perceived disconnect. However, there seems to be a lack of consensus on a consistent definition of 'fake news.'

Some liberal journalists have included legitimate news organizations, such as Independent Journal Review (IJR) and The Blaze, under the 'fake news' umbrella alongside objectively false sites that generate viral hoaxes. This practice has been criticized for misleading the public and serving a particular narrative.

For instance, BuzzFeed News, a left-leaning news organization, has been accused of misleading the public with its coverage of 'fake news,' including stories about hoax websites run by teenagers in Macedonia pushing lies like "Pope Francis endorses Donald Trump."

Meanwhile, other left-leaning news organizations have lumped legitimate news organizations alongside objectively false sources. A list of 'fake news' sites compiled by a liberal college professor, which was uncritically accepted and distributed by some liberal journalists, included top right-of-center sites like IJR and The Blaze.

The Washington Post labeled one website as 'fake news' without providing any evidence, a move that has led to a potential defamation lawsuit. The website, which was included on a similar list, argues that it is a legitimate news source.

Some liberal journalists have argued that 'conservative news' and 'fake news' are the same thing. This argument has been criticized for conflating legitimate news organizations with objectively false sites.

The debate has raised concerns that the crackdown on 'fake news' sites, the actual influence of which remains unknown, could be used by liberals to censor their conservative competitors. Some argue that this could lead to government control over First Amendment-protected speech or increased censorship by social media platforms.

In an interview with a conservative site, Media Research Center director of media analysis Tim Graham warned, "The danger here is that when liberals try to define 'fake news,' it can be defined as 'fake angles,' as in 'things that should not be explored,' like paying for protesters."
