Conservative website The Daily Wire was listed as 'fake news' without justification, leading to concerns that the 'fake news' label is being used to censor conservative viewpoints.

The debate over 'fake news' and its definition continues, with some arguing for a more nuanced approach to distinguish between legitimate news organizations and objectively false sites, while others see it as a tool for censorship.

Title: Over 250 Foreign Students Arrested in Sting Operation at Fake Detroit University

 Article:

 About 90 additional foreign students at a university in metro Detroit, revealed to be a creation of the Department of Homeland Security, have been arrested in recent months. This brings the total number of students arrested on immigration violations by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to approximately 250 since January.

 The university, known as the University of Farmington, marketed itself as offering graduate programs in technology and computer studies. The students, mostly from India, had arrived legally in the U.S. on student visas but lost their immigration status when the University of Farmington was shut down in January. The school was staffed with undercover agents posing as university officials.

 Out of the approximately 250 students arrested on administrative charges, "nearly 80% were granted voluntary departure and departed the United States," the Detroit office of ICE's Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) told the Free Press in a statement Tuesday.

 Of the remaining 20%, about half have received a final order of removal; some were ordered removed by an immigration judge, and others "were given an expedited removal by U.S. Customs and Border Protection." HSI Detroit said the remaining 10% "have either filed for some sort of relief or are contesting their removals with Executive Office for Immigration Review."

 ICE said in March that 161 students had been arrested, a number that has now grown to about 250. Meanwhile, seven of the eight recruiters who were criminally charged with trying to recruit students have pleaded guilty and been sentenced in Detroit. The remaining defendant will be sentenced in January.

 Attorneys for the students arrested said they were unfairly trapped by the U.S. government since the Department of Homeland Security had said on its website that the university was legitimate. An accreditation agency that was working with the U.S. on its sting operation also listed the university as legitimate.

 More than 600 students were enrolled at the university, which was created a few years ago by federal law enforcement officials with ICE. Records filed with the state Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs show that the University of Farmington was incorporated in January 2016.

 Many of the students had enrolled with the university through a program known as Curricular Practical Training, which allows students to work in the U.S through a F-1 visa program for foreign students. Some had transferred to the University of Farmington from other schools that had lost accreditation, which means they would no longer be allowed to remain in the U.S.

 Emails obtained by the Free Press this year showed how the fake university attracted students to the school, which cost about $12,000 on average in tuition and fees per year.

 "They preyed upon on them," said Rahul Reddy, a Texas attorney who represented or advised some of the students arrested. "They trapped the vulnerable people who just wanted to maintain (legal immigration) status."

 The fake university is believed to have collected millions of dollars from the unsuspecting students. No one has filed a lawsuit or claim against the U.S. government for collecting the money or for allegedly entrapping the students.

 Attorneys for ICE and the Department of Justice maintain that the students should have known it was not a legitimate university because it did not have classes in a physical location. Some CPT programs have classes combined with work programs at companies.

 "Their true intent could not be clearer," Assistant U.S. Attorney Brandon Helms wrote in a sentencing memo this month for one of the eight recruiters. "While 'enrolled' at the University, one hundred percent of the foreign citizen students never spent a single second in a classroom. If it were truly about obtaining an education, the University would not have been able to attract anyone, because it had no teachers, classes, or educational services."

 In the memo, federal prosecutor Baker said the case raises questions about the U.S. "foreign-student visa program."

 Baker wrote that "immigration and visa programs have been hot-button topics in the United States for years and national scrutiny has only been increasing."

 Reddy said, though, that in some cases, students who transferred from the University of Farmington after realizing they didn't have classes on-site, were still arrested.

 Detroit ICE spokesman Khaalid Walls said the recruiters sentenced so far include Barath Kakireddy, 29, of Lake Mary, Florida, 18 months; Suresh Kandala, 31, of Culpeper, Virginia, 18 months; Santosh Sama, 28, of Fremont, California, 24 months; Avinash Thakkallapally, 28, of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, 15 months; Aswanth Nune, 26, of Atlanta, 12 months; Naveen Prathipati, 26, of Dallas, 12 months. Phanideep Karnati, 35, of Louisville, Kentucky, is to be sentenced in January.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Use as Secretary of State Posed National Security Threat, Report Suggests

Article:

A new report by the State Department's Inspector General has revealed that Hillary Clinton's decision to use a personal email system while serving as Secretary of State in 2009 posed a significant threat to national security. The report, released last week, details multiple warnings issued to Clinton and her staff regarding cybersecurity threats, yet Clinton continued to use her personal email for sensitive State Department business.

The first warning came in January 2011, when hackers attempted to breach Clinton's private server. The staffer responsible for maintaining the server notified State Department officials, and Clinton's top aides advised against discussing sensitive matters via email.

In March 2011, the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security sent a memorandum on cybersecurity threats directly to Clinton, warning of an increase in efforts to compromise the private home email accounts of senior department officials. The memo also stated that some personal email accounts had already been compromised and were being used to forward emails to hackers.

In May 2011, Clinton herself suspected a hacking incident after receiving a suspicious email link. Hours later, she received another email with a suspect link from the personal account of the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

A month later, the State Department sent a cable to all diplomatic and consular posts, advising against conducting official business from personal email accounts. The cable was signed by Hillary Clinton.

These warnings, issued over a six-month period, should have alerted any responsible public official to the national security risks associated with insecure email communications. However, Clinton and several of her top aides continued to use personal email for thousands of instances of sensitive State Department business.

While Clinton is under potential criminal investigation by the FBI for mishandling classified material sent through her email, she has remained silent during the investigation. This silence may be in her best interests and is within her rights. However, to become President, she will need to convince voters that she can prioritize the national security of the United States over her personal self-interest.

It is clear that Clinton broke the rules regarding email usage while serving as Secretary of State. The question now remains whether she also broke the law.

This editorial represents the opinions of the ███ Editorial Board, separate from the news staff. Most editorials include an opposing view, a unique feature of ███.

After this editorial was published, CNN's Jake Tapper asked Clinton to respond to the Editorial Board's criticism. Clinton stated that it was "obvious" that she has always put national security above personal self-interest.

Title: Homeland Security Reveals High Rate of Visa Overstays, Critics Call It a National Security Concern

Article:

In a hearing held by the Senate's immigration subcommittee on Wednesday, Homeland Security officials disclosed that approximately 527,127 individuals overstayed their visas in 2015, representing 1.17% of the 45 million temporary visas issued for business and tourist travelers during the same period. This revelation has sparked criticism from lawmakers who view it as a significant loophole in immigration enforcement and national security.

The report, which is more than a decade overdue and incomplete, does not cover major visa categories for students or guest workers, both of which are likely to have higher overstay rates. The government deported only about 2,500 visa overstays last year, and has only about 3,000 active cases, accounting for a small fraction of the problem.

Sen. Jeff Sessions (Alabama Republican and chairman of the immigration subcommittee) stated, "This is the way the system gets eroded. This is where public confidence is being destroyed. This is how we’re sending a message to the world that you can get away with it."

Among those who overstayed are thousands from countries with connections to terrorism: 219 from Afghanistan, 681 from Iraq, 564 from Iran, 56 from Libya, 1,435 from Pakistan, 440 from Syria, and 219 from Yemen in fiscal year 2015 alone.

Craig C. Healy, assistant director of National Security Investigations at U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, noted that individuals who overstay are unlikely to be prioritized for investigation unless they are deemed national security threats, serious criminals, or meet the secretary's priorities.

The high rate of overstays, coupled with the surge of Central Americans coming across the southwest border, likely means the number of illegal immigrants in the U.S. is rising. The government is struggling with how to measure who has left the country, as there is still no biometric exit system, and the government relies on passenger information from airlines to complete its checks.

Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have called for a solution, particularly after Congress recently dedicated $1 billion from visa fees to be spent on the problem. John Wagner, deputy assistant commissioner at U.S. Customs and Border Protection, stated that the hiccup is in trying to find a way to do the checks without disrupting international travel at airports.

Jessica Vaughan, policy studies director at the Center for Immigration Studies, expressed concern about the high rate of overstays in visitors from visa-waiver countries, with nearly 3% of visitors from Greece overstaying, and the worst offenders being regular visa countries such as Djibouti and Bhutan, where about a quarter of all visitors overstayed in 2015.

Tourist and business visas are supposed to be issued only to those who appear to have ties to their home countries and are likely to return. Japan had one of the best compliance rates, with only a fifth of a percent of the more than 3 million visitors in 2015 breaking the terms of their visas. Vatican City was among the best, with all 22 of its citizens who came on tourist or business visas leaving by the time their passes expired.

Title: 3D-Printed Gun Blueprints Released Early Amid Legal Challenges

Article:

The blueprints for 3D-printed guns, initially scheduled for public release on Wednesday following a U.S. Justice Department ruling, were made available four days early on the Defense Distributed website. The designs for nine types of guns were downloaded thousands of times before multi-state legal action was filed to block the release.

The controversy surrounding 3D-printed guns began in 2013 when Cody Wilson, a self-styled crypto-anarchist, showcased the world's first 3D-printed gun. Files detailing the process were immediately uploaded to the Defense Distributed website and downloaded hundreds of thousands of times. This led to the U.S. State Department ordering the files to be removed from the internet.

A four-year legal battle ensued, with Defense Distributed joining forces with the Second Amendment Foundation, an organization that defends the right to own guns, to sue the State Department. In a surprise move last month, Defense Distributed won its case, with the U.S. Justice Department ruling that Americans may "access, discuss, use, and reproduce" the technical data.

This decision led to a backlash from lawmakers, and on Monday, Washington State Attorney General Bob Ferguson announced that it would be suing the State Department "to stop the illegal distribution of 3D printed guns" on behalf of eight U.S. states. In a statement, Mr. Ferguson said, "These downloadable guns are unregistered and very difficult to detect, even with metal detectors, and will be available to anyone regardless of age, mental health, or criminal history."

The State Department had already received a letter asking it to reinstate its ban, signed by 21 attorneys general from states including California, Massachusetts, Virginia, and Pennsylvania. The letter stated, "As the chief law enforcement officers of our states, we believe the settlement terms and proposed rules are deeply dangerous and could have an unprecedented impact on public safety."

"In addition to helping arm terrorists and transnational criminals, the settlement and proposed rules would provide another path to gun ownership for people who are prohibited by federal and state law from possessing firearms," the letter continued.

Mr. Wilson has celebrated his victory as the beginning of "the age of the downloadable gun." However, critics are concerned it will result in a significant increase in so-called ghost guns, unregistered weapons that the government is unaware of and unable to trace. Since the legal action began, Defense Distributed has been working on new gun designs and has also created a milling device, known as Ghost Gunner, that can turn parts purchased online into a fully functioning weapon.

Title: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi Announces Impeachment Proceedings Against President Trump, but No Violations of Law Identified

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D, California) announced on Thursday that Democrats will draft articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump. Pelosi's statement was ominous, suggesting that Trump is acting like an "oppressive monarch" or a "king president." She warned, "If we allow a president to be above the law, we do so surely at the peril of our republic."

However, it is important to note that President Trump is not above the law, but Democrats have struggled to identify any laws that the president has broken throughout the Ukraine-related impeachment inquiry. In a largely overlooked portion of his testimony, one of the Democrats' star witnesses, Army Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, stated that the National Security Council found that the 55-day pause in U.S. military aid to Ukraine was lawful.

President Trump's request for Ukraine to investigate alleged Ukrainian interference in the 2016 election, Ukrainian hacking of DNC computers, and corruption accusations against the Bidens conformed to America's Treaty with Ukraine on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, which was signed by President Clinton in July 1998 and ratified by the Senate in October 2000. The U.S. and Ukraine agreed to "provide mutual assistance... in connection with the investigation, prosecution, and prevention of offenses, and in proceedings related to criminal matters."

The aid pause was within Trump's responsibility to assure that $391 million did not vanish down a black hole of graft. OMB official Mark Sandy testified that he "attributed the hold to the President's concern about other countries not contributing money to Ukraine." This policy echoed Trump's statements on this matter.

Delays in foreign aid are not uncommon. Ambassador Kurt Volker, who testified before the Intelligence Committee, stated that he had seen holdups of assistance before and assumed it was part of the decision-making process. President Trump withheld $300 million in aid to Pakistan last year for neglecting its anti-terrorism commitments, and Obama chopped aid to Uganda in 2014 after it adopted cruel anti-gay statutes. Human-rights concerns prompted President Carter to slice aid to Argentina, Ethiopia, and Uruguay.

Ukraine received its lethal military aid on September 11, 2019. If those funds were unallocated on October 1, that would have been illegal. However, these funds beat the September 30 Fiscal Year-end deadline by 19 days, which some experts argue would not violate the 1974 Budget and Impoundment Control Act.

Despite all the controversy, Ukraine received its lethal military aid before September 30, 2019. Therefore, President Trump obeyed the Impoundment Control Act, too. It is important to note that impeachment is a political, not a legal, process. However, rather than punishing a crime spree, Democrats want to impeach President Trump—for honoring one law, legal opinion, or precedent after another.

Title: Dave Chappelle's New Stand-up Special, "Sticks & Stones," Sparks Controversy with Alleged Racist and Transphobic Remarks

Article:

Comedian Dave Chappelle returned to Netflix with a new stand-up special, "Sticks & Stones," on Monday. The special, which includes a secret epilogue titled "The Punchline," features Chappelle's controversial views on various topics, including his stance on the allegations against Michael Jackson, his continued use of transphobic jokes, and his defense of fellow comedians Kevin Hart and Louis C.K.

In the special, Chappelle expresses his belief that Michael Jackson did not molest children, stating, "Do you know how good it must've felt to go to school the next day after that shit?" He also makes jokes about being a Chinese person trapped in a Black man's body and uses a racist impression of a Chinese person.

Chappelle's comments about the trans community have also drawn criticism. He says, "I can't stop writing jokes about these niggas," referring to trans people. In the Q&A section at the end of the special, Chappelle recounts an incident where a white woman left one of his practice sets, telling him she was raped. Chappelle reportedly responded, "It's not your fault you were raped. But it's not my fault either. Ta-ta, bitch," to which the audience laughed.

The special has been met with backlash for Chappelle's alleged racist and transphobic remarks, as well as his apparent disregard for the criticism of his comedy style. The special seems to highlight the common accusation that Chappelle is only interested in repairing his relationship with marginalized groups if he doesn't have to change anything about himself.

Throughout his career, Chappelle has been known for his controversial and daring comedy style, including his early-2000s skits about R. Kelly's court trials on "Chappelle's Show." However, with his latest special, Chappelle has chosen to ignore the historic criticism against his style of comedy and new criticism from the trans community, coming off as a defiant rejection of change at any cost. As he continues down this path, the potential cost could be tarnishing his own legacy.

Title: Foxconn Shifts Focus of Wisconsin Campus from Manufacturing to Research Hub

Article:

Electronics giant Foxconn Technology Group announced on Wednesday that its planned $10 billion Wisconsin campus will primarily serve as a research hub, rather than a blue-collar manufacturing facility as originally intended. The shift in focus has been met with criticism, as the project was initially touted by President Donald Trump as a sign of a resurgence in American manufacturing.

In a statement, Foxconn said it remains committed to Wisconsin and the creation of 13,000 jobs as promised. However, due to changes in the global market environment, "this has necessitated the adjustment of plans for all projects."

The move was criticized as a bait-and-switch by some, including Wisconsin Assembly Minority Leader Gordon Hintz, a Democrat, who said, "We were promised manufacturing jobs...And now, it appears Foxconn is living up to their failed track record in the U.S.—leaving another state and community high and dry."

Economic development officials and other supporters of the project urged patience, stating that Foxconn still plans to invest what it promised. The White House had no immediate comment.

Foxconn, a major supplier to Apple, is the world's largest contract maker of electronics. Louis Woo, special assistant to Foxconn's CEO, was quoted as telling Reuters that it is scaling back and possibly shelving plans to build display screens in Wisconsin because "we can't compete."

Instead of a factory, Foxconn wants to create a "technology hub," with about three-quarters of the jobs in research and development and design. Those jobs typically go to college graduates. The plant is under construction and scheduled to open in 2020.

Marc Levine, senior fellow and founding director of the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee's Center of Economic Development, called it "one enormous bait-and-switch." He scoffed at the idea that Foxconn, known for manufacturing, could transform into a research and development giant.

"That's simply not what Foxconn is," Levine said in an email. "So the notion that there will be 13,000 research jobs at Foxconn is highly, highly unlikely."

The company initially billed the massive 20 million-square-foot (1.86 million-square-meter) Wisconsin complex as its first North American manufacturing site for the next generation of display panels to be used in a wide variety of products, including large-screen TVs, self-driving cars, notebooks, and other monitors.

Wisconsin state and local governments promised roughly $4 billion to Foxconn, the richest incentive package in state history and the biggest pledged by a state to a foreign corporation in U.S. history. Foxconn was required to invest $10 billion and create 13,000 jobs to get the full incentives.

It had already fallen short last year, hiring 178 full-time employees rather than the 260 targeted, and failed to earn a state tax credit worth up to $9.5 million. Former Gov. Scott Walker, the Republican who brokered the deal, emphasized in a tweet Wednesday that Foxconn earns tax credits only for actual investment and job creation. "No jobs/investment? No credits. Period," Walker tweeted.

Republican legislative leaders who pushed the project blamed new Democratic Gov. Tony Evers for Foxconn's change in plans. They said he had created an air of economic uncertainty by supporting the elimination of a manufacturing tax credit program.

Evers was critical of Foxconn in the campaign against Walker but did not pledge to undo the deal. His top aide Joel Brennan said that the administration was surprised by the news from Foxconn. He did not address the accusations that Evers was to blame.

Democratic critics said the incentives promised to Foxconn were too rich, and they questioned whether the company would ever fulfill its promises. The president of Wisconsin's Technology Council, Tom Still, said he is not surprised Foxconn wants to change course since televisions are becoming less expensive and iPhone sales are declining.

Still, whose group nurtures technology in Wisconsin, said Foxconn can succeed if the plant becomes more research-oriented because its areas of interest match up with Wisconsin's strengths, such as robotics, medical imaging, and industrial imaging.

Last summer, Trump highlighted his economic policies at a groundbreaking event for the Foxconn complex. "Made in the USA: It's all happening and it's happening very, very quickly," the president said in June after visiting the Foxconn site. "Today we're seeing the results of the pro-America agenda."

Title: Minimum Wage Debate: A Look at the Economic Implications and Constitutional Questions

Article:

The ongoing debate surrounding the minimum wage, particularly the push for a nationwide increase to $15 per hour, has sparked discussions about government intervention in the employer-employee relationship. Critics argue that such a move could represent an intrusion by the government into the market, with the government potentially overestimating the value of employees' services compared to employers and employees.

Some contend that the minimum wage hike, if implemented, could be seen as a means for the government to transfer wealth through threats and force. The $15-per-hour figure, they suggest, may be the result of political compromise rather than free market forces or economic realities.

Critics also warn of potential negative economic consequences, including increased unemployment and higher prices for goods and services. They argue that these wealth transfers could negatively affect everyone, with employees whose salaries rise showing gratitude not to their employers but to the politicians who forced the employers to pay them more.

The debate also touches on constitutional questions. Some argue that the right of an employee to sell labor and an employer to purchase that labor are part of the natural right to exchange goods and services, protected by the Constitution. They claim that the Constitution prohibits the government from interfering with freely entered-into contracts and from taking property without due process.

However, critics argue that modern courts have ignored these clauses and allowed the government to interfere in the employer-employee relationship and to take property without due process. They question whether the government's understanding of business, wealth creation, and salary determination is flawed, with the government's mindset being more aligned with control and central planning rather than market-driven competition.

Critics also warn of potential unintended consequences, such as employers reducing their workforce due to increased labor costs, leading to higher unemployment. They argue that the poor may be better off with employment and lower wages, with an opportunity for advancement, than being unemployed and relying on welfare.

In conclusion, the debate surrounding the minimum wage increase to $15 per hour raises questions about government intervention in the market, constitutional protections, and the potential economic consequences. Critics argue that the government's actions could lead to unintended negative effects, including higher unemployment and increased prices for goods and services. They also question the government's understanding of business and the economy, and the potential for political motivations in minimum wage increases.

Title: Senate Delays Vote on Military Airstrikes in Syria as Opposition Grows

Article:

The push by President Barack Obama for congressional approval of military airstrikes in Syria has faced a setback as opposition from senators in both parties has grown, leading to a delay in a procedural vote. Six senators, including five Republicans and one Democrat, announced on Monday they would vote against a resolution authorizing the use of force, indicating the administration's efforts to build bipartisan support have been ineffective.

The Senate was initially scheduled to vote on Wednesday on a procedural motion to begin formal debate on the resolution, but Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., announced late Monday the vote would be delayed to give the president more time to make his case to senators and the public.

The delay comes amid reports that Russia is seeking a deal with Syria to dismantle its chemical weapons program. President Obama, in television interviews on Monday, suggested such a deal could obviate the need for U.S. military intervention, but senators had not been briefed on the development and expressed skepticism.

Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., said, "I have no idea what's going on. It'd be great if the Russians could convince Assad to turn over his chemical weapons to the international community. That'd be a terrific outcome. I just am very dubious and skeptical."

Secretary of State John Kerry's comments made in London on Monday, describing the military effort as "unbelievably small," also raised concerns among lawmakers. Graham stated that Kerry "undercut everything the president has been doing for the last couple of days" to build support.

The rapid succession of senators announcing their opposition on Monday has cast serious doubts on the president's ability to garner the necessary support in either the House or Senate. The GOP-led House is unlikely to take up a resolution unless the Senate can pass it first. A final Senate vote was expected this weekend, but Reid's decision to delay the formal debate has put the schedule in flux.

Five GOP senators, Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, Roy Blunt of Missouri, Johnny Isakson of Georgia, Roger Wicker of Mississippi, and Mike Enzi of Wyoming, all announced opposition on Monday, as did Democratic Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota.

Sen. Heitkamp is the latest in a string of Democratic senators from conservative states to come out in opposition, including Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., and Sen. Mark Pryor, D-Ark. Heitkamp and Manchin are working on an alternative resolution that would give the Assad government 45 days to sign an international chemical weapons ban and begin turning over its chemical weapons before authorizing U.S. military action.

Two Democratic senators, Barbara Mikulski of Maryland and Martin Heinrich of New Mexico, have declared their support. However, Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Md., who voted for the resolution in the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, cautioned on Monday that he preferred pursuing diplomatic solutions.

The opposition underscores the uphill battle Obama faces on Capitol Hill to rally around his foreign policy agenda. The president will visit separately with Senate Democrats and Senate Republicans on Tuesday before his prime-time television address.

Graham, who supports the resolution, said he believed it could still pass the Senate: "If the president does a good job tomorrow night, yes."

Title: North Korean Delegation Concludes Visit to South Korea, Invitation for Summit Unclear

Article:

North Korea's high-level delegation, led by Kim Yo Jong, the sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, concluded a three-day visit to South Korea on Sunday. The visit, the highest-ranking to the South, was marked by "frank and candid" talks with South Korean President Moon Jae-in, but no mention of a North Korean invitation for Moon to visit Pyongyang for a summit was made in the North Korean news agency's report.

During the visit, South Korean President Moon Jae-in met Kim Yo Jong four times, and the North Korean delegation attended a performance by a North Korean orchestra, the last item on their itinerary before returning home. In a toast during Sunday's dinner, Kim Yo Jong expressed hope to meet "friendly faces" in Pyongyang later.

Earlier, South Korean Prime Minister Lee Nak-yeon had hosted a lunch for the Pyongyang delegation at a five-star hotel. On Saturday, Kim Yo Jong "courteously" handed over a personal letter from the North Korean leader to Moon and told him of her brother's "intention," without elaborating on the details.

South Korean officials stated that Moon had been invited to Pyongyang to speak with Kim Jong Un during the talks and lunch that Moon hosted at the presidential Blue House in Seoul on Saturday. Such a meeting, if it occurred, would mark the first inter-Korea summit since 2007.

U.S. Vice President Mike Pence, who returned to Washington after attending the opening of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, stated that the United States, South Korea, and Japan were in complete agreement on isolating North Korea over its nuclear weapons program.

Loud applause greeted the appearance of Moon, Kim Yo Jong, and her delegation at the concert, attended by more than a thousand people. The North Korean orchestra will return home on Monday after their second and last performance on Sunday.

North Korea's nominal head of state, Kim Yong Nam, a member of the delegation, was seen wiping away tears with his handkerchief and at times clapping enthusiastically during the show.

The main opposition party in South Korea warned that any talks between the two Koreas where the scrapping of North Korea's nuclear program was not a precondition would only "benefit the enemy." Japanese editorials sounded a similar warning, stating that dialogue would be meaningless unless it led to denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.

Title: USCIS Approved DACA Request for Alleged Murderer Jesus Rangel-Hernandez

Article:

The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) has admitted Jesus Rangel-Hernandez, a North Carolina resident charged with four counts of first-degree murder, despite his previous removal proceedings and alleged gang membership. According to a letter from USCIS to Senator Grassley, Rangel-Hernandez requested deferred action under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in January 2013, while he was in removal proceedings.

At the time of his DACA request, Rangel-Hernandez was in the United States without being admitted or paroled. He came to the attention of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) due to a 2012 arrest for possession of marijuana, for which charges were subsequently dismissed. ICE records indicate that they were not aware of Rangel-Hernandez's gang membership at the time of the arrest. His DACA request was approved on August 26, 2013, despite a TECS record indicating that he was a known gang member.

After the deferred action request was approved, immigration proceedings were administratively closed on December 18, 2013. Rangel-Hernandez was scheduled for deportation but was able to stay in the country due to the DACA approval.

In February 2015, Rangel-Hernandez allegedly murdered four people in North Carolina. Police in Charlotte-Mecklenburg, N.C., stated in a Wednesday statement that 19-year-old Emmanuel Jesus Rangel-Hernandez has been charged with three counts of first-degree murder in the death of 19-year-old Mirjana Puhar and two other victims. The victims' bodies were found Tuesday in a Charlotte home, and police did not reveal how they were killed. Rangel-Hernandez is also charged in connection with a murder at a motel Sunday.

North Carolina Senators Richard Burr and Thom Tillis have expressed concern over the approval of Rangel-Hernandez's DACA request. Burr stated, "The flawed implementation of the President's blanket deferred action program has created a loophole that allows dangerous criminals who came here illegally – even known gang members – to stay in the country." Tillis added, "The USCIS needs to immediately start performing detailed criminal background checks to prevent similar tragedies from occurring in the future."

Today, the Senate Judiciary Committee will hold a hearing examining the Obama administration's Central American Minors Refugee and Parole Program. During the unaccompanied minor crisis last summer, MS-13 gang members were using Border Patrol processing centers as recruitment areas and as a way to easily access the United States.

Title: Senate Tax Overhaul: CBO Report Highlights Redistribution of Resources Toward Upper-Income Americans

Article:

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released a report detailing the potential impact of the Senate tax overhaul bill, providing insights into the legislation's effects on various income groups. The report goes beyond analyzing personal income taxes, also considering spending cuts and their impact on the rich and poor.

The CBO report reveals that the Senate Republicans' bill would disproportionately benefit upper and upper-middle-class Americans, while lower-income groups would face overall losses. The following chart illustrates the net change in taxes per person or family for each income group:

[Insert chart showing net change in taxes per person or family for each income group]

It is important to note that the wealthy, due to their larger incomes, may receive a larger nominal benefit. However, when the overall effect on each group is divided by the midpoint income for that group, the wealthy gain more relative to their income.

For instance, Americans earning between $10,000 and $20,000 would see a negligible change, with a loss worth just 0.14% of their income next year. In contrast, Americans earning between $500,000 and $1 million would see a net benefit worth nearly 3% of their income.

Furthermore, the report also considers the population size of each income group. The data shows that lower-income groups have a larger number of taxpayers but would benefit far less from this tax overhaul. Higher-income groups have fewer taxpayers but would gain significantly more from the GOP bill.

[Insert chart showing the percentage of federal tax returns from each income group compared to the relative size of the benefit or loss for each group]

The Republicans argue that the wealthy, while fewer in number, contribute a larger portion of U.S. taxes. This is part of their rationale for a sweeping tax change that extends beyond tax cuts or reform. However, these numbers suggest that the GOP tax plan represents a shift towards a less progressive tax system, moving resources from the poor to the rich.

Title: Women Candidates in Key Senate Races Could Determine Control of the Senate

Article:

In the upcoming Senate elections, several women are running in key races that could potentially flip Democratic-held seats and determine the control of the Senate. The balance of power in the Senate could hinge on the performance of these women candidates from both parties.

One of the most prominent races is in Kentucky, where Democratic nominee Alison Lundergan Grimes, in her challenge to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, is using her gender to appeal to female voters, who make up more than half of the Kentucky electorate. Grimes, in a speech on Tuesday, declared, "I am a strong Kentucky woman who is an independent thinker."

In her primary victory in Kentucky, Grimes emphatically told supporters, "I am not an empty dress." Meanwhile, in Oregon, Republican hopeful and pediatric neurosurgeon Monica Wehby touted her own qualifications for Senate, stating, "I am a doctor, a mom."

Another notable candidate is Michelle Nunn, the daughter of veteran Sen. Sam Nunn, who is running in Georgia. Nunn said in a speech on Tuesday, "I believe that change is possible."

In addition to these candidates, there are vulnerable female senators in Louisiana, North Carolina, and New Hampshire. If these women candidates perform well, the Senate's balance of power could be significantly impacted.

In no place is gender more at play than in Kentucky, where Grimes is running a fierce challenge to McConnell. McConnell, when asked about a potential gender gap problem, responded, "We'll find out in November, won't we?"

In his victory speech, McConnell spoke glowingly of his late mother and his wife Elaine Chao, a former cabinet secretary under George W. Bush. McConnell also highlighted three Kentucky women he said were hurt by President Barack Obama's health care law.

Democrats' other big hope for picking up a GOP Senate seat is Michelle Nunn in Georgia. As for Republicans, Monica Wehby is a pediatric neurosurgeon hoping to unseat Democrat Jeff Merkley in Oregon, running as a political outsider.

In West Virginia, Shelley Moore Capito, a Republican, is favored to pick up a Democratic seat, but even if she loses to Democrat Natalie Tennant, either way, the state would elect its first female senator.

Currently, there are 20 women senators, a record but still far from representative of the country, which is more than 50% female. 2014 could mark another historic number.

Title: President Trump Revives Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines, Announces Supreme Court Nominee

Article:

President Donald Trump signed executive orders on Tuesday, reviving the controversial Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines. The orders were widely expected, as Trump had previously criticized his predecessor for blocking the projects.

The Keystone XL pipeline, which would run from Canada to Nebraska and connect to existing lines running to U.S. refineries on the Gulf Coast, was stopped by former President Obama in late 2015. The U.S. government needs to approve the pipeline because it would cross the nation's northern border.

Builder TransCanada said Tuesday afternoon it was "preparing the application" for the Keystone XL pipeline. TransCanada spokesman Terry Cunha stated, "We appreciate the President of the United States inviting us to re-apply for KXL." Cunha added that the pipeline would create thousands of well-paying construction jobs, generate tens of millions of dollars in annual property taxes to counties along the route, and more than $3 billion to the U.S. GDP.

The Dakota Access pipeline, which would carry North Dakota oil through South Dakota and Iowa to a shipping point in Illinois, was the subject of fierce protests until the Army Corps of Engineers stepped in. The Army Corps of Engineers had declined to allow construction of the Dakota Access pipeline under Lake Oahe, stating that alternative routes needed to be considered. The Standing Rock Sioux tribe and its supporters say the project threatens drinking water and Native American sites, though Energy Transfer Partners, the company that wants to build the pipeline, disputes that and says the pipeline will be safe.

In addition to the pipeline orders, Trump also signed three other orders related to pipeline construction, including one expediting the environmental permitting process for infrastructure projects and one directing the Commerce Department to maximize the use of U.S. steel.

Trump also announced he planned to nominate a justice for the Supreme Court next week, moving swiftly to try to fill the seat left vacant by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia. The president was summoning top senators to the White House later Tuesday to discuss his upcoming nomination.

The moves on the pipelines and the Supreme Court nomination come as Trump makes the economy and jobs the centerpiece of his administration's first week in office. Trump met Tuesday morning with representatives from the auto industry, including GM and Ford, after meeting a day earlier, separately, with business and union leaders.

The pipeline orders follow earlier executive actions covering everything from trade to ObamaCare. Trump on Monday signed measures withdrawing the U.S. from the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal and instituting a hiring freeze for most of the federal government. He also ordered federal agencies on his first day in office to ease the regulatory burden of the Affordable Care Act.

The moves are likely to spark a new fight with environmentalists. Even before Trump's orders were official, Sierra Club Executive Director Michael Brune put out a statement blasting what he called the "dangerous" decision. "The Keystone pipeline was rejected because it was not in the country's interest, and the environmental review of the Dakota Access Pipeline was ordered because of the threats it poses to the Standing Rock Sioux. Nothing has changed. These pipelines were a bad idea then and they're a bad idea now," he said.

Title: Boehner Offers Tax Revenue Increase in Bid to Avert Fiscal Cliff

Article:

House Speaker John A. Boehner has extended an olive branch to President Barack Obama in an effort to avoid the impending "fiscal cliff," stating that the GOP will allow for increased tax revenue if the president abandons his plan to raise tax rates on the wealthy. The move sets the stage for negotiations during the lame-duck session of Congress, which begins next week, and the 113th Congress, which opens in January.

In the aftermath of Tuesday's election, which saw Mr. Obama's re-election and an expanded Democratic majority in the Senate, while Republicans retained control of the House (albeit with fewer numbers), leaders from all sides have emphasized the need for cooperation to address the looming tax increases and automatic spending cuts.

Boehner's proposal involves closing tax loopholes to generate more revenue, which can then be used to lower income tax rates for everyone. This approach, he argues, would foster economic growth, resulting in more revenue for the federal government in the long run.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, has interpreted Tuesday's election as a mandate for raising taxes on the wealthy. However, Boehner and his fellow House Republicans have stated that they will not accept increases in tax rates.

The absence of President Obama from the public conversation on Wednesday was noteworthy, as he placed private calls to Mr. Reid, Mr. Boehner, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi. Vice President Joseph R. Biden spoke to reporters instead, expressing optimism about the potential for cooperation.

The "fiscal cliff" refers to the combination of expiring Bush-era tax cuts and automatic spending cuts set to take effect on January 1 and 2, respectively. If Congress does not act, these measures could plunge the U.S. into a short but deep double-dip recession, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

Both sides in Congress have expressed reservations about the magnitude of the tax increases and spending cuts, but have not yet reached a consensus on a solution. The Senate has not passed a budget in three years, and House Republicans have faced difficulties passing large pieces of legislation, such as the farm bill, this year.

The election resulted in a slight shift in the balance of power, with Democrats expanding their majority in the Senate to at least 54-45, and the Republican majority in the House decreasing, though 10 seats remained undecided as of Wednesday evening. In the presidential race, Mr. Obama's popular vote and Electoral College margins decreased, and Florida was still undecided as of Wednesday. Despite this, Mr. Obama has secured another four years in office to pursue his election promises.

Boehner has emphasized the need for spending cuts on entitlement programs such as Medicare and Medicaid as part of any deal with the White House. Grover Norquist, head of Americans for Tax Reform, has expressed support for the revenue deal Boehner is offering, stating that it aligns with his no-new-taxes pledge.

Title: Economists Praise Strong Job Growth, Yet Warn of Ongoing Economic Challenges

Article:

In a flurry of positive appraisals, economists have hailed the latest job growth figures as "extraordinary," "blowout," and "wow." The robust employment data, according to David Berson, chief economist of Nationwide, dismisses concerns of an impending recession. Berson stated, "The fears of the economy tipping into a recession now have clearly been overstated."

President Trump welcomed the strong job growth in a White House Rose Garden address, calling the 312,000 new jobs a "tremendous number" that has significantly impacted the stock market. He also praised the increase in wage growth as "beautiful to watch."

However, the positive employment report comes amidst a backdrop of economic challenges. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell acknowledged these issues on Friday. The ongoing trade war with China, a nation currently experiencing an economic downturn, could potentially dampen global demand. Domestically, there is a slump in the housing sector, with indications that the auto industry may also be affected.

This week, Apple reduced its revenue forecast for the first time in 16 years, attributing the move to weak iPhone sales in China. Kevin Hassett, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, stated on CNN that Apple is not the only American company to face the brunt of tensions with Beijing. Hassett said, "There are a heck of a lot of U.S. companies that have a lot of sales in China that are basically going to be watching their earnings be downgraded next year until we get a deal with China."

Furthermore, on Thursday, the Institute for Supply Management released a survey showing the steepest decline in manufacturing activity since 2008. Many manufacturers blamed the drop on rising costs related to tariffs. Despite this, the index reading of 54.1 still indicates an expanding economy. Measures of consumer confidence have also weakened recently.

The stock market has been experiencing its worst decline since the financial crisis. In response, Powell stated, "We’re listening sensitively to the messages markets are sending," but added that investors "are way ahead of the data."

Title: Donald Trump Announces 2016 Presidential Campaign Bid

Article:

According to The Washington Post, businessman and reality television personality Donald Trump is expected to announce his candidacy for the 2016 Republican Party presidential nomination. The Post cites Trump's plan to release a financial document summarizing his net worth as a key indicator of his intention to run.

Trump's potential entry into the race has been met with skepticism, as he has previously teased a presidential run in 2012. In the past, Trump has been criticized for using publicity stunts to garner attention, such as his comments about a possible presidential run during the reality television show Celebrity Apprentice.

The Republican Party's presidential field is seen as increasingly focused on appealing to the Tea Party base and boosting their popularity within the conservative entertainment complex, rather than on governing or winning the election. Trump is expected to compete for celebrity heft within this field.

According to RealClearPolitics, Trump is currently polling around 3.6 percent, placing him in the middle of the field. This is significant as Trump is ahead of several other candidates, including Rick Perry, Rick Santorum, Carly Fiorina, Lindsey Graham, Bobby Jindal, and Ohio Gov. John Kasich.

Trump's campaign platform includes a "secret plan" to defeat ISIS, which he has pledged to reveal upon his inauguration in 2017. Critics argue that this lack of transparency and specifics demonstrates a lack of seriousness in Trump's candidacy.

The potential impact of Trump's candidacy on American politics has been a topic of debate, with some viewing him as a circus sideshow attraction and others seeing him as a somewhat serious contender. If the first debate were to be held tomorrow, Trump would likely be among the top-tier candidates invited to participate. However, the concern is that the Republican Party is not fielding candidates commensurate with the seriousness of the nation's challenges.

Title: Saudi Arabia Arrests 11 Princes, Including Prominent Investor Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, and Former Ministers

Article: Saudi Arabia announced on Saturday the arrest of 11 princes, several current and former government ministers, in a move that appears to consolidate power around Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The arrests were first reported by Al Arabiya, the Saudi state satellite TV network, according to the New York Times. Among those arrested was Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, a prominent member of the royal family and a major investor in Apple and Twitter.

Just hours before the arrests, King Salman established a new anti-corruption committee, headed by the 32-year-old crown prince. The committee is authorized to investigate, arrest, and freeze the assets of anyone it suspects of corruption.

The unexpected arrests occurred on the same day that King Salman fired Prince Miteb bin Abdullah, Saudi Arabia's minister of the National Guard. Miteb was once considered a contender for the Saudi throne before the rise of Prince Mohammed two years ago. His removal gives the crown prince, who is already the Saudi defense minister, tighter control over the kingdom's security services.

It was not immediately clear if Saturday's arrests were connected to the new anti-corruption committee. The royal order said the committee was needed "due to the propensity of some people for abuse, putting their personal interest above public interest, and stealing public funds," according to The Wall Street Journal.

King Salman has moved to stamp out dissent in the kingdom before his expected abdication in favor of Crown Prince Mohammed. Prince Miteb, who was one of the few powerful princes from outside King Salman's branch of the royal family, had been critical of the king's decision to appoint Prince Mohammed as his successor.

Title: President Trump Pledges Support for Law Enforcement, Criticizes FBI Amidst Ongoing Investigations

Article:

In a speech to a graduating class of law enforcement officers at the FBI Academy on Friday, President Donald Trump pledged his administration's unwavering support for the police.

"The president of the United States has your back 100 percent," Trump said during a 17-minute speech to state and local law enforcement officers who had completed a special training course at the bureau.

The president's support for law enforcement has been a consistent theme, but the comments at the FBI Academy came amidst a period of heightened tension between the White House and the bureau. Trump has publicly criticized the bureau's senior leadership and its reputation, labeling it as "in tatters" and "the worst in history."

"It's a shame what's happened with the FBI," Trump said Friday, moments before he left for Quantico. "But we're going to rebuild the FBI. It'll be bigger and better than ever."

The president praised agents who keep the country safe and distanced himself from any blame for the investigations that have dogged his administration. However, he did take aim at the growing violence in Baltimore and Chicago.

"What the hell is going on in Chicago? What the hell is happening there?" he asked, which was followed by an awkward silence and then mild applause.

The White House, on Friday, revealed newly disclosed FBI records showing an "extreme bias" against Trump among senior leadership at the FBI. Deputy press secretary Hogan Gidley made these remarks to Fox News, stating that edits to former FBI Director James Comey's statement on Hillary Clinton's private email server and text messages from a top agent critical of Trump were "deeply troubling."

Gidley alleged that there was "extreme bias against this president with high-up members of the team there at the FBI who were investigating Hillary Clinton at the time." This statement comes as special counsel Robert Mueller continues his probe of possible Trump campaign ties to Russia.

Edits to the Comey draft appeared to soften the gravity of the bureau's finding in its 2016 investigation of Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while secretary of state. Gidley described the disclosure of politically charged text messages sent by one of the agents on the Clinton case, Peter Strzok, as "eye-opening." Strzok, who was in the room as Clinton was interviewed, was later assigned to special counsel Robert Mueller's team to investigate potential coordination between Russia and the Trump campaign. He was re-assigned after the messages were uncovered this summer.

Approximately 200 leaders in law enforcement from around the country attended the weeks-long FBI National Academy program aimed at raising law enforcement standards and cooperation. Coursework included intelligence theory, terrorism and terrorist mindsets, law, behavioral science, law enforcement communication, and forensic science.

Title: Texas Hospital Apologizes for Ebola Handling as Two Nurses Infected, Schools Close Over Fear of Virus Spread

Article:

In the aftermath of the Ebola outbreak in the United States, a Texas hospital where an Ebola patient died and two nurses became infected has issued an apology for mistakes made in the initial treatment of the patient. The hospital's chief clinical officer, Dr. Daniel Varga, admitted that they "did not correctly diagnose [Ebola] symptoms as those of Ebola."

Nina Pham, the first nurse infected, is set to be transferred to the National Institutes of Health facility in Maryland. She is currently being cared for at the same hospital where she worked and where she contracted the virus from a patient she treated, Thomas Eric Duncan.

CDC Director Tom Frieden stated that a second nurse, Amber Vinson, who tested positive for Ebola and flew a day before it was known that she might be suffering from the virus, should not have been cleared to fly. Vinson reported a fever to the agency but was told she could continue her travel. As a result, 132 passengers on her flight are now questioning their potential exposure.

Vinson is currently being treated at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, which has successfully treated two other Ebola patients without any of its employees becoming infected. The decision to transfer Vinson to Emory was reportedly due to staffing issues at the Texas hospital, leading to concerns and potential walkouts among nurses.

In response to the Ebola outbreak, the federal government is considering placing those who treated Duncan on a list that would prohibit them from flying. The CDC is also considering lowering the fever threshold that would be considered a possible sign of Ebola, currently set at 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit.

School closures in two states have occurred due to the fear of Ebola spread. In Texas, a few schools in the Belton Independent School District are closed Thursday because two students were on the same flight as Vinson from Cleveland to Dallas. In Ohio, two schools in the Solon School District in suburban Cleveland are closed Thursday due to a staffer who traveled home from Dallas on Frontier Airlines Tuesday on a different flight but potentially the same aircraft as Vinson.

Frontier Airlines has placed six crew members on paid leave for 21 days "out of an abundance of caution." The airline also removed the plane's seat covers and carpet near where the infected passenger sat, even though it had not been asked to do so by the CDC.

Following scathing allegations by a nurses' union, a Texas Health Presbyterian spokeswoman stated that several of the claims were not true. The union had alleged that Duncan was "left for several hours, not in isolation, in an area where other patients were present" during his second visit to the hospital. However, the hospital spokeswoman claimed that Duncan "was moved directly to a private room and placed in isolation" during his second visit. The union also claimed that "there was no one to pick up hazardous waste as it piled to the ceiling," but the hospital spokeswoman stated that the waste was "well-contained in accordance with standards, and it was located in safe and containable locations."

Title: Black Friday: A Critical Examination of the Annual Consumer Event

Article:

The day after Thanksgiving, known as Black Friday, is a contentious annual occasion in the United States, often associated with American excess and indignity. This day illustrates the nation's unique penchant for conspicuous consumption, even in the aftermath of the Great Recession. Despite economic challenges, the cultural obsession with acquiring big-ticket items as a measure of social worth persists.

In some states, the Black Friday shopping frenzy has become so uncivilized that there are analytics predicting which states are most likely to have fights over discounted merchandise. These states often have lower median incomes, suggesting that the pressure to keep up with the bling associated with higher incomes contributes to Black Friday brawls.

The dynamics of Black Friday extend beyond the in-store chaos. Politicians and corporations have collaborated to send American jobs overseas in pursuit of cheap labor. This results in relatively inexpensive products being sold back to American stores, forcing consumers to earn less while being sold cheaper, more disposable goods.

Moreover, it has been discovered that Black Friday deals are not always the best bargains, with similar prices available throughout the year. The quality of these items is often compromised to maintain profit margins, leading to a vicious cycle of cutting costs and decreasing quality.

While there are valid reasons for saving money in stores, the practice of stampeding over each other and making national news for all the wrong reasons has become a tradition for many Americans. Given the reality of Black Friday, it is worth questioning whether the indignity is worth the savings, especially in the age of online retailers.

Title: Christie's Past Statements Called into Question During Presidential Debate

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Chris Christie launched his campaign under the motto, "telling it like it is." However, a review of some of the New Jersey governor's statements during the Fox Business debate on Thursday suggests that he may have misrepresented some facts.

The testy exchange between Christie and fellow candidate Marco Rubio erupted on the debate stage when Rubio accused Christie of holding liberal views, citing Common Core, gun control, the appointment of Sonia Sotomayor, and a donation made to Planned Parenthood.

In response, Christie stated, "Let's get the facts straight... I didn't support Sonia Sotomayor." However, fact-checking website Politifact reports that in 2009, while running for New Jersey governor, Christie initially stated that Sotomayor would not have been his choice. Later that year, he issued a statement voicing support for her appointment to the Supreme Court.

Christie argued on Friday that his 2009 statements did not constitute support, claiming he was only calling for a straight up-or-down vote. In a 1994 Newark Star-Ledger story, Christie is quoted as saying, "I support Planned Parenthood privately with my personal contribution." However, his campaign has since stated that he did not make the donation. Planned Parenthood, a non-profit, does not disclose its private donors' information.

Rubio's allegations, whether true or not, provided Christie with an opportunity to deliver a memorable zinger during the debate, as he accused Rubio of attacking a rival to boost his own poll numbers, a tactic he once accused Jeb Bush of using.

Title: Trump Holds Rally in Michigan During Impeachment Vote in U.S. House of Representatives

Article:

In an unprecedented event in American history, President Donald Trump held a rally in Battle Creek, Michigan, as the U.S. House of Representatives voted on his impeachment articles on Wednesday night. The impeachment was initiated due to a whistleblower complaint regarding Trump's attempt to pressure Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, as well as a Republican theory that Ukraine interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Vice President Mike Pence warmed up the crowd, with the rally taking place in a district represented by Rep. Justin Amash, who left the Republican Party earlier in the year to become an independent and voted in favor of the two articles of impeachment.

Trump's speech began in a subdued manner, with the president discussing the restoration of the practice of Americans wishing each other "Merry Christmas." He also praised the USMCA trade deal, but his speech was interrupted by a heckler. Trump responded by saying, "Get her out of here!" and added, "There's one disgusting person who made a horrible gesture with the wrong finger."

Throughout the rally, Trump boasted about the strong economy, the size of his rally crowds, and a new poll showing him ahead of the Democratic nomination candidates. He also made light of the impeachment process, referring to it as a "political suicide march" for the Democrats.

Trump was impeached by the House, becoming the third president in U.S. history to be impeached. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Democrats were criticized by Trump, who claimed they were seeking to overturn "the results of an election."

Late in his speech, Trump returned to the topic of impeachment, stating, "They've been trying to impeach me from day one." He also made light of the impeachment process, saying, "It's a political suicide march for the Democrats."

Trump also made references to his former reality TV show, "The Apprentice," and his potential political opponent, Hillary Clinton, who is rumored to be considering another presidential run. He also mocked Michigan Rep. Debbie Dingell, who voted for impeachment, and made a joke about her late husband, Rep. John Dingell, who would have been proud of her vote, according to Dingell.

In conclusion, Trump's speech during the impeachment vote was a somewhat muted performance, with the president focusing on various topics, including the economy, his rallies, and the impeachment process itself. He also made light of the impeachment process and made several political jabs throughout his speech.

Title: The Ongoing Issue of Voter Fraud in U.S. Elections and the Role of Voter-ID Laws

Article:

The issue of voter fraud in American elections has been a topic of debate for decades. Instances of voter fraud have been reported in various elections, such as Lyndon Johnson's election to the U.S. Senate in 1948, where he allegedly won by manufacturing fake votes, or the 1960 presidential election in Illinois and Texas, where voter fraud is believed to have influenced the results.

In recent times, cases of voter fraud have been reported in several states during the 2016 election cycle. For instance, in San Pedro, California, 83 absentee ballots were sent to different registered voters who supposedly lived in the same small, two-bedroom apartment. In Pennsylvania, a Democratic organization, FieldWorks LLC, was raided for fraudulently filling out registration forms for thousands of voters. In Indiana, state police believe there could be hundreds of fraudulent voter registration records. In Chicago, an investigation found people who had been registered to vote after their death. In Virginia, illegal aliens were discovered to have illegally registered to vote in an examination of just eight out of the Commonwealth's 133 counties and independent cities. In New York, Democrats were recently caught complaining about voter fraud created by New York City mayor Bill de Blasio's decision to give out ID cards without checking recipients' identities.

Many argue that these problems could have been avoided if voters had to register in-person using a valid photo ID. This simple, commonsense requirement is standard in about a hundred countries around the world. Many countries' voter requirements are more stringent than anything being discussed in the United States. For example, Mexican voters must present voter IDs that include not only a photo but also a thumbprint to help ensure people don't register more than once. The IDs carry holographic images, embedded security codes, and a magnetic strip with still more security information. As an extra precaution, multiple-voting is further prevented by dipping voters' fingers in indelible ink.

In Mexico, voters cannot register by mail; instead, they must go to their registration office and fill out forms for their voter ID. When the voter card is ready three months later, the voter must make a second trip to pick it up from the registration office. Absentee ballots must be requested at least six months before the election. Despite these restrictive rules, people in Mexico are still able to vote, and the voter-participation rate actually went up after the 1991 reforms.

The debate over voter-ID laws in the United States is ongoing. There is evidence that voter-ID laws are associated with increased voting rates, and there hasn't been any evidence that voting regulations disproportionately harm minorities, the poor, or the elderly. However, the fate of America's recent, limited experiment with voter-ID laws will be determined by this election. After Supreme Court justice Antonin Scalia's death earlier this year, Democratic-appointee-dominated district and appeals courts around the country have had free reign in striking down voter-ID laws. If Hillary Clinton wins and gets to appoint Scalia's replacement, which will result in a 5-to-4 liberal majority on the Supreme Court, these rulings will be upheld.

The rigging of elections undermines the government's legitimacy and discourages lawful voting. Today's election will determine whether states have any chance of solving this problem.

Title: Obama Administration Seeks Expansive War Powers to Combat Islamic State

Article:

Secretary of State John F. Kerry told Congress on Tuesday that President Obama is seeking expansive war powers to pursue the Islamic State terrorists in various locations, a move that has left lawmakers stunned by the proposed war authorization, which could potentially allow the Pentagon to commit American combat troops to the fight.

During his testimony before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, Mr. Kerry stated that while Mr. Obama does not want combat troops, he does not want to restrict the president's ability to respond to unforeseen developments in the war should the Islamic State evolve, expand its fight to other countries, or prove more difficult to defeat.

"I don't think anybody wants to get into a long-term ground operation here. But we also don't want to hamstring the generals and the commanders in the field and the president, who is commander in chief, from their ability to be able to make some decision they need to make," Mr. Kerry said.

The administration's approach has sparked a growing furor, with lawmakers from both parties criticizing the White House for not taking action and for failing to lead on the issue. Sen. Bob Corker, the ranking Republican on the committee, stated, "The reason we're here is a total failure of the president to lead on this issue."

President Obama has repeatedly refused to propose his own war resolution. For now, Sen. Robert Menendez, New Jersey Democrat and chairman of the committee, has written a draft authorization for the use of military force (AUMF) that would impose a three-year limit on the authority and forbid ground combat troops in most situations, with exceptions for intelligence gathering, acting as spotters, or for rescue missions. The draft resolution does not specify a geographic limitation.

Lawmakers had hoped Mr. Obama, who won the presidency in 2008 in part due to his opposition to the Iraq War, would support strict limits. However, Mr. Kerry stated that the administration does not want such limits written into law.

"It sounds to me like you're making the case for a rather open-ended authorization," Mr. Menendez told Mr. Kerry, adding that he's been disappointed with the lack of cooperation from the president's team.

Mr. Menendez plans to have his committee vote on Thursday on a war resolution, and if the Senate stays in session next week, he said he'd like to see a vote on the chamber floor. He stated he'll push ahead even if they haven't been able to iron out differences with Mr. Obama over limits to his war powers.

No matter what the Senate does, the debate won't be finished this year. House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, has stated his chamber will take up the war debate next year, and he said it's Mr. Obama's job to propose a resolution to Congress and make the case for it to the American people.

The rise of the Islamic State, which goes by the acronyms ISIS or ISIL, has been embarrassing for the president, who a year ago declared al Qaeda on the run and said it was time to begin ramping down the war on terror. On Tuesday, Mr. Kerry made clear the administration considers the Islamic State, which has captured large swaths of Syria and Iraq, to be a branch of al Qaeda operating under a different name. He stated that means Mr. Obama already has powers to go after them under the 2001 and 2002 AUMFs, so even if Congress doesn't act, the president will continue to pursue the war.

Mr. Obama has already committed thousands of troops to Iraq in what he says is a supporting role, backing that country's troops. The U.S. has also conducted airstrikes in both Iraq and Syria to try to halt Islamic State advances. Meanwhile, a defense policy bill about to clear Congress authorizes the president to arm and train Syrian rebel groups for the next two years, with the hope that those rebels will take the fight to the Islamic State inside that country.

Senators did credit Mr. Kerry and Mr. Obama with pushing Iraq's politicians to push for political unity, which has helped solidify much of the country in opposition to the Islamic State. However, Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican who has a long history of working with and against Mr. Kerry during their days together in the Senate, blasted his former colleague for being too timid in pursuing the Islamic State. He called Tuesday's hearing a "charade."

Title: The Origins and Controversy Surrounding the Sequestration: A Look at the Budget Control Act of 2011

Article:

The ongoing political debate surrounding deficit reduction and the impending automatic spending cuts, known as sequestration, on March 1, 2013, can be traced back to the Budget Control Act of 2011. This act was designed to reduce the deficit and prevent default, creating a supercommittee on deficit control. The act stipulated that if the supercommittee failed to reach an agreement, automatic spending cuts would be imposed on all discretionary spending, including the military, and the expiration of various tax cuts would result in tax increases for millions of Americans.

On August 1, 2011, an overwhelming majority of Republicans (174-66) in the House voted for the bill. House Democrats split evenly, with 95 voting in favor and 95 against. Key Republican leaders, including John Boehner, Eric Cantor, and Kevin McCarthy, voted yes, while Democratic leaders Nancy Pelosi, Steny Hoyer, and Jim Clyburn also voted yes. The bill passed the Senate the following day, with 45 Senate Democrats supporting it, joined by 28 Republicans and one Independent.

President Obama signed the bill, a bicameral, bipartisan effort in cooperation with the White House, into law. However, during the October 22, 2012, presidential debate with Mitt Romney, President Obama denied any involvement in the sequester, stating, "The sequester is not something that I proposed... It will not happen... The budget we are talking about is not reducing our military spending. It is maintaining it."

This statement was a key moment in the final debate, which was generally scored in favor of the president. It could have gone the other way if Romney had been aware of the potential impact of sequestration, including a potential increase in unemployment up to 9.1 percent by the end of 2013, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

In his book "The Price of Politics," Bob Woodward traced the sequester idea as a negotiating strategy that originated in the White House. The idea of draconian cuts to the Defense budget was a White House proposal, which moved to the Democratic leader of the Senate, and eventually reached Republican leaders, culminating in mutually flawed assumptions that a bipartisan agreement on the supercommittee would be reached. The supercommittee could not agree, and the automatic spending cuts of sequestration are now on the way.

As a member of the 112th Congress, some representatives voted against the Budget Control Act of 2011. These representatives argue that there is waste in government, and that spending should be cut, particularly in areas such as wars, interventions, and foreign aid that may lead to interventions. They also argue that the U.S. needs to address its $600 billion trade deficit and focus on domestic issues.

With automatic spending cuts looming, the president will continue to distance himself from the sequestration process, while Republicans will try to bring him back to where he started: as the initiator. The White House will likely adopt a "share the pain" approach to deficit reduction, but it may not be enough to avoid sequestration. The Democrats will attack Republicans for sequestration, while the Republicans will argue that the cuts are necessary to reduce the deficit. The outcome of the political battle over deficit reduction and automatic spending cuts remains to be seen.

Title: Trump Leads Republican Presidential Field by 11 Points in Latest National Poll

Article:

Businessman Donald Trump has taken an 11-point lead over his closest rival in the latest national poll on the 2016 Republican presidential field. According to the Washington Post-ABC poll released on Monday, Trump was the first choice of 24 percent of Republicans and GOP-leaning independents. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker follows closely at 13 percent, while former Florida Governor Jeb Bush is at 12 percent.

Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee is next at 8 percent, followed by Senator Marco Rubio of Florida at 7 percent, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky at 6 percent each. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and former Texas Governor Rick Perry are at 4 percent each. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie rounds out the top 10 at 3 percent.

Trump's lead in the poll is a significant increase from his 4 percent showing in a Post-ABC poll released in late May. In that survey, Trump, Walker, and Paul were tied for first at 11 percent, followed by Bush and Rubio at 10 percent each, Huckabee at 9 percent, and Carson and Cruz at 8 percent each.

In response to the survey, Trump's campaign released a statement from him, stating, "People are tired of incompetent leaders and being pushed around at will by other nations, our enemies, and even our friends. Politicians have completely failed the American people. We owe $18 trillion dollars, have porous and dangerous borders, and can't even take proper care of our magnificent Veterans. If I become president, I will do what I do best—fix these problems and Make America Great Again!"

Trump has faced criticism for recent comments he has made about Mexico and illegal immigrants, as well as the military service of Senator John McCain of Arizona. However, Trump's campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, downplayed any potential impact on Trump's poll numbers, stating that 8 percent of the poll was conducted on Sunday and calling it a "statistical error."

The overall survey of 1,002 adults was taken from July 16-19 and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: House Transmits Articles of Impeachment to Senate, Setting Stage for Trial

Article:

The United States House of Representatives is set to vote on Wednesday to send the two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump to the Senate, marking the start of a trial that is expected to result in an acquittal for the President. The House's decision to transmit the impeachment articles follows a nearly four-week delay during which House Speaker Nancy Pelosi attempted to dictate rules for the trial.

The Senate is expected to begin the trial on Tuesday with a standard set of rules preferred by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. Democrats hope to put pressure on Senate Republicans, particularly those from swing states facing reelection in November, to back demands for additional witness testimony at the trial.
