However, the prevailing wisdom on Capitol Hill is that impeachment as an election issue will backfire on Pelosi, whose Democrats won the majority in 2018 by picking up seats in traditionally Republican strongholds. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer has been criticized for demanding a decision on witnesses in pretrial negotiations, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell accusing Schumer of using the trial process to hurt Republican election chances.

Senate Democrats need at least four Republicans to vote with them to get the 51 votes needed to call a witness. They are eyeing four witnesses close to the President, including acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney and former National Security Adviser John Bolton. Senators Susan Collins of Maine and Cory Gardner of Colorado, who are both moderate Republicans up for re-election, have expressed a willingness to consider calling witnesses. Senators Mitt Romney of Utah and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, who are not up for reelection this year, have also not closed the door to hearing from more witnesses.

House Democratic leaders insist their side is winning the impeachment debate. House Democratic Caucus Chairman Hakeem Jeffries of New York said, "We'll see what happens in the Senate, but I think there's been substantial movement. That's a good thing." He also named several Republican senators, including Martha McSally, Joni Ernst, Cory Gardner, and Lamar Alexander, whom he hopes will support their case.

Recent polling suggests an overwhelming number of Americans would like to hear from John Bolton during the trial. A Quinnipiac poll released this week showed 66 percent of respondents were eager to hear from the former national security adviser. The House Democrats' impeachment managers are expected to be named on Wednesday, with House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff of California and Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler of New York at the top of the list of likely managers.

The House impeached Trump in a party-line vote on December 18, charging him with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The two articles of impeachment stem from a July 25 phone call with the Ukrainian president in which Trump requested a probe of a political rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden. Pelosi held on to the articles for about a month, demanding the Republican-controlled Senate hold a fair trial and echoing Schumer's calls for more witnesses. The nearly four-week impasse did not yield any assurances on whether or not McConnell's chamber will hear more testimony.

Title: Senate Adopts University's Doctrine of Self-Censorship, No-Go Zones, and Safe Spaces in Supreme Court Confirmation Hearings

Article:

During the recent Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge Brett Kavanaugh, the Senate adopted a set of norms reminiscent of modern universities, characterized by self-censorship, no-go zones, and safe spaces. The polarizing atmosphere of the university has extended to Congress, as seen in the hearings for Kavanaugh and his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford.

The hearings demonstrated how college values have become the norms of the Senate. In the university setting, constitutional due process often vanishes when accusations of sexual harassment arise. This was evident in the false charges lodged against the Duke University lacrosse players and the concocted smear of a University of Virginia fraternity.

The credibility of either Kavanaugh or Ford was a contentious issue, but the asymmetry of the campus governance was evident in the hearings. Ford's veracity hinged on empathy and perceived believability, with little requirement for corroborating testimonies, witnesses, or physical evidence. In contrast, Kavanaugh was considered guilty from the start, and he had to prove his innocence.

One belief of the university is the postmodern idea of relativist truth. On campus, all narratives can present equally valid stories, with no clear distinction between them based on reality, as established by evidence and facts. Powerful individuals supposedly "construct" truths based on their self-interests, leading to self-described victims of historical biases being under no obligation to play by what they consider to be rigged rules of facts, evidence, or testimony.

This dynamic is exemplified by Senator Cory Booker (D, N.J) insisting that Dr. Ford told "her truth." In other words, evidence was not so relevant. Ford's story of events from 36 years ago inherently would have as much claim on reality as Kavanaugh's rebuttal—and perhaps more so, given their different genders and asymmetrical access to power.

Truth-finding would have required difficult, time-honored examinations of physical evidence, the testimony of witnesses, and even unpleasant cross-examinations about the time and place of the allegations. However, such an approach would have potentially hurt feelings and questioned motives, as they are under constitutional norms of due process.

In the Senate, the race and gender of individuals increasingly determine who we are. Republican senators were often written off as "old white men," not unique individuals who might be disinterested or biased, fair or prejudicial. Kavanaugh was largely assumed guilty, in part for once being a privileged white kid of 17 who had gone to a prep school.

Meanwhile, Booker, by virtue of not being old and white, was considered a credible senatorial examiner. No one cared that Booker had once invented stories about an imaginary friend named "T-Bone."

Such blanket race- and age-based stereotyping was not even consistent. Senator Richard Blumenthal (D, Conn.) is 72 and white. Yet given his progressive politics, no one dismissed him on the basis of gender and age, much less for being a serial fabricator who concocted false stories of being a Vietnam veteran.

The Senate also adopted the modern university's doctrine of self-censorship, no-go zones, and safe spaces. Given issues of gender and the university concept that accusations of sexual assault inherently are exempt from constitutional protections of due process, Ford was more or less excused from normally tough cross-examination.

In her testimony, Ford never explained why, despite her self-professed fear of flying, she has been a frequent flyer on business and leisure trips. Ford's privacy and medical status were understandably to be respected and off-limits. Yet Ford suggested that her friend, Leland Ingham Keyser, was suffering from "significant health challenges" after Keyser did not corroborate Ford's allegations.

Ford was never really asked why her narratives concerning the number of witnesses to the alleged assault and their genders were not compatible. Her accounts of the location and time of the alleged assault were either inconsistent or nonexistent. In contrast, Kavanagh was grilled on everything from his high-school yearbook to a made-up accusation that he once committed sexual assault on a docked boat in Newport, R.I.

Swarming and shouting down those who hold different views in order to shame and intimidate them is part and parcel of the modern university. Now, we are seeing such campus street theater in Congress. During a break in the hearings, female protesters cornered Senator Jeff Flake (R, Ariz.) in an elevator and screamed in his face.

The psychodrama worked—just as it usually does on campus. A shaken and flushed Flake soon backed down from his stated intention of voting to confirm Kavanaugh.

Campuses are no longer out-of-touch ivory towers. Their creed is now beginning to run the country, which is frightening.

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Announces Retirement, Sparking Succession Race and Political Uncertainty

Article:

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan announced on Wednesday that he will retire from the House of Representatives at the end of this year, closing out a two-decade career in Congress and igniting a succession race within the Republican Party. The announcement comes as the party braces for a challenging election season.

Ryan rejected claims that he was fleeing a sinking ship, predicting that Republicans will maintain their House majority despite headwinds in November's elections. He vowed to be an active lame-duck speaker as he serves out his term, pushing for spending controls and the rest of the Republican agenda.

Ryan's decision was reportedly driven by family considerations. He noted that he came to Congress from Wisconsin before his first child was born and now all three children are teenagers. "If I am here for one more term, my kids will only have ever known me as a weekend dad," he said. "I just can't let that happen. So I will be setting new priorities in my life."

The announcement set off jockeying among Republicans to fill Ryan's post. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California and Majority Whip Steve Scalise of Louisiana are seen as his most likely successors. Some lawmakers and conservative groups urged a go-slow approach on choosing the next leader, particularly since Republicans' position will not be clear until after November's elections.

Ryan has been speaker for about 2½ turbulent years. He faced down conservative rebellions and secured a large tax cut, but he failed to repeal Obamacare or lock down a deal on immigration. He considered his biggest accomplishments to be tax cuts and last month's omnibus spending bill that included a massive spike in Pentagon funding along with a big boost in domestic funding.

His biggest regret, he said, was failing to win changes to big social spending programs, though he said the House, under his leadership as a committee chairman and then as speaker, had done its part by passing "the biggest entitlement reform bill ever considered in the House of Representatives."

Ryan, the Republican Party's 2012 vice presidential nominee, said he thinks he is finished with elected politics for the immediate future—and potentially for good. After serving as a prominent critic of Donald Trump at times during the 2016 campaign, he became the president's most effective ally on Capitol Hill by helping push the White House agenda.

Democrats said they hoped that Ryan, free from having to face voters, will now turn against Trump and sideline conservatives who have resisted efforts to strike more liberal-leaning deals. However, Ryan's relationship with conservatives as speaker has been uneasy at times, with spending concerns and a perceived lack of input from the rank and file being among the issues.

Conservative members generally praised Ryan for his approach to the job and for helping win tax cuts last year. They said they would leave a more broad-based examination of his record for another time. The succession race and the political landscape in the House of Representatives will continue to evolve in the coming months.

Title: Romney's Business Ties and Bain Capital Investments Under Scrutiny in Presidential Campaign

Article:

The ongoing scrutiny of Mitt Romney's business ties and investments made by his private equity firm, Bain Capital, has intensified as the Obama campaign has accused Romney of either misrepresenting his role at Bain to federal regulators or to the American public regarding the duration of his tenure at the firm.

The allegation, based on a report in the Boston Globe, suggests that documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicate that Romney may have led Bain until 2002, three years longer than he claims. This is significant because the Obama campaign asserts that Romney shares responsibility for the investments Bain made between 1999 and 2002, which allegedly led to jobs being shipped off to China and India.

Stephanie Cutter, deputy campaign manager for the Obama campaign, stated in a conference call that if Romney was lying to the American people about his role at Bain, it raises serious character and trust issues. The Romney campaign, in response, labeled the accusation as "reckless and unsubstantiated" and called for an apology from the Obama team.

The Romney campaign maintains that internal Bain documents show Romney had stopped managing the firm's clients when he went to oversee the Salt Lake City Olympics. Bain Capital also released a statement supporting Romney's claim that he left in 1999 and had no involvement with the management or investment activities of the firm or its portfolio companies since his departure.

Democrats have demanded Romney release more tax returns to provide voters with a better understanding of his finances, and they argue that his role at Bain is crucial for voters to have a complete picture of his approach to job creation.

David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois, stated that Romney's complex finances make it difficult for him to control the narrative surrounding his business history. He also criticized the Romney campaign for not having better answers ready, given their years of running for the presidency.

Before the Boston Globe story, the Romney campaign had already released an ad accusing President Obama of lying about Romney's role in offshoring jobs. The ad, titled "No Evidence," questions Obama's credibility and cites the analysis of Factcheck.org and The Washington Post, which found no evidence that Romney shipped jobs overseas and labeled the Obama campaign's charge as "misleading."

The Globe report, according to the Obama campaign, proves that Romney was in "full control of Bain Capital through 2002" and directly responsible for the related outsourcing, bankrupting, and layoffs. "Whatever the consequences of Bain investments were, he was responsible," the campaign stated.

Title: Mitt Romney and President Obama Tied in Virginia Poll, Electoral Map Could Differ from 2008

Article:

A new poll by Quinnipiac University shows a tight race between Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama in the swing state of Virginia. The poll, conducted from July 10-16, shows both candidates tied at 44 percent, with 8 percent undecided, 2 percent preferring another candidate, and 2 percent stating they would not vote. This is a significant shift from March, when Obama held an 8-point lead over Romney in the same state.

In the poll, independent voters slightly favor Obama, with 40 percent supporting the president and 38 percent supporting Romney. However, Obama's advantage with women has decreased from 16 points in March to 5 points in July. Additionally, Obama's favorability ratings are underwater for the first time since December, with 46 percent holding a favorable opinion of him and 48 percent an unfavorable one.

Romney's favorability ratings are also not particularly strong, with a 39-42 favorable-unfavorable split. Peter A. Brown, assistant director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, commented, "One of them is going to win the White House, but neither would get elected Prom King."

The poll surveyed 1,673 registered voters and has a margin of error of 2.4 percentage points. The poll results suggest that the electoral map this year could look different from four years ago, when Obama expanded Democratic territory and flipped historically red states such as Virginia and North Carolina. Instead, it could resemble the 2004 election, where an under-fire incumbent, President George W. Bush, fended off a challenger, Sen. John F. Kerry, who was not particularly popular.

If Obama holds onto the states he won in 2008, which now have 246 electoral votes, Virginia's 13 votes could clinch re-election for Obama even if he loses the other key swing states - Ohio, Florida, and North Carolina. Because New Mexico is trending toward Obama, the president could reach the required 270 electoral votes by winning just one of the three other Bush states he flipped in 2008 - Nevada, Colorado, or Iowa.

Paul Goldman, a longtime Democratic strategist who advised former governors L. Douglas Wilder and Mark R. Warner, stated, "The president doesn't have to win Virginia to get elected, but there's a good chance Romney does."

NPR also released a poll that gives Obama a 47 percent to 45 percent lead, within the margin of error of 3.1 percentage points. However, voters in 12 battleground states, which included Virginia, were split, with 46 percent favoring Obama, 46 percent favoring Romney, and 3 percent undecided. The poll of 1,000 likely voters was conducted from July 9-12 and had a margin of error of 4.56 percentage points.

Other recent polls also indicate a close race nationally. Romney leads 47 percent to 46 percent in a CBS/New York Times poll, while Obama leads 45 percent to 41 percent in a Fox poll. The new numbers were released as first lady Michelle Obama is scheduled to visit Virginia on Friday to launch a voter outreach program the campaign plans to take to other battleground states next week.

On July 13, at a campaign stop in Roanoke, Va., Obama made the now-infamous "If you've got a business, you didn't build that" remark, which argued that other people or government services inevitably help along the way. Since then, Romney's campaign has used the remark as a rallying cry to argue that Obama does not understand or care for the free enterprise system.

On Thursday, Romney's campaign unveiled a Web ad titled "These Hands," which features Jack Gilchrist, the owner of Gilchrist Metal Fabricating Company in Hudson, N.H., where Romney stopped in January. The ad questions the idea that Obama's hands didn't build his company. The Obama campaign countered with its own online ad, titled "Mitt Romney: Saying Anything to Get Elected," which splices recent remarks from Romney with Obama's comments to argue that the challenger was essentially agreeing with the president's larger point.

Title: Republican Rep. Mark Sanford Loses GOP Primary in South Carolina

Article:

In the latest primary election held on Tuesday, Republican Rep. Mark Sanford of South Carolina lost his seat to state Rep. Katie Arrington. This outcome was the most significant in a series of elections held in Virginia, Maine, Nevada, and North Dakota.

The primary elections saw a consistent trend in Democratic primaries, particularly in three key House races in Virginia, where female candidates are winning at unprecedented rates and often by large margins. Notable retirements and runoffs in the Republican party include Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake, Tennessee Sen. Bob Corker, and Alabama Rep. Martha Roby.

Sanford's loss was attributed to his criticism of President Donald Trump, a factor that also led to Alabama Rep. Martha Roby's runoff. Trump endorsed Arrington, stating that Sanford had been "unhelpful" to him and was "better off in Argentina."

In an ad, Arrington urged voters to tell Sanford to "take a hike," referencing Sanford's 2009 scandal involving an extramarital affair.

Corey Stewart, a controversial Republican candidate known for his support of the Confederate flag and monuments, won the Republican Senate nomination in Virginia. National and state Republicans expressed concern that Stewart's presence on the ballot could lead Republican voters to stay at home, hurting the party in several competitive House races.

In Virginia's competitive House races, women will represent the Democratic party in November, marking another example of the party turning to women to unseat vulnerable Republicans in the Trump era. Three women—Elaine Luria, Abigail Spanberger, and Jennifer Wexton—won Democratic primaries in Virginia on Tuesday.

A record number of Democratic women have filed to run for Congress since Trump took office, with many citing his presidency as their motivation. To date, 476 women have filed to run for the House in 2018, surpassing the 272 who filed in 2016.

In Wisconsin, Caleb Frostman, the Democrat running in Wisconsin State Senate District 1, claimed victory in Tuesday's special election. Meanwhile, Ann Groves Lloyd, the Democrat running in the special election in Wisconsin State Assembly District 42, conceded to her Republican opponent.

North Dakota Republicans chose Rep. Kevin Cramer to challenge Sen. Heidi Heitkamp, while Nevada Democrats picked Rep. Jacky Rosen as their nominee against Sen. Dean Heller. The two primaries were relatively quiet, but will be among the nation's most important battlegrounds in November.

CNN was unable to project a winner in the Maine House District or either the Democrat or Republican primary for Maine governor due to the complexity of asking voters multiple questions on each race.

Title: Romney Addresses NAACP, Criticizes "Obamacare" and Economic Conditions for Blacks

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney faced a cool reception at the NAACP annual convention in Houston on Wednesday, as he criticized the Affordable Care Act, also known as "Obamacare," and addressed economic and educational issues affecting the African-American community.

Romney questioned the historical loyalty of the black community to the Democratic Party, suggesting that decades of Democratic policies have failed to address persistent problems in the community. He proposed a new approach, stating, "When decades of the same promises keep producing the same failures, then it's reasonable to rethink our approach—and consider a new plan."

The former Massachusetts governor emphasized his support for charter schools and vouchers, a stance similar to that of the Obama administration. He also attempted to counter the perception that his campaign is focused on helping the wealthy, stating, "The president wants to make this a campaign about blaming the rich. I want to make this a campaign about helping the middle class."

Romney did not address the issue of voter ID laws, a topic that has been a point of contention between Republicans and civil rights groups. He acknowledged President Obama's historic election but presented economic data, including the 14.4 percent unemployment rate in the black community, to suggest that the current administration has failed to address these issues effectively.

Romney referenced his father, Michigan Governor George Romney, and closed with a religious note, quoting Reverend Martin Luther King Jr. "Every good cause on this Earth relies in the end on a plan better than ours," Romney said, before quoting King: "Without dependence on God, our efforts turn to ashes and our sunrises into darkest night."

Romney's use of the term "Obamacare" and his criticism of the healthcare law, which remains controversial, was met with boos from the audience. His strong case for school choice, including a proposal to link federal funding to students, rather than schools, appeals to some segments of the African-American electorate but is aimed at his conservative base.

Romney also touched on his opposition to same-sex marriage, a divisive issue within the black community, and reiterated his jobs message, including his aim to reduce government spending by eliminating "expensive nonessential programs like Obamacare."

Peeling off African-American voters, who overwhelmingly voted for Obama in 2008, has always been a challenging task for Republicans, even without an African-American incumbent in the White House. In a statement after the speech, NAACP President Benjamin Todd Jealous criticized Romney's stance on the Affordable Care Act, stating, "His criticism of the Affordable Care Act—legislation that will improve access to quality health care for millions—signals his fundamental misunderstanding of the needs of many African Americans."

NAACP Chairman Roslyn M. Brock, however, praised Romney for his courage in addressing the convention directly.

Title: Monster Blizzard Affects Over 70 Million People, Causes Massive Disruptions

Article:

A massive blizzard, expected to impact more than 70 million people, began dumping snow across the nation's capital on Friday. The storm, which has prompted an army of plows to maintain open major arteries and transportation systems, is predicted to be one of the top three snowfalls of all-time for Washington, D.C., according to National Weather Service forecaster Daniel Peterson.

The Washington Metro subway system is set to shut down entirely late Friday night and remain closed through Sunday for the safety of workers and riders. Underground stations usually stay open during major snowstorms. Mayor Muriel Bowser urged government workers to head home by the early afternoon, warning the storm has "life and death implications."

Tens of thousands of people crowded into the airports as more than 3,300 flights were canceled for Friday, most in Charlotte and Raleigh, North Carolina. Thousands more were delayed. For Saturday, over 3,300 flights were canceled, including all flights into and out of Philadelphia International Airport. All major airlines have issued waivers for travel over the weekend, allowing passengers to rebook onto earlier or later flights to avoid the storms.

The storm is expected to hit areas around the nation's capital the hardest, dropping more than 2 feet of snow. Philadelphia could get 12 to 18 inches, and New York 8 to 10 inches, although some forecasts suggest even more. Train service could be disrupted by frozen switches, the loss of third-rail electric power, or trees falling on wires.

Across the region, track workers, power company employees, road crew members, firefighters, and other first-responders were mobilized for the long weekend. In New York City, 79 subway trains will have "scraper shoes" to reduce icing on rails, the Metropolitan Transit Authority said.

Conditions quickly became treacherous as the storm moved northeast. Arkansas and Tennessee got eight inches; Kentucky got more than a foot, and states across the Deep South grappled with icy, snow-covered roads and power outages. At least eight people died in traffic fatalities in the dangerous weather.

The National Weather Service issued blizzard warnings stretching from northern Virginia to parts of New York's Long Island, where the U.S. Coast Guard warned seas could swell up to 18 feet. The blizzard warnings are scheduled to last until early Sunday.

Gov. Chris Christie declared a state of emergency in New Jersey late Friday and said roadways had been pre-brined but suggested people stay home on Saturday. Forecasters also warned of "thundersnow," a dangerous type of thunderstorm that drops snow instead of rain.

"The most intense part of the storm will come Saturday morning from around 4 a.m. through 12 p.m," said Fox 5 DC meteorologist Gary McGrady. "We can expect heavy snow, possibly 2 inches per hour, and blizzard conditions with 30 to 35 mph winds creating legitimate whiteout conditions." McGrady added that his forecast called for between 1 and 2 feet of snow to fall in the national capital region before all was said and done.

The same storm system dropped 6 inches of snow in the Little Rock area overnight, breaking a snowfall record set more than 20 years ago. Schools and state government offices in central Arkansas shut down on Friday. The state's largest utility, Entergy Arkansas, said about 12,500 homes and businesses lost power.

The Mid-Atlantic region is notorious for struggling to cope with winter weather, and a light dusting on Wednesday night served as an ominous prelude to the massive blizzard. Less than an inch of snow was enough to immediately turn roadways treacherous in the District, Maryland, and northern Virginia, causing hundreds of accidents and leaving drivers gridlocked for hours. President Obama was not spared, as his motorcade slowly weaved and skidded along icy streets to the White House.

The U.S. Capitol Police said sledding on Capitol Hill—which only recently became legal after an act of Congress—would be welcome for the first time in decades, as long as conditions are safe. Even the start of the snowstorm could not keep some tourists from visiting the White House. On Friday afternoon, several groups and couples were walking in the park in front of the mansion, and the fountain in the home's yard was still spraying water.

Newlyweds Stefan Tomic and Cherokee Tomic, both 22, were visiting from New York and had just arrived in the city Friday by bus. They said they did not want to change their plans because of the weather, and their first stop was the White House. As far south as Atlanta, people were urged to go home and stay there to avoid a repeat of the city's "icepocalypse," when a fairly light winter storm in 2014 caused commuter chaos for days.

NWS Director Louis Uccellini warned at a news conference that the snowfall could easily cause more than $1 billion in damage and paralyze the Eastern third of the nation. "It does have the potential to be an extremely dangerous storm that can affect more than 50 million people," Uccellini said at the service's Weather Prediction Center in College Park, Maryland.

Title: Trump's Syria Strike Sparks Controversy Among Far-Right Supporters

Article:

The sudden shift in U.S. policy towards Syria, marked by President Donald Trump's decision to launch a missile strike against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, has sparked controversy among Trump's far-right supporters. This change in policy, which was met with praise from hawkish critics, has left many of Trump's supporters, who had previously supported his anti-interventionist stance, perplexed.

In the weeks leading up to the strike, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley had stated that the U.S.'s focus was no longer on removing Assad from power. However, Trump's condemnation of the chemical weapons attack in Syria, which resulted in the deaths of dozens of civilians, led some of his supporters to accuse him of being manipulated by a "false flag" operation orchestrated by deep state agents.

Prominent alt-right figures, such as Mike Cernovich and Alex Jones, spread conspiracy theories about the attack, with Cernovich suggesting that the attack was a staged operation and Jones blaming the attack on Democrat billionaire George Soros. Ann Coulter, a prominent Trump supporter, criticized Trump for abandoning his campaign principles, implying that he was swayed by emotional images of the attack.

The missile strike occurred hours after the removal of Steve Bannon, a key figure in the alt-right, from the National Security Council Principals Committee, which limited his access to military decision-making. Bannon's supporters quickly attributed the Syria situation to the same individuals they believed were responsible for his diminishing influence in the White House, namely Jared Kushner and the "West Wing Democrats."

Breitbart, a far-right news outlet, expressed disapproval of the strike by noting the praise from "Republican Hawks," a term used to describe pro-war neoconservatives. Raheem Kassam, Breitbart London's editor-in-chief, spent his radio show criticizing the Trump administration and calling for an investigation into the Syria situation.

The controversy highlights the divide between Trump's far-right supporters and the more hawkish elements within the administration, as well as the potential influence of different advisors on the President's policy decisions.

Title: HUD Proposes Rent Increase for Millions of Public Housing Residents

WASHINGTON (AP) — The Housing and Urban Development (HUD) Secretary Ben Carson has unveiled a proposal that would raise the rent paid by millions of families living in federally subsidized public housing to 35 percent from 30 percent of household income. The proposal, named the Make Affordable Housing Work Act, would also eliminate all deductions that could lower the rent and evaluate rents every three years instead of annually.

The proposal, which would need to be approved by Congress, could spark a debate over supporting the country's poorest and most vulnerable families. Democrats are expected to offer strong opposition, and some members of the Republican majority may be reluctant to endorse the plan ahead of the midterm elections in the fall.

Under the proposal, rents would no longer be subject to deductions for utilities, medical expenses, or other factors that could lower the rent-to-income ratio. Elderly and disabled tenants, who make up more than half of the 4.7 million public housing families, would be exempted.

Carson stated that the changes are necessary to bring more money into the system and modernize an outdated model. He argued that the current system discourages public housing residents from earning more income due to the rent-to-income ratio.

Tenants' rights advocates have already expressed concern over the proposal. Jack Cooper, executive director of the Massachusetts Union of Public Housing Tenants, described it as a "war on low-income people." Cooper, who understands Carson's perspective as a self-made individual, expressed concern that the proposal would force families into homelessness due to the increased rent burden.

Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, has long advocated for the idea that too much government support can create a culture of dependency among recipients. During a 2016 speech at his alma mater, Yale University, Carson stated, "Government should not keep people in a dependent state. It should be used as a springboard, and not as a hammock."

Cooper, however, argued that the proposal would not encourage greater self-sufficiency but would instead force families into homelessness due to the increased rent burden. He noted that the nationwide average annual income for public housing residents is $12,000, and many families may not be able to afford the additional expenses.

"We're talking about keeping a roof over people who can't afford the market," Cooper said. "They're devastating folks that are already in dire straits."

Title: Georgia Senator Saxby Chambliss Breaks with Anti-Tax Pledge, Cites National Debt Concerns

Article:

In a departure from the long-standing anti-tax pledge advocated by conservative activist Grover Norquist, U.S. Senator Saxby Chambliss (R-GA) has expressed his dissent, stating that he values the wellbeing of his country over a 20-year-old pledge. In an interview with Georgia television station WMAZ, a CNN affiliate, on Wednesday, Chambliss expressed his disagreement with Norquist's stance on the U.S. budget deficit and the potential consequences of the fiscal cliff.

The U.S. Congress is facing a year-end deadline to reach an agreement on addressing the U.S. budget deficit or implement other measures to avoid the so-called fiscal cliff, which experts warn could lead the country back into recession. The budget standoff centers on disagreements over how to generate new revenue to reduce the deficit.

President Barack Obama and Senate Democrats advocate for increasing tax rates for the wealthiest Americans, while House Republicans, who control the majority in that chamber, favor alternative methods for generating revenue, such as closing certain tax loopholes and eliminating deductions.

Norquist, who heads the conservative group Americans for Tax Reform, has been successful in persuading a strong majority of congressional Republicans to sign his pledge not to raise taxes. Many GOP candidates who ran for office also signed the promise, but a small number of freshman lawmakers have rejected the idea that they are bound to the document this year.

According to the Americans for Tax Reform website, Chambliss, along with 38 other senators and 219 House members entering the next Congress, have signed the pledge. However, Chambliss, who has previously criticized Norquist's influence on anti-tax sentiments, stated this week that Norquist's ideas are obstructing the search for a solution to the mounting debt.

"Norquist has no plan to pay this debt down," said Chambliss, who is up for re-election in 2014. The anti-tax crusader has stated that he predicts congressional Republicans will hold firm and negotiate a deal that excludes tax hikes.

When asked if Chambliss is concerned Norquist may use his resources to challenge his re-election bid, the senator replied, "In all likelihood, yes."

"But I do not worry about that because I care too much about my country," he said. "I care a lot more about it than I do Grover Norquist." The two-term senator from Georgia added he is "willing to do the right thing and let the political consequences take care of themselves."

Title: Republican Candidates in Ohio and Kansas Face Tight Races, Raising Concerns for Party Funding

Article:

As Republican candidates backed by President Donald Trump narrowly led in closely watched races in Ohio and Kansas on Wednesday, concerns grew in Republican circles about their ability to continue extending millions of dollars in aid to candidates in November's Congressional elections.

In Ohio's 12th congressional district, Republican Troy Balderson may have eked out a victory in a special election for a U.S. House of Representatives seat, but was leading Democrat Danny O'Connor by only about 1,700 votes or less than 1.0 percent. The final result could be days away as state officials count more than 8,000 provisional and absentee ballots.

In the Kansas primary to select a Republican candidate for November's mid-term U.S. elections, Kris Kobach was unable to convert an endorsement by Trump into a resounding victory. He clung to a 191-vote lead over his Republican primary opponent, current Governor Jeff Colyer, with potentially thousands more provisional and absentee ballots outstanding.

The narrow margin in Ohio is attributed to the $4 million-plus the party and outside groups pumped into the district in the final weeks to boost voter turnout. The infusion of cash into a district that has been represented by Republicans for 30 years further triggered alarm bells for the party.

In November, all 435 U.S. House members and one-third of the Senate stand for reelection. Democrats need to pick up 23 seats to take control of the House, and there are dozens of seats currently held by Republicans with larger Democratic populations than the Ohio district.

"Moving forward, we cannot expect to win tough races when our candidate is being outraised," said Corry Bliss, executive director of the Congressional Leadership Fund, a Republican Super PAC that supported Balderson in Ohio. "Any Republican running for Congress getting vastly outraised by an opponent needs to start raising more money."

Bliss's group, as of mid-July, had raised $96.6 million and had $73.3 million in remaining cash.

Republicans hope Balderson's narrow win on election night will jolt the field out of complacency. The biggest unknown may be just how much cash remains for Republicans to tap.

Casino executive Sheldon Adelson, historically a large donor, has already kicked in $30 million to help Republicans. However, the network of donors managed by Charles and David Koch have gone in the opposite direction, warning Republicans they may not support their candidates in large part because of Trump's protectionist trade policies.

There may still be a well of cash for Republicans thanks to the deep-pocketed donors delighted last year when Republicans passed sweeping tax cuts.

"There is going to be an awful lot of thank-you checks written for the tax bill," Brettell said.

In Democratic circles, the Ohio results were cast as a win, even if their candidate was not victorious. Other Republicans, including Vice President Mike Pence and Ohio Governor John Kasich, had rushed to Balderson's aid in a district Kasich once represented.

"He should be running scared this fall," said David Pepper, chair of the Ohio Democratic Party, regarding Balderson, who faces O'Connor in a rematch on Nov. 6. "He's not going to have Donald Trump, Mike Pence, and all that money bailing him out."

Both races left unanswered questions about whether Trump will be able to lift endangered members to victory, regardless of how much cash they have. Trump took credit for Balderson's lead, writing on Twitter that the campaign took "a big turn for the better" after he appeared in the district on Saturday.

However, Pepper noted that Trump's presence energizes Democrats as well, adding that "if he thinks that finish in this district is a good result, all power to him."

The Ohio race mirrored other special federal elections over the past 12 months, including upsets by Democrat Conor Lamb in a Pennsylvania congressional race in March and by Democrat Doug Jones over Roy Moore for an Alabama Senate seat in December of last year. Trump stumped for both candidates in losing efforts.

In those races, rural voters favored Trump-supported candidates, but turnout in those regions lagged heavy suburban turnout, where Democrats expanded on margins won by Hillary Clinton in 2016.

Kobach had hoped to ride his ties to Trump to victory after the president endorsed him in a tweet, but even as Kobach sought to declare himself the virtual winner on Wednesday, he acknowledged he could still lose, and a protracted recount could aid Democrats. Kansas state law allows for a recount if the vote margin is within half a percentage point, but the candidate has to request the recount. The candidate who requests the recount must pay for it if the results are unchanged by that process, Kobach said.

Title: White House Condemns Extremist Groups, Including White Supremacists and Neo-Nazis

Article:

In a statement on Sunday, a White House spokesman confirmed that President Donald Trump explicitly condemns all extremist groups, including white supremacists, the Ku Klux Klan, neo-Nazis, and other extremist organizations. The spokesman stated, "The President said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups." The spokesman further added that Trump called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.

The President's statement on Saturday was met with criticism for not specifically calling out and condemning white supremacist groups. Among the critics was former White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci, who told ABC News that Trump should have been much harsher. Scaramucci stated, "I wouldn't have recommended that statement. I think he would have needed to have been much harsher."

While in New Jersey, Trump described the Charlottesville rally as an "egregious display of hatred, bigotry, and violence on many sides." Many political observers deemed the President's response as not aggressive enough, given that a member of the alt-right allegedly drove a car through a group of antifa protesters, resulting in one death and at least 19 injuries.

Scaramucci added, "With the moral authority of the presidency, you have to call that stuff out." Other Republicans also expressed their opinions on Trump's statement publicly. GOP Sen. Orrin Hatch stated on Twitter, "We should call evil by its name. My brother didn't give his life fighting Hitler for Nazi ideas to go unchallenged here at home." GOP Sen. Cory Gardner urged Trump to declare the incident an act of terror. Gardner said, "Mr. President – we must call evil by its name. These were white supremacists, and this was domestic terrorism."

Title: Media Concerns Arise Over Mueller's Statement on Trump-Russia Investigation

Article:

In an unexpected move, Special Counsel Robert Mueller publicly disputed reported allegations related to the Trump-Russia investigation, sparking concerns within the media about potential backlash from Mueller's announcement. However, these worries were not centered on media accuracy but rather on the perception that Mueller had confirmed President Donald Trump's "fake news" label.

Jeffery Toobin, a senior CNN analyst and writer for The New Yorker, expressed his concerns on-air following Mueller's announcement. "I have a different view of the implications of all this," Toobin told CNN's Anderson Cooper. "My view is the larger message that a lot of people are going to take from this story is that the news media are a bunch of leftist liars who are dying to get the president, and they're willing to lie to do it." Toobin added, "I just think this is a bad day for us."

CNN anchor Chris Cuomo also observed that "Mueller did not do the media any favors." "And he did do the president one, because as you saw with Rudy Giuliani and as I'm sure you'll see with the president himself, this allows them to say, 'You can't believe it. You can't believe what you read, you can't believe what you hear, you can only believe us,'" Cuomo said.

In response to the development, Trump characterized the situation as "a very sad day for journalism, but a great day for our country!" He later denounced "fake news" as the "enemy of the people." The president's statement referred to Buzzfeed, which released the "discredited 'Dossier,'" a document paid for by Hillary Clinton and the Democrats as opposition research, on which the entire Russian probe is based.

Title: U.S. Admits 12,587 Syrian Refugees in FY 2016, 98.2% Are Sunni Muslims

Article:

The United States admitted a total of 12,587 Syrian refugees during the 2016 fiscal year, surpassing the target President Obama declared last fall by 2,587 (20.5%). The majority of the refugees are Sunni Muslims, with 12,363 (98.2%) identifying as such, while another 103 are identified as Muslims and 20 as Shi'a Muslims.

Sixty-eight of the 12,587 Syrian refugees (0.5%) are Christians. This group includes 16 Catholics, eight Orthodox, five Protestants, four Jehovah's Witnesses, one Greek Orthodox, and 34 refugees who self-identified as simply Christians.

The remaining Syrian refugees resettled in the U.S. in FY 2016 are 24 Yazidis, eight refugees with religion given as "other," and one with "no religion."

In the final month of the fiscal year, 1,847 Syrian refugees were admitted, with 1,812 being Sunnis, 13 being other Muslims, 12 being Christians, seven being Yazidis, and three being "other" religion.

Throughout the year, the numbers of Christians and other religious minorities among the Syrians granted refugee status in the U.S. were dwarfed by those of Sunni Muslims. Although the majority of Syrians are Sunnis, the number of Sunnis among the refugees was still disproportionately high, and the number of Christians disproportionately low, when compared to the overall population makeup.

When the conflict began in 2011, an estimated 10% of the Syrian population (1.5-1.7 million) was Christian, and 74% was Sunni Muslim. In contrast, Christians accounted for just half of one percent of the refugees resettled in the United States in FY 2016, while Sunnis accounted for 98.2%.

The United Nations reports that 4,806,702 million Syrians are registered as "persons of concern" in Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, and North Africa. It does not provide a denominational breakdown.

Estimates of the number of Christians who have fled their homeland vary, but the European Parliament this year said at least 700,000 had done so, while a Chaldean Catholic bishop from Aleppo last March put the figure at at least one million.

The U.S. government administration has determined that atrocities carried out by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) against religious minorities in areas under its control amount to genocide. Administration officials say, however, that its refugee program does not and will not prioritize any particular religious group when considering Syrians' applications.

President Obama has not declared a target figure for Syrian refugee admissions for FY 2017, although a recent report to Congress stated that the administration "aims to admit a significantly higher number" of Syrian refugees in the new fiscal year than the 10,000 target initially set for FY 2016.

Assistant Secretary of State Anne Richard said last week that even though the department is working with a stipulated target for FY 2017, "this administration has been very clear that we want to bring more Syrians, so my own guidance to our staff is that we want to bring even more than we brought this year."

Over the course of the conflict that began when small anti-government protests in early 2011 were met with a harsh crackdown by the Assad regime and later widened into a convoluted civil war, the U.S. has resettled a total of 14,460 Syrian refugees – 87% of them during FY 2016. Of those 14,460, 14,082 (97.3%) are Sunnis, 196 (1.3%) are Shi'a and other Muslims, and 124 (0.8%) are Christians. The rest are 25 Yazidis, six Zoroastrians, three atheists, two Baha'i, 14 refugees with "other" religion, and eight with "no religion."

Title: Autopsy Report Suggests Michael Brown Was Shot Multiple Times, Family Calls for Arrest of Officer Darren Wilson

Article:

A preliminary autopsy report, conducted at the family's request, suggests that Michael Brown, an 18-year-old unarmed black man who was fatally shot by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson on August 9, was shot at least six times, including twice in the head. The autopsy was performed by pathologist Michael Baden, who shared his opinion that Brown did not suffer before his death.

At a news conference in Ferguson, Missouri, attorney Benjamin Crump, representing the Brown family, stated that Brown's mother, Lesley McSpadden, asked, "What else do we need to get them to arrest the killer of my child?" Crump also revealed that Baden shared his opinion that Brown could have survived all of his wounds except for the shot to the top of his head.

Baden explained that the shot to the top of Brown's head was probably sustained last, hitting him as he was bending over, and exited through his right eye. The pathologist also stated that six bullets entered Brown's body, and at least two bullets ricocheted and traveled back through his body. Bullet wounds to Brown's arms could have been sustained by putting his hands up or crossing his arms, according to Baden.

U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder ordered a separate federal autopsy of Brown, which was being performed by a U.S. military medical examiner on Monday. Holder stated that the additional autopsy would be thorough and aid in the investigation. The Justice Department is conducting a separate inquiry into possible civil rights violations related to the shooting.

Baden also mentioned that a final autopsy report would require study of the clothes Brown was wearing to see if they contained gunshot residue, which would indicate whether at least one shot was fired at close range. No residue was found on Brown's body, according to Baden.

The St. Louis County Medical Examiner's autopsy concluded that Brown died of gunshot wounds, but other details have not been released. The Washington Post, citing a person familiar with that autopsy, said the county autopsy indicates Brown was shot six to eight times and that he had marijuana in his system. Suzanne McCune, administrator of the medical examiner's office, stated that the office is only providing information that Brown died of gunshot wounds to the head and chest and could not confirm the marijuana report.

Shawn Parcells, a forensic pathologist assistant who helped conduct the autopsy requested by Brown's family, told CNN on Monday afternoon that he was surprised that the preliminary results of the autopsy were not released sooner. U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder ordered a separate, third autopsy, citing the "extraordinary" nature of the case at the request of Brown's family.

Title: The Evolution of Journalism: A Look at the Past and Present

Article:

The recent layoffs at digital news outlets BuzzFeed, Huffington Post, and Vice have sparked concerns about the state of journalism and its impact on democracy. Antonio García Martínez, a former Facebook employee and author, suggests that the Founding Fathers, such as Ben Franklin and Samuel Adams, would find today's journalistic landscape unrecognizable, but would recognize social media, blogs, and partisan outlets like Daily Kos or National Review.

García Martízen argues that the concept of journalistic objectivity, which is often considered a cornerstone of modern journalism, is a relatively recent development in American history. In the past, newspapers were overtly political, and a name like The Press Democrat would have signified a Democratic party affiliation. Advertising was a minor concern, as party leaders encouraged members to subscribe to their local party organ.

The shift towards a more neutral, advertising-driven model occurred in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, in response to the growth of the national market for consumer goods after the Civil War. Newspapers increased the number of ads relative to content and moved away from political partisanship to expand circulation. This change was driven by both ideals and greed, as newspapers sought to reach larger audiences and generate more revenue.

Jill Abramson, former executive editor of The New York Times, offers insights into this collision between the legacy grandeur and profitability of journalism and the current zeitgeist in her memoir, Merchants of Truth. In one scene, the Times' CEO asks Abramson to come up with new revenue ideas, to which she indignantly responds, "If that's what you expect, you have the wrong executive editor." This disconnect between editorial and business would have been inconceivable to a reborn Founding Father journalist, who would have embraced new monetization ideas.

Title: DHS Confirms Use of DACA Recipients' Information for Deportation Proceedings

Article:

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has confirmed that personal information provided by Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) recipients can be used for immigration enforcement proceedings. This information, which includes sensitive details about their residences, workplaces, and schools, was provided by the recipients during the application process.

In a memo, the DHS stated that US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), the agency responsible for handling DACA, would not proactively provide a list of DACA recipients' personal information to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) or Customs and Border Protection (CBP) for immigration enforcement purposes. However, if ICE officers request such information, USCIS will provide it.

The Trump administration has signaled that they will not defend the constitutionality of DACA, as they question its legality, particularly in regards to the separation of powers. The GOP has long criticized DACA as executive overreach, and a dozen Republican state attorneys general have threatened to sue the administration if they settle the DACA issue. As a result, the program was ended with a six-month enforcement delay to allow Congress time to pass DACA-like legislation.

Recently, there has been a debate in Congress and the media regarding the enforcement of DACA. While this discussion continues, two DACA recipients were apprehended by the Border Patrol for smuggling illegal immigrants across the border. This incident highlights the ongoing tension between border security and immigration policy.

Senate Republicans, such as Tom Cotton from Arkansas, see this as an opportunity to push for the passage of the RAISE Act, which aims to overhaul the green card process to prioritize immigrants with high skills and includes a language provision. This proposal is met with opposition from Democrats, who view any aspect of border security as anathema.

Title: Neutral Analysis on George Zimmerman Case: A Journalist's Perspective

Article:

The George Zimmerman case, a highly debated topic in recent times, has seen various opinions expressed by public figures such as former President Jimmy Carter and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. However, a practicing attorney and columnist, with experience in a murder trial, offers a neutral perspective on the matter.

The attorney, who once served as lead counsel for a 17-year-old boy facing the death penalty, has chosen to remain silent on the Zimmerman verdict. The complexity of the laws governing such serious cases and the impact of testimony and evidence make it difficult to second-guess the strategy of the prosecution or defense, or to judge the jury's decision.

The attorney notes that legal analysts, while their opinions may vary, are grounded in law and experience. However, when politicians and political pundits pass judgment on a jury's decision, their comments are often uninformed.

The attorney also addresses the ongoing discussions about "stand your ground" laws in Florida and other states. They point out that the defense in the Zimmerman case did not rely on this particular law, and that the arguments over its effectiveness and potential problems are not central to the courtroom proceedings.

Furthermore, the attorney questions the practicality of stricter laws against racial profiling, as it may be challenging for Congress to determine if an individual is racially profiling another. They also question the applicability of such laws to all races and the treatment of individuals by others.

The attorney concludes by acknowledging that Trayvon Martin's death is a fact that cannot be undone, and that Zimmerman, despite being declared "not guilty," faces a sense of a "sentence" due to the hatred and threats he faces. The attorney, with a passing interest in the case, expresses a lack of qualification to opine on the merits of this case, given their limited experience in murder trials.

Title: Barr and Mueller: A Clash of Perspectives in the Release of Mueller Report

Article:

Attorney General William Barr testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on May 1, 2019, following a letter from Special Counsel Robert Mueller expressing concerns about Barr's summary of the Mueller report's findings.

The release of Barr's summary of the Mueller report's top-line conclusions sparked controversy, with Democrats and the press focusing on the process of the report's release rather than its content. The full 400-page report was later made public with redactions.

Barr's decision to release a summary of the report's findings was aimed at providing a swift assessment of whether President Donald Trump had conspired with Russian officials. He opposed the subsequent release of summaries of the report, preferring to release the entire report at once.

Mueller, in a letter to Barr, expressed concerns about the summary and the public's perception of it. However, Mueller did not dispute the accuracy of Barr's summary, as Barr noted that Mueller did not "exonerate" Trump on obstruction.

Barr is facing accusations of perjury in prior congressional testimony regarding his handling of the report. During a conversation with Representative Charlie Crist (Fla.), Barr stated that he was unaware of specific complaints from unnamed Mueller staff regarding the summary's release to the press. He also offered his own perspective on why he chose not to release summaries of the report.

What is notable about this episode is that Mueller, or people close to him, were reportedly concerned about the media coverage and political discussion surrounding the report, particularly its perceived lack of damning evidence against the president. This is not a prosecutorial concern, but a political one that is unbecoming of individuals entrusted with immense investigative power in the name of objectivity.

The ongoing debate between Barr and Mueller, as well as the media's coverage of the issue, continues to generate controversy and speculation. The focus on process rather than content has led to accusations and counter-accusations, highlighting the political polarization that surrounds the Trump administration.

Title: Fact-Checking the Dakota Access Pipeline Controversy: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

The Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) has been a subject of intense controversy, with anti-fracking activists and the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe voicing concerns over the project's potential impact on tribal lands and the environment. However, a closer look at the facts surrounding the DAPL reveals a more nuanced picture.

The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe did not participate in the initial consulting process regarding the DAPL route, according to court documents. The Army Corps of Engineers attempted more than a dozen times between 2014 and 2016 to discuss the DAPL route with the tribe, but the tribe either failed to respond or delayed the process.

The DAPL runs parallel to an already existing pipeline, the Northern Border Pipeline, built in 1982, which has never received protests or complaints from demonstrators associated with Standing Rock. The government rerouted the DAPL several times to avoid tribal lands, and the modifications were made to avoid 91 of the 149 eligible sites containing stone features considered sacred by American Indian tribes.

The DAPL route does not cut through Standing Rock's reservation, and the tribe has argued that the land is theirs under the Fort Laramie Treaty of 1851. However, the treaty was forged between the U.S. government and the Great Sioux Nation, not Standing Rock. The tribe has challenged the treaty and others like it in court for not being honored.

Eminent domain was not used on the North Dakota route, and Energy Transfer Partners relied on voluntary easements to construct the pipeline's southern route near Standing Rock Sioux's reservation. Federal officials are refusing to evict protesters occupying private property along the DAPL route, citing free speech rights. Eminent domain was used in other portions of the route in Iowa, prompting farmers to sue the Iowa Utilities Board (IUB) in an effort to prevent the company from gaining the right to use the property-seizing tool.

Investments in pipelines like DAPL have increased by 60% since 2010, according to an American Petroleum Institute study, and have nearly doubled from $56.3 billion in 2010 to $89.6 billion in 2013. The increase has likely raised concerns among environmentalists about the use of eminent domain.

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers evaluated the Bismarck route, eventually concluding it was not a viable option due to the project's close proximity to the capital's municipal water supply wells. The department also determined the northern route would have made it difficult to stay 500 or more feet away from homes, a policy required in North Dakota. The southern route near Standing Rock's reservation is mostly rural, making it easier for the pipeline to be constructed with as little environmental impact as possible. The Army Corps of Engineers deemed the new pipeline route crossing Lake Ohae safe in an environmental assessment.

Title: Trump Disputes Puerto Rico Hurricane Death Toll, Sparking Controversy Amidst Approaching Hurricane Florence

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has disputed the official findings that nearly 3,000 people died in Puerto Rico as a result of last year's hurricanes. In a series of tweets, Mr. Trump claimed, "3000 people did not die in the two hurricanes that hit Puerto Rico," without providing evidence for the claim.

The official death toll of 2,975 was released last month after an independent study by George Washington University. The study concluded that the initial death toll of 64 only included those killed directly by hurricanes Maria and Irma, either by drowning, flying debris, or building collapse. George Washington University also counted those who died in the six months following the storm as a result of poor healthcare provision, a lack of electricity, and clean water.

The politics surrounding the death toll have become a contentious issue, with Democrats accusing Mr. Trump of downplaying the disaster's impact on Puerto Rico. The president's tweets came as Hurricane Florence, a category two storm projected to bring catastrophic flooding, bore down on the U.S. East Coast.

The governor of Puerto Rico, who commissioned the research, said he accepted the estimate as official. Puerto Rico's Mayor of San Juan, Carmen Yulin Cruz, responded to Mr. Trump's tweets, stating, "Mr. Trump, you can try and bully us with your tweets BUT WE KNOW OUR LIVES MATTER."

In response to the criticism, Mr. Trump hailed the U.S. response in Puerto Rico as "an incredible, unsung success." This statement was met with backlash from Puerto Rican officials, with San Juan's Mayor Cruz describing Mr. Trump's handling of Maria as a "stain on his presidency."

The U.S. federal government's response to Hurricane Maria has come under fresh scrutiny this week, with photos emerging showing 20,000 pallets of bottled water meant for victims still sitting on a runway in Ceiba, Puerto Rico, a year after the storm. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) is currently investigating whether or not it placed the water bottles on the runway and, if so, will "fess up."

The ongoing controversy surrounding the death toll and the federal government's response to Hurricane Maria has sparked criticism from both political parties. Even some of Mr. Trump's fellow Republicans have spoken out against him, with Florida Republican Congresswoman Ileana Ros-Lehtinen calling the president's tweets "mind-boggling." Florida Governor Rick Scott, who is currently running for the U.S. Senate, tweeted, "I've been to Puerto Rico 7 times & saw devastation firsthand. The loss of any life is tragic."

The ongoing debate over the death toll and the federal government's response to Hurricane Maria has raised questions about the U.S. government's ability to effectively respond to natural disasters in Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories.

Title: U.S. Stock Market Enters Bear Market Territory Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The U.S. stock market has entered a bear market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) falling into bear-market territory on Wednesday, marking the first time in over a decade. The decline in risk assets continued on Thursday, with U.S. stock indexes set to close in bear-market territory.

The World Health Organization declared COVID-19, the infectious disease first identified in Wuhan, China, in December, a pandemic on Wednesday. This declaration, along with President Donald Trump's Oval Office address about the pandemic, failed to alleviate market anxieties going into trading on Thursday.

The coronavirus outbreak has infected over 127,000 people and claimed nearly 4,700 lives worldwide. Market experts fear that the pandemic could disrupt global supply chains and drive the global economy into recession.

The Dow DJIA, +9.36%, composed of 30 blue-chip companies, has been pulled lower by a significant decline in shares of component Boeing Co. BA, +9.92%. The S&P 500 SPX, +9.28% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +9.34% are also expected to end the day in bear-market territory.

The Dow plunged 1,464.94 points, or 5.9%, to settle at 23,553.22 on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 fell 4.9%, to 2,741.38. The Nasdaq tumbled 4.7%, to end at 7,952.05.

Stocks dropped into correction mode, defined as a pullback of 10%, late last month as fears over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak began to rise.

There is some hope that a stint in bear-market territory will be short-lived if the viral outbreak is effectively mitigated by governments and central banks across the globe. Historically, the period in a bear market can be lengthy.

On average, a bear market for the Dow lasts 206 trading days, while the average bear period for the S&P 500 is about 146 days, according to data from Dow Jones Market Data. The Dow is currently off 29% from its Feb. 12 record, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq are 27% from their Feb. 19 peaks, as of late Thursday.

The move for the Dow also represents the blue-chip index's fastest move from a record high to a bear market since 1931—19 days. In November 1931, as the Great Depression was enveloping the U.S., the Dow took a brisk 15 days from a record to a drop of at least 20%.

Title: African-American Trump Supporter Faces Criticism and Discrimination

Article:

Washington, D.C. - Devinn Smart, a 24-year-old African-American supporter of President Donald Trump, has faced criticism and discrimination for his political views. In an interview with ███ News, Smart expressed his belief that Trump will win the 2020 presidential election by a landslide.

Smart, who grew up in a family of die-hard Democrats and attended a historically black university in Hampton, Virginia, initially held a different political view. However, after researching Trump's policies, he became a supporter.

In 2016, Smart did not vote, but after Trump's election, he publicly declared his support on Twitter, complete with a "Make America Great Again" hat. This decision led to a barrage of insults, including being called a "coon," a "bootlicker," and an "Uncle Tom" due to his support for the president.

Smart has also faced discrimination in his role as a preacher. Twice, he was disinvited from spiritual revival conferences in Virginia after the organizers learned of his political views. In one instance, a pastor asked Smart to denounce his support for Trump on Twitter or be disinvited. Smart refused, questioning the pastor's adherence to biblical principles.

Despite the backlash, Smart remains steadfast in his support for Trump. He cites the historically low unemployment rate for African-Americans, the groundbreaking prison reform law, and the record amount of federal money allocated to historically black colleges as achievements that may be paying political dividends.

In 2016, Trump won eight percent of the black vote. A new poll shows him with almost double that now at 15 percent. Smart attended the White House in October as part of the Black Leadership Summit. During the event, he and a friend had a unique experience. They asked President Trump if they could pray, and he granted their request. The friend's subsequent prayer has since gone viral.

Smart believes there are many other African-Americans who support Trump but are too afraid to express their views publicly. He shared that he received over 100 messages on Twitter from people who support Trump but are not as vocal as he is.

The Trump Campaign is hopeful that Smart's prediction of a strong African-American voter turnout in 2020 will come to fruition.

Title: Former Witch Warns Parents About Influence of Disney's "The Owl House"

Article:

A new Disney cartoon, "The Owl House," has been teaching children that being a witch is a positive concept, recently premiering on the Disney Channel. The show portrays witchcraft as a tool to combat evil, sparking debate among some who argue that it is merely make-believe and poses no concern for children.

However, a former witch and lesbian, Jenny Weaver, expressed caution to parents regarding the content their children consume. In an interview with "The Prayer Link," Weaver shared her personal experiences and the impact that similar media had on her life.

Weaver, who grew up in a dysfunctional home and battled depression, recounted her connection to the 1996 movie "The Craft," which follows four high school witches with immense power. Weaver saw the power portrayed in the movie as an escape from her struggles, leading her to self-harm and eventually becoming a practicing witch.

"I remember hearing these voices, 'Just kill yourself. Just go away. It would be better off if you would just die.' And so, I started to cut my wrists severely," Weaver explained, detailing the 56 cuts she inflicted on her arms.

Weaver's self-harm opened a door to the demonic realm, leading her to practice witchcraft, study Wiccan religion, and engage in spells and incantations. She emphasized the importance of parents being mindful of the media their children consume, stating, "It's not a joke when we say be careful what your children are watching."

Weaver also shared her experiences with lesbianism and drug addiction, which she overcame after years of struggle. Today, she ministers through prophetic worship to thousands via Facebook through her ministry, Jenny Weaver Worships.

For more insights into Jenny Weaver's life-changing story, tune into "The Prayer Link" on the ███ News Channel Tuesday nights at 6:30 pm eastern.

Title: AP Investigation Reveals Repeated Hacks on U.S. Power Grid, Potential for Catastrophic Blackout

Article:

A new Associated Press (AP) investigation has uncovered repeated hacking incidents on the U.S. power grid, with one of the most severe attacks linked to Iran. The investigation reveals that sophisticated hackers now have the capability to strike at any moment they choose.

The power grid, which supplies power to the military, mass transit, business, and millions of Americans, is protected 24/7 against physical and cyber attacks. However, the AP investigation reports that, in the past decade, nearly a dozen times foreign hackers have gained remote access to networks that run the grid.

Eireann Leverett, with the Cambridge Center for Risk Studies, stated, "We're still in this era where everyone believes it's secure by default... and it's not." Stephen Swick, with American Electric Power, added, "We're seeing people looking for vulnerabilities, people scanning to see what types of openings they can find."

Some of the attacks against the U.S. power grid are believed to have been carried out by hacking teams from Russia, China, and Iran, with ISIS also attempting to hack American power companies. Alejandro Mayorkas, with the Department of Homeland Security, stated, "We are not where we need to be and we are very, very focused on getting to where we need to be."

As of now, intrusions into the networks that control the power grid have not caused the catastrophic blackout that experts fear. However, it is believed that many cyber attackers already have the information they need to do just that, giving them the capability to strike at will.

Swick warned, "It's all real. There's lots of variables and lots of potentials that could happen." The Department of Homeland Security emphasizes public and private cooperation as the key to fighting cyber attacks. The agency is coordinating efforts to strengthen grid cybersecurity nationwide and to raise awareness about evolving threats.

Title: Carter Assures Independence as Defense Nominee, Disagrees with White House on Key Issues

Article:

Ashton Carter, President Obama's nominee for the position of Defense Secretary, assured senators during his confirmation hearing on Wednesday that he would maintain an independent voice within the administration. Carter's stance on critical issues such as Guantanamo Bay, Ukraine, and troop deployment in Iraq and Afghanistan differed from the White House's, prompting a response from the White House.

White House spokesman Joshua Ernest cautioned that President Obama, not Mr. Carter, sets policy. In response to questions about Carter's testimony on arming Ukraine against Russian aggression, Ernest stated, "A decision like this will be made by the commander in chief."

Two of Obama's previous defense chiefs, Robert Gates and outgoing Secretary Chuck Hagel, have publicly expressed frustration over what they perceived as White House micromanagement of the Pentagon.

Carter, who is popular in the Senate and whose nomination is all but assured, faced questions from Republican senators on the Senate Armed Services Committee about his plans to remain independent. Carter immediately took the challenge, expressing support for sending arms to Ukraine in the fight against Russian separatists, a stance that differs from Obama's.

Carter did not specify the weapons to be considered but said, "I incline in the direction of providing them with arms, including to get to what I'm sure your question is, lethal arms."

At the White House, Ernest was peppered with questions and tried to put a positive face on a new defense secretary who is unafraid to express his opinions publicly. Carter was described as a "strong believer in the chain of command."

Carter also assured lawmakers he would not allow the White House to pressure him into rapidly closing the U.S. military detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. In a statement made just the day before, Carter expressed doubt about Obama's goal of closing Gitmo, despite supporting it.

Senator John McCain, the chairman of the committee and an Arizona Republican, expressed concerns about White House micromanagement of the Defense Department and over-centralization of foreign and defense policy. Senator Kelly Ayotte echoed McCain's concerns and urged Carter to commit to the committee that he would not succumb to any pressure from the administration to increase the transfers of Guantanamo detainees.

Title: U.S. Adds 151,000 New Jobs in August; Unemployment Rate Remains Steady at 4.9%

Article:

The United States added 151,000 new jobs in August, and the unemployment rate remained steady at 4.9%, according to the monthly jobs report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). The job growth and unemployment rate fell short of expectations, as economists were anticipating approximately 180,000 new jobs and a slight decrease in the unemployment rate to 4.8%.

The U.S. economy has experienced 78 consecutive months of job growth. The job growth for the past few months was revised, with June numbers decreasing to 271,000 from the initially reported 292,000, and July numbers increasing to 275,000 from the previously reported 255,000. The net change was a slight drop, with about 1,000 fewer jobs added in the past two months than the BLS had originally believed.

Average hourly earnings rose by 3 cents, to $25.73. The percentage of involuntary part-time workers, as well as the labor force participation rate and the number of long-term unemployed, all saw little change.

Service-providing sectors performed well last month, with food services, social assistance, professional and technical services, and financial activities all experiencing growth. Health care jobs continue to increase, but at a slower pace than recent months. Mining employment, on the other hand, continues its long decline.

The jobs report has been closely monitored in recent months, as the Federal Reserve considers raising interest rates for only the second time since the global financial crisis. The second-in-command at the Fed, Stanley Fischer, told CNBC last week that the August jobs report "will probably weigh in our decision" on the timing of a possible rate increase.

According to NPR's John Ydstie, if job growth had kept pace with expectations, there would have been pressure on the Fed to raise rates sooner rather than later. Now, many analysts expect that the Federal Reserve will not be adjusting interest rates during its September meeting.

Title: "Lenny McAllister Advocates for a More Consistent and Resourceful Approach to Post-COVID-19 Economic Recovery"

Article:

Lenny McAllister, Director of Western Pennsylvania for the Commonwealth Foundation, an award-winning think tank based in Pennsylvania, has called for a more consistent and resourceful approach to economic recovery in the post-COVID-19 world. McAllister, who has appeared on Fox News, The Blaze, Sirius XM Radio, and other outlets, argues that the discussion around re-opening local economies should be more in line with the spirit and successes of America.

McAllister contends that, during times of crisis, people tend to act out of either fear or resourcefulness. He suggests that, for weeks, too many Americans have acted out of fear, leading to over-arching, non-transparent, and single-tracked subjective decision-making that has caused harm to both those who contracted COVID-19 and those who have not.

In his opinion piece, McAllister argues that it is time for Americans to change course and think bigger. He believes that the old question of "fight or flight" still applies, but that we must fight smartly, confidently, yet differently.
