McAllister suggests that we must fight back against all impacts of the virus, not just the health crisis.

From an economic standpoint, McAllister makes the case for re-opening America for a variety of reasons, including the fact that the curve has flattened, and hospitals are not currently overrun. He also points out that experts have shown that the worst-case scenarios given for fatalities linked to COVID-19 were over-estimated, with some calling for "...time to end the COVID-19 Hysteria..." Even many epidemiologists are critiquing how often the models for projections are inconsistent at best.

McAllister argues that it is time to re-open our society and bolster our consumer-driven economy, leaning on the time-tested ingenuity of the American people. He believes that personal responsibility, consumer-driven decision-making, and business innovation can keep us safe while getting people back to work.

McAllister points out that "big box" stores such as Target, Publix, and Wal-Mart have remained open during some of the strictest shelter-in-place orders and kept their customers safe. He questions why we cannot also trust small business owners, who are often family-owned and locally-invested, to do the same. After all, they are the type of business operators that can least afford to flub social distancing and safety guidelines at the risk of losing their hard-earned consumer base due to small margins of operating expenses, leaving very little room for error.

McAllister also highlights the example of distillers stepping up and pivoting their businesses when Americans were in short supply of hand sanitizers. He expects them and other manufacturers to step up once again, revving up their economic engines while adjusting their business practices to keep their employees and customers safe.

According to McAllister, businesses exist to make profit and provide value, not just for their stakeholders, but for their consumers as well. That value includes providing proven quality in their products but also safe environments for commerce. He believes that, through innovation, businesses can survive and society can thrive.

McAllister cites examples from American history, such as the weight-related epidemic in America, the Tylenol tampering cases of the early 1980s, and the evolution of car safety, to illustrate how businesses have adapted to changing circumstances. He argues that our post-curve-flattening world is very much the same, and that our successful re-opening must be driven mostly by the power of free markets, not free-wheeling governors.

McAllister concludes that, with more people making good, self-directed decisions to keep us all safe while getting our economy and society back on track, we can have more assurances that more people can overcome the medical, social, economic, and emotional impacts of COVID-19. He believes that, with more people in the fight, there will become more ways for us to overcome the aftermath of the virus safely.

Title: Trump Super PACs Struggle to Raise Funds Amidst Campaign's Bombastic Rhetoric

Article:

Super PACs supporting Donald Trump's presidential campaign are facing difficulties in fundraising due to the candidate's controversial rhetoric and unclear financial support expectations. According to the Federal Election Commission, Trump's campaign war chest is significantly smaller than Hillary Clinton's, with Clinton having $42.5 million in the bank at the start of June compared to Trump's $1.3 million.

Trump has repeatedly taunted big donors and boasted for months that his campaign would not rely on them or Super PACs. However, recent statements suggest a change in his stance.

Billionaire broadcaster Stan Hubbard, who has donated $100,000 to the pro-Trump Great America Pac, criticized Trump's recent trip to Scotland and his comments about the plunge in the pound post-Brexit. Hubbard stated, "He should have let his kids do it."

Similarly, potential Super PAC donors have expressed concerns about Trump's rhetoric and the need for a clearer, less bombastic message. Michael Epstein, who has raised significant funds for Wisconsin governor Scott Walker, said he might back a Super PAC if Trump demonstrates more presidential behavior and shows a strong performance at the Republican National Convention. However, Epstein expressed doubts, stating, "I’m less and less hopeful. He can’t get out of his own way."

Four key pro-Trump Super PACs have been launched, but they have run only about $5 million in ads combined, compared to the leading pro-Clinton Super PAC, Priorities USA Action, which reportedly began a massive ad blitz in mid-May worth almost $130 million.

Signs of turmoil and slow growth among the Trump Super PACs, which can accept unlimited donations, are evident. Texas mega-donor Doug Deason, who has met with Trump, stated that the candidate's top fundraiser had signaled that a new Super PAC, Make America Number One, backed by hedge fund billionaire Robert Mercer, was the "official" one. However, Make America Number One is reportedly seeking big checks from GOP donors who are not yet ready to back Trump but want to stop Clinton.

Billionaire casino mogul Sheldon Adelson, who has pledged some $100 million to help Trump, has been cautious and slow in opening his checkbook after at least two meetings with Trump since late May. Adelson is said to be considering setting up his own Super PAC and discussing cobbling one together to help Trump, according to fundraising sources.

Other wealthy donors, including Bernie Marcus and Toby Neugebauer, are reportedly being considered by Adelson for teaming up on a Super PAC. Adelson may also release his funds in installments, with about half coming after Trump picks his running mate, according to a GOP operative with ties to Adelson.

Existing Super PACs are making efforts to attract big donors. The Great America Pac, which boasts veteran GOP operative Ed Rollins as a strategist, has raised $5 million and has commitments for another $4 million. The Pac plans to raise $150 million by the election, with a focus on key states such as Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania.

Other pro-Trump Super PACs are also ramping up their fundraising and ad drives. Laurance Gay, the managing director of the Super Pac Rebuilding America Now, stated that it had raised $2 million, most of which has paid for two TV ads. Rebuilding America Now expects to raise and spend close to $20 million through the Republican National Convention and then hopes to raise another $80 million for the rest of the campaign season.

However, fundraising remains a challenge for the pro-Trump Super PACs. Fred Malek, a veteran money man and top fundraiser for GOP governors, cautions that Trump's policies and temperament pose obstacles for Super PAC fundraising. Malek emphasizes that GOP donors and voters "want to see a nominee who is more inclusive rather than divisive and recognizes that politics is a game of addition and not a game of subtraction."

Title: Debt Ceiling and Congressional Scandals Dominate Washington Agenda

Article:

The United States Congress is currently grappling with a multitude of pressing issues, including the debt ceiling, budget, immigration, jobs, and the Keystone pipeline, among others. These matters have accumulated in the inbox, with the debt ceiling being reached over the weekend. While President Obama has vowed to maintain his focus on the middle class, the bipartisan response to at least three ongoing scandals has become an integral part of the 2013 congressional agenda.

Treasury Secretary Jack Lew notified Congress on Friday that he was implementing "extraordinary measures" to enable the government to continue paying its bills. This action was taken as the U.S. government technically hit the debt ceiling, following the expiration of a prior suspension on that limit.

In 2011, the debate over the debt ceiling was a significant news event, with the full faith and credit of the U.S. government at stake. This time around, the situation is almost routine, with Lew referring to the "standard set of extraordinary measures" in his letter to House Speaker John Boehner on May 17. However, Lew cautioned that Washington may only last until sometime after Labor Day, and urged Congress to act promptly to protect the country's good credit and avoid potential catastrophic consequences.

Congressional Republicans are expected to seek cost-cutting concessions to partially offset the increase in the debt ceiling, but have not specified what these will be. Michael Steel, spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner, stated that Congress is in the process of discussing with members and the American public on how to address the debt ceiling and "Washington's out-of-control spending."

In the House, lawmakers are primarily focused on investigating the administration's handling of the Benghazi terror attack, the IRS's targeting of conservative groups, and the Justice Department's seizure of phone records from Associated Press journalists. The latter scandal was exacerbated by revelations that the department obtained a search warrant for a Fox News reporter's private emails as part of a separate leak investigation.

President Obama and his administration are also dealing with the fallout from these scandals, with a portion of his administration's staff dedicating time to answering investigators' questions. Andrew Card, former chief of staff to President George W. Bush, suggested that the White House counsel's office will be closely focused on White House cooperation with the investigations, while the current chief of staff, Denis McDonough, is likely keeping the president and his senior staff focused on other matters.

The issue of gun control, which was a priority for Obama in his second term, appears to have been set aside for the time being. However, the matter of the budget, including the possibility of major entitlement and tax reform, still looms. The Senate and House have each passed their own budget, but an agreement has not been reached on reconciling the differences between the two versions.

Some work on Capitol Hill will likely continue unaffected by the scandals. A Senate committee is moving toward finalizing its work on an immigration bill this week, while bipartisan House negotiators are crafting a bill of their own.

Title: Consumer Expectations and Online Data Collection: A Study by Digital Content Next

Article:

With the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) now in effect, digital media companies are reassessing their online data collection policies and procedures to ensure compliance. The CCPA is considered the most comprehensive consumer privacy law and a benchmark for other states to follow.

Digital Content Next, the trade association of major digital publishers, conducted a survey of a nationally representative sample of U.S. adults to understand their expectations around online privacy and their engagement with online tracking. The findings show that consumers generally expect websites and apps to collect data about them to personalize, protect, and improve their experience. However, they do not expect outside vendors to collect data about them for reuse or sale.

When asked about their expectations regarding data collection by websites and apps, 59% of respondents expect data collection to protect them from fraud and malicious activity. Similarly, 55% expect data collection to help improve the website or app overall. Around half (54%) expect data collection to identify if they are a paid subscriber or member when they log into the website or app. Nearly half (49%) expect data collection to offer a personalized experience, while only 32% expect data to be shared with outside vendors to deliver targeted ads while they are on the website or app to help fund its content.

When asked about the data practices of outside vendors, fewer respondents (38%) expect the future reuse of their personal data, and even fewer (24%) expect it to be sold. Interestingly, when given a clear explanation of how their data will be used and the benefits, more respondents (47%) align with the practice.

Consumers' awareness of their ability to opt out of data collection is relatively low. Only half (52%) of all U.S. adults said they were aware of ways they could choose not to participate in online data collection. Furthermore, fewer consumers have opted out of online data collection or plan to do so in the next 30 days (40%) than those who either don't know how to opt out or don't understand what it means (44%).

For those opting out of online data collection, the top consumer actions remain cookie-related, such as deleting browser cookies on a regular basis or turning them off, followed by turning on "Do Not Track" and installing an ad blocker. However, deleting cookies or turning on "Do Not Track" doesn't completely remove the consumer from online data collection.

In the former case, deleting cookies has the frustrating consequence of logging the user out of news and other subscription sites and depersonalizing experiences consumers are comfortable with, like a weather site knowing their location to provide an accurate forecast. In the latter, privacy policies show that most of the industry, especially third-party ad tech vendors, ignore "Do Not Track," as there's no incentive to move independently. The new CCPA regulation may change this, raising the bar for everyone.

As a result of opting out of online data collection, consumers expect greater privacy, an improved online experience, and enhanced security. These findings highlight the need to align data collection practices with consumer expectations. While consumers understand the need for websites and apps to collect some amount of user data, there's a significant disconnect with third parties selling or reusing this data in the future. Offering seamless and simplified controls is an important part of the compliance process and, arguably more importantly, of preserving and growing the trust of publishers' audiences.

Title: New Hampshire Primary Poll: Buttigieg Leads Democratic Contenders, Warren and Biden Slip

Article:

In the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, a new poll indicates South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg with a significant lead over his top-tier rivals in New Hampshire, which hosts the first primary in the race for the White House. According to a Saint Anselm College Survey Center poll released Tuesday, Buttigieg garnered the support of 25 percent of likely Democratic presidential primary voters in New Hampshire. Former Vice President Joe Biden and Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts were tied for second, each at 15 percent.

The poll showed Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont at 9 percent, Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota at 6 percent, billionaire environmental and progressive advocate Tom Steyer at 5 percent, Sen. Cory Booker of New Jersey and Rep. Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii each at 3 percent, tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang at 2 percent, and everyone else tested in the survey at 1 percent or less.

Buttigieg, the youngest candidate in the large field of White House hopefuls, has surged in the polls since the spring, reaching top-tier status. He has gained 15 percentage points since the previous Saint Anselm College poll, which was conducted in September. Warren's support has dropped 10 points since the previous poll, while Biden's support has decreased by 9 points.

"With less than three months before the primary, the race for New Hampshire's Democratic delegates is still in a great deal of flux," New Hampshire Institute of Politics Executive Director Neil Levesque noted.

The reputation of New Hampshire voters as late deciders was reflected in the survey. Thirteen percent of respondents said they remained undecided, and of those who were backing a candidate, only 36 percent said they were firm in their choices. If voters change their minds, Warren may benefit, as she topped the list for second choice, at 23 percent.

The poll's release came two and a half months before the Iowa caucuses, which kick off the presidential nominating calendar, followed eight days later by the New Hampshire primary. A Des Moines Register-CNN-Mediacom poll released this past Saturday indicated Buttigieg at 25 percent among likely Iowa Democratic presidential caucus-goers, with Warren at 16 percent, and Biden and Sanders at 15 percent. A Monmouth University survey also conducted earlier this month showed Buttigieg with a single-digit advantage over his top rivals in the Hawkeye State.

The Saint Anselm College Survey Center poll was conducted November 13-18, with 255 likely Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire questioned by live telephone operators. The survey's sampling of error was plus or minus 6.1 percentage points. The poll's release came days after former Gov. Deval Patrick, D-Mass., entered the presidential nomination race, with less than 1 percent support in the New Hampshire primary. The poll also indicated over three-quarters of those questioned said they would discourage former New York City mayor and billionaire business and media mogul Mike Bloomberg from launching a bid. Ninety-one percent said they would discourage 2016 presidential nominee Hillary Clinton from running again. However, more than four in ten said they would encourage former first lady Michelle Obama to run.

Title: Federal Reserve Leaves Door Open for Possible Additional Stimulus Measures

Article:

NEW YORK ( CNNMoney ) -- The Federal Reserve has left the possibility of additional stimulus measures on the table, with Chairman Ben Bernanke indicating that the central bank stands ready to take further action if the U.S. economy worsens.

During a press conference on Wednesday, Bernanke stated, "In case things get worse, we are prepared to protect the U.S. economy and financial system." This statement was interpreted by many as a sign that the Fed may consider a third round of asset purchases, known as quantitative easing (QE).

Ian Shepherdson, chief U.S. economist for High Frequency Economics, commented in a note to clients, "Mr. Bernanke's press conference surely left few doubts that the Fed will take more aggressive action and renew QE if the economy fails to perform as they expect."

Meanwhile, University of Pennsylvania Economist Justin Wolfers tweeted, "I read the Fed as saying: One more bad jobs report, and we'll do more."

The job market remains a top concern for Bernanke, with the unemployment rate still high at 8.2%. The latest jobs report showed employers added only 69,000 jobs in May, marking the weakest hiring in a year.

Bernanke also addressed Europe's financial crisis and the uncertainty surrounding the "fiscal cliff," which is dampening U.S. growth. (Read: Fiscal cliff: What you need to know)

In response to these concerns, the Fed extended its existing policy known as Operation Twist and lowered its expectations for the job market and the broader U.S. economy this year. The central bank predicts the unemployment rate will end the year between 8% and 8.2%. Just two months ago, it was more optimistic, predicting the jobless rate could fall as low as 7.8%.

The Fed also sees broader weakness ahead, predicting the economy will grow between 1.9% and 2.4% this year. In April, it had forecasted that the economy would grow as much as 2.9%. This weaker outlook prompted the Fed to extend Operation Twist by $267 billion.

The program swaps short-term bonds for ones with longer durations, thereby pushing interest rates lower on mortgages and business loans. The hope is that cheaper credit will reach consumers and businesses, who will then boost the economy by spending more. However, the effect on Main Street has been questionable, with mortgage rates at record lows but new home sales remaining choppy and banks still reluctant to lend to those with less-than-perfect credit. Small business owners are also struggling to secure loans.

Title: Chris Matthews Ties Texas Senator Ted Cruz and Second Amendment to Murders in Texas and Colorado

Article:

In a controversial statement on MSNBC's Hardball, host Chris Matthews linked Texas Senator Ted Cruz and the Second Amendment to the murders of prosecutors in Kaufman, Texas, and a prison guard in Colorado. The Media Research Center criticized Matthews for ignoring the criminal element of the prosecutor slayings and instead attributing the murders to individuals exercising their Second Amendment rights.

According to the Media Research Center, on March 30, the bodies of 23-year Army veteran and Kaufman County District Attorney Mike McLelland and his wife Cynthia were found in their home, victims of an apparent assassination. A national security expert suggested the murders were intended to send a message that no one is safe and that the killers are in control.

The Aryan Brotherhood, a violent prison gang, is suspected of being behind the murders in Kaufman County, Texas, and the killing of a top prison official in Colorado. The FBI has declassified 156 pages of internal documents that reveal the Aryan Brotherhood's history of engaging in brutal, high-profile killings to intimidate foreign narcotics cartels and other organized crime groups.

In response to the Kaufman County murders, county courthouses across Texas are implementing increased security measures, including more armed guards. Prosecutors in the Dallas area have also been urged to carry their own guns for self-protection against armed violent criminals.

The Media Research Center criticized Matthews for failing to discuss the criminal elements of the cases involving firearms and for smearing millions of law-abiding citizens in the process. The organization also noted that the Aryan Brotherhood does not care about gun control or votes on gun safety.

Title: New Jersey Middle School Teacher Reassigned After Kneeling During Pledge of Allegiance

Article: A teacher at Sgt. Dominick Pilla Middle School in New Jersey has been reassigned following incidents where the educator reportedly knelt during the school's recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance. The school is named after a U.S. Army Ranger who died during a 1993 mission in Somalia.

The teacher's actions sparked a heated debate among parents, who viewed the silent protest as inappropriate and agenda-driven for a middle school setting, according to the Philly Voice. Partisan political behavior is prohibited on school premises and during school hours, as noted by the Voice.

During a school board meeting of Vineland Public Schools in early October, parents expressed their concerns about the teacher's behavior. Resident Ron Maccri stated, "Teachers are paid to educate our students, they're not paid to indoctrinate our students. What this woman is doing would be bad in any school, but because it's in the (Sgt. Dominick Pilla) School — who gave his life for our military — it's reprehensible."

Another resident, Randy London, a U.S. Coast Guard veteran, also voiced his displeasure during the meeting. "That type of behavior offends me," London said. "I'm not saying anyone needs to agree with everything, but if that is the district's policy, there should be no teacher…taking a knee during the Pledge of Allegiance."

Lou Russo, president of the Vineland Education Association, suggested that students could learn from the teacher's missteps. "It would be one thing if [the teacher] was proselytizing to kids that you can't stand, or you should not stand for this reason, but she's not doing that," Russo insisted, pointing out that teachers themselves can not force students to stand for the pledge anyway.

On Tuesday, the district determined the teacher's fate, with Pilla school Principal Ismael Bermudez reassigning the teacher away from conducting homeroom. Joseph Rossi, the district's executive director of personnel, added, "Like all principals, Mr. Bermudez has the authority to utilize his building staff as appropriate."

Russo stated that the school deployed what they believe was a reasonable accommodation for the teacher. "It is a reasonable compromise that balances a school employee's free exercise of their religion versus a parent's concern of how that free exercise may influence their child," Russo said, noting that they have requested a legal opinion from their state affiliate and await its findings.

The teacher defended her First Amendment rights and insisted that her actions were not politically motivated, according to the Voice's reporting.

Title: Iran Confirms 18 Cases, Four Deaths of COVID-19 Coronavirus

Article:

A small outbreak of the COVID-19 coronavirus in Iran has been linked to cases in Canada and Lebanon, as well as a 45-year-old woman in Lebanon who traveled to the Middle Eastern nation. On February 20, Iran confirmed 13 new cases, bringing the total number of cases in the country to 18. Seven cases were diagnosed in Qom, four in Tehran, and two in Gilan.

World Health Organization (WHO) officials have expressed concern over the outbreak, with Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stating that the cases outside of China, although small in number, not linked to Wuhan or China, are "very worrisome." He added that the "dots are actually very concerning."

Tedros stated that the window of opportunity to contain the virus is still open but is narrowing, and action must be taken quickly before it closes completely. He also cautioned that the outbreak could still go in any direction.

Iran's health-care system has the "basic capacity" to detect and contain the coronavirus, according to Dr. Jaouad Mahjour, assistant director of emergency preparedness at WHO. However, world health officials remain concerned about the potential spread of the virus to countries with weaker health systems.

Outside of China, there are 1,152 cases across 26 countries, including eight deaths, according to Tedros. The respiratory disease is capable of spreading through human-to-human contact, droplets carried through sneezing and coughing, and germs left on inanimate objects.

Title: Federal Judge Halts Execution of Dementia-Suffering Inmate in Second Federal Execution This Week

Article:

TERRE HAUTE, Ind. (AP) — A federal judge on Wednesday halted the execution of a man, who is reportedly suffering from dementia, set to die by lethal injection in the federal government's second execution this week after a 17-year hiatus. Wesley Ira Purkey, convicted of a gruesome 1998 kidnapping and killing, was scheduled to die at the U.S. Penitentiary in Terre Haute, Indiana, where Daniel Lewis Lee was put to death Tuesday after his eleventh-hour legal bids failed.

U.S. District Judge Tanya Chutkan in Washington, D.C. imposed two injunctions prohibiting the federal Bureau of Prisons from moving forward with Purkey's execution, but the Justice Department immediately appealed. An appeals court panel kept in place both injunctions in orders Wednesday evening. Appeals to the Supreme Court were still pending.

The issue of Purkey's mental health arose in the runup to his 2003 trial and when jurors had to decide whether he should be put to death in the killing of 16-year-old Jennifer Long in Kansas City, Missouri. Prosecutors said he raped and stabbed her, dismembered her with a chainsaw, burned the body, and dumped her ashes in a pond in Kansas. Purkey was separately convicted and sentenced to life in the beating death of 80-year-old Mary Ruth Bales, of Kansas City, Kansas.

However, the legal questions of whether he was mentally fit then are different from whether he's fit now to be put to death. Purkey's lawyers argue he clearly isn't, saying in recent filings he suffers from advancing Alzheimer's disease.

The legal questions surrounding Purkey's case have been hashed, rehashed, and settled by courts over nearly two decades. "Competency is something that is always in flux," according to Robert Dunham, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, who teaches law school courses on capital punishment.

In a landmark 1986 decision, the Supreme Court ruled the Constitution prohibits executing someone who lacks a reasonable understanding of why he's being executed. It involved the case of Alvin Ford, who was convicted of murder but whose mental health deteriorated behind bars to the point, according to his lawyer, he believed he was pope.

Purkey's mental issues go beyond Alzheimer's, his lawyers have said. They say he was subject to sexual and mental abuse as a child and, at 14, was diagnosed with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depression, and psychosis.

Last week, three mental health organizations urged U.S. Attorney General William Barr to commute Purkey's sentence to life in prison without possibility of parole. The National Alliance on Mental Illness, Mental Health America, and the Treatment Advocacy Center said executing mentally ailing people like Purkey "constitutes cruel and unusual punishment and does not comport with 'evolving standards of decency.'"

The execution of Wesley Ira Purkey is now on hold, with the legal battle likely to continue into the evening. The fate of other scheduled executions, including Dustin Lee Honken, an Iowa drug kingpin, remains uncertain.

Title: Warren's Senate Campaign Ends in Debt Despite Record Fundraising

Article:

The Boston Globe reports that Massachusetts' newly elected Senator Elizabeth Warren ended her campaign in debt, despite raising a record-breaking $42 million for her Senate race this year, making her the most financially successful congressional candidate in the country. In an email to her supporters, Warren, a Harvard Law professor and prominent scholar of American debt, requested donations to help pay off the remaining campaign bills.

Warren did not disclose the exact amount of debt her campaign has accumulated, but attributed part of the shortfall to the thousands of volunteers who joined her campaign, stating that it led to increased last-minute expenses for coffee and pizza.

"One of the results of our embarrassment of riches was, well, I'll come out and say it - we ended up with a little bit of debt," Warren wrote. "Everyone, we need a little more money to pay off our final bills. Can you help one more time?"

While it is common for campaigns, even successful and well-funded ones, to end in debt, the disclosure is notable for Warren due to her extensive research on the roots of debt in American families and businesses.

"I know this was the most expensive Senate race in the country," Warren wrote. "And I know that we've sent you a bazillion emails asking for money over the past year. I'm sure you expected them to all end once the votes were counted - and yes, that's what I thought too. Right now, I'd rather be writing about filibuster reform and banking regulation. But we still have a little more to do to wrap things up. Can you help one more time to finish 2012 strong?"

Title: Ohio Polls Tighten as Romney Narrows Obama's Lead, Early Voting Factors into Discussion

Article:

The race for Ohio's electoral votes is tightening, but Mitt Romney does not hold a lead in any of the current Real Clear Politics average polls, with two polls showing a five-point lead for President Barack Obama. The Democratic advantage in party identification has increased across these polls, with an average increase from 5.5 to 6.5 points.

One reason for the increase in Democrats' share in the polls is early voting. If a pollster calls someone who says they have voted, they are automatically passed through the likely-voter screen since they have, after all, voted. However, as Gregory House famously stated, "Everybody lies." Pollsters can only work with the information their respondents provide, and this is the reason that likely-voter screens can be so tricky, though important, in polling.

In Ohio, where early in-person and absentee voting estimates show early turnout to be about 15 percent of voters, responses in the current polls claim that 23 percent of registered voters have already voted. This means that polls are overstating early voting by eight percentage points on average. This could be due to some voters having requested an absentee ballot and reporting that as voting, some having mailed in ballots that haven't been counted yet, or some voters simply lying about having voted when they haven't.

In the polls' early-voting results, Obama leads on average by 20 points. However, it is unclear how much the Democratic advantage in this category has shrunk from 2008. Obama's early-voting advantage gives him a lead that Romney is only slowly chipping away at with his Election Day voter lead. But if pollsters are finding more respondents who are claiming to have already voted than what the records show, some of this early-voter advantage is illusory.

Romney's strength with independents and crossover voters, as well as historical trends in Ohio, suggest that he is in a strong position to win the state on Election Day. Romney leads among independents by an average of 12.3 points, up from 8.7 points last week. In the last nine elections, the GOP has outperformed in Ohio, and with Romney currently running just ahead of Obama nationally, it seems more likely that Obama's lead in Ohio has more to do with the higher party-ID advantage than a dramatic shift in Ohio from the past nine elections.

In addition to Romney's strength with independents, in the past two elections, the GOP candidate has won over more Democrat votes than they've lost Republican ones. Obama's Ohio win in 2008 was based entirely on his strength with independents and the wave turnout, both of which are highly unlikely to be repeated in 2012. If Romney wins with independents by anywhere near the current average and takes more crossover voters than Obama does, Obama would need to exceed 2008 turnout greatly to win.

With less than two weeks until Election Day, it is important to remember that the picture for Romney in Ohio is better than many pundits would have us believe. Romney's rallies are a reminder that it's not 2008 anymore, as Republicans have reclaimed the enthusiasm advantage that led to such sweeping 2008 victories for Democrats. That GOP enthusiasm has become contagious since the debates, and it is exactly what has Team Obama so afraid these days. All they have left to hang their hopes on is a slim lead in the polls, and even that might not be enough on Election Day.

Josh Jordan, a small-business market-research consultant, wrote this article. You can follow him on Twitter @ Numbersmuncher.

Title: House Republicans Predicted to Pass Funding Bill Before Government Shutdown

Article:

In the final hours before a vote, House Republicans are optimistic about passing their $1.1 trillion, nine-month government funding bill before a potential government shutdown on Thursday. According to top aides and lawmakers on the GOP whip team, between 150 and 175 Republicans are expected to support the bill. Senior House Democrats predict some of their members will help make up for Republican defections to get the bill across the finish line.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) and his staff have been in contact with Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) throughout the process, despite Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's (D-Calif.) public proclamation that Democrats were worried about provisions tucked into the bill that would loosen Wall Street regulations and campaign finance laws.

The deal to jack up donation limits to national party committees was negotiated by top aides to a leading Democrat and Republican: Speaker John Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid. If the larger funding package falls apart, Speaker Boehner will put a three-month stop-gap spending bill on the floor to set up a fiscal fight next year when Republicans have control of both chambers.

As of late Wednesday evening, Republicans were not formally making fallback plans if the bill failed, and House Democrats weren't formally whipping against the measure. House Democratic leadership plans to meet Thursday morning ahead of the vote. The government will begin to shut down by Friday morning if nothing passes. Almost no one expects a shutdown.

Lawmakers are angry that they only had one full day to read a 1,600-page spending bill that extends all government funding through September 2015, and Homeland Security funding through February. When lawmakers started digging into the bill, they found a provision that helps big banks trade derivatives in units backstopped by a government guarantee. Another last-minute addition would allow all national party committees to collect $777,000 each year from individuals, up from $32,400 annually under current law.

High-profile lawmakers like Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) vowed to vote against the bill, backed by progressive groups on the outside who were seizing on Pelosi's (D-Calif.) skepticism. Republicans were already worried that the legislation doesn't pick a strong enough fight with Obama over his unilateral changes to immigration law – a few conservative members like Rep. Louie Gohmert of Texas and Rep. Tom McClintock of California privately questioned the strategy.

Speaker Boehner also faced criticism for breaking one of his central 2010 campaign promises: that he would advance legislative issues one at a time. "All these provisions in this bill got worked out in a bipartisan bicameral fashion or they wouldn't be in the bill," the speaker said. Boehner added, "When you get to the end of a two-year session of Congress, a lot of work gets built up and never gets to cross one floor or the other floor. And as a result, when we get to the end of session, members try to find a way to get their legislation across the finish line because of not really issues on the House side, more issues on the Senate side, to facilitate their ability to move legislation, some of the stuff ends up in one bill."

The mood was tense in the Capitol Wednesday when GOP leaders started whipping the bill, and Senate Democrats were unsure how many of their House counterparts would vote for the bill. But Pelosi and Boehner have been in close contact. On Wednesday morning when they spoke, Boehner demurred when Pelosi asked how many Democratic votes he needed. That responsibility falls to House Majority Whip Steve Scalise of Louisiana, Boehner answered. Boehner warned Pelosi that if the large bill failed, he would have a short-term funding bill ready for immediate consideration.

If Republican defections swell, Scalise could catch blame, but if the GOP posts better-than-expected numbers, he'll start off the 114th Congress with a stronger hand. Pelosi is trying to regain her own strong hand, which has been weakened dramatically by her party's disastrous showing on Election Day. She was involved in the negotiations, but objected to many of the last-minute additions to the package - and is using the situation to boost her sway with disaffected Democrats. Pelosi believes she can get Republicans to change the bill, but GOP leadership staff has repeatedly made clear that they will not change the omnibus.

Republicans have one victory in this lame duck: they cleared a renewal of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act by a huge margin. The GOP leadership had hoped to include this legislation in the omnibus, but House Financial Services Chairman Jeb Hensarling (R-Texas) insisted the TRIA extension include unrelated changes to the Dodd-Frank financial services law. Democrats protested, but the bill passed with 417 votes.

Title: Vice Presidential Debate: Mike Pence Outshines Tim Kaine in Debate on Substance and Mannerism

Article:

The vice presidential debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine on Tuesday night exposed the stark contrast between the two candidates, with Pence appearing as a statesman and Kaine as a partisan hack. The debate, moderated by Elaine Quijano, exposed the depths of the Hillary campaign's "demagogic cheapness" as Kaine repeatedly interrupted Pence and rattled off opposition research.

Pence, speaking slowly and authoritatively, reiterated basic points about Hillary Clinton's tax-and-spend policies and her feckless foreign policy. He deftly answered the litany of accusations against Donald Trump by noting that Kaine was indulging in the very "insult-driven campaign" he pretended to find so shocking in Trump.

Kaine devoted most of his energy to rattling off his opposition research, much of it too insiderish and transparently canned to impress anyone. Pence, on the other hand, looked directly at the camera and reiterated basic points about Clinton's policies.

One of the most notable moments of the debate came when Pence noted that Clinton had called much of the country a "basket of deplorables." Kaine's response, claiming Trump cared more about his tax returns than the troops, was met with a shake of Pence's head in disbelief.

Pence's calm demeanor and ability to re-direct the debate back to serious issues was a stark contrast to Kaine's irritated and short-circuiting performance. Pence's thoughtful discussion of adoption and the sanctity of life also made Kaine's partisan gibbering look ignoble.

During several exchanges, Pence turned what Kaine and Clinton consider strengths into weaknesses. For example, when Kaine launched into a windy attack on Putin and a tendentious description of Trump's admiration for him, Pence simply drew attention to Clinton's disastrously ineffective "reset" with Putin.

In debates, less is more, as Pence showed. Against a flailing, gabbing, and demagogic opponent, it is better to step back and let the audience see that the person who talks the most often says the least. Come Sunday, Trump would do well to imitate his running mate.

Title: Bipartisan Collaboration in U.S. Politics: A Look at Cross-Aisle Efforts and the Importance of Bipartisanship

Article:

In the midst of political division, a group of Republicans and Democrats, former administration officials, and individuals from various industries outside of Washington, D.C., are collaborating to advance the nation's work, despite the partisan rhetoric that dominates Pennsylvania Avenue. This core group, which includes a registered Republican who has served four presidents, including one Democrat, and who partnered with Michelle Obama's office on the Let's Move anti-obesity campaign, emphasizes the importance of finding common ground and focusing on areas of agreement.

The individual, who has created a 60/40 rule for collaboration, agrees with someone on 60% of the issues and focuses on the areas of agreement, setting aside the 40% of differences. This approach is not unique among those who align with one political party but find ways to work with the other.

In 2009, 16 CEOs from consumer goods companies joined the Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation, implementing the largest voluntary food and beverage industry marketplace initiative, which ultimately removed 6.4 trillion calories from the American diet by reducing the sugar and fat content of hundreds of products. In 2005, as U.S. Commissioner General, the individual worked alongside governors from both parties and the private sector to launch the US Pavilion at the Aichi World EXPO.

Similar bipartisan efforts are ongoing in various bipartisan commissions and blue-ribbon panels addressing issues such as Social Security, biodefenses, tax reform, and the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. These collaborative efforts, which focus on personal consideration, listening, and respect, succeed because the end goal is what matters, not party ideology.

The principles of bipartisanship, which are common in many areas beyond politics, emphasize personal consideration, listening, and respect. These collaborative efforts, which focus on fixing problems and finding new paths, are alive and in need of further nurturing. The individual notes that the shouting on cable TV and the blogosphere is not the whole picture and that bipartisanship is not dead but in need of further nurturing.

Title: Michelle Obama Makes Surprise Appearance at the 2013 Oscars to Announce Best Picture Winner

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events at the 2013 Academy Awards, First Lady Michelle Obama made a surprise appearance via satellite from the Governors' Ball in Washington, D.C., to announce the Best Picture winner. The event, which was hosted by Jack Nicholson, was marked by Obama's introduction of the nominees and the eventual announcement of the winner, Argo.

"These nine movies took us back in time and all around the world," Obama said. "They made us laugh, they made us weep, and they made us grip our armrests just a little tighter." She continued, "They taught us that love can endure against all odds and transform our lives in the most surprising ways, and they reminded us that we can overcome any obstacle if we can dig deep enough and fight hard enough and find the courage to believe in ourselves."

After handing Nicholson an envelope to announce the winner, Obama said, "Hang on a second," before making the announcement. The tweet, "@pfro, "I love how Michelle Obama was all like: oh, sorry, I was just hangin' with some US servicemen, hold on a sec - lem me present at the #oscars," captured the moment.

The appearance of Michelle Obama at the Oscars received mixed reactions on social media. Some tweets praised her for her performance, such as "@juliweiner's "Daniel Day Lewis’s Michelle Obama is GOOD." However, others criticized her for what they perceived as too many celebrity-laden appearances, with tweets like "@daveweigel's "Having Nicholson introduce Michelle Obama probably spared us from the ultimate McFarlane sexist joke #Oscars."

Some tweets expressed disapproval of Obama's appearance at the Oscars, with comments like "@davidplotz's "Michelle Obama is doing WAY too many cameos. Bad memories of Nancy Reagan on Mr. T's lap." Others criticized the decision to have Obama present at the Oscars, with tweets like "@abenedikt's "MIchelle Obama jumps the shark."

Despite the backlash, Obama seemed to enjoy her appearance at the Oscars, tweeting, "@FLOTUS's "It was a thrill to announce the #Oscars2013 best picture winner from the @whitehouse! Congratulations Argo!" This article is from the archive of our partner The Wire.

Title: Reflections on Easter Amidst Political and Social Divisions

Article:

In the midst of a politically and socially divisive year, some individuals find solace in the celebration of Easter, a Christian holiday symbolizing renewal and resurrection. The world, it seems, is more divided than ever, with societal fault lines along race, gender, class, immigration status, religion, sexual orientation, and more, causing a series of tremors that permeate daily life.

The actions and rhetoric of the current administration have become a rhythm for many, whether they support or oppose the leader. Each outburst generates a response, either a cheer or an outcry, creating a shifting tide of energy that ebbs and flows.

As the nation moves towards a self-centered, self-interested future, questions arise about the ability to care for the less fortunate, protect refugees, and value all lives equally. Boundaries are being drawn, and fortified walls are being erected to safeguard the "we" that is being narrowly defined.

This period is marked by a turning-in and turning-on, a shift back to a time when the nation was divided and fractured. In the midst of this tumult, some find Easter - a moment of respite amidst raw, natural times.

The story of Easter revolves around a faultless man who absorbs the faults of others, a hated man who refuses to retaliate against scorn, and a man who sacrifices himself for the good of the world, bringing others life through his embrace and defeat of death. The scriptures that tell this story are jarring when juxtaposed against the values of the current era:

"For God so loved the world that he gave his only son..."
"...while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us..."

The question remains: can we ever become an Easter people? What event or circumstance will bring about a return to grace and make us whole again or perhaps whole for the first time?

It is unclear what it will take to provoke such a transformation - an election, a disaster, new leadership, or cataclysmic loss. The resistance may need to reach its pinnacle, or the current leader may need to hit his penitential floor. Alternatively, the change may not be about them or him, but rather a collective internal transformation that feels like national atonement.

Imagining such a future is challenging, especially when warships are moving and MOABs are exploding, and the next breaking news report or fiery tweet is always imminent. Yet, there is no hope as hopeful as the sunshine on a Sunday morning, and no day as dream-worthy as Resurrection Day.

On such a day, perhaps we will catch a glimmer of a different future, bright enough to light a path that helps us get there. And maybe once we see it, we will take a step - towards Easter.

Title: Donald Trump's Refusal to Commit to Accepting Election Results Sparks Controversy

Article:

In the aftermath of the latest presidential debate, the focus has been on Donald Trump's refusal to commit to accepting the election results, a stance that has been met with criticism and concern. The Republican nominee's statement, while controversial, is consistent with his efforts this month to question the integrity of the democratic process.

Trump's reluctance to accept the election results, despite the potential consequences, is attributed to his personality traits, particularly his narcissism and inability to accept defeat. The debate performance, which has been widely criticized, underscores Trump's unstable and disordered personality, a weakness that has been a recurring theme throughout the campaign.

Trump's obsession with polls and his fear of being labeled a loser has led him to manufacture excuses for his potential defeat, with the claim of a rigged election being the most recent example. This claim, which undermines a nearly sacred democratic rule, not only risks his chances of winning but could also widen the margin of his potential defeat.

The American public's reaction to Trump has been largely negative, with many viewing him as a radical and destabilizing force rather than an agent of change. His narcissism, particularly his inability to accept that he may lose to a woman in the presidential race, has been a significant factor in his debate performance and other controversial moments during the campaign.

Peter Wehner, a contributing opinion writer who served in the last three Republican administrations, noted that Trump's egotism and self-obsession are unlike anything seen in American political life. This character flaw has led to several detrimental moments during the election, including his inability to cite a favorite Bible passage earlier in the campaign and his response about not being prepared to say he would abide by the election results in the debate.

Wehner cited a Bible passage, "Pride goes before destruction, a haughty spirit before a fall," as a foreshadowing of Trump's fate. The passage underscores the potential consequences of unchecked pride and self-obsession in political leadership.

Title: Fauci Disputes Concept of Second Wave of Covid-19 Cases in the US

Article:

Dr. Anthony Fauci, a leading US public health expert and member of the White House coronavirus taskforce, has stated that the US may not experience a "second wave" of Covid-19 cases. The US has reported over 2 million cases of Covid-19 and nearly 115,000 deaths, according to researchers at Johns Hopkins University in Maryland.

Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told CNN on Friday that increases in cases in several states are not necessarily indicative of a "second spike" of infections. He emphasized that an increase in hospitalizations is a cause for concern and requires close attention.

The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that close to 80% of Americans self-isolated in the last month and 74% wore face coverings in public either always or often. Residents of New York and Los Angeles self-isolated and wore face coverings about 90% of the time.

In the past week, 19 states, including Texas, South Carolina, Utah, Arizona, North Carolina, Arkansas, Alabama, Oregon, California, Nevada, and Florida, have reported seven-day rolling average highs for new Covid-19 infections. In Arkansas, Governor Asa Hutchinson, a Republican, announced a record number of cases in the previous 24 hours. In Oregon, Governor Kate Brown, a Democrat, placed a seven-day hold on lifting or loosening social restrictions. In Maryland, Baltimore announced it would not be moving into phase two of planned reopening.

Some experts have become more optimistic that a vaccine for Covid-19 can be developed swiftly. However, they caution that this does not guarantee the speed, safety, and durability of the vaccine. In New York City, mass protests have sparked fears of a resurgence of the virus, but new infections are now at the lowest level in the entire US. New York's governor, Andrew Cuomo, stated that the state was the "No 1 state in terms of infection" but is now the "last state in terms of rate of transmission."

The CDC could not confirm reports of striking increases in coronavirus hospitalizations but would monitor the numbers "very closely." Such developments sent stock markets into a tailspin on Thursday, before a slight recovery on Friday.

Title: Ted Cruz Raises $20 Million in Three Months Ahead of Iowa Caucus

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz has reportedly raised nearly $20 million in the past three months, according to an internal memo obtained by NBC News. This significant fundraising haul comes as the Iowa caucus approaches in the final month.

A campaign aide told NBC News, "We're showing we have the strength going into the Iowa caucus. If people want to get behind a candidate who can go the distance, we're showing we've got that."

The $20 million raised in the third quarter surpasses the $12.2 million Cruz brought in during the previous quarter, bringing his total yearly fundraising to $45 million. In the same timeframe, rival candidate Ben Carson, who was then a rising contender in polling, also raised a similar $20 million, while Marco Rubio brought in $6 million.

Cruz is the first candidate to report their fundraising totals for this quarter, which technically ends on Thursday. At the beginning of October, Cruz's campaign had the most cash on hand—$13.8 million—but it has yet to publicly release its current cash holdings.

The substantial fundraising by Cruz, who often emphasizes on the campaign trail that his campaign is built to last, is mirrored by hefty fundraising by several super PACs supporting his candidacy. Through September, the super PACs had raised $38 million, with the organizations spending little of that money to date.

The additional funds provide Cruz with expanded resources to potentially buy advertising in the upcoming early states. However, through the summer and fall, the campaign resisted spending on traditional television and radio advertising, putting in less than $1 million so far. The campaign has yet to reveal its advertising plan, stating it will buy television airtime on a week-to-week basis.

Title: New York Coronavirus Cases Surge Past 11,600 as Statewide Lockdown Looms

Article:

New York state reported over 4,500 new coronavirus cases on Saturday, pushing the statewide total to 11,600. New York City, the epicenter of the nation's COVID-19 crisis, accounted for the majority of the increase, with more than 2,400 new cases reported, raising the total number of infected in the city to 8,115. The virus claimed at least 15 more lives in the city on Saturday, bringing the death toll to 60.

Governor Andrew Cuomo announced plans to purchase 6,000 new ventilators and two million N95 masks in response to the mounting crisis. One million masks will be sent to health care responders in the city, and 500,000 will go to Long Island. Hospitals statewide have been directed to end elective surgeries and alter their space and staffing to accommodate the influx of infected patients.

New York is also considering four possible locations for temporary "field hospitals" to be set up by the Army Corps of Engineers and operated with FEMA assistance. The four sites being considered are the city's Javits Center, SUNY Stony Brook, SUNY Westbury, and the Westchester Convention Center. The Javits Center could be converted into a 1,000-patient hospital in the next few days.

The number of cases in Westchester, where the state's first major outbreak was located, is slowing, according to Governor Cuomo. However, there were at least 294 cases there as of Saturday. In New Jersey, the sick tally rose to 1,327 on Saturday, with 16 deaths. Both Governor Phil Murphy and Governor Cuomo attributed their states' increases in reported infections to increased testing.

A statewide lockdown is set to take effect 8 p.m. Sunday night, setting tight limits on shopping, work, and recreation to minimize close contact and prevent a healthcare-system-crippling spike in cases. The lockdown will force the shutdown of most of the state's businesses, with the exception of grocery stores and bodegas, liquor stores, gas stations, laundromats, and restaurant delivery services. The city has appointed a "Food Czar," Kathryn Garcia, to ensure no one goes hungry. Those lucky enough to still be working in "non-essential" businesses must do so from home, and exercising outdoors is limited to solitary, non-team endeavors such as walking, biking, and running.

Title: Bloomberg Poll Shows Obama Leading Romney by 13 Points Among Likely Voters

Article:

According to a recent Bloomberg poll, President Barack Obama is leading his Republican opponent, Mitt Romney, by 13 points among likely voters. The poll, conducted from June 15-18, shows Obama with 53 percent of the vote, while Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, has 40 percent.

The poll indicates that Romney has yet to repair the damage to his image during the Republican primary. Thirty-nine percent of Americans view him favorably, which is about the same as when he announced his presidential candidacy last June. In contrast, 48 percent see him unfavorably, a 17-percentage point increase during the nomination fight marked by attack ads.

The survey also reveals that a majority of likely voters, 55 percent, view Romney as more out of touch with average Americans compared with 36 percent who say the same about President Obama.

The poll sample is skewed, but the survey results can be viewed from another perspective. Questions to consider include:

1. Do you believe Obama's popularity is twice as high as it was in 2008 (when Obama won by roughly 6.5 points)? This poll suggests it is.
2. How has Obama gained 13 points since Bloomberg's March poll, which had the race tied at 47?
3. Does Bloomberg have a better grasp on this race than Rasmussen and Gallup, both of which show Romney ahead today by identical 47-45 margins?
4. Does Barack Obama have a commanding lead nationally, despite being tied or down in new polls from Michigan and Iowa - both states he won by double digits last time?
5. If Barack Obama is cruising to a decisive victory, why is an expanding pool of elected Democrats choosing to jump ship from the Democratic National Convention, where Obama will be re-nominated?
6. How large would Obama's lead be if he had not just experienced a solid month of failed attacks, exploded narratives, party defections, botched events, inadvertent tells, and dreadful economic news?

It is worth noting that the economic numbers are being revised downward today, and there is a possibility that the U.S. could cross back into negative job growth this month.

Title: Sen. John McCain Criticizes President Obama's Foreign Policy on CNN's "State of the Union"

Article:

In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, Senator John McCain (R-AZ) criticized President Barack Obama's foreign policy, stating that it has contributed to the "unraveling of the world order that was established after World War II."

Regarding President Obama's response to Russian hacking, McCain expressed concern over the perceived lack of a clear strategy or policy. He called for a select committee to investigate the cyber attacks, particularly their potential impact on the American election.

McCain asserted, "We need to get to the bottom of this. We need to find out exactly what was done and what the implications of the attacks were, especially if they had an effect on our election." He also questioned the effectiveness of President Obama's response to Russian hacking, stating, "I'm sure that when Vladimir Putin was told 'cut it out,' unquote, I'm sure that Vladimir Putin immediately stopped all cyber activity."

McCain further expressed concern over the increasing cyber attacks on various aspects of American life, stating, "We have no strategy, nor do we have any policy towards that, and it's very disturbing."

In addition, McCain linked the current geopolitical situation to a lack of American leadership, stating, "What's happening here when we see the seizure of these ships, when we see the cyber attacks, when we see the dismemberment of Syria, when we see the tragedies that are taking place there which are heartbreaking, actually heartbreaking while we sat by and watched all this happen, this is a sign of a possible unraveling of the world order that was established after World War II."

McCain concluded by emphasizing the importance of American leadership in maintaining global peace, stating, "We're starting to see that, the strains and unraveling of it, and that's because of an absolute failure of American leadership. When America doesn't lead, a lot of other bad people do, and that's why we're seeing this slaughter in Aleppo that breaks your heart."

Title: Doug Jones Expresses Concerns Over Witnesses and Evidence in Impeachment Trial

Article:

Democrat Doug Jones, the current senator of Alabama, has expressed concerns over the lack of witnesses and evidence in the ongoing impeachment trial of President Donald Trump. In an interview with ABC's The Week, Jones criticized the "gaps in testimony" and called for a "full, fair, and complete trial."

Jones argued that the Senate needs to interview witnesses and receive documents to provide a comprehensive understanding of the impeachment case. He stated, "It means witnesses, it means documents, it means getting the information out now, in this very serious matter, and not over the course of the next few months."

The Democrats have charged President Trump with "obstruction of Congress" for directing "the unprecedented, categorical, and indiscriminate defiance of subpoenas" in the buildup to impeachment. The White House is currently embroiled in a legal battle over Congressional subpoenas.

Sen. Doug Jones attributed the lack of evidence to President Trump's refusal to allow his associates to testify and deliver documents. He said, "I would like to see a full and complete picture. And we don't have that because the president has refused to have his people come and testify and deliver documents."

However, Jones also indicated that he could oppose impeachment if the evidence does not support Trump's removal. He stated, "If those dots aren't connected and there are other explanations that I think are consistent with innocence, I will go that way too."

In a recent poll regarding the Alabama Senate race, Jones trails former Attorney General Jeff Sessions, former Auburn head football coach Tommy Tuberville, and Representative Bradley Byrne. Only 23 percent of those surveyed favored Jones's reelection. Among voters 65 and older, the largest age cohort in the poll, 31 percent favored Jones's reelection, while 54 did not.

When asked whether his reelection concerns were affecting his vote, Jones denied making a political calculation. He said, "This has to do with the future of the presidency, and how we want our presidents to conduct themselves." Jones concluded, "If I did everything based on a pure and political argument, all you'd need is a computer to mash a button."

Title: Rubio Questions Significant Impact of Tax Overhaul on American Workers

Article:

WASHINGTON - Republican U.S. Senator Marco Rubio has cast doubt on the recent tax overhaul's impact on American workers, potentially undermining his party's message ahead of the 2018 midterm elections. In an interview with The Economist magazine, Rubio stated there is "no evidence whatsoever" the law has significantly benefited American workers.

The tax overhaul, which passed through the Republican-controlled U.S. Congress in December without Democratic support, permanently reduced the top corporate rate to 21 percent from 35 percent. However, tax cuts for individuals are temporary and expire after 2025.

Republicans, including President Donald Trump, have maintained their tax overhaul will result in increased take-home pay for workers and have pointed to bonuses some workers received from their employers as evidence the law is effective. Rubio, who voted for the proposal despite advocating for a larger child tax credit, had lobbied party leaders for this provision.

In response to Rubio's comments, Olivia Perez-Cubas, Rubio's spokeswoman, stated, "Senator Rubio pushed for a better balance in the tax law between tax cuts for big businesses and families, as he’s done for years. As he said when the tax law passed, cutting the corporate tax rate will make America a more competitive place to do business, but he tried to balance that with an even larger child tax credit for working Americans."

The tax law serves as the only significant legislative achievement for Republicans since President Trump took office, as they approach the midterms, during which all 435 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives and about a third of the 100-member Senate's seats are being contested.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projected earlier this month that the tax bill, as written, would add $1.9 trillion to the national debt over the next decade.

Title: Obama's Middle East Policy Shift and the Egyptian Crisis

Article:

In May 2011, President Barack Obama announced a significant reorientation of American policy in the Middle East during a speech at the State Department. The traditional American interests, which included regional stability, countering terrorism, nuclear proliferation, and ensuring the free flow of oil and commerce, often led to alliances with authoritarian regimes.

The president emphasized that the events of the Arab Spring, particularly in Egypt, Tunisia, and Libya, demonstrated the need for a shift in strategy. He stated, "Strategies of repression and strategies of diversion will not work anymore." The president's new "core principles" included supporting universal rights, encouraging political and economic reforms, and opposing violence and oppression.

The president emphasized that these principles were not secondary but a top priority, stating, "Our support for these principles is not a secondary interest. Today I want to make it clear that it is a top priority that must be translated into concrete actions and supported by all of the diplomatic, economic, and strategic tools at our disposal."

However, in the ensuing two years, particularly in the eight weeks since the Egyptian military's coup, the Obama administration has faced criticism for its response to the Egyptian crisis. Critics argue that the U.S. has appeared cautious, timid, indecisive, reactive, and shortsighted, struggling to balance its professed commitment to change with the fear of chaos.

Vali Nasr, a critic of the administration from the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, suggests that U.S. policy may, intentionally or not, be returning to a pre-Arab Spring, Islamophobic, order-at-all-costs policy, aligning the U.S. with countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia.

This shift in policy and the U.S.'s perceived response to the Egyptian crisis has raised questions about the U.S.'s influence and commitment to the principles outlined by President Obama in 2011. Critics argue that the Egyptian military's actions, including the murder of civilians, and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's continued use of chemical weapons against his own people, demonstrate a lack of credibility in the U.S.'s stance against violence and oppression.

Title: Obama Administration Designates ISIS Atrocities Against Christians and Minorities as Genocide

Article:

The Obama administration's decision to label ISIS's atrocities against Christians and other minorities as genocide is a significant step, but many warn that it is only the beginning of a lengthy process. In a statement, Secretary of State John Kerry declared, "In my judgment, Daesh is responsible for genocide against groups in territory under its control."

The genocide designation is a critical first step towards safeguarding Christians from ISIS and other Islamic extremists in Iraq and Syria. Johnnie Moore, author of the book Defying ISIS, stated, "Every jihadist in the Middle East believes they can kill, kidnap, enslave, and otherwise torture Christians and other religious minorities, and they believe they can do it without repercussions."

In northern Iraq, Assyrian Christians, an ancient people descended from the first followers of Christ, are facing extinction. Juliana Taimoorazy, founder and president of the Iraqi Christian Relief Council, warned, "As Assyrians of the Middle East, we are on the verge of extinction." Taimoorazy recently visited Telskuf in the Nineveh Plains of Iraq, where 200,000 Christians have fled from ISIS. She described the devastation, stating, "The homes are destroyed when you walk inside. Their closets are all broken, the beds are all overturned - the kitchens are destroyed."

Secretary Kerry's genocide designation aims to keep the plight of these Christians at the forefront of U.S. foreign policy. Advocates are already working with the State Department to ensure Christians are represented in Syrian peace talks and that property rights for those forced to flee their homes in Iraq are enforced.

Nina Shea, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, stated, "There are going to be borders redrawn, constitutions redrafted." She emphasized, "It's absolutely essential that the Christians have a voice in this process or they will have no place in the new Syria or in the new Iraq."

An effort is already underway to create a safe haven in the Nineveh Plains so that Christians, Yazidis, and other minorities can return home, govern themselves, and rebuild their lives without fear of extermination. Robert Nicholson, executive director of the Philos Project, stated, "If you care about the presence of Christianity, the Christian witness, in this very Gospel-poor part of the world, you will support the idea of a safe haven."

Despite the horrors they have experienced at the hands of ISIS, Christians in this region are experiencing a revival of their faith. Taimoorazy shared, "They have told me repeatedly it's because of persecution that has been inflicted on them that they have grown closer to Christ, that they find themselves praying more, that they're thirsty for the Gospel more."

Now, the same advocates who pushed for the genocide designation are moving to maintain the pressure, hoping to ensure the Obama administration not only talks but acts to protect those persecuted Christians and other religious minorities. They aim to make real progress before the next administration takes office.

Title: Romney Defends Campaign Strategy Amidst Conservative Criticism, Denies Writing Off Half of Voters

Article:

In a recent interview with CBS News, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney defended his campaign strategy, stating that it is "doing a very good job" despite criticism from some conservative thought leaders. The interview followed the release of a video from a secretly recorded fundraiser held by Romney last spring, in which he described 47% of the electorate as viewing themselves as victims, dependent upon government services, and likely to vote for President Barack Obama.

Romney's campaign responded aggressively to the comments, with the candidate holding a press conference hours after the comments emerged. However, the comments, Romney's response, and his criticism of Obama over violence in the Arab world in the previous week have fueled a narrative advanced by some conservative thought leaders.

Peggy Noonan, a conservative columnist whose work appears in The Wall Street Journal, described Romney's campaign as "incompetent" this week. In a Thursday column, Noonan stood by her comments, stating, "I really meant 'rolling calamity.'" Bill Kristol, editor of the conservative publication The Weekly Standard, likened Barack Obama and Mitt Romney as "two presidential candidates who - when they thought they were speaking privately to their fellow 1 percenters - have shown contempt for fellow Americans."

In the CBS interview, Romney pushed back against charges that his 47% comment meant he was writing off nearly half of the country. "I want to make it very clear, I want to help 100 percent of the American people," he said, echoing a new line he debuted on the campaign trail this week after the fundraiser video emerged.

When asked if his skills in turning around businesses, a reputation which he and his supporters tout, were needed for his campaign, Romney said, "My campaign doesn't need a turnaround."

Romney also pushed back on recent national and battleground state polling which appears to give Obama a slight edge over Romney, either within or just outside of the sampling error for each survey. "We've got a campaign which is tied with an incumbent president to the United States," Romney said.

In addition, Romney announced plans to ramp up his campaign schedule with a bus tour, starting in Ohio on Friday. The tour will cover several battleground states, including Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, and Iowa. The tour is intended to help Romney connect with voters and address concerns about the economy and jobs.

Title: Shift in Strategy: Republicans and Allies Broadening Focus Beyond Obamacare Repeal

Article:

Recent polling and political strategies suggest that the Republican Party and like-minded groups may be moving away from a singular focus on repealing the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare. The shift in strategy is becoming increasingly evident as the 2014 midterm elections approach.

In March, Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, who is in a reelection bid against Democrat Alison Lundergan Grimes, stated that while he wants to repeal the law, Kentucky's version, Kynect, is "unconnected" to the fate of Obamacare. Kynect, which provides insurance coverage to over 413,000 people, was created under the Affordable Care Act and is primarily funded through federal funds.

McConnell's stance is a shift from his primary campaign, where he took a hard-line stance on getting rid of Obamacare. Similarly, Americans for Prosperity (AFP), an organization expected to spend over $100 million this election cycle backing issues that Republicans favor, has also broadened its scope.

In the lead-up to the launch of Obamacare last fall, AFP had a laser-like focus on the issue, spending millions of dollars in states and districts where Democrats are vulnerable. However, the organization's website now features a campaign against the Export-Import Bank, which is not related to Obamacare. Additionally, an ad airing in Louisiana, where Democratic Sen. Mary Landrieu is locked in a tight reelection race, attacks her for "wasteful government spending," with no mention of Obamacare.

AFP's partner group, AFP Foundation, launched an $850,000 ad buy in Wisconsin earlier this week that focuses on taxes and does not mention Obamacare. AFP spokesman Levi Russell stated, "We're responding to the changing environment. That initial shock (of Obamacare) has changed a little bit, but it has not gone away."

Republicans are now retooling their message, having emerged from primary battles of who's farther to the right. They must now try to appeal to a more diverse audience that has become more accepting of the federal health care program approved in 2010 without Republican support.

According to a recent CNN poll, 38% of people want to either replace the law or get rid of it. This is a significant decrease from a November poll that found 43% of respondents wanted the law repealed. Elizabeth Wilner with the Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan polling group, wrote that Republicans are starting to use the word "fix" in their campaigning instead of "repeal."

Since Republicans gained control of the House in 2011, they have voted more than 50 times on a full or partial repeal of the health care law. However, the pace has fallen off dramatically in recent months. This shift in strategy may indicate a recognition that a singular focus on Obamacare repeal may not be as effective in the current political climate.

Title: Trump Administration Reaches Deal with ZTE, Over Congressional Objections

Article:

The Trump administration has finalized a deal with Chinese tech giant ZTE, as announced by Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on Thursday. The agreement, according to Ross, concludes the phase of negotiations with the company, which had been subject to crippling penalties for its previous evasion of sanctions against North Korea and Iran.

Under the terms of the agreement, ZTE will pay a $1 billion fine, replace its management, and submit to oversight from the U.S. Commerce Department. Ross stated, "We are literally embedding a compliance department of our choosing into the company to monitor it going forward. They will pay for those people, but the people will report to the new chairman because we are also having them replace the entire management and the entire board."

President Trump had instructed Ross to look into easing restrictions on ZTE following a personal request from Chinese President Xi Jinping. Ross described the deal as a victory, stating that the previous strict actions had "brought... a $17 billion company to its knees, more or less put them out of business," and that the new agreement is "something I think even more effective."

Ross warned that if the company fails to comply with the new agreement, strict punishment will be enforced. "Now, if they do violate it again, in addition to the billion dollars they're paying us right up front, we have them put $400 million in escrow so the total deal is a billion 400 million," Ross said.

Many in Congress, both Republicans and Democrats, have strongly opposed the president's handling of the ZTE matter, with Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer tweeting, "The deal with ZTE proves the president just shoots blanks." Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a leading GOP critic, tweeted, "This deal will do nothing to keep us safe from corporate and national security espionage."

Title: Media Errors Plague 2017 Reporting on Trump-Russia Investigation

Article:

In 2017, several high-profile media outlets were embroiled in controversies surrounding inaccurate reporting on the Trump-Russia investigation. One such instance involved CNN, which in December reported that Donald Trump Jr. was colluding with Wikileaks over stolen documents. The network claimed that a man named Mike Erickson emailed Trump Jr. on Sept. 4, 2016, with a link to Wikileaks documents and the decryption key needed to access them.
