However, a copy of the email given to ███ showed that it was actually sent on Sept. 14, 2016, after the stolen documents had already been leaked to the general public. Furthermore, Erickson has no apparent ties to Wikileaks or Russia.

The Washington Post identified him as the president of an aviation management company. To this day, CNN has yet to explain how two different anonymous sources fed the network the wrong date.

Another instance of media error occurred with The New York Times, which had to "look into" its own fake news when former FBI director James Comey questioned its reporting. The NYT claimed that U.S. intelligence officials intercepted communications between the Trump campaign and senior Russian intelligence officials in the year leading up to the election. Comey called the reporting "almost entirely wrong" and warned media outlets about relying on sources who don't have a full understanding of "what's going on."

In the week leading up to the G20 summit in Hamburg, Germany in July, CNN anchors reported that President Trump would not be confronting Russian President Vladimir Putin about his country's meddling in American elections. The CNN report—which relied on a single, anonymous source—turned out to be dead wrong.

An ABC News reporting error resulted in a stock market panic and the suspension of reporter Brian Ross earlier this month. Ross reported that former national security adviser Mike Flynn was prepared to testify that candidate Trump ordered him to make contact with the Russians. Hours later, ABC clarified that Flynn wasn't asked to contact Russia until after the election, during the Trump team's transition period. The story quickly fizzled from Trump-Russia collusion to standard preparation for an incoming presidential administration.

Three CNN employees resigned over a poorly-sourced story on the Trump transition team in June. Relying on a single, unnamed congressional source, CNN claimed that Trump adviser Anthony Scaramucci was under investigation over a meeting with a Russian banker that took place shortly before Trump's inauguration. CNN retracted the story and apologized to Scaramucci after multiple parts of the report were proven to be inaccurate.

Bloomberg News was forced to correct a bombshell report in December that claimed Special Counsel Robert Mueller had subpoenaed Deutsche Bank records related to President Trump and his family. The story claimed that Mueller had "zeroed in" on Trump. Bloomberg later corrected the report, noting that the bank records "pertain to people affiliated" with Trump, not the president himself.

CNN broke another flawed bombshell in May. Attorney General Jeff Sessions, while applying for his security clearance, had failed to disclose two meetings with then-Russian Ambassador to the United States Sergey Kislyak. CNN described the story as "the latest example of Sessions failing to disclose contacts he had with Russian officials." CNN quietly walked back the scoop seven months later, noting that the FBI specifically told Sessions he wasn't required to disclose the meetings. In other words: CNN's report excoriated Sessions for simply following protocol.

Journalists at multiple outlets, specifically CNN, consistently pushed the false claim that Republican donors had originally funded the infamous Trump-Russia dossier. Republican donor Paul Singer funded the firm behind the dossier, Fusion GPS, to conduct opposition research on candidates including Trump during the GOP primary. However, Singer had no involvement in the dossier, which has played a central role in the Trump-Russia narrative.

As former FBI Director James Comey geared up for a congressional testimony in June, CNN found the perfect opportunity to make some bold—but incorrect—predictions. CNN reported that Comey would testify that he did not tell Trump he was the subject of an investigation, as it would be improper for him to do so. CNN was proven drastically wrong when Comey released his prepared testimony, complete with the confirmation that he assured the president that he was not under FBI investigation.

A number of media outlets, including The New York Times, CNN, ABC News, and the Associated Press spent the year perpetuating a false claim Hillary Clinton made during the 2016 presidential debates. Each outlet incorrectly reported that "all 17 intelligence agencies" agreed that Russia meddled in the election. The truth is only four intelligence agencies evaluated and made judgments about Russian interference because the rest, like the Department of Energy and the Drug Enforcement Agency, have little authority on the matter.

NBC News published what the network hyped as a "potential bombshell" in September. Former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort's notes from the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting with a Russian lawyer contained the word "donations" near a reference to the Republican National Committee, the network reported. NBC began walking back the anonymously sourced story almost immediately, before a report in Politico debunked the "bombshell" altogether. Despite what NBC's sources told the network, the word "donations" did not appear in Manafort's notes, which weren't considered to be damaging to the Trump team at all.

In August, The New York Times "obtained" and published a draft of the National Climate Assessment (NCA), quoting anonymous scientists who feared "the Trump administration could change or suppress the report." There's just one problem: despite the paper's fear mongering, the draft report had already been publicly available for months.

Reports about "fake news" on Twitter turned out to be fake news themselves. CNN reported that "fake news" was higher in swing states, citing a study from the Oxford Internet Institute. However, the researchers in the study never talked about "fake news," but rather "junk news" that apparently comes from mainstream conservative outlets like the Washington Examiner.

Title: GOP Primary Kicks Off as Jeb Bush Announces Exploration of 2016 Presidential Run

Article:

The announcement by former Florida Governor Jeb Bush on Tuesday that he is "actively" exploring a 2016 presidential run has set the stage for the Republican primary, with other potential GOP candidates following suit. Kentucky Senator Rand Paul and neurosurgeon Dr. Ben Carson have made moves indicating their interest in the race.

Bush's Facebook announcement was followed by two Google ads bought by Paul's leadership political action committee (PAC). The first ad appeared in search results for those who searched Bush's name, while the second ad, which included the line "We need leaders who will stand against Common Core," was perceived as an attack ad due to the national school-curriculum standards supported by Bush but opposed by conservative-minded supporters of state autonomy and less government.

Paul, who stated he is "still a few more months" away from making a 2016 decision, discussed his stance on Fox News' "The Kelly File" later that night. He expressed his belief in less federal government and more decentralized government, particularly in education, and expressed skepticism about Bush's chances in the primary.

Republican strategist David Payne, a senior vice president at Washington, D.C.-based VOX Global, offered a mixed review of the "digital shadow boxing" between the potential candidates, suggesting they will need to be more innovative to capture the interest of Republican primary voters.

The effort to elect Carson also entered the mix before the end of the day. The National Draft Ben Carson for President Committee announced it will open an office in Iowa, historically the site of the first caucus of the presidential election cycle, followed by the New Hampshire primary.

Political strategists argue that if Bush's announcement triggered a starting gun, it was the one that prompted big donors to become more active, particularly those waiting to see if Bush, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, or 2012 GOP nominee Mitt Romney would try to become the party's establishment candidate.

Other top 2016 GOP hopefuls, such as Texas Senator Ted Cruz and Florida Senator Marco Rubio, also used Bush's announcement to draw attention to their own efforts. Cruz expressed his respect for Bush but stated he would wait until Bush officially decides before assessing his potential impact on the GOP primary. Rubio's spokesman indicated that Rubio's decision on whether to run for president or re-election would be based on where he can best achieve his agenda, not on who else might be running.

Title: Obamacare Sign-ups Reach 100,000 in November, Still Short of Initial Goal

Article:

The Department of Health and Human Services reported that approximately 100,000 people signed up for health insurance on the federal Obamacare website in November, according to a Bloomberg report citing a source familiar with the program's progress. The agency, however, declined to confirm the specific number, stating that they are still in the process of finalizing the data and expect to report the November numbers in mid-December.

The reported sign-up number is a significant increase from the 26,794 enrollments in October, marking a fourfold increase. Several states running their own exchanges have also reported steady climbs in enrollment, although some, like Oregon, are still facing technical issues that hinder sign-ups.

Health and Human Services spokeswoman Joanne Peters stated, "We expect that enrollment will increase with the technical improvements we've made, enrollment taking place across our customer service channels and the surge in enrollment that many states who are running their own marketplaces have reported."

The administration had initially hoped for about 800,000 people in the state and federal exchanges by now, and about 7 million by the end of March. Officials announced over the weekend that they had met their targets for making key fixes to the website, which is now reportedly working faster and with fewer crashes and errors. However, they acknowledged that the website is far from perfect despite the repair effort, and will need more work.

This article first appeared on ███ Pro at 7:41 a.m. Dec. 2, 2013.

Title: Congress to Pass Government Funding and Terrorism Insurance Bills Before Year-End

Article:

In the final days of the 113th Congress, the House and Senate are expected to pass a government-funding bill and renew the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA) this week. The deadline for government funding is Thursday, and both bills are anticipated to pass, albeit with some last-minute drama.

The government-funding bill, unofficially dubbed the "cromnibus," is set to keep most of the government open through September 2015, but it will extend Department of Homeland Security (DHS) funding only until February. The shorter DHS funding deadline is intended to pressure President Barack Obama over his recent executive action on immigration.

Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio), Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), and Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) are expected to lead the effort to secure GOP support for the bill. However, several dozen House Republicans have expressed unease with the legislation due to its lack of specific provisions to block Obama's immigration executive action. Democrats, led by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), are expected to support the bill, but a potential wild card exists. If the bill is pushed further to the right with controversial riders on environmental or labor policy, Democrats may vote against it, and the White House may issue a veto threat.

If the legislation is unveiled on Monday, it could hit the House floor by Wednesday, allowing the Senate one day to pass it to avoid a government shutdown. The House has canceled its votes Monday evening for the White House Christmas party, giving the GOP leadership just two days to get its members in line.

The controversy over Obama's immigration policy will continue into 2015. Boehner has stated that the new Republican-controlled Congress, which comes into session on January 6, will work to change Obama's executive order when DHS funding comes up for renewal next year. However, it is unclear how Congress will be able to revise or alter the president's unilateral action.

Renewing TRIA has proven more challenging in Congress' rush to leave town. The federal government provides a backstop for insuring against terrorist attacks, and passage is a priority for potential targets like cities, municipalities, and professional sports teams. House Financial Services Committee Chairman Jeb Hensarling (R-Texas) is negotiating with Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) to hash out a deal. The two sides were on the brink of an agreement last week, but Hensarling wants to insert reforms to Dodd-Frank regulations into the package. House GOP leadership aides have vowed that they will not let the negotiations fall apart and will pass the measure.

On the foreign policy front, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is expected to debate and vote on a resolution authorizing the use of military force against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL). The measure, being pushed by Sens. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) and Tim Kaine (D-Va.), won't have time to reach the Senate floor or be taken up by the House. The debate, however, will set a benchmark for lawmakers when they return to debate this issue more fully in the next Congress. An Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF) vote would also boost Paul's GOP presidential ambitions by placing him in the spotlight on a critical foreign policy issue.

Two other matters will also receive attention during the next 96 hours. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who are switching their respective roles in January, will try to hammer out a last-minute agreement on executive-branch nominations, the final time Obama will have that opportunity during his presidency under a Democratic-run Senate. Additionally, the House Ethics Committee is being closely watched over whether it will make any late announcements on high-profile cases. The secretive panel is scheduled to meet privately several times this week. If the Ethics Committee does not act on these pending cases before the end of this Congress, it will have to vote to take them up again once the next Congress begins. Rep. Charlie Dent (R-Pa.) will take over as Ethics Committee chairman next year from Rep. Mike Conaway (R-Texas).

Title: Democrats Gain Edge Over Republicans in Midterm Elections, According to New Poll

Article:

A new CNN/ORC poll released Tuesday indicates that Democrats have a slight edge over Republicans in the upcoming November midterm elections, with 47% of likely voters supporting the Democratic party compared to 45% for the Republican party. This 6-point swing from a CNN poll three weeks ago, where likely voters favored the Republicans by a 4-point margin, falls within the poll's 3.5% margin of error.

The poll, conducted after the U.S. launched airstrikes against ISIS in Syria, suggests a shift toward the Democrats nationally, although the gains are primarily in the Northeast and not in the competitive races that could determine control of the Senate. The "generic ballot" question, which asks Americans to choose between an unnamed Democrat and an unnamed Republican in their vote for U.S. House, indicates a shift toward the Democrats if not in key races in key states.

The poll also reveals that the economy is a more important issue for voters than military action against ISIS, with roughly two out of three Americans stating that the economy is more important in determining their vote for the midterms. This contrasts with the lead-up to the Iraq War in 2002, when 49% of Americans considered the possibility of war with Iraq a more important factor than the economy.

In addition, most Americans, 59%, do not consider the conflict with ISIS to be a war, according to a CNN/ORC poll released Monday. The poll also indicates that Americans are largely unsatisfied with Congress's handling of the situation with ISIS, with 60% disapproving. This is just weeks after members of Congress absconded from Capitol Hill without a vote on military action against ISIS to campaign for reelection in their districts.

The poll also shows that Democrats gained the most ground among men and independent voters, two key groups that could help Democrats in competitive races this November. Men took a 7-point swing toward Democrats from the previous poll, bringing the party within 6 points of Republicans' 49% support. Republicans also lost support among independents as Democrats saw a 7-point bump, giving them a 44-42% advantage over their rivals.

The traction for Democrats comes in the wake of an expanded military campaign ordered by President Barack Obama. The polling director for CNN, Keating Holland, stated that the Democrats' gains among men and independent voters "may be a sign that some men wanted to see aggressive action taken against ISIS and are rewarding the President's party—or simply that the President's actions have convinced men that they do not need to send more Republicans to Washington in order to get action that they are looking for."

Title: Obama Nominates Tom Perez for Labor Secretary, Sparking Political Debate

Article:

President Barack Obama has nominated Tom Perez, the Assistant Attorney General for the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, to be his next Labor Secretary. If confirmed by the Senate, Perez would replace Hilda Solis, who resigned in January.

Perez, 51, is the son of Dominican immigrants and worked his way through college and law school before joining the Justice Department and becoming Maryland's state labor secretary. In his nomination announcement, Obama praised Perez as a man who embodies the American promise, stating, "His story reminds us of this country's promise, that if you're willing to work hard, it doesn't matter who you are or where you come from, what your last name is, you can make it if you try."

Perez emphasized the importance of open-mindedness, listening to all sides, and focusing on results during his nomination speech. However, the issue of immigration reform and its impact on undocumented workers has already become a contentious point in the nomination process.

Republican opposition to Perez's nomination was swift, with Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), the ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, criticizing the appointment as "an unfortunate and needlessly divisive nomination." Sessions argued that Perez's past work for the advocacy group Casa de Maryland has involved seeking ways to hire more illegal workers.

Sen. David Vitter (R-La.) has also announced his intention to block the Perez nomination, citing the Justice Department's alleged failure to respond to a 2011 letter he wrote with questions about federal enforcement of the 1993 Motor Voter Act.

Meanwhile, AFL-CIO president Richard Trumka praised Perez as a champion for ordinary working people and a strong advocate for workers' rights. The White House has portrayed Perez as an individual aligned with Obama's sense of social justice, highlighting his work in settling the nation's three largest fair-lending housing cases, boosting enforcement of human trafficking laws, and protecting the rights of veterans and students.

Perez's confirmation hearings are expected to feature questions about a scathing inspector general's report released last week that revealed internal racial hostilities in the Civil Rights Division and found Perez gave misleading public testimony in 2010 regarding the decision to drop prosecution of New Black Panther Party members. The report has added fuel to the political debate surrounding Perez's nomination.

Title: Romney Outraises Obama by $21 Million in May Fundraising

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, raised approximately $86 million in May, outpacing President Barack Obama's fundraising efforts by about $21 million, according to campaign finance reports filed on Wednesday. Romney's campaign, along with his super PAC allies and the Republican Party, raised an estimated $65 million by Obama and his allies.

Romney's fundraising advantage is expected to persist through November, as his team is planning a weekend of donor schmoozing at a Utah ski resort. The event invites 100 supporters who have raised $100,000 or more, featuring Romney, his top campaign staff, and notable GOP figures such as Karl Rove, Tim Pawlenty, Rob Portman, Paul Ryan, and Bobby Jindal.

President Obama's campaign is attempting to keep pace. While the president's campaign often portrays itself as small-donor-powered, Wednesday's reports show that his allies are mounting a big-money push, attracting three new million-dollar donors to a supportive super PAC and raising larger checks into a campaign committee restructured to accept larger donations.

The reports, filed with the Federal Election Commission, depict a well-positioned Romney fundraising network for the new big-money age, capable of challenging an Obama operation that, in some ways, is still adapting to the era of mega-donors.

"It's easier to raise money in big chunks if there are people who are willing to give it that way, then it is to mobilize thousands of people to give $20 each," said Bob Biersack, a leading campaign finance tracker who recently joined the Center for Responsive Politics after decades at the FEC.

Big donors have fueled record fundraising for GOP super PACs, including Restore Our Future, which raised $5 million, and American Crossroads, which raised $4.6 million, according to Wednesday's filings. Repeat donors to the super PACs included Pennsylvania medical executive Rocco Ortenzio, Idaho vitamin executive Frank VanderSloot, and a company controlled by Dallas developer Harlan Crow, who collectively donated $1.6 million last month.

However, Wednesday's reports do not fully reflect the efforts to attract new donors who previously wrote big checks to Romney's GOP opponents, such as casino mogul Sheldon Adelson, who pledged $10 million this month, and also intends to give generously to American Crossroads' nonprofit sister group.

Democrats have expressed concern for months about their inability to counteract Restore Our Future and a constellation of GOP-allied outside groups already spending heavily on ads attacking Obama. They received some positive news on Wednesday, as the pro-Obama super PAC Priorities USA Action, which had been struggling to attract big donors, reported raising $4 million in May—its best month yet. This came largely from three new donors who gave $1 million each in May—developer Franklin Haney, Houston lawyer Steve Mostyn, and philanthropist Barbara Stiefel—all of which had the group feeling optimistic and touting the impact of its ads attacking Romney over his tenure at the private equity firm Bain Capital.

However, Priorities' $18.6-million total haul for the cycle pales in comparison with the $61.5 million raised by Restore Our Future.

Title: The Impact of European Arrival on Native American Populations: A Historical Perspective

Article:

The arrival of European explorers, such as Samuel de Champlain and Capt. John Smith, in the early 1600s marked a significant turning point in the history of the New World. According to historian Mancall, a disease, believed to be leptospirosis, spread among Native American communities, potentially introduced by Old World bacteria carried by rats on European ships. This illness weakened the native population, creating an opportunity for European settlers, such as the Pilgrims.

King James's patent referred to this spread of disease as a "wonderful Plague" that could help devastate and depopulate the region. However, many Native Americans not killed by disease were victims of direct violence.

The celebration in 1621, often associated with the first Thanksgiving, did not mark a friendly turning point and was not an annual event. Relations between the Wampanoag and the settlers deteriorated, leading to the Pequot War. In 1637, in retaliation for the murder of a settler believed to have been killed by the Wampanoag, settlers burned a nearby village, killing as many as 500 men, women, and children. Following the massacre, William Bradford, the Governor of Plymouth, wrote that every Thanksgiving Day ordained by a Governor was in honor of the bloody victory, thanking God that the battle had been won.

Just 16 years after the Wampanoag shared that meal, they were massacred. This was one of the earliest episodes in a series of violent encounters between settlers and Native Americans. There were numerous massacres and wars, with the U.S. government authorizing over 1,500 wars, attacks, and raids on Native American communities, more than any other country in the world against its indigenous people.

This account says nothing of all the treaties brokered and then broken or all the land grabs that removed populations, including the most famous removal of natives: the Trail of Tears. Beginning in 1831, tens of thousands of Native Americans were forced to relocate from their ancestral lands in the Southeast to lands west of the Mississippi River. Many died along the way.

Title: Former President Obama Criticizes Trump Administration's Response to Covid-19 Pandemic, Addresses Racial Inequality

Article:

In a rare break from tradition, former President Barack Obama has criticized the Trump administration's response to the Covid-19 pandemic during speeches to graduating students of historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) and high school students. The comments, made on Saturday, come amidst the ongoing coronavirus pandemic that has claimed over 88,000 lives in the United States, a death toll far higher than any other country.

During his address to HBCU graduates, Obama stated, "More than anything, this pandemic has fully, finally torn back the curtain on the idea that so many of the folks in charge know what they're doing. A lot of them aren't even pretending to be in charge." He further criticized the administration's response in a second speech for graduating US high school students, saying, "Doing what feels good, what's convenient, what's easy—that's how little kids think. Unfortunately, a lot of so-called grown-ups, including some with fancy titles and important jobs, still think that way—which is why things are so screwed up."

Obama's comments come amidst dual crises—one being the pandemic disproportionately affecting people of color in the US, and the other being the economic impacts of attempts to contain the virus through lockdowns. As of now, there have been 1.4 million confirmed cases of Covid-19 in the US.

The former president also addressed the high-profile killings of black people by police, including the case of Ahmaud Arbery, an unarmed black jogger who was shot and killed after being pursued in broad daylight by a white former police officer and his son through a neighborhood in Georgia. Obama stated, "We see it when a black man goes for a jog and some folks feel like they can stop and question and shoot him, if he doesn't submit to their questioning."

The remarks prompted a response from Peter Navarro, a top economic adviser to President Trump, who said he was "glad Mr. Obama has a new job as Joe Biden's press secretary." Biden, Obama's former vice president, is running against Trump for president.

Obama's comments come after a leaked call last week in which he described the US government's coronavirus response as, "an absolute chaotic disaster," and questioned whether the justice department's decision to drop charges against former national security advisor Michael Flynn could endanger the "rule of law" in the United States. The remarks prompted Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell to tell the former president to "keep his mouth shut."

The remarks also come amidst the emergence of the #Obamagate conspiracy theory, a theory pushed by President Trump that accuses Obama of attempting to frame Trump for colluding with Russia to win the 2016 election. One former CIA analyst described the hashtag as "a hashtag in search of a scandal."

The speeches were preceded by performances by musicians, actors, and entertainers such as Steve Harvey, Anthony Hamilton, Doug E Fresh, Wyclef Jean, Common, Kevin Hart, Wendy Raquel Robinson, and Vivica A Fox. The messages to graduates tuning in online because they could not hold traditional celebrations on campus were shot through with acknowledgements of America's history of racial segregation.

Speakers noted the perseverance required to spend a final semester largely online, and the bittersweetness of the moment itself. "This is obviously not the way you wanted to graduate," said Doc Rivers, coach of the NBA's Los Angeles Clippers. "But you know what else we know? You're going to make us all proud."

Graduates were sent out into an "uncertain world," but one they had a chance to improve upon. "As graduates, you now join the ranks of national and world leaders, influencers," said Senator Kamala Harris of California. "I know this is a trying time, but please do not let the moment of this crisis dampen your ambitions, your hopes, or your dreams, because your country needs you." Harris attended the HBCU Howard, recently ran for the Democratic nomination, and is a contender to become Joe Biden's running mate in the 2020 election.

Title: Terrorist Attack in New York: Eight Dead, Suspect in Critical Condition

Article:

Investigators at the scene of a terrorist attack in New York have found a note referencing Islamic State, according to New York Governor Andrew Cuomo. The attack occurred on Tuesday afternoon when a man drove a rented truck down a popular cycle path in Manhattan.

The man, who is in critical condition in a New York City hospital after being shot by a police officer, is expected to survive. The truck collided with a school bus at the corner of Chambers Street, bringing the rampage to a halt. The school bus was later removed.

The attack resulted in eight deaths and 11 injuries. The stretch of the cycle lane in lower Manhattan, near the site of the 9/11 attack, remained sealed off on Wednesday morning. Mangled bicycles were still strewn along the approximately one-mile length of the path where people were struck.

The truck was still at the scene, with its smashed front visible. The site is just a few blocks from the One World Trade Center skyscraper, which was only recently completed on the site of the original Twin Towers, destroyed in the terrorist attack of September 11, 2001, killing nearly 3,000 people. Tuesday's attack represented the highest death toll from a terrorist incident in the city since 9/11.

The victims of the attack were from various nationalities, including Belgium and Argentina. The suspect in the attack is 29-year-old Sayfullo Saipov, a national of Uzbekistan who immigrated to the US in 2010 and was a driver for the car service Uber, living in New Jersey.

Investigators converged on an apartment building in Patterson, New Jersey, where the suspect is understood to have lived. The president of Uzbekistan, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, has sent his condolences to President Donald Trump and offered his country's assistance in investigating the attack.

New York City officials have expressed defiance and resilience in the face of the attack, with Mayor Bill de Blasio describing it as an act of terror. The suspect's motives and the exact details of the attack are still under investigation.

Title: Lawmakers Propose Economic Stimulus Packages and Universal Basic Income Amid Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

Multiple lawmakers, including Representative Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii), have proposed economic stimulus packages and universal basic income programs in response to the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. On Friday, Gabbard introduced a resolution that would provide a monthly income of $1,000 to every American until COVID-19 no longer poses a public health emergency.

In an effort to contain the spread of the virus, the U.S. has imposed travel bans on several countries heavily affected by the pandemic, and numerous large events and conferences have been canceled or postponed. The stock market experienced its worst losses since 1987 on Thursday, but the exact number of workers affected is unavailable.

Last week, Republicans and Democrats united to enact $8.3 billion in emergency funding, primarily dedicated to healthcare concerns arising from the crisis. A second round of relief, set to receive a House vote on Friday, focuses on the economic fallout, providing financial assistance to those most directly affected by the outbreak. The bill expands unemployment insurance, extends paid sick leave for workers forced to stay home, and provides food aid to low-income children due to school closures. The bill also aims to offer free coronavirus testing for everyone showing symptoms, including the uninsured.

However, some members argue that a universal basic income is necessary to prevent lasting economic damage. "The coronavirus pandemic has created a threat to the health and well-being of the American people, as well as to our country's economic stability," Gabbard said in a statement. "While some in Washington are focused on taking care of Wall Street, everyday Americans get left behind. That's wrong...Taking care of all Americans will stimulate our economy during this downturn."

Economist Nouriel Roubini supported the idea in a tweet on Friday, suggesting it be financed with bonds and monetized by the Federal Reserve.

On Friday, Democratic Reps. Ro Khanna (Calif.) and Tim Ryan (Ohio) also introduced legislation to establish an emergency Earned Income Tax Credit. The bill would provide a payment of $1,000 and $6,000 to over a third of Americans who earned less than $65,000 last year.

"In order to alleviate the economic fallout of the Coronavirus, we must ensure hard-working Americans have money in their pockets and are able to pay their bills," Khanna said in a statement. "We must soften the blow for workers as large gatherings and events are canceled and hours are cut. A payroll tax cut is not sufficient."

Title: Biden's 2020 Campaign: A Comparison to Hillary Clinton and George W. Bush

Article:

Joe Biden, the 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, kicked off his campaign in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on May 18, 2019.

Matt Continetti, editor of the Washington Free Beacon, recently posed the question, "Is Biden the new Hillary Clinton?" The question arises as Trump's team is reportedly planning to employ similar tactics against Biden as they did against Clinton in the 2016 election.

In 2016, Trump defined Clinton as a candidate of entrenched interests who used a long career in politics for familial gain. He highlighted Clinton's support for the 1994 crime bill and for NAFTA and TPP, creating divisions between the former secretary of state and important Democratic constituencies. Trump also attacked Clinton's foreign-policy credentials, portraying her as an interventionist who weakened America's standing in the world.

According to the RealClearPolitics average, Biden is currently leading Trump by 8 points. In crucial states like Pennsylvania, Biden has a double-digit lead, with a 10.5 percentage-point advantage in Michigan, 8 points in Wisconsin (though polling there is sparse), and 4 points in Ohio. Biden is tied in Florida, according to the RealClearPolitics average.

Trump won the Electoral College by taking a handful of states out of the traditional Democratic column with razor-thin margins. It's early, but the concerning part for Trump is that Biden is not only outperforming other Democrats in the field, but he's also outperforming Clinton at a comparable time in 2015.

However, the comparison between Biden and Clinton may not be entirely accurate. Clinton ran as an experienced Washington hand, but after 16 months of Trump attacks, she lost to Trump by 77,000 votes in three states. The same could happen again to a nominee easily caricatured as the epitome of Beltway cluelessness, according to Continetti. What looks like Joe Biden's greatest strength—electability born of experience—may also be a debilitating weakness.

While Trump's attacks on Clinton were effective at times, Trump was aided enormously by the fact that Americans, particularly Republican and Republican-friendly ones, were skeptical or outright hostile to her already, thanks to decades of experience with, and criticism of, her. Trump didn't define Clinton as much as she did.

Moreover, implicit to her campaign was the promise of both a third Obama term and a restoration of the Clinton dynasty. Trump did not need to work hard to convince voters exhausted or frustrated by the Obama years or disdainful of Clinton Inc. to vote against her.

Biden occupies a different space, psychologically and politically. There's a lot of conventional wisdom in Washington that the early front-runner always loses. However, this is true except when it isn't. In 2003, former Vermont governor Howard Dean dominated the polls but eventually lost. In 1999, George W. Bush dominated the polls and, except for a brief scare from Senator John McCain in the New Hampshire primary, essentially cruised to victory.

A key part of Bush's early success, not just in polls but in fundraising, stemmed from the fact that he was promising a Bush restoration. Indeed, some of his early approval ratings were a direct result of nostalgia for his father, with whom he shared a name. Also, he was offering a referendum on the incumbent president and the scandals and partisanship that defined the end of his administration. He vowed to restore "honor and dignity to the Oval Office" and to be a "uniter not a divider."

The very different context notwithstanding, this is pretty much Biden's campaign message. The ideological, activist, and Twitter-obsessed base of the Democratic party may not like Biden's pitch. But it sure looks like rank-and-file Democrats do, particularly African-American women who may see in Biden something of an Obama restoration.

Of course, Biden can blow it, as he did the two previous times he ran for president. But counting on the past repeating itself is a good strategy only when you pick the right example from the past.

Title: GOP Steps Up Digital Efforts to Enhance Online Presence Ahead of Midterm Elections

Article:

Republicans, following their losses in the 2012 election, are taking aggressive steps to improve their digital strategy in preparation for the upcoming midterm elections. According to Eric Frenchman, a strategist at Connell Donatelli Inc., the Republican Party needs to prioritize digital media as their first line of defense, rather than relying on traditional offline media such as TV, talk radio, and direct mail.

In the 2012 election cycle, the Democratic Party outspent the Republicans on digital media and advertising, with President Obama's team investing $52 million compared to Mitt Romney's $26 million. Obama posted four times as much online content as Romney and was active on twice as many digital platforms, according to a Pew Internet & American Life study.

The digital strategies employed by both parties during the 2012 election mirrored the 2008 election, where Sen. John McCain's campaign launched an 11th-hour tech offensive that came too late. Similarly, Romney advisers took aggressive steps during the summer to close the digital gap but were outmaneuvered.

Across platforms, Obama published 614 posts during a two-week period compared with Romney's 168. The greatest contrast was on Twitter, where Romney averaged one tweet per day while Obama had 29. Republicans were also outperformed on YouTube, with Democrats publishing two videos for every GOP video.

To address these shortcomings, Republican strategists are taking proactive measures to become more competitive. Last week, members of the Republican Party, along with consultants from companies like Facebook and Twitter, met in Washington to strategize on building a better digital platform. The group was led by Romney's digital director Zac Moffatt, RNC digital director Tyler Brown, and RNC Chief of Staff Jeff Larson.

Frenchman, who directed over $175 million in online advertising for the 2008 McCain-Palin presidential bid, emphasized the importance of allocating sufficient funds to compete with the already tech-savvy Democratic team. "Spend money earlier in the process," Frenchman said. "It's not something you can afford to wait to finance. It's going to take money, and it needs to happen now."

The Republican Party's digital shortcomings in the 2012 election highlighted cracks in their plan, as the Obama team had a four-year head start. Frenchman suggested that the GOP should pool their resources and assemble a super RNC digital team to address the situation early.

Some have criticized the Romney campaign for wasting time trying to reinvent the digital wheel instead of building on foundations already in place. The Romney campaign was also called out for being too slow to respond to developments in the race.

Obama's digital team used their website, emails, and text messages to push the president's message, as well as developing tools that made it easier to donate online, assemble groups to canvas neighborhoods, and volunteer for field operations in swing states. They also started a campaign that helped supporters find their Facebook friends in battleground states through an Obama 2012 app that also reminded them to vote. They then put a link on Facebook that helped supporters find voting locations.

For its part, the Romney campaign has stated that they will hand over their digital files, which includes data on 1 million new voters, to the RNC.

Title: GOP's Scant Legislative Agenda for 2018 Due to Loss of Senate Seats Due to Poor Candidates

Article:

The Republican Party's legislative agenda for the remainder of 2018 is minimal, according to a report by The Washington Post. The $1.3 trillion spending bill, which President Trump signed into law last month, is likely the last significant legislation to pass Congress before the November elections.

The House of Representatives is expected to take a largely symbolic vote on a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced federal budget and attempt to reverse some spending while also finalizing a banking deregulation bill and drafting legislation to address the opioid crisis. The Senate, meanwhile, is likely to focus on confirming Trump nominees, including more judges and the president's picks to lead the State Department and the CIA following last month's Cabinet shuffle.

The article points out the irony of House Republicans calling for a vote on a balanced-budget amendment after passing a deficit-financed tax cut and a budget-busting omnibus bill. The Senate filibuster is not entirely to blame for the legislative stalemate, as the process creates a barrier against many types of legislation but not all. The process of budget reconciliation enables a narrow, 51-vote majority to change policies related to spending and taxes, which is how the GOP got tax reform passed in December. However, Republicans are declining to pursue this option in 2018.

The cause for the legislative stalemate is rooted in the various maladies and mistakes of state Republican parties across the country. The article argues that the GOP has lost eminently winnable Senate races, allowing Senate Democrats to pad their caucus. This has stymied the Republican legislative agenda.

The Senate's composition, when viewed from a partisan state perspective, makes sense, with strongly Democratic states electing two Democrats, and strongly Republican states electing two Republicans. Purple states have one Democrat and one Republican. However, the deviations do not always hold across purple states, with New Hampshire having two Democrats and Iowa having two Republicans.

The main exception to this is a group of six Senate Democrats who come from strongly Republican states. These are Doug Jones of Alabama, Joe Donnelly of Indiana, Claire McCaskill of Missouri, Joe Tester of Montana, Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, and Joe Manchin of West Virginia. The only Republican from a strongly Democratic state is Susan Collins of Maine.

Candidate effects explain many of these Democratic-held seats. Jones, Donnelly, and McCaskill won their races because their Republican opponents said or did outrageous things that alienated the broad middle of their states. Tester and Heitkamp are still in office because their opponents, while not ridiculously bad, ran thoroughly lackluster campaigns in 2012, failing to win despite the boost they received from Mitt Romney's winning their respective states with ease. Among the six, only Manchin, a former governor, had the sort of reputation that could inoculate him from a strong Republican campaign to oust him.

The article concludes that the GOP should not have lost all six of these seats. Three to four should be in Republican hands, and the failure rests not with the party's leadership but with Republican voters and leaders in these states: They failed to select good candidates, and now the party is paying the price.

Title: Romney's Assertion on Medicare Pay Cuts for Doctors Challenged

Article:

In the ongoing 2020 presidential campaign, healthcare, particularly Medicare, has been a significant topic. Over the past couple of weeks, Republican candidate Mitt Romney has made a claim regarding $716 billion in Medicare reductions over ten years, which is a part of the federal health law, the Affordable Care Act (ACA). This claim has become a recurring theme in Romney's stump speeches.

During his economic speech in Ames, Iowa, last week, Romney stated:

"It matters to the senior who needs to get an appointment with a medical specialist, but is told by one receptionist after another that the doctor is not taking any new Medicare patients; because Medicare has been slashed to pay for Obamacare."

Harold Pollack, a professor of public health policy at the University of Chicago, disputes Romney's assertion, stating, "I'm honestly rather baffled at the arguments that Governor Romney is making."

While it is true that the ACA envisions reductions in Medicare, and some of that money is used to fund the rest of the law, these two factors are not directly connected. The issue of Medicare pay for doctors predates the ACA by more than a decade, according to Pollack. "And every year, Congress has to go through the song and dance with something called the doctor fix to prevent Medicare fees from a fairly catastrophic reduction. That has nothing to do with the Affordable Care Act. Health reform does not cut physician fees," Pollack explains.

The Medicare pay for doctors problem has been a long-standing issue, with Congress needing to address it annually through the so-called "doctor fix." This issue is unrelated to the ACA.

The ACA did take a few steps to boost payments for some doctors, including improving reimbursement for primary care providers in both Medicare and the Medicaid program, where the shortage of doctors has been more pronounced.

A campaign email referenced a 2010 survey of doctors by the Physicians Foundation, in which 30% said the law would prompt them to close their practices to new Medicare patients. However, the survey had a response rate of only 2.4%, and more than two-thirds of those who responded started with a self-described negative view of the law.

Title: Democratic National Committee Elects Tom Perez as New Chair in Contested Race

Article:

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) elected Tom Perez as their new party chair on Saturday, in a contentious race that marked a significant transition for the party. Perez, a favorite among the more centrist wing of the party, received 235 votes, while Rep. Keith Ellison (D-MN), a favorite among progressives, received 200 votes. Perez, the son of Dominican immigrants, will be the first Latino to hold the post.

As the chair, Perez will lead the party's organizing, messaging, and fundraising operations. This role carries substantial influence in defining the Democrats' identity and pitch to voters following their shock loss in the 2016 presidential election.

The DNC chair election comes at a time when the Democrats hold little political control, having lost 20% of their Senate seats, 25% of their House seats, 45% of their governors, and over half of state legislatures since 2009, according to the Associated Press. Several candidates, including Perez, campaigned on a promise to focus more on down-ballot races and ramp up small-donor fundraising.

One of the crucial questions for Perez is interpreting national demographic trends and translating them into Democratic strategy. Some Democrats argue that the next DNC chair needs to target more progressive white voters, often referred to as "Bernie voters," who were skeptical of Hillary Clinton's candidacy. They believe demographic trends favor them and move away from the white working-class voters who unexpectedly supported President Trump.

However, others argue that these numbers oversimplify the situation. Lanae Erickson Hatalsky and Jim Kessler of the centrist think tank Third Way suggest that changes are concentrated in urban Democratic strongholds, voters cast ballots across parties more often than believed, and the rising proportion of voters who identify as liberal is offset by other factors, including a corresponding rise in conservative-identifying voters.

Perez's election to the post may come as a surprise to some who expected Ellison to prevail, partly as a concession to the progressive wing. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT), a backer of Ellison, had framed the choice as one between the "failed status quo" and a "fundamental restructuring of the Democratic Party."

Jerry Shriner, a DNC member from Idaho, expressed concerns about Perez's election, stating, "There are risks with every candidate, but [with Ellison and Perez] in particular...I think there will be people who pull back." However, Shriner added, "But the way I look at it, we have four years to work on that. Whatever problems either candidate might create in terms of divisiveness, we have four years to pull that together."

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Seeks Information on Surveillance Allegations by Obama Administration

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky, has formally requested information from the White House and the U.S. intelligence community regarding potential surveillance by the Obama administration. In an exclusive interview with Breitbart News on Friday, Sen. Paul expressed concerns about the politicization of intelligence agencies.

In a tweet, Sen. Paul stated, "I have formally requested from the WH and the Intel Committees info on whether I was surveilled by Obama admin and or the Intel community." He further questioned whether the Obama administration targeted other presidential candidates, members of Congress, journalists, clergy, lawyers, and federal judges.

Sen. Paul, a critic of intelligence programs that capture metadata on innocent Americans, told Breitbart that several individuals have approached him with allegations of surveillance. Former National Security Adviser Susan E. Rice acknowledged in April that associates of President Donald Trump were "unmasked," but denied any wrongdoing.

Sen. Paul expressed concern about the potential misuse of information, stating, "We've had several people come to us and say that it happened. I don't have access to that information, but I've been very concerned that too many Americans' information is being culled through without a warrant. I don't have any facts to say it happened. But numerous sources are coming to us saying it did happen, so I want to search through, find out why I wasn't notified. Was it on purpose?"

The senator's request follows a report that NSA officials honored almost 2,000 "unmasking" requests in 2016. Sen. Paul told Breitbart, "We have several sources telling us that members of the Obama administration were looking at politicians, particularly [those] who were running for office."

FBI Director James B. Comey has previously denied that President Trump's campaign was ever targeted directly by the Obama administration. The details of Sen. Paul's request and the response from the White House and the intelligence community are yet to be disclosed.

Title: Tlaib Rejects Israel's Offer to Visit Grandmother Due to Restrictive Conditions

Article:

Rashida Tlaib, a Democratic U.S. House member, has declined Israel's offer to visit her grandmother in the West Bank, citing the restrictive conditions as contradicting her beliefs in fighting against racism, oppression, and injustice. Tlaib made the announcement on Twitter on Friday.

Israel had initially barred Tlaib and fellow Democratic congresswoman Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, also a Muslim, under pressure from President Donald Trump. However, Israel announced on Friday that it would allow Tlaib to visit her family, a day after the initial ban.

Israel's Interior Minister Aryeh Deri stated that Tlaib agreed not to re-state her support for a boycott of Israel during the visit as a condition for entry. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a firm ally of Trump, had laid out this condition.

After Tlaib indicated she would reject the offer, Deri questioned on Twitter whether her interest in visiting relatives was genuine. "I approved her request as a gesture of good will on a humanitarian basis, but it was just a provocative request, aimed at bashing the State of Israel," he wrote. "Apparently her hate for Israel overcomes her love for her grandmother."

The decision to block the visit, initially planned to start this weekend, sparked furor among Democrats and at least one prominent Republican - Senator Marco Rubio of Florida. The staunchly pro-Israel group American Israel Public Affairs Committee also stated that the two lawmakers should be allowed to visit.

U.S. Ambassador to Israel David Friedman called the trip "nothing more than an effort to fuel the BDS engine," referring to the "boycott, divestment and sanctions" movement against Israel over the country's treatment of Palestinians, a cause Omar and Tlaib have voiced support for.

The decision to block the visit reversed a previous announcement in July from Israel's ambassador to the U.S., Ron Dermer, that Israel would permit the women to enter out of respect for Congress.

Tlaib stated that her family would not want her to agree to Israel's restrictions and that they were an effort "to humiliate me and my family or take away our right to speak out."

"When I won the election to become a United States congresswoman, many Palestinians, especially my grandmother, felt a sense of hope, a hope that they would finally have a voice," Tlaib said in a statement from her congressional office. "I can not allow the Israeli government to take that away from them or to use my deep desire to see my grandmother, potentially for the last time, as a political bargaining chip."

Title: Trump, Putin Hold First Face-to-Face Meeting in Helsinki, Discuss "Difficult Multi-national Issues"

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin held a face-to-face meeting in Helsinki, Finland, marking the first time the two leaders have met in person. The meeting, which was described by Trump as a "good start," included two hours of closed-door talks followed by a working lunch with their senior advisers.

Prior to the summit, Putin stated that it was time to discuss "difficult multi-national issues." Relations between Russia and the West have been strained due to Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 and allegations of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election, a claim Russia strongly denies.

Before the much-anticipated summit, Trump expressed hope for an "extraordinary relationship" and blamed U.S.-Russia tensions on previous administrations. Some U.S. politicians called for the summit to be cancelled following the indictment of 12 Russian military intelligence agents on Friday for hacking the presidential campaign of Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton.

However, Trump put the blame for the deterioration in relations with Russia on "years of U.S. foolishness and stupidity and now, the Rigged Witch Hunt." The tweets are likely to alarm White House advisers who are already nervous about the risks of ceding too much ground to the Russian leader during the talks.

The two leaders were joined only by their interpreters during their two hours of face-to-face talks. The summit comes after a tumultuous European tour that saw Trump sharply criticize longstanding allies of the U.S. over trade and military spending.

Russia has been criticized in the U.S. for its military support for President Bashar al-Assad in Syria as well as its destabilizing actions in Ukraine. Relations have also been damaged by accusations of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election and Trump campaign collusion in the effort. The allegations are being investigated by Special Counsel Robert Mueller.

Trump has consistently denounced the inquiry as a "witch hunt." The 12 Russians indicted on Friday were targeted as part of Mueller's investigation. Top Democrats, including party chairman Tom Perez, urged Trump to cancel the talks, saying Putin was "not a friend of the United States." On the Republican side, Senator John McCain said the summit "should not move forward" unless the president "is prepared to hold Putin accountable."

Russia denied the hacking allegations and said it looked forward to the talks as a vehicle for improving relations. U.S. National Security Adviser John Bolton has said that both sides have agreed the meeting will have no set agenda. However, he said he found it "hard to believe" Putin would not expect the alleged election hacking to be brought up.

Trump has also been urged to raise the poisoning of two people in the UK who came into contact with the nerve agent Novichok on 30 June. Investigators believe the incident is linked to the poisoning of a former Russian spy and his daughter in March.

During a joint news conference with UK Prime Minister Theresa May last week, Trump elaborated on what would be discussed at the summit. "We'll be talking about Syria," he said. "We'll be talking about other parts of the Middle East. I will be talking about nuclear proliferation."

This is not the first time U.S. and Russian leaders have met in Helsinki. Finland remained politically and militarily neutral after World War Two, making it an attractive meeting spot for the two superpowers. The city was a backdrop to the signing of the 1975 Helsinki Accords, which are credited for improving relations between the Soviet Union and Western countries. Helsinki remained a destination in the post-Soviet era, and the Trump-Putin summit is the fourth such meeting in the city.

What has Trump been doing so far in Europe? His tour has included a NATO summit in Belgium and a visit to the UK. Neither passed without controversy. Following the NATO summit, Trump said the allies had pledged to "substantially" raise their defense budgets, but other leaders cast doubt on this claim. The UK visit also had its ups and downs after Trump told a newspaper the U.S. would probably not give the UK a trade deal under the terms of May's Brexit plans - and then later appeared to backtrack on this position. He also said Europe was "losing its character" because of immigration from Africa and the Middle East. On Sunday, just before he departed for Helsinki, Trump described the European Union as a foe on trade. He told CBS News that European countries were taking advantage of the U.S. and not paying their NATO bills.

Title: Trump Issues Executive Order Temporarily Blocking Some Foreigners from Permanent U.S. Residency

Article:

President Donald Trump issued an executive order on Wednesday that temporarily blocks some foreigners outside the United States from obtaining U.S. permanent residency, a move he said would protect American workers amid the economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak. The executive order includes a number of exemptions and is not a full suspension of legal immigration, as suggested by a Trump tweet late on Monday night.

The order blocks some foreigners outside the United States from settling permanently in the United States by obtaining what is informally known as a "green card." The measure applies to both requests for permanent residence based on employment in the United States and requests based on familial ties but contains a number of exceptions.

The order does not affect people coming to the United States on non-immigrant visas, including tourists and business travelers. It also does not affect workers such as farm laborers entering the United States on temporary visas or skilled workers on H-1B visas. Foreigners already in the United States and seeking to adjust their status will not be blocked by the latest measure.

The immediate impact of the order was not clear since most U.S. consulates around the world have already shuttered most immigration processing services. Doctors, nurses, and other healthcare professionals will be exempt, as will other prospective immigrants coming to the country to perform "essential" work to combat the new coronavirus, as determined by federal agencies.

The measure also excludes immigrants applying for the EB-5 visa program, which allows foreigners willing to invest large sums of money in U.S. projects that create or preserve jobs to obtain permanent residence. The order makes an exception for spouses of U.S. citizens and their unmarried children under the age of 21. The measure contains several other exemptions, including a general exemption for "any alien whose entry would be in the national interest."

The suspension will begin just before midnight on Thursday and last 60 days. After that, Trump will review U.S. economic conditions and decide whether it should be extended. Future extensions could potentially be longer than 60 days, Trump said this week. The executive order states that the administration will review all temporary visa programs - including guest worker programs - to determine if additional steps should be taken to protect U.S. workers.

Trump's latest immigration order draws on the same legal authority his administration cited in its 2017 travel ban that suspended the entry of travelers and immigrants from seven majority-Muslim nations. While that policy cited security concerns, critics dubbed it a "Muslim ban." Federal judges blocked several iterations of the ban from taking effect, but the Supreme Court eventually upheld a reworked version of the measure in 2018 and it continues to be in force and was expanded in January.

Some legal experts argue the high court's ruling does not permit a broad, worldwide ban on immigration into the United States and expect Trump's latest order to be challenged in court. The United States suspended routine visa services in most countries worldwide in mid-March due to the coronavirus outbreak, which was expected to dramatically slow legal immigration. In addition, countries around the world have closed their borders and enacted quarantines to limit the spread of the virus, greatly reducing travel worldwide.

Amid the global slowdown, the number of permanent residency visas issued by the State Department fell to around 24,000 in March, a 35% decrease from the previous month, according to department statistics published on Thursday. The number of temporary visas issued also decreased by roughly a third. Trump said on Tuesday that an immigration suspension would protect U.S. workers, an extension of the message he employed during his 2016 presidential campaign. However, researchers generally agree that immigration into the United States has actually stimulated economic growth, increased the size of the economy, and created jobs, according to Giovanni Peri, an economics professor at the University of California, Davis.

"The idea that immigration threatens American jobs is just not there in any data," he said.

Title: U.S. Special Forces Mission to Rescue American Hostage Luke Somers Fails; Al Qaeda in Yemen Issues Threatening Video

Article:

Hours before the Obama administration revealed a failed U.S. special forces mission to rescue American hostage Luke Somers in Yemen last month, al Qaeda's branch in the nation circulated a harrowing video giving Washington three days to meet unspecified demands or face "consequences" for Mr. Somers.

The video, which mimicked hostage videos released by AQAP's rivals from the Islamic State group, showed local al Qaeda commander Nasser bin Ali al-Ansi delivering a statement in Arabic and English. Al-Ansi criticized U.S.-led airstrikes against the Islamic State group and President Obama for his "latest foolish action," referring to the "failed operation" in Hadramawt. He warned the U.S. against future attempts to rescue hostages.

In the 3-minute video, Mr. Somers appeared somber and gave a brief statement in English, asking for help. The video was first reported by SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors militant sites. Mr. Somers, a 33-year-old photojournalist born in Britain, had been working in Yemen since 2011 as a freelancer for the Yemen Times when operatives from al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) kidnapped him in September 2013.

Officials at the White House and Pentagon said Thursday that President Obama had personally authorized last month's mission to rescue Mr. Somers, the lone American among roughly a dozen hostages held by AQAP in Yemen. The mission was coordinated with the Yemeni government and was undertaken by U.S. and Yemeni forces. Regrettably, Mr. Somers was not present, though hostages of other nationalities were rescued.

In light of Thursday's developments, Rep. Michael McCaul, the chairman of the House Committee on Homeland Security, warned the administration to proceed carefully and assertively in the Somers case. "This administration has already broken this policy once with the release of the Taliban Five, and in doing so allowed dangerous terrorists to resume the fight," he said.

"AQAP's latest threat against an American hostage reflects the unrelenting and pervasive brutality of Islamist extremist groups who are at war with the West," the Texas Republican added. "We must send a clear message to extremists: 'We will not negotiate with you. We will do everything in our power to stop you and bring you to justice.'"

Title: Sanders Aims to Gain Momentum with Wins in Kansas, Nebraska, and Maine

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont is seeking to revitalize his struggling presidential campaign this weekend, with the objective of winning three of the four state Democratic contests. The aim is to create momentum heading into Tuesday's crucial Michigan primary.

On Saturday, preliminary results indicated that Sanders was on track to achieve his goals. The Kansas Democratic Party declared Sanders the winner in their caucuses, and multiple news reports suggested he was leading in Nebraska. With 79% of the vote in from Nebraska, Sanders was at 55% compared to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's 45%.

Sanders' team is also targeting a win in Maine on Sunday. As anticipated, Clinton won Louisiana on Saturday, where approximately half of the electorate is black. Clinton has been performing strongly in polls with black voters, with over 80% of them voting for her.

Sanders, on the other hand, has performed well in states with predominantly white populations, who identify with his populist economic message. In the seven states he has won, they all rank among the 18 whitest in the country.

Sanders renewed his commitment to taking his campaign all the way to the convention on Saturday. "We have now won double-digit victories from New England to the Rocky Mountains to the Great Plains to the Midwest," he said in a statement. "Democrats in Kansas today added to a column of double-digit victories in Minnesota, Colorado, Oklahoma, New Hampshire, and Vermont."

"We have the momentum," he said. "We have a path toward victory. Our campaign is just getting started, and we are going all the way to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia."

Democrats had 109 delegates at stake on Saturday night, and Sanders needed to capture a majority of them to have a viable path to the White House. After Saturday's contests, Clinton led Sanders 1,104 to 446 in the delegate race. Either candidate needs 4,763 to win the party nomination.

After the Super Tuesday contests, where Sanders lost seven of the 11 caucuses and primaries to Clinton—six of which were held in the south—his campaign made winning Nebraska, Kansas, and Maine a priority. Sanders' first campaign stop after the March 1 contests was in Maine, and over one-fifth of his advertising spending since Super Tuesday has been dedicated to Kansas and Nebraska. Both states have embraced his authenticity, the fact that he's not beholden to corporate interests, and his proposals for debt-free university.

In Nebraska, where Democrats but not Republicans held county caucuses, large crowds and long lines were reported outside caucus locations on Saturday in the greater Omaha and Lincoln areas.

Kaitlin Heavin of Omaha was one of many young Sanders supporters who dominated the Sarpy County Caucus at Platteview High School in rural Springfield. "I don't hate Hillary, but I don't love her either," said Ms. Heavin, who wore a Sanders T-shirt. "I love Bernie."

Her friend Kim Anthony of Millard, who has two children with graduate degrees and hefty loans to show for it, cited Mr. Sanders' stance on reducing student debt. "I know he can't do everything, but if he can just do some of what he's talking about, he can get us on the right path," Ms. Anthony said.

In Kansas, Sanders held a pre-caucus rally in the liberal stronghold of Lawrence with the aim of attracting voters. Although Clinton had establishment support in the state with the backing of former Gov. Kathleen Sebelius, Sanders' supporters were able to overcome it.

With weekend wins, Sanders is looking to head into March 8 with momentum, as delegate-rich Michigan is up for grabs. Sanders' advisers have said his path to the nomination involves winning in industrial Midwestern states and targeting states like New York and California where many delegates are up for grabs.

Both candidates have been campaigning heavily in Michigan, and spent the weekend there. On Sunday, Sanders and Clinton will debate in Flint, Michigan. Clinton requested to debate in the city to highlight the poisoned water crisis. Both Clinton and Sanders have said if the city wasn't predominantly black and poor, the crisis may never have happened.

Sanders' campaign manager Jeff Weaver told reporters the team feels good about their chances in Michigan. "I think his message on trade in particular will be very powerful out there," Mr. Weaver said after his team's March 1 losses on the path ahead. "He has been a consistent opponent of the kind of job-gutting trade deals that Secretary Clinton has consistently supported for decades. And I think there will be some serious questions that will have to be answered by the Clinton campaign about why people should vote for a candidate who has voted for the type of trade deals that have gutted the economy in Michigan, Ohio, and other places."

Title: Hillary Clinton Affirms Retirement from Politics, but Speculation Persists

Article:

In an interview with Marie Claire magazine, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has stated that she has no plans to return to politics, including a potential 2016 presidential bid. Despite her assertions, speculation remains as to whether Clinton will indeed step away from politics or if her supporters hope for a change of heart.

Clinton, who has been out of politics for 20 years, expressed a desire to reclaim personal time and independence. "I have been on this high wire of national and international politics and leadership for 20 years," Clinton said. "It has been an absolutely extraordinary personal honor and experience. But I really want to just have my own time back. I want to just be my own person. I'm looking forward to that."

Clinton also expressed hope for a female president, stating, "That would be a great experience for me, to be up there cheering." A search for "Hillary Clinton for President" and "2016" on Google yields over 4 million hits, including several "Hillary for 2016" Facebook pages, indicating that her supporters may be holding out hope for a political comeback.

Despite her popularity, Clinton has faced criticism, particularly regarding the 2012 attack on the US diplomatic post in Benghazi, which resulted in the death of Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. In a CNN interview this week, Clinton attempted to quell the political firestorm surrounding the attack.

"I take responsibility," Clinton said. "I'm in charge of the State Department, 60,000-plus people all over the world, 275 posts. The president and the vice president certainly would not be knowledgeable about specific decisions that are made by security professionals. They're the ones who weigh all of the threats and the risks and the needs and make a considered decision."

Republican attacks have primarily been directed at President Obama, but Clinton was asked whether there was an attempt to undermine her potential 2016 chances. "That is just so far from anything that anybody should be thinking about," Clinton responded.

Clinton has been supported by a loyal staff known as "Hillaryland," many of whom have worked with her for years. Last summer, former director of policy planning Anne-Marie Slaughter caused a stir within the State Department when she wrote a controversial article in The Atlantic about the challenges of balancing high-level government work with family responsibilities. Slaughter, who is now a professor at Princeton University, was criticized by Clinton in the Marie Claire interview.

"Some women are not comfortable working at the pace and intensity you have to work at in these jobs… Other women do not break a sweat. They have four or five, six kids. They're highly organized, they have very supportive networks," Clinton said, emphasizing her own approach as a hands-on mother who prioritized her child while remaining committed to her work.

Clinton expressed little patience for those who fail to take advantage of their opportunities, stating, "I can't stand whining. I can't stand the kind of paralysis that some people fall into because they're not happy with the choices they've made. You live in a time when there are endless choices… But you have to work on yourself… Do something!"

Title: An Analysis of the Relationship Between America and Russia: A Historical and Contemporary Perspective

Article:

The relationship between America and Russia has been a complex and evolving one, marked by a series of events that have shaped the political landscape of both nations. The following is a neutral analysis of the relationship, based on the provided text, focusing on historical events and contemporary issues.

Recent events suggest a contentious relationship, with allegations of Russian involvement in the assassination of an ex-spy using a chemical weapon on British soil, interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, annexation of Crimea, and the downing of a passenger airliner in Ukraine. However, it is also noted that Russia has been a significant player in the Middle East, intervening in Syria, and providing safe haven for Edward Snowden.

Historically, the relationship between the two nations has been marked by significant shifts. The end of the Cold War saw Russia withdrawing from 700,000 square miles of Europe and Eurasia, and the implementation of economic reforms under Boris Yeltsin's government, which was met with resistance from the Russian population. American intervention, in the form of financial aid and political consultancy, was a contentious issue during this period.

The relationship between the two nations has been used as a symbol of Western self-doubt, reflecting various concerns and fears within Western societies. These range from doubts about the leadership class's commitment to the interests of their own people, to concerns about the impact of the post-Cold War program of freer movement of goods, capital, and people on their economies and political stability.

The text suggests that the relationship between America and Russia is often viewed through a lens of projection, with Russia being blamed for political developments in other countries, such as the rise of populist nationalist parties in Hungary and Poland. However, it is also noted that Russia is a nation with its own history, impelling national interests, and problems, and not merely a ghost written into the Western storyline.

In conclusion, the relationship between America and Russia is a complex one, shaped by historical events and contemporary issues. The text suggests that the relationship is often used as a symbol of Western self-doubt, reflecting various concerns and fears within Western societies. It is also noted that the relationship is often viewed through a lens of projection, with Russia being blamed for political developments in other countries. However, it is crucial to recognize that Russia is a nation with its own enduring interests, and its relationship with America should be understood in this context.

Title: The Limits of Presidential Influence on Economic Growth: A Neutral Analysis of Donald Trump's Job Creation Claims

Article:

In the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign, a significant portion of Donald Trump's appeal lies in the perceived unsatisfactory performance of the U.S. economy and his promise to improve it. Supporters argue that Trump's business acumen would enable him to restore manufacturing jobs, get tough with China and Mexico, and make America great again.

However, these ideas are largely unfounded, according to economists. In an economic speech in Detroit last month, Trump claimed he would "jump-start America," but economist John Cochrane of the free market Hoover Institution at Stanford University states that even the wildest campaign promises make little difference to the economy as a whole.

The economy is subject to numerous unpredictable factors, such as growth in China, oil production in Saudi Arabia, Britain's withdrawal from the European Union, and unforeseen events like terrorism, natural disasters, war, and financial crises. Demographic changes at home also play a role.

Presidents have limited control over the economy, with the Federal Reserve having more direct influence. The Fed, for years, has been using low interest rates and expansionary monetary policy to stimulate growth. However, growth has lagged, and the Fed has struggled to achieve its optimal annual growth rate of 2 percent.

Presidents face numerous constraints, including the need for legislation to implement major policy changes, which requires compromise with Congress. They do not control either spending or revenues, which are subject to the approval of lawmakers. Flows of cash are also susceptible to the ups and downs of the economy, which can raise or lower incoming amounts and outgoing obligations with no action by the people in power.

Trump's promise to create a net total of 25 million jobs over the next decade qualifies as utterly preposterous. The longest peacetime expansion in American history, which occurred under President Bill Clinton, fell short of that feat.
