The next president will face headwinds, such as sluggish growth abroad, an aging population, and an immigration slowdown, that Clinton did not.

The most important economics book of 2016, according to Northwestern University economist Robert Gordon, is The Rise and Fall of American Growth. The book makes an exhaustive case that the huge improvements in living standards during the 20th century were a unique phenomenon that cannot be repeated. Gordon contends, "America is riding on a slow-moving turtle. There is little that politicians can do about it."

While this view may be too pessimistic, it underscores the limited influence a president has on economic growth. Regardless of whether Trump is atop a turtle or a thoroughbred, he cannot make it gallop.

Title: Mitch McConnell Secures Victory Over Tea Party Challenger, GOP Incumbents Fare Well in Primary Elections

Article:

In the 2014 primary elections, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell secured a decisive victory over his tea party challenger Matt Bevin, overshadowing the night. The results indicate a resurgence of the once-iron law of politics: it is difficult to unseat a sitting member of Congress who is determined to hold onto their seat.

In three states on Tuesday, long-serving lawmakers defeated tea party opponents. Eight-term Idaho Rep. Mike Simpson fended off a challenger supported by the Club for Growth, while Rep. Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania easily dispatched an opponent once considered a tea party warrior.

McConnell's triumph over Bevin was the most significant event of the night. Bevin, a Louisville investor, was supported by outside groups such as the Senate Conservatives Fund and FreedomWorks. However, Bevin's campaign was unable to match McConnell's efforts, and his public image was severely damaged as McConnell's campaign scrutinized his record on issues such as bank bailouts and cockfighting.

The cost of winning renomination as a sitting Republican senator has more than doubled since 2002, according to an analysis of Federal Election Commission filings. Chris Chocola, the former Indiana congressman who now heads Club for Growth, stated, "We were able to sneak up on people in the past. There's no sneaking up on people anymore."

Since the start of the tea party wave in 2010, only a handful of Republican incumbents have lost primaries. However, conservative insurgents have scored major successes in open-seat races, such as Marco Rubio's primary win in 2010 and Ted Cruz's in 2012. The record of conservative insurgents against incumbents features fewer big victories, and in almost every case, the loser was a lawmaker who either underestimated the challenge or lacked the will to fight.

Republican campaign committees have taken notice and have been preparing their members for tough primaries. The National Republican Congressional Committee and the National Republican Senatorial Committee have held briefings and one-on-one meetings with sitting senators to emphasize the importance of working actively to secure the party nomination.

In Kentucky, McConnell thoroughly discredited Bevin as a conservative messenger. McConnell's campaign ran advertisements attacking Bevin for praising the Troubled Asset Relief Program bailouts while he was a financial executive, and McConnell's campaign manager, Jesse Benton, humiliated Bevin at a conservative rally with a pop quiz about the Constitution that Bevin failed.

Elsewhere, in primary fights that are still ongoing, incumbents have blunted or broken the momentum of hard-right challengers. In Kansas, Sen. Pat Roberts has watched a primary challenge from physician Milton Wolf falter and fade after revelations that Wolf posted images of X-rayed gunshot victims on his Facebook page. Mississippi Sen. Thad Cochran still faces a potentially competitive primary from state Sen. Chris McDaniel, but early fears that Cochran might collapse have subsided as McDaniel's record of incendiary statements and inconsistent support for Mississippi's federal priorities has been aired before the voters.

Title: Young Adult Enrollment in ObamaCare Lags Behind Expected Goals, Concerns Raised by Insurers

Article:

Insurers have expressed concerns over the low number of young adults signing up for health insurance through the ObamaCare exchanges, as newly released statistics showed that less than a quarter of people who have enrolled are between the ages of 18 and 34. According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, only 24 percent – or 489,460 – of the 2.2 million people who signed up for the Affordable Care Act (ACA) were in the coveted 18-to-34 age range. This means the government has hit only 18 percent of its stated goal of registering 2.7 million adults in the 18-to-34 age range.

Experts have predicted that the program will need roughly 40 percent of enrollees to be in that prime demographic to be fiscally solvent. Adults ages 55 to 64 made up 33 percent of the total number of Americans who signed up, the largest group represented in the data.

ObamaCare needs so-called 'invincibles' – healthy young adults – to sign up in coming months to help offset the costs of older and less healthy enrollees. If that doesn't happen, insurers could be forced to raise the rates, making the costs and future of ObamaCare uncertain.

Marty Anderson, marketing director for Wisconsin-based Security Health Plan, told the Wall Street Journal, "This is concerning that we're seeing this portion come in so old." Allan Einboden, chief executive of Scott & White Health Plan, told the Journal that the data was "more negative than we thought it was going to be," and added that several requests to pre-authorize surgeries for enrollees in the first days of their coverage had executives worried about costs.

Robert Laszewski, a consultant who works with insurers, told The New York Times, "You need healthy people of all ages... the program is not ramping up fast enough to guarantee a good balance of healthy and sick people, which you need to sustain the program."

Administration officials, however, were upbeat in describing the numbers Monday. They said they're in a "solid place," and noted that this age group makes up just 26 percent of the general population. Monday's report was the first time the government has released demographic data on the performance of President Obama's signature health care overhaul. In all, about 1.8 million people enrolled in new individual health plans through the law in December, bringing the total number of new enrollments between Oct. 1 and Dec. 28 to about 2.2 million.

"There's no way to spin it: youth enrollment has been a bust so far," said Brendan Buck, a spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner, in a statement following the release. "When they see that ObamaCare offers high costs for limited access to doctors – if the enrollment goes through at all – it's no surprise that young people are not rushing to sign up."

As analysts have told ███, insurance companies have said they may want to take advantage of the "risk pool" provisions – which involve the federal government covering 80 percent of any losses associated with an older and unhealthier base of customers.

According to HHS, 79 percent of ObamaCare customers selected a plan with financial assistance. While only 2.2 million people have actually signed up, 44.5 million called or visited state and federal websites.

Of the 2.2 million who have signed up, 54 percent are female and 46 percent are male, HHS said. Individuals and families are able to choose from four plans offered through the federal marketplace – bronze, silver, gold, and platinum. Sixty percent selected a silver plan, while 20 percent selected a bronze plan, according to HHS.

Title: Johnson & Johnson Settles Ohio Opioid Lawsuit for $20 Million Ahead of Federal Trials

Article:

Pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson has reached a settlement of $20 million with two Ohio counties, Cuyahoga and Summit, to avoid a federal trial over the opioid epidemic's corporate responsibility. The settlement, which includes Cleveland and Akron, is a significant step in the ongoing litigation over the opioid crisis, which has claimed over 400,000 lives in the past two decades.

The Ohio settlement, set to commence on October 21, is the first in a series of federal trials aimed at determining the extent of opioid painkiller manufacturers', distributors', and pharmacy chains' liability for the worst drug epidemic in American history. A second trial is scheduled for West Virginia in January. The outcomes of these and other test cases will shape a broad settlement covering numerous federal lawsuits across the United States.

Until now, Johnson & Johnson has maintained its innocence in the opioid crisis, refusing to settle similar lawsuits and denying any responsibility. However, in August, the company lost a landmark case in Oklahoma, where a judge found Johnson & Johnson instrumental in causing addiction and death due to a "false and dangerous" sales campaign that contributed to the crisis. The state of Oklahoma sued the company, alleging it ran a "cunning, cynical, and deceitful scheme" to mass-market opioid painkillers with false claims of minimal addiction risk. The judge ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $572 million in the first year of a longer-term settlement.

Johnson & Johnson made no admission of liability in the Ohio settlement and stated that the agreement was reached to direct resources toward addressing the opioid crisis. However, law professor Carl Tobias of the University of Richmond suggested that the Oklahoma loss may have influenced the company's decision, as it may have reconsidered litigating every case due to potential liability exposure.

It remains uncertain whether Johnson & Johnson will settle with hundreds of other litigants, potentially totaling hundreds of millions to billions of dollars. However, most drug-makers have reportedly folded as the trial approaches, apparently wary of larger payouts. Johnson & Johnson's retreat came days after one of the largest opioid manufacturers, Mallinckrodt, reached a $30 million deal with the two Ohio counties. Two other companies, Endo and Allergan, agreed to settlements earlier. This leaves only one manufacturer, Teva, still fighting the case alongside pharmacy chain Walgreens and drug distributors, which are some of the largest corporations in the US, despite their names not being widely known.

The remaining trial may provide an unwelcome focus on the role of distributors such as Cardinal Health and McKesson, which shipped millions of opioid pills into small communities. Law professor Tobias suggested that this will add to the pressure on them to settle before the trial. "They should be feeling the pressure because they're the deepest pockets left. They may settle to avoid a substantial settlement. They may want to avoid a huge verdict at the beginning," he said.

Separately, Purdue Pharma, the drug-maker that initiated the epidemic with its powerful opioid OxyContin, has reached a tentative deal potentially worth several billion dollars with some states, using bankruptcy to remake the company as a trust and surrender future profits toward addiction treatment and prevention.

Title: Boehner's Re-election as House Speaker Seems Imminent Despite Fiscal-Cliff Controversy

Article:

In the aftermath of the fiscal-cliff debate, House Speaker John Boehner appears to be on track for re-election as the top Republican in the House of Representatives on Thursday. Two GOP congressmen, Rep. Mike Grimm of New York and Chris Smith of New Jersey, who earlier criticized Boehner, have now endorsed him for a second term.

With these endorsements and a lack of viable alternatives, many observers believe Boehner is on track for another year as Speaker. A potential challenge centered around an aid package for victims of Superstorm Sandy, but even that issue seems to have passed.

"Whatever's done is done, and that's it," declared Rep. Pete King of New York on Wednesday afternoon after a meeting with Boehner and Majority Leader Eric Cantor in which GOP leaders pledged to allow a vote on $9 billion in aid for victims of the record-breaking storm. A second vote on the remaining $51 billion will come on Jan. 15.

"The bottom line is we need the $60 billion," King said. "We have gotten that solid commitment."

Earlier Wednesday, King and several other members of the New York-New Jersey congressional delegation had criticized Boehner for not allowing a vote on the aid to come to the House floor. However, King later stated that his anger at Boehner was in the past.

"As far as I'm concerned, that was a lifetime ago," he said after the meeting with Boehner and Cantor, according to the Hill. "The bottom line is we are getting the result that we need."

Ron Meyer, a spokesman for the conservative group American Majority Action, which was among several calling for Boehner's ouster, acknowledged that House Republicans do not have a viable alternative to Boehner.

"It turns out no one else seems willing to pick up the mantle," he said on Wednesday. "I hesitate to say it, but this goes to some degree to cowardice."

"You can't beat somebody with nobody," added a senior House Republican to the National Journal on Wednesday.

Boehner's speakership seems all but certain to survive several challenges in recent months. Two weeks ago, dozens of GOP legislators refused to support Boehner's "Plan B" fiscal-cliff proposal that would have staved off rising tax rates for most Americans. The party split capped an extensive day of lobbying and arm-twisting of the GOP rank and file, which included a late-night meeting Boehner called to determine whether he had enough votes for approval.

That not being the case, Majority Leader Cantor announced that no vote would be held—and Boehner himself was spotted leaving the Capitol shortly thereafter.

Much of the criticism centered around conservative GOP legislators and outside groups seeing Boehner as too willing to compromise with the White House and Democrats on taxes and other fiscal issues. And last month, Boehner stripped four Republicans—including three heavily supported by the Tea Party Patriots—from their coveted committee seats. The move created tension within the GOP ranks.

However, other conservative groups were joining with American Majority Action to attack Boehner for his support of the fiscal-cliff bill that was negotiated by Vice President Joe Biden and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, according to the National Journal. Boehner was among just 85 House Republicans ultimately supporting the measure. But Cantor and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy of California voted against it. They were among 151 House GOP members to do so.

Title: White House Maintains Neutral Stance on FBI's Clinton Email Investigation Developments

Article:

White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest has stated that he would neither defend nor criticize Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) Director James Comey's decision to announce new developments in the Hillary Clinton email investigation, a stance that contrasts with the criticism from the Clinton campaign and other Democrats.

On Friday, Mr. Comey revealed that the FBI was looking into new evidence related to an investigation of the Democratic presidential nominee's email. This news has once again put Mrs. Clinton's email troubles, which were thought to be largely behind her, back in the spotlight.

In remarks in Ohio on Monday, Mrs. Clinton said there was "no case here" and questioned the agency's motives in announcing the developments just 11 days before the presidential election. A day earlier, Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid accused Mr. Comey of violating a law barring federal officials from using their position to influence an election. In a letter to Mr. Comey, Mr. Reid wrote: "I led the fight to get you confirmed [by the Senate] because I believed you to be a principled public servant. With the deepest regret, I now see that I was wrong."

However, Mr. Earnest said President Barack Obama thought Mr. Comey a man of integrity. "The president believes that Director Comey is a man of integrity, he's a man of principle and he's a man of good character," Mr. Earnest said.

Mr. Comey announced in a letter to congressional committee chairmen on Friday that the FBI would look into new emails related to the investigation of Mrs. Clinton. The newly-found emails surfaced as a result of a probe into former Rep. Anthony Weiner, the estranged husband of Mrs. Clinton's long-time aide, Huma Abedin.

In a separate development, it has been reported that interim Democratic National Committee chair Donna Brazile shared a primary debate question with the Clinton campaign, according to hacked emails released by WikiLeaks. The authenticity of the emails has not been independently verified.

Title: CNN's Don Lemon Sparks Controversy with Claim that Jesus Christ Was Not Perfect

Article:

CNN anchor Don Lemon, who identifies as Baptist and was educated in a Catholic school, has sparked controversy with his recent comments suggesting that Jesus Christ was not perfect during His time on earth. In a conversation with fellow CNN anchor Chris Cuomo, Lemon stated, "Jesus Christ — if that’s who you believe in, Jesus Christ — admittedly was not perfect when He was here on this earth."

The statement, made on the Monday morning edition of Newswatch on the ███ News Channel, has been met with criticism from several Christian leaders. Dr. Derwin L. Gray, a pastor based in North Carolina, responded to Lemon's comments on Twitter, stating, "Good sir, Jesus was perfect. He had no sin. He is the unblemished Lamb of God who takes away the sins of the world."

The belief in Jesus' perfection is central to the substitutionary atonement, a doctrinal belief that Jesus died for humanity, granting salvation to those who put their faith in the Son of God. The Bible states that Jesus lived a sinless life while on earth, with passages such as 1 Peter 2:22, 2 Corinthians 5:21, 1 Peter 1:19, and Hebrews 7:26 attesting to His sinlessness.

Thomas Aquinas, an Italian priest, defined sin as "an utterance, a deed, or a desire contrary to the eternal law." Given that God's character is the basis for this eternal law, going against it would be a direct contradiction to His nature, making sin an impossibility for Jesus. Catholic teaching, like evangelical Christian theology, affirms that Jesus was "like us in all things, except sin."

Lemon's comments have been met with criticism for their inaccuracy, with some suggesting that, given his background, he should have been more aware of the Christian doctrine he was discussing. It remains unclear if Lemon's comments were intended to be taken literally or were made in a more figurative sense.

Title: Media Bias and the Clinton Email Scandal: A Neutral Analysis of Washington Post Columnists' Perspective

Article:

In a recent column for The Washington Post, Dana Milbank and Ruth Marcus, both Yale-educated journalists, have expressed their views on the ongoing controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State. Both columnists have criticized Clinton for her decision, with Milbank's column titled "Hunkered Hillary made things worse" and Marcus's column stating, "The greatest irony may be that the Clintonian urge for privacy produces the opposite of what she needs."

Both columnists argue that Clinton's use of a private email server was a self-inflicted wound on her campaign, rather than evidence of wrongdoing. Milbank's column primarily rebuts Donald Trump's nickname for Clinton, "Crooked Hillary," stating that investigations into her activities have not yielded substantial evidence of wrongdoing.

The columnists' criticism of Clinton's email scandal is met with a critique of their perceived bias towards Clinton. They are accused of downplaying the significance of the email scandal and the potential conflicts of interest associated with the Clinton Foundation. The column argues that the media, particularly liberal media, have not held Clinton accountable for her actions, instead focusing on investigating and "getting the goods" on Republican politicians.

The article also highlights the discrepancy in media coverage of the Clinton Foundation, comparing the minimal coverage of the foundation's potential conflicts of interest to the extensive coverage of the "Bridgegate" scandal involving Chris Christie. The article suggests that the media have allowed the Clinton Foundation to operate with minimal scrutiny, even after reporters exposed potential rule-breaking.

In conclusion, the article presents a neutral analysis of the perspectives of Dana Milbank and Ruth Marcus on the Clinton email scandal and the Clinton Foundation, highlighting the perceived bias of the columnists and the discrepancy in media coverage of the two scandals. The article does not take a political stance, but instead presents the facts and allows readers to draw their own conclusions.

Title: CNN and MSNBC Devote Significant Airtime to Debunked Hydroxychloroquine Study

Article:

On May 22, CNN and MSNBC dedicated substantial airtime to a now-retracted study that claimed taking hydroxychloroquine while battling COVID-19 could be fatal. CNN devoted 90 minutes and 54 seconds, while MSNBC's total was 19 minutes and 19 seconds.

The Media Research Center (MRC) analyzed every hour of live programming from CNN and MSNBC on May 22, and, in the case of CNN shows and MSNBC primetime, backed up by Nexis transcripts. Since the study went live just before 9:00 a.m. Eastern, each of the 10 subsequent CNN shows covered the study. On MSNBC, nine shows featured it.

As of this study's publication, MSNBC has ignored the retraction, while CNN has only given it one minute and 45 seconds during The Lead with Jake Tapper.

The study, published in The Lancet, was retracted on Thursday due to a myriad of problems, ranging from skepticism of its accuracy to bizarre ethical issues about one of the companies involved. The study was not fully peer-reviewed, a hallmark for ensuring that studies hold weight and actually found what they stated.

The Hill reported that the study's authors retracted it because independent peer reviewers could not access the data used for the analysis. The source of the data was Surgisphere Corporation, which told peer reviewers it would not transfer the full dataset used for the study because it would violate client agreements and confidentiality requirements.

The Lancet wrote in a statement that it "takes issues of scientific integrity extremely seriously" and that there are "many outstanding questions about Surgisphere and the data that were allegedly included in this study."

Over the following days, more information emerged about Surgisphere, including an investigation from The Guardian that Surgisphere had some questionable hires for a healthcare company, including a "science fiction writer and an adult-content model."

Despite the study's flaws and subsequent retraction, CNN and, to a lesser extent, MSNBC continued to discuss the study without questioning its accuracy. For example, during the May 22 airing of CNN Newsroom, co-hosts Poppy Harlow and Jim Sciutto were enthralled, trumpeting the "expansive study" as "big news" and a "major development" that spelled "real danger" for patients taking hydroxychloroquine.

On MSNBC, Rachel Maddow fretted that the study signaled Trump's promotion of hydroxychloroquine had "moved on from absurd and sort of insane to a potentially deadly threat." Similarly, during the May 22 airing of Morning Joe, hosts Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski shared the breaking news and expressed concern about the study's findings.

However, as more information has come to light, it has become clear that the study was flawed and inaccurate, and its retraction should have prompted a reevaluation of the initial coverage. It is essential for news organizations to fact-check and verify the information they present to the public, especially in times of crisis.

Title: Tea Party Patriots Launch SuperPAC for 2014 Midterm Elections

Article:

The Tea Party Patriots Citizens Fund SuperPAC was launched on Monday, with the aim of focusing on key Senate races during the 2014 midterm elections. The organization, led by Jenny Beth Martin, president and co-founder of the parent group, aims to empower grassroots activists to have a significant impact in targeted districts and states.

According to Martin, the organization is currently collaborating with activists in South Carolina and Kentucky, where they are seeking alternatives to Senators Lindsey Graham and Mitch McConnell, respectively. The organization plans to expand its mission into Mississippi, Nebraska, Louisiana, Arkansas, and North Carolina races.

Martin described the Citizens Fund as "community organizing for conservatives," differentiating it from other Super PACs due to its grassroots activist network across the country. The organization has also initiated an early-bird presidential straw poll, reflecting the interests of its membership. The candidates in contention are Republican Senators Ted Cruz of Texas, Rand Paul of Kentucky, Marco Rubio of Florida, Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, and Sarah Palin.

In Kentucky, there are interesting dynamics afoot. According to pollster Scott Rasmussen, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell runs even with Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes in the 2014 U.S. Senate race. However, McConnell's GOP primary rival Matt Bevin leads Grimes by six points, with 48% support compared to Grimes' 42%.

Matt Kibbe, president of FreedomWorks for America, a liberty-minded, low-tax group, stated, "The results of this poll are clear. Matt Bevin has a stronger chance at defeating the Democrat in the general election. Anybody interested in protecting this Republican Senate seat needs to revisit the premise that a do-nothing incumbent is a safe bet. To beat Grimes in November, we have to ditch Mitch."

Title: Bill on Amnesty for Illegal Immigrants Does Not Include Requirement for Back Taxes

Article:

Jon Feere, legal policy analyst at the Center for Immigration Studies, has stated that claims from amnesty advocates suggesting the bill contains a requirement for illegal immigrants to pay back taxes for their years working off the books are inaccurate. The bill only requires illegal immigrants to resolve any existing issues with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) if they have been audited and requested payment of unpaid taxes.

According to Feere, approximately 45 percent of illegal immigrants, who are estimated to be working off the books, are not on the IRS's radar and are highly unlikely to have ever been audited due to the lack of tax forms to audit. The number of illegal immigrants who have been audited by the IRS is also likely small, as the IRS historically audits only about 1 percent of tax filers.

The current tax provision in the bill will not affect the overwhelming majority of illegal immigrants applying for amnesty. At least one amendment has been offered to require payment of back taxes for the period that amnesty applicants have worked illegally in the United States.

Additionally, the bill does not require employers of illegal immigrants to pay FICA taxes for the years they paid illegal immigrants under the table.

The lack of a back-taxes provision in the bill is not surprising, as Sen. Charles Schumer (D-NY) snuck a provision into a tax law following the 1986 amnesty becoming law, barring amnesty adjudicators from sharing the tax information of amnesty applicants with the IRS. Schumer reasoned that a successful legalization program could not be achieved if an alien became vulnerable to an enforcement action by the IRS upon submitting an application. Similarly, the Bush administration requested Congress strip a back-taxes provision from the failed 2007 amnesty bill.

Title: Gun Rights Activists Accuse Katie Couric of Deceptive Editing in Documentary

Article:

Gun rights activists from the Virginia Citizens Defense League have accused Katie Couric of deceptive editing in the documentary "Under the Gun," in which they participated in a roundtable discussion. The controversy revolves around a clip that appears to show nine seconds of silence after Couric asked the activists, "If there are no background checks for gun purchasers, how do you prevent felons or terrorists from purchasing a gun?"

Audio released to the Washington Free Beacon reveals that the activists immediately answered a similar question posed by Couric. Director Stephanie Soechtig told The Washington Post that the pause was intended to allow viewers to consider the question. Couric has expressed support for the film and is "very proud of the film."

However, some critics, including the Independent Women's Forum, have expressed outrage over the film's portrayal of the activists. Culture of Alarmism Director Julie Gunlock issued a statement on Wednesday, calling for Couric to be fired. Gunlock stated, "Katie Couric should be ashamed of herself for her dishonest and distorted reporting on this issue... Like serial fabricator Brian Williams, Couric should be fired. Her tactics have been exposed, and Americans should never again trust her to report on these important issues."

Social media users, including Mark Hemingway, Jen M, and Ursula Hennessey, have also criticized Couric for the alleged deceptive editing. The National Rifle Association (NRA) has also weighed in, calling the edits "outrageous" and "unbelievable," and urging Couric to explain the editing.

"Under the Gun" premiered on May 15 on Epix and first screened at the Sundance Film Festival in January.

Title: Trudeau Wins Second Term as Canadian Prime Minister Despite Scandals and Loss of Majority

Article:

In the Canadian national elections held on October 21, 2019, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau secured a second term, albeit without a majority in Parliament. The Liberal party, led by Trudeau, took the most seats, providing them with the best opportunity to form a government. However, falling short of a majority means the Liberals will have to rely on an opposition party to pass legislation.

Robert Bothwell, a professor of Canadian history and international relations at the University of Toronto, commented, "Trudeau is prime minister because the rest of the party was able to pull itself together and prevail. While Trudeau certainly deserves credit for what has happened, he’s really going to have to demonstrate qualities that he hasn’t yet shown."

The results were a surprise given the series of scandals that tarnished Trudeau's image, particularly the resurfacing of old photos showing him in blackface and brownface. Nelson Wiseman, a political science professor at the University of Toronto, noted, "I’m surprised at how well Trudeau has done. I don’t think anybody expected Trudeau to get a majority, but they are not that far off."

With results still trickling in early Tuesday, the Liberals had 156 seats, 14 short of the 170 needed for a majority in the 338-seat House of Commons. In his early Tuesday address, Trudeau stated, "Tonight Canadians rejected division and negativity. They rejected cuts and austerity. They elected a progressive agenda and strong action on climate change."

The Canadian vote was essentially a choice between Trudeau and Andrew Scheer, the unassuming leader of the Conservative Party, who was seen as the antidote to Trudeau's flashy and celebrity-laden image. Barack Obama, the former American president, made an unprecedented endorsement by a former U.S. president, urging Canadians to re-elect Trudeau and stating the world needs his progressive leadership.

Andrew Scheer, 40, is a career politician who was seen as a potential antidote to Trudeau's flashiness. However, Robert Bothwell, a professor of Canadian history and international relations at the University of Toronto, stated late Monday that he expected Scheer to resign, saying, "He’s gone. He ran a really dirty campaign. There is nothing to be proud of on his side. He had the opportunity and blew it."

In his concession speech, Scheer said the results showed Trudeau was much weakened since his 2015 election, when pundits had predicted the beginning of another Trudeau dynasty. Scheer stated, "Tonight Conservatives have put Justin Trudeau on notice. And Mr. Trudeau, when your government falls, Conservatives will be ready, and we will win."

Trudeau was also hurt by a scandal that erupted this year when his former attorney general said he pressured her to halt the prosecution of a Quebec company. Trudeau has said he was standing up for jobs, but the damage gave a boost to the Conservative Party.

The Liberal party will likely rely on the New Democrats to form a new government and pass legislation. Opposition New Democrat leader Jagmeet Singh stated early Tuesday that he had congratulated Trudeau and vowed to play a constructive role in Parliament.

The results left the Conservatives deeply disappointed. Nelson Wiseman, a political science professor at the University of Toronto, commented, "The Conservatives are deeply disappointed. Scheer had promised to end a national carbon tax and cut government spending, including foreign aid, by 25 percent."

Trudeau's efforts to strike a balance on the environment and the economy have been criticized by both the right and left. He brought in a carbon tax to fight climate change but rescued a stalled pipeline expansion project to get Alberta's oil to international markets. His legalization of cannabis nationwide and his efforts to strike a new free trade deal for Canada with the U.S. and Mexico have also been points of contention.

Trump, who has clashed with Trudeau over trade, tweeted his congratulations early Tuesday, saying, "Canada is well served."

Title: Christmas Reflection: Jesus' Birth and the Refugee Experience

Article:

As Christmas approaches, the over two billion Christians worldwide reflect on the significance of the holiday, focusing on the story of Jesus' birth. While the celebration is observed with varying levels of intensity, those who prioritize the religious aspect of Christmas emphasize the central role of Jesus in the festivities.

Jay Parini, a poet, novelist, and professor at Middlebury College in Vermont, highlights this focus in his book "Jesus: The Human Face of God." Parini's opinions, as expressed in this commentary, are solely his own.

The story of Jesus' birth, as recounted in the Bible, is a poignant narrative that combines elements of joy and terror. A young family from Galilee arrives in a small town as strangers, with the pregnant mother unable to find a place to stay. Upon the child's birth, magi, or wise men, travel from the East to worship him, unintentionally alerting a malevolent king to the newborn's existence. The king, fearing the child as a potential rival, orders a massacre of infants in an attempt to eliminate him. An angel then appears to Joseph, instructing him to flee with his family to Egypt, making Jesus a refugee in search of a safe haven.

Parini emphasizes the importance of Jesus' message during this season, urging love as a means to combat hate, whether from King Herod or contemporary figures like al-Baghdadi. The story of Jesus' birth serves as a reminder of the plight of refugees, a situation that continues to affect millions worldwide.

Title: President Obama Discusses Daughters' Upbringing and Perception of Wealth

Article:

In an interview for the Amazon Kindle store, President Barack Obama discussed the unique living situation of his daughters, Sasha and Malia, and the steps he takes to ensure they understand the abnormal nature of their White House lifestyle.

"We are constantly reminding Malia and Sasha of the slightly unreal environment that they're in, and that that's not the norm and they should not expect to be the norm," Obama said.

The President explained that having relatives who do not live like the commander-in-chief, and even struggle to get by, has kept his children grounded. "One of the advantages we have is that we still have family members who are not only middle class, but we've got some family members who are poor," he told Amazon editor David Blum.

Obama further elaborated that Malia and Sasha have cousins who understand the struggle of making ends meet, and that they recognize the worth of these family members despite their circumstances. "They know that those kids are just as worthy as they are, they just haven't had as much luck," he said.

The President, who spoke at an Amazon.com distribution plant in Tennessee on Tuesday, also addressed the distorted sense of wealth that children, even those not living in the White House, may have. "If you look back on your childhood, or if I talk to my friends, all of us have that same impression when we go back home and we realize that the place where we were living was pretty small," he said.

Obama noted that a cultural shift has occurred, with a constant barrage of made-for-television wealth changing what kids consider a normal life. Traditional benchmarks of success, such as a home, job, education, health care, and retirement, are no longer deemed sufficient, he said.

"There was not that window into the lifestyles of the rich and famous," he said. "Kids were not monitoring every day what Kim Kardashian was wearing, or where Kanye West was going on vacation, and thinking that somehow that was the mark of success."

Title: North Korea Conducts Submarine Ballistic Missile Test, Claims Weapon Capable of Striking "Hostile Forces"

Article:

North Korea has reportedly conducted an underwater test-firing of a submarine ballistic missile (SLBM), according to the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) on Saturday. The test, which took place near Sinpo South Shipyard on the east coast, is said to have proven the missile's ability to meet the latest military science and technology requirements.

The North's state-run Rodong Sinmun newspaper published photos of a projectile rising from the surface and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un smiling from a distance at what looked like a floating submarine. Kim described the missile as a "world-level strategic weapon" and an "eye-opening success."

Kim declared that his military now has a weapon capable of "striking and wiping out in any waters the hostile forces infringing upon the sovereignty and dignity of (North Korea)," according to KCNA. The news agency report said the missiles "soared into the sky from underwater."

Experts in Seoul suggest that the North's military demonstrations and hostile rhetoric are attempts at wresting concessions from the United States and South Korea, whose officials have recently discussed the possibility of holding preliminary talks to test North Korea's commitment to denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.

In recent years, North Korea has expressed a desire to resume talks aimed at denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula. The last public U.S. attempt to restart the six-party process, involving China, Japan, Russia, South Korea, North Korea, and the U.S., collapsed in 2012 after the North launched a long-range rocket. Pyongyang conducted its third nuclear test in February 2013, and has test-fired numerous shorter-range missiles since then.

In January, the U.S. again proposed a meeting with North Korea, but the bid failed to gain traction. This week, South Korean envoy Hwang Joon Kook said, after meeting with his U.S. and Chinese counterparts, that all five parties are ready once again to test North Korea's intentions on talks.

North Korea also threatened to fire at South Korean naval vessels it claims have been violating its territorial waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula. South Korea's presidential Blue House held an emergency national security council meeting to review the threat and discuss possible countermeasures.

Intelligence sources from Seoul and Washington claim that Pyongyang has been developing a SLBM, which could represent a new threat to South Korea. The sources tell South Korea's Yonghap news agency that the North has succeeded in installing a missile launcher onto the submarine after conducting a series of experiments on shore as well as underwater.

Ministry officials have previously said that North Korea has about 70 submarines and appears to be mainly imitating Russian designs in its efforts to develop a system for submarine-launched missiles. North Korea is believed to have obtained several of the Soviet Navy's retired Golf-class ballistic missile submarines in the mid-1990s.

The move is seen as part of efforts by North Korea to equip its missiles with miniaturized nuclear bombs. If so, that would mean the Pyongyang has developed a naval strike capability that is at least a decade ahead of the South, according to Yonghap news agency, quoting unidentified "North Korea watchers."

The South Korean navy has just laid out a plan to build six 3,000-ton submarines equipped with vertical missile launchers between 2027 and 2030, the South Korean agency says.

Title: Biden Addresses Allegations of Inappropriate Touching, Vows to Change Campaign Style

Former Vice President Joe Biden, a potential 2020 presidential candidate, joked about past allegations of making women uncomfortable through physical contact during a speech on Friday. In a speech before the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Biden joked about seeking permission before hugging a labor union president and putting his arm around a boy he invited onstage.

Biden's conduct has been under scrutiny in the past week as several women have claimed they felt uncomfortable due to hugs, shoulder grasps, and other close physical contact initiated by Biden during his career. During a question-and-answer session after the speech, Biden stated he was "sorry that I didn't understand more" when asked if he would directly apologize to the women. He clarified, "I'm not sorry for my intentions. I'm not sorry for anything I've ever done."

Biden acknowledged that his intentions were not the issue and that he would need to change his campaign style to ensure consent before touching anyone, regardless of his intentions. He also conceded that his conduct might affect his campaigning methods moving forward.

Biden stated he is "very close" to announcing his 2020 presidential bid, but is being cautious with his words to avoid starting the campaign clock. He also dismissed the label of being a moderate, stating he wished he had been labeled as such when he ran for the Senate seven times. Biden contended that the majority of Democratic Party members are still liberal-to-moderate Democrats in the traditional sense.

President Trump, who has been accused by more than a dozen women of inappropriate sexual contact, defended a tweet he posted earlier this week showing a parody video of Biden being approached from behind by a second Biden who rubs his shoulders. When asked if he was the "right messenger" for that, Trump responded, "I think I am a very good messenger." Trump also stated that he did not view Biden as a threat, adding, "I think he's only a threat to himself."

After Biden's speech, Trump tweeted that union workers would be voting for him instead.

Title: Twelve Republican Senators Join Democrats to Terminate President Trump's National Emergency Declaration

Article:

Twelve Republican senators joined forces with Democrats on Thursday to pass a resolution terminating the national emergency declared by President Trump last month. The 59-41 vote was a rare bipartisan rebuke of Trump, who will now issue the first veto of his presidency to preserve the emergency declaration.

The Senate GOP dissenters, including Lamar Alexander, Roy Blunt, Susan Collins, Mike Lee, Jerry Moran, Lisa Murkowski, Rand Paul, Rob Portman, Mitt Romney, Marco Rubio, Pat Toomey, and Roger Wicker, span the ideological spectrum from conservative to moderate. Most argued that the president was operating outside the rule of law, while some simply called the emergency declaration an executive overreach that Congress had a duty to stop.

Senator Lamar Alexander, who plans to retire after three terms representing Tennessee rather than seek reelection next year, stated, "Never before has a president asked for funding, Congress has not provided it, and the president then has used the National Emergencies Act of 1976 to spend the money anyway. The problem with this is that after a Revolutionary War against a king, our nation's founders gave to Congress the power to approve all spending so that the president would not have too much power. This check on the executive is a crucial source of our freedom."

Senator Collins, the moderate from Maine who is the only senator facing a 2020 reelection campaign among the twelve Republicans to vote for the resolution, argued in a floor speech that Trump's declaration failed to pass the longstanding five-part test of a genuine emergency: "necessary, sudden, urgent, unforeseen, and not permanent."

Senator Mitt Romney, who took a hard-line stance against illegal immigration during his 2012 presidential campaign, stated, "This is not a vote against border security. In fact, I agree that a physical barrier is urgently needed to help ease the humanitarian crisis at the southern border, and the administration already has $4.5 billion available within existing authority to fund a barrier—even without an emergency declaration."

Senator Mike Lee, who thought Trump's declaration was legal under the 1976 National Emergencies Act, was willing to uphold it if the law could be changed to curb the power it gives the executive. However, when a deal to pass Lee's Article One Act, which would have satisfied his concerns, fell through, he decided to vote "no."

Two of the more surprising votes against terminating the national emergency were those cast by Thom Tillis of North Carolina and Ben Sasse of Nebraska, both of whom face reelection in 2020. Tillis had been expressing disapproval of the emergency declaration for weeks, while Sasse has generally voiced more public criticism of President Trump than any other Republican in the Senate.

Senator Ben Sasse said in a statement, "The National Emergencies Act (NEA) is 'overly broad and I want to fix it, but at present Nancy Pelosi doesn't, so I am therefore voting against her politically motivated resolution.' As a constitutional conservative, I believe that the NEA currently on the books should be narrowed considerably. That's why I'm an original sponsor of Senator Lee's legislation, and it is why I have repeatedly gone to the White House to seek support for NEA reform."

Republican senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, who voted to uphold the emergency, spoke for the vast majority of Senate Republicans when he took the floor to argue that there is a genuine emergency on the Southern border and that President Trump's declaration was both legal and proper. "Since last October, Border Patrol agents have apprehended more than 260,000 illegal aliens at the border, a surge of 90 percent—almost double—from the previous year," he said. "He [Trump] is only exercising the statutory authority delegated to him by us."

While Cotton said he respects colleagues who worry about a slippery slope, he dismissed that objection because Congress has "not delegated to the executive the power to confiscate guns, close power plants, or any of the other common entrants in the parade of horribles on the slippery slope. That's the difference between lawful and lawless government, and it's the case here."

"If you want to see lawless executive action, by the way, you can look instead to the last administration," Cotton added. "President Obama purported to give millions of illegal aliens legal status and work permits in clear violation of statutes passed by Congress. Strange how I don't recall the self-styled 'Resistance' manning the ramparts and rushing to the Ninth Circuit back then. In fact, I only recall congressional fanboys of a president using the 'pen and phone' to encroach on our constitutional prerogatives."

In 2014, when the House voted to rescind President Obama's DACA program for illegal immigrants who arrived as minors, only four Democrats joined most Republicans to rebuke what many said was an unconstitutional action. Democrats controlled the Senate at the time, and Majority Leader Harry Reid never brought the legislation opposing DACA up for a vote.

Title: Sen. Bernie Sanders Defends Record, Highlights Policy Stances Ahead of 2016 Democratic Presidential Nominating Contest

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a candidate for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, defended his political record on Wednesday, emphasizing his opposition to free trade agreements and his efforts to regulate Wall Street banks.

In an interview on CNN's "New Day," Sanders stated that voters would need to compare his record with that of Hillary Clinton, the party's frontrunner for the presidential nomination. He expressed respect for Clinton but clarified that he was running to represent working families and the middle class, not to run against Clinton.

Sanders highlighted his opposition to trade agreements, citing his votes against various trade deals and his leadership in the fight against the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). He argued that the TPP would result in the outsourcing of well-paying jobs to low-wage countries.

Furthermore, Sanders discussed his proposals for a breakup of the largest financial institutions on Wall Street, asserting that these institutions, if they are too big to fail, are too big to exist due to their excessive power.

Sanders also emphasized his support for free college tuition at public colleges and universities, his leadership on climate change, and his push for legislation that would require the wealthiest individuals and largest corporations to pay a "fair share" of taxes.

"Those are my views, and people are going to have to judge Secretary Clinton's views," Sanders said. He added, "I think you have to look at my record."

Sanders concluded by stating that his record demonstrated a strong commitment to standing up for the voiceless and powerless, particularly those who have given up on the political process.

Title: Three Suspects Sought in Brussels Terror Attacks; ISIS Claims Responsibility

Article:

Authorities in Belgium are searching for three suspects in connection with the coordinated attacks at the Brussels airport and a subway station in the Belgian capital on Tuesday, which left at least 30 people dead and 230 others injured. ISIS has claimed responsibility for the attacks, but it is too soon to confirm whether the terror group was behind the blasts.

Surveillance footage shows a man wearing light-colored clothes and a hat pushing a baggage cart through the airport, which is one key piece of evidence authorities are examining. Police have released photos of three men they believe are suspects tied to the airport attack, standing side-by-side. The man on the right is the focus of the investigation, as authorities believe he planted a bomb at the airport and then left.

Two of the men, wearing black in the surveillance images, are believed to be suicide bombers who died in the explosions in the airport's departure lounge. The man in light-colored clothing is a wanted man, and authorities are asking for the public's help in tracking him down.

A photograph released by investigators shows the three suspects side-by-side. Federal Prosecutor Frederic Van Leeuw said the two men wearing black in the photograph were likely the suicide attackers. Video shows the men exiting a taxi and moving through the airport, according to two U.S. officials. The man dressed in white left the airport after accompanying the other two, a move the officials said appeared to be planned.

A break in the investigation may have come from a taxi driver who took the suspects to the airport. The driver contacted authorities after seeing surveillance footage and gave them the address where he picked the men up, according to two U.S. officials briefed on the investigation. That information prompted authorities to raid a residence after the attacks.

Investigators found a nail bomb, chemical products, and an ISIS flag during a house search in the northeast Brussels neighborhood of Schaerbeek, Belgium's federal prosecutor said in a statement. Hours later, they were still combing through the building for evidence. Security was high, with a helicopter hovering overhead carrying a sniper with a weapon trained on the building.

As masked, armed officers stood guard outside the building, the burst of camera flashes inside could be seen from the street below. Officers left the building carrying bags of evidence they loaded onto vehicles.

A Belgian government representative told CNN that 10 people were killed and 100 wounded at Brussels' international airport. At least 20 people died and 130 were wounded at the Maelbeek metro station. The blasts sent wounded people fleeing into the streets, spurred evacuations of nuclear plants and transit hubs, and led to raids in some areas as authorities searched for suspects and evidence.

Authorities in Belgium have been trying to crack down on terror threats for months as they raided homes in the area in search of suspects. Tuesday's violence came just days after investigators closed in on Europe's most wanted man, Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam, who was hiding out in a Brussels suburb.

The "working assumption" is that the attackers came from the network behind November's massacres in Paris, which left 130 dead, Belgian security sources said, while cautioning it is very early in the latest investigation. ISIS also claimed responsibility for those attacks.

As doctors treat the wounded and authorities search for suspects, a key question remains unanswered: Could the attacks have anything to do with Abdeslam's arrest? On Tuesday, Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel deflected a question about whether there is any link between the attacks and Belgium-born French citizen Abdeslam's capture, saying it is too early to tell.

Two senior U.S. officials told CNN they believe the Belgium attack is tied to the same network as Abdeslam. One of the two airport explosions happened outside security checkpoints for ticketed passengers and near the airline check-in counters, an airline official briefed on the situation said. The subway station blast happened about an hour later in the Brussels district of Maelbeek, near the European Quarter, where European Union institutions are based.

"We were fearing terrorist attacks," Michel told reporters Tuesday. "And that has now happened." Belgium is no stranger to terror. "The Belgians have been sitting on a ticking time bomb," a U.S. counterterrorism official said, given all those who have traveled from the small European nation to Syria and Iraq to join ISIS, then possibly come back home.

But for survivors of Tuesday's blasts, the repeated warnings from officials in recent months did not dull the shock of seeing the carnage. "You can not believe it; you can not believe it," said Jef Versele, who was in the airport's departure hall when bombs exploded there. "It was so insane. Not in my backyard." The second blast inside the airport blew out windows, created a lot of smoke, and caused parts of the ceiling to fall, he added.

"People were on the floor," Versele said, estimating he saw 50 to 60 who were thrown to the ground and did not seem to be able to walk. Anthony Barrett saw the wounded carried out on stretchers and luggage carts as he watched from his hotel across from the terminal building.

After the attacks in Brussels, the home of NATO and the capital of the European Union, leaders inside Belgium and beyond vowed not to back down in their fight against terror. In Belgium, where officials declared three days of national mourning, Michel offered a resolute message to those who supported and cheered the attackers.

"To those who have chosen to be barbarous enemies of freedom, democracy, and fundamental values... we remain united as one," Michel said. "We are determined to defend our freedoms and to protect our liberties." In its message claiming responsibility, ISIS noted that Belgium is one of the nations "participating in the international coalition against the Islamic State."

Title: ACLU's Commitment to the First Amendment Remains Controversial, According to ACLU's National Legal Director

Article:

David Cole, the national legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), has reassured readers in a New York Times op-ed that they should not "lose faith in the First Amendment." The op-ed, directed at "liberals or progressives," can also be interpreted as a response to critics who question the ACLU's commitment to the First Amendment, including libertarians and conservatives.

The debate about the ACLU's support for freedom of speech has been ongoing since 1990, as evidenced by a cover story published by ███. Charles Oliver argued that the ACLU's commitment to free speech had been compromised by its pursuit of progressive causes. Critics, including longtime ACLU members such as Nat Hentoff and Alan Dershowitz, expressed concern that "greed and left-wing ideology have corrupted the union," which had "diluted its message, compromised its mission, and, in some instances, abandoned its commitment to the First Amendment."

Nearly three decades later, the argument about the ACLU's support for freedom of speech continues, indicating that the organization remains divided on the issue, and that the stalwarts are influential enough that the ACLU is still willing to defend the First Amendment rights of people who offend progressives.

Recent evidence of internal qualms about free speech is a staff memo revealed by Wendy Kaminer, a former member of the ACLU's national board. The memo suggests that the organization's lawyers, in selecting First Amendment cases, should consider the impact of speech on "other values advanced by the ACLU," such as equality and racial justice. While the memo affirms the ACLU's commitment to defending speakers whose views its members find repugnant, the very idea that the organization's goals conflict with each other is an invitation to prioritize some of those "other values" over freedom of speech.

Cole's response to Kaminer reaffirmed "our commitment to defending speech with which we disagree," but it also repeated the memo's thesis that First Amendment cases can "pose conflicts between our values." In his New York Times piece, Cole argues that the ACLU still takes a viewpoint-neutral approach to First Amendment cases, citing various cases the organization has defended, including high school students disciplined for political activism, students penalized for social media posts, and anti-Trump and pro-Trump demonstrators, among others.

Cole defends the First Amendment as a principle that is useful to both the left and the right, citing the Supreme Court's ruling that the First Amendment prohibits holding the Westboro Baptist Church liable for displaying anti-gay signs outside a military funeral. Cole rebuts the idea that neutrality is suspect because it favors the rich and powerful, stating that the First Amendment favors people without power and influence.

While Cole's defense of the First Amendment is encouraging, it is purely instrumental, as he argues that progressives should support freedom of speech because it helps advance their goals, not because using force to silence offensive speakers is unjust or immoral. This omission may mean Cole knows his audience, as judging from the grumbling within his own organization about the freedom that white supremacists and other unsavory characters enjoy under the First Amendment.

Title: Brexit Vote: Immigration Emerges as Key Factor in UK's Decision to Leave EU

Article:

The recent Brexit referendum has sparked discussions centered on immigration, with many British citizens expressing dissatisfaction with the country's inability to govern itself independently from the European Union (EU). One individual, who voted to leave the EU, stated that his primary reason was to halt the flow of immigration, regardless of Europe or trade deals.

Stephen Booth, co-director of Open Europe, a nonpartisan think tank based in London and Brussels, reported that of the approximately 5 million net immigrants to the United Kingdom between 1990 and 2014, over three-quarters came from outside Europe. Currently, immigration from the EU accounts for nearly half of the United Kingdom's net inflow, Booth said. The expansion of the EU in 2004 and 2007, which brought in poorer countries like Bulgaria, Romania, and Poland, and the Eurozone economic crisis have contributed to substantial internal immigration to Britain and its relatively strong economy.

Proponents of immigration argue that it has grown the British economy, increased tax revenue, and attracted skilled workers. However, critics claim that immigration has overwhelmed Britain's public resources, changed the country's culture and values, and placed an enormous strain on the welfare state.

In a letter to the UK-based Guardian, Richard Mountford of Tonbridge, Kent, stated that the Brexit vote was a protest against the mass immigration flow. He suggested that the EU should offer an opt-out from the free movement of people to the UK and any other member state that desires it. This, he argued, would address the main reason for the vote to leave and make it legitimate for the UK government to offer a second referendum, rather than initiate the exit process immediately. An opt-out, Mountford added, would also help alleviate anti-EU sentiments in several other EU countries.

After the votes were counted, Britain voted 52% to 48% to leave the EU. UK Prime Minister David Cameron, who backed the "Remain" camp, lost the referendum and announced his resignation the morning after the vote. A new prime minister is projected to be installed in October, with Cameron remaining in a caretaker role until then.

Title: Sen. Mitt Romney Criticizes President Trump's Behavior in Mueller Report

Article:

Senator Mitt Romney, a Utah Republican and the 2012 GOP presidential nominee, expressed his disapproval of President Trump's behavior as detailed in the special counsel Robert Mueller's report released on Thursday. In a series of tweets, Romney shared his reaction after reviewing the report, which summarizes the special counsel's investigation into the 2016 presidential race and related matters.

"It is good news that there was insufficient evidence to charge the President of the United States with having conspired with a foreign adversary or with having obstructed justice. The alternative would have taken us through a wrenching process with the potential for constitutional crisis. The business of government can move on," wrote Romney.

However, he continued, "I am sickened at the extent and pervasiveness of dishonesty and misdirection by individuals in the highest office of the land, including the President." Romney also expressed his dismay at various actions taken by individuals associated with the Trump campaign, such as welcoming help from Russia, failing to inform American law enforcement, and promoting Russian interests in Ukraine.

In response, President Trump tweeted on Saturday, sharing a video that mocked Romney's loss during the 2012 election to former President Barack Obama. Trump tweeted, "If @MittRomney spent the same energy fighting Barack Obama as he does fighting Donald Trump, he could have won the race (maybe)."

The 488-page report summarizes the special counsel's findings nearly two years since Mueller, a former FBI director, was appointed by the Department of Justice to lead an investigation into the 2016 race started by his successor, James Comey. Mueller's probe concluded that Russia interfered in the 2016 race in a "sweeping and systematic fashion" and identified numerous links between individuals with ties to the Russian government and individuals associated with the Trump Campaign. However, investigators did not find evidence of Trump's associates illegally coordinating with Moscow, and Mueller concluded the probe without making a determination with respect to the obstruction question.

"The evidence we obtained about the President's actions and intent presents difficult issues that prevent us from conclusively determining that no criminal conduct occurred. Accordingly, while this report does not conclude that the President committed a crime, it also does not exonerate him," Mueller wrote.

Trump has celebrated the report in the wake of its release, declaring on Twitter that "The Russia Hoax is dead!"

Elected to the Senate in 2018, Romney has been a vocal critic of Trump since prior to his presidency. Speaking in early 2016, Romney called the future president "a phony, a fraud" and a "failed candidate."

Title: Former DNC Chair Donna Brazile Alleges Clinton Campaign's "Cult-Like" Atmosphere in New Book

Article:

Former Democratic National Committee (DNC) chair Donna Brazile, in her recently published book and subsequent media interviews, has portrayed the 2016 Hillary Clinton presidential campaign as an impenetrable and even "cult-like" environment, hindering any efforts by advisers who warned about the missteps that ultimately led to Donald Trump's victory.

In an interview on Fox News' "Tucker Carlson Tonight," Brazile seemed to walk back suggestions in her book that some on the Clinton team were sexist, but described their attitude as "dismissive" and "condescending."

Brazile suggested that the campaign placed too much emphasis on data analysis and algorithms, neglecting traditional, grassroots campaigning. In her book, "Hacks," she wrote, "Everybody worshipped the data and the analytics."

Brazile told Fox News that she and campaign manager Robby Mook came from "different" schools, with the Clinton team focusing on algorithms and data modeling. If she had concerns, why couldn't she break through? Brazile claimed she tried but "could not crack them."

In an interview on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Brazile stated, "I felt like it was a cult. You could not penetrate them."

The book and Brazile's subsequent media interviews have sparked tensions between Brazile and the Clinton camp. Over the weekend, dozens of Clinton campaign team members released an open letter, stating, "We do not recognize the campaign she portrays in the book." They added, "But we do not recognize the campaign she portrays in the book."

One of the most explosive claims in the book, released in an excerpt ahead of publication, alleges that the DNC struck a special deal with the Clinton campaign, giving the campaign partial control over party decisions and resources in exchange for financial assistance. This claim has fueled concerns among Bernie Sanders supporters that the former Democratic primary candidate was at a disadvantage from the start in his race against Clinton for the nomination.

Brazile maintains she worked hard during the general election to help Clinton win and stresses that her aim even now is to help the party heal. "I'm focusing on making sure that grassroots Democrats know that our party is going to become stronger," she told Fox News. "We had a very competitive primary. I don't know when the Republicans will sit down and heal their wounds, but we are healing our wounds, and we are going to learn how to become a stronger, more effective party."

Title: East Coast Storm Causes Travel Disruptions and Casualties Across the Country

Article:

A massive winter storm, which originated on the West Coast, has been causing disruptions and casualties across the United States. The storm, which started on Thursday, has led to more than 100 wrecks and has been blamed for at least seven deaths.

The storm has affected much of the East Coast, with snow and sleet falling in pockets of Pennsylvania and New York. The system is not expected to dissipate anytime soon, and it could cause even more problems and headaches on Wednesday, particularly for air travelers waiting to fly home for Thanksgiving.

Winds are forecast to pick up and affect densely populated areas in the Northeast in the next day or so. For drivers, big gusts mixed with drenching rains can slow things down, while for air travelers, there is always a big trickle-down effect when airports like New York's LaGuardia and Kennedy airports or those in Philadelphia and Boston experience wind delays.

The expected issues should not overshadow what this storm has already done. The system started on the West Coast, proving its might from the get-go. A 52-year-old man in Yuba County, California, died on Thursday when a tree fell on top of a vehicle, according to the county sheriff's office. Road conditions were blamed for the deaths of two people in New Mexico, and three people were killed in an icy pileup along Interstate 40 late Friday in northwest Texas. The weather also was blamed for four deaths in Oklahoma since late last week.

The storm's impact was felt Tuesday, with one stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, about 20 miles east of Pittsburgh, seeing a mix of snow, rain, and ice over the course of the day. Snow was the issue for cities and towns along the Appalachian Mountains, all the way down to West Virginia. Parts of upstate New York, including Buffalo and Syracuse, were seeing flakes on Tuesday night.

However, the temperature was not expected to be especially chilly everywhere. The National Weather Service forecast temperatures to rise into the 50s during the night in Philadelphia and Boston. But there, the temperature wouldn't be the story so much as the wind speed. Sustained winds in New York, where the thermostat should hit 55 degrees by 5 a.m., will reach 19 to 24 mph, with gusts blowing as strong as 55 mph. It will not be much better on Thursday, when the forecast calls for breezes from the west at 21 to 24 mph, with more potent gusts.

The wind could hamper the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade through the streets of Manhattan. The giant balloons that are the parade's trademarks -- featuring characters from Hello Kitty to Snoopy to the Pillsbury Doughboy -- won't soar if sustained winds exceed 23 mph that day, because of fears that the balloon handlers won't be able to control them.

As of Tuesday night, the weather's effect on flights was fairly minimal. As of 10:30 p.m., 158 flights had been canceled nationwide, with another 84 scuttled Wednesday, according to the air travel tracking website Flightaware.com. The highest number of pre-Thanksgiving Day cancellations, with 28 so far, is northern New Jersey's Newark Liberty International Airport, the site says.

There is a possibility this situation could turn for the worst, quickly, leading to major delays if not more cancellations. CNN's meteorology unit estimates, if winds blow as forecast, New York metro area airports could see average delays of two to three hours, and Boston's Logan airport could be even worse. This would not just affect those flying in and out of those airports, or others like Washington's Dulles or Reagan that could be similarly affected. There's a ripple effect because of the logistics of carefully coordinated schedules and connecting flights that could affect many of the 3.14 million people that AAA projects will fly this weekend.

In expectation of such headaches, major airlines like Delta, US Airways, JetBlue, and United have already relaxed their policies by letting some customers change their reservations without a fee. Still, the vast majority of travelers -- 43.4 million, by AAA's count -- won't be in the air but on the road. For them, the combination of strong winds and slick surfaces, even if they are not coated with snow or ice, could lead to problems. In other words, make a plan if you will be among these millions over the next few days, packing snacks and patience in case you come to a crawl. And, as always, drive safely.

Title: Paul Ryan's Political Evolution: From Fiscal Hawk to House Speaker

Article:

In a 2008 interview with a media personality, former Representative Paul Ryan (R-WI) discussed his political views and the evolution of his stance on government intervention in the economy. Prior to his tenure in Congress, Ryan had visited the interviewee at ABC and shared his concerns about the approaching debt crisis and the unfairness of entitlement programs.

Ryan's political career took a turn when the housing bubble burst, leading him to vote for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) and the auto bailout. The interviewee questioned Ryan's adherence to free-market principles, to which Ryan explained his votes as a response to the impending deflationary spiral and the potential collapse of the economy.

The interviewee inquired about the government's role in bailing out the auto industry, to which Ryan responded that his vote was aimed at preventing the auto companies from receiving TARP funds. He also expressed concern over TARP's transformation into a "revolving government slush fund."

The interviewee posed the question of whether government should have bailed out the auto industry in an ideal world. Ryan admitted that he would have preferred to vote against the bills, but the political climate at the time, marked by near panic, influenced his decision.

Ryan explained his view that the increasing reliance on the federal government for benefits and livelihoods is moving the country towards a "road to serfdom." He argued that this trend signifies a shift from a society where the goal of government is to promote equal opportunity, to one where the government aims to equalize the results of people's lives.

The interviewee expressed concern that most Americans may not understand economics and prefer a government that "takes care" of them. Ryan countered that Americans believe in the American idea, where rights do not come from government, and do not want a government that redistributes, regulates, and rations their rights.

In 2008, Ryan proposed a "Roadmap for the Future," a budget plan aimed at slowing the growth of government. The plan, while timid, would not eliminate the Education Department or other unnecessary government agencies and would not balance the budget for decades. Despite its moderate nature, even fellow Republicans criticized the plan, with Newt Gingrich labeling it "right-wing social engineering."

The interviewee invited Ryan back on his show in subsequent years to discuss the progress of his Roadmap. By then, Ryan felt that the political landscape had shifted, with his Roadmap helping to change the conversation and inspiring many Republicans to embrace smaller government and fiscal responsibility.

Ryan expressed satisfaction with the progress made in moving the country towards limited government and economic freedom. He acknowledged that, for 50 years, the needle did not move in terms of reducing the size of government, but now more Americans understand the importance of fiscal responsibility.

Ryan concluded the interview by stating that America has one more opportunity to revive and reapply the American idea, but there will come a point where that moment might pass. He emphasized that the people of southern Wisconsin are ready to engage in adult conversations about the debt crisis and that the country can get back toward limited government and economic freedom.

Title: Whispers of Iran Nuclear Deal Emerge as Deadline Approaches

Article:

As Iran and world powers faced another self-imposed deadline on Monday, whispers of a potential nuclear deal began to emerge from the negotiating room. According to two unnamed diplomats, as reported by The Associated Press, the deal, which would limit Iran's nuclear program in exchange for a lifting of sanctions, is expected to be announced on Monday.

NPR's Peter Kenyon, reporting from Vienna, reported that Iranian TV is adding to the expectation for a deal. He stated, "The signals from Iran are positive, with state-run media predicting an agreement will happen, and Iranian officials describing the document as running to almost 100 pages, including several technical annexes."

However, most reports of an imminent deal include the caveat that a few issues need to be resolved, and the various capitals must sign off on any agreement. If an accord is reached, exhausted negotiators will have little time to celebrate their achievement, as critics in Congress have warmed up their attacks, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has re-stated his argument that Iran poses a greater threat than the self-proclaimed Islamic State.

The BBC has rounded up what high-level officials said on the record about the negotiations on Sunday:

* US Secretary of State John Kerry said, "A few tough things need to be resolved, but added: 'We're getting to some real decisions.' "
* French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius, who cancelled a trip to Africa to stay at the talks, said, "I hope we are finally entering the final phase of these marathon negotiations. I believe it."
* In Iran, President Hassan Rouhani said, "The sides had 'come a long way.' 'We need to reach a peak and we're very close,' the Isna news agency quoted him as saying."

If the deal is reached, it would mark the culmination of decades of diplomacy. However, the deal would have to be approved by several capitals, including the U.S. Congress.

Title: Number of VA Facilities Under Investigation for Falsified Records and Treatment Delays More Than Doubles

Article:

The number of Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) facilities under investigation following complaints about falsified records and treatment delays has more than doubled, according to the Office of Inspector General (IG) at the Veterans Affairs Department. As of late Tuesday, 26 facilities are being investigated nationwide.

Acting Inspector General Richard Griffin revealed last week that at least 10 new allegations about manipulated waiting times and other problems have surfaced since reports of problems at the Phoenix VA hospital came to light last month. The expanded investigations come as President Barack Obama's choice to help carry out reforms at the Veterans Affairs Department, Rob Nabors, is set to travel to Phoenix to meet with staff at the local VA office.

Obama announced last week that Nabors would be assigned to the VA after allegations of delayed care that may have led to patient deaths and a cover-up by top administrators in Phoenix. Similar claims have been reported at VA facilities in Pennsylvania, Wyoming, Georgia, Missouri, Texas, Florida, and elsewhere.

Nabors met Tuesday in Washington with representatives of several veterans' organizations, including the American Legion and Disabled American Veterans, among others. He will meet Thursday with leadership at the Phoenix Veterans Affairs Medical Center, including interim director Steve Young. White House spokesman Jay Carney confirmed the meeting.

Young took over in Phoenix after director Sharon Helman was placed on leave indefinitely while the VA's Office of Inspector General investigates claims raised by several former VA employees that Phoenix administrators kept a secret list of patients waiting for appointments to hide delays in care.

Critics say Helman was motivated to conceal delays to collect a bonus of about $9,000 last year. A former clinic director for the VA in Phoenix first came out publicly with the allegations of secret lists in April.
