Title: Obama's Struggles with Government Inefficiency: A Look at the VA Scandal and Healthcare Website Woes

Article:

President Barack Obama, who once expressed ambition and confidence in the government he was about to lead, is currently grappling with a series of bureaucratic inefficiencies that have come to light, including the VA scandal and the health care website woes. CNN's Gloria Borger compares this situation to Lewis Carroll's "Alice Through the Looking Glass," suggesting that Obama is "staring down a rabbit hole of government bureaucracy and inefficiency."

The VA scandal, following the health care website fiasco, highlights the President's challenges in managing the government. The President's efforts to grow, manage, and change the government have, in some cases, become his own personal adversaries. This raises questions about the President's trust in government, as the government he has tried to expand and reform has become a source of problems rather than solutions.

The health care reform, the signature legislative achievement of the administration, was marred by a botched rollout, while the VA scandal, involving potential mismanagement and long wait times for veterans' healthcare, has raised concerns about the administration's ability to effectively manage a key aspect of the President's platform.

The President's approach to governing seems to have two extremes: issues that are micromanaged, such as foreign policy, and issues that are completely delegated, such as VA management. What appears to be missing is a middle ground: continual monitoring and early warning systems that avoid presidential blindsiding.

The President's management style is not universally praised. While he excels in leading a hierarchical organization with a single goal, such as a presidential campaign, managing or negotiating with people with mixed motives, like members of Congress, is not a strong point for him.

Borger suggests that the President needs to take control of the bureaucracy to be effective. The government apparatus to carry out the nation's business competently exists, and it is the President's responsibility to use and manage it effectively.

The VA scandal and health care website woes are not trivial matters. They are core issues that touch on the President's ability to manage the government and deliver on his promises to the American people. The President's legacy may be at stake if these issues are not addressed effectively.

Title: Hillary Clinton Makes First Post-2008 Presidential Campaign Visit to Iowa, Sparking 2016 Speculation

Article:

Former U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton made her first visit to Iowa since her 2008 presidential campaign on Sunday, attending the 37th annual steak fry event organized by retiring Senator Tom Harkin. The visit has sparked renewed speculation about Clinton's political future.

Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, headlined the event in Indianola, where they celebrated Harkin's 40-year political career. During the event, Clinton shook hands, posed for pictures, signed autographs, and flipped steaks while ignoring questions about the 2016 presidential campaign.

When asked about her plans, Clinton teased the crowd, saying her focus is on her future grandchild and "that other thing." She later clarified that she is considering a presidential run but was not in Iowa for that purpose.

Clinton praised Harkin's record of service and urged the 5,000 activists in attendance to work hard for Democrats in the November election, including Harkin's protege, U.S. Rep. Bruce L. Braley, who is running for Harkin's seat against state Sen. Joni Ernst, a Republican.

Clinton emphasized the importance of the Iowa race in determining whether Democrats will continue to control the Senate during the final two years of the Obama administration. Republicans need to pick up a net of six seats to flip control of the upper chamber.

A CNN/ORC poll released Friday showed that Braley has a slight 49 percent to 48 percent lead over Ernst among likely voters. The survey also found that 53 percent of registered Democrats said they would support Clinton in the Iowa caucuses, which traditionally kick off the nomination race.

Vice President Joe Biden, who is scheduled to travel to Iowa on Wednesday, received 15 percent in the poll, compared to 7 percent for Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and 5 percent for Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is openly considering a bid.

Sanders, who was also in Iowa over the weekend, said on ABC's "This Week" that Americans do not want to anoint a candidate but instead want to see a debate about the important issues facing the country.

Clinton said earlier this month that she will decide "probably after the first of the year" about whether she will run for president again.

Before the steak fry, the Clintons attended a private reception for Harkin's To Organize a Majority PAC at Principal Park, the home of Des Moines' minor league baseball team.

When asked on CNN's "State of the Union" whether he would support Clinton for president, Harkin was noncommittal, saying they are "very close friends" and that she has inspired women across the globe. Harkin also mentioned that Biden, Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, Sen. Mark R. Warner of Virginia, Sanders, and former Virginia Sen. Jim Webb could also run for the Democratic nomination.

Clinton placed a disappointing third in the 2008 Iowa caucuses behind then-Sen. Barack Obama of Illinois and former Sen. John Edwards of North Carolina. In her memoir "Hard Choices," Clinton described the Iowa result as "excruciating." At the steak fry Sunday, Harkin suggested Clinton could rebound from the experience, calling the Clintons the "comeback couple."

Title: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry Declares ISIS Committing Genocide Against Christians in Iraq and Syria

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry has determined that the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS, is committing genocide against Christians and other minorities in Iraq and Syria. This determination, set to be announced on Thursday, is in response to a congressional deadline and follows similar declarations from various governments, legislative bodies, and world leaders.

The genocide declaration does not obligate the United States to take additional action against ISIS militants and does not prejudge any prosecution against its members, according to U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to publicly preview Kerry's decision.

The genocide determination is based on the available evidence demonstrating that ISIS' actions rise to the level of genocide. The Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, signed by the U.S. and 147 other nations, prohibits the intentional destruction, in whole or in part, of an ethnic or religious group.

The genocide declaration requires countries to work together "to liberate mankind from this odious scourge," as stated in the 1948 treaty. However, there are still issues that the U.S. has to work through, considering that a genocide designation could "require an adjustment to US military strategy," according to Yahoo News.

Last week, the House voted unanimously 393-0 to declare the actions of ISIS against Christians a genocide. European leaders, the Pope, and Hillary Clinton have also been calling for the official declaration to be made.

Legal organizations representing persecuted Christians in the Middle East have urged Kerry to declare the genocide and have offered the State Department the legal evidence for doing so. The Knights of Columbus also submitted a nearly 300-page report to Kerry and the State Department last week laying out a detailed case for genocide declaration.

Ten years ago, there were nearly two million Christians living in Iraq and Syria. Today, there are just 250,000.

Title: U.S. Imposes Personnel Cap on Chinese State-Run Media in Response to Expulsion of American Journalists

Article:

The Trump administration has imposed a cap on the number of Chinese citizens permitted to work for China's major state-run media companies in the United States. This move comes in response to China's expulsion of several Wall Street Journal reporters earlier this year.

According to the Wall Street Journal, the cap will reduce the number of Chinese nationals working for the state-run media companies in the United States from 160 to 100 employees. The affected media entities include Xinhua News Agency, China Global Television Network, China Radio International, China Daily Distribution Corporation, and Hai Tian Development USA.

The decision to impose a cap was announced by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in a tweet on Monday. He stated, "Today, we announced a personnel cap on Chinese government-controlled media organizations in the United States. We urge Beijing to respect freedom of expression and will continue to seek reciprocity across the bilateral relationship."

Pompeo further explained in a statement that the goal is to establish a "long-overdue level playing field" and to spur Beijing to adopt a more fair and reciprocal approach to U.S. and other foreign press in China. He also urged China to uphold its international commitments to respect freedom of expression, including for members of the press.

The move to impose a cap follows China's expulsion of three Wall Street Journal reporters in February, in response to an opinion piece printed in the Journal that was critical of China. The expulsion sparked fury from White House officials, leading to the current personnel cap.

The State Department spokesperson told the Wall Street Journal that the cap is part of the Trump administration's efforts to seek reciprocity in the U.S.-China relationship. The move may escalate already-existing tensions between the two countries, particularly as the deadly coronavirus outbreak continues to spread globally.

China has expressed unhappiness with the move, with a Foreign Ministry spokesperson questioning the validity of the White House's goal of "reciprocity" on Twitter. She wrote, "Now the US kicked off the game, let's play."

Title: Facebook Restores Senator Warren's Ads After Removal Over Logo Misuse

Article:

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, has faced a recent incident involving the removal and subsequent reinstatement of several ads on Facebook. The ads, which promoted Warren's plan to curtail growing monopolies owned by tech giants such as Amazon, Google, and Facebook, were initially pulled by Facebook due to a violation of the social network's policy against the misuse of Facebook's logo.

On March 8, Warren issued a plan to address the growing monopolies she believes are stifling innovation and hurting small businesses. Facebook pulled four of Warren's ads on March 11, citing the use of the letter "f" in a video that represented Facebook as a violation of their policy. However, the ads were reinstated shortly thereafter, with Facebook stating, "In the interest of allowing robust debate, we are restoring the ads."

The majority of Warren's ads, nine others placed on Facebook, were not affected by the removal. In response to the incident, Warren commented on Twitter, "Curious why I think Facebook has too much power? Let's start with their ability to shut down a debate over whether Facebook has too much power." She later thanked the company for restoring her posts but added, "I want a social media marketplace that isn't dominated by a single censor."

In her plan, titled "Here's How We Can Break Up Big Tech," Warren outlined her support for regulators breaking up "anti-competitive" mergers such as Facebook's acquisitions of WhatsApp and Instagram, as well as Amazon's deals for Whole Foods and Zappos, and Google's acquisitions of Waze, Nest, and DoubleClick.

Title: Al Qaeda in Yemen Claims Responsibility for Charlie Hebdo Attacks

Article:

Al Qaeda's affiliate in Yemen, known as Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), has claimed responsibility for the deadly attack on the offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris last week. Nasr al-Ansi, a top commander of AQAP, appeared in an 11-minute Internet video posted Wednesday, stating that the massacre was in "vengeance for the prophet."

Al-Ansi also said in the video that France belongs to the "party of Satan" and warned of more "tragedies and terror." He claimed that Yemen's Al Qaeda branch "chose the target, laid out the plan, and financed the operation," though he produced no evidence to support the claim.

It was revealed last week that one of the brothers who carried out the attack, Saïd Kouachi, did his training in Yemen. The White House has repeatedly argued that Al Qaeda is "on the run" and that its core leaders have been "decimated." However, the White House has been cautious about using the term "Islamic terror" to describe the attack.

Chilling raw video shows the Kouachi brothers yelling about vengeance for the prophet Mohammed just after they murdered Charlie Hebdo editors and left the scene. The White House has not yet announced a response to the claim of responsibility by AQAP.

Title: The Constitutional Protection of Flag Burning and the First Amendment

Article:

In the United States, the issue of flag burning, a controversial act that is widely viewed as a desecration of the national symbol, has been a topic of debate among elected officials. However, the Supreme Court has consistently upheld the right to free speech, including the act of flag burning, as a protected form of expression under the First Amendment.

The late Justice William J. Brennan, in a poignant statement, expressed his disdain for flag burning but acknowledged that he would not advocate for its criminalization. The current political climate has seen a call for the criminalization of flag burning, with many politicians expressing their support for such a measure.

The Supreme Court has ruled that flag burning is a constitutionally protected form of expression. Furthermore, the court has also established that citizenship cannot be revoked based on a criminal conviction, including for flag burning. This means that President-elect Trump, upon taking office, would not have the authority to strip the citizenship of flag burners.

The Supreme Court's decision on flag burning is a matter of precedent, and any attempt to change it could potentially open a "slippery slope" for the denial of other basic freedoms of expression. The late Justice Scalia, who was in the majority in the most recent flag burning case, advocated for the criminalization of flag burning. If his replacement takes the minority view, the Supreme Court may reconsider its decision.

Candidate Trump, who has expressed a desire to change the libel laws to make it easier to sue his critics, may find himself in a precarious position if the constitutional rules were to be loosened. Trump's use of defamatory language against his opponents could potentially make him a target for defamation actions.

The First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech, has served the United States well for over two centuries. It has protected extremists on both the right and left, and while many Americans may prefer to ban speech they dislike, the principle of freedom of expression is one that liberals and conservatives alike should support.

President-elect Trump is urged to withdraw his calls for the criminalization of flag burning and to respect the principles of the First Amendment. The act of flag burning, while offensive to many, is a symbol of the very freedom it seeks to undermine. The First Amendment is not broken, and it is not in need of repair.

Title: Twitter-DHS Dispute Highlights First Amendment Rights and Dark Money in Politics

Article:

Last week, the Department of Homeland Security's Customs and Border Protection (CBP) division demanded that Twitter reveal the identity of the person behind an account criticizing the Trump administration. However, the agency quickly retracted the demand, acknowledging it had no authority to issue such a demand.

Twitter's primary objection, the company stated, is that allowing the government to unmask Twitter critics violates the Constitution's First Amendment right to free speech. The company argued that this right is particularly important when discussing political speech.

Twitter expressed concern that the demand "may reflect the very sort of official retaliation that can result from speech that criticizes government officials and agencies." Democratic Sen. Ron Wyden (Ore.) called the CBP demand a "witch hunt." In a letter to CPB, he expressed "grave alarm" over an apparent attempt to "squelch the exercise of First Amendment rights to comment on U.S. policy, and to make those comments anonymously."

Esha Bhandari, a staff lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), stated that the case was "about the broader right to speak anonymously on the internet." She told The Washington Post, "Speaking anonymously about issues of the day is a longstanding American tradition, dating back to when the framers of the Constitution wrote under pseudonyms. The anonymity that the First Amendment guarantees is often most essential when people criticize the government, and this free speech right is as important today as ever."

Alex Howard, deputy director of the Sunlight Foundation, praised Twitter's rebuff of the CBP demand, stating, "The choices they made to stand up for their users set important precedents for other companies now and into the future."

The article also discusses the issue of "dark money" in political campaigns. Dark money consists of donations to politically oriented nonprofit groups that can use the money for independent expenditures urging the public to vote for or against a political candidate. Dark-money expenditures have increased in recent years, but they still represent only a tiny fraction of total campaign spending.

The article argues that the term "dark money" sounds despicable and has elicited calls for "disclosure." Legislation has been introduced in Congress and in more than half the states that would require such incorporated nonprofits to disclose their donors. One New York proposal would require nonprofits to disclose the identities of anyone who gave them more than $1,000 if they express any opinion about any position taken on any issue by any candidate, legislature, or executive agency.

The article concludes by noting that the ACLU has criticized dark-money disclosure laws as overly broad measures that "could chill constitutionally protected speech." The article suggests that the issue of political speech and campaign finance reform cannot be separated, and that limiting expenditures would limit political speech, just as limiting abortions would limit abortion rights. The article also references the Supreme Court's ruling in Citizens United, which allowed non-profit corporations to publish criticism of politicians in the weeks leading up to an election. The article suggests that those who were horrified by the administration's demand that the Twitter user be unmasked should think carefully about whether they want the government unmasking other critics as well.

Title: George H.W. Bush Discusses Faith and Leadership During Interviews

Article:

Former U.S. President George H.W. Bush, the 41st president of the United States, discussed the importance of faith in leadership during interviews throughout his presidency. In 1992, during an interview with Pat Robertson, Bush stated, "I don't believe that an atheist could be president of the United States. Anyone that did not have something bigger than himself or herself -- and faith is the answer."

Bush spoke about his regular prayers at meals and before bed with his wife, Barbara. He also agreed with Robertson about the need for faith in the Oval Office. During the interview, Bush noted that Abraham Lincoln once said he could not handle the job except on his knees, and Bush responded, "Yes, you have to."

In 1990, before ordering the start of Operation Desert Shield in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Bush found himself turning to prayer. He told Robertson, "The decision rests only with the president for that -- only the president -- and there was certainly time and need for prayer on that."

In 2007, Bush spoke about his spirituality during a dedication ceremony for the Billy Graham Library in Charlotte, North Carolina. He stated, "I've always viewed my faith as a personal matter, an intensely personal matter and that's just the way I'm wired. There's nothing self-conscious, however, about my relationship with Jesus Christ and thanks to Billy I have come to understand this all-important relationship in deeper and more meaningful ways."

Bush's casket will rest in the Capitol rotunda all day Tuesday for the public to pay their respects. A presidential aircraft designated as "Special Air Mission 41" flew his casket to the nation's capital on Monday. Bush's eldest son, President George W. Bush, and other family members flew on the flight.

On Wednesday at 11 a.m., President Trump and the first lady will attend an invitation-only state funeral for Bush at the National Cathedral. Afterwards, the casket will be flown back to Houston for a service at St. Martin's Episcopal Church on Thursday, followed by a private ceremony and burial at the Bush presidential library on the campus of Texas A&M University in College Station. Bush will be buried alongside his wife Barbara, who died in April, and their daughter Robin Bush, who died of leukemia in 1953 at age 3.

Title: Romney Remains Silent on Obama's Decision to Halt Deportation of Young Illegal Immigrants

Article:

Presumed Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney declined to comment on whether he would reverse President Obama's decision to halt the deportation of young-adult illegal immigrants during a Sunday interview. The White House, which had previously stated it lacked the authority to categorically halt deportations, now claims it has solid legal ground for the move.

On Friday, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano announced that the department would stop deporting illegal immigrants under the age of 30 who were brought to the country before the age of 16, have been in the U.S. for at least five years, and have completed high school, earned an equivalency diploma, or joined the U.S. military. The move does not grant the illegal immigrants permanent legal status but ends their risk of being deported and may provide them with legal work rights.

After taking a hard-line stance on immigration during the primary, Romney said on Sunday that he would pursue a broader immigration solution but did not comment on whether he would maintain the non-deportation policy in the meantime. Romney also accused Obama of politicizing the issue, stating that the timing of the decision was "pretty clear."

For three years, the Obama administration had denied having the authority to halt deportations for students who would have been eligible for the Dream Act. In 2011, Obama told Univision that ignoring congressional mandates through executive order would not conform with his role as president. However, after reversing his stance, the administration claims it is not unilaterally enacting the Dream Act because it cannot grant full legal status.

The Dream Act, which would have granted a path to citizenship to most illegal immigrants under 30, has failed several times in Congress. However, Democrats have reintroduced a version, and several Republicans are working on their own legislation. Rep. David Rivera and Sen. Marco Rubio, both Florida Republicans, have introduced their own versions of the bill, which would grant a path to citizenship to a narrower category of students than the administration's policy.

Title: Marco Rubio's Strategic Approach to Immigration Reform

Article:

Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) has been successful in courting grass-roots Republican voters in his efforts to address immigration reform. After the bipartisan group's formation late last year, following Mitt Romney's presidential election loss due in part to a rejection by Hispanic voters, Rubio embarked on a media blitz, outlining his immigration principles and garnering praise from conservative media figures such as Rush Limbaugh and Sean Hannity.

Rubio and his team have studied the mistakes of the 2007 immigration overhaul attempt and tailored their pitch to address conservative concerns. Emphasizing strict border security and enforcement, Rubio insists that illegal immigrants cannot be put on a path to citizenship until border security goals are met. He also advocates for refining the current system, focusing on increased enforcement and a workable plan for future legal immigrants, aiming to prevent another wave of illegal immigrants in the future.

Former Republican Senator Mel Martinez, who was part of the failed 2007 immigration overhaul attempt, commends Rubio's strong leadership and communication skills, stating that his emphasis on strong border security and enforcement is resonating with Democrats. Rubio has also been proactive in preventing the dynamic that contributed to the 2007 bill's failure, such as the impression that the immigration proposal was written in secret and rushed to the Senate floor.

Rubio has been active behind the scenes, regularly reaching out to conservative news media outlets, grass-roots supporters, and House Republicans. In one-on-one phone calls and meetings, he has emphasized the importance of a full committee review and transparency in the process. Rubio has also brought Enrique Gonzalez, a well-known immigration lawyer based in Miami, onto his staff full-time and assigned a legislative assistant to work nearly exclusively on immigration issues.

In January, Rubio also made headlines for his active role in the bipartisan group's efforts, with Rush Limbaugh enthusing on his show that Rubio had emphasized the need for hearings and transparency in the process.

Title: FBI Completes Supplemental Background Check on Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh; Report to be Delivered to Senate Wednesday Evening

Article:

The FBI has reportedly concluded its supplemental background investigation into Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, and the Senate is expected to receive the results Wednesday evening, according to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. The report, which is planned to focus on allegations of sexual misconduct by Kavanaugh during his youth, is expected to be kept secret.

Speaking on the Senate floor Wednesday evening, McConnell stated, "This evening, the Senate will receive the results of the FBI’s supplemental background investigation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh." He further noted that the information gathered during this investigation, in addition to what has already been one of the most thorough and exhaustive Senate reviews of any Supreme Court nominee in U.S. history, would be provided to senators.

The report's release has been a significant point of anticipation, as it may influence the votes of three Republican senators who hold swing votes on Kavanaugh's appointment due to the conservative party's thin 51-49 majority in the Senate.

Christine Blasey Ford, who accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault, was not contacted or interviewed by the FBI during its investigation, as of late Wednesday. Nor was another woman, Julie Swetnick, who also accused Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct. Ford's lawyers released a statement late Wednesday night, condemning the investigation for proceeding without Ford's participation.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic leader on the Senate Judiciary Committee, stated that the FBI's investigation would not be deemed credible without testimony from both Ford and Kavanaugh, given reports that they might not be interviewed.

The FBI has contacted at least a handful of key witnesses in its investigation, but some have questioned why others were not interviewed. The report is expected to center on allegations posed by Ford, who testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee that Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her while they were in high school. Kavanaugh vehemently denied the allegations.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., called for a slowdown in the process, suggesting senators should have a day to study the FBI report before deciding Kavanaugh's fate. President Donald Trump expects a vote by the end of the week, and a full vote on Kavanaugh could happen as early as Saturday afternoon if the Senate is ordered to work over the weekend.

Title: Republicans Eye Bipartisan Elements for Potential Health Care Reform

Article:

In the ongoing debate surrounding the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, some Republican lawmakers have indicated that they may preserve certain elements of the president's controversial health care overhaul if they were to repeal the law and implement their own reforms.

Since its inception, conservatives in Congress have been vocal about their dislike of President Obama's signature domestic policy achievement. However, as demonstrated by a recent proposal from House conservatives, they would not just repeal the law; they would replace it with one of their own. The new plan would not be ObamaCare, but it could share some similarities with the current law, particularly in areas that have bipartisan support.

Michael Gerson, former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, recently urged Republicans to start thinking about creating a health care policy rather than just tearing down the existing one. In a piece for The Washington Post, Gerson proposed a Republican plan that would offer a universal credit to anyone not covered by a large employer and include protections for those without insurance from "catastrophic expenses."

These ideas would be scaled-back versions of the subsidies and consumer protections currently offered in ObamaCare. The difference, according to Gerson, is that "Obamacare creates a powerful regulatory mechanism (the exchanges) that mandates comprehensive coverage" among other changes.

David Kendall, a senior fellow for health and fiscal policy at Third Way, told FoxNews.com that there is an overlap in ideas between the parties, and parts of ObamaCare would likely show up in a Republican-penned plan. Kendall noted that the law is not dissimilar to versions of health care reform that Republicans have proposed in the past, including a universal plan offered by President Richard Nixon at the end of his term.

According to a May 2012 Kaiser Health poll, popular provisions of ObamaCare favored by both parties include allowing children to stay on their parents' plans until they turn 26 and providing subsidies on a sliding scale to those who cannot afford insurance.

Recently, Republican Study Committee Chairman Rep. Steve Scalise, R-La., called his party's counter-proposal a 180-degree turn from ObamaCare but a closer look shows some similarities. The American Health Care Reform Act would let people buy insurance across state lines and offer tax deductions, as opposed to subsidies, to help purchase insurance. The bill would not include the mandate on almost everyone to obtain insurance, which is perhaps the least popular element of ObamaCare.

One of the biggest selling points in ObamaCare, as well as in the GOP proposal, is the coverage of adults with pre-existing conditions. Under the ACA, insurers would not be able to turn down consumers who have a history of medical problems or charge them more for coverage.

The experience with the exchanges, which are a centerpiece of the health reform plan, has been plagued by problems since their launch on Oct. 1. The rollout of the main exchange websites has been problematic, leaving Republicans hesitant to try to recreate them if they ever were in a position to try their own plan. For now, the latest budget fight proved Republicans do not have the numbers or the leverage to repeal or replace ObamaCare at this point, and may have to wait until 2016 for their next shot at changing the balance of power.

Title: Trump's Decision on DACA: Congress Now in Charge

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision this week to phase out the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which protects approximately 800,000 immigrants who came to the United States illegally as children, has been met with criticism. The announcement was made by Attorney General Jeff Sessions, rather than by the president himself, and Trump subsequently tweeted that if Congress does not act to address the issue, he may revisit his decision.

The DACA program, established by President Barack Obama in 2012, provides temporary protection from deportation and work permits to eligible individuals who were brought to the U.S. as children. The program does not provide a permanent solution, as it is not a legislative act, but rather an executive action.

The future of DACA is now in the hands of Congress, which has the power to pass legislation that would provide a more permanent solution for these individuals, often referred to as "Dreamers." Bipartisan support exists for such legislation, but it will require cooperation from both parties to pass.

In a meeting with congressional leaders this week, President Trump sided with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, supporting a proposal to keep the government funded and raise the debt ceiling for three months, rather than seeking a longer-term solution. This decision took Republicans by surprise, but it aligns with Trump's reputation for unpredictability.

The biggest impediment to passing legislation to grant permanent resident status to Dreamers has been the reluctance of GOP leaders to bring a bill to the floor that does not have majority support among Republicans. However, Speaker Ryan could potentially ignore the Hastert rule, a tactic used by former Speaker Dennis Hastert to maintain party discipline, and allow a bill to move forward.

It is crucial to recognize that Dreamers are Americans in every way that matters. Half of Dreamers arrived in the U.S. when they were 6 years old or younger. They have attended American schools, graduated, and are employed at rates higher than their American-born peers. They can and should be asked to contribute to the country by paying taxes and serving in the U.S. military, but they cannot do so without permanent resident status. The alternative would be to deport hundreds of thousands of young, productive workers.

Congress should work across party lines to pass immigration reform. It is the right thing to do.

Title: New Polls Show Obama Leading Romney in Three Swing States

Article:

New polls conducted by Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times and Franklin and Marshall College indicate that President Barack Obama is exceeding 50% support among likely voters in the swing states of Ohio, Florida, and Pennsylvania. The polls show Obama leading Republican nominee Mitt Romney by margins of 9 to 12 points in these states, which together account for 67 electoral votes.

The new surveys, released on Tuesday, suggest that Romney has lost his edge on the economy, an issue that has been a key focus of his campaign. The polls were conducted after the release of secretly recorded clips from a May fundraiser during which Romney made controversial remarks about Obama supporters.

In Ohio, the Quinnipiac/CBS News/New York Times poll indicates Obama leading Romney 53% to 43% among likely voters. In Florida, the poll shows Obama at 53% and Romney at 44%. In Pennsylvania, the new Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times survey puts the president at 54% and the former Massachusetts governor at 42%.

The economy remains the top issue for Americans when it comes to their vote for president. According to the polls, voters in the three states questioned in the Quinnipiac survey saw Obama as better for handling the economy, health care, Medicare, national security, international crisis, and immigration. Romney tied or edged ahead on dealing with the budget deficit.

Peter A. Brown, assistant director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, said that while Romney's controversial remarks about Obama supporters might have influenced these polls, the economy appears to be a key factor in Obama's increasing advantage.

"The wide difference between the two candidates is not just a result of Romney's bad week. In Ohio and Florida, votes are basically split down the middle on whether the country and they and their families are worse or better off than they were four years ago," Brown said.

"If voters do not think they are worse off, it is difficult to see them throwing out an incumbent whose personal ratings with voters remains quite high," Brown added.

Brown also noted that the economy remains the top issue for Americans when it comes to their vote for president. "The president's strength results from the fact that for the first time in the entire campaign, he is seen as better able to fix the economy than is Romney, the issue that has been the Republican's calling card since the general election campaign began," Brown said.

Both Romney and Obama are currently campaigning in Ohio, with the Quinnipiac/CBS News/New York Times poll indicating the president leading Romney 53% to 43% among likely voters. The polls go up and down, but Obama's lead in Ohio and Florida is significant, and the economy remains a key factor in his advantage.

The first presidential debate is scheduled for next week in Denver, and the three presidential showdowns are Romney's best chance to try and change the numbers. Early voting is already underway in a handful of states, and Iowa becomes the first battleground state to begin early voting on Thursday.

Title: Obama Proposes Budget Plan with Social Security and Medicare Changes, New Taxes, and Deficit Reduction Measures

Article:

President Barack Obama's upcoming budget plan, set to be presented on Wednesday, will outline proposed changes to Social Security and Medicare, as well as new tax increases, in an effort to reach a deal with Republicans on deficit reduction. The plan, which includes an offer made to House Speaker John Boehner in December, is projected to generate $400 billion in Medicare savings over 10 years.

The proposal has drawn criticism from liberal groups, with MoveOn.org labeling the president's proposed changes to Social Security as "unconscionable" and Democracy for America calling the cuts "profoundly disturbing."

Anna Galland, executive director of MoveOn.org, stated, "Millions of MoveOn members did not work night and day to put President Obama into office so that he could propose policies that would hurt some of our most vulnerable people."

The budget will reportedly include the offer Obama made to House Speaker John Boehner in December, which also included $400 billion in savings to Medicare over 10 years.

For Social Security, Obama plans to propose a switch to a key Republican request called "chained CPI," which is an inflation formula. Proponents argue that chained CPI is a more accurate way to measure inflation than the current method, as it overstates growth in consumer prices. However, some critics contend that chained CPI is not a better way to measure inflation for Social Security recipients, as they spend a significant amount on health care, which rises faster than inflation.

The new budget is expected to result in $1.8 trillion in savings over 10 years and replace the forced budget cuts that took effect on March 1, also known as the sequester. The budget will also fund initiatives outlined in Obama's State of the Union address, including universal access to prekindergarten education, which will be paid for by increases to cigarette taxes.

Additionally, the plan would close a current loophole that allows people to collect disability and unemployment benefits simultaneously, a move that could create savings for the government, according to officials.

The budget's release was initially delayed, with Republicans criticizing the White House for the delay following protracted negotiations over spending cuts and tax rates. House Speaker John Boehner has stated that he and the president were never able to reach an agreement because Obama's "offers never lived up to his rhetoric." Boehner added that the president has not heeded the call for common ground, as reported tax increases are still part of the plan.

Title: G-7 Summit Focuses on Russia-Ukraine Tensions and ISIS Conflict

Article:

The G-7 summit, held in Germany over the weekend, saw the leaders of industrialized democracies discuss pressing global issues, with Russia-Ukraine tensions and the war against the Islamic State (ISIS) taking center stage.

Russia was absent from the meeting for the second consecutive year, having been excluded in 2014 following its annexation of Crimea from Ukraine. The G-7 nations imposed sanctions on Russia last year in response to its actions in Crimea and its support of pro-Russian rebels in Ukraine.

President Barack Obama, during a beer conversation with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, expressed his focus on "standing up to Russian aggression in Ukraine." Both leaders agreed that sanctions against Russia should not be lifted until Russian President Vladimir Putin fully implements the terms of the peace accord reached in Minsk last February.

Putin, in response, asserted that Russia's actions in Crimea, Ukraine, and elsewhere are defensive, not offensive. Some European officials have expressed support for weakening the sanctions against Russia, potentially without the United States and Germany.

In addition to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the G-7 leaders also addressed the ongoing war against ISIS in Iraq and Syria. The general leading the effort to recapture Ramadi and other areas in Anbar province reported that the Iraqi military has secured the defense lines leading to Baghdad. However, some European leaders have expressed doubts about President Obama's strategy in combating ISIS.

With ISIS making gains in both Iraq and Syria, and Russia's Putin demonstrating military strength in Ukraine and globally, Obama's foreign policy decisions are facing scrutiny, not only from domestic critics, but also from some of America's closest allies.

Title: FBI Experiences Record Number of Gun Background Checks Amidst Calls for Tighter Gun Control

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is currently handling a surge in gun background checks this year, following a series of mass shootings that have renewed calls for more restrictive gun laws. The biggest spikes in background checks occurred in August and September, after attacks in El Paso and Odessa, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, which left 38 people dead.

Larry Keane, general counsel for the firearms industry trade group National Shooting Sports Foundation, stated that the increase in background checks is a response to perceived threats to the Second Amendment rights. He noted that this trend has been ongoing since August.

While the FBI does not track gun sales, its National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) serves as a gauge of market demand. For the first time since the bureau began conducting checks in 1998, the number of monthly checks has not fallen below 2 million this year. With the holiday shopping season approaching, the number of background checks for 2019 could break the one-year record of 27.5 million.

Analysts suggest that the industry may be emerging from the "Trump slump" that followed the election of the pro-gun president. In 2016, when the Obama administration sought tougher gun control legislation, the FBI was inundated with requests for background checks, processing a record number of checks that year.

This year, the FBI has requested additional money and personnel to manage the workload. FBI Director Christopher Wray, in testimony before a House committee, cited increasing background checks in his request for 40 new positions and $4.2 million. Some of the money would be used for new equipment.

The FBI has dealt with the volume by reassigning nearly 300 people at various times, which has caused backlogs elsewhere, according to the budget request. The FBI has been criticized for problems with its background check system, most recently in 2017, when the Air Force failed to provide the FBI with the criminal record of a man who went on to massacre 26 people at a Texas church.

Earlier this month, the Justice Department reported that the military and other federal agencies had increased their submissions of criminal and mental health records to the background check system by more than 6% in the past year. A 2018 law passed in the wake of the Texas church shooting, known as the Fix NICS Act, requires agencies to make sure they share such information with the FBI.

Gun check numbers need only remain steady for the rest of the year to break the record. The FBI recorded nearly 23 million checks through the end of October. The political calendar and unrelenting gun violence is likely to keep up demand for firearms.

In September, former Texas congressman Beto O'Rourke caused perhaps the biggest stir during a Democratic presidential debate when he called for mandatory buybacks of popular semi-automatic rifles used in some recent attacks, including the El Paso assault. That shooting left 22 dead at a local Walmart.

Several of the leading candidates, including former Vice President Joe Biden, South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, and Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, have called for measures including bans on assault-style weapons, universal background checks, and voluntary gun buybacks.

Title: Presidential Campaign Advertising Suspended in Colorado Following Tragedy

Article:

In a rare display of unity amidst political differences, both President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have suspended their campaign advertising in Colorado following the tragic shooting incident in Aurora that left at least 12 people dead and dozens more injured. Two major super PACs, American Crossroads, Crossroads GPS, and Priorities Action USA, have also temporarily halted their political advertisements.

Andrea Saul, a spokeswoman for Mitt Romney, confirmed the suspension of ads, stating, "We are pulling all ads in Colorado until further notice." Jen Psaki, an Obama campaign spokeswoman, echoed the sentiment, saying, "The president's ads are being taken down as well."

American Crossroads and Crossroads GPS, which have spent millions of dollars on attack ads against President Obama in Colorado, have also ceased their advertising efforts. Steven Law, the group's president, said, "In moments of tragedy like the Aurora shooting, we all stand together as Americans."

Priorities Action USA, a super PAC supporting President Obama, has also suspended its ads. Colorado is one of the battleground states where a fierce advertising war is ongoing, with most of the ads being negative in nature.

President Obama's campaign had been airing three attack ads in Colorado, one of which mocked Mitt Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, by showing him singing "America the Beautiful" while headlines about his holdings in Bermuda and the Cayman Islands flashed on the screen. Another ad cited Romney's opposition to abortion, and a third claimed his economic plan would raise taxes on 18 million working families.

The two English-language ads Mitt Romney had been running in Colorado accused President Obama of showering his friends and campaign contributors with federal stimulus dollars and of lying about Romney's business record. The suspension of these ads marks a temporary pause in the intense advertising war in Colorado during this election year.

Title: G-20 Summit: Tensions Emerge Between U.S. and China Despite Climate Agreement

Article:

President Obama attempted to downplay diplomatic tensions with China during the G-20 summit in Hangzhou, China, on Sunday, attributing the altercations to the complexities of international negotiations. Tensions between the two nations emerged as early as Saturday, with protocol issues arising upon Obama's arrival.

Upon landing, no mobile staircase was prepared for the U.S. president to exit the front door of Air Force One, forcing him to leave via the lower back door, which has its own stairs. Additionally, Obama was the only national leader not to be provided with a red carpet on arrival.

Obama acknowledged that such incidents were not uncommon, stating, "Part of it is we also have a much bigger footprint than a lot of other countries." He further explained, "We've got a lot of planes and a lot of helicopters and a lot of cars and a lot of guys, and if you're a host country, sometimes it may feel a bit much."

Despite the tensions, Obama emphasized that they did not detract "from the broader scope of the relationship." He pointed to the productive bilateral discussions he had with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday, touching on the environment, the South China Sea, protectionism, and human rights. The two nations announced they would formally join the Paris Climate Change Agreement.

Obama also addressed the media, stating, "We think it's important that the press have access to the work that we're doing, that they have the ability to answer questions." He added, "We do not leave our values and ideals behind when we take these trips."

Tensions continued throughout the day, with Chinese officials blocking U.S. traveling media from watching the president disembark, and cutting American press access to the bilateral events. The press pack was reduced from six to one during Obama and Xi's evening walk along Hangzhou's famous West Lake, according to the Washington Post.

National Security Advisor Susan E. Rice and her deputy, Benjamin J. Rhodes, were also blocked from approaching President Obama on the tarmac. Later, Rice stated the Chinese had done things that "weren't anticipated."

The G-20 summit continues through Monday, with Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin scheduled to meet to discuss, among other issues, the ongoing conflict in Syria.

Title: Chief Justice John Roberts Admonishes Senate Impeachment Trial Participants for Lack of Civility

 Article:

 In a significant intervention during the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, Chief Justice John Roberts admonished the House managers and the president's counsel for their heated exchanges over amendments to the resolution outlining the rules and format of the trial. Roberts emphasized the need for civility and respectful discourse, citing historical precedents from the Senate.

 The admonishment came during an argument over whether former national security adviser John Bolton should be subpoenaed to testify before the Senate. Roberts, in his first major intervention in the trial, referred to an incident from the impeachment trial of Florida District Judge Charles Swayne in 1905, when a senator objected to a House manager using the term "pettifogging."

 In the heated argument between Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler and White House counsel Pat Cipollone, Nadler accused senators who voted against calling Bolton to testify of being "part of the cover-up." Cipollone, in response, called for Nadler to apologize to the Senate, the president, and "most of all, you owe an apology to the American people."

 The role of John Roberts, as the presiding officer, is to maintain a fair and neutral arbiter during the trial. Jeffrey Rosen, president of the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia, stated, "This is his most prominent chance on the national stage to show his commitment to being a fair, neutral arbiter." Roberts, according to Rosen, values the nonpartisan, institutional legitimacy of the courts above all else.

 For those interested in further political discussions, join our Facebook group, "Across the Aisle, Across the Nation."

Title: Vox Media Implements Furloughs and Pay Cuts for Staff Members Amidst Economic Challenges

Article:

Vox Media, a digital publishing company that owns brands such as Eater, SB Nation, New York Magazine, and The Strategist, has announced it will furlough 9% of its staff from May 1 through July 31. A source familiar with the moves told ███ that health insurance premiums will be fully covered during this period.

In addition to layoffs, Vox Media is implementing several other measures, according to a source at the company. About 1% of staff are moving to reduced hours from May 1 through July 31, with health insurance premiums still fully covered. There will be a temporary tiered pay reduction for employees starting at an annual salary of $130,000 for the same time period. 401(k) matches will be suspended through the end of 2020, and there will be a freeze on merit-based increases and promotions.

In a memo to staff on Friday, Vox Media CEO Jim Bankoff wrote, "The expectations that we had just a few weeks ago for our business and our lives no longer apply." He added, "When I say it’s our goal to limit the impact on our employees, I mean it."

The pandemic is forcing dozens of major media companies to carry out layoffs and pay cuts. Group Nine Media, which includes brands like Thrillist, Seeker, The Dodo, PopSugar, and NowThis, laid off 7% of its workforce last week. Bustle Digital Group laid off two dozen staffers in early April and shuttered its tech website The Outline. Cheddar, BuzzFeed, and dozens of other digital-native websites have also resorted to layoffs, furloughs, and other measures to survive the pandemic.

The digital news industry has been reeling from a tough economic outlook for a while. Vox Media laid off roughly 50 staffers in 2018, and it also laid off hundreds of freelancers last year, after a new law passed in California that reclassified freelance journalists as contract workers.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 138,000 Jobs in May; Unemployment Dips Slightly

Article:

The U.S. economy added 138,000 jobs in May, according to the monthly jobs report released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) on Friday. The national unemployment rate nudged lower, to 4.3 percent from 4.4 percent - a 16-year low. The 4.4 percent level had been the lowest since 2007, before the recession hit.

However, the jobs numbers were not as strong as some were hoping to see. Economists had been expecting job gains of about 185,000, NPR's Yuki Noguchi reports, and to see the unemployment rate holding steady.

Last month's report initially showed job creation bouncing back in April, with the economy adding 211,000 jobs to nonfarm payrolls. That figure was revised to 174,000 on Friday, a drop of 37,000. Revisions also cut disappointing March results even further, from a gain of 79,000 to a gain of only 50,000 jobs.

The numbers suggest job growth is slowing slightly, with an average gain of roughly 121,000 jobs over the past three months, compared with an average of 181,000 over the past 12 months.

In May, the number of unemployed Americans (6.9 million) remained essentially unchanged from the previous month. Since January, the unemployment rate has declined by 0.5 percentage point, and the number of unemployed has decreased by 774,000, according to the BLS.

"Among the unemployed, the number of job losers and persons who completed temporary jobs declined by 211,000 to 3.3 million in May," according to the BLS report.

The Department of Labor also recently released more specific data about the job markets in different U.S. cities. For metropolitan areas in April, the agency says Ames, Iowa, and Boulder, Colorado, had the lowest unemployment rates, at 1.7 percent and 1.8 percent, respectively. The highest unemployment rate was in El Centro, California, at 19.2 percent.

For large cities (with a population over 1 million in the 2010 Census), the Denver area had the lowest unemployment rate, at 2.1 percent. The highest rate was in the Cleveland area, at 5.4 percent.

Title: GOP Establishment Reunites with Trump as Voters' Views on Conservatism Diverge

Article:

As the presidential election campaign enters its final days, a noticeable shift has occurred within the Republican Party, with prominent members of the GOP establishment re-endorsing Donald Trump after initially distancing themselves from the nominee.

Notable figures such as Jason Chaffetz, the former House Oversight Committee chair, and Sen. Deb Fischer of Nebraska, have returned to Trump's camp after initially withdrawing their endorsements following the release of the "grab 'em by the pussy" tape. Even Trump skeptic and conservative pundit Hugh Hewitt has joined the ranks of those backing the Republican nominee.

The rift between the GOP elites and their voters has become increasingly apparent, as the elites' interpretation of conservatism, often defined as economic, social, and defense conservatism, has been challenged by the base's beliefs, which some perceive as racism, sexism, and nationalism.

A new Pew Research Center poll reveals that the hope among GOP elders for a return to the previous status quo, where the party's base is perceived as caring about issues like tort reform and the capital gains tax, is unlikely. The poll shows that 65% of Republican and Republican-leaning voters believe Trump represents the core principles and positions the Republican Party should stand for, while 31% think he does not.

The divide between conservative and moderate or liberal Republicans is significant, with conservative Republican voters being far more likely to view Trump as representative of the party's principles. In contrast, only about half of moderate and liberal Republican voters see Trump as embodying the party's core values.

The election's outcome will likely determine the future direction of the Republican Party, with a Trump victory potentially leading to a quick consolidation under his leadership. Even if Trump loses, the genie cannot be put back in the bottle, as the party's base's views on conservatism have become increasingly clear.

Trump's political beliefs have remained consistent throughout his campaign, with a focus on foreign policy and law and order. His stance on immigration, Obamacare, and Common Core, among other issues, has been shaped by right-wing media, as reported by New York magazine's Gabriel Sherman. Trump's earliest advisers, including notorious trickster Roger Stone and right-wing lawyer Sam Nunberg, provided him with insights into the GOP base's concerns.

The Republican Party's future remains uncertain, as the divide between the GOP elites and their voters becomes more pronounced. The party's base's views on conservatism, as expressed by Trump, have challenged the traditional definition and may lead to a significant shift in the party's direction, regardless of the election's outcome.

Title: President Obama Strengthens Alliances in Asia Through Trans-Pacific Partnership

Article:

President Obama has recently spent time in the Philippines and Malaysia, focusing on strengthening alliances in Asia and building multilateral organizations in a region that is shaping global economic and political rules. The economic centerpiece of America's Asia policy is the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a comprehensive trade and investment pact among 12 countries representing 40% of global GDP and 30% of global trade.

The TPP, which is currently under debate in Congress, is a crucial part of the effort to secure the Pacific Rim trade deal. The agreement, if approved, will be a linchpin in the TPP's development into a Free Trade Area of the Pacific, potentially including all 21 Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) countries and non-APEC countries such as India and Columbia.

While the economic benefits of the TPP have been the primary focus of the debate, the agreement's impact on security is another less-discussed aspect that reinforces the economic arguments in support of the pact. The TPP provisions and deeper engagement with trading partners are essential for protecting the United States from non-traditional security risks.

These risks include the re-emergence of pandemic diseases, such as Severe Acute Respiratory System (SARS), which was first discovered in Asia and killed thousands as it spread to three dozen countries. The World Bank estimates SARS cost the global economy $54 billion, and the costs of a future pandemic might be as high as $3 trillion. Other non-traditional challenges relate to human health, such as food security and nutrition, which have a significant impact on the productivity of countries that have signed the agreement.

The TPP also addresses some non-traditional risks more explicitly. For example, illegal fishing would decline, helping meet the nutritional needs of the developing world and lessening disruptive human migration. The deal also aims to reduce deforestation and illegal animal trafficking, which contribute to climate change and the incidence of zoonotic diseases.

Other explicit benefits include improving transparency and non-discrimination provisions with regard to state-linked companies and government procurement. When people describe the TPP as the highest quality trade deal ever negotiated, it's in part because of these benefits, which haven't been found in previous free trade agreements.

Greater global interdependence has increased the non-traditional security challenges we face. The TPP would help manage these challenges by raising the capital of our trade partners and binding us together in the common cause of promoting a rules-based, sustainable global economy. Such an alliance will be necessary if we are to lessen the impact of the risks we all face.

The TPP is more than the sum of its terms. For our friends across the Pacific, it is a capacity-builder promoting a more peaceful and prosperous world. The United States increasingly will need to ally with its political and economic partners to help address the full range of security issues. The failure of our friends to do so will contribute to our own.

Today's risks are tomorrow's security crises. The violence this week is a stark reminder that the world is a very dangerous place, and the United States needs strong partners to keep Americans safe. A century ago, President Woodrow Wilson remarked that "we are citizens of the world.... The tragedy of our times is that we do not know this." The world has become even more intertwined since his observation. The far-reaching benefits of the TPP bring into clear focus the realization that we must do our part to fulfill America's obligation as a leading citizen of the world.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Lawsuit Against Obama's 2014 Immigration Executive Actions

Article:

The Supreme Court has announced that it will hear a lawsuit filed by 26 states against President Obama's 2014 executive actions aimed at protecting millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation. The decision is expected by the end of June.

The states' standing to sue the president in the first place has been contested, and the substantive claims have been deemed groundless. The United States is home to over 11 million undocumented immigrants. The feasibility of deporting all of them is widely questioned, with the focus instead shifting towards addressing public safety concerns and deferring action on most of the remaining immigrants, while helping them to come out of the shadows.

In 2012, the Obama administration implemented a program that granted work permits and exempted young immigrants brought to the country as children from deportation. In November 2014, the president announced a plan to offer work permits and a three-year reprieve from deportation to as many as five million undocumented parents of American citizens or permanent residents, provided they had no criminal record and had lived in the country for at least five years.

The issue of integrating hardworking, community-rooted undocumented immigrants is not a new one. In a 1980 presidential debate, George Bush criticized harsh efforts to marginalize undocumented immigrants, stating, "We're creating a whole society of really honorable, decent, family-loving people that are in violation of the law." President Obama, along with other politically-reality-based figures on both the left and the right, shares this understanding, but congressional Republicans have failed to pass any meaningful immigration reform.

Title: Gun Control Advocacy Shifts from Capitol Hill to Main Street

Article:

In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre last December, President Barack Obama called for an end to the nation's indifference towards gun violence. However, a year and a failed Senate vote later, the major players in the gun control push have retreated from the public eye, with the fight moving from Capitol Hill to Main Street.

The focus has shifted from an immediate public push for legislation in Congress to a series of local events across the country and the building of a political infrastructure capable of competing with the National Rifle Association (NRA). Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America, which organized a successful campaign this summer to pressure Starbucks into banning guns from its cafes, is preparing a similar effort aimed at McDonald's, according to the organization's founder, Shannon Watts.

Saturday's anniversary of the Sandy Hook tragedy was not marked by a significant political event in Washington D.C. The Newtown families requested a solemn remembrance rather than a political production. President Obama marked the massacre's anniversary with a private moment of silence at the White House, rather than visiting Connecticut or attending the National Cathedral memorial service.

The nation's latest school shooting, which left a shooter dead and a classmate in critical condition on Friday, did not come as a surprise. The White House released a statement saying Obama was briefed about the situation and that federal officials remain in touch with their local law enforcement counterparts.

Gun control advocates have learned political lessons from the Newtown shooting, where the Senate waited four months to vote on background check legislation. Not only did they lose momentum and give the NRA a chance to rally its supporters, but the 20 years of inaction on gun control meant lawmakers were not well-versed on the issue.

"The infrastructure just wasn't there to turn it around quickly—the knowledge wasn't there among Hill staff, among members of Congress who hadn't voted on it for a decade," said Lanae Erickson Hatalsky, the director of social policy and politics at Third Way, a centrist think tank. "Now all of us know a heck of a lot more about this. We won't need to take so much time to figure that out. If there is a tragedy that specifically involves one of the policies we're talking about, we'll see more swift action."

Last year, when Obama returned to Washington after speaking at the Newtown memorial service, Dan Gross, the president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, was the first gun control activist to get a White House meeting. This was partly because he was the only game in town. Since then, former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords' Americans for Responsible Solutions, the Sandy Hook Promise, and Moms Demand Action have all formed. The post-Obama campaign nonprofit Organizing for Action launched in January with gun violence prevention as one of its four main policy areas.

OFA solicited its members recently to host Newtown anniversary vigils but said it was not using the date to make a policy push; volunteers were simply "coming together in their communities in remembrance of the tragic events in Newtown a year ago," a spokesman said. The low-key events were meant to keep activists engaged and lawmakers from forgetting the issue. They are also planning for the midterm elections while doing the macabre job of preparing a response for what they see as the inevitability of the next mass shooting while at the same time making the fight as much cultural as political.

"I hope there's not a next time, but if there is, we've laid the groundwork; we've got momentum across the country," said Rep. Mike Thompson (D-Calif.), the chairman of the House Democrats' gun violence task force.

Shannon Watts, the founder of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America, is at the forefront of this effort. Watts, a mother and stepmother of five, is the head of an organization aiming to become the MADD of gun control. Watts hopes to make background checks a women's issue, similar to how abortion rights are, forcing candidates, particularly Democrats, to forcefully support it. The McDonald's campaign, coming off the successful Starbucks effort, won't be the last.

"There are more white whales out there," she said in an interview at a Capitol Hill Starbucks.

Title: Reflection on 2016 Election Predictions and Trump Presidency

Article:

The 2016 presidential election has led to introspection for many, including political commentator and conservative critic of Donald Trump, David French. French, who was a vocal "Never Trump" supporter during the primaries and general election, has faced criticism from both sides of the political spectrum.

In an article, French admits to getting the election wrong, as he had predicted a Clinton victory, but he argues that this does not mean he was wrong about Trump as a person or his presidency. French states that the idea that getting the election wrong equates to being wrong about Trump's character is a flawed assumption.

French acknowledges that he got some things wrong about what a Trump presidency would look like, but he is pleasantly surprised by the conservative-leaning appointments and policy proposals made by the Trump administration. He also notes the benefits of having a political novice in the White House, citing Trump's unconventional approach to diplomacy and policy-making.

However, French emphasizes that he is concerned about Trump's character, citing his reported lack of interest in daily intelligence briefings, his impulsive behavior, and his disregard for policy due diligence. French states that he firmly believes that character is destiny and that Trump's character troubles him deeply.

Despite the criticism and self-reflection, French does not express remorse, but acknowledges that if the Trump administration's serious and sober-minded advisors can constrain and contain the dangerous aspects of Trump's character, he may reconsider his stance.

Title: Bipartisan Government Funding Deal Stalled Amid Border Wall Dispute

Article:

With the departure of President Donald Trump from office, a bipartisan deal to fund the government ahead of the holidays appears unlikely due to the ongoing border wall dispute. The House and Senate left town on Thursday without a strategy to prevent a partial government shutdown next week, putting Congress on the brink of an intractable conflict that could last through New Year's Day, furloughing hundreds of thousands of workers and costing taxpayers millions.

Lawmakers in both parties are frustrated, stating that congressional leaders have made no progress since Tuesday, when Trump announced that he would take the blame for a government shutdown if he does not receive funding for his border wall. There is no public or secret plan to prevent a partial government shutdown, according to lawmakers.

"There is no discernable plan. None that’s been disclosed," said Sen. John Cornyn, the Senate's No. 2 Republican, as he threw his hands into the air. "Everybody’s looking to [Trump] for a signal about what he wants to do. So far, it’s not clear."

The House is not planning to return until the night of Dec. 19, leaving only about 72 hours to reach a border wall deal that has eluded both parties for months. Democrats say they are waiting on Republicans, and Republicans say they are waiting on Trump.

With one week to go, the GOP must find an agreement that can satisfy both Trump and Democratic leaders, who have only grown more emboldened since their sit-down with Trump. "I’ve not heard of any Republican who’s sitting down and figuring out how to get this through. There’s no plan," said Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.).

There is no indication that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer are even talking. Senators in both parties said they were unaware of anything cooking between the two leaders, and the often-chatty Schumer was tight-lipped when asked if there were ongoing discussions. "No comment," he said Thursday.

The House was expected to make the first move this week, with House GOP leaders planning to try and pass a bill giving $5 billion for Trump's wall and forcing Senate Democrats to reject it under the chamber's 60-vote threshold. However, with morale and attendance low in the House following a brutal election loss last month, Republicans left Washington empty-handed, with all eyes now focused on the Senate.

"It’s just all politics and theatrics," said Rep. Tom Cole (R-Okla.). He said leaders of both parties have the same thought going into next week's final round of negotiations: "Somebody has to lose, and it’s going to not be them."

Meanwhile, Democrats say they are completely in the dark because Republican leaders have not taken part in formal back-and-forth negotiations for more than two weeks, according to a Democratic aide. Republicans have already rejected the Democratic proposal to freeze the budget of the Department of Homeland Security, including border fencing, through next October, while approving new funding for the rest of the government. However, Democrats say they have had radio silence since then from the GOP.

Privately, some GOP appropriators have been told to prepare backup options to temporarily extend funding, though they admit they have little confidence that the bills could be signed by Trump without a cash infusion for the border wall. Some Republicans say they want to delay the decision until Jan. 3 at 11:59 p.m., the exact minute when House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) would take over leadership in the House. Others are pushing GOP leaders to move the deadline to Dec. 26 to give them at least a few days at home with their families for Christmas.

Another idea—that some appropriators are already preparing—is a long-term funding bill that freezes funding through October 2019. "We’re at an impasse. Something’s going to happen or we’re going to have to have a [continuing resolution] or a shutdown," said Senate Appropriations chief Richard Shelby (R-Ala.).

Six of the seven spending bills are ready to go next week, which would make up nearly $200 billion in total spending. However, Republican leaders in the House are refusing to put any spending package on the floor that doesn't include border wall money. Meanwhile, Democratic leaders have hammered Trump for his vow that he would be "proud" to shutter one-quarter of the government—delaying paychecks for hundreds of thousands of federal workers—over the holidays.

Title: Trump Defends Puerto Rico Relief Efforts, Criticizes San Juan Mayor and Media

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended his administration's response to the humanitarian crisis in Puerto Rico, dismissing critics of his relief efforts as "fake news" and "politically motivated ingrates." In a series of tweets and public statements, Trump has accused Puerto Rico's mayor of San Juan, Carmen Yulin Cruz, of acting on behalf of Democrats and being "nasty" towards him.

Cruz, however, has maintained that she was only appealing for quicker help to save lives. In an interview with MSNBC, Cruz stated, "I was not saying anything nasty about the president."

Trump is scheduled to visit Puerto Rico on Tuesday to review rescue efforts. He may also visit the U.S. Virgin Islands, which is also undergoing a hurricane relief effort. Puerto Rico National Guard Maj. Paul Dahlen stated that the president's expected visit to the island is not affecting aid deliveries or any other relief operations.

In a third tweet on Sunday morning, Trump praised Puerto Rico's governor, Ricardo Rossello, and thanked him and "all of those who are working so closely with our First Responders. Fantastic job!"

Rossello told reporters on Sunday that the U.S. Defense Department has increased its presence on the island, and the emphasis remains on ensuring that "food, water and other supplies get delivered to the people of Puerto Rico." However, when asked whether all buildings were inspected for safety as Trump had claimed, Rossello said, "I’m not sure about that. There are areas in Puerto Rico that we haven’t gotten in contact."

Trump also drew criticism for stating that some people in Puerto Rico "want everything to be done for them when it should be a community effort." FEMA Administrator Brock Long acknowledged major challenges remain and there "is still a long way to go," but he said a lot has been accomplished.

Political opponents have contrasted Trump's approach to Puerto Rico with his recent hurricane recovery efforts in Texas and Florida. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) suggested skin color may be a factor in Trump's response, while Ohio Republican Gov. John Kasich stated it is "not appropriate" for Trump to criticize public officials who are "in the middle of a disaster."

Cruz herself appeared to dismiss Trump's tweets during an interview on ABC's This Week, saying that "any dialogue that goes on just has to be able to produce results." As for Trump's visit, Cruz said, "If he asks to meet with me, of course I will meet with him."

Title: Media Policy and Political Polarization: The Impact of the Telecommunications Act of 1996

Article:

The Telecommunications Act of 1996, a comprehensive overhaul of US media policy, has been linked to the rising political polarization in the United States. The act relaxed ownership regulations, leading to an increase in television channels on cable TV systems and the emergence of partisan news outlets like Fox News and MSNBC.

Research indicates that partisan news outlets attract distinct audiences, with conservatives favoring Fox News and liberals preferring MSNBC. The availability of such content is significant, as studies show that watching content on these outlets contributes to political polarization. Furthermore, increased niche programming allows non-partisans to tune out politics altogether.

A recent study published in the International Journal of Public Opinion Research suggests that structural changes to media systems, such as the Telecommunications Act of 1996, can alter the relationship between media and polarization. The study found that the relationship between media and polarization changed after 1996, with TV news contributing more to polarization following the enactment of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 than it did before.

Frequent consumers of TV news showed greater increases in polarization on a year-to-year basis after 1996 compared to individuals who spent less time watching TV news. This suggests that the policy changes may have encouraged the introduction of partisan media outlets and contributed to an increase in horse race coverage, focusing on the positive and negative traits of candidates rather than policy debates.

Critics argue that the Telecommunications Act of 1996 led to media consolidation, with companies like the Disney Corporation purchasing major TV networks like ABC. Decreased competition among cable companies following the law has been linked to hikes in cable prices, incentivizing media companies like Fox to create their own cable networks. This resulted in an increase in the number of cable stations owned by big media companies.
