The addition of partisan news sources to the media system provides viewers with an opportunity to seek out information that supports their existing worldview. Scholars have noted that when these media conglomerates took control of networks, news coverage suffered. News is now seen as an additional source of profit instead of a public service for viewers. This shift may have contributed to increasing levels of cheap, conflict-oriented programming, which has the potential to increase people's level of polarization.

In conclusion, the Telecommunications Act of 1996 appears to have played a role in the rise of political polarization by encouraging the introduction of partisan media outlets, contributing to an increase in horse race coverage, and potentially leading to decreased funding of news departments, resulting in cheap, conflict-oriented programming.

Title: Trump Faces Pressure to Show More Presidential Tone at Saturday's Republican Debate

Article:

With the South Carolina Republican primary vote scheduled for February 20, the upcoming debate on Saturday night at 9 p.m. EST is a critical event for Donald Trump's opponents, who aim to question the New York billionaire's suitability before it's too late. The debate comes as Trump, who won handily in New Hampshire after placing second in Iowa, maintains a significant lead in South Carolina polls, potentially positioning him for the party's presidential nomination by November 8.

The debate's participants include Texas Senator Ted Cruz, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, Ohio Governor John Kasich, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson. These candidates are competing to emerge as the top alternative to Trump for mainstream Republicans.

Republican strategist Doug Heye described the debate as a "melee." In previous debates, attempts to challenge Trump have been unsuccessful, with the former reality TV star demonstrating quick reflexes and a dismissive attitude towards rivals.

Trump's use of vulgar language during the New Hampshire primary campaign, repeating a comment from a rally attendee who called Cruz a "pussy," may raise concerns in South Carolina, where evangelicals form a significant voting bloc.

At a candidates' forum at evangelical Bob Jones University on Friday, Bush addressed the front-running candidate's use of obscenities, asking the crowd, "Is anybody worried about the front-running candidate shouting out obscenities at children?" Trump was not present, sending Pastor Mark Burns to speak on his behalf. When Burns stated that Trump is "pro-faith," someone from the audience shouted, "Trump is profane."

Each candidate faces specific challenges ahead of the debate. Rubio needs to demonstrate his ability to rebound from a poor debate performance in New Hampshire, while Kasich aims to generate more momentum after a second-place finish in New Hampshire. Cruz seeks to solidify his position with evangelical voters, and Bush needs to gain upward movement in any area possible. Carson, whose campaign has slowed, must demonstrate that he remains in the race.

David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois University, noted that each candidate has an image issue to address. "Can Trump start acting more presidential without losing what makes him so appealing? Can Jeb continue the flicker of momentum he has coming out of New Hampshire? Have Rubio's bruises healed? Can Carson show something that puts a spark back into his campaign? Has Kasich got more than his New Hampshire game?"

As the debate approaches, Trump has been targeting Cruz and Bush, who finished third and fourth in the New Hampshire primary, respectively. In response to an attack ad run by the Cruz campaign, Trump tweeted that he might sue Cruz to settle any remaining questions about his eligibility to run for president, given that he was born in Canada.

Cruz and many legal experts argue that Cruz meets the constitutional requirements, as he was born to an American mother and grew up in the United States. However, Trump, who has previously questioned President Barack Obama's citizenship, tweeted against Cruz, stating, "If @ TedCruz does not clean up his act, stop cheating, & doing negative ads, I have standing to sue him for not being a natural-born citizen." The Cruz campaign dismissed Trump's comments as a "Trumper-tantrum."

Title: Trump's Claims of Election Rigging: A Historical Perspective

Article:

In a recent development, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has expressed concerns about the upcoming November election being "rigged" against him. At a rally in Columbus, Ohio, Trump stated, "I'm afraid the election is going to be rigged. I have to be honest." This sentiment was echoed by Trump's unofficial advisor, Roger Stone, who has a history of promoting conspiracy theories.

Trump's allegations of election rigging are not a new tactic. During the GOP primaries, similar claims were made when the primaries were not favoring Trump. By making these claims, Trump is laying the groundwork for a potential explanation of a loss in November. Since Trump's campaign is based on winning, he cannot admit to the possibility of losing fair and square, leading him to believe someone must have stolen the election.

This line of attack is reminiscent of the supporters of past Republican presidential losers. Trump is essentially amplifying the paranoia about supposedly shady Democrats and biased mainstream media, making it a part of his official campaign narrative.

In the past, such talk was considered undignified for a presidential candidate. It was often left to campaign surrogates or fringe figures. During the 2012 election, for instance, conservative activist Dean Chambers ran the website UnskewedPolls.com, claiming polls were weighted in favor of Democrats. Chambers' re-weighted polling numbers showed a narrow win for Mitt Romney in the Electoral College. However, when Obama won with 332 electoral votes to Romney's 206, Chambers blamed his failure on voter fraud.

Democratic-leaning voters have also voiced concerns about "stolen" or "rigged" elections, but these claims have generally remained on the fringes of the party. In 2004, there were calls for contesting the general election results in Ohio over allegations of tampering with electronic voting machines. However, these calls never gained traction within John Kerry's campaign.

Comparatively, the infamous election of 2000 saw a disinformation campaign by Republicans, claiming Democratic officials in Florida were manipulating the recount in Miami-Dade County. This led to the infamous Brooks Brothers riot, where khaki-clad Republicans disrupted a ballot recount meeting.

Ironically, one of the leaders of the Brooks Brothers riot was none other than Trump's current advisor, Roger Stone. Thus, Donald Trump's claims of election rigging and potential post-election disputes are not unprecedented, and he will likely have support from various sectors of the Republican Party and right-wing media. However, the candidate himself openly discussing claims of stolen elections three months before voting starts is a departure from past practices. This suggests that Trump may not accept a loss gracefully if he loses the election.

Title: Obama Declares State of the Union as "Stronger," Amidst Persisting Economic Challenges

Article:

In his State of the Union address, President Barack Obama declared that the state of the union is "stronger." However, this assertion has been met with skepticism, as millions of Americans continue to struggle with unemployment, and the country grapples with the aftermath of economic bailouts and government programs.

The President's optimistic assessment overlooks the challenges faced by many Americans, including those still unemployed and the taxpayers who have shouldered the burdens of government initiatives that have not yielded the expected results. The President's second-term agenda includes a range of issues, such as gun control, global warming, immigration, and raising the minimum wage.

During his address, President Obama assured the nation that his proposals would not increase the deficit. He emphasized the need for a "smarter government that sets priorities and invests in broad-based growth." However, it is worth noting that the national debt has more than doubled since Obama took office, currently standing at approximately $16 trillion, compared to around $10 trillion at the start of his presidency.

Critics argue that the President's economic policies have not been effective in reducing the deficit, as he had promised during his first term. Instead, the deficit has grown significantly. The President's latest proposal aims to create jobs, which he described as the "North Star" that should guide the nation's efforts.

The address was met with a mixed response, with some finding the President's optimism inspiring, while others questioned the feasibility of his proposals and the accuracy of his statements. Vice President Joe Biden was seen wiping tears from his eyes during the address, while House Speaker John Boehner maintained a stoic expression. The Vice President, in an attempt to keep up with the President's optimistic tone, was seen wearing rose-colored glasses during the speech.

Title: "Trumbull's 'Declaration of Independence' - A Depiction of Historical Fact and Portraiture Accuracy"

Article:

John Trumbull's painting, "Declaration of Independence," is a well-known and iconic representation of the momentous event that took place on July 4, 1776, when the United States declared its independence from Great Britain. However, the painting, which has hung in the Rotunda of the Capitol in Washington for nearly two centuries, depicts a scene that did not occur as portrayed.

In the painting, the five men appointed to draft the Declaration of Independence—John Adams, Roger Sherman, Robert Livingston, Thomas Jefferson, and Benjamin Franklin—are shown presenting their draft to the Continental Congress in Philadelphia. However, it was on June 28 that the committee's original draft was reported to the Congress, and only Jefferson, who chaired the drafting committee, would have submitted the document to the presiding officer. The vote in favor of independence came on July 2, and the final text was agreed upon and sent for printing on the morning of July 4.

The signing of the document took place two weeks later, on August 2. There was no ceremony or posed formality, and some congressional delegates did not affix their signatures for months, while others, including Livingston, never had a chance to sign at all.

Trumbull also took liberties with many of the painting's physical details, such as the seating arrangements, window treatments, and congressional tableau. However, when it came to the likenesses of the men depicted, Trumbull prioritized authenticity. He painted many of the signers from life, traveling extensively to sketch or paint them in person. Trumbull, who himself fought in the Revolutionary War, was passionate about preserving the true-to-life facsimiles of the "great actors" in what he considered "the noblest series of actions which have ever presented themselves in the history of man."

Trumbull's painting, while not an accurate depiction of the events that transpired on July 4, 1776, serves as a valuable historical record of the likenesses of the founding fathers. The painting took more than 30 years to complete, and Trumbull journeyed extensively to sketch or paint in person as many of the surviving signers as he could find. He recorded some of his travels, noting that he painted Adams in London, Jefferson in Paris, Hancock and Samuel Adams in Boston, and others in various locations. Trumbull's dedication to capturing the personal resemblance of the founding fathers ensures that their images will be remembered for generations to come.

Title: K-pop Fans' Online Activism: A Double-Edged Sword

Article:

K-pop fans have recently gained attention for their online activism, with thousands of tickets registered for President Trump's rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, allegedly with the intention of not showing up. The event, which saw the arena appearing more than half empty, has been interpreted by some as a demonstration of solidarity with Black Lives Matter protesters and Juneteenth celebrants.

This is not the first instance of K-pop fans' online activism. Earlier this month, they sabotaged a surveillance app used by the Dallas Police Department, and they have also derailed a "White Lives Matter" hashtag.

While these actions have been celebrated by many on the left, including politicians and protesters, they have also sparked discussions about K-pop's history of cultural misappropriation and racism. In recent years, Korean pop idols have been called out for perpetuating stereotypes about black Americans and for misappropriating black culture. Artists have also received backlash for statements like claiming they are skilled at "talking Black" and for racist acts like wearing blackface.

Miranda Ruth Larsen, a K-pop fan and cultural studies researcher at the University of Tokyo, whose work focuses on male Korean and Japanese idols and groups, discussed this issue on the Reset podcast. She stated, "It sounds sort of racist because it often is racist."

Larsen emphasized that the cultural misappropriation within K-pop should not be solely blamed on the artists. "So let's say that a K-pop artist is wearing a controversial hairstyle—like they're wearing dreads or they're wearing cornrows—eight times out of 10, they did not pick that hairstyle," Larsen said. "The decision for their hairstyle came from a company, came to a manager, came through an entire chain of command that is responsible and culpable for this bad decision."

Larsen believes it is crucial for fans and journalists to understand this history and the workings of the industry to get a full picture of the recent online activism campaigns coming from K-pop fandoms. Without this understanding, it is impossible to fully comprehend the nature of these activist actions.

This article aims to provide factual information and promote understanding, as part of ███'s mission to answer important questions and offer free articles, videos, and podcasts that have the power to save lives. ███'s work is reaching more people than ever, but resources are needed to continue this vital work during a pandemic and an economic downturn. Consider making a contribution to ███ today.

Title: White House Hesitant to Verify Latest Claims of Chemical Weapons Use in Syria, Maintains Investigation Ongoing

Article:

The White House has not ruled out providing further assistance to Syrian rebel groups following opposition claims that the government of Bashar al-Assad used chemical weapons to kill over 1,000 people. The administration is seeking an urgent United Nations (U.N.) investigation and demanding accountability, but has not yet verified the authenticity of the videos purportedly showing civilians suffering from chemical agents outside Damascus.

White House spokesman Josh Earnest stated, "There is an investigation team that's on the ground in Syria right now. And we are hopeful that the Assad regime will follow through on what they have claimed previously, that they are interested in a credible investigation that gets to the bottom of reports that chemical weapons have been used."

The Obama administration has been facing pressure to take more decisive steps in Syria, and the latest development could potentially change the overall calculus for the United States. Key questions that would arise include what new steps the U.S. would take, how it would address uncertainty about the rebel makeup, and how it would approach the worsening trust gap regarding rebel assistance.

The administration has previously opted for a political solution and provided humanitarian, logistical, and limited weaponry and other hardware, but has faced challenges in identifying which rebel groups to support due to their alleged ties to militant groups, including some with ties to al Qaeda.

Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Martin Dempsey, wrote in a letter to Rep. Eliot Engel of New York that Syria is not about choosing between two sides, but rather about choosing one among many sides. He expressed concern that the chosen side may not be ready to promote their interests and those of the U.S. when the balance shifts in their favor.

Political mistrust, sharp partisan divisions in Washington, and close congressional vetting have also influenced the response to Syria. According to experts who have traveled to Syria during the war, opposition groups have little faith in the U.S. David Lesch, Middle East history professor at Trinity University and author of "Syria: The Fall of the House of Assad," stated, "Our credibility was not high to begin with and obviously did not improve with time. They basically shrug their shoulders and say, 'Oh well, what is new?' They feel like they are on their own on this."

This is the second time the administration has faced questions about chemical weapons use in Syria. Last August, President Barack Obama said using chemical weapons would cross a "red line" and provoke a U.S. military response. However, the "red line" tag has reportedly damaged U.S. credibility in the region. Andrew Tabler, author of "In the Lion's Den: An Eyewitness Account of Washington's Battle with Syria," stated, "Reacting way too late - that has been our policy on Syria for some time."

A team of U.N. chemical weapons inspectors landed in Syria this week to begin probing chemical weapons allegations, and the U.N. Security Council planned a meeting on Wednesday to address the issue.

Title: The Evolution and Challenges of Journalistic Objectivity in American History

Article:

The contemporary debate over journalistic objectivity and accuracy is a contentious issue, with concerns being raised from both sides of the political spectrum. On the right, there is an increasing embrace of partisan slants in news reporting, as seen in outlets like Breitbart, Fox News, and various right-wing imitators. On the left, outlets such as Truthout, HuffPost, and the New York Times have been criticized for sloppiness and displays of partisanship, driven in part by hostility towards President Trump and the Republican Party, as well as economic pressure to generate online traffic and increase ad revenue.

However, it is essential to recognize that the standards of fairness and accuracy often associated with journalism are not the American norm. These standards became the norm in the decades following World War II, as the bipartisan centrist-liberal consensus that prevailed in political culture left its mark on the media. This was also a time of unprecedented uniformity in the institutions that delivered the news to the American people.

Before the mid-20th century, newspapers were explicitly tied to different parties and factions, and regularly used blistering language to denounce those on other sides of political disputes. They also published rumors and conspiracy theories alongside factual accounts of events, often mixing the one in with the other. This informal and blatantly slanted style of reportage continued down through the 19th century.

In the words of historian Christopher Childers, during the time of the Civil War, the partisan press often acted as a part of the campaign apparatus, a standard practice that most Americans accepted. Candidates used partisan newspapers to promote themselves and their platform without worrying about anything resembling the objective journalism that modern political observers claim we have lost. From the vantage point of the 19th century, the non-partisan media seems the anomaly.

It was an anomaly—and an extremely salutary one. As the United States became a global hegemon at the close of World War II, the American press became professionalized and set itself the goal of serving as an arbiter of extra-partisan truth. The new standards were ideals—goals to strive for while often falling short. But they also did lots of good, imposing rigor on reporting and giving journalists formal and informal guidelines about how to report in a trustworthy and fair-minded way about the world.

Many reporters, editors, publishers, and broadcast news producers still work very hard to realize these ideals today—reporting aggressively but also with great care, double- and triple-checking sources and facts, reflecting thoughtfully on the competing demands of the public's right to know and the need for government secrecy.

However, growing numbers of media companies and personalities are also willing to cut corners or abandon these norms entirely in the pursuit of influence and profit. The result is a reversion to the flagrantly partisan norms that prevailed before the mid-20th century. The consequences of this shift are uncertain, but it is hard to imagine them being good. The centrifugal forces driving political polarization contribute to the breakdown of trans-partisan journalistic norms, which in turn makes the polarization worse. The feedback loop then breeds cynicism and contributes to the collapse of social trust and the erosion of the authority of all institutions that claim to speak for and act in the name of the common good.

Before long, it can begin to seem that it's impossible to evaluate the world dispassionately—that claims to objectivity itself are just masks concealing insidious power-grabs. This may sound like a headlong leap into postmodern relativism, but it's really a plunge back into the rancorous squabbles and sometimes insurrectionary clashes of an earlier era in American history—before the country achieved its power and influence on the world stage or attained its still-formidable economic might.

Can the country maintain its power and prestige with a citizenry that treats every item of news about the world with maximal suspicion, and when public debate about matters large and small invariably takes the form of acrimonious partisan vituperation? We do not yet know the answer. But in the coming years, we're likely to find out.

Title: US Health Secretary Calls for Expanded Health Care Access Without "Reproductive Health and Rights" References at UN General Assembly

Article:

In a speech delivered at the United Nations General Assembly today, US Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar called for expanded access to health care without the inclusion of terms such as "reproductive health and rights."

Azar stated, "We do not support references to ambiguous terms and expressions, such as sexual and reproductive health and rights, in UN documents because they can undermine the critical role of the family and promote practices like abortion in circumstances that do not enjoy international consensus and which can be misinterpreted by UN agencies."

The statement, suggesting a stance against abortion, was presented during a high-level meeting on universal health coverage. The meeting aims to accelerate progress toward universal health coverage for everyone around the world, which would include access to health care services, medicines, and vaccines. The effort is part of the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, under which all countries have committed to try to achieve universal health coverage by 2030.

Azar further stated, "We therefore request that the UN, including UN agencies, focus on concrete efforts that enjoy broad consensus among member states." He added, "To that end, only documents that have been adopted by all member states should be cited in UN resolutions."

In his remarks, Azar was joined by health officials from Guatemala, Brazil, Iraq, Poland, and Hungary. He said that he and the other health officials were speaking on behalf of the United States, Bahrain, Belarus, Brazil, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Egypt, Guatemala, Haiti, Hungary, Iraq, Libya, Mali, Nigeria, Poland, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, United Arab Emirates, and Yemen.

Azar concluded, "We support equal access to health care which includes but is not limited to reproductive concerns, maternal health, voluntary and informed family planning, HIV, elimination of violence against women and girls, and empowerment to reach the highest standard of health." He emphasized, "Let us focus on concrete issues and challenges to accelerate access to health for all. International solidarity has a key role to play in order to build broad consensus by member states."

Title: CNN/ORC Poll Shows Shift in Midterm Election Outlook for U.S. Congress

Article:

A new CNN/ORC International poll indicates a significant change in the battle for control of the U.S. Congress in next year's midterm elections. The poll, conducted last week and released Tuesday, shows the Republican Party with a 49% to 47% advantage over the Democratic Party among registered voters in a generic ballot question.

The generic ballot question asks respondents to choose between a Democrat or a Republican in their congressional district without identifying the candidates. In a similar poll conducted a month ago, the Democrats held a 50% to 42% advantage.

The shift in the poll results follows a political uproar over the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), which included the botched rollout of HealthCare.gov and controversy over insurance policy cancelations due primarily to the new health law.

The turnaround in the CNN/ORC poll follows similar shifts in recent national surveys from Quinnipiac University and Fox News. At a news conference two weeks ago, President Barack Obama acknowledged that problems plaguing the startup of the new healthcare law could hurt Democrats.

"There is no doubt that our failure to rollout the ACA smoothly has put a burden on Democrats, whether they are running or not, because they stood up and supported this effort through thick and thin," Obama said.

The CNN/ORC poll, released as the President makes a West Coast campaign fundraising swing on behalf of fellow Democrats, indicates both parties making gains within their base. According to CNN Polling Director Keating Holland, "The biggest shifts toward the Republicans came among white voters, higher-income Americans, and people who live in rural areas, while Democrats have gained strength in the past month among some of their natural constituencies, such as non-white voters and lower-income Americans."

"If those patterns persist into 2014, it may indicate that Obamacare is popular among those who it was designed to help the most, but unpopular among the larger group of voters who are personally less concerned about health insurance and health care," Holland said.

Currently, the Republicans have a 17-seat advantage in the U.S. House, with the Democrats holding a 55-45 majority in the Senate. While the generic ballot question is a commonly used indicator when it comes to the battle for Congress, the poll results are a long way from predicting what will happen next November.

"There is just under a year to go before any votes are actually cast, and the 'generic ballot' question is not necessarily a good predictor of the actual outcome of 435 separate elections," Holland cautions. "A year before the 2010 midterms, for example, the Democrats held a six-point lead on the generic ballot, but the GOP wound up regaining control of the House in that election cycle, thanks to an historic 63-seat pickup."

The poll was conducted November 18-20 for CNN by ORC International, with 843 adult Americans, including 749 registered voters, questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Pope Francis Lists "Ailments of the Curia" in Annual Christmas Greeting

Article:

Pope Francis, in his annual Christmas greeting to the cardinals, bishops, and priests of the Vatican, delivered a critical address on Monday, highlighting what he termed as the "spiritual Alzheimer's" among some members of the clergy who prioritize power over religious life.

The Pope denounced the "terrorism of gossip" and its potential to ruin the reputation of colleagues and brothers, as well as the formation of cliques that can become a cancer threatening the harmony of the Church. He described power-hungry clergy as living lives characterized by "mediocre and progressive spiritual emptiness that no academic degree can fill."

Francis emphasized that these maladies and temptations pose a danger to every Christian and any administrative organization, and can affect both individuals and the corporate level. He listed 15 "Ailments of the Curia," complete with footnotes and Biblical references, which he had compiled.

The speech was met with tepid applause, and few were smiling as Francis enumerated the ailments. The annual Christmas greeting comes at a tense time for the Curia, the central administration of the Holy See, which governs the 1.2-billion-strong Catholic Church.

Pope Francis, an Argentine who had never worked in the Italian Curia before becoming pope, has faced pushback from some cardinals who feel he is criticizing an institution he does not fully understand.

In an interview with CNN's Christiane Amanpour, Vatican watcher Marco Politi stated that Francis has also faced pushback for his progressive social views. "Within the Church, there is a tough group of conservative bishops and priests and cardinals, and also very traditionalist bishops and cardinals who are practically against the Pope, who are working against the Pope," said Politi. "They don't like what he wanted to do with the synod about family, to give new possibilities to remarried and divorced people to get the communion, or to have a new look on the homosexual union."

For a complete list of Pope Francis' 15 "Ailments of the Curia," please click here.

Title: Trump's Fact-Bending History: A Look at the President's Record of Distortions and Falsehoods

Article:

Fred Trump, the father of the current U.S. President, was born in New York City. Contrary to some claims made by the President, his grandfather was born in Germany. This fact has been confirmed, but it is at least the third time that the President has stated his father was born in Germany when this is not accurate.

The reason for these inaccuracies is unclear, but it is believed that Trump has a history of bending facts to fit the narrative he is presenting about himself. For most individuals, making factual errors in a public setting can be disconcerting and embarrassing. However, Trump does not seem to share this sentiment. Facts are, for Trump, whatever he wants them to be, and they can change depending on his own circumstances. He tells a story of his life in which he is always the hero, always the winner, and repeats this story consistently.

There are several theories as to why Trump's record of distortions and falsehoods seem to have no effect on his willingness to continue lying or on how people perceive him.

1. It's baked in the cake: Donald Trump's history of bending (and breaking) the truth is not a new phenomenon. During the 2016 campaign, he made numerous exaggerations, distortions, and outright false statements. Voters were aware of this, as evidenced by the fact that only 33% said he was "honest and trustworthy" according to exit polling in 2016. However, a significant number of voters (64%) did not consider him honest or trustworthy, yet still voted for him.

2. All politicians lie: During the 2016 campaign, some voters defended Trump by stating that, while he lies, all politicians do. This argument is flawed, as Trump did not acknowledge his own false statements. However, it suggests that voters saw Trump as transparent in his willingness to say anything and do anything to win, which differentiated him from other politicians.

3. Many people do not trust the media: Trump did not create distrust in the media, but he has weaponized it in a way that has not been seen before. The term "fake news" has become ubiquitous in the culture, with some viewing it as an ironic punchline, while others see it as a legitimate criticism of the media. The rise of Fox News and its near-monopoly on conservative mind-share in the country has contributed to both a political and economic model that monetizes distrust in the media for gain.

In conclusion, the President's history of distortions and falsehoods has not deterred him from continuing to lie, and it has not significantly affected how people perceive him. This is due to a combination of factors, including the acceptance of lies as a part of politics, the weaponization of media distrust, and the belief that Trump is transparent in his willingness to say anything to win.

Title: DC Convention Results: Marco Rubio and John Kasich Take the Lead, Ted Cruz Wins 9 Delegates

Article:

The District of Columbia Republican Convention took place on Saturday, with Marco Rubio and John Kasich emerging as the frontrunners. Rubio received 37.3% of the votes, while Kasich was close behind with 35.5%, a difference of less than two percentage points. Donald Trump and Senator Ted Cruz trailed with 13.8% and 12.4% of the votes, respectively, and neither will receive delegates from this race.

Rubio and Kasich will each receive 10 and 9 delegates, respectively, from the DC convention. The state's other 29 delegates will be awarded at the state convention next month.

The DC convention is not a traditional primary or caucus, as the District of Columbia does not impact the GOP in the general election due to the Republicans knowing they won't get 10% of the vote. However, they do participate in the primary, and any registered Republican can vote at a single convention roughly two blocks from the White House.

The race for the 19 delegates up for grabs today is significant, as the race to 1,237 delegates is expected to come down to the wire. The rules for the DC convention are assigned proportionally to any candidate meeting a 15% threshold, but a winner can sweep all 19 if they make it to 50% plus one. Voting took place from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., but voters with religious restrictions on voting during the day can come and vote after dark.

There are two other races going on today, including the GOP primary in Guam, which won't be done until long after the DC results are in, and the "conventions" in Wyoming to select a total of 29 delegates. The results of the DC convention are expected after 9 p.m., and this article will be updated at that time.

Title: Biden's Response to Ukraine Business Dealings Query Sparks Controversy

Article:

The ongoing investigation into President Trump's dealings with Ukraine has led to renewed scrutiny of former Vice President Joe Biden's son, Hunter Biden, and his business dealings with a Ukrainian oil company. The Trump campaign has seized on Biden's perceived defensive response to questions about his son's business activities as evidence of guilt.

During a press conference in Los Angeles on Friday, CBS News reporter Bo Erickson asked Biden whether his son's lucrative job with Burisma Holdings, an oil company owned by an oligarch accused of corruption, posed a conflict of interest. Biden's response was testy, denying any conflict of interest and accusing the reporter of focusing on the wrong issues.

"It's not a conflict of interest," Biden said. "There's been no indication of any conflict of interest from Ukraine or anywhere else. Period."

Biden's response was reminiscent of a similar exchange he had with a journalist two weeks prior, where he berated a reporter for questioning him about his son's Ukraine entanglements.

The Trump campaign has seized on Biden's responses, with Deputy Communications Director Matt Wolking stating in an emailed statement that Biden "bullies the press" and has no good explanation for what many independent observers see as an obvious conflict of interest.

The controversy surrounding Biden's son's business dealings in Ukraine has persisted since 2016, when allegations emerged that Biden had threatened to withhold a $1 billion loan guarantee from Ukraine if the government did not oust Viktor Shokin, the country's top prosecutor, who had targeted Burisma. Biden has denied the story, but a Monmouth poll released Tuesday found that 43% of Americans believe it, and the charge continues to impact his primary campaign.

Biden was the clear front-runner in May, holding a commanding 27-point advantage over second-place Senator Bernie Sanders, but he now holds just a two-point lead over Senator Elizabeth Warren, according to the RealClearPolitics polling average. Warren has also surpassed Biden in the two most recent national polls, both released Wednesday.

Furthermore, Biden's fundraising has also taken a hit, with third-quarter figures showing that he raised $15.2 million in the last three months, placing him fourth in fundraising behind Sanders, Warren, and South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg.

Title: Endorsement of Mitt Romney for President: A Call for American Leadership and Economic Renewal

Article:

In an endorsement article, the authors express their optimism for the future of the United States despite historical comparisons to other great powers that have fallen. They argue that the U.S. remains the world's most powerful and indispensable country, contributing significantly to global peace, prosperity, and democratic values.

The authors highlight the ongoing threats of international terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, emphasizing the importance of American leadership in maintaining global security. They argue that the U.S. cannot be strong militarily, politically, or diplomatically unless it is strong economically.

The authors then endorse Mitt Romney for president, citing his experience, strategy, and temperament as qualifications for leading a robust economic recovery and addressing the mounting federal debt. They believe that Romney's understanding of the link between U.S. prosperity and influence abroad makes him an ideal candidate.

The article outlines Romney's vision for American leadership, which is based on the premise that peace abroad depends on American vitality. The authors mention Romney's support for alliances, military strength, free trade, opposition to weapons of mass destruction proliferation, and his unwavering commitment to democratic principles.

The authors conclude by stating that America is at its best when it assumes a leadership role on the world stage and that Romney, if elected, will work towards building an America that remains the hope of the world—a world of peace, justice, and democracy.

Notable figures who have served as U.S. secretaries of state, such as Condoleezza Rice, James A. Baker, George P. Shultz, and Henry A. Kissinger, are mentioned in the article. However, no specific policies or strategies proposed by Romney are detailed in the provided text.

Title: U.S. Mission in Benghazi Warns of Potential Attacks Before Fatal Assault

Article:

A classified cable, dated August 16, 2012, and marked "SECRET," revealed that the U.S. Mission in Benghazi convened an emergency meeting less than a month before the deadly attack that killed Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. The cable, which was reviewed by ███, summarized an Aug. 15 emergency meeting and stated that the State Department's senior security officer, also known as the RSO, did not believe the consulate could be protected due to limited manpower, security measures, weapons capabilities, host nation support, and the overall size of the compound.

The cable also warned of approximately ten Islamist militias and Al-Qaeda training camps within Benghazi. The U.S. mission's Emergency Action Committee, responsible for security measures and emergency planning, was briefed on these groups, which included the QRF Brigade and Ansar al-Sharia, as well as "Takfirist thugs."

The details in the cable seemed to foreshadow the deadly Sept. 11 attack on the U.S. compound, which was a coordinated, commando-style assault using direct and indirect fire. Al-Qaeda in North Africa and Ansar al-Sharia, both mentioned in the cable, have since been implicated in the consulate attack.

The cable also stated that the mission would ask for more help, submitting specific requests for additional physical security upgrades and staffing needs. The cable warned that the militias in Benghazi were not concerned with any significant retaliation from the Libyan government, which had apparently lost control in Benghazi.

While the administration's public statements have suggested that the attack came without warning, the Aug. 16 cable seems to undercut those claims. It was a direct warning to the State Department that the Benghazi consulate was vulnerable to attack and that it could not be defended.

In a three-page cable on Sept 11, the day Stevens and the three other Americans were killed, Stevens wrote about "growing problems with security" in Benghazi and "growing frustration" with the security forces and Libyan police. The ambassador saw both as "too weak to keep the country secure."

When asked to respond to a series of questions about the Aug. 16 cable, the State Department declined to answer specific questions, citing the classified nature of the cable. The State Department stated, "An independent board is conducting a thorough review of the assault on our post in Benghazi. Once we have the board's comprehensive account of what happened, findings, and recommendations, we can fully address these matters."

Title: U.S. President's Refusal to Associate Terrorism with Islam Sparks Controversy

Article:

A recent news bulletin reported that police in Nova Scotia thwarted a plot by two men who intended to carry out a mass shooting at a shopping mall and then commit suicide. The Associated Press reported that the plot was not related to Islamic terrorism.

The statement by the Associated Press has sparked debate and controversy, with some commentators questioning the Obama administration's stance on the issue. The article, published by the New York Post, criticizes President Obama for refusing to associate Islamic terrorists with Islam, citing instances of terror attacks against Christians and Jews.

The article argues that the Obama administration's refusal to acknowledge the role of Islam in terrorism leads to flawed understandings of the problem and missed opportunities for potential solutions. The article also criticizes the administration for its response to the murder of three Muslims in North Carolina, opening a civil rights investigation and suggesting the murders were hate crimes, while downplaying the beheading of 21 Coptic Christians in Libya as an "outrage linked to a genocidal religious cleansing."

The article also touches on the issue of corruption in Albany, New York, and the refusal of Mayor Bill de Blasio and Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito to acknowledge the legality of a federal judge's ruling on President Obama's immigration orders. The article concludes by criticizing the progressive political culture in St. Louis, which it suggests may be contributing to a rise in murders in the city.

It is important to note that the article presents a critical and negative view of the Obama administration's stance on terrorism and immigration, and does not provide a balanced perspective on the issue. Additionally, the article contains personal commentary and speculation, which is not in line with the guidelines for this response.

Title: Senate Republicans Urge President Trump to Cease Criticizing Congress

Article:

Senate Republicans have expressed concerns that President Donald Trump's repeated criticisms of Congress could dampen enthusiasm among the GOP base, potentially hurting turnout for the midterm elections. The President is known for touting results and criticizing lawmakers when they do not move fast enough on his priorities.

Last week, Trump warned Senate Republicans through Twitter to pass the annual spending bills before the August recess, a high bar for a chamber that did not pass any regular appropriations bills in 2017. He also slammed the Senate's pace on approving nominees as "the worst in history." A few days prior, he criticized Congress for a lack of progress on immigration reform.

Earlier this month, Trump took aim at GOP lawmakers for not being more vocally critical of special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, warning, "Republicans better get tough and smart before it is too late!" This flurry of criticism has some Republicans worried.

Sen. Mike Rounds (R-S.D.) stated that Trump was asked to acknowledge the accomplishments of the Republican-led Congress during a meeting on Capitol Hill this past week. Rounds said the message was well received by the President.

Republicans argue that Trump's complaints about the lack of accomplishments in Congress, such as the failure to pass legislation to repeal and replace ObamaCare, have overshadowed accomplishments, such as passing a $1.5 trillion tax cut last year.

Sen. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) said he has received numerous questions and complaints about the ObamaCare failure and has printed out cards that list all the accomplishments of the 115th Congress. These include tax reform, confirming 21 circuit court judges, opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling, repealing ObamaCare's individual mandate, and using the Congressional Review Act to repeal 14 Obama-era federal regulations.

Sen. John Hoeven (R-N.D.) gave Trump one of these cards during their meeting with the GOP conference. Alexander told Trump that Republicans' chances of keeping control of the Senate and House after November will depend on him rallying the base. That means touting its accomplishments, not panning it for the backlog of executive and judicial branch nominations or stalemate on immigration.

Republicans have a slim 51-49 majority in the Senate and hope to expand it as Democrats must defend 26 seats in November while Republicans have to worry about only nine. However, Democrats have hopes of seizing the majority because the President's party tends to fare badly in the first midterm election, and polls show them leading Republicans by an average of 5 points on the generic ballot.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) warned on Thursday that control of the chamber is "absolutely" up for grabs. GOP strategists think Senate Republicans are right to ask Trump to be more positive.

"One, Trump has great clout with the Republican base. Two, hammering Republicans [in Congress] undermines their central argument in the midterm election, which is, 'the president needs reinforcements—look at the great results, he needs more Republicans not Democrats,'" said Republican strategist Ford O'Connell.

Gallup reported that Trump reached an 11-month high at the end of April, with 42 percent of respondents nationwide saying they liked the job he was doing. A CNN poll released earlier this month found his job approval rating at 41 percent, with 53 percent disapproving. While more people disapprove than approve of Trump's job performance, he's doing significantly better in the public's opinion than Congress. A Gallup poll conducted earlier this month showed Congress with a 17 percent job approval rating.

Strategists say Trump will be key to turning out Republican voters in November. "The megaphone that President Trump has to fire up the base and get them to vote on election day is crucial for Republicans to win," said Ron Bonjean, a strategist and former Senate GOP leadership aide. He noted that Republicans held onto the Senate majority in 2016, despite predictions that Democrats would win back control, because of Trump's ability to motivate voters. Senate GOP candidates hung on to win in Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and Wisconsin thanks in part to Trump's victory in states where Hillary Clinton was expected to prevail. Bonjean said, "Republicans were activated during the presidential election, and it's just as important to get them motivated to support members of Congress" in the midterm.

Title: Differences in Private Jet Usage by Trump Administration Officials Clarified

Article:

The use of private jets by members of the Trump administration has become a topic of controversy, with Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price facing criticism for his expensive and unnecessary use of private jets for official business. The President publicly rebuked Price over the issue yesterday, and there is speculation that Price may be dismissed from his position. However, the use of private jets by other administration officials, such as Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt, has also been questioned.

In the case of Secretary DeVos, it has been reported that she pays for her work-related travel out of her own pocket, and there is nothing ethically problematic about this whatsoever.

Regarding Administrator Pruitt, there has been a kerfuffle over flights he has taken, with some comparing his use of private jets to Price's. However, Fox News' John Roberts has explained that the relevant details and distinctions between the two situations are significant.

According to Roberts, Administrator Pruitt took a total of four flights that were not commercial. The only charter flight was between Denver, Colorado and Durango, which was booked after a commercial flight on United Airlines was delayed for eight hours, preventing the Administrator from attending an event. The EPA also asked the Governor of Colorado if they could jump on his plane, but were initially told there was no room. After chartering the aircraft, the Governor offered a seat, but it would not have been sufficient for the Administrator's staff. The other flights were government flights, including a military flight from Cincinnati to JFK so the Administrator could attend the G7 Summit. All of this was cleared by the EPA office of ethics.

Roberts concludes that the Pruitt situation is not comparable to the Price situation, as the private charter was a last-minute booking resulting from a lengthy commercial airline delay, and the other flights were government or military planes. Therefore, the Pruitt issue may be a non-story.

It is worth noting that public officials using government or military planes for travel is a common and bipartisan practice. Republican Senator John Thune notably refused to offer any spin on the Health and Human Services Secretary's behalf, stating, "No excuses here. Can't put lipstick on a pig. It's a pig."

Title: Trump Cancels Military Parade, Cites High Cost Estimate from Washington D.C. Government

Article:

Washington, D.C. - President Donald Trump announced the cancellation of a proposed military parade on Friday, citing a high cost estimate from the Washington, D.C. government. However, Washington officials denied Trump's claim and federal agencies raised concerns about the cost and logistics.

Washington Mayor Muriel Bowser provided a cost estimate of $21.6 million on Friday via Twitter, which is closer to the administration's $12 million projection from February. On Thursday, Pentagon officials told CNN the actual costs would be $92 million, or $80 million more than the original estimate.

President Trump tweeted, "The local politicians who run Washington, D.C. (poorly) know a windfall when they see it. When asked to give us a price for holding a great celebratory military parade, they wanted a number so ridiculously high that I cancelled it. Never let someone hold you up!"

Trump also announced he would attend a smaller parade already scheduled for Joint Base Andrews, as well as a Nov. 11 parade in Paris to mark the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I. He tweeted, "Maybe we will do something next year in D.C. when the cost comes WAY DOWN. Now we can buy some more jet fighters!"

Bowser said the proposed parade carried significant concerns for taxpayers, and she mocked Trump for his complaints. "Yup, I’m Muriel Bowser, mayor of Washington DC, the local politician who finally got thru to the reality star in the White House with the realities ( $21.6M ) of parades/events/demonstrations in Trump America (sad)," she said in a sub-tweet.

John J. Falcicchio, chief of staff to Bowser, took issue with Trump's claim that the city is "poorly" run, calling it "fake news." He cited a newly earned AAA bond rating. "When they go low, we go high... Like our bond rating," Falcicchio said in sub-tweeting Trump.

Trump's attendance at a Paris military parade last year inspired him to call for an American version. U.S. officials on Thursday cited expenses for aircraft, equipment, personnel, and security, not charges from the Washington, D.C. government as claimed by Trump.

In a statement, the Pentagon said, "The Department of Defense and White House have been planning a parade to honor America's military veterans and commemorate the centennial of World War I. We originally targeted November 10, 2018, for this event but have now agreed to explore opportunities in 2019."

The American Legion stated, "The parade money would be better spent fully funding the Department of Veterans Affairs and giving our troops and their families the best care possible."

Title: Missouri Senate Race: McCaskill's Vote Against Kavanaugh Confirmation May Not Affect Re-Election Chances, Poll Shows

Article:

A new poll suggests that Democratic U.S. Senator Claire McCaskill's vote against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation may not significantly impact her re-election chances in conservative-leaning Missouri. The poll, conducted by ███/Ipsos/UVA Center for Politics, shows McCaskill with 44 percent support among likely voters, while her Republican challenger, state Attorney General Josh Hawley, has 45 percent. The poll has a credibility interval of 3 percentage points.

The Missouri race is considered a toss-up, and Democrats need to gain two seats to win control of the U.S. Senate. Achieving this will require successfully defending Democratic seats in states that President Donald Trump won in 2016, which include Missouri, West Virginia, and Indiana.

McCaskill joined all but one of her Democratic colleagues in voting against Kavanaugh, who was confirmed by a 50-48 vote after being accused of sexual assault. The confirmation process became a political brawl that deepened the country's divisions.

Hawley, who has been pressuring McCaskill to support Kavanaugh and criticizing her as a "radical" in campaign ads, may not have gained much from the issue. The poll shows that 44 percent of likely voters are "more likely" to support McCaskill because of her opposition to Kavanaugh, while 46 percent are "less likely."

The Supreme Court did not rank highly among likely voters' priorities in the state. Respondents were much more likely to cite healthcare, the economy, or immigration as top issues. Sixty-nine percent of likely voters told the poll they were "very motivated" to support a candidate who would "defend laws that protect healthcare for people with pre-existing conditions." This could pose a problem for Hawley, who has said he wants to protect people with pre-existing conditions but has joined a multi-state effort to repeal the federal law that does so, the Affordable Care Act.

A separate poll found Illinois Democratic gubernatorial candidate J.B. Pritzker holding a 20-percentage-point lead over Republican incumbent Bruce Rauner. The race is on track to be the most expensive governor's election in U.S. history, with nearly $249.7 million raised so far. Illinois looks set to break California's record-setting $251.9 million 2010 contest between Democrat Jerry Brown and former tech executive Meg Whitman.

The Missouri and Illinois polls were conducted online, in English, from Sept. 27 to Oct. 7. They surveyed between 968 and 1,111 likely voters and weighted the responses according to the latest government population estimates. The results measured how voters felt at the time of the survey, and those feelings may change. In 2016, one in eight Americans decided on the presidential pick in the week before Election Day, according to a ███/Ipsos poll.

Title: Political Language and the Disintegration of Shared Language in the United States

Article:

In the Bible, the people of Babel united in defiance against God, attempting to build a massive tower to challenge His supremacy. God, displeased by their presumption, caused them to speak a variety of tongues, dividing them and ending the project. This story illustrates a simple truth: unity relies, at least in large part, on shared language.

In the United States, the shared language is disintegrating. On Tuesday, President Donald Trump tweeted about the Democrats' impeachment inquiry, expressing frustration over the lack of clarity on process. He wrote, "So some day, if a Democrat becomes President and the Republicans win the House, even by a tiny margin, they can impeach the President, without due process or fairness or any legal rights. All Republicans must remember what they are witnessing here -- a lynching. But we will WIN!"

Trump's use of the word "lynching" sparked a firestorm. Criticisms included one from former Vice President Joe Biden, who stated, "Our country has a dark, shameful history with lynching, and to even think about making this comparison is abhorrent. It's despicable."

However, it was revealed that Biden used the same language in October 1998 to describe the Clinton impeachment. "History is going to question whether or not this was just a partisan lynching," Biden said at the time. This prompted Biden to condemn himself, stating, "That was not the right word to use and I'm sorry about that. Trump, on the other hand, chose his words deliberately today in his use of the word lynching and continues to stoke racial divides in this country daily."

When Joe Biden used the word "lynching" to describe his perception of a politically motivated impeachment in 1998, it was merely poor word choice. When Trump used it in 2019, he obviously meant to liken himself to black victims of white supremacist violence.

Politics is skewing our use of basic language, and this phenomenon is one of the key factors tearing apart the country. Every word becomes a potential dog whistle. Every phrase is parsed by the politically motivated for signs of malign intent. Politically correct language policing becomes the order of the day. Misunderstanding becomes malice; clarity becomes confusion.

The deliberate confusion regarding gender pronouns is another example of this phenomenon. It is not a sign of malice to suggest that gender pronouns refer to objective measures of sex. It is a sign of a delusional culture to suggest that third-party use of gender pronouns must refer instead to subjective self-identification. Yet we are told that virtue mandates that we pretend that transgender women are women, even if that means that biological men compete with biological women in sport; we are told that virtue requires that parents call their confused 7-year-olds by their chosen pronouns, even though confused children desperately require guidance, love, and advice from parents, not mere affirmation of malleable self-identification.

We cannot have conversations with one another if we refuse to define terms. But refusal to define terms is one of the most fruitful methods of impugning others. If we seek division rather than unity, we'll certainly find it. And as we cordon ourselves off into separate interpretations of language we once held in common, we're less and less likely to ever again find common ground.

Ben Shapiro, 35, is a graduate of UCLA and Harvard Law School, host of "The Ben Shapiro Show" and editor-in-chief of DailyWire.com. He is the author of the No. 1 New York Times bestseller "The Right Side Of History." He lives with his wife and two children in Los Angeles. To find out more about Ben Shapiro and read features by other Creators Syndicate writers and cartoonists, visit the Creators Syndicate website at www.creators.com.

Title: Whistleblower Complaint Alleges White House Moved Trump-Ukraine Call Records to Separate System

Article:

The whistleblower complaint that centered on President Donald Trump's request to Ukraine's government to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden also alleges that White House officials moved records of some of Trump's communications with foreign leaders onto a separate computer network.

First reported by the Washington Post and now confirmed with the public release of the whistleblower complaint, the complaint alleged that the transcript of Trump's phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was placed on a computer system directly managed by the National Security Council Directorate for Intelligence Programs.

The whistleblower cited officials he or she spoke with that this was not the first time a presidential transcript was placed into the system "solely for the purpose of protecting politically sensitive—rather than national security sensitive—information."

The complaint more broadly alleges that Trump is using the power of his office to solicit foreign interference in the U.S. election.

Trump defended his July phone call with Ukraine's president, stating there was "no pressure" on him as a summary showed Trump urging his counterpart to open a probe related to Biden.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the opening of an impeachment inquiry on Tuesday.

When asked for comment about the complaint's allegations, White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said, "Nothing has changed with the release of this complaint, which is nothing more than a collection of third-hand accounts of events and cobbled-together press clippings—all of which show nothing improper. The president took the extraordinary and transparent steps of releasing the full, unredacted, and declassified transcript of his call with President Zelensky, which forms the heart of the complaint, as well as the complaint itself. That is because he has nothing to hide. The White House will continue to push back on the hysteria and false narratives being peddled by Democrats and many in the mainstream media, and President Trump will continue to work hard on behalf of the American people as he always does."

Additional sources:
1. Whistleblower complaint alleges White House tried to ‘ lock down ’ call details - The Washington Post
2. Acting intelligence chief says whistleblower did ‘ right thing ’ with Trump complaint - The Washington Post
3. Here’s what’s happening next in Democrats’ impeachment inquiry into Trump - The Washington Post
4. Here's what's in the whistleblower complaint against Trump - CNN
5. Trump's Ukraine call transcript: Read the full, unredacted document - CNN
6. Full transcript: Trump's call with Ukraine's president - The Washington Post

Title: Grassroots Movements Seek to Bridge Political Divide in America

Article:

In her 2016 book, "Strangers in Their Own Land: Anger and Mourning on the American Right," author Arlie Hochschild details her journey across America's political divide, living in liberal Berkeley, California, and immersing herself in a deeply conservative town, Lake Charles, Louisiana, a center of the petrochemical industry. Nearly all the people she came to know voted for Donald Trump, with most doing so with hope and excitement.

Since the book's publication, Hochschild has returned to Louisiana three times to gauge the feelings of Trump supporters during the first year of his presidency. According to a recent Pew survey, the political divide between Democrats and Republicans is formidable. The survey reveals that 71% of Democrats believe the government should do more to help the needy, while only 24% of Republicans agree. Similarly, 64% of Democrats think discrimination is the main reason blacks can't get ahead, while only 14% of Republicans do.

Despite some criticism of Trump's behavior, such as his comments about African and Haitian nations, his supporters remain committed to him. However, some Trump supporters have expressed discomfort with his remarks, while others have defended him, viewing his critics as hypocritical.

A grassroots movement has been growing, aiming not to eliminate difference but to soften its edge. This movement seeks to foster respect and explore potential areas of agreement. Initiatives such as Living-room Conversations, spearheaded by local mediator Joan Blades, bring together individuals from different political backgrounds to discuss common goals and find areas of agreement.

Even among the most ardent Trump supporters, Hochschild found potential for coalition on specific issues, such as safeguarding children online, reducing prison populations for non-violent offenders, protecting against commercialization of the human genome, and promoting job creation and infrastructure development.

Signs of a desire to reach out extend beyond Hochschild's personal experiences. The Bridge Alliance, a non-profit, non-partisan umbrella group, lists over seventy cross-partisan groups based in towns across the country. These groups, with names like Common Good, Better Angels, American Public Square, and AllSides, aim to restore a culture of respect while exploring potential points of agreement.

Experts estimate that over one in ten people who voted for Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary ended up voting for Trump in the presidential election. Additionally, it is estimated that between 6.7 and 9.2 million people who voted for Trump in 2016 had also voted for Obama in 2012.

As of October 2017, the Bridge Alliance had three million supporters. As the nation heads into the next three years with a divided media and a president who speaks to one base, more of us need to reach out to people we disagree with. By crossing the partisan divide, we may not resolve our political crisis, but it could help us rebuild a nation in which we feel as if we know each other again.

Title: New Experimental Therapies for Sickle Cell Disease and CAR-T Therapies for Cancer Gain Investor Attention

Article:

A flurry of experimental therapies for sickle cell disease and CAR-T therapies for cancer has captured the attention of investors, following recent Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approvals and significant investments in the sector. This week, much of the high-profile clinical data presented at the American Society of Hematology's annual meeting in Orlando, Florida, focused on companies developing products for these therapeutic areas.

In November, the FDA approved two new treatments for sickle cell disease: Novartis' Adakveo and Global Blood Therapeutics' Oxbryta. Adakveo reduces the frequency of one of the disease's complications, while Oxbryta treats the root cause of sickle cell anemia. The wholesale list prices for both drugs are approximately $10,000 per month.

Bluebird Bio's investigational gene therapy for sickle cell disease also garnered attention. Analysts expect Bluebird to outperform peers substantially, following positive data for LentiGlobin in a Phase 1/2 study. The therapy showed a reduction in vaso-occlusive crises and acute chest syndrome (both complications of sickle cell disease) in some patients. Shares of Bluebird, which also presented data on its experimental CAR-T therapy and LentiGlobin as a treatment for severe beta-thalassemia, at ASH, were up 10% in afternoon trading on Tuesday.

In the CAR-T therapy field, which was first approved by the FDA in 2017 with Novartis' Kymriah for certain patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a growing number of large and small pharmaceutical companies are entering the market. This week, Bluebird and Bristol-Myers Squibb shared results from their early-stage trial for an experimental CAR-T therapy treating multiple myeloma. BMS also said Saturday that a pivotal trial for liso-cel, its investigational CAR-T treatment, showed high rates of durable responses, and it will submit an application to the FDA this month. Johnson & Johnson is developing a CAR-T for multiple myeloma, and its mid-stage study data was described as "clearly impressive" by Bernstein analysts.

Some of the experimental therapies are aiming to capitalize on the costs associated with CAR-T treatment. The currently available CAR-T therapies are expensive, with Kymriah costing $475,000 at launch and Yescarta costing $373,000. Hospitals have been struggling with the cost of CAR-T as patients require hospitalization within three days of treatment, which means the treatment is considered inpatient and reimbursed as part of transplantation diagnostic related grouping. About one-quarter of the patients in the liso-cel trial were treated in an outpatient setting, which is less expensive than if a patient is hospitalized. If approved, that change in setting may shift the market away from an already approved therapy, such as Yescarta, to one that can deliver on a more cost-effective approach.

The headlining deal in hematology is Merck's $2.7 billion buyout of ArQule, a biopharmaceutical company developing treatments for cancer and rare diseases. The deal, announced Monday, will add ArQule's mid-stage therapeutic candidate, ARG 531, a Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitor, to Merck's high-performing oncology portfolio. Shares of ArQule were up 1.27% in afternoon trading on Tuesday. "We see this acquisition as unlocking value for investors as it places ARQ 533 in the hands of a larger player who can develop this asset more broadly and aggressively," wrote Jonathan Chang, an analyst at SVB Leerink, in a note.

Title: Superdelegate Lead for Hillary Clinton in Democratic Primary Race

Article:

In the ongoing Democratic primary race, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are closely competing for votes. However, the picture changes when considering superdelegates, party insiders who can support any candidate of their choice. According to the latest Associated Press survey, Clinton has the support of 449 superdelegates, or approximately 63 percent, while Sanders has only 19. The AP did not reach 62 superdelegates, and 182 remained uncommitted or undecided.

Excluding superdelegates, Sanders leads Clinton among delegates based on the votes in Iowa and New Hampshire, with a margin of 36-32. Since the AP's November survey, Clinton's superdelegate count has increased by 90, while Sanders has gained 11.

It is important to note that Clinton also had a significant superdelegate lead during her previous presidential campaign, but ultimately lost the nomination. In January 2008, she had a lead of 201 to Barack Obama's 89 and John Edwards' 40, according to the AP.

In the following months, Obama began to gain superdelegates, while Clinton started to lose some to his side. This trend seems to be repeating itself in the current race, with Clinton maintaining strong support among the party's establishment, despite the tight primary and caucus races.

Superdelegates consist of well-known figures such as members of Congress and former presidents, as well as lesser-known party insiders like state party leaders and Democratic National Committee members. The non-superdelegates are allocated based on the results of the state caucuses and primaries, while superdelegates are "unbound," meaning they can choose whom they want.

This system has been a source of contention among Sanders supporters, with some contacting superdelegates and a MoveOn.org petition urging them to "pledge to back the will of the voters." As of now, the petition has over 161,000 signatures.

The superdelegate system was created in 1982 to "improve the party's mainstream appeal" by giving party insiders more influence and reducing the influence of "activists," as explained by Thomas Mann and Norman Ornstein of the Brookings Institution in 2008. The system is intended to provide a "peer review" to choose the most electable candidate and promote unity within the party, making "stronger ties between the party and its elected officials."

In a tight race, the "unity" argument may be difficult to see from a voter's perspective. Superdelegates are aware of this, with one, then-Sen. John Kerry, stating in 2008 that it would be a mistake for superdelegates to overturn the expressed view of the pledged delegates. Superdelegates remain unbound, even if they have already chosen a candidate, and could potentially switch their support should the race shift in favor of another candidate.

Many superdelegates must be re-elected at some point, and going against the voters' wishes is not beneficial in that regard. However, superdelegates remain unbound, even if they have already chosen a candidate. This means that should the race swing heavily in Sanders' favor, some superdelegates currently backing Clinton could potentially switch their support.

Title: Trump Affirms Support for National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster Amid Controversy Over Classified Information Access

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed his continued support for National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster following a controversy over a letter McMaster sent to his predecessor, Susan Rice, granting her access to classified information. The letter, which McMaster's supporters claim was routine, was leaked to suggest that the Army Lieutenant General was aiding Trump's political adversaries.

The letter, reportedly a standard procedure for sending classified information to former national security advisers and presidents, has been a subject of debate within the White House. McMaster's feud with other powerful factions within the administration has been well-documented, and a series of recent firings by McMaster has escalated tensions. However, Trump issued a statement late Friday, expressing his confidence in McMaster, stating, "General McMaster and I are working very well together. He is a good man and very pro-Israel. I am grateful for the work he continues to do serving our country."

McMaster has been under scrutiny due to a series of firings he has ordered on the National Security Council (NSC). The most recent dismissal was of Ezra Cohen-Watnick, the senior director for intelligence at the NSC, who was viewed as a Trump loyalist.

Thursday's report by Circa News alleged that McMaster sent a letter granting Rice access to classified material, weeks after her alleged role in the "unmasking" of identities of Trump associates in intelligence reports was disclosed. However, sources from the NSC told Fox News that the letter was a standard procedure document and that McMaster was required to send it.

The NSC also clarified that extending Rice's security clearance does not grant her access to classified information; it only allows her to be called back in (if necessary) to discuss classified information.

The fact that McMaster sent the letter to Rice, given the controversy surrounding her and the "unmasking" of members of the Trump campaign, transition, and administration in intelligence documents, has not been viewed favorably by administration members who are not particularly fond of McMaster.

Cohen-Watnick, who was brought into the NSC by former national security adviser Mike Flynn, was at the center of the controversy over House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Devin Nunes' visit to the White House in March to review intelligence reports about incidental surveillance of Trump officials during the presidential campaign.

Additionally, Rich Higgins, who served as director for strategic planning at the NSC, was fired on July 21. Higgins was an ally of senior White House adviser Steve Bannon. Derek Harvey, a top Middle East adviser who served as special assistant to the president and senior director for the Middle East on the NSC, was also relieved of his duties last week.

The staff changes at the NSC come as the White House has seen a number of high-profile staff changes, including the resignation of Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, Press Secretary Sean Spicer, and the forced exit of newly tapped communications director Anthony Scaramucci after just 11 days on the job.

Title: Pelosi's Rising Popularity and Shutdown Strategy

Article:

In the ongoing 33-day government shutdown, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has been a formidable adversary to President Donald Trump. She has dismissed his proposals to reopen the government as "nonstarters" due to his insistence on $5.7 billion for the border wall, which she terms "an immorality." Pelosi has also pressured Trump to postpone the State of the Union address, scheduled for next Tuesday, over shutdown-related security concerns, potentially forcing him to hold the event elsewhere.

New polling shows that Pelosi's popularity has increased during the shutdown. According to polling from Civiqs, Pelosi's favorability among Democrats has jumped from 59 to 72 percent. The Washington Post's Michael Tesler argues, "It appears that Pelosi's opposition to the president has rallied her party's base and increased her favorability ratings."

The CBS News poll released on Wednesday indicates that more Americans want Trump to give up wall funding than prefer the congressional Democrats to agree to wall funding. Moreover, more Americans feel Pelosi is handling negotiations better than the president.

Democrats' strategy of not compromising during the shutdown has been effective, as they have not relented, given the unpopularity of the president and the border wall. The length and severity of this shutdown, now the longest in U.S. history, could potentially cause lasting damage to Trump's presidency.

Pelosi's recent performance during the shutdown could significantly alter the narrative about her in history books. She has previously proven her resolve in obstructing George W. Bush's plan to privatize Social Security in 2005 and her legislative prowess in passing Obamacare and the (ultimately doomed) cap-and-trade bill in 2009 and 2010.

Looking ahead to 2020, progressives may express reservations about Pelosi's continued leadership—especially if Democrats win back both the presidency and the Senate. Pelosi has shown caution when confronting the progressive wing's increasingly ambitious agenda, implementing a pay-go rule in the House, requiring new spending to be offset by budget cuts or tax increases. On Medicare for All, she has advocated for strengthening Obamacare, but has allowed hearings on universal health care to proceed. Regarding Ocasio-Cortez's Green New Deal, Pelosi does not seem to be a supporter, having rebuffed the freshman's attempt to form a committee on the proposal.

However, 2020 is still far off, and Democrats' unified control of the government may be an even longer way off. For now, Pelosi's strategy of undercutting and emasculating Trump at every turn has earned her the loyalty of her entire caucus. Winning tends to have that effect.

Title: Political Violence and Confrontations Targeting Media and Lawmakers on the Rise in U.S.

Article:

A mob of left-wing antifa activists descended on Fox News personality Tucker Carlson's D.C. home on Wednesday, marking a new phase in the political violence and angry confrontations that have been targeting the news media and lawmakers.

Political violence has been on the rise in the U.S. since 2012, according to the Global Terrorism Database. Increasingly aggressive activists have pushed political confrontation to the limit since 2016, accosting Republican lawmakers and Trump administration officials in restaurants and in the halls of Congress. Now, they are targeting conservative journalists at their homes.
