"Tucker Carlson, we will fight. We know where you sleep at night!" the activists, allied with antifa, chanted outside Mr. Carlson's home. Antifa, short for anti-fascist, targets anyone perceived as not in step with a far-left agenda.

Mr. Carlson, whose wife was home alone during the disturbance, told Fox News, "I never thought twice about leaving them home alone, but this is the reaction because this group doesn't like my TV show."

On Capitol Hill, the overheated political debate has lawmakers increasingly working under a threat of violence. Capitol police say they saw a surge in protective details assigned to lawmakers earlier in the fall, when senators were facing hallway protests during the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh. Security details were assigned to at least two Republican senators on the Judiciary Committee, Chairman Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and Jeff Flake of Arizona.

Security details are typically assigned only to members of leadership. Senators have mostly been away from Washington since the Kavanaugh confirmation, and it's not clear whether enhanced security will still be the norm.

About 2,000 threatening incidents and communications were made against members of Congress last year, according to the House Sergeant at Arms office. That's nearly double the 902 threatening incidents and communications in 2016. Capitol Police spokeswoman Eva Maleki refused to divulge the numbers so far for 2018.

The threats have extended to anyone entering the political arena. California psychology professor Christine Blasey Ford is still receiving death threats and has been unable to return to work more than a month after she testified to Congress against Justice Kavanaugh during confirmation hearings, according to her legal team.

The threats started when she accused Justice Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her more than 30 years ago when the two were at high school parties. The allegations were never corroborated, but her testimony nearly derailed his confirmation.

Former IRS official Lois G. Lerner told a federal judge this month that she is still getting threats stemming from her role in the tea party targeting scandal of five years ago. She has been locked in a long legal battle trying to permanently seal her old testimony about the targeting, saying she expects a new surge of threats if her actions became publicly known.

"We are seeing more violent events recently as there seems to be a retreat from basic democratic norms," said American University professor Joseph Young, a scholar of terrorism and political violence.

He said President Trump's attacks on the press and reluctance to denounce violence on the right doesn't help but isn't the main cause.

"Some extremists do not see the value of dialogue or compromise and are concerned with the speed of change. Most importantly, when core values seem under threat, these individuals are using violence in what they perceive as a defensive action," he said. "ISIS-inspired actors always cite their actions as defensive. The Pittsburgh synagogue shooter felt that his race and people were under threat. Whether this is true or not, I think these beliefs are motivating people to violent action."

The threats, confrontation, and violence come from extremists on the left and the right. Cesar Sayoc, a crazed supporter of Mr. Trump, is charged with sending at least 16 pipe bomb packages to people viewed as enemies of the president, including high-profile Democrats Hillary Clinton and former President Barack Obama and commentators at CNN.

Left-wing activist James T. Hodgkinson opened fire on a congressional Republican softball practice in June 2017, almost killing House Majority Whip Steve Scalise of Louisiana. Also shot were House aide Zack Barth, lobbyist Matt Mika, and U.S. Capitol Police Officer Crystal Griner, who was assigned to protect Mr. Scalise.

D.C.'s Metropolitan Police Department is investigating the incident at Mr. Carlson's home, during which the demonstrators allegedly damaged the front door. Fox News executives called the incident at Mr. Carlson's home "reprehensible."

"The violent threats and intimidation tactics toward him and his family are completely unacceptable. We as a nation have become far too intolerant of different points of view. Recent events across our country clearly highlight the need for a more civil, respectful, and inclusive national conversation. Those of us in the media and in politics bear a special obligation to all Americans, to find common ground," Fox News CEO Suzanne Scott and Fox News President Jay Wallace said in a joint statement.

It wasn't the first time the group went after a journalist. But they usually attack reporters covering demonstrations, such as when they hurled eggs and water bottles at D.C. police and journalists during a counter-protest against the "Unite the Right 2" rally in August.

A year earlier, the first "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, sparked clashes between white supremacists and counter-protesters. A man involved with white supremacy was charged with driving his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer, 32.

Title: National and North Carolina Democrats Adjust Strategy in Response to State Party Scandal

Article:

Top national and North Carolina Democrats have taken a series of unusual steps to protect their candidates in the state from additional damage following a sexual harassment scandal that rocked the North Carolina Democratic Party (NCDP). The scandal weakened the party's chairman, David Parker, who has managed to hold onto his job despite calls for his ouster from top state Democrats and pressure from Washington.

North Carolina was already an uphill battle for President Barack Obama's reelection campaign before the revelation in April that the NCDP's then-executive director, Jay Parmley, was accused of misconduct by a young male employee. Parmley resigned.

The result presents a challenge for the Obama campaign and other Democrats up and down the ballot, who must now find ways to tiptoe around state officials linked to the harassment scandal. Complicating matters further, Democrats will hold their presidential nominating convention in Charlotte this summer, an event that was suffering from fundraising difficulties even before the scandal broke.

Rather than backing away from the state, Democrats in North Carolina and Washington say they believe they can work around Parker. The chairman, they say, currently appears more focused on shoring up his own shaky political position and reaching out to local activists than taking operational control of campaign machinery. That leaves room for other national and state Democrats to try and take charge of the situation—and most importantly, control the purse strings of the 2012 campaign.

"The Obama campaign appears to be dug in here and committed and working here," said veteran North Carolina Democratic strategist Gary Pearce, a former adviser to four-term Gov. Jim Hunt. "The talk here is the Obama campaign and the [Lt. Gov. Walter] Dalton campaign feel pretty confident they can work around [Parker]."

"The problem is, who's going to trust David Parker with a few million dollars? Well, nobody," Pearce added.

Discussions are underway to set up a coordinated campaign apparatus between national and state Democrats for high-profile state campaigns—chiefly, the governor's race between Dalton and former GOP Charlotte Mayor Pat McCrory—and congressional races. To the extent that the state party is involved, it would only be one of numerous decision-makers at the table, and campaigns say they expect to be able to work with competent staff members there to maneuver around the mess with Parker.

"It's going to be focused, it's going to have the resources it needs... Because of what transpired [with the NCDP] I think there's a clear difference in terms of participation and guiding hands," said one knowledgeable North Carolina Democratic operative, who characterized Parker's involvement as exceedingly limited.

"I think it would be safe to say that David Parker's focused very much on the internal party politics and not the business of messing with these campaigns. The state convention is a big deal... That's right in his wheelhouse," the operative said, referring to the North Carolina Democratic convention on June 16. "I would say his participation in the day-to-day workings of coordinated campaigns, infrastructure, that kind of thing, is diminished."

Title: House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff Prepared to Sue and Subpoena Mueller Report

Article:

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff has stated that he is prepared to take legal action against the Trump administration and subpoena special counsel Robert Mueller if the Mueller report on possible Russia interference in the 2016 presidential campaign is not made public.

In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Schiff, a California Democrat, said, "We will obviously subpoena the report. We will bring Bob Mueller in to testify before Congress. We will take it to court if necessary."

When asked by host George Stephanopoulos if he would take the White House to court, Schiff responded, "Absolutely. We are going to get to the bottom of this."

Schiff further stated, "We are going to share this information with the public. And if the president is serious about all of his claims of exoneration, then he should welcome the publication of this report."

The Mueller report is expected to be released soon, although not this week. The Justice Department is not required to release the document to the public.

Schiff made it clear that he would do whatever necessary to make the findings public. "He [Mueller] does have a responsibility to report it," Schiff said. "And in fact, if you take the position—and I think it's a flawed one—but if you take the position that the president can not be indicted and the only remedy for improper or illegal or other conduct is impeachment, then you can not withhold that information from Congress or essentially the president has immunity."

Schiff also stated that Attorney General William Barr would be under "immeasurable pressure" to publish the report. "If he were to try to withhold, to bury any part of this report, that will be his legacy," Schiff said. "And it will be a tarnished legacy. So I think there will be immense pressure not only on the department but on the attorney general to be forthcoming."

Title: House Freedom Caucus Urges President Trump for Economic Reopening as Small Businesses Struggle

Article:

Members of the House Freedom Caucus have sent a letter to President Donald Trump, urging for the reopening of the economy as businesses across the country continue to face difficulties. The letter, signed by House members Reps. Andy Biggs, Jody Hice, Ron Wright, Jeff Duncan, Scott Perry, Andy Harris, Scott DesJarlais, Ken Buck, Paul Gosar, Randy Weber, Ted Yoho, Dan Bishop, and Ted Yoho, according to Fox News, was sent on Friday.

In the letter, the House Freedom Caucus members expressed their concern about the economic impact of the closed economy, stating, "The American people are resilient, but they have suffered tremendously under the weight of this closed economy. Measures enacted by Congress have provided limited relief." They further argued that reopening the economy is the solution to the economic woes, stating, "We are a free people with a free and fair market. The sooner we return to it, the sooner our economy will again thrive."

The letter also highlighted the impact of the virus on employment, with many people losing their jobs and businesses being forced to close. The members of the House Freedom Caucus acknowledged that measures have been taken to slow the spread of the virus, but they argued that some of the measures enacted to combat the virus have caused economic hardship.

The letter comes as Democrats in the Senate blocked Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's request for more aid for small businesses on April 9, labeling it a "political stunt." The Republicans' bill would have provided an additional $250 billion for a loan program for small businesses, but it was blocked from passing due to Democratic opposition.

The current state of Congress is such that most members are still on recess, making it difficult for legislation to be passed quickly. The full House and Senate are not expected to return to Washington D.C. before May 4. The members of Congress are currently working on legislation to fund small businesses.

Title: Market-Based Solution Emerges for California's Housing Shortage, Shifting Office Space to Residential Use

Article:

A market-based solution is gaining traction in California as a potential solution to the state's housing shortage, with the potential to transform urban areas by converting office spaces into residential units. This shift away from traditional office spaces is being driven by the increased adoption of remote work due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

White-collar businesses, such as insurance companies, law firms, and venture capitalists, are vacating office towers in urban areas like Century City in Los Angeles, downtown San Diego, and San Francisco's financial district. Tenants are refusing to pay rent, having sent their workforces home during the pandemic, and are not being evicted due to state emergency rules allowing for rent delays during the health crisis.

As California reopens, it has become clear that vast numbers of workers will continue to work from home, either by preference or necessity. This shift in work patterns is causing a decline in demand for office space in urban areas, while demand for housing is increasing in suburban counties.

Realtors in suburban counties are reporting an increase in demand from people who previously worked in office towers but are now working from home. As their employers allow them to continue working remotely, some are seeking more spacious quarters and a less urban environment.

In the next phase, entire floors of high-rise buildings are expected to go vacant and remain empty for significant periods. Once building owners realize that new lessees will not be forthcoming in large numbers, they will opt for other ways to monetize their buildings, such as converting much of the empty floor space to condos and apartments. These will likely come in all sizes and price levels, from large ocean-and mountain-view units to small apartments on the lower floors.

Zoning changes are inevitable as market forces drive the conversion of office spaces into residential units, creating vast numbers of units within the next five years, many of them very affordable. This shift in land use is a response to the increased demand for housing and the decreased demand for office space due to the pandemic-induced remote work trend.

Title: Human Rights Watch Accuses Ukrainian Government Forces of Using Cluster Munitions in Eastern Ukraine

Article:

Human Rights Watch (HRW) has released a report alleging that Ukrainian government forces have used cluster munitions in eastern Ukraine, a violation of an international treaty banning the weapon. The report, released on Monday, details suspected cluster munitions attacks in more than 12 locations in eastern Ukraine, where over 3,700 people have been killed in fighting since April.

The watchdog group found signs of cluster munitions attacks in Donetsk, a rebel-held city with a peacetime population of over one million. The attacks, according to HRW, have killed at least six people and wounded dozens, although the actual toll may be higher.

While HRW could not conclusively account for each attack, the report states that "there is particularly strong evidence that Ukrainian government forces were responsible" and that their use of the munitions "may amount to war crimes." The group also suggests that rebels may have used the munitions.

A New York Times investigation also found physical evidence—supported by interviews with witnesses and victims—of cluster munitions fired by Ukrainian forces into Donetsk. Two attacks on Oct. 2 and Oct. 6 wounded at least six people and killed a Swiss employee of the International Red Cross, according to the Times.

The allegations could undermine the fragile cease-fire signed by Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko and pro-Russian rebels in September. It could also jeopardize long-term peace negotiations in the area.

Ukrainian military officials have denied the accusations to reporters, while rebels have not commented.

Cluster munitions are banned by 114 countries under the Convention on Cluster Munitions, an international treaty that bans the stockpile or use of the weapons. In addition to Ukraine, Russia and the US are among those that have not joined it, according to the BBC.

Meanwhile, a new report from Germany's foreign intelligence agency (BND) found that pro-Russian rebels were responsible for shooting down Malaysian Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July. The crash killed 298 people. BND President Gerhard Schindler told a parliamentary committee earlier this month that his agency had "ample" evidence to implicate the rebels, Der Spiegel reports. He refuted Russian claims that Ukrainian soldiers shot down the plane with a missile. However, the German investigation concluded that the missile launcher used to down the plane was Ukrainian, not Russian. It said rebels had captured the launcher from a Ukrainian base.

Title: Journalists Raise Concerns Over Electoral College Intervention

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2016 presidential election, some journalists and political analysts have expressed concerns over a proposed movement urging electors to deny Donald Trump the presidency. This electoral vote, scheduled for Monday, is typically a formality, with electors expected to support the candidate who carried their respective state.

However, some Democrats have suggested that if they can persuade 37 Republican electors to change their votes, they could prevent Trump from taking office. This proposal has sparked debate, with critics arguing that such an action would undermine the democratic process and amount to an unjust seizure of the presidency from the candidate who won the popular vote.

E.J. Dionne, a Washington Post columnist, author, and MSNBC contributor, has expressed support for the electoral revolt, stating that Trump's unsuitability for the presidency is evident due to his behavior during the campaign and post-election. Dionne argues that Trump did not win the presidency through the will of the people, as he lost the popular vote by over 2.8 million votes.

Kathleen Parker, a moderate conservative Washington Post columnist and former CNN host, has also weighed in on the issue. She suggests that the Founding Fathers created the Electoral College as a safeguard against the election of a demagogue or autocrat, citing Trump as an example of such a candidate. Parker argues that the electoral college was designed to prevent individuals unfit for the presidency from taking office, and that Trump, in her opinion, falls into this category.

The debate over the electoral college intervention has sparked comparisons to a hypothetical scenario where Trump supporters would urge electors to change their votes if Hillary Clinton had won a close election. Critics argue that such actions would be met with outrage and accusations of undermining democracy.

Despite the ongoing debate, it appears that the movement to change the electoral votes is unlikely to succeed, as the electors are expected to follow the results of the popular vote in their respective states. However, the debate has shed light on the ongoing controversy surrounding the Electoral College and the role it plays in the American democratic process.

Title: Former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley Praises Trump's Decision to Strike Iran's Top General

Article:

Former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley praised President Donald Trump for ordering the drone strike that killed Iran's top general, Qasem Soleimani, last week. Haley made the comments during an interview with Fox News host Sean Hannity on Monday night.

Gen. Qasem Soleimani, the leader of Iran's elite Quds Force, was killed on a road near the Baghdad airport on Friday. The strike that killed Soleimani came after the U.S. blamed Iran for an attack on the U.S. Embassy in Iraq by a mob of demonstrators belonging to Shiite militias.

The U.S. said one of those Iran-backed militias was responsible for a rocket attack that killed an American contractor and killed at least two dozen of its fighters in airstrikes at the end of December.

"What the president did left the Iranian regime completely flat-footed," Haley said. "They did not see this coming. They thought they could continue to do their multiple strikes. But when it got to the lives of Americans, the president is never going to allow that to happen."

Soleimani led Iran's involvement in proxy wars in the Muslim world, including the civil wars in Syria and Yemen. He supported militias throughout the Middle East that are loyal to Tehran. And he oversaw the training of Shiite Iraqi militants to kill U.S. troops, teaching them how to make deadly roadside bombs.

The U.S. estimates that Soleimani and the Iran Revolutionary Guard were responsible for killing more than 600 American service members in Iraq following the 2003 invasion.

Haley said Soleimani's killing was "a long time coming" and that it left Iran's leaders "shaking in their boots."

"You do not see anyone standing up for Iran. You're not hearing any of the Gulf members. You're not hearing China. You're not hearing Russia," Haley said.

"The only ones that are mourning the loss of Soleimani are our Democrat leadership, and our Democrat presidential candidates."

Her unsubstantiated claim was slammed as irresponsible by several commentators.

"This kind of statement is ridiculous, inflammatory and dangerous. Rather than inform viewers, Ambassador Haley wants to divide Americans," said former Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Donna Brazile.

Democrats have questioned the wisdom of killing Soleimani and whether the Trump administration fully considered the potential consequences before taking action. But many have stressed that Soleimani was responsible for thousands of deaths and that they were not sad to see him go.

In response to the killing, Iran has approved a bill calling the U.S. military and the Pentagon terrorists. There have also been reports of a stampede at Soleimani's funeral that killed at least 40 people.

Former Vice President Joe Biden said, "No American will mourn Qassem Soleimani’s passing," and that he deserved to be brought to justice for his crimes against American troops and thousands of innocents throughout the region.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., said Soleimani was a "murderer, responsible for the deaths of thousands, including hundreds of Americans" but she said the decision to kill him was a "reckless move" that "escalates the situation with Iran."

Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Va., has introduced a resolution requiring congressional approval for further military action against Iran and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Sunday that the House would vote on a similar resolution this week.

Democrats have also called on the administration to brief more members of Congress on the intelligence it says showed Soleimani was planning upcoming attacks on Americans and that he presented an "imminent threat."

"I accept the notion that there was a real threat," Sen. Mark Warner, D-Va., said on NBC's "Meet the Press" during an interview Sunday. "The question of how imminent is something that I need more information on."

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., said Sunday that it was "accurate" to say Soleimani was plotting against American interests.

"But it's also true that Soleimani has been plotting against the United States for decades. The question is, did the plotting here rise to the level that required his elimination from the battlefield?" Schiff said.

Haley shared a clip of her appearance on "Hannity" on Twitter and her claim that Democrats were mourning Soleimani. Several public figures ridiculed her claim on the social media platform.

"Shameful, dangerous comment," tweeted 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Marianne Williamson. "We're in trouble as a nation when an ex-Governor and UN Ambassador would say something so dishonest."

"Nikki Haley. I've rarely agreed with your politics but I've always before respected you as a person. It demeans everyone when politicians go low," Williamson said.

"Just knock it off," tweeted David Frum, an ex-speechwriter for former President George W. Bush. He included a link to an October 2015 CNN article about then-presidential candidate Trump saying the world would have been better off if dictators Saddam Hussein and Moammar Gadhafi were still in power in Iraq and Libya.

"This is categorically false. The former Governor of South Carolina, former Ambassador to the United Nations & current member of the board of directors of Boeing Corporation – on television saying something she absolutely knows is untrue," MSNBC host Stephanie Ruhle said.

"Here's a question: What WON'T Nikki Haley say at this point?" asked New York Daily News sports columnist Mike Lupica.

Title: Media's Role in Donald Trump's Rise: A Neutral Analysis of Politico Magazine's Special Issue

Article:

In the aftermath of Donald Trump's potential Republican nomination win in Indiana, a wave of introspection and criticism towards the media has emerged, with some arguing that the press has played a significant role in Trump's rise. This perspective is evident in Politico Magazine's recent special issue, which features Trump facing a media mob on its cover with the headline, "What Have We Done?"

The issue, which is heavily critical of Trump, includes several essays that blame the media for Trump's success. However, one essay by media writer Jack Shafer argues that the blame game "gives too much credit to the media and too little credit to Donald Trump."

One of the contributors, reporter Ben Schreckinger, who became a full-time Trump correspondent despite having no prior experience, expresses frustration over criticism from Trump and his team, as well as a lack of access, both of which are common in political journalism.

Former CNN and NBC anchor Campbell Brown, in her essay titled "Why I Blame TV for Trump," argues that TV news is catering to Trump by giving him editorial control and prioritizing ratings over journalistic integrity. She claims that Trump's candidacy is largely a creation of a TV media that wants him to be the central character in this year's political drama.

However, Brown's argument overlooks several factors. Trump has seized a significant amount of "free" airtime by doing numerous interviews and driving the campaign dialogue. Reporters have also extensively investigated Trump's businesses, rhetoric, promises, and contradictions, albeit with limited impact on his lead.

Moreover, a large portion of the media attention Trump receives is harshly negative, often from conservative and liberal commentators who oppose him ideologically. Trump responds forcefully, particularly on Twitter, though he has toned it down recently. His supporters view these denunciations as evidence of his opposition to the failed media/political establishment.

It is essential to acknowledge the media's role in Trump's rise, but it is equally important to consider the factors that have allowed Trump to forge a connection with millions of Republican voters and overcome media criticism. The media's coverage of Trump is not without criticism, but it is also not solely responsible for his success.

Title: US to Open New Embassy in Jerusalem in May, Coinciding with Israel's 70th Anniversary

Article:

The United States Department of State has announced that a new American embassy in Jerusalem will open in May, coinciding with Israel's 70th anniversary. The announcement brings forward the controversial plan, initially announced by President Trump in December, by at least a year.

The embassy will initially be located at existing consular facilities in the Arnona district of Jerusalem. The status of Jerusalem is a contentious issue, as it goes to the heart of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israel considers Jerusalem its "eternal and undivided" capital, while the Palestinians claim East Jerusalem, occupied by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war, as the capital of a future state.

The announcement has been met with criticism from Palestinian officials. Saeb Erekat, a senior Palestinian official, called the move a "blatant provocation." The anniversary of Israel's founding precedes by a day what Palestinians call the Nakba, or "catastrophe" of their displacement in the 1948-49 Arab-Israel war.

In December, President Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital and move the embassy from Tel Aviv, where all other embassies are located, infuriated Palestinians. The declaration broke with decades of US neutrality on the issue and put the US out of step with the rest of the international community.

Within days of President Trump's declaration, a UN resolution was passed declaring any decisions regarding the status of the city "null and void" and insisting on its cancellation. It was backed by 128 states, with 35 abstaining and nine voting against.

Last month, US Vice-President Mike Pence told the Israeli parliament that the move would occur sometime before the end of 2019. The sudden change to May has been seen by some as a deliberate snub to Palestinians.

The move was welcomed by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who said, "This decision will turn Israel's 70th Independence Day into an even bigger celebration." He also expressed gratitude to President Trump, saying, "Thank you, President Trump, for your leadership and friendship."

However, the move has been criticized by some as a potential obstacle to peace negotiations between Israel and Palestine. Mr. Erekat stated, "The US move reflects their total insensitivities to what goes on in this region." He added, "The US administration has become part of the problem and not part of the solution."

Title: Congressional Hearing on Russia Inquiry: Trump, Schiff, and Mueller Report

Article:

Washington, D.C. - A contentious congressional hearing took place on Thursday, as President Donald Trump's Republican allies clashed with one of Trump's most prominent Democratic critics, Representative Adam Schiff, during a hearing on Russian meddling in the U.S. elections. The hearing, titled "Putin's Playbook: The Kremlin's Use of Oligarchs, Money, and Intelligence in 2016 and Beyond," was marked by heated exchanges and political maneuvering.

Hours prior to the hearing, Trump took to Twitter, demanding that Schiff resign from Congress due to his comments about the president's 2016 campaign and Russia. In response, Republican lawmakers called for Schiff to step down as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, citing his comments about the president's associates and their actions during the 2016 campaign.

Schiff, however, fired back during the hearing, labeling actions by the president's associates as unpatriotic and corrupt. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat, defended Schiff and criticized the actions of Trump and committee Republicans, calling them "shameful" and "irresponsible."

U.S. Attorney General William Barr, who was empowered by Justice Department regulations to decide how much of the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report to make public, on Sunday released a four-page summary of Mueller's findings. Barr stated that Mueller did not establish that Trump's campaign conspired with Russia in the 2016 election.

On Wednesday, Barr informed House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler about the length of the report, which is over 300 pages long. Barr also agreed to testify before Nadler's committee, although no date was set.

Republicans in the Senate thwarted another effort by Democrats to pass a resolution calling for the Mueller report to be made available to the public and Congress. The House has passed a similar resolution.

A Justice Department official stated on Tuesday that Barr would issue a public version of the report within "weeks, not months." However, top Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer criticized Barr's delay in the release, stating that it has "too much of the odor of political expediency to help the man who appointed him, President Trump."

Pelosi also demanded the report's release, stating, "No, thank you, Mr. Attorney General. We do not need your interpretation. Show us the report, and we'll come to our own conclusions."

Republicans have since launched a counter-attack against Democrats since Barr released his summary. Trump used an early-morning Twitter post to assail Schiff, whose committee is investigating Russia's influence on U.S. elections. Trump did not provide specifics of his accusations against Schiff, who has not been accused by authorities of leaking classified information.

During the hearing, Schiff cited a list of the Trump campaign's contacts with Russians, from Donald Trump Jr. welcoming a Russian offer of "dirt" on Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, to former national security adviser Michael Flynn secretly discussing easing U.S. sanctions on Russia with Moscow's ambassador before Trump became president.

"You might say that's all OK," Schiff said. "You might say that's just what you need to do to win. But I don't think it's OK. I think it's immoral. I think it's unethical. I think it's unpatriotic, and yes, I think it's corrupt - and evidence of collusion."

During his investigation, Mueller brought charges against 34 people, including Russian agents and former Trump aides. Mueller left unresolved in his report the question of whether Trump committed obstruction of justice by impeding the Russia investigation and did not exonerate the president, Barr said. Barr himself concluded there was insufficient evidence to establish that Trump had committed obstruction of justice.

The House Intelligence Committee has been bitterly split along party lines for years on the Russia investigation, which was taken over by Mueller in May 2017 after Trump fired FBI Director James Comey. The committee's Republicans wrapped up their investigation a year ago, finding no collusion between Trump and Moscow to influence the vote. Democrats, led by Schiff, blasted the announcement as premature.

Thursday's hearing continued after the angry exchange between its members.

Title: Career Diplomat William Taylor Testifies on Alleged Quid Pro Quo in Ukraine Aid

Article:

Ambassador William Taylor, a career diplomat who has served as the U.S. envoy to Ukraine since June, testified before Congress that President Donald Trump made the release of military aid to Ukraine conditional on a pledge that a political rival would be investigated. Taylor's testimony is the latest development in the ongoing impeachment inquiry into suspected abuse of power by President Trump.

In his opening remarks, Taylor stated, "Our relationship with Ukraine was being fundamentally undermined by an irregular, informal channel of U.S. policy-making and by the withholding of vital security assistance for domestic political reasons."

Taylor's testimony corroborates other reported accounts of White House efforts to get Ukraine to open investigations that could be damaging to Democrats, particularly former Vice-President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter. Taylor related a conversation he had with Gordon Sondland, one of the coordinators of what he described as an "irregular, informal channel of U.S. policymaking," in which Sondland told him that everything, including military aid and a White House visit, was dependent on the Ukrainian president making a public statement that he would order these investigations.

Taylor's remarks appear to contradict Sondland's earlier statement before lawmakers, where he said he had had "no discussions" with state department or White House officials regarding the investigating the Bidens.

The "irregular" channel also included U.S. envoy to Ukraine Kurt Volker, Ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland, Energy Secretary Rick Perry, and Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

By mid-July, Taylor said, it was apparent that the meeting Zelensky wanted with Trump "was conditioned on the investigation of Burisma and alleged Ukrainian interference in the 2016 U.S. elections." Taylor also noted that he heard a White House budget and management staffer say she was ordered not to release aid to Ukraine and realized "one of the key pillars of our strong support for Ukraine was threatened."

Taylor's testimony is significant as it provides a detailed account of the alleged quid pro quo between the Trump administration and Ukraine. The credibility of Taylor's testimony may be challenged by the president's defenders, but his career as a diplomat and his reputation for meticulous note-taking may make it difficult for his testimony to be dismissed as inaccurate.

If the House finds sufficient evidence, articles of impeachment will be put to a vote. If they are approved, proceedings will move to trial in the Senate, which is controlled by Trump's Republicans. The outcome of the impeachment inquiry remains uncertain.

Title: California and New York Lease Hotel Rooms for Homeless Individuals Released from Jail Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

California and New York are leasing hotel rooms to provide temporary housing for homeless individuals, including those released from jail, as part of an effort to limit the spread of the coronavirus in crowded jails and homeless encampments. The move is an unprecedented response to the pandemic, as law enforcement agencies across the country grapple with how to prevent outbreaks in jails and find housing solutions for released inmates.

In Oakland, California, the Alameda County Sheriff's Office is leasing 393 rooms in two hotels near the airport for homeless individuals, including those released from Santa Rita Jail, one of the state's largest lockups. The hotels, a Comfort Inn and Suites and the Radisson Hotel at the Oakland Airport, began taking people under the new contracts on March 25.

The pandemic has prompted law enforcement officials to make difficult decisions to prevent outbreaks in crowded jails. Some agencies have released thousands of people early. However, when people leave jails, finding housing can be a challenge. In the best of times, it's a thorny question, and cities are trying to find answers.

In California, the pandemic coincides with a historic homelessness crisis. Makeshift tent encampments line highways, railroad tracks, and parks. There are an estimated 150,000 homeless Californians, driven to the streets by soaring home prices, a housing shortage, and lack of access to mental health care.

Governor Gavin Newsom signed an executive order that includes $50 million to lease hotel rooms or buy travel trailers for homeless people, including those released from jails. As of Friday, the state had secured 7,000 hotel rooms.

Phil Ting, a San Francisco Democrat and chair of the California Assembly Budget Committee, said lawmakers allowed flexibility for local governments to house particularly vulnerable people, like homeless prisoners. "If someone in a homeless encampment got sick because of coronavirus, the whole encampment could be infected," Ting said.

Eve Garrow, a homelessness policy analyst and advocate for the ACLU of Southern California, said, "Being placed in a motel room means having your own living space, your own shower, your own bed, and it allows you to self-isolate. Honestly, I feel that it will save lives."

Randall Kuhn, an associate professor at UCLA's Fielding School of Public Health and co-author of a recent study, said Bay Area counties were "really setting an example for the rest of the country." Oakland's agreement allows the government to lease 393 rooms in the two hotels near the airport.

Other counties throughout the state have also started lease negotiations, including San Diego and San Francisco, where county supervisors unanimously approved a resolution that included housing for people who had been in jail. San Francisco's public defender, Mano Raju, estimated 20 to 30 percent of the local jail population did not have anywhere to live.

Sgt. Ray Kelly, the sheriff's spokesman in Alameda County, said he hopes his county's plan can serve as a blueprint for places throughout the country as they wrestle with how to safely release people from jails. He said crime is down, and no jail detainees have yet to test positive for the virus.

Title: Administration Proposes Charging for Protests, Closing 80% of White House Sidewalks

Article:

The U.S. administration, under the leadership of President Donald Trump, has proposed a plan that could potentially charge citizens for protests and close 80% of the sidewalks surrounding the White House. The proposal was introduced by Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke in August.

Under the proposed plan, the administration is considering closing 80% of the sidewalks near the White House, and may charge "event management" costs for demonstrations. Currently, the National Park Service can recoup costs for special events but not for spontaneous protests, such as those that typically occur in Lafayette Park across from the White House.

The charges could include costs for erecting barriers, cleaning fees, repairs to grass, permit fees, and the salaries of personnel on hand to monitor demonstrations, all tallied at the discretion of the police.

Civil liberties groups have expressed concern over the proposals, viewing them as a violation of the rights guaranteed under the First Amendment. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) stated that such fees "could make mass protests like Martin Luther King Jr.'s historic 1963 March on Washington and its 'I have a dream' speech too expensive to happen."

During the Vietnam War, the federal government attempted to impose similar barriers on citizens' right to assemble in protest and were sued by the ACLU. In their ruling, the courts reasserted the importance of parks for public assembly and the airing of opinions, stating that such sites were "cardinal values" in democratic society. The White House sidewalk, Lafayette Park, and the Ellipse were unique sites for the exercise of these rights, and the courts could not "accord deference to an executive approach to use of the White House sidewalk that is rooted in a bias against expressive conduct."

Brie Jackson (@PositivelyBrie) tweeted, "If you have to pay for free speech, it's not free."

The National Park Service has attempted to justify the proposal by stating that large protests, like the Women's March, overtax their abilities and place a heavy cost on the government. However, some argue that when it comes to preserving the right to protest, no cost is too high.

The public has until October 15 to comment on the plans.

Title: Gas Prices: Regional Differences in Gasoline Costs Considered in Light of Local Wages and Usage

Article:

A new study by GasBuddy reveals that the cost of filling up a car varies significantly across the United States when factoring in average gasoline usage, local wages, and average gas prices. Contrary to conventional wisdom, states in the Southeast, which are typically among the cheapest areas for gasoline, are surprisingly expensive when considering the number of hours of local labor needed to pay for a year's worth of gas.

According to Patrick DeHaan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy, there are some surprising findings in the study. "You tend to see areas that are more rural, with challenged incomes or lower median hourly wages where the true cost of filling up is more hard work than other areas," DeHaan said.

To assess the true cost of filling up, GasBuddy calculated the average amount of gasoline consumed per driver for every state, average hourly wages in those states, and the average gas price for each state as of Aug. 1. This allowed the researchers to determine "how much work it would take" to pay for a year's worth of gas, DeHaan explained.

For example, Mississippi, which had the second-lowest average price per gallon in the country on Thursday ($2.20), ranks as the fifth most expensive state in the country, requiring an average of 100.3 hours of work to pay for a year's worth of gas. On the flip side, Hawaii, which had the highest average price per gallon on Thursday ($3.66), is actually the 11th cheapest state in the country, requiring an average of 80.4 hours of work to pay for a year's worth of gas.

People living in most Northeast states need the fewest number of hours worked to pay for their gas. Measured by these standards, the cheapest state in the country is Massachusetts at only 66.8 hours, followed by Connecticut at 70.6, Maryland at 71.7, New York at 73.8, Rhode Island at 75.4, and Delaware at 76.8.

One big reason for this discrepancy is that people don't drive as much in the Northeast, where mass transit options are more prevalent. Some states that have a high cost per gallon also rank as the most expensive when measured by the number of hours worked to pay for a year's worth of gas. Nevada, which had the fourth-highest price per gallon on Thursday ($3.12), requires the most hours worked at 107.7, according to GasBuddy.

Here is the full list of states, ranked by the number of hours the average person needs to work to afford a year of gas, according to GasBuddy:

1. Nevada - 107.7
2. Montana - 107.4
3. Idaho - 107.1
4. South Dakota - 101.4
5. Mississippi - 100.3
6. Oregon - 100.1
7. West Virginia - 98.8
8. Arkansas - 98.2
9. Utah - 97.0
10. California - 95.5
11. Kentucky - 94.8
12. Indiana - 94.4
13. Nebraska - 93.2
14. Oklahoma - 92.9
15. Wyoming - 92.7
16. Michigan - 92.4
17. New Mexico - 92.4
18. Alaska - 92.1
19. Louisiana - 91.4
20. Arizona - 91.1
21. Alabama - 91.0
22. South Carolina - 91.0
23. North Dakota - 90.8
24. Maine - 90.6
25. Kansas - 90.5
26. Tennessee - 90.4
27. Iowa - 89.7
28. Missouri - 89.1
29. Wisconsin - 89.0
30. Ohio - 88.1
31. North Carolina - 88.1
32. Florida - 88.1
33. Georgia - 88.1
34. Illinois - 87.9

Title: Hillary Clinton Advocates for Gun Control at Mental Health Conference

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton expressed concerns about the widespread acceptance of the right to carry firearms in any location at any time during a speech at the National Council for Behavioral Health conference in Maryland on Tuesday. Clinton suggested that the current perspective, which she referred to as an "almost article of faith," is not in the best interest of the majority of citizens.

"I think again we're way out of balance. I think that we've got to rein in what has become an almost article of faith that anybody can have a gun anywhere, anytime," Clinton said. "And I do not believe that is in the best interest of the vast majority of people. And I think you can say that and still support the right of people to own guns."

Clinton expressed concerns about the proliferation of guns in settings like movie theaters, citing instances of shootings over seemingly minor incidents such as loud gum chewing or cellphone use. She compared this situation to countries with no rule of law and no self-control, implying that the United States should pay attention to this issue.

When asked about which countries Clinton was referring to, the article does not provide specific details. However, it mentions a study by Harvard in 2013 that found a correlation between high gun ownership and low crime rates globally. The article also notes that while American gun ownership is high, many other developed nations, such as Norway, Finland, Germany, France, and Denmark, have high rates of gun ownership but lower murder rates compared to countries with less gun ownership.

The article also mentions that Clinton has not yet decided whether or not she will run for president in 2016, but encouraged Americans to "stay tuned."

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker's Shift in Immigration Stance Sparks Controversy

Article:

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has found himself in the midst of an immigration-related controversy, following the dismissal of a communications aide after old tweets critical of Representative Steve King (R-IA) were brought to light. The aide, Liz Mair, had tweeted, "In other news, IA is once again embarrassing itself, and the GOP, this morning. Thanks, guys," in reference to King's January 24th Iowa Freedom Summit where Walker, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), Carly Fiorina, and other potential Republican presidential candidates spoke.

Walker's immigration troubles began in January, as opponents circulated prior statements indicating that Walker had endorsed a "path to citizenship" and the Senate's Gang of 8 bill. Walker has since attempted to distance himself from these positions, telling Fox News Sunday's Chris Wallace on March 1st, "My view has changed. I’m flat-out saying it. Candidates can say that, sometimes they don’t."

Walker's stance on immigration has evolved over time. In July 2013, he stated, "You hear some people talk about border security and a wall and all that. To me, I do not know that you need any of that if you had a better, saner way to let people into the country in the first place." In March 2015, he expressed, "I've talked to people all across America. And the concerns I have is that we need to secure the border. We ultimately need to put in place a system that works. A legal immigration system that works. And part of doing this is put the onus on employers, getting them E-Verify and tools to do that."

Walker's current position is that illegal immigrants already in the United States should be given a path to citizenship, but only after the border is secured. In response to a question about a potential path to citizenship for these individuals, Walker stated, "I believe there's a way that you can do that. First and foremost, you've got to secure that border or none of these plans make any sense."

Walker's stance on immigration appears to align with that of fellow Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush. Both politicians believe that the border should be secured first, and only after that is accomplished can illegal immigrants currently in the United States be given legal status or a path to citizenship. The differences, if any, between Walker and Bush on immigration are not immediately apparent.

Title: Conservative Media and Liberal Criticism: A Neutral Analysis of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s Comments

Article:

Robert F. Kennedy Jr., in a discussion on HuffPost Live, expressed concerns about the right-wing influence in the American media, particularly Fox News. Kennedy stated that 95% of talk radio in the U.S. is right-wing, and 22% of Americans consider Fox News their primary news source. He argued that this has contributed to the country's division since the Civil War and has empowered certain ideologues in the U.S. Congress.

Kennedy's comments were met with criticism from conservatives, who often complain about liberal media bias. Kennedy's assertion that conservative media is unfairly biased while ignoring the bias in liberal media is a point of contention. The article notes that liberal media is often accused of slanting their reporting in favor of Democrats, which is evident in their selection, presentation, and treatment of news stories.

Kennedy's most significant criticism, however, is his scapegoating of conservative media for the divisiveness in the nation. The article suggests that the emergence of a robust alternative media has given conservatives a consistent public voice, and the division in the nation may be due to differing worldviews rather than media bias.

The article also highlights Kennedy's apparent blindness to liberal media bias and intolerance of opposing viewpoints. Many liberals, according to the article, believe that only their views are legitimate and that contrary ones are dangerous. This has led to calls for the suppression of opposing speech, as seen in campus speech codes, crusades against so-called hate speech, and the Fairness Doctrine.

The article concludes by stating that America's problem is not divided opinion and rigorous debate, but journalists who once acted as watchdogs against abuses of power and now function as co-conspirators in those abuses by liberal politicians. The article suggests that conservatives, both in the media and in public service, are more honest about their beliefs and biases, and thus represent less danger to the republic than liberal politicians and media masquerading as neutral, unbiased, or objective. The article does not advocate for the suppression of liberal speech but calls for more transparency and honesty in reporting.

Title: The Limited Role of Federal Government in Gun Regulation: A Constitutional Perspective

Article:

The current debate on gun control in the United States has seen President Obama and Vice President Biden express a commitment to use federal powers to ensure safety. This commitment, however, raises questions about the constitutionality of federal involvement in matters of health, safety, welfare, and morality, as these areas were not explicitly delegated to the federal government by the U.S. Constitution.

The Constitution, drafted by the Founding Fathers, was created to establish a federal government of limited powers, derived from the states. The states are sovereign, and their powers were not delegated to the federal government. The Constitution grants the federal government 16 unique, discrete powers, all of which concern nationhood, such as foreign affairs, national defense, and interstate commerce.

The Supreme Court has consistently ruled that the "police power," or the power to regulate for health, safety, welfare, and morality, remains with the states. This principle is consistent with the philosophical principle of "subsidiarity," which states that governmental intervention should be the minimum needed and that problems closest to the people should be addressed by the government closest to those people.

The Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution prohibits all governments, including the federal government, from infringing upon the right of the people to keep and bear arms. This right allows individuals to defend themselves when the police cannot or will not, and it provides a residue of firepower in the hands of the people to counter any potential tyrant.

The current debate on gun control, with the federal government's involvement, raises questions about the constitutional limits of government power. The Constitution was designed to protect personal freedom from the lust for power of those in government and from the passions of the people who elect them. It is crucial to uphold these principles to maintain a balance between individual rights and government intervention.

Title: Bipartisan Discussions on Spending Bill and Immigration Policy in the Senate

Article:

In a statement on the Senate floor on Monday, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, announced that he has been engaged in "productive, bipartisan conversations" with Speaker John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, and Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, regarding the passing of the spending bill. Reid expressed optimism that Republican leaders are committed to keeping the government funded.

However, some Republicans, including Mr. Boehner, have not ruled out the possibility of a government shutdown. Representative Steve King, Republican of Iowa, an outspoken opponent of an immigration overhaul, is reportedly preparing legislation to counteract any executive actions taken by the president regarding immigration policy.

Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the second-ranking Senate Republican, shared concerns among his colleagues that any unilateral action by the president could jeopardize the opportunity for passing their own immigration legislation once Republicans control both chambers in the next Congress.

Despite opposition to the president's immigration policies, some Republicans, such as Senator John McCain of Arizona, have expressed opposition to a government shutdown as a tactic. McCain stated, "I'm just unalterably opposed to another government shutdown. I'm not going to do that to my state, and I will do everything in my power to see that we don't shut down the government."

The article does not provide specific details on the immigration policies or executive actions being referred to, nor does it offer a definitive timeline for the passing of the spending bill or any potential immigration legislation. Additionally, the article does not attribute any statements to the president regarding his immigration policies or executive actions.

Title: Brazilian-American Activist Julia Song Discusses Her Political Activism in Brazil and the U.S.

Article:

Julia Song, a Brazilian-American political activist and commentator, has been featured on One America News Network (OANN), Rebel Media, and other platforms. She can be followed on Twitter @realjuliasong. The views expressed in this commentary are her own. View more opinion on CNN.

Song, a native of Brazil, was involved in organizing peaceful protests against government corruption and abuses of power in her home country during 2013. At the time, Brazil was grappling with widespread corruption, and many of its politicians, the source of much of the scandal, continued to push agendas that benefited themselves and a select few.

However, the excessive spending on the World Cup drained the country's already depleted resources, providing an opportunity for Song and Brazilians from across the political spectrum to come together. Their collective protests led to a government investigation into corruption, resulting in the imprisonment of many politicians and the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff.

Shortly after the protests, Song moved to the United States on a family visa, eventually being granted temporary residency, which allowed her to work. She then embarked on a four-year-long process to gain full citizenship, navigating the complexities and financial costs of the American immigration bureaucracy.

Upon arriving in the U.S., Song believed her activism days were behind her. However, she noticed a growing political divide between the elites, or establishment politicians, and working-class Americans struggling to make ends meet. Sensing the disconnect and the growing power of the political elite, she began using social media to raise awareness of the issue, first on Instagram and then on Twitter.

Song advocates for her belief in a smaller government that guarantees more individual freedoms and allows everyday Americans a chance at success. For those who may not have guessed, she identifies as a Republican and supports President Donald Trump's emphasis on fighting for ordinary Americans.

Title: Senate Democrats Issue Warning to GOP on Obamacare Repeal and Replacement

Article:

Senate Democrats have issued a warning to Republicans planning a quick repeal of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) next year, stating that they will not cooperate in replacing it. The warning comes as top Republicans are plotting to move forward with a budget plan in January, allowing them to repeal much of Obamacare on a straight-party line vote around the time President-elect Donald Trump is sworn into office.

Sen. Patty Murray, who will be the third-ranking Senate Democrat in the new Congress, said, "If they take it away, they better tell us how to fix it because they broke it." Sen. Chuck Schumer, the incoming Senate Democratic leader, told CNN on Thursday, "They're going to find repealing Obamacare without putting in a replacement will be far more disastrous and less clever than they think."

To replace Obamacare under the Senate rules, Republicans would need the support of at least eight Democratic senators to reach the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster. Top Democrats are warning that the GOP will get little cooperation from their caucus on a replacement plan if they dismantle the health care law.

Republicans are gambling that Democrats will buckle, particularly Democratic senators up for reelection in 2018 from states Trump won. However, Sen. Dick Durbin, Schumer's chief deputy, said, "I want to know what the replacement is going to be. I want to know if it's real protection, and as good as [the Affordable Care Act] for the millions who count on it."

GOP leaders are weighing a plan that would delay the health care repeal from taking effect for up to three years, giving Congress time to craft a new system to provide health insurance for the millions who could lose it. They are also planning an ambitious legislative agenda in the new year, moving forward on a plan to rewrite the tax code, a new government funding bill, and confirming a spate of Trump's nominees, including to the Supreme Court.

However, dealing with the red-hot issue of health care could be the trickiest, especially since there's no consensus within the GOP yet on what the replacement plan would look like. Even if the GOP writes into its legislation that a repeal won't take effect for three years, some health policy experts warn that the health care system could collapse immediately because insurers may pull out of the expiring system. That could intensify pressure on the GOP to find a solution right away.

The issue has been discussed at length between House Speaker Paul Ryan, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and senior Trump officials, and it dominated talk among top House Republicans in a closed-door meeting on Thursday. Oklahoma GOP Rep. Tom Cole, who attended the meeting, conceded that moving ahead with repeal will put the burden on Republicans to lay out the next steps. North Carolina Rep. Mark Meadows, who will chair the conservative House Freedom Caucus next Congress, said the GOP was still sorting out its plans on the issue.

Title: California Legislature Passes Bill Requiring Presidential Candidates to Release Tax Returns

Article:

California lawmakers have passed a bill that would require presidential candidates to make their tax returns public before appearing on the state's ballot. The legislation, passed by a Democratic-controlled Legislature, marks the latest move in California's ongoing dispute with President Donald Trump.

The bill, authored by Democratic state Sen. Mike McGuire, was passed after similar measures failed to advance in other states. The enforceability of the bill remains questionable, as the U.S. Supreme Court has held that states cannot add to the qualifications for U.S. Senate or House members, according to a legislative analysis. California's legislative counsel released an opinion ahead of the vote stating the measure as unconstitutional. However, other legal experts have suggested that such a requirement could pass constitutional muster.

It is uncertain if Governor Jerry Brown will sign the measure. While Trump is the first president in years to ascend to the White House without releasing his tax returns, the Democratic governor has resisted similar disclosures. In a break with longstanding tradition of gubernatorial candidates in California, he did not release his tax returns during his 2010 or 2014 campaigns.

The bill passed the state Senate on the final day of this year's legislative session, after gaining approval in California's lower house the previous day. The bill would require, as a condition for appearing on the primary ballot, that presidential candidates file copies of their five most recent tax returns with state officials. The state, in turn, would make them public.

Title: Canada Legalizes Recreational Cannabis: A Nationwide Celebration and Regulatory Changes

Article:

Canada marked the end of cannabis prohibition on Wednesday with nationwide celebrations, parties, and media coverage. The shift in policy, which makes Canada one of only two nations where marijuana is legal, was a significant milestone for the country.

Ian Power, a resident of Newfoundland and Labrador, was the first person to purchase legal cannabis in Canada. Across the country, Alex Smith was among the many who made purchases hours later. The BC Cannabis Store in Kamloops, British Columbia, currently the only legal store in the province, boasted a clean "west coast casual" interior and a range of products.

For many, the experience of shopping for cannabis legally was a significant change. Mr. Smith, a long-time cannabis user, described the experience as "a little surreal." He noted that, for much of his adult life, he had hidden his cannabis use due to the stigma associated with it.

However, the legalization of cannabis was not without its challenges. In Ontario, public consumption remained prohibited, and the streets of Toronto were largely drug-free on the day of legalization. Most of the partying took place on the premises of private businesses, such as Hot Black Coffee in Downtown Toronto, which transformed its back patio into a "chill" lounge.

The Canadian Medical Association Journal published an editorial calling the legalization a "national, uncontrolled experiment in which the profits of cannabis producers and tax revenues are squarely pitched against the health of Canadians." The Canadian Psychiatric Society cautioned Canadians under 25 about using cannabis, warning of potential negative effects on memory, attention, and the ability to process thoughts.

The Canadian government has implemented several regulations to control cannabis consumption. Users must be 18 or 19 (depending on the province) to purchase, and there are penalties for those caught selling to minors. Canadians will be limited to the number of plants they can grow themselves and can only hold 30 grams (one ounce) on their person in public at a time.

The government also introduced new drug-impaired driving legislation that includes stiff fines and possible jail time. Police will be able to demand suspected drivers take a roadside sobriety test or provide a saliva sample to test for THC, the psychoactive compound in cannabis. The reliability of these saliva tests has raised concerns, and legal experts expect challenges to the law to make their way to court.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who promised to make marijuana legal in 2014, has admitted to smoking cannabis five or six times in the past. He has no intention of using marijuana and has called the criminal prohibition of cannabis a "failure." The government hopes the new regulatory system will be more effective at keeping cannabis out of the hands of minors and at reducing health and social harms related to its use.

On Wednesday, Canada also announced it would waive wait time and fees for those who have served their time for minor cannabis possession convictions and want to apply for a pardon. This move is intended to address the disproportionate impact of previous cannabis laws on young people from minorities.

Some advocates for amnesty say this is a good first step but are calling on Canada to have those convictions expunged, which would completely erase the record. The day's events were met with a flurry of marijuana-themed puns and jokes, with police departments using humor to advocate for responsible consumption. The day's name remains a topic of debate, with no general consensus reached.

Title: Obama Outlines Economic Vision for Second Term, Emphasizes American Nationalism in DNC Speech

Article:

In a speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday, President Barack Obama called for a "harder" path to long-term economic prosperity, outlining grand economic promises for a second term in office. The speech concluded three days of speeches from Democratic leaders who emphasized that their party is the only one that can be trusted to look out for the interests of the suffering middle class.

Obama acknowledged the nation's economic struggles, stating that the economy is far from fully healed and that the country does not currently sense that it is on the doorstep of a better future. In a departure from his last presidential campaign, Democrats argued in the starkest language yet that Republican Mitt Romney is an out-of-touch plutocrat who lacks simple patriotism.

Obama attempted to strike a balance between connecting with voters in the midst of a protracted economic downturn and offering an optimistic vision for the future. He outlined specific benchmarks for success, including a million new manufacturing jobs by the end of 2016, a sharp reduction in oil imports, 600,000 jobs in the natural gas industry, 100,000 new math and science teachers, and new controls on the rising cost of college tuition.

The mechanics of achieving those goals were largely absent from the speech, but Obama stated that he would aim to extract sacrifices from the wealthiest citizens and special interests in order to bring about widely shared economic gains. Throughout the speech and the evening as a whole, there was an undercurrent of America-first triumphalism, and a combination of implicit and explicit charges that Republicans do not share that brand of nationalism.

Obama took time in his speech to mock his challengers and question their readiness for the job of president and vice president. In an allusion to Romney's bumbling summer trip overseas, Obama joked, "You might not be ready for diplomacy with Beijing if you can't visit the Olympics without insulting our closest ally." It remains to be seen whether Obama accomplished his goal of delivering a forward-looking economic vision and breaking away from a debate focused on an unemployment rate stuck persistently above 8 percent.

Title: Trump Signs $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill, Replaces National Security Adviser

Article:

President Donald Trump has signed a $1.3 trillion spending plan to fund the government through September, overcoming his initial threat of a veto. The bill, which passed in the wee hours of the morning on Friday, includes funding for the military, homeland security, and other government operations.

Trump had initially expressed dissatisfaction with the bill, criticizing the lack of action on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) debate and his proposed border wall. In a tweet on March 23, 2018, Trump stated, "I am considering a VETO of the Omnibus Spending Bill based on the fact that the 800,000 plus DACA recipients have been totally abandoned by the Democrats (not even mentioned in Bill) and the BORDER WALL, which is desperately needed for our National Defense, is not fully funded."

However, Trump signed the bill on "national security" grounds, citing the rebuilding of America's military and improvements to homeland security. He expressed displeasure with the bill, stating, "There are a lot of things I'm not happy about in this bill."

The bill received robust bipartisan support in both the House and Senate, but conservatives in both houses criticized the bill, with some complaining they had only seven hours to read the 2,232-page bill. The high price tag and inclusion of line items, such as funding for Planned Parenthood, were among the criticisms.

One item in the measure that both sides celebrated is the Taylor Force Act, named for an American combat veteran who was brutally murdered by a Palestinian terrorist while visiting Israel. The Palestinian government provided financial rewards to the terrorist's family, a practice the Taylor Force Act aims to stop by suspending US funding to the Palestinian Authority until they change their laws incentivizing terrorism.

Meanwhile, there is a shakeup in the president's inner circle, with Trump replacing his national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, with John Bolton, former US ambassador to the UN and an outspoken hawk on foreign affairs. Bolton's appointment increases the chance the US will pull out of the Iran nuclear deal and may lead to a trade war with China, as the president announced he will charge tariffs on as much as $60 billion in Chinese imports to the US. China has responded by announcing a list of American goods that may be hit with higher import taxes.

Title: Hillary Clinton Praises George W. Bush's Foreign Policy, Critiques Obama's in CNN Interview

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, in an interview on CNN's "Fareed Zakaria GPS" show, expressed praise for former President George W. Bush's foreign policy, particularly his emergency program for AIDS relief in Sub-Saharan Africa. Clinton also seemed to critique President Obama's foreign affairs policies, suggesting that the U.S. needs to clarify its values and intentions to lead and manage effectively on the international stage.

During the interview, Clinton stated, "We have to go back out and sell ourselves. It is not to be taken for granted. What do we stand for and how do we intend to lead and manage? How do we try to enlist the rest of the world in this struggle between cooperation and order and conflict and disorder which is really at the root of so much that’s going on today — and I don’t think we’ve done a very good job of that."

Clinton went on to discuss the differences between headline news and actual trends, implying that Bush, and not Obama, had a long-term view of the international stage. She cited Bush's AIDS relief program as an example of his positive impact, stating, "George W. Bush is very popular in Sub-Saharan Africa. Why? Because of the president’s emergency program for AIDS relief. Whether you agree or disagree with a lot of what else he did — and I disagree with a lot of it — I am proud to be an American when I go to Sub-Saharan Africa and people say, ‘I want to thank President Bush and the United States for helping us fight HIV/AIDS.’"

Clinton also seemed to take another jab at Obama's White House, stating that the U.S. spends a "lot of money and a lot of time and effort" to exert influence around the world. She added, "I think we would be able to succeed more effectively if we were clearer about who we are and what we stand for and the values that we hold."

Fox News analysts suggested that Clinton's pro-Bush views may be genuine, but they also speculated that she may be trying to distance herself from Obama's foreign affairs policies if she decides to run for the presidency in 2016. The specifics of Clinton's potential presidential campaign were not discussed in the provided text.

Title: Timeline of Events Suggests Mitt Romney's Criticism of Obama Administration's Response to Middle East Attacks May Be Misleading

Article:

A timeline of events suggests that Mitt Romney's criticism of the Obama administration's response to the attacks on U.S. missions in Libya and Egypt may be misleading. The following is a chronology of the events that transpired on Tuesday, September 11, 2012:

1. Tuesday morning in Egypt, the U.S. Embassy in Cairo released a statement condemning the continuing efforts by misguided individuals to hurt the religious feelings of Muslims. The statement did not specifically mention the controversial video, but it said the embassy "firmly reject(s) the actions by those who abuse the universal right of free speech to hurt the religious beliefs of others."

2. Protesters began to breach the embassy in Cairo, where ultimately several men scaled the walls of the mission and tore down its American flag.

3. At 6:30 p.m. ET, the embassy tweeted about its earlier statement: "This morning's condemnation (issued before protests began) still stands. As does our condemnation of unjustified breach of the Embassy." The tweet was posted by a foreign service officer, CNN confirmed. Several State Department sources said that the U.S. ambassador to Egypt did not sign off on the original statement, as she was in Washington at the time.

4. Reports then emerged Tuesday evening, Eastern Standard Time, of attacks on the consulate in Benghazi, Libya. The State Department also told CNN that a consulate employee had been killed in the attacks. At the time, however, the employee's nationality was not clear.

5. At 10:10 p.m. ET, Romney's campaign released an embargoed (until midnight) statement blasting the Obama administration. The statement had a veiled reference to the Egypt embassy's statement that condemned offensive speech against Muslims and referred to it as the administration's "first response":

   "I'm outraged by the attacks on American diplomatic missions in Libya and Egypt and by the death of an American consulate worker in Benghazi. It's disgraceful that the Obama Administration's first response was not to condemn attacks on our diplomatic missions, but to sympathize with those who waged the attacks."

6. At 10:25 p.m. ET, the campaign lifted the embargo, and news outlets began reporting the statement.

7. At 12:11 a.m. ET, Obama's re-election campaign put out a statement accusing Romney of taking a political swipe during the crisis.

   "We are shocked that, at a time when the United States of America is confronting the tragic death of one of our diplomatic officers in Libya, Governor Romney would choose to launch a political attack."

8. At 6:21 a.m. ET, CNN reported on its wire service that U.S. ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens was killed in a rocket attack. Over the next few hours, it was revealed that three other personnel, including a Foreign Service information management officer, were also killed.

9. At 10:16 a.m. ET, Romney held a press conference at his campaign office in Jacksonville, Florida. He renewed his criticism of the Obama administration, saying "Obama has demonstrated a lack of clarity as to a foreign policy."

   Asked if he regretted the wording in his statement Tuesday night, the Republican then issued his own timeline of the events in answering the question.

10. Romney then said the administration's original statement from the embassy in Cairo was effectively an "apology." His language went further than the Tuesday release from his campaign where he called it "disgraceful" and an expression of "sympathy for those who waged the attacks."

   "I think it's a terrible course for America to stand in apology for our values. That instead when our grounds are being attacked and being breached, that the first response of the United States must be outrage," he said. "An apology for America's values is never the right course."

11. His comments also raise the question of where Romney stands on the offensive video. While he was not asked about the video in the press conference, Romney stood by the right to free speech.

   "We'll defend also our constitutional rights of speech and assembly and religion," he said. "We encourage our nations to understand and respect the principles of our Constitution because we recognize that these principles are the ultimate source of freedom for individuals around the world."

12. CNN obtained talking points from the Romney campaign in which they advise Republicans on how to respond to the press over the issue. The document suggests Republicans be prepared to answer this question: "Don't you think it was appropriate for the embassy to condemn the controversial movie in question? Are you standing up for movies like this?"

   The answer prompts the responder to say that Romney "rejects the reported message of the movie," but to add that "we will not apologize for our constitutional right to freedom of speech."
