In addition to the American Cancer Society, the proposition is backed by the American Heart Association and the American Lung Association, among other groups. The proposition's supporters, including former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, have been surprised by the amount of money being spent by big tobacco in opposition to the initiative. However, they remain optimistic about its chances.

Title: Obama Criticizes Trump as Unfit for Presidency, Citing Unprecedented Campaign and Divisive Remarks

Article:

In a rare move, President Barack Obama on Tuesday publicly declared Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, as "unfit" to serve as president. During a press conference at the White House with Singapore's prime minister, Obama criticized Trump's remarks about Muslim parents of a U.S. Army officer who was killed in the Iraq War.

"If you are repeatedly having to say in very strong terms that what he has said is unacceptable, why are you still endorsing him?" Obama asked. He further questioned, "What does this say about your party that this is your standard bearer?"

Obama's comments come in response to Trump's criticism of the Muslim parents of a U.S. Army officer who was killed in the Iraq War. Obama added, "This is not a situation where you have an episodic gaffe, this is daily and weekly where they are distancing themselves from statements he's making."

Trump released a statement an hour after Obama spoke, criticizing the president and Hillary Clinton, his Democratic opponent, for their handling of the economy, foreign policy, and the Iran nuclear deal. Trump also criticized Clinton's use of a private email server as secretary of State, saying it put national security at risk.

The controversy surrounding Trump escalated last week after a feud with Khizr and Ghazala Khan, the parents of the soldier. Khizr Khan delivered a blistering rebuke of Trump's proposal to temporarily ban Muslims from entering the U.S. during a speech at the Democratic convention in Philadelphia.

Trump responded to Khan's comments during a Monday night interview on Fox News, stating, "His son died 12 years ago, and if I were president, his son would not have died because I would not have been in the war, if I was president back then."

While no GOP leaders have dropped their endorsement of Trump, Rep. Richard Hanna, a retiring congressman from New York, became the first GOP lawmaker to say he would vote for Clinton. Hanna cited Trump's comments on Khan in explaining his decision to vote for Clinton.

"I think Trump is a national embarrassment," Hanna told The Syracuse Post Standard. "Is he really the guy you want to have the nuclear codes?"

Title: Former Intelligence Community Inspector General Charles McCullough III Discusses Clinton Email Investigation Backlash

Article:

Former Intelligence Community Inspector General Charles McCullough III, who played a central role in the Hillary Clinton email investigation during the Obama administration, has revealed that he, his family, and his staff faced intense backlash from Clinton allies, including threats of dismissal if Clinton won the 2016 election.

In an exclusive interview with Fox News, McCullough, who was responsible for the 17 intelligence agencies, discussed his role in the Clinton email probe for the first time on television. He shed light on how the probe was politicized and his office was marginalized by Democrats.

In January 2016, after McCullough informed the Republican leadership on the Senate intelligence and foreign affairs committees that emails beyond the "Top Secret" level passed through Clinton's unsecured personal server, the backlash intensified. McCullough recalled, "All of a sudden I became a shill of the right. And I was told by members of Congress, ‘Be careful. You're losing your credibility. You need to be careful. There are people out to get you.'”

McCullough's comments came during an in-person meeting about a year before the presidential election with then-Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, who was also disturbed by the independent Clinton email findings. Clapper reportedly said, “This is extremely reckless.”

After the Clapper meeting, McCullough's team was marginalized, with senior officials telling him to keep Clapper out of it. As one of the few people who viewed the 22 top-secret Clinton emails deemed too classified to release under any circumstances, McCullough stated, "There was a very good reason to withhold those emails...there would have been harm to national security."

Some of the email exchanges contained Special Access Program (SAP) information characterized by intel experts as "above top secret." WikiLeaks documents show the campaign was formulating talking points as the review of 30,000 Clinton emails was ongoing.

McCullough was critical of the campaign's response, as the classified review had barely begun. "There was an effort...certainly on the part of the campaign, to mislead people into thinking that there was nothing to see here," McCullough said.

In March 2016, seven senior Democrats sent a letter to McCullough and his State Department counterpart, raising serious questions about the impartiality of the Clinton email review. However, McCullough clarified that he was not making the decisions on what material in Clinton's emails was classified—he was passing along the findings of the individual agencies who got the intelligence and have final say on classification.

McCullough described one confrontation with Democratic Sen. Dianne Feinstein's office just six weeks before the election, amid pressure to respond to the letter—which Feinstein had co-signed. "I thought that any response to that letter would just hyper-politicize the situation," McCullough said. "I recall even offering to resign, to the staff director. I said, ‘Tell [Feinstein] I'll resign tonight. I'd be happy to go. I'm not going to respond to that letter. It's just that simple.'"

As Election Day approached, McCullough said the threats went further, singling out him and another senior government investigator on the email case. "It was told in no uncertain terms, by a source directly from the campaign, that we would be the first two to be fired—with [Clinton's] administration. That that was definitely going to happen," he said.

McCullough said he was just trying to do his job, which requires independence. "I was, in this context, a whistleblower. I was explaining to Congress—I was doing exactly what they had expected me to do. Exactly what I promised them I would do during my confirmation hearing," he said. "...This was a political matter, and all of a sudden I was the enemy."

He also mentioned increased pressures early on from Clinton's former team at the State Department, especially top official Patrick Kennedy. "State Department management didn't want us there," McCullough said. "We knew we had had a security problem at this point. We had a possible compromise."

Speaking about the case more than a year after the FBI probe concluded, McCullough in his interview also addressed the possibility that a more cooperative State Department and Clinton campaign might have precluded the FBI's involvement from the start. "Had they come in with the server willingly, without having us to refer this to the bureau...maybe we could have worked with the State Department," he said.

More than 2,100 classified emails passed through Clinton's personal server, which was used exclusively for government business. No one has been charged. When asked what would have happened to him if he had done such a thing, McCullough said, "I'd be sitting in Leavenworth right now."

Fox News reached out to a Clinton campaign spokesman, Feinstein's office, and Clapper for comment but received no immediate response.

Title: Wisconsin and Minnesota Primary Elections Set Up Tight Races for November Congressional Elections

Article:

In a significant development, voters in the key battleground states of Wisconsin and Minnesota chose their nominees in primary elections on Tuesday, setting the stage for tight races as the November congressional elections approach.

In Wisconsin, state senator Leah Vukmir was projected to challenge incumbent Democratic U.S. Senator Tammy Baldwin, following a contentious primary that could potentially impact her chances in November. Wisconsin played a crucial role in Republican Donald Trump's surprising presidential win in 2016, and turnout in both Wisconsin and neighboring Minnesota could serve as a gauge of Democratic strength ahead of the midterm elections.

Both states have shown signs of shifting to the right in recent years. Trump became the first Republican presidential candidate to win Wisconsin in 32 years, and he narrowly lost to Democrat Hillary Clinton in Minnesota. All 435 U.S. House members and one-third of the Senate are running for re-election in November. Democrats need to win two Senate seats to seize control of that chamber, while they need to win 23 House seats to take control, which would disrupt or stall much of Trump's policy agenda and increase congressional oversight and investigation of the administration.

Vukmir emerged victorious after a bitter primary fight with Kevin Nicholson, a U.S. Marine Corps veteran backed by conservatives such as Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Steve Bannon, the former Trump political adviser. The primary contest saw each candidate accusing the other of a lack of loyalty to Trump.

"It's now critical for our party to unify behind Leah so we can achieve our ultimate goal: defeating Tammy Baldwin," U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan said in a statement congratulating Vukmir.

Charlie Sykes, a longtime Republican commentator in Wisconsin, said the bruising primary could help Baldwin retain her seat, a setback for Republicans who once considered her a top target. "The biggest winner is Baldwin," Sykes told a news source. "It was an unnecessarily nasty intramural fight."

Republicans also selected Bryan Steil, a former aide to Ryan, to replace Ryan in his seat in southeast Wisconsin. Steil is projected to defeat Paul Nehlen, an avowed white nationalist, to be the Republican nominee. Steil will face Randy Bryce, an ironworker known on Twitter as "Iron Stache," in November in a suburban Milwaukee district that Democrats covet.

In Wisconsin, Democrats chose Tony Evers, the state schools chief, to challenge incumbent Republican Governor Scott Walker, who is seeking a third term. The outcome of Walker's challenge will be closely monitored, as another measure of Democratic intensity.

"A really strong Democratic turnout in November could cause him to lose," said Ford O'Connell, a Republican strategist in Washington. State Democrats will be motivated by their opposition to Trump in trying to bring down Walker, he said.

In Minnesota, state senator Karen Housley was picked to take on Democratic incumbent U.S. Senator Tina Smith, appointed after former Senator Al Franken resigned last year amid sexual harassment allegations. Primaries in two House districts representing regions affected by Trump's trade policies could play a significant role in determining control of Congress.

Former state representative Joe Radinovich outlasted a group of Democrats in an open-seat race in the state's northeastern mining region, known as the Iron Range, which has seen some benefits from the administration's steel and aluminum tariffs. Trump has campaigned in the district for the Republican favorite, Pete Stauber.

In the state's south, Republican Jim Hagedorn defeated Carla Nelson in a district the party hopes to seize after the Democratic incumbent, Tim Walz, ran for governor. Farmers in the district have complained about harm from retaliatory tariffs by China and elsewhere.

Walz won the Democratic nomination for governor, while former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty lost to Republican Jeff Johnson, ending Pawlenty's political comeback bid.

Beyond the Upper Midwest, Connecticut and Vermont also held primaries on Tuesday. In Vermont, unofficial results showed Christine Hallquist as the first openly transgender person to win a major U.S. party nomination for statewide office in the Democratic governor's primary. Senator Bernie Sanders, the former presidential candidate, easily won Vermont's Democratic Senate primary. However, Sanders, as before, is expected to decline the nomination and run as an independent.

Title: Republican Party Faces Uncertain Future as Trump Gains Momentum Toward Nomination

Article:

The Republican Party is experiencing a period of uncertainty as Donald Trump's strong performance in the Super Tuesday primaries puts him on a path toward the Republican presidential nomination. Hillary Clinton's victories on the Democratic side all but secure her own nomination.

The Republican establishment is grappling with the Trump phenomenon, which they view as a hostile takeover of their party. Trump's message and his appeal to voters, many of whom are longtime Republicans and others who are new to politics, are driving this change.

Republican strategist Ford O'Connell notes that the party's conservative message on social issues, particularly its hostility to same-sex marriage, is falling out of favor. Views on healthcare are varied, and neoconservative foreign policy faces growing resistance.

Trump's positions on free trade agreements, his praise for Planned Parenthood, and his incendiary rhetoric, particularly on immigration, are anathema to Republican orthodoxy.

John Pitney Jr., a political scientist at Claremont McKenna College, suggests that a Republican Party with Trump as the nominee will be "the party of left-out white people." He acknowledges that economically challenged white people deserve attention but argues that alienating large segments of the electorate, such as Hispanics and African Americans, is not a recipe for a successful party in the long term.

The party's image of intolerance was highlighted by House Speaker Paul Ryan's comments on Tuesday, where he distanced the party from Trump's association with white supremacists. Ryan, like most Republican elected officials, has pledged to support the GOP's nominee, but some, like freshman Sen. Ben Sasse of Nebraska and retiring Rep. Scott Rigell of Virginia, have publicly rejected Trump.

In the race for the nomination, Marco Rubio scored his first victory of the cycle in the Minnesota caucuses, and he is expected to stay in the race, aiming to win the Florida primary on March 15. Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who has yet to win a contest, is polling well in the Ohio primary, also on March 15.

Trump won seven out of 11 contests on Tuesday, and Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas won three, including his home state. Cruz's victories position him as Trump's main opponent going forward, but his hard-line, no-compromise style has alienated most of his Republican colleagues in the Senate.

Some Republicans hope for no candidate to reach the Republican National Convention with the majority of delegates required to secure the nomination, in which case party leaders would hope to win over enough delegates for a more electable candidate, likely Rubio. However, Trump's momentum makes it difficult for Cruz or any other candidate to knock him off his path to the nomination.

The exit polls from Super Tuesday contests reveal that among voters who did not support Trump, three-fourths said they would not be satisfied with him as the nominee. This raises questions about whether such voters would turn out or vote for the Democrat, potentially posing a challenge for the Republican Party in the general election.

Title: U.S.-China Trade Tensions Escalate, Fueling Market Volatility and Fear of Reciprocal Tariffs

Article:

The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted by over 700 points on Friday, amid growing concerns of a trade war between the United States and China. The White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, attributed the tit-for-tat tariffs imposed by the world's largest two economies to years of Chinese policies. The Dow recovered slightly before the end of trading, closing with a loss of 572 points.

The Trump administration maintains that there is no trade war, with White House chief economic advisor Larry Kudlow insisting that the actions are an attempt to address some of the wrongs regarding China's intellectual property practices. However, trade groups in Washington and GOP lawmakers have expressed alarm at the back-and-forth.

President Trump announced a possible expansion of U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods by $100 billion, following previous announcements of $50 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods and $3 billion in tariffs on aluminum and steel imports. This escalation has caused concern among industries such as the auto repair industry and the chemical industry, which could face retaliation from China.

Republicans are struggling to find a middle ground between Trump's aggressive trade stance and the party's free trade orthodoxy. Some, like Rep. Bill Flores, have defended the president's actions, stating that while they would not have implemented the tariffs in the same manner, they are seeing results. Others, such as Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch, have been more critical, expressing concern about self-inflicted harm to the U.S. economy.

The expanding list of potential tariffs opens the possibility for China to find new ways to retaliate against the U.S., such as manipulating its currency, selling off U.S. debt, or making it difficult for U.S. financial, travel, and other services industries to operate in China. The Asian giant has already criticized Trump's actions and has sought to close ranks with the European Union, which has also criticized Trump over steel and aluminum tariffs.

The European Commission has reiterated its belief in free and fair trade, stating that it is one of the most powerful engines for growth, supporting millions of jobs, and contributing to prosperity. China, for its part, has called for a clear stance against protectionism and the preservation of the rules-based multilateral trade order.

Title: Debbie Wasserman Schultz Announces Support for Iran Nuclear Deal

Article:

Florida Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, has announced her support for the Iran nuclear deal. In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union," she stated that she would vote in favor of the agreement, citing a lack of evidence that alternative plans, such as economic pressure, would be effective in forcing Iran back to the negotiating table.

Wasserman Schultz expressed some concerns but concluded that the deal would keep Iran years away from becoming a nuclear threshold state and allow for a greater focus on Iran's terrorist activities. She stated that intelligence officials have assured her that Iran will not be allowed to use its own inspectors to certify compliance with the deal.

Last week, President Obama secured enough votes in the Senate to implement the pact. Wasserman Schultz, who represents a largely Jewish constituency and is Jewish herself, also announced her support for the deal in an op-ed in the Miami Herald, stating that it was the most difficult decision she has had to make in her nearly 23 years in elected office.

In an emotional statement on CNN, Wasserman Schultz, who is Jewish, emphasized her commitment to ensuring Israel's existence. She stated that she is confident that her decision-making process will ensure Israel's continued existence.

The White House is closely watching Wasserman Schultz's decision, as she is a leading Jewish lawmaker and the head of the DNC. Wasserman Schultz stated that she spoke with President Obama on Saturday night, and he assured her that she would be part of a group in Congress working with the administration to develop an enhanced security package for Israel, as well as "tightening our ability to enforce this deal."

Many Jewish lawmakers have struggled in recent weeks over whether or not to support the deal. Vice President Joe Biden met with Jewish leaders in South Florida last week, urging them to support the deal, which he said would put the U.S. in a stronger position to address concerns from Israel and the Arab states about Iran's behavior in the region.

Former Vice President Dick Cheney criticized the Iran agreement on Fox News Sunday, calling it a "major, major defeat" and comparing it to the appeasement of Nazi Germany in the lead-up to World War II. Former Secretary of State Colin Powell, on the other hand, called the Iran agreement "a pretty good deal" on NBC's "Meet the Press" Sunday.

Opponents of the deal argue that it would leave open a lane for Iran to rev up its nuclear program in the future, but Powell stated that Iran has been on a superhighway for the last 10 years to create a nuclear weapon with no speed limit. He called the changes agreed to under the deal "remarkable."

Title: Kavanaugh's Confirmation to the Supreme Court Appears Imminent, Despite Democratic Opposition

Article:

The confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court of the United States appears to be nearly inevitable, barring any last-minute scandalous revelations. Attracting a couple of Republican senators to vote against the judge seems increasingly remote, with no indications from Maine Republican Sen. Susan Collins or Alaska's Sen. Lisa Murkowski that they will oppose Kavanaugh.

Democratic activists have been urging Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer to pressure West Virginia's Sen. Joe Manchin, Sen. Heidi Heitkamp from North Dakota, and Indiana's Sen. Joe Donnelly to vote against Kavanaugh. However, such acts of self-sacrifice would be unlikely in today's Senate, where careers are not easily discarded. Even if Schumer could persuade these Democrats to oppose Kavanaugh, the party would likely suffer significant losses in the upcoming midterm elections.

The concerns of Democratic senators about potential rulings on issues such as Roe v. Wade and the Affordable Care Act are legitimate, but the unpredictable nature of the Supreme Court's chemistry makes it difficult to predict the court's future direction. The possibility of Chief Justice John Roberts adjusting his behavior to prevent a sharp turn to the right is a speculative scenario.

The defeat of three vulnerable Democratic senators could significantly weaken the Democratic party's influence in the Senate and hinder their ability to thwart President Trump's legislative agenda. If the Democrats are able to hold down their losses in the worst midterm environment in decades, it would constrain the Republican majority. However, the loss of a handful of Democrats would diminish the party's ability to use the filibuster to gain concessions from the majority on legislation.

Ross K. Baker, a distinguished professor of political science at Rutgers University and a member of ███'s Board of Contributors, suggests that the pressure on Sen. Schumer from rank-and-file Democrats to scuttle the Trump agenda in Congress has been fierce and unrelenting. However, it is important for Schumer to manage the expectations of party loyalists and dissuade them from pressing for objectives that are unattainable, such as the defeat of the Kavanaugh nomination. The potential loss of seats could cost the party its current influence and move it further away from a future majority.

Title: Trump's Recent Statements Face Fact-Checking Scrutiny

Article:

In the past week, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has faced scrutiny for several statements made during his speeches in Pennsylvania and Scotland. Fact-checking organizations have found numerous instances of exaggerations, contradictions, and half-truths in Trump's statements on various topics, including trade, the founding fathers, and his own campaign.

1. Trade Policies:
During a speech in Monessen, Pennsylvania, Trump stated, "When subsidized foreign steel is dumped into our markets, threatening our factories, the politicians do nothing." In 2015, five U.S. steelmakers complained about Chinese producers receiving government subsidies and flouting import rules. This year, the Obama administration imposed a 522% tariff on Chinese companies, and the U.S. International Trade Commission announced an investigation into aluminum imports, hinting at more tariffs on the Chinese.

2. U.S. Trade Deficit:
Trump also claimed, "Today, we import nearly $800bn more in goods than we export." While the U.S.'s 2015 deficit on goods was indeed $762.6bn, the U.S. is a service economy, and last year it had a surplus in its service trade. The overall trade deficit was about $500bn due to the exports of services and other market forces, according to the Census Bureau.

3. Founding Fathers and Trade:
Trump asserted, "Our founding fathers understood trade much better than our current politicians." While the founding fathers may have understood trade better than at least one current politician, they understood it in a world of slavery, plantations, and New England shipping. Even then, Trump's trade ideas would not have necessarily been welcome, as the founders had vicious disagreements over trade.

4. US-Korea Free Trade Agreement:
Trump stated, "It was also Hillary Clinton, as secretary of state, who shoved us into a job-killing deal with South Korea in 2012." In 2007, Republican George W. Bush signed the US-Korea Free Trade Agreement, but Congress refused to ratify it for nearly five years. Barack Obama warned of employment consequences from the deal in 2008, but argued it would boost the shattered economy after he became president. Clinton opposed the deal as a candidate but supported it as Obama's secretary of state.

5. Immigration and Refugee Policies:
Trump has contradicted his proposal to ban Muslims from entering the U.S. over several months. In December, he proposed a "total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is going on." In May, he called that "just a suggestion." On June 25, he said the ban would apply to regions "where there is a proven history of terrorism" and "Islamic terror"; on June 25, he said British Muslims "wouldn't bother" him but those from "terror countries" would; and then on June 27, his campaign claimed nothing had changed.

6. Loan to Campaign:
Trump's statement, "Mr. Trump has fully extinguished ( terminated ) this loan per his commitment. Therefore, he has personally invested in excess of $50 million dollars in the future of our country," regarding a large loan he made to his campaign, has been called into question. As of Friday, the Federal Election Commission confirmed to fact-checking organizations that it has no record of Trump converting loans to donations.

7. Disavowal of Republican Leader:
Trump's statement, "I know nothing about him," regarding former Republican Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson, contradicts his 2008 interview with CNN, where he praised Paulson. Trump's frequent claims of ignorance when confronted with uncomfortable topics have been noted.

Title: Major Anti-Trump Groups Focus on Indiana to Prevent Republican Front-Runner's Victory

Article:

Major anti-Trump groups are channeling their funds into Indiana, viewing the state as crucial in preventing Donald Trump, the Republican presidential front-runner, from securing the party's nomination. Doug Sachtleben, spokesman for the well-funded anti-Trump super-PAC, Club for Growth Action (CFGA), stated that the group has already spent at least $1.7 million in Indiana, primarily on statewide television advertising opposing Trump.

Sachtleben expressed confidence in Ted Cruz's ability to win Indiana, stating, "We think Ted Cruz must win and will win Indiana." The CFGA's Indiana ad, titled "Math," argues that a vote for John Kasich divides the Republican field, helping Trump.

Trump's rivals are attempting to use the delegate process to their advantage, aiming to prevent Trump from winning 1,237 delegates in the state contests. This strategy could force a contested Republican National Convention, which is currently the only viable chance for either Cruz or Kasich to secure the nomination.

Sachtleben noted that the Kasich team has, in essence, endorsed the message of the CFGA ad in Indiana, with the understanding that to stop Trump in Indiana, voters should vote for Cruz.

Three other major Republican-aligned anti-Trump groups are also focusing on Indiana to halt Trump's momentum. Our Principles PAC, an anti-Trump group funded by GOP mega-donors including billionaire hedge fund manager Paul Singer and the Ricketts family, is spending at least $1 million in Indiana opposing Trump. Katie Packer, the group's chairwoman, declined to disclose the exact amount of spending but stated that they have a comprehensive television, mail, and digital campaign in place, similar to their approach in Wisconsin.

Indiana holds a winner-take-most contest, with the statewide winner receiving 30 delegates, and 27 more being awarded through winner-take-all contests in each congressional district. Trump currently has 987 delegates, according to the Associated Press delegate tracker, and needs fewer than 50 percent of the remaining delegates to secure the nomination. Both Cruz and Kasich are mathematically unable to reach that mark without a contested convention.

A Trump victory in Indiana could leave him needing as little as 43 percent of the remaining delegates, and a total loss would leave him needing 56 percent. While Trump is seen as a lock for New Jersey's 51 winner-take-all delegates, the remaining contests present few options for Trump to accumulate delegates outside of Indiana and California.

The fervent hope among the anti-Trump movement is that Trump's delegate accumulation can be slowed in Indiana and ultimately stopped short in the June 7 California primary. If Cruz and the anti-Trump forces can keep Trump from the 1,237 mark and convince unbound delegates not to push him over that threshold on the convention's first ballot, it would reset the contest. Cruz has been successful in winning the loyalties of delegates, and after the first ballot, the majority of them would be free to vote their conscience.

Packer stated that Our Principles PAC is targeting three states in particular: Indiana, Nebraska, and California.

Title: Federal Government's Enforcement of Gun Laws Under Scrutiny

Article:

The ongoing debate over gun violence and gun control in the United States has taken a new turn, with the federal government launching a campaign to discourage individuals from purchasing firearms on behalf of felons who are legally prohibited from doing so. The campaign, which is being advertised through radio and billboard ads, urges potential gun buyers to "don't lie for the other guy."

This campaign comes amidst a push in Washington for sweeping new gun control laws, including universal background checks and a ban on military-style rifles and large ammunition magazines. However, recent studies have shown that the Obama administration has not enforced many existing gun laws effectively.

According to a study by Syracuse University, gun crime prosecutions hit a decade low in 2011, down 40 percent from their peak under President George W. Bush in 2004. This has prompted 23 House Republicans to call on President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder to prosecute more people for gun-related crimes.

The Syracuse study found that the number of federal weapons prosecutions fell from about 11,000 in 2004 to about 6,000 under the Obama administration in 2011, and then ticked up to 7,770 in 2012.

The GOP letter also cited data from the National Criminal Justice Reference Service (NCJRS), which found that of 6 million Americans who applied to buy a gun in 2010, less than 2 percent—or 76,000—were denied. Of those, the ATF referred 4,732 cases for prosecution. Of them, just 44 were prosecuted, and only 13 were punished for lying or buying a gun illegally.

Former Attorney General Alberto Gonzales criticized the current administration's approach, stating, "If the prosecution of people lying on forms is really a priority for the president, then all he has to do is say, 'I want my federal law enforcement officials to prosecute these kinds of cases.' Obviously, there is a different level of priority given to these type of crimes in this administration compared with other administrations."

Justice Department sources argue that the Attorney General has finite resources and prefers to prosecute prohibited persons who have obtained guns illegally, rather than those who just lie on the form, which is also a crime. They also argue that "lie and try" cases have little jury appeal, as they are essentially about lying on a form where the person was ultimately denied the ability to purchase the gun.

Prosecutions for making a false statement when buying a gun are down 29 percent from five years ago, while prosecutions for illegal possession are down 14 percent, according to federal data. Penalties are also light, with a third of those charged with gun crimes serving no jail at all, and those who do typically only serving one to four years of a possible 10-year sentence for lying or illegally possessing a firearm.

Republican Rep. Scott Rigell of Virginia stated, "I think when we punish the bad guys we are protecting the good guys." He is one of four lawmakers proposing a bill to make straw purchases a federal crime and to increase the penalty from 10 to 20 years.

Title: Gitmo Transfers to Resume This Weekend, Pentagon Confirms

Article:

The United States Department of Defense will begin transferring two detainees from the Guantanamo Bay Detention Facility this weekend, according to a U.S. official speaking to Fox News. This follows the largest transfer of detainees from the U.S. Naval Station at Guantanamo, Cuba in January, which saw the transfer of ten detainees at once.

The upcoming transfer cannot occur all at once due to a legal requirement for the Pentagon to notify Congress 30 days before any transfers. The first notification was sent to Congress in early March, with a second notification made in mid-April. The first transfer of two detainees is set to take place this weekend, with the remainder expected in mid-May. In total, approximately a dozen detainees will be transferred in the next two rounds.

As of now, there are 91 detainees remaining at Guantanamo. Thirty-five have been cleared for transfer to other countries. The Pentagon spokesman, Cmdr. Gary Ross, declined to confirm the transfer of any Gitmo detainees beginning this weekend, stating, "I do not have a timeline on when particular detainees will be transferred from Guantanamo. However, the Administration is committed to reducing the detainee population and to closing the detention facility responsibly."

In the past, the Pentagon only confirmed detainee transfers once they are completed. The detainees are flown on U.S. military aircraft to their third-party nation. However, there have been concerns regarding the recidivism of some detainees following their release. In a recent statement, the Pentagon's point man for Gitmo, Paul Lewis, revealed that some detainees transferred from the prison have in fact re-joined the fight and, in some cases, have been involved in actions that led to the loss of American lives.

Congressman Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., questioned Lewis about the number of lives lost due to Gitmo detainees, to which Lewis responded, "Unfortunately, there have been Americans that have died because of GITMO detainees." The Pentagon later issued a statement stating that only 5% of detainees who have been released have returned to the battlefield during the Obama administration.

In January, the Defense Department released new statistics showing that the number of former Gitmo detainees suspected of re-engaging in terrorism doubled from six to 12. Senator John McCain has refuted the administration's statistics, stating that he believes more released Gitmo detainees return to the battlefield, putting more American lives at risk.

Last month, the Pentagon submitted a plan to transfer those detainees not eligible for transfer overseas to American prisons in Colorado, Kansas, or South Carolina. The plan was immediately rejected by Congress, who passed a law forbidding the transfer of any Gitmo detainees to the United States.

In response to the ongoing controversy, President Obama, flanked by his defense secretary and vice president, vowed once again to close the prison. "It is viewed as a stain on our broader record of upholding the highest standards of rule of law," Mr. Obama said. "This is about closing a chapter in our history."

However, critics in Congress have demanded a plan for handling ISIS detainees, following the recent killing of the group's second in command by a 200-man special operations task force. The U.S. military has no plans to hold captured Islamic State operatives for more than a month before turning them over to the Iraqi government. The lack of a well-defined policy for handling captured ISIS terrorists is raising concerns on Capitol Hill.

Title: FBI Director Robert Mueller Faces Tough Questions on IRS Probe, Surveillance Programs, and Leaks

Article:

In a heated hearing on Thursday, FBI Director Robert Mueller faced tough questions from lawmakers regarding various ongoing investigations, including the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) probe into the targeting of Tea Party and conservative groups. Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) grilled Mueller for not providing specific details about the IRS investigation, stating that it has been the biggest story in the country and that the FBI's lack of information is not typical for ongoing investigations.

Mueller repeatedly declined to answer Jordan's questions, citing the ongoing nature of the investigation or stating that he would have to get back to the lawmakers with answers. When Jordan asked who the lead investigator was, Mueller responded, "Off the top of my head, no."

The hearing also touched on the federal government's surveillance programs, the Benghazi scandal, and the Boston Marathon bombings. Mueller defended the government's collection of millions of U.S. phone records, emails, and other information as vital to the nation's national security. He argued that law enforcement must stay a step ahead of criminals and terrorists while still heeding the civil liberties of Americans.

Mueller also testified that the government's controversial surveillance programs complied "in full with U.S. law and with basic rights guaranteed under the Constitution." However, Judiciary Committee Chairman John Conyers Jr. expressed skepticism, stating that by Mueller's interpretation, it would be an "anything and everything goes" situation.

The Justice Department revealed last month that it had secretly gathered emails of James Rosen, a correspondent for Fox News, and phone records of The Associated Press in an effort to crack down on leakers of classified information. The department later acknowledged that Attorney General Eric Holder was on board with a search warrant for Rosen's personal emails, obtained after federal officials accused him in an affidavit of being a likely criminal "co-conspirator" under the Espionage Act.

In the past week, a 29-year-old contractor leaked National Security Agency documents on the agency's collection of millions of U.S. phone records and the NSA's collection of emails and other information that people transmit online to and from foreign citizens. This has sparked a national debate over whether the Obama administration, in its efforts to thwart terrorism, has overstepped by using intrusive surveillance methods.

Rep. Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.), the committee's chairman, stated that when it comes to national security leaks, it's important to balance the need to protect secrecy with the need to let the news media do its job. Goodlatte also mentioned that the committee planned to find out more about the status of what the congressman called the FBI's "stalled investigation" into the attack in Benghazi, Libya that killed four Americans, including the U.S. ambassador.

As for the Boston Marathon bombings, committee members want to know whether there was a breakdown in information-sharing between federal agencies, preventing the FBI from thwarting the explosions that killed three people and injured more than 260.

Title: Supreme Court Decisions Impact State Voting Laws Ahead of Election Day

Article:

In the lead-up to the upcoming election, several significant decisions regarding state voting laws have been made by the U.S. Supreme Court. Here's a recap of the recent legal activity and its implications for voters:

1. Arkansas: The Arkansas Supreme Court has struck down the state's voter ID law, finding that requiring voters to present a photo ID imposes a new qualification for voting, violating the state's constitution. Consequently, the voter ID law will not be in effect for the November elections.

2. Ohio: The U.S. Supreme Court voted 5-4 to block a lower court ruling that would have prevented Ohio from shortening its early-voting period. This decision extends the early-voting period by a week, starting on Oct. 6, and eliminates early voting during evening hours and on Sunday, Oct. 26. However, early voting will still be available in Ohio on the weekend before Election Day.

3. North Carolina: The U.S. Supreme Court stayed a federal appeals court decision to block part of the state's new voting law. The appeals court had ruled that two provisions—eliminating same-day voter registration and prohibiting the counting of ballots cast in the wrong precinct—should not go into effect this year, while the law is being challenged.

4. Wisconsin: The U.S. Supreme Court blocked a federal appeals court ruling that had allowed the state's voter ID law to go into effect this year. As a result, Wisconsin voters do not have to show a photo ID at the polls.

5. Texas: Civil rights groups have asked the U.S. Supreme Court to block the state's new voter ID law—one of the strictest in the nation—from remaining in effect this year, while the law is being challenged. A decision is expected soon.

6. Arizona and Kansas: A case involving a requirement by Arizona and Kansas that voters show proof of citizenship when they register to vote is pending before a federal appeals court. If a decision is not made before Election Day, voters in those states who used the federal registration form and have not shown proof of citizenship will not be allowed to vote in state and local elections.

The Supreme Court has shown reluctance to allow major voting changes to be put in place right before an election. However, it has not yet ruled on the constitutionality of these laws, which is expected to happen after the election and more likely next year.

Title: Car Manufacturers Pivot Production to Aid in Coronavirus Response

Article:

In response to calls from governments worldwide, several car manufacturers are repurposing their facilities to produce personal protective equipment (PPE) and ventilators to aid in the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

On Monday, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) announced plans to convert one of its plants in China to produce approximately one million masks per month. The company aims to initiate production in the coming weeks, as stated in an email by FCA's CEO, Mike Manley.

Other major car companies, such as General Motors (GM), Ford, Tesla, Nissan, and Formula 1 teams in the UK, have pledged their support to offer resources for the production of ventilators. Ford, in collaboration with GE Healthcare and 3M, is working on designing modified respirators and ventilators using fans, batteries, and other parts typically used in cars.

The companies have not provided a set timeline for the delivery of the products, but Ford has already started producing transparent face shields for hospital staff, with the first 1,000 set for delivery at three Detroit-area hospitals this week. The company expects to produce about 75,000 of such shields this week.

US President Donald Trump tweeted on Sunday, "Ford, General Motors, and Tesla are being given the go-ahead to make ventilators and other metal products, FAST! Go for it auto execs, let's see how good you are?" The tweet followed the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) announcing reduced barriers in the medical device approval process to expedite the production of ventilators.

According to US Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar, medical device makers can more easily make changes to existing products to address current manufacturing limitations or supply shortages. Other manufacturers, such as carmakers, can more easily repurpose production lines to increase supply.

However, some experts have warned that carmakers may find it challenging to switch production due to the highly specific materials and components required to build ventilators, as well as the specialized know-how needed. Jens Hallek, head of ventilator manufacturer Hamilton Medical, told Wired that the materials and components needed to build a ventilator are "highly specific" and require "specialized know-how."

Former US Defense Department officials told the Washington Post that it could take more than a year for carmakers or aerospace factories to start making ventilators. Meanwhile, Tesla CEO Elon Musk said he had bought 1,255 FDA-approved ventilators from China and had them shipped to Los Angeles.

Last week, Formula 1 teams in the UK said they hoped to find "a tangible outcome in the next few days" to help increase the supply of medical equipment. Working with the government and health authorities, F1 said it had experts in design, technology, and production capabilities who could assist.

Nissan is part of a consortium, including sports car firm McLaren and aerospace company Meggitt, looking to develop a new medical ventilator. "We are fully focused on the project," McLaren said in a statement, but warned of the "limited time and scale of the challenge."

Indian billionaire Anand Mahindra said his company, The Mahindra Group, would begin work immediately to explore how its factories could make ventilators. The conglomerate is the world's largest tractor maker and India's biggest electric vehicle manufacturer, according to its website.

Title: Interest Rates on Stafford Student Loans Double as Congress Fails to Reach Agreement

Article:

Interest rates on federally subsidized Stafford student loans have doubled overnight, rising from 3.4 percent to 6.8 percent following Congress's failure to reach a deal on the matter. The increase, which could potentially cost the average college student an additional $2,600, according to the Congress's Joint Economic Committee, is a result of the legislative impasse.

The debate surrounding student loan interest rates has been a contentious issue, with Democrats advocating for maintaining low interest rates to support poor and middle-class students in their pursuit of higher education. Republicans, on the other hand, have proposed linking student loans to the financial markets, as opposed to having Congress set federal lending rates. President Obama's budget for this year includes a market-based approach, a proposal that has faced opposition from fellow Democrats.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell's spokesman, Don Stewart, expressed hope that President Obama would be able to persuade Democrats to support a bipartisan effort to assist students. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, however, has expressed skepticism about tying loan rates to the 10-year treasury note yield, stating that such a proposal would not pass the Senate without stronger protections for students and parents.

Adam Jentleson, a spokesman for Reid, stated last week that a proposal to link loan rates to the 10-year treasury note yield could not pass the Senate and that Democrats are working in good faith to reach a compromise, but are being obstructed by the Republicans' insistence on reducing the deficit at the expense of students and middle-class families.

Senate Democrats have indicated that they may consider voting on a one-year extension of the current interest rates on July 10, following a recess for the 4th of July holiday. However, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has expressed a preference for including a comprehensive student loan measure in a long-range law governing colleges and universities. Warren stated that a one-year patch would provide the necessary time to address the issue comprehensively.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Expresses Uncertainty Over Sequester's Economic Impact

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has expressed uncertainty about the impact of the forced spending cuts, known as the sequester, that began taking effect on Friday. In a recent op-ed, Boehner argued that the sequester could threaten "U.S. national security, thousands of jobs, and more."

During an interview that aired Sunday on NBC's "Meet the Press," Boehner stated, "I don't know whether it's going to hurt the economy or not." He further added, "I don't think anyone quite understands how the sequester is really going to work."

Boehner and President Barack Obama were among those who issued dire warnings about the $85 billion in cuts that are now supposed to take place over the next seven months, the remainder of the fiscal year. Both sides escalated their rhetoric in the weeks leading up to the sequester deadline, March 1, in an attempt to build pressure on the other side to compromise and reach a deal to avoid the cuts.

During the interview, Boehner was asked if he had been exaggerating when discussing the consequences of the spending cuts before the deadline. He responded, "I am concerned about its impact on our economy and its impact on our military. Listen, we've known about this problem for 16 months." Boehner blamed Democrats and President Obama for not acting to address the issue.

President Obama, during a press conference at the White House on Friday, did not sound as pessimistic about the impact of the cuts as he and his administration had before the deadline. He stated, "What's important to understand is that not everyone will feel the pain of these cuts right away. The pain, though, will be real. Beginning this week, many middle-class families will have their lives disrupted in significant ways."

When asked if the president had been exaggerating his claims about the sequester, Boehner pointed to the example of Education Secretary Arne Duncan stating that teachers in West Virginia were already being laid off because of the spending cuts. Duncan's claim has since been debunked. Boehner added, "There's a lot of questions about how the White House is handling the communications on this."

Title: Study Reveals Importance of Blood Sugar Control for Type 2 Diabetes Patients with COVID-19

Article:

A new study published in the journal Cell Metabolism has provided evidence that people with Type 2 diabetes (T2D) who maintain control over their blood sugar levels will fare better if they contract the novel coronavirus. The study, which examined a cohort of 7,336 COVID-19 patients with or without T2D from 19 hospitals in Hubei Province, China, found that those with well-controlled blood sugar who had COVID-19 were less likely to die than those whose blood glucose was poorly controlled.

The data showed that people admitted to the hospital with COVID-19 and T2D required more medical interventions, despite these interventions, they also had significantly higher mortality (7.8 percent versus 2.7 percent), as well as a greater incidence of multiple organ injury. However, those with well-controlled blood sugar who had COVID-19 were less likely to die than those whose blood glucose was poorly controlled. Furthermore, those with well-managed T2D also received fewer medical interventions, including supplemental oxygen and/or ventilation, and had fewer health complications.

"We were surprised to see such favorable outcomes in the well-controlled blood glucose group among patients with COVID-19 and pre-existing Type 2 diabetes," said senior study author Hongliang Li, at Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University. The study found that controlling blood glucose well may act as an effective auxiliary approach to improve the prognosis of patients with COVID-19 and preexisting diabetes.

Experts have identified risk factors for dying from COVID-19, including the prevalence of diabetes, obesity, and hypertension. The virus has devastated African-American and Hispanic communities in several states. Tracey Brown, president and CEO of the American Diabetes Association, stated that the alarming COVID-19 mortality rate in America's communities of color can be directly attributed to problems with health access and resources.

"In order to tackle America's systemic health inequity problem, we must meet those who are most at risk in their community. Greater accessibility and availability to COVID testing is critical in order to slow the rampant spread of COVID-19 in minority communities. When disadvantaged Americans' are forced by circumstance to delay testing, they risk dangerous health outcomes for themselves, their families, and their communities," Brown explained.

Overall, researchers offered a few core messages for those with diabetes: they should take extra precautions to avoid becoming infected with COVID-19 due to the higher risk of severe complications or dying after being infected, and those with diabetes should take extra care to keep their blood sugar under good control during the pandemic.

Title: Florida Becomes New Epicenter of COVID-19 Cases; Governor Signs Controversial Immigration Bill

Article:

Florida, currently, is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases, making it the new epicenter of the virus in the United States. As of July 6, the state has reported over 200,000 cases and more than 3,731 deaths. In South Florida, where cases are most concentrated, hospitals are reducing elective surgeries due to a lack of intensive-care unit beds for adults.

Governor Ron DeSantis signed SB 664, also known as the Verification of Employment Eligibility or E-Verify bill, into law on June 30. This bill requires businesses in Florida to use the E-Verify program to verify the employment eligibility of their workers, potentially discriminating against immigrants.

The signing of SB 664 occurred during a time when Florida was experiencing its first two coronavirus deaths and growing concerns about a spreading pandemic. Immigrant rights organizations warned that this bill would intimidate undocumented immigrants in the state and cause them to avoid contact with government institutions due to fear of being detained and deported.

Since assuming office, Governor DeSantis has been criticized for prioritizing immigration enforcement and playing political games during the pandemic. The state's unemployment website frequently goes down, and thousands of new cases of COVID-19 are reported each week. DeSantis has refused to take steps to mitigate the spread, such as closing non-essential businesses, a tactic that has helped bring the virus under control in other states.

"We're not going back, closing things," DeSantis said. "I don't think that's really what's driving it. People going to a business is not what's driving it. I think when you see the younger folks—I think a lot of it is more just social interactions, so that's natural."

DeSantis has also been criticized for his lack of commitment to encouraging people to stay home or wear masks. Instead, Florida Republicans are pushing for an economic restart in the middle of a pandemic that is overwhelming the healthcare system in South Florida.

Thomas Kennedy, a communications fellow for Community Change Action, tweeted about the situation in Florida, stating, "Every week, the website to file unemployment claims goes down. Every week, we have thousands of new cases of COVID-19 in the state. Every week, Floridians get to watch our governor do press conferences where he is clearly improvising, falsifying data, and blaming others for his failures."

November, and the opportunity to vote at the ballot box, cannot come fast enough, according to Kennedy.
